Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: BEfore I enter upon the matter of the Subject I have undertaken, I think my Self obliged to advertiÅ¿e you, That Gardening is not among us Moderns, what it was in the firÅ¿t Ages of the World. In thoÅ¿e early times 'tis probable, they knew no other Gardens than thoÅ¿e of Fruits and Legumes, which we now call Fruit and Kitchin-Gardens; whereas in our Days, there are Å¿everal other Å¿orts beÅ¿ides them, Å¿ome being for Parterres and Flowers, Å¿ome for NurÅ¿eries, Å¿ome only for plain Gardens for Common UÅ¿e, and others for Rare and Medicinal Plants, &c.

So great a multiplicity of different Å¿orts of Gardens, affording no leÅ¿s diverÅ¿ity of employments for Gard'ners, in proceÅ¿s of time, introduced Å¿everal ClaÅ¿Å¿es of them; Å¿ome being Å¿imply called Gard'ners, others taking the quality of FloriÅ¿ts, and others well deÅ¿erving the Title of BotaniÅ¿ts, and others being named, Verbatim. MarÅ¿h Gard'ners. Market Gard'ners, beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e that apply themÅ¿elves only to the raiÅ¿ing and maintaining of NurÅ¿eries, for which there wants yet a particular Term, unleÅ¿s we Å¿hould call them NurÅ¿ery Gard'ners.
In the explication of the Original, and eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment of which Å¿everal Ranks of Gard'ners, I think it will not be impertinent to beÅ¿tow a few Lines, before we paÅ¿s further.

My Opinion in this Matter, is, That the FirÅ¿t Man having been Created in a Garden, and received Orders after his TranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion, to till the Earth, The Original of the DiverÅ¿ity of Gardens. Ex ea vives in laboribus omnibus diebus vitae tuae. GeneÅ¿. cap. v. and to get his Maintenance out of it by the Sweat of his Brows. It follows from thence, that one of the chiefeÅ¿t Employments, both of HimÅ¿elf and his firÅ¿t DeÅ¿cendants, was to apply themÅ¿elves to the culture of Fruits and Legumes; that being then the Function which alone Å¿upplyed Humane Kind, with all the neceÅ¿Å¿aries of Life. And indeed the Ground Å¿o tilled, did it not conÅ¿iÅ¿t of true Fruit and Kitchin-Gardens? And conÅ¿equently, becauÅ¿e in thoÅ¿e firÅ¿t Ages, no other Gardens were known but Å¿uch, there could be no other Gard'ners neither, but thoÅ¿e which govern'd them, who may on that account, be juÅ¿tly eÅ¿teemed the firÅ¿t of the whole Order of Gard'ners. For the Patriarchs properly Å¿peaking, were thoÅ¿e firÅ¿t Fruit and Kitchin-Gard'ners, and continued to perform that Function, till being diverted by their Application to the Invention of Arts, they were obliged to make uÅ¿e of the Service of Å¿ome principal DomeÅ¿tick to help them in their Gardens, who diÅ¿dained not to take the Name of that we commonly underÅ¿tand by the Term of Gard'ner.

But in the Ages following, as Å¿oon as Men thought they had made a Å¿ufficient proviÅ¿ion for their NeceÅ¿Å¿ities, and there begun to be eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd among them, Å¿ome diÅ¿tinction of Degrees and Fortunes; it hapned that the PleaÅ¿ures of the Sight and Smell, inÅ¿pired Å¿ome PerÅ¿ons with the CurioÅ¿ity to gratifie them with Flowers agreeable to one or both of thoÅ¿e SenÅ¿es, and accordingly, they begun to gather together Å¿ome of all thoÅ¿e Beautiful Plants which they obÅ¿erv'd Å¿o curiouÅ¿ly to enamel, and Å¿o admirably to perfume the Fields, where they were before confuÅ¿edly diÅ¿perÅ¿ed.

Thus was the Culture of Flowers begun indeed by Å¿uch Gard'ners as thoÅ¿e we juÅ¿t now mentioned, becauÅ¿e there were no others that could do it; but when Men had a mind to have Å¿o great a number of them, as is now practiÅ¿ed by way of Ornament, to the palaces of Great PerÅ¿ons, they begun to make particular Gardens of them which they called by a name
proper to a Flower Garden; and becauÅ¿e it was not poÅ¿Å¿ible for one Gard'ner at the Å¿ame time, to manage the Culture of Å¿o great a number of Fruits, Legumes, Flowers, Shrubs, &c. as were then required, there was a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing a Å¿econd ClaÅ¿s of Gard'ners, to eaÅ¿e thoÅ¿e of the firÅ¿t, which new Gard'ners were commonly named FloriÅ¿ts, to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h them from the others, which were called only plain Gard'ners. Flower Gard'ners or FloriÅ¿h.

I might tell you here by the way, that in thoÅ¿e times, Orange and Limon-trees, were perhaps look'd upon as Trees only for Flowers, juÅ¿t as the Myrtles, JeÅ¿Å¿imins, and LauruÅ¿tinus-Trees, &c. are now, the delicacy of Mens palates being not arrived to that degree of Luxury, to Å¿eek after Å¿o many Å¿orts of ReliÅ¿hes, Sawces, and Å¿eaÅ¿onings as now; Å¿o that 'tis very poÅ¿Å¿ible, that Limon and Orange-trees might then belong only to the Province of the FloriÅ¿ts.

But yet methinks it may be more probably affirmed, that in thoÅ¿e early times, thoÅ¿e Trees were not diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed from Fruit-trees, Å¿ince they are truly Å¿o; and therefore I am apt to believe, they were cultivated by the firÅ¿t Gard'ners only for their Fruit, and that the rather, becauÅ¿e the firÅ¿t Culture of the Earth being begun in hot and temperate Countries; the Å¿lavery and trouble of Boxes, and ConÅ¿ervatories, which in our Climates they cannot be without, were there of no uÅ¿e at all. It was therefore the rigour of the Winter SeaÅ¿on in cooler Regions that gave occaÅ¿ion to thoÅ¿e Inventions for the preÅ¿erving of thoÅ¿e plants that were of too tender a ConÅ¿titution to endure any great Cold, and then the Gard'ners of the Å¿econd ClaÅ¿s, who otherwiÅ¿e were not over-much taken up with the Culture of their Flowers, begun to be charged with the care of Orange and Limon-trees.

And further, the affectation of Men to gratiÅ¿ie the PleaÅ¿ure of their Eyes, inciting them to puÅ¿h on things to more and more Perfection; there came firÅ¿t into the minds of Noble PerÅ¿ons, Å¿ome conceits of Ranging thoÅ¿e Flowers with a little more agreeableneÅ¿s and Symmetry than was practiÅ¿ed by the firÅ¿t CurioÅ¿i's, which gave the firÅ¿t beginning to Parterres, or Flower-plots among FloriÅ¿ts, the firÅ¿t of which, in all probability, were but D ãâ¦ã pez. cut pieces Å¿haped after but a plain and groÅ¿s manner. But afterwards there were Å¿ome made of another faÅ¿hion, called Embroidery FaÅ¿hion, which were better contrived, and more delightful than the other, with which two Å¿orts, the World contented themÅ¿elves for Å¿everal Ages, Å¿o that Gardens were not accompanied with any other Beauties than thoÅ¿e, till in theÅ¿e laÅ¿t times, CurioÅ¿ity, Good Judgment, and Fancy, and Magnificence it Å¿elf being grown by little and little, to an extraordinary heighth, our Age which excells in all that Humane induÅ¿try is able to invent, has given in particular, by the ingenious skill of the famous Mr. Le NoÅ¿tre, the laÅ¿t perfection to this part of Gardening, which appears by Å¿o many Canals, Water-Works, CaÅ¿cades, Spouting Fountains, Labyrinths, Bowling Greens, TerraÅ¿es, &c. Ornaments indeed that are new, but Å¿uch as in earneÅ¿t, do wonderfully Å¿et off the natural Beauty of a Garden.

Having Å¿poken largely enough of the firÅ¿t and Å¿econd ClaÅ¿s of Gard'ners, Market or MarÅ¿h or Kitchin-Gard'ners. I proceed to the third, which is of thoÅ¿e which meddle neither with Fruits nor Flowers, but only with Kitchin-plants, whoÅ¿e Original might come from Å¿ome of our firÅ¿t Gard'ners, who being Å¿eated near Å¿ome very populous Cities, thought good to plant Å¿ome particular Gardens of Herbs, in hopes they might make a conÅ¿iderable gain of them in the publick Markets, and becauÅ¿e Grounds that were a little fat and moiÅ¿t Å¿eemed to them moÅ¿t proper, as well for the managing the Culture, as promoting the abundance, and bigneÅ¿s, and height of every Plant, they choÅ¿e low places to make thoÅ¿e kinds of Gardens in; nay, and perhaps Å¿uch places had been
formerly perfect Fenns or MarÅ¿hes, which were afterwards drained and laid dry, Å¿o that in Vulgar Speech, thoÅ¿e Å¿orts of Gard'ners were termed MarÅ¿h Gard'ners, which was as much as to Å¿ay, Gard'ners of dryed MarÅ¿hes or Fenns. And the vent of thoÅ¿e Herbs, proving by the Å¿ucceÅ¿s Å¿o profitable to thoÅ¿e that made it, Å¿tirred up Mens InduÅ¿try to multiply that Å¿ort of Gardens, even in very dry and Å¿andy places, and to Å¿upply with their frequent Waterings, and improvements with plenty of Dung, the defects of goodneÅ¿s in the Ground.

This Account which I here give, eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hes clearly three ClaÅ¿Å¿es of Gard'ners very different one from the other, without mentioning the other two ClaÅ¿Å¿es, viz. that of thoÅ¿e Gard'ners that mind only NurÅ¿eries, and the NurÅ¿ery Gard'nersâª BotaniÅ¿ts. other of thoÅ¿e that conÅ¿ine themÅ¿elves to the Culture of Rare and Medicinal Plants; and yet 'tis certain, there are Å¿ome very able and knowing PerÅ¿ons, that make it their PleaÅ¿ure and BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s too, to cultivate both of them, and to perform it with SucceÅ¿s and Reputation.

But as for my own inclination, it was always fixed to that Å¿ort of Gard'ning that was known in the infancy of the World, and practiÅ¿ed by our firÅ¿t Parents, Å¿o that for a long time, I have particularly applyed my Å¿elf to the Culture of Fruit, and Kitchin Gardens. And by this Application, having not only diÅ¿covered a great number of Beauties, but likewiÅ¿e a great many Faults that are committed in that Å¿ort of Gardening, I cannot but think my Å¿elf obliged before all things, to deÅ¿cribe them carefully, that they may be avoided.

I find then firÅ¿t, that commonly theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Gardens are not only unfurniÅ¿h'd with what they Å¿hould, and might eaÅ¿ily have for each Å¿eaÅ¿on of the Year, whether Fruits or Legumes, but that beÅ¿ides, they are ill contrived in the DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition and Ranking of the things contained in them.

Secondly, That there appears but little skill and capacity in moÅ¿t of the Gard'ners that cultivate them, and as little underÅ¿tanding in the MaÅ¿ters that employ them, to know how to direct them better; Å¿o that uÅ¿ually 'tis the fault both of the Owners, and their Gard'ners too, that thoÅ¿e Å¿orts of Gardens come Å¿hort of yielding either that PleaÅ¿ure or Profit they might otherwiÅ¿e do, and which was expected from them.

I will do what I can, to remedy thoÅ¿e great Failings, as well out of Obedience to the Orders I have received to that effect, as out of an inclination to pleaÅ¿ure others, an inclination which I dare affirm natural to me, and eÅ¿pecially in affairs of Gardening, which of it Agriculture is an Art truly noble, and capable to ennoble its worthy profeÅ¿Å¿ours; moÅ¿t of which are Å¿o generous and communicative, that they take an extreme PleaÅ¿ure in letting the whole World Å¿ee their Works; and when they happen tomake any proÅ¿perous experiment, they have no greater, joy than to declareto Å¿uch as have a mind to know them; the means they uÅ¿ed to Å¿ucceed in it, whereas commonly the humour of other ArtiÅ¿ts is to make a MyÅ¿tery of all things, and diÅ¿ingenuouÅ¿ly to keep to themÅ¿elves alone, the new DiÅ¿coveries they have made in their Art. For which purpoÅ¿e I undertook to compoÅ¿e and publiÅ¿h this TreatiÅ¿e, as thinking it might effectually be a uÅ¿eful work, if, as I believe, I may, and as I propoÅ¿e to my Å¿elf to do, I Å¿hall be Å¿o Å¿ucceÅ¿sful to give any aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance to ingenious Gentlemen to order their Gardens with a more advantageous Conduct, and at the Å¿ame time direct their Gard'ners to execute their MaÅ¿ter's Intentions better than hitherto, and conÅ¿equently by the means of a well managed Culture, how to reap thoÅ¿e advantages which the Earth beÅ¿tows only upon the Laborious and InduÅ¿trious. BeÅ¿ides which, three other principal reaÅ¿ons have obliged me to write.

The firÅ¿t was the little inÅ¿truction, I obÅ¿erved was to be gathered from Å¿o many Books, which have been made upon this Subject in all Ages, and in all Languages. 'Tis true, we have a great deal of Obligation, not only to Å¿ome Colum â¢ 'la, Cato, Varre, TheophraÅ¿tus, Xenoph â¢ n, Geopenna. ancient Authors, that have Å¿o Å¿olidly treated of general Agriculture, but likewiÅ¿e to Å¿ome modern Writers which have imparted

PerÅ¿ons of Eminent Quality, who under, the title of the Memoires or ObÅ¿ervations of the Famous Curate of Enonville, have Å¿o politely written of the Culture of Fruit-trees. And truly I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s, it was from them I had the firÅ¿t views of the principal Ornaments of our Gardens, as well as thoÅ¿e of the PleaÅ¿ure and Advantage we reap from Å¿uch of them as are well managed. The moÅ¿t part of which, I may without injuÅ¿tice affirm, are not to be lookt upon otherwiÅ¿e than as troubleÅ¿om TranÅ¿lations, and nauÅ¿eous Repetitions of Å¿everal old Maxims, which I hope, I Å¿hall carefully mark out to you, and demonÅ¿trate at the Å¿ame time to be for the moÅ¿t part faulty, or at leaÅ¿t very inÅ¿igniÅ¿icant.

The Å¿econd ReaÅ¿on that obliges me to write, is the aÅ¿Å¿urance I have, that I am the CauÅ¿e of peoples acting erroneouÅ¿ly in many Gardens, though it be the moÅ¿t innocently in the World on my Å¿ide, which proceeds from the inconÅ¿iderate conduct of certain PerÅ¿ons that being prejudiced with too favourable a conceit of my Abilities in this kind, when they Å¿ee what I do in our Kitchin Gardens, and to our Fruit-trees, are Å¿ometimes tempted blindly to imitate my Practice; but becauÅ¿e they are ignorant of my Principles, and think it would reflect too much upon their Reputation, to Å¿toop Å¿o low as to ask me them, they venture to gueÅ¿s at them themÅ¿elves, thinking without doubt that nothing is Å¿o eaÅ¿ie as to hit them right.

Å¿ave the poor innocent Trees from being Å¿o barbarouÅ¿ly handled any more upon my account, which would not have failed to act their parts well, if they had been wiÅ¿ely ordered.

But becauÅ¿e the Trees are now grown tall how ill Å¿atisfied Å¿oever a man may be at the Fruit they produce, he can hardly find in his heart to reÅ¿olve upon new grafting them, and much leÅ¿s upon beginning a new Plantation, Å¿o much afraid are people of engaging in any attempt to correct their firÅ¿t miÅ¿takes, that is attended with the hazard of making new ones equally pernicious; and by that means they find themÅ¿elves plunged in the mire, and are Å¿o diÅ¿pirited as to remain in it, vexing in the mean while, to Å¿ee themÅ¿elves deceived of the hopes they had conceived of their beloved project; which produces that DiÅ¿guÅ¿t which we obÅ¿erve Å¿o commonly, to Å¿ieze Å¿ome men, and make them, though at firÅ¿t they appeared paÅ¿Å¿ionately inamoured with their Gardens, Å¿eek in a few years after, to get rid of them at any rate.

There are likewiÅ¿e two other faults that are very common: The firÅ¿t is that for want of knowing the reaÅ¿onable diÅ¿tances that are to be obÅ¿erved between Trees, with reÅ¿pect to the goodneÅ¿s of the Ground, the height of the Walls, and the quality of the Å¿everal Å¿orts of Fruits; They are oÅ¿ten planted either too nigh to, or too far off one from the other; The Å¿econd is, that likewiÅ¿e for want of duly underÅ¿tanding what Situations agree beÅ¿t with each Å¿ort of Tree, a conÅ¿iderable number of them are often unluckily planted in unkindly Places.

And is it poÅ¿Å¿ible for a man animated with Å¿o warm a Zeal for Gard'ning as I am, not to be Å¿enÅ¿ibly touch'd at all theÅ¿e misfortunes, and not to IgnaroÅ¿

But becauÅ¿e if a Gentleman, were never Å¿o well Experienced in the Knowledge of the good Å¿orts of Fruits, he would be never the further advanced, if it were very difficult, or perhaps ImpoÅ¿Å¿ible, to find them in the NurÅ¿ery Gardens, this is the AnÅ¿wer I make to Å¿o Important a Difficulty.

I Hope my exactneÅ¿s in the Choice and proportion of Fruits I Å¿hall preÅ¿cribe, will produce a Regulation and kind of Reformation in all NurÅ¿ery Gardens; I mean, that it will not only baniÅ¿h all confuÅ¿ion, and effects of unskilfullneÅ¿s out of them that have been ill contrived, but will cauÅ¿e new ones to be modelled with all poÅ¿Å¿ible Art and underÅ¿tanding; And then it will happen, that inÅ¿tead of grafting any more either of thoÅ¿e kinds I reject by name, or of thoÅ¿e I name not, that both of them will grow Å¿o much out of requeÅ¿t, that they will be but loÅ¿t to the Gard'ners, and conÅ¿equently they will be obliged for their own intereÅ¿t, to graft only thoÅ¿e which I expreÅ¿s Å¿ome eÅ¿teem for; whether they be new or Ancient Kinds, and none at all of the others, and fewer of thoÅ¿e of which few are to be planted, and more of thoÅ¿e of which I adviÅ¿e to plant the greateÅ¿t number; by which means, the able Plant-Merchants may be aÅ¿Å¿ured of a good and never-failing vent for their Goods on one Å¿ide, which may encourage them to do better and better, and on the other, all Gardens will inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly come to be eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed upon a perfect Model, which is the main thing aimed at for the pleaÅ¿ure and Å¿atisfaction of all our Curious Gentlemen.

And in the mean time, till NurÅ¿eries can be brought into that Å¿tate of Perfection I have propoÅ¿ed, Å¿o that we may one day enjoy the convenience, to find in them a Å¿ufficient Å¿tore of all Å¿orts of good Trees, we may have occaÅ¿ion for, now Gentlemen are informed by the choice I have expreÅ¿Å¿ed in this TreatiÅ¿e, which are the Prime Fruits of every SeaÅ¿on, if they happen, among a great number of other Fruits which are rejected, to find but a part of thoÅ¿e that are Prized, they will do well to take rather more of them than they firÅ¿t intended, than to venture to meddle with any of the worÅ¿er kinds. And in doing this, their beÅ¿t way will be, to obÅ¿erve theÅ¿e two reÅ¿olutions, FirÅ¿t, either to plant no Trees but of thoÅ¿e few Good Å¿orts which they have found, and to fill up all the places they have to fill, wholly with them, or elÅ¿e to Å¿tay till another year, to gain time to look for thoÅ¿e Å¿orts they could not find the laÅ¿t, rather than to hazard the planting of any unknown or doubtful kinds.

And perhaps, as it is very expedient they Å¿hould, they will have Å¿o much wiÅ¿e forecaÅ¿t of themÅ¿elves, to prepare at leaÅ¿t, in the mean while Å¿ome Stocks to graft thoÅ¿e kinds upon the next, which they could not find the laÅ¿t year, and which I have adviÅ¿ed them to plant; which they may do either upon Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e Å¿upernumerary Trees they have already taken, or upon good Wildings, which they may plant ready in their aÅ¿Å¿igned places, for that effect.

For, to conclude, in the matter of Plantations, aÅ¿Å¿oon as ever we have reÅ¿olved to have a Fruit Garden, we muÅ¿t not forget any thing that may aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t us to follow exactly Cato's precept, which adviÅ¿es us to gain time, and to advance our Projects of CurioÅ¿ities in this Nature, with all the Expedition imaginable. div.p: I Cannot conceive but it muÅ¿t needs be a very acceptable AdvertiÅ¿ement, and of UniverÅ¿al Concern to all Noble-men, and PerÅ¿ons of Quality, lovers of Gardens, and Improvers of Plantations (of all DiverÅ¿ions and Employments the moÅ¿t Natural, UÅ¿efull, Innocent and Agreeable) at what DiÅ¿tance Å¿oever (from a Place of Å¿o eaÅ¿y and Å¿peedy CorreÅ¿pondence and which is Å¿o nere this great City) to give this Notice.

That of all I have hitherto Å¿een, either at Home or Abroad; or found by Reading many Books publiÅ¿h'd on this Subject, pretending to Å¿peak of NurÅ¿eries and Plantations for Å¿tore and variety; Directions for the DeÅ¿igning (or as they term it) the Skillful Making, Plotting, Laying-out, and diÅ¿poÅ¿ing of a Ground to the beÅ¿t Advantage: In a word, for whatÅ¿oever were deÅ¿ireable for the Furniture of Å¿uch a Ground, with the moÅ¿t excellent, and Warantable Fruit (I Å¿ay Warantable; becauÅ¿e it is peculiarly due to their honneÅ¿t InduÅ¿try, and Å¿o rarely to be met with elÅ¿ewhere) and other AcceÅ¿Å¿ories to Gardens of all Denominations, as in that VaÅ¿t, and ample Collection which I have lately Å¿een, and well conÅ¿ider'd at Brompton Park near KenÅ¿ington: The very Å¿ight of which alone, gives an Idea of Å¿omething that is greater than I can well expreÅ¿s, without an endumeration of Particulars; and of the exceeding InduÅ¿try, Method and AddreÅ¿s of thoÅ¿e who have undertaken, and Cultivated it for publick UÅ¿e: I mean Mr. George London (chief Gardner to their MajeÅ¿ties) and his AÅ¿Å¿ociate Mr. Henry WiÅ¿e: For I have long obÅ¿erv'd (from the daily practice, and effects of the laudable InduÅ¿try of theÅ¿e two Partners) that they have not made Gain the only mark of their Pains; But with Extraordinary, and rare InduÅ¿try, endeavour'd to improve themÅ¿elves in the MyÅ¿teries of their ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion, from the great Advantages, and now long Experience they have had, in being Employ'd in moÅ¿t of the celebrated Gardens and Plantations which this Nation abounds in; beÅ¿ides what they have learn'd Abroad, and where Horticulture is in higheÅ¿t Reputation.

I find they not only underÅ¿tand the Nature and Genius of the Å¿everal Soils; but their uÅ¿ual Infirmities, proper Remedies, CompoÅ¿ts and Applications to Reinvigorate exhauÅ¿ted Mould; Å¿weeten the foul and tainted, and reduce the Sower, HarÅ¿h, Stuborn and Dry, or over moiÅ¿t and diluted Earth to its genuine Temper and ConÅ¿titution; and what AÅ¿pects, and Situations are proper for the Å¿everal Å¿orts of Mural, Standard, Dwarf and other Fruite-trees.

They have made ObÅ¿ervations, and given me a Specimen of that long (but hitherto) wanting particular, of DiÅ¿criminating the Å¿everal kinds of Fruits, by their CharacteriÅ¿tical Notes, from a long, and Critical obÅ¿ervation of the Leafe, TaÅ¿t, Colour, and other diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing Qualities: So as one Å¿hall not be impos'd upon with Fruits of Several Names; when as in truth, there is but one due to them. For inÅ¿tance, in Peares alone, a Gentleman in the Country Å¿ends to the NuÅ¿eries for the Liver Blanch, Piguigny, de chouille, Rattau blane, &c. the EngliÅ¿h St. Gilbert, Cranbourn Pears (and Å¿everal other names) when all this while, they are no other than the well known Cadillac. The Å¿ame alÅ¿o hap'ning in Peaches, Apples, Plums, Cherris and other Fruit; for want of an accurate examination
(by comparing of their TaÅ¿te, and thoÅ¿e other Indications I have mentioned) For which Gentlemen complain (and not without cauÅ¿e) that the NurÅ¿ery-Men abuÅ¿e them; when 'tis their Ignorance, or the Exotic Name of which they are Å¿o fond.

I find they have likewiÅ¿e apply'd themÅ¿elves to attain a Å¿ufficient MaÅ¿tery in Lines and Figures for general deÅ¿ign, and expeditious Methods for caÅ¿ting and leveling of Grounds; and to bring them into the moÅ¿t apt Form they are capable off; which requires a particular AddreÅ¿s, and to determine the beÅ¿t Proportions of Walks and Avenues, Starrs, Centers, &c. Å¿uitable to the lengths; and how, and with what materials whether Gravel, Carpet, &c. to be layed.

They have a numerous Collection of the beÅ¿t DeÅ¿igns, and I perceive are able of themÅ¿elves to Draw, and contrive other, applicable to the places when buÅ¿ie Works, and Parterrs of Imbroidery for the Coronary and Flower Gardens are proper or deÅ¿ired. And where Fountaines, Statues, VaÅ¿as, Dials, and other decorations of Magnificence are to be plac'd with moÅ¿t advantage.

To this add, a plentiful, and choice Collection of Orange-trees, Lemon, Mertil, Baies, JaÅ¿Å¿mines, and all other Rarities, and Exotics, requiring the ConÅ¿ervatory; after they have embelliÅ¿h't their proper Å¿tations abroad during the Summer, and for continuing a no leÅ¿s ornament in the Green-HouÅ¿e during Winter.

They have a very brave and noble AÅ¿Å¿embly of the Flowery and other Trees; Perennial and variegated Ever-Greens and Å¿hrubs, hardy, and fitteÅ¿t for our Climate; and underÅ¿tand what beÅ¿t to plant the humble BoÅ¿cage, WilderneÅ¿s, or taller Groves with: where, and how to diÅ¿poÅ¿e, and govern them, according as Ground, and Å¿ituation of the place requires both for Å¿helter and ornament. For which purpoÅ¿e (and for Walks and Avenues) they have Å¿tore of Elms, Limes, Platans, ConÅ¿tantinople-CheÅ¿nuts, Black-Cherry-trees, &c.

Nor are they, I perceive, leÅ¿s knowing in that moÅ¿t uÅ¿eful (though leÅ¿s pompous part of Horticulture) the Potagere, Meloniere, Culinarie Gardent Where they Å¿hould moÅ¿t properly be plac'd for the use of the Family; how to be planted, furniÅ¿h'd and Cultivated Å¿o as to afford great pleaÅ¿ure to the Eye, as well as profit to the MaÅ¿ter. And they have alÅ¿o Seeds, Bulbs, Roots, Slips, for the Flowery Garden, and Å¿hew how they ought to be order'd and maintain'd.

LaÅ¿tly, I might Å¿uper-add, the great number of Grounds and Gardens of Noble-men and PerÅ¿ons of Quality, which they have made and planted ab Origine, and are Å¿till under their Care and inÅ¿pection (though at ConÅ¿iderable DiÅ¿tances) and how exceedingly they proÅ¿per, to juÅ¿tifie what I have freely Å¿aid in their behalf.

And as for the NurÅ¿ery part in Voucher, and to make good what I have Å¿aid on that particular, one needs no more than take a Walk to Brompton Park (upon a fair Morning) to behold, and admire what a Magazine theÅ¿e InduÅ¿trious Men have provided, fit for age, and Choice in their Å¿everal ClaÅ¿Å¿es; and all within one IncloÅ¿ure: Such an AÅ¿Å¿embly I believe, as is no where elÅ¿e to be met with in this Kingdom, nor in any other that I know of.

I cannot therefore forbear to PubliÅ¿h (after all the Encomiums of this great Work of MounÅ¿ â¢ de la Quintinye, which I confeÅ¿s are very juÅ¿t) what we can, and are able to perform in this part of Agriculture; and have Å¿ome Amaenities and advantages peculiar to our own, which neither France, nor any other Couutry can attain to; and is much due to the

lg.l: YE Hills, ye purling Streams, and chriÅ¿tal Springs
Ye Å¿tately Piles, the Rural Seats of King;

The Country loÅ¿t, and here ariÅ¿e to Å¿tate:

At gay VerÅ¿ailles, the brighteÅ¿t Court below,

That mighty Prince, whom wildeÅ¿t The K. of France's Aqueducts. Streams obey,

What Å¿tart of Nature! Let her learn to yield,

But I return, the Å¿tubborn Fields remain,

When gay Pomona Å¿hould her Å¿tate regain,

Yet Å¿till Å¿he doubted, many vows before

All Soils affect not every Å¿ort of Å¿tock,

The hotteÅ¿t Sun, and chooÅ¿e an open Air:

TheÅ¿e Laws Quintinius gave, and every part

To Å¿hallow Ground forbear to truÅ¿t the Fruit,

ObÅ¿erve theÅ¿e Rules, the Å¿tubborn'Å¿t ground will yield,

Thus learn'd Quintinius Å¿poke, and more deÅ¿ign'd,

div.head: OF FRUIT-GARDENS AND Kitchen-Gardens. VOL. I.
PART I.
CHAP. I.

argument.p: How NeceÅ¿Å¿ary it is for a Gentleman, who deÅ¿igns to have Fruit and Kitchen-Gardens, to be at leaÅ¿t reaÅ¿onably InÅ¿tructed in what relates to thoÅ¿e Kind of Gardens.

div.p: THAT Part of Gard'ning, I begin to treat of here, certainly affords a Gentleman who underÅ¿tands and applies himÅ¿elf to it, a great deal of PleaÅ¿ure; but that very Gard'ning being manag'd by an unskilful lazy Gard'ner, is liable to many Inconveniencies, and Vexations. TheÅ¿e are Two Noted and undeniable Truths, Å¿ince nothing in the World requires more ForeÅ¿ight and Activity than thoÅ¿e kind of Fruit and Kitchen-Gardens. They are, as it were, in a perpetual Motion, which inclines them always to Act either for Good or Ill, according to the good or ill Conduct of their MaÅ¿ter; and Å¿o largely recompence the Ingenious, as they Å¿everely puniÅ¿h the Unskilful.

The Proof of my firÅ¿t PropoÅ¿ition conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in that certainly nothing affords more Delight, firÅ¿t, than to have a Garden well Å¿eated, of a reaÅ¿onable largeneÅ¿s, and fine Figure, and that perhaps of our own Contriving or Modelling.

In the Å¿econd Place, to have that Garden at all times not only Neat, for Walking, and to divert the Sight, but likewiÅ¿e abounding in good Things to pleaÅ¿e the Pallate, as well as for the preÅ¿ervation of Health.

Thirdly, daily to meet with Å¿ome new Thing or other to do in it, as to Sow, to Plant, to Prune, to PalliÅ¿ade, to Å¿ee Plants grow, Legumes thrive, Trees BloÅ¿Å¿om; Fruit Knitting, then Thickning, Colouring, Ripening, at laÅ¿t come to Gather them, TaÅ¿te them, Treat ones Friends with them, hear their Beauty, GoodneÅ¿s and Abundance commended; all which Things together certainly form a very agreeable Idea, which affords a World of Variety.

To prove my Å¿econd PropoÅ¿ition, I Å¿hould only need in few Words to Enumerate all the DiÅ¿orders, wherewith our Gard'ning is Threatned, or rather DiÅ¿honour'd when it wants Culture; but they are too well known, nothing being Å¿o common as to hear Complaints of that Kind.

It follows from thence, that there are both PleaÅ¿ures and Vexations in Gard'ning; and it is as certain, that the PleaÅ¿ures are reÅ¿erved for Skilful, Active Gard'ners, and the Vexations infallibly for thoÅ¿e that are either Lazy or Unskilful.

This being granted, it muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be allowed, that thoÅ¿e are neither to be excuÅ¿ed or pitied, who inÅ¿tead of improving the Advantages they expected from their Gardens, are reduced to the MiÅ¿ery of laying out a great deal of Money, with LoÅ¿s, DiÅ¿guÅ¿t and cauÅ¿e of Anger, &c. While others with a little Skill have avoided all thoÅ¿e DiÅ¿orders, and enjoy all the Delights; from whence it follows, that if an Ingenious Man deÅ¿igns to have a Garden, which is a thing Å¿o Å¿uitable to that Qualification, he muÅ¿t abÅ¿olutely think of attaining Å¿ome Skill in Gard'ning, or elÅ¿e not meddle with it at all.
The grand QueÅ¿tion is to know, whether that Skill, which I think Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary, may be acquir'd with eaÅ¿e or difficulty, now to take a juÅ¿t Medium in this CaÅ¿e.

As to the firÅ¿t, which is to know whether it be eaÅ¿ie to acquire that Skil, I am perÅ¿uaded that many Gentlemen would be deÅ¿irous to attain it; for naturally every Body deÅ¿ires it. I am likewiÅ¿e perÅ¿uaded, that the number of Å¿uch would have been conÅ¿iderable already, had there been Å¿ufficient InÅ¿tructions for it.

As to the Second CaÅ¿e, whether it be difficult to attain a Å¿ufficient Skill, it is to be fear'd, that few of the Curious will be willing to undertake it; being diÅ¿guÅ¿ted by the Uncertainty of Å¿ucceeding in it, after having Employ'd a great deal of Time and Labour about it.

The Honour of having had for Å¿o many Years the Direction of the Fruit and Kitchen Gardens of the Royal-Family, Å¿eems to give me Å¿ome Authority to anÅ¿wer that grand QueÅ¿tion: So that, without deÅ¿igning to deceive any Body, and having a great deÅ¿ire to contribute to the Satisfaction of the Ingenious, I affirm that it is very eaÅ¿ie to attain as much Knowledge as is reaÅ¿onably neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the Curious, in order to avoid what might vex them, and to put them at the Å¿ame time in a Condition to enjoy their WiÅ¿hes.

It will be eaÅ¿ie for me to prove this AÅ¿Å¿ertion, after having Explain'd my Å¿elf more particularly upon what I think of all the PleaÅ¿ures that are inÅ¿eparable Companions of that part of Gard'ning, now in debate.

The moÅ¿t ConÅ¿iderable of thoÅ¿e PleaÅ¿ures, is not only to be able to obtain what may IpÅ¿a ratio arandi Å¿pe magis & jucunditate, quam fructu, atque emolumento tenetur, &c. Cicero. be produced by Earth, that Å¿hall have been well ordered, and a Ground well improv'd with Trees that perhaps Å¿hall have been Graffed, Planted, Prun'd, Cultivated, &c. by our Å¿elves, though really the Ideas of Å¿uch Injoyments are powerful Charms to Engage us to the Study of them; It conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in a great many other Things, as well for thoÅ¿e that will act themÅ¿elves, as for thoÅ¿e that will only act by their Advice and Orders.

In the firÅ¿t Place, to know with certainty what is moÅ¿t proper to be done, in order to make each Part of the Garden produce happily and in abundance, what is deÅ¿ired for every Month in the Year. The Judicious Gard'ner, as I have already obÅ¿erv'd, never fails in this, of being recompenced of his Labour, Cares and Skill. The Ground he Cultivates HoneÅ¿tis manibus omnia melius proveniunt, quoniam & curioÅ¿ius fiunt. Plinius. himÅ¿elf, without doubt affords him more ProfuÅ¿ion, being in reality better Cultivated, as if it dreaded, as I may Å¿ay, the Misfortune of belonging to a MaÅ¿ter, who only knows by his Gard'ner how it muÅ¿t be uÅ¿ed. It Å¿eems, that to Engage that skilful MaÅ¿ter it belongs to, to continue the Cultivating of it himÅ¿elf, it endeavours to produce more than it uÅ¿ed to do.

This PleaÅ¿ure of Gard'ning in the Å¿econd Place conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in knowing how to avoid many In foelix ager, cujus Dominus Villicum audit, non docet. Columella. great uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Expences, to which we are often engaged by ill Councils. Is it not uÅ¿ual in moÅ¿t Places to Å¿ee People continually Imploy'd in doing, undoing, and doing again? And moreover is it not common to Å¿ee a great deal of Time, and many Workmen Imploy'd about a thing that might have been done quicker, and by leÅ¿s Hands? So that a great deal of Money is laid out, which often creates great Vexations, and Å¿ometimes great Inconveniencies.

It conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in the Third Place, in knowing the Inconveniencies, that I Å¿hall explain in due place, of which Å¿ome are Invincible, and others not: This knowledge Å¿erves to prepare us betimes to receive the firÅ¿t patiently when they happen, and Å¿ecurely to avoid the Å¿econd, without entering into a thouÅ¿and impertinent reaÅ¿ons of an unskilful, careleÅ¿s Gard'ner, who endeavours to conceal his negligence, or incapacity, by imputing all the DiÅ¿orders, and BarrenneÅ¿s of his Garden to a wrong cauÅ¿e.

This PleaÅ¿ure conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in the Fourth Place in being able to condemn juÅ¿tly on the one Å¿ide what is amiÅ¿s or ill done in a Garden, and on the other to commend what is well, and according to Rules. There is hardly any thing more natural in all MaÅ¿ters who Å¿peak of their Gardens, than to blame or commend Å¿omething in them, as if they really intended thereby to diÅ¿cover what they are; and yet nothing is more dangerous for the Å¿ervice of a Garden, nor more diÅ¿agreeable for Å¿uch a MaÅ¿ter than to expoÅ¿e himÅ¿elf to be laugh'd at, or corrected by his Gard'ner, which certainly happens when the MaÅ¿ter is not capacitated to Å¿peak like an ArtiÅ¿t upon that Subject.

It conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in the Fifth Place in being reputed capable of giving good advice, and willingly to thoÅ¿e who Å¿tand in need of it: What greater Å¿atisfaction can a man receive, than to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t or undeceive a friend who was in an error, or at a loÅ¿s, and ready to give over his undertaking, putting him afterwards in a way of daily commending the good Fortune his Friend has procured him in his Work?

LaÅ¿tly, this PleaÅ¿ure chiefly conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in being capable of judging by our Å¿elves, and for our Å¿elves, of the capacity of a Gard'ner, either to avoid the Inconveniency of Å¿ometimes diÅ¿charging a good one upon very trivial pitiful reaÅ¿ons, and then taking an ill one in his room, or to reÅ¿olve wiÅ¿ely to diÅ¿card him who has not done his duty, and be able to chuÅ¿e another better qualify'd.

Now if it be true, that there is Å¿o much facility in attaining Å¿o many real PleaÅ¿ures, which I am going to demonÅ¿trate viÅ¿ibly; am I not in the right to conclude that when any body undertakes a Garden, without endeavouring to get at leaÅ¿t a Å¿ufficient inÅ¿ight in Gard'ning, he deÅ¿erves all the diÅ¿guÅ¿ts, which are numerous, inÅ¿tead of deÅ¿erving all the delights, it may produce, the number of which is infinite, and that conÅ¿equently it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Å¿tudy the attaining of Å¿uch a degree of knowledge, as is abÅ¿olutely requiÅ¿ite in thoÅ¿e Affairs?

It may perhaps be objected at firÅ¿t, that hereby I propoÅ¿e an Infallible expedient to introduce the moÅ¿t pernicious thing in nature in all manner of affairs, that is, to introduce ScioliÅ¿ts, or Smatterers: The Objections Å¿eems pretty Å¿trong, but the two AnÅ¿wers I am going to make to it, in my opinion, are yet of much more force.

The firÅ¿t is, that when a Gentleman Å¿hall once have attain'd a certain knowledge of Å¿ome Principles capable of affording him a good Tincture of Gard'ning, it is moÅ¿t certain, that he will not reÅ¿t with that bare knowledge of the firÅ¿t Elements, but will infallibly have a paÅ¿Å¿ionate deÅ¿ire of knowing Å¿omething more of an Art, that he is Å¿o much delighted with. He will Å¿oon improve the knowledge he Å¿hall have acquir'd, and conÅ¿equently will not remain long in that dangerous and Å¿o much fear'd Å¿tation, which is call'd Smattering.

The Second AnÅ¿wer, which is no leÅ¿s material, is, that without doubt, that Smattering of an Ingenious PerÅ¿on, if we may call it Å¿o, is much better, being grounded upon good Principles, than the falÅ¿e Notion of knowledge of common Gard'ners; it being moÅ¿t certain that you Å¿eldom find any thing among Å¿uch beyond a preÅ¿umptuous Pratling Ignorance, upheld by Å¿ome wretched Rote. Is it not a great happineÅ¿s to be able to attain a Å¿ufficient inÅ¿ight into thoÅ¿e matters, and to put our Å¿elves above Å¿o many falÅ¿e reaÅ¿onings, we Å¿hould otherwiÅ¿e be lyable to, and Å¿o avoid a great deal of vexation, to purchaÅ¿e abundance of PleaÅ¿ure?

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: How eaÅ¿ie it is for a Gentleman to acquire at leaÅ¿t a Å¿ufficient Knowledge in Point of Gard'ning.

div.p: NExt to that firÅ¿t Foundation, which eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hes, that a Judicious Man muÅ¿t apply himÅ¿elf to the attaining a Å¿ufficient skill into Gard'ning.

I propoÅ¿e this, That if he cannot afford Å¿o much time as to arrive to a full Perfection (which is not abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary) he may reÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ured that he may learn enough for his
purpoÅ¿e, that is, to be capable of ordering the moÅ¿t material Things that are to be done in his Garden, and to hinder the Gard'ner from ImpoÅ¿ing daily upon him, provided he be in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure inÅ¿tructed in the Five or Six following Articles.
The FirÅ¿t relates to the Quality of the Ground, its neceÅ¿Å¿ary Depth, to the Tillage, Amendments and ordinary modelling of uÅ¿eful Gardens.

The Second relates to the Trees, to chuÅ¿e them well qualified, either when they are Å¿till in the NurÅ¿eries, or taken from thence, to know at leaÅ¿t the Names of the Principal Kinds of Fruits of every SeaÅ¿on; to be able to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h them, and what number of each the CompaÅ¿s of his Garden may require; to underÅ¿tand how to prepare Trees both as to the Head and Roots, before they are put into the Ground again; and afterwards to place them at a convenient diÅ¿tance, and expoÅ¿e them well; to know, if not all, the Rules of Pruning, yet at leaÅ¿t all the Principal ones, either as to Dwarfs or Wall-Trees; how to Pinch off Å¿ome Branches, being over Vigorous; to PalliÅ¿ade Å¿uch as require it, as alÅ¿o the Triming of Å¿uch uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Buds and Sprigs as cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion; and laÅ¿tly to give every one of them the Beauty which they are capable of.

div.head: FirÅ¿t ARTICLE. Of the Qualifications of the Earth or Soil.
div.p: THE Earth of a Garden is known to be good, particularly for Fruit-Trees.

list.item: FirÅ¿t, when all that the Ground produces of it Å¿elf, or by Culture, is Beautiful, Vigorous, Abundant and conÅ¿equently nothing Poor; or Å¿mall, when it Å¿hould be Å¿trong; or yellow, when it Å¿hould be green.

div.p: Beneath the Surface, that appears good, you muÅ¿t have Three Foot of Earth like unto that which is above, which is a very material Maxim, of which you muÅ¿t be reaÅ¿onably well aÅ¿Å¿ur'd, by Å¿ounding the Ground at leaÅ¿t in five or Å¿ix different Places.

div.p: The moÅ¿t frequent are commonly the beÅ¿t, at leaÅ¿t in relation to Trees, there muÅ¿t be Four Yearly; viz. at the Spring, and MidÅ¿ummer, at the end of AuguÅ¿t, and immediately before Winter; and generally Å¿peaking the Ground, muÅ¿t never be left unmanur'd and full of Weeds, nor trampled or beaten by great Showers of Rain: It is very pleaÅ¿ing to the Eye when newly Till'd.

div.p: All Å¿orts of Rotten Dung of what Animals Å¿oever, HorÅ¿es, Mules, Oxen, Cows, &c. are excellent to amend the Grounds that are uÅ¿ed for Kitchen Garden Plants: Sheeps Dung has more Salt than all the others, Å¿o that a Å¿maller quantity of it muÅ¿t be uÅ¿ed; It is partly like that of Hens and Pigeons, but I would not adviÅ¿e any one to make uÅ¿e of it, by reaÅ¿on of a little Å¿ort of Fleas they abound with, which generally Å¿poil the Plants.

div.head: Fifth ARTICLE.
div.p: As for the common DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of Fruit and Kitchen-Gardens, in my Opinion the beÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t convenient for a Gard'ner, is that which is made, as much as can be, in well regulated Squares; Å¿o that if it be poÅ¿Å¿ible the Length may Å¿omewhat exceed the Breadth; the Breadth of the Walks muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be proportion'd, both to their Length and the whole Extent of the Garden.

The narroweÅ¿t muÅ¿t not be leÅ¿s than Å¿ix or Å¿even Foot to Walk in, and the broadeÅ¿t, though never Å¿o long, muÅ¿t not exceed three or four Fathom at moÅ¿t; and as for the largeneÅ¿s of the Squares, in my Opinion, it is a Fault to make any above Fifteen or Twenty Fathom on one Å¿ide, to a little more or little leÅ¿s on the other; they will be pretty well of Ten or Twelve on one Å¿ide, to Fourteen or Fifteen on the other, all which is to be regulated proportionably to the largeneÅ¿s of the Kitchen-Garden.

div.head: Sixth ARTICLE.
div.p: As to this Article, which relates to the Knowledge of Fruit Trees that are to be planted, it Å¿uffices, and is material to know.

As to Peach and Apricock Trees, thoÅ¿e that have not been Graffed above a Year, provided the Shoot be fair, are better than thoÅ¿e that have been Graffed Two or more; and yet the Peach Trees require more exactneÅ¿s in this than the Apricocks; and you muÅ¿t never take a Peach Tree, unleÅ¿s it has fine, Å¿ound and whole Eyes or Buds at the lower part of the Stem. The Principal kinds of Fruits, either Pears, Apples, Peaches or Plums, are Å¿ufficiently known; but whereas the making of a very well contriv'd Plantation is of great ConÅ¿equence. Our new CurioÅ¿o will do well to conÅ¿ult the TreatiÅ¿e I have written with a great deal of ExactneÅ¿s upon the Choice, and proportion of all Å¿orts of good Fruits to be planted in any Garden whatever, either Dwarfs, High Standards or wall Trees; otherwiÅ¿e I dare affirm, that he will be liable to commit abundance of Faults that will very much vex him. div.head: Seventh ARTICLE.
div.p: To prepare a Tree, both as to the Head and Roots, before the planting of it, I am of Opinion, that all the Capillar Roots muÅ¿t be taken away.

div.head: Eighth ARTICLLE.
div.p: In order to Plant well, you muÅ¿t chuÅ¿e dry Weather, to the End that the Earth being very dry, it may eaÅ¿ily cling about the Roots, and leave no vacuity; and particular Care muÅ¿t be taken leÅ¿t it grow to the ConÅ¿iÅ¿tence of Morter, which afterwards coming to harden, might hinder the Production, and the Shooting of the New Roots.

The beÅ¿t SeaÅ¿on for Planting is from the beginning of November until the End of March; yet in dry Grounds it is very material to Plant at the very beginning of November, but in moiÅ¿t Soils it is better to Å¿tay till the beginning of March.

The DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of Roots requires, that the Extremity of the LoweÅ¿t Å¿hould not be above a full Foot deep into the Ground, and the neareÅ¿t to the Surface, muÅ¿t be covered with Eight or Nine Inches depth of Mould. In a dry Soil it will not be improper to make a little But or Hillock over thoÅ¿e Roots, to hinder the Sun from Å¿poiling of them, and when the Tree has taken Root into the Ground, it muÅ¿t be Levell'd again.
After having Prun'd the Roots of a Tree, you muÅ¿t cut the Steem of the Length it is to remain, before you Plant it, and never Å¿tay to cut it till after 'tis Planted.
In Dwarfs, I regulate that height to be about Five or Six Inches in a dry Soil, and about Eight or Nine when MoiÅ¿t.
And in high Standards the proper height is between Six and Seven Foot in all manner of Soils.

In Planting, care muÅ¿t be taken to turn the beÅ¿t Roots on that Å¿ide which has moÅ¿t Earth, and that none, as much as is poÅ¿Å¿ible, may incline Å¿treight downwards, but rather look towards the HoriÅ¿on.

ThoÅ¿e who after planting, Å¿hake or trample on little Trees, do them a great deal of Injury; whereas on the contrary, it is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary to trample and raiÅ¿e the Ground about the great ones, to Å¿ecure them againÅ¿t the ImpetuoÅ¿ity of the Winds.
The Head or Top of EÅ¿paliers or Wall Trees muÅ¿t lean towards the Wall, yet Å¿o, that the Extremity of the Head muÅ¿t be at Three or Four Inches diÅ¿tance from it, and the Wound muÅ¿t not appear.

The diÅ¿tance between them is to be regulated according to the GoodneÅ¿s of the Earth, and particularly according to the height of the Wall; they muÅ¿t be nearer to one another againÅ¿t high Walls, and at more diÅ¿tance againÅ¿t low ones.

In this particular CaÅ¿e of the common diÅ¿tance of Wall Trees, it is to be regulated from Five or Six Foot, to Ten, Eleven or Twelve. The Walls being Twelve Foot high or more, you muÅ¿t always let one Tree Å¿hoot up to garniÅ¿h the Top, between two that Å¿hall garniÅ¿h the Bottom; in which caÅ¿e the Trees muÅ¿t be planted within Five or Six Foot of one another: But againÅ¿t Walls that are not above Six or Seven Foot high, the diÅ¿tance muÅ¿t be about Nine Foot.
The diÅ¿tance of Dwarfs muÅ¿t be from between Eight and Nine Foot to Twelve, or even a little more, being Plum-Trees, or Kernel-Fruit upon Free Stocks.
In high Standards from Four Fathom to Seven or Eight, for great Plantations.
In good Soils the Trees muÅ¿t be at a greater diÅ¿tance than in bad ones, becauÅ¿e there their Heads or Tops Å¿pread more.
When Trenches are newly made, the Earth will Å¿ink at leaÅ¿t Three or Four large Inches.

This is a very neceÅ¿Å¿ary ObÅ¿ervation, to make in order to the keeping the Earth about them, higher than the Neighbouring Surface, and to avoid falling into the Inconveniency of having Trees Å¿unk too deep into the Ground.
For the SucceÅ¿s of Kernel Fruit, it matters but little whether the Graff be above or under Ground.

But as for Stone Fruit, it is better not to be in the leaÅ¿t cover'd with Earth. Yet for the Beauty of both, it is to be wiÅ¿h'd that it may appear; but the main point is to have the Roots well plac'd, Å¿o that neither the great Heat, nor great Cold, nor the Iron of the Spade may prejudice them.

As for the UnderÅ¿tanding of the ExpoÅ¿itions, that are moÅ¿t proper for the different kinds, is an account which will be beÅ¿t learned in a TreatiÅ¿e written on purpoÅ¿e upon that Subject: Yet generally Å¿peaking I may Å¿ay, that the beÅ¿t of all in our Climates is the South, and the WorÅ¿t is the North; the EaÅ¿t is almoÅ¿t as good as the South, eÅ¿pecially in hot Soils; and laÅ¿tly the ExpoÅ¿ition of the WeÅ¿t is not amiÅ¿s for Peaches, Plums, Pears, &c. but is Å¿tark nought for MuÅ¿cat, ChaÅ¿Å¿elas, and all manner of large Grapes.

div.head: Ninth ARTICLE.
div.p: To have a reaÅ¿onable InÅ¿ight into the Pruning of Trees it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary at leaÅ¿t to know the Time and CauÅ¿e, and eÅ¿pecially, if poÅ¿Å¿ible, the Manner.
As to the Time, it is always good to Prune from the Beginning of the Fall until the New Leaves grow again, and no Tree muÅ¿t be Prun'd above once a Year.
Keeping within theÅ¿e Bounds, it will not be improper to Prune Weak Trees Å¿ooner, and thoÅ¿e that are Vigorous later.

As for the CauÅ¿e, there are two ReaÅ¿ons for Pruning; the firÅ¿t to diÅ¿poÅ¿e Trees to bear finer Fruit; and the Å¿econd to render them at all Times more pleaÅ¿ing to Å¿ight than they Å¿hould be, if they were not Prun'd.
To attain the Effect of this Å¿econd Condition, muÅ¿t be by the means of the Figure, that is given to every Tree.
That Figure muÅ¿t differ according to the difference of the Ground Plats, and does not Extend beyond Dwarfs and Wall Trees; for as for the generality high Standards are not Prun'd often.
The thick Branches only are capable of affording that Figure, which is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be well underÅ¿tood, and muÅ¿t be had conÅ¿tantly in the Mind.

A Dwarf, in order to be of a beautiful Figure, muÅ¿t have a low Stem, be open in the middle, and of a round Circumference, equally garniÅ¿h'd on the Sides: Of theÅ¿e four Conditions the moÅ¿t material is that which preÅ¿cribes the opening of the middle, the greateÅ¿t Defect conÅ¿iÅ¿ting in a ConfuÅ¿ion of too much Wood in that very middle, which of all things muÅ¿t be avoided.

The Perfection of a Wall Tree conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in having its Å¿trength and Branches equally divided on the two OppoÅ¿ite Sides, in order to be equally furniÅ¿h'd throughout the whole Extent of it, whatever part the Head begins at, whether it has a low Stem, in which caÅ¿e it muÅ¿t begin within half a Foot from the Ground, or high, and then it begins from the Extremity of the Stem, which is commonly about Six or Seven Foot.

The main thing in this depends on the DiÅ¿tinction which is to be made among the Branches, and the good uÅ¿e that is to be made of them; the Branches are either thick and Å¿trong, or Å¿lender and weak; every one of them furniÅ¿hing us with a ReaÅ¿on to take it away or preÅ¿erve it, to leave it long, or to prune it Å¿hort.
Among both, Å¿ome are good, and others ill, whether Thick or Slender.
The good are thoÅ¿e that grow according to the Order of Nature, and thoÅ¿e have thick or large Eyes, pretty cloÅ¿e to one another.
The ill ones on the contrary, are Å¿uch as grow againÅ¿t the Order of Nature, have flat Eyes, and at a great diÅ¿tance, for which ReaÅ¿on they are call'd Branches of FalÅ¿e Wood.

To underÅ¿tand that Order of Nature, you muÅ¿t know in the firÅ¿t Place, that the Branches Å¿hould only Å¿hoot from thoÅ¿e that were cut Å¿horter at the laÅ¿t Pruning, and that all Å¿uch as Å¿hoot from other Parts are Branches of FalÅ¿e Wood.

Secondly, that according to the Order of New Branches, if there be more than one, that which Å¿hoots from the Extremity muÅ¿t be thicker and longer than that which grows immediately beneath it; and this thicker and longer than the third, and Å¿o of all the reÅ¿t; and conÅ¿equently when any of them prove thick where they Å¿hould be Å¿lender, it is a Branch of FalÅ¿e Wood. There are Å¿ome few Exceptions Å¿et down in the TreatiÅ¿e of Pruning.
The good Å¿mall Branches, both as to Stone and Kernel-Fruit, are the bearing Branches; and the good Thick ones are for Wood; but quite contrary as to Fig-Trees and Vines.

As for the manner of Pruning it is generally look'd upon as much more difficult than really it is; the Principles, which are pretty eaÅ¿ie, being once underÅ¿tood, there is no difficulty in the Operation, and yet it is the MaÅ¿ter-Piece of Gard'ning.

The Chief Maxims are, FirÅ¿t, That Young Trees are much more eaÅ¿ie to Purne than old Ones, eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e having been often Ill Prun'd, and not having the Figure they Å¿hould have: The beÅ¿t Gard'ners are very much put to it, to correct thoÅ¿e old Defects. I have given particular Rules for Å¿uch Inconveniencies.

Secondly, That the Å¿trong Branohes muÅ¿t be cut Å¿hort, and commonly reduc'd to the length of Five, Six or Seven Inches; yet there are certain CaÅ¿es in which they muÅ¿t be kept longer; but thoÅ¿e are not common: I Å¿pecifie them in my great TreatiÅ¿e.

Thirdly, That among the others, there are Å¿ome that may be kept Å¿horter, and others longer; that is, even to Eight, Nine and Ten Inches; nay, and to a Foot, a Foot and a half, and perhaps more, eÅ¿pecially in Peach, Plum, and Cherry Wall Trees, which muÅ¿t be regulated accorded to their Strength and ThickneÅ¿s, to be capable of NouriÅ¿hing and Bearing, without breaking Å¿uch Fruits as they Å¿hall be Burthen'd with.

Upon Vigorous well Proportion'd Trees, there can hardly be too many of thoÅ¿e we call Branches for Fruit, provided they cauÅ¿e no ConfuÅ¿ion: But as for the Thick ones, which we call Branches for Wood, for the Generality in all Å¿orts of Trees only one muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd, of all thoÅ¿e that have been produc'd by every Branch, having been Prun'd the preceding Year.

UnleÅ¿s the Trees, being very Vigorous, the Extremities of the new Branches chance to be very diÅ¿tant the one from the other, and looking towards different oppoÅ¿ite Parts, being bare on the Å¿ides; which of neceÅ¿Å¿ity will require, being fill'd up for the perfecting of the Figure; in which CaÅ¿e we may leave Two, nay Three, provided they be all of different Lengths, and never form a forked Figure.
The Fruit bearing Branches, periÅ¿h after having perform'd their Duty with this DiÅ¿tinction, that in Stone-Fruit they die at the End of one Year, or Two, or Three at moÅ¿t.
And in Kernel-Fruit, not till after having Å¿erved Four or Five Years.
Therefore foreÅ¿ight is of great UÅ¿e, to think betimes of providing new Branches to fill up the Room of Å¿uch as we know are to die, in order to avoid growing too bare and barren.
ThoÅ¿e kind of Fruit Branches are good, whatever part of the Tree they Å¿hoot from, either Inwards or Outwards.
But a Thick one is always Ill, when it Å¿hoots Inwards in a Dwarf, unleÅ¿s it be to cloÅ¿e Å¿uch as open too much, as it commonly happens in Butter Pear Trees.

So that the Beauty of the Trees, and the Beauty and Abundance of the Fruit, depend chiefly upon good Pruning, the good Management of certain Branches that are at once Thick and Good, and the taking quite away of Å¿uch as are both Thick and Bad.

And whereas it happens Å¿ometimes, that a Branch having been left long the foregoing Year in order to bear Fruit, receiving more NouriÅ¿hment than naturally it ought to have, grows thick, and Å¿hoots other thick ones. One of the material Points of Pruning conÅ¿iÅ¿ts not only in uÅ¿ing this Branch like other Branches for Wood, but eÅ¿pecially in not leaving upon it any thick one grown on the Extremity of it, unleÅ¿s it be with a deÅ¿ign to let the Tree Å¿hoot upwards, in order to make it a Standard.

This good Conduct teaches for the Generality to lower Trees, I mean, that it is better in Pruning, wholly to take away the higheÅ¿t Branches that are thick, preÅ¿erving only the loweÅ¿t, than to do the contrary. Provided always, that the higheÅ¿t prove not better plac'd than the lower, to contribute towards the Beauty of the Tree, which is not uÅ¿ual; for in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, the loweÅ¿t muÅ¿t be taken away, and the higheÅ¿t preÅ¿erv'd: The firÅ¿t deÅ¿ign in this is, to have fine Trees, it being moÅ¿t certain that the Abundance of fine Fruit never fails attending Å¿uch a DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of a fine Figure, Å¿ince none of the Å¿mall Branches for Fruit, are removed, but on the contrary are thereby multiplied, and afterwards freed from whatever might obÅ¿truct them.

The lowring of them, contracts into the Branch Å¿eated on the Extremity of that which has been cut down, all the Sap that would have gone into the Superior, or Superiors, that have been taken away; whereby the preÅ¿erv'd Branch grows much Å¿tronger, and conÅ¿equently capable of greater Production than it Å¿hould have been.

And whereas Å¿ometimes, contrary to the Order of Nature, weak Branches Å¿hoot from the Extremity of the thick one, that had been Å¿hortned at the preceding Pruning; this Conduct teaches us to preÅ¿erve thoÅ¿e weak Branches, and to perform the Pruning upon that among the thick ones, which being underneath that, or thoÅ¿e weak ones, appears moÅ¿t proper for the perfecting of the Beauty of the Figure.

BeÅ¿ides the Pruning we have now mention'd, we Å¿ometimes perform another Operation which we call Pinching or Breaking; which is commonly of more uÅ¿e for Peach Trees than any others, unleÅ¿s it be upon all Å¿orts of Graffs perform'd upon thick Vigorous Trees already placed in the Garden: The Effect of this Pinching is to hinder the Branches from growing too thick, and conÅ¿equently uÅ¿eleÅ¿s for Fruit, as alÅ¿o from growing too long, to hinder a Tree from Å¿hooting upwards too Å¿oon, or from being broken by high Winds.

The Effect of it, is likewiÅ¿e to produce many Branches inÅ¿tead of one, among which Å¿ome Å¿mall ones will be of uÅ¿e for Fruit, and Å¿ome thick ones for Wood: The uÅ¿e of it, or rather the time of uÅ¿ing it, is about May and June, and muÅ¿t be perform'd by breaking with the Nail that Branch, which being about half a Foot, or Å¿omewhat more in length, begins to appear too thick.

In Order to Pinch or break to the purpoÅ¿e, the thick Branch muÅ¿t be reduc'd to Three or Four Eyes or Buds; and when the Branch Å¿o Pinch'd proves obÅ¿tinate in Å¿hooting thick again, the Å¿ame Operation of Pinching muÅ¿t be perform'd again, but a Weak Branch muÅ¿t never be Pinch'd.
I will neither mention here the Pruning of Old Trees, nor of Vines, or Fig-Trees, which I refer to the particular TreatiÅ¿es I have written upon each of them.

div.head: Tenth ARTICLE.
div.p: 'Tis commonly towards the middle of May that EÅ¿paliers or Wall Trees begin to require being PalliÅ¿ado'd or Bent.

The Beauty of PalliÅ¿ading or bending, conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in diÅ¿poÅ¿ing with Order to the Right and Left thoÅ¿e Branches that may grow on each Å¿ide, to avoid ConfuÅ¿ion, BarrenneÅ¿s and CroÅ¿Å¿ing one another.
But whereas the Defect of BarrenneÅ¿s is the greateÅ¿t of all, no Å¿cruple muÅ¿t be made of CroÅ¿Å¿ing, when BarrenneÅ¿s cannot otherwiÅ¿e be avoided.
Care muÅ¿t be taken to PalliÅ¿ade or tack as often as the Branches appear long enough to be tack'd, which otherwiÅ¿e would be in danger of breaking.

Above all things it is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to preÅ¿erve all the fine Branches Peach-Trees Å¿hoot in the Summer, unleÅ¿s they prove Å¿o numerous as to cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion, which happens but Å¿eldom in a well order'd Tree.

But however when neceÅ¿Å¿ity requires it, a great deal of DiÅ¿cretion muÅ¿t be uÅ¿ed, in tearing or cutting cloÅ¿e Å¿ome of the moÅ¿t Unruly, to hinder thoÅ¿e that are hid from Å¿tretching too much, and growing bad: It is likewiÅ¿e proper to take away the Branches of falÅ¿e Wood, that grow Å¿ometimes in the Front of Pear Wall Trees, as well as thoÅ¿e that grow in the middle of Dwarfs, which we call Triming of Buds or uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches.

div.head: Eleventh ARTICLE.
div.p: It is likewiÅ¿e very material for the MaÅ¿ter, as well as for the Gard'ner, to know how to gather all manner of Fruits well, of whatever SeaÅ¿on they are; and to lay up, and order, in the Store-houÅ¿e, Å¿uch as do not ripen upon the Trees, to preÅ¿erve both the one and the other in their Natural Beauty, and eat them in due SeaÅ¿on, without allowing them time to Å¿poil.
This may have been learn'd in the particular TreatiÅ¿e written upon that Subject.

div.head: As to the Twelfth ARTICLE. Which relates to Graffs and NurÅ¿eries.
div.p: The moÅ¿t common and beÅ¿t Method of Graffing, is either cleftwiÅ¿e, or ScutcheonwiÅ¿e: The firÅ¿t in February or March upon Trees from the ThickneÅ¿s of an Inch Diameter to Ten and Twelve Inches Circumference, and even more: This way of Graffing is good for all manner of Fruit Trees, excepting only Peach, Almond, Mulberry, Fig-Trees, &c. upon which it Å¿eldom Å¿ucceeds.

As to the Scutcheon Graff for Stone and Kernel-Fruit, if it be at the Time of Å¿hooting, it muÅ¿t be perform'd about MidÅ¿ummer; if at the cloÅ¿ure of the Eye, and upon Plum, Pear and Apple-Trees, about the middle of AuguÅ¿t; and upon Peach and Almond Trees, towards the middle of September; that is, both on the one and the other it muÅ¿t only be done about the Declining of the Sap.

Every Body knows, that the manner of Graffing CheÅ¿nut Trees is FlutewiÅ¿e and towards the End of April or the Beginning of May, when the Bark begins to looÅ¿en with EaÅ¿e: The Fig Trees may be GraÅ¿Å¿ed at the Å¿ame time, and in the Å¿ame manner, or elÅ¿e plain ScutcheonwiÅ¿e.
Vines are GraÅ¿Å¿ed likewiÅ¿e upon old Wood, which muÅ¿t be covered with Earth, and in the Months of March or April.
Pears Å¿ucceed equally well upon Wildings and Quince-Stocks.
Peaches upon Plums and Almonds.
Apples upon an Apple Wilding to make great Trees, and upon ParadiÅ¿e for Dwarfs.
Plums and Apricocks upon the Suckers or New Shoots of Plum Trees, of which the beÅ¿t are thoÅ¿e of St. Julien, and black Damask.
They Å¿ucceed Å¿ometimes upon Almond Trees, and Å¿ometimes alÅ¿o Pears and Plums are Graffed mutually upon each other, but commonly without Å¿ucceÅ¿s.

div.head: There Remains the laÅ¿t ARTICLE. Which relates in the firÅ¿t place to the Profit of Kitchen-Gardens, and in the Å¿econd to the Work of every SeaÅ¿on.
div.p: AS to the Profit it is Å¿ufficient to know, that the Kitchen-Garden muÅ¿t afford its owner Å¿ome Thing in every Month of the Year: InÅ¿omuch, that he may never be neceÅ¿Å¿itated to Å¿end for out of his Garden, what skilful Gard'ners expoÅ¿e to Sale in Publick Places.

For Example, in November, December, January, February, March and April, beÅ¿ides what has been preÅ¿erv'd in the Store-houÅ¿e, viz. Kernel-Fruit, Roots of all kinds, Cardoons, Artichokes, Colliflowers, and Pumpions. The Kitchen Garden muÅ¿t afford Potherbs, that is, Sorrel, Beets, Winter Cabbage, Leeks, Chibols, ParÅ¿ly, MuÅ¿hrums, Sallads, eÅ¿pecially Winter-Succory, Selery, Macedonian ParÅ¿ly or Smallage, with the Furnitures of Charvel, Burnet, Alleluya or Wood Sorrel, Balm, Tarragon, PaÅ¿Å¿epierre, &c.

In caÅ¿e there be hot Beds, during the great Colds you may expect Novelties, viz. Green AÅ¿paragus, Small Lettuce, Charvil, BaÅ¿il, CreÅ¿Å¿es, Hartshorn, and even Sorrel, &c. at all times; to which may be added, RaddiÅ¿hes in February and March, and Purcelain in April, &c.

In May and June you may eaÅ¿ily have abundance of Pot-herbs, and new Sallads of all Kinds, viz. Purcelain, Lettuce to bind, abundance of Artichokes, PeaÅ¿e, Beans, Cowcumbers, RaddiÅ¿hes, AÅ¿paragus, GooÅ¿sberries. Currans commonly begin in June, with Strawberries and Rasberries for the remainder of the Month, and MuÅ¿hrums always.
In July and AuguÅ¿t an equal abundance with the preceding Months. And beÅ¿ides that, French Beans, new Apple-Cabbage, and eÅ¿pecially Melons, Pears, Plums, Peaches and Figs.
In September you begin to have, beÅ¿ides the other, MuÅ¿cats, ChaÅ¿Å¿elas, and other Grapes of all kinds, as alÅ¿o Å¿econd Figs.

In October the Å¿ame Things, perhaps excepting the Melons; of which the SeaÅ¿on generally paÅ¿Å¿es when the Nights grow cool, and rainy Weather comes in: But in recompence the Autumn produces a world of good Pears and Cardoons, Selery and Spinage, &c. comes in SeaÅ¿on.

As for the Method of making all theÅ¿e Things grow, together with the Works of every Month, is what a Gard'ner muÅ¿t of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity UnderÅ¿tand and Practice; and when the MaÅ¿ter Å¿hall be Å¿o curious as either to deÅ¿ire to UnderÅ¿tand it himÅ¿elf, to correct the Gard'ner when he fails, or to enjoy the PleaÅ¿ure of Å¿eeing the Order and SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of the Productions. He may afford himÅ¿elf that divertiÅ¿ement, in reading the Book in which this Matter is throughly treated of, beÅ¿ides he may fully inform himÅ¿elf of all the ReÅ¿t of Gard'ning from all the particular TreatiÅ¿es, that are written upon every individual Part thereof.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: How to make Choice of a good Gard'ner.

div.p: IT is not Å¿ufficient, as we have already Å¿aid, for our VirtuoÅ¿o to have acquired the UnderÅ¿tanding of what we have mention'd, he muÅ¿t moreover be Capacitated to judge by Vitio noÅ¿tro agricultura male cedit, qui rem ruÅ¿ticam peÅ¿Å¿imo cuique Å¿ervorum velut carnifici noxae dedimus, quam majorum noÅ¿trorum optimus quiÅ¿que optime tractavit. Columella. himÅ¿elf, without any other help of the Skill, or Ignorance of all Å¿orts of Gard'ners, in order, if poÅ¿Å¿ible, never to be deceiv'd in his Choice; but yet the Truth is, that the number of the good Qualifications, eÅ¿Å¿ential to that Employment, is Å¿o conÅ¿iderable, that whenever I reflect on them all, I almoÅ¿t DeÅ¿pair of ever meeting with an AccompliÅ¿h'd one.

And yet without rendring the thing almoÅ¿t ImpoÅ¿Å¿ible, and without minding a Å¿cruple that comes into my mind, that I can Å¿ay nothing here but what every Body knows as well as my Å¿elf, I am reÅ¿olv'd to treat of this BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s at large, being perÅ¿waded that it is one of the moÅ¿t EÅ¿Å¿ential of all thoÅ¿e that belong to Gard'ning, and indeed the very Soul of Gardens; for Å¿ince a perpetual Culture is the only way to render a Garden Delightful, it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible ever to expect it Å¿o, unleÅ¿s it be in the hands of a Skilful Laborious Gard'ner.

Therefore barely relating my Method on Å¿uch OccaÅ¿ions, I Å¿hall only Å¿ay, that to act Prudently in the Choice of a Gard'ner, it is fit to mind fitÅ¿t the exterior Part of his PerÅ¿on, Pater ipÅ¿e colendi, haud facilem eÅ¿Å¿e viam voluit. Virg. Georg. 1. Labor omnia vincit improbus, & duris urgens in rebus egeÅ¿tas. Georg. 1. and Å¿econdly, the good interior Qualifications that are abÅ¿olutely requir'd in him.
By the firÅ¿t, I mean his Age, Health, Shape and Motion; and by the Å¿econd, Probity in his Manners, HoneÅ¿ty in his common Dealings, and chiefly Capacity in his ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion.

I Å¿hall begin with the good Qualifications of the OutÅ¿ide, of which the Eyes are the only and firÅ¿t Judges; for often at firÅ¿t Å¿ight we find our Å¿elves all of a Å¿udden inclined either to a good Liking and EÅ¿teem, or Scorn and AverÅ¿ion for the Gard'ner that offers himÅ¿elf.

As for the firÅ¿t ConÅ¿ideration, which is about Age, Health, Shape and Motion, I am In rebus agreÅ¿tibus maxime officia Juvenum, & imperia Å¿enum congruunt. Palladius. for a Gard'ner that is neither too Old nor too Young; both Extreams being equally dangerous. Too much Youth is to be Å¿uÅ¿pected of Ignorance and WildneÅ¿s, and too much Age, unleÅ¿s Å¿upported by Å¿ome Children of a reaÅ¿onable Age and Å¿ome Capacity, is Subject to LazineÅ¿s or Infirmity. Therefore, in my Opinion, the beÅ¿t Age is from Twentyfive to Fifty and Fifty-five, carefully obÅ¿erving, whether the Face denotes any viÅ¿ible Appearance of Health, without any evaporated Brain, or fooliÅ¿h PreÅ¿umption; likewiÅ¿e carefully chuÅ¿ing a Shape and Motion denoting a Sturdy, Vigorous, Nimble Man, not affecting to be dreÅ¿s'd or adorn'd above the common Station of a Gard'ner; all which ObÅ¿ervations ought to be believ'd, and I affirm to be very material.
Being Å¿atisfy'd with the Exterior part, the EÅ¿Å¿ential Proofs of his Merit muÅ¿t be examin'd, to which End a little ConverÅ¿ation will be requir'd with the Å¿aid Gard'ner.

list.item: FirÅ¿t, To know the Place whence he comes, the Times he has lived there, and the ReaÅ¿on of his leaving it.

Secondly, Where he has learn'd his Trade, what part of Gard'ning he is moÅ¿t vers'd in, whether of Fruit or Kitchen-Gardens, or of Flowers or Orange-Gardens. TheÅ¿e being the two different ClaÅ¿Å¿is of Gard'ning, that appear at preÅ¿ent beÅ¿t eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd.
Thirdly, whether he is Married and has Children, and whether his Wife and Children work in the Garden.

div.p: And laÅ¿tly, whether he can Write and Draw; thoÅ¿e being, in my Opinion, all proper QueÅ¿tions for a Man of Sence to make on Å¿uch OccaÅ¿ions.

The Gardner's AnÅ¿wer to the FirÅ¿t, may give us great Light to Judge of his DeÅ¿ert or Imperfections, becauÅ¿e that if he names Å¿everal Credible HouÅ¿es where he has liv'd in a few Years CompaÅ¿s, without being able to give good ReaÅ¿ons for his leaving them, it will give cauÅ¿e to Å¿uÅ¿pect either his Ignorance or DebauchneÅ¿s.

If on the contrary, he give warrantable ReaÅ¿ons for his Å¿o doing, it may be an Inducement to reÅ¿olve upon the taking of him, after having firÅ¿t made the uÅ¿ual Enquiries in Å¿uch CaÅ¿es, and receiv'd a good Account of his Conduct, from Å¿uch as are capable of giving it, and of whom it is to be expected, provided Malice and Revenge have no part in it.

I mean, after having been inform'd, firÅ¿t, of his Prudence and HoneÅ¿ty in his way of We muÅ¿t dread Gard'ners who prefer their IntereÅ¿t to their Honour and Reputation. Xenoph. div.p: I Am particularly to treat here of Four Things: The firÅ¿t relating to the Advantages to be wiÅ¿h'd for, in order to make Gardens: The Å¿econd relating to Earth, in reÅ¿pect to thoÅ¿e Gardens: The third, to what is proper to Correct the Defects we meet with in Gardens already made: The fourth, to the manner of Cultivating Gardens, together with Å¿uch Qualifications of Soil, as are proper for every particular Kind of Fruit.

I will Å¿peak of what relates to the firÅ¿t Article, after having firÅ¿t declar'd that I am only to treat here of Fruit and Kitchen-Gardens, whether they be City Gardens, which commonly are but of a Moderate CompaÅ¿s: The Ground of conÅ¿iderable Cities being too precious to employ much of it in Gard'ning, or Country Gardens, which for the generality are pretty large, at leaÅ¿t much larger than thoÅ¿e of Cities, and that in proportion to the Abilities of the MaÅ¿ter, and StatelineÅ¿s of every HouÅ¿e.

I am Å¿enÅ¿ible, that for the generality, both City and Country Gardens are made for the Conveniency of the HouÅ¿es, and therefore Å¿hould be pretty cloÅ¿e to them; yet conÅ¿idering that thoÅ¿e of the Country require a pretty large Extent, in order to yield conÅ¿iderably, being neceÅ¿Å¿ary for SuÅ¿tenance, as well as PleaÅ¿ure: In my Opinion, it were to be wiÅ¿h'd that the HouÅ¿es were built for the Gardens, and not the Gardens made for the HouÅ¿es. So that the Gardens in QueÅ¿tion are commonly the laÅ¿t Thing thought upon,

And indeed it is much more common to become MaÅ¿ter of a HouÅ¿e ready Built, either by PurchaÅ¿e or SucceÅ¿Å¿ion, &c. than to chuÅ¿e the Situation, and begin to lay the Foundations of it; Å¿o that generally People are neceÅ¿Å¿itated to make Å¿uch Gardens as the Dependencies of their HouÅ¿es will allow, which is the ReaÅ¿on they are not commonly Å¿o good as they Å¿hould be.

argument.p: Of Earth in General.

div.p: IN Order to prove what Earth is, not taking in a PhiloÅ¿ophical or ChriÅ¿tian Sence, whereby is underÅ¿tood the whole MaÅ¿s, this not being a queÅ¿tion proper to be decided in this Place: It is Å¿ufficient to know, Earth being conÅ¿idered in that Sence, that it is a great round MaÅ¿s, which forming one part of the created World, is Situated in the middle of the CeleÅ¿tial Sphere; where, by the Orders of the Creator, it Å¿uÅ¿tains it Å¿elf, as it were by its own Weight.

But to take Earth in the Sence of a good Husbandman, or a Gard'ner, to be able to Explain what it is in relation to all the Å¿mall Particles that compoÅ¿e it, and the Culture it receives from the Hand of Man.

In that Sence, I think, I may Å¿ay, that Earth is a quantity of a certain kind of Å¿mall Sand, which by the Operation of a certain Salt, wherewith Nature has endued every Grain of that Sand, is proper for the Production of Vegetables; in order to which there muÅ¿t be Å¿everal Grains together, which receiving a temperate MoiÅ¿ture, form a compacted Body, which afterwards receiving Å¿ome degrees of moderate Heat, Å¿eems to compoÅ¿e an animated Body: So that without theÅ¿e two helps of MoiÅ¿ture and Heat, this Earth remains uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, and as it were dead. 'Tis almoÅ¿t in the Å¿ame manner that Flower, which is an entire Body, compoÅ¿ed of an Infinite Number of Å¿mall Particles, all well Å¿eperated the one from the other; this Flower, I Å¿ay, being moiÅ¿tned to a certain degree, forms PaÅ¿te or Pap, either of which being Å¿eaÅ¿on'd with a little Salt, and afterwards heated to a certain degree, become proper for the NouriÅ¿hment of Man; whereas this Flower would remain uÅ¿eleÅ¿s or dead, if Water, Salt and Fire were not introduc'd to Animate it. However, we find this difference between Earth and Flower, that the laÅ¿t being once wetted, alters its nature to that degree, that it cannot return to its firÅ¿t Condition, although the MoiÅ¿ture be altogether drein'd out of it,
whereas on the contrary, Earth having once loÅ¿t the MoiÅ¿ture it had receiv'd, remains in the Å¿ame Condition it was before, when it receives a Å¿econd MoiÅ¿ture; but yet this difference ought not to deÅ¿troy our CompariÅ¿on.

In fine, Å¿ome are Unctuous and Sticking together, of which thoÅ¿e that are but moderately Å¿o, make Å¿trong Earth; others that are more inclining to it, make clean Loamy Earth, and thoÅ¿e that are extreamly Unctuous, make clayiÅ¿h and heavy Earth, altogether unfit for Culture.

BeÅ¿ides the difference of Sands, in Relation to FruitfulneÅ¿s and BarrenneÅ¿s, there are others which only differ as to Colour; for among Sands Å¿ome are BlackiÅ¿h, others ReddiÅ¿h; Å¿ome are White, Å¿ome Grey and others Yellow, &c. from whence Earth derive the Names of Black, Red, White, Grey, &c. But thoÅ¿e kind of Colours are not very EÅ¿Å¿ential to the goodneÅ¿s of Soil, as we Å¿hall demonÅ¿trate hereafter.

It is moÅ¿t certain, that thoÅ¿e Fertile Sands have really Å¿ome Qualities in themÅ¿elves, or rather a certain fruitful Salt, which is communicated to the Water that MoiÅ¿tens them, which being Å¿eaÅ¿on'd by theÅ¿e Qualities, muÅ¿t Å¿erve for the Production of Plants. JuÅ¿t in the Å¿ame Manner as SennÃ©, Rubarb and moÅ¿t Plants have in themÅ¿elves Medicinal Virtues and Properties, which communicate themÅ¿elves to the Water into which they are Infus'd, for the UÅ¿e of the Health of Man, &c. which Truth is undeniable.

I might aÅ¿Å¿ert here in the firÅ¿t Place, that Earth (conÅ¿idering it in it Å¿elf as one of the Four Elements) has really no Original or Natural DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition for Vegetation, being in its principal Qualities Cold and Dry, whereas Vegetation requires Heat and MoiÅ¿ture; but as by Ãt vocavit Deus aridam terram. Gen. cap. 1. v. 11. the ExpreÅ¿s Order and Command of Divine Providence, it finds it Å¿elf endu'd with a Salt neceÅ¿Å¿ary for Fertility, and is afterwards aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted both by the Rays of the Sun, and Subterraneous Fires which give it heat, as well as by Å¿ome Waters that moiÅ¿ten it, it Å¿eems to change its Nature; Å¿o that, in Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion to Å¿o abÅ¿olute a Command of the Sovereign MaÅ¿ter, it appears as if it were a living animated Being, a Being, having its particular Germinet terra herbam virentem, &c. Gen. cap. 1. v. 11. Activity, that is, of Producing, as if in Effect Plants were no more in relation to it than the Teeth of an Animal are in relation to that Animal: I mean, that as it is the Animal that Lives, and not the Teeth; Å¿o it would be proper to Å¿ay, that the Earth lives, and not the Vegetables. This Earth, I Å¿ay, in Obedience to that Command, makes that vaÅ¿t number of different Productions we have Å¿o much ReaÅ¿on to admire.

I might Å¿ay, Secondly, That there was a Å¿econd Command, after the CurÅ¿e occaÅ¿ion'd by Spinas, & tribulos germinabit tibi, &c. Gen. cap. 3. v. 18. In laboribus comedes ex ea cunctis diebus vitae tuae. Gen. cap. 3. v. 17. the DiÅ¿obedience of Man, and that by Vertue of that Å¿econd Command, that Earth Å¿eems moÅ¿t Inclin'd to produce Ill Plants or Weeds; Å¿o that this very Man having for his PuniÅ¿hment receiv'd a particular Order to Cultivate that Earth for his SubÅ¿iÅ¿tance, he finds himÅ¿elf in Å¿ome manner neceÅ¿Å¿itated to wage a perpetual War againÅ¿t it: He Labours and makes uÅ¿e of all his InduÅ¿try to VanquiÅ¿h and Overcome the malicious Inclination of that Earth, which on its part defends it Å¿elf with all its Might, to avoid, deceive and croÅ¿s the Subordinate Authority of that Å¿econd MaÅ¿ter.

And Å¿o we Å¿ee, that being no wiÅ¿e inclin'd to favour Children that are in Å¿ome manner Sponte Å¿ua quae Å¿e tollunt in luminis aur as, infaecunda quidem, Å¿ed laeta, & fortia Å¿urgunt. Virg. Georg. 2. Strangers to her, which by Culture we make her produce againÅ¿t her Will. She relapÅ¿es as Å¿oon as Å¿he can, Å¿hooting vigorouÅ¿ly ThiÅ¿tles, Nettles, and a ThouÅ¿and other Plants of no UÅ¿e to us, which are properly her natural welbelov'd Children.

In this the Earth reÅ¿embles thoÅ¿e Children who are Å¿eldom tired with Voluntary Games and Sports, though never Å¿o Rough or Violent in themÅ¿elves, and yet appear Å¿oon weary in the performance of what a Superior Authority enjoins them for their good, though never Å¿o eaÅ¿ie in the Execution.

Thus then, this Earth is oblig'd to obey in a great many Things, which Man requires of it, in which perhaps it might be compar'd to a young Colt, Vigorous and ObÅ¿tinate, Loquere terrae, & reÅ¿pondebit tibi, &c. Iob. which being once Å¿ubjected to the Hand and Spur of an able Rider, becomes Å¿ubÅ¿ervient for PleaÅ¿ures, Combats and Triumphs, &c.

Thirdly, I might Å¿ay, that all Å¿ort of Soils are not proper for all Sorts of Productions, Å¿o that every Clime Å¿eems in Å¿ome Sence to be reduc'd to Å¿ome particular Thing, which it produces Nec vero terrae ferre omnes omnia poÅ¿Å¿unt. Virg. Georg. 1. happily and with EaÅ¿e; whereas other Plants cannot Å¿ucceed in it, without much
Toil and Care: It is in this point that Man Å¿tands in need of InduÅ¿try, nay even of ObÅ¿tinacy, finally to overcome the ReÅ¿iÅ¿tance he meets with Å¿ometimes, in the Culture of his Ground.

ThoÅ¿e happy or unfortunate SucceÅ¿Å¿es of Plants, in certain Places ought to inform us demonÅ¿tratively, what kind of Earth is abÅ¿olutely fit for every Å¿ort of Fruit, and which is improper; for InÅ¿tance, the large Cherry Trees of the Vale of Montmorency, and the fine Plum Trees of the Hills of Meudon, &c. InÅ¿truct me what Soil is proper for Cherries, and what for Plums, &c. leaÅ¿t I Å¿hould engage to the rearing of them in Soils of a different Temper, with Confidence and PreÅ¿umption of Å¿ucceeding without difficulty.

From whence it follows, that it is very difficult to give general and poÅ¿itive Rules for every Climate in general, conÅ¿idering the great Proximity or NearneÅ¿s of good Soil to bad.

So that we Å¿ay in reÅ¿pect to the Production of Earth in every Clime, that Å¿ome are extraordinary good, that is, very Fertile, as we have often cauÅ¿e to Å¿ay, in reÅ¿pect to the Å¿aid Production, that Å¿ome are very Bad, that is, very Barren: This difference proceeding apparently from the Internal Qualifications of every Ground, Å¿ince it cannot be imputed to the Sun, which looks upon them all with the Å¿ame Eye; it may likewiÅ¿e proceed from another CauÅ¿e, which we will demonÅ¿trate hereafter: But, in fine, our Gardens abÅ¿olutely require Earth, therefore let us now examine what Conditions are neceÅ¿Å¿ary to that Earth, in order to make our Garden thrive.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the Conditions that are NeceÅ¿Å¿ary for the Earth of a Garden, to Qualifie it to be good.

div.p: MAny Things are to be Å¿aid in relation to Earth, which are neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be underÅ¿tood; I will Å¿peak of each in particular without omitting any Thing of what I know; but whereas we have eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd heretofore, that the firÅ¿t and moÅ¿t eÅ¿Å¿ential Thing to be deÅ¿ir'd, for Fruit and Kitchen-Gardens, is a good Earth, it will be proper firÅ¿t to Explain what a good Soil is, to the making of which many Things muÅ¿t Concur.
