div.head: FirÅ¿t SECTION.

argument.p: Of the FirÅ¿t Proof of good Earth.

div.p:
In my Opinion, the beÅ¿t Proof of a real good Ground or Soil, is chiefly when of it Å¿elf it abounds in very vigorous and numerous Productions, appearing Å¿eldom or never ExhauÅ¿ted: Quid faciat l â¢
tas Å¿egetes, &c. Virg. 1. When Plants grow viÅ¿ibly, with large thick Leaves, &c. When Trees grow up in few Years, producing fine Shoots, green Leaves, not drooping until the great FroÅ¿ts come in, having Å¿ine, lively, Å¿hining Barks, &c. TheÅ¿e Marks are certain Proofs of a good Earth.

div.head: SECTION II.

argument.p: Of the Second Proof of good Earth.

div.p: BeÅ¿ides this, the Nature of this Soil muÅ¿t be Å¿uch, that it may eaÅ¿ily repair what has been Impair'd by Å¿ome Extraordinary Accident, viz. by a great Heat, or a great Cold; by a great Drought, or great MoiÅ¿ture; by a long NouriÅ¿hment of Å¿ome Foreign Plant, &c. Å¿o as eaÅ¿ily and certainly to recover its former GoodneÅ¿s, if left in quiet, and, as it were, abandon'd to it Å¿elf; which Å¿uppoÅ¿es that the Accidents that had troubled it in its ordinary Productions ceaÅ¿ing, the goodneÅ¿s of its Nature, and particularly its happy Situation, are apparently the principal CauÅ¿es thereof; which is Å¿o true, as to that Situation, that Å¿uch a Soil being admirably good in Å¿uch a Place, will Å¿oon ceaÅ¿e to be Å¿o, if carried into another, where it may not meet with the good Fortune of Å¿uch an advantageous Situation: Whereas, on the contrary, if Barren in Å¿ome Place, being TranÅ¿ported into another, where the Situation happens to be better, it will undoubtedly prove much better in its Production there.

This is the ReaÅ¿on that TranÅ¿ported Earth, though never Å¿o good in the place whence it was brought, only has a TranÅ¿itory GoodneÅ¿s, and will Å¿oon ceaÅ¿e to be Å¿o, not meeting with a proper Situation, in which caÅ¿e it will require extraordinary Helps to be maintain'd in a Fruitful Condition.

Therefore we may lay down as a certain Maxim, that no Earth can be call'd good, unleÅ¿s it Å¿hows a great Fertility by its natural Productions, and be capable to recover it Å¿elf without help. ThoÅ¿e are the Earths that are abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary for Gardens, without amuÅ¿ing our Å¿elves in hopes of correcting a natural BarrenneÅ¿s abÅ¿olutely, by laying out a great deal of Money, in Dunging, &c. eÅ¿pecially in Relation to Fruits; as for Pot-herbs, I grant, that having abundance of Dung and Water, together with Å¿everal Indefatigable Gard'ners, they may be made to grow in a common Soil; but that Remedy is too ExpenÅ¿ive, and the real PleaÅ¿ure of a Garden, is inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with Å¿o much Toil and Charge.

div.head: SECTION III.

argument.p: Third Proof of a good Earth.

div.p: Moreover, in my Opinion, the real GoodneÅ¿s of Earth conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in having neither Smell nor TaÅ¿te; Å¿ince it would be Vain for our Fruits to be the Children of a very Fruitful Soil, and to be large and beautiful; if, at the Å¿ame time, that Soil had any ill Smell, or ill TaÅ¿te, by ReaÅ¿on that the Fruits and Legumes, or Edible Plants, will infallibly be tainted with it, and conÅ¿equently cannot be good or pallatable, which is their main Excellence.

The Example of thoÅ¿e Wines that taÅ¿te of the Soil, is a convincing Proof of this Truth, it being moÅ¿t certain that the Sap, which is prepar'd by the Roots, is only made by the Water, which Å¿oaking in the Ground where thoÅ¿e Roots are to Work, of neceÅ¿Å¿ity participates to the TaÅ¿te and Qualities of that Soil, and Å¿till retains them, notwithÅ¿tanding its being turn'd into Sap.
Earth to be good, muÅ¿t be altogether like good Water, that is, that without being Tart, or InÅ¿ipid, and SweetiÅ¿h, it muÅ¿t have no manner of Smell whatever, neither Good nor Bad.

This is the firÅ¿t and moÅ¿t material ObÅ¿ervation to be made, in order to ReÅ¿olve and Determine upon the Ground of a Garden, when it appears Fertile; which ObÅ¿ervation is very eaÅ¿ie, Å¿ince every Body is capable of making it, either in Smelling barely to a handful of that Earth, to judge of the Smell, or in taÅ¿ting the Water, in which it Å¿hall have Å¿oak'd, to judge of its TaÅ¿te. It is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to be too Nice in point of TaÅ¿te; Legumes do not require quite Å¿o much nicety, by ReaÅ¿on that moÅ¿t of them, in the boiling, loÅ¿e whatever might be diÅ¿agreeable in their TaÅ¿te.

div.head: SECTION IV.

argument.p: The Fourth Proof of good Earth.

div.p: Though it might Å¿eem Å¿ufficient in order to judge of the GoodneÅ¿s of Earth, to find its Production Vigorous, and that it does not grow weary of Producing, as alÅ¿o that it has no manner of ill TaÅ¿te; yet notwithÅ¿tanding the Knowledge of our Curious, who will make a Garden, muÅ¿t extend farther: It is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Å¿ound the Depth of the Ground, and to dig into its Entrails, to Å¿ee whether it contains, at leaÅ¿t, Three Foot of as good Mould as the Surface. The Tress he Å¿hall plant there will not grow Å¿o eaÅ¿ily as thoÅ¿e which Nature has produc'd of it Å¿elf; they will not thrive, unleÅ¿s they be, as it were, certain of a ProviÅ¿ion of Food for the Time to come, which ProviÅ¿ion conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in having Three Foot of good Mould, very Å¿oft or labourable on the Top; and whereas by daily requiring Å¿ome new thing from that Earth, it is tired at laÅ¿t, and grows Lazy and Lean in its Productions, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to make Å¿ome Alterations; the moÅ¿t material of all which, as well as the moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ie, is to lay the Mould that lay in the Bottom on the Top, where not having had any Thing to employ it, it preÅ¿erv'd its natural FruitfulneÅ¿s, in Expectation of being put to Tryal, that is, of being Expos'd to the Sun and Cultivated; in which Motion of the Earth, the Surface is turn'd in the Room of the other, which was taken up there to lay at reÅ¿t in its Turn, in order to come to it Å¿elf again in Å¿ome Years Time, and to be put into a Condition of acting again as well as ever: Not unlike thoÅ¿e Animals, which, though never Å¿o tired at the end of the firÅ¿t Day's Journey, go on the next Day with the Å¿ame Vigour as before, provided they have ReÅ¿t in the Night.

It is not enough to have laid down as a Maxim, that Trees abÅ¿olutely require Three Foot in Depth of good Mould, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary beÅ¿ides to decide how much will be proper for long Rooted Legumes: For Example, Artichokes, Beet Roots, Scorzonere, ParÅ¿neps, Carots, &c. all which, in my Opinion likewiÅ¿e, require the Å¿ame Depth of Three Foot. Other Plants, as Sallads, Greens and Cabbage, &c. may do with a Foot leÅ¿s. But thoÅ¿e among the Curious who, in both caÅ¿es, of Trees and large Legumes, are Å¿atisfied with leÅ¿s Depth than I have InÅ¿tanc'd, are certainly in a very great Error, and are to be pitied, or rather blam'd. And laÅ¿tly, they will be Expos'd to have Å¿mall Trees and Legumes, and thoÅ¿e neither good nor come to perfection, &c. Which Inconveniencies ought to be avoided, by following of my Precepts in chuÅ¿ing of a Å¿ufficient Depth.

div.head: SECTION V.

argument.p: The Fifth Proof of good Earth.

div.p: The Natural and Perpetual Fertility of Earths, their TaÅ¿te and Depth, being thus eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd as Four indiÅ¿penÅ¿able Conditions, there remains a Fifth, which is, That Earth, without being too light, ought to be eaÅ¿ie for Cultivation (like thoÅ¿e we call Fat Sand, or Flax Land, &c.) and pretty free from Stones, not only for the EaÅ¿e of Culture and to make Plants grow the eaÅ¿ier, but alÅ¿o to pleaÅ¿e the Eye, which undoubtedly is offended at the Å¿ight of many Stones or Rubbage in Å¿tirring of the Ground: So that when any Earth has that Imperfection, it muÅ¿t be remedied, when there are but a few, they may be eaÅ¿ily clear'd with a Rake; but when the Ground is full of them, I know no Remedy but Å¿ifting of it. Light Moulds have great Advantages for Culture, they are convenient to Plants for the Optima putri arva Å¿olo: id venti curant, gelidaeque pruinae, & labefacta movens robuÅ¿tus jugera foÅ¿Å¿or. Georg. 2. Multiplication of their Roots, they eaÅ¿ily drink the Water of Rains, and Waterings, and yet preÅ¿erve MoiÅ¿ture enough for Vegetation; beÅ¿ides they are eaÅ¿ily heated by the Beams of the Sun, and conÅ¿equently are quick in their Production, which is particularly deÅ¿ir'd by every Body.

div.head: SECTION VI.

argument.p: Sixth mark of good Earth.

div.p: The beÅ¿t way to know eaÅ¿ie Mould, is to compare it with other Earth that is not Å¿o; for Example:

Earth that is too Å¿trong cuts with the Spade like loamy or Å¿tif Ground, which are apt to cloÅ¿e and grow hard, to that degree, that it is almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible for Rain, or Waterings to penetrate or Å¿oak into them, wich is a very vexatious and moÅ¿t pernicious Inconvenience for Culture; beÅ¿ides, they are naturally inclin'd to rottenneÅ¿s, and are cold and backward, preÅ¿erving a continual moiÅ¿ture in their bottom, three of the worÅ¿t Qualifications Earth can have; the Å¿urface of them eaÅ¿ily Å¿plits and parches in great heats, inÅ¿omuch that they are incapable of receiving the leaÅ¿t Culture, and conÅ¿equently are neither fit for new Plantations, or to receive new Seeds, which occaÅ¿ions a great Å¿carcity in moÅ¿t SeaÅ¿ons; beÅ¿ides, thoÅ¿e cranys are very prejudicial both to Trees and Plants, having already taken new Root, by uncovering the Roots, breaking the new ones, and hindering them from continuing their Functions.

It is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to be better inform'd than I am, with all the diÅ¿orders that attend Å¿uch Soils, and with all the Inconveniencies they cauÅ¿e in Culture; and therefore I think it will not be improper for me to make a Å¿hort Relation, by the by, of what I have been oblig'd to do in the Kitchen-Garden of VerÅ¿ailles; of which the Earth is partly of the Nature of thoÅ¿e, which it were to be wiÅ¿h'd, might not be met with any where, and which we would not have there, had it been eaÅ¿ie to bring better in the room of it. The NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of making a Kitchen-Garden in a Situation proper for Walks, and the King's Satisfaction, oblig'd us to pitch upon that Place where it is; and the difficulty of meeting with extraordinary good Earth in the adjacent Parts, neceÅ¿Å¿itated us to be Å¿atisfied with Å¿uch as was paÅ¿Å¿ably good.

This Kitchen-Garden is in a Place, where there was formerly a large and very deep Pond; we were oblig'd to fill up the Place of that Pond, and raiÅ¿e the Surface of it even above that of the Grounds about it, otherwiÅ¿e it being a MarÅ¿h, and the Å¿ink of the neighbouring Hills, it would never have Å¿ucceeded for the uÅ¿e it was deÅ¿ign'd to: we met with no great difficulty in the filling of it, by means of the Sands we were oblig'd to dig out to make the adjacent Canal, of which we us'd ten and twelve Foot in depth every where, but yet the difficulty of meeting with proper Mould to lay over thoÅ¿e Sands, and to have it Å¿peedily, together with the Expence and Time for the diÅ¿tant TranÅ¿portation of the great quantity that was neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the Å¿urface of near twenty five Acres, or Furlongs, were capable to diÅ¿courage any body from the EnterpriÅ¿e; therefore we were oblig'd to take that which lay neareÅ¿t to us, that is from the Mountain of Satory: I examin'd it upon the Å¿pot, and found that it was a kind of loamy Ground which turn'd to Pap or Mortar, when after great Rains the Water remain'd long upon it, and look'd as if it had been petrify'd when it was dry; I likewiÅ¿e perceiv'd that common Showrs did not eaÅ¿ily Å¿oak into it, which troubled me much, but I imputed the cauÅ¿e of it to a kind of white Sand, or Å¿oft and chalkey Stone, which was found upon that Mountain at the Å¿econd Å¿pit deep of the Spade, and comforted my Å¿elf in hopes of meeting with a Remedy againÅ¿t it, by means of the Sands, upon which that Earth was to be plac'd; upon that Foundation I diÅ¿pos'd the ground of this Kitchen-Garden in Å¿uch a manner that the Earth of the Å¿urface might lay upon a level, without any declivity, as commonly moÅ¿t Gardens are; but I was extreamly Å¿urpriz'd when I found the contrary of what I expected; this Earth in changing of Place, did not change its Nature, it remain'd impenetrable to Water; that which happen'd moÅ¿t favourable to me in this, was, that I was expos'd the firÅ¿t year to the greateÅ¿t miÅ¿chief that could poÅ¿Å¿ibly befall me, there falling Å¿uch great and frequent Showers of Rain, that the whole Garden Å¿eem'd to be turn'd into a Pond, or at leaÅ¿t into a puddled MarÅ¿h, which was inacceÅ¿Å¿ible, and above all, Mortal, both for the Trees that were rooted up, and all the Kitchen Plants that were overflow'd by it: A Remedy was to be found Å¿uitable to Å¿o great an Inconvenience, otherwiÅ¿e the great work of the Kitchen-Garden, the Expence of which had made Å¿o great a NoiÅ¿e, and the Figure whereof afforded Å¿o much PleaÅ¿ure, Å¿hould have been of no uÅ¿e: Happily in cauÅ¿ing this Å¿ame Garden to be made, I had at the Å¿ame time alÅ¿o made an Aqueduct that went a croÅ¿s it, in order to receive all the Waters of the Hills, which were wont to fall into that very Place to Å¿upply the former Pond, and were neceÅ¿Å¿ary to fill the great neighbouring Canal; therefore I bethought my Å¿elf to order Matters Å¿o, that thoÅ¿e Waters which were Å¿o pernicious to me, might loÅ¿e themÅ¿elves in that great Aqueduct, to which end I thought my Å¿elf oblig'd to raiÅ¿e every Plat or
Square into Ridges, which Remedy was good, but would have been violent, had I been forc'd to get new Earth for that Elevation; in order to perform this with more eaÅ¿e, I made uÅ¿e of long Dung, of which I was very well provided, as well to place it underneath, as to mix it with the Mould deÅ¿ign'd for Legumes, which anÅ¿wer'd my Expectation. The SucceÅ¿s prov'd good, and the Charge inconÅ¿iderable; in forming of this Work, I allow'd every Square an imperceptible Declivity to lead or carry all the Waters Å¿liding down from all the parts Å¿o rais'd into one of the Corners; and caus'd a Å¿mall Stone Gutter to be made at every Corner, to carry thoÅ¿e Waters into the Aqueducts; and was not long before I found the benefit of that Invention; my Squares with their Plants, and my Borders with their Trees, being thereby preÅ¿erv'd according to my WiÅ¿h; beÅ¿ides, it contributed conÅ¿iderably towards the PreÅ¿ervation and good TaÅ¿te of all the things that I could rear there.

This manner of Ridges appear'd at firÅ¿t Å¿urprizing by its Novelty, but yet it had the good Fortune to pleaÅ¿e the King, whoÅ¿e Penetration and Judgment are infinite in all things; What Honour, and what Joy for me to have the Approbation of Å¿o great a Prince! But when People have no Inclination to make Å¿uch Elevations, they muÅ¿t at leaÅ¿t reÅ¿olve to have recourÅ¿e to frequent Tillages, to avoid the Inconveniencies that attend Soils that eaÅ¿ily Chop in the time of great long heats, it being a very good and infallible Remedy.

div.head: SECTION VII.

argument.p: Seventh Mark of good Earth.

div.p: We have now Å¿een the Inconveniencies attending a Soil that is too ponderous, or too fat, and too Å¿trong, and have found a Remedy for it; on the other hand, thoÅ¿e that are too light, and conÅ¿equently dry, are accompany'd with Å¿o many difficulties, that they are capable wholly to diÅ¿guÅ¿t the Curious.

Let us now conÅ¿ider what relates to thoÅ¿e Soils that are too dry and light, and let us examin whether it be poÅ¿Å¿ible to correct thoÅ¿e defects.

It happens often that Earth is dry and light, becauÅ¿e Nature at firÅ¿t formed it in that Temperature, Å¿uch is that of dry Turf in certain Fens, Å¿uch is the Sandy Soil of the Plain of Grenelle; it is pretty difficult, tho not impoÅ¿Å¿ible to render them more Ponderous and Fat, which is only to be done by mixing abundance of other Å¿trong Earth among it, or by making of a way for a conÅ¿iderable diÅ¿charge of Water towards the Bottom, which might Å¿pread all over it, which is not very practicable; Å¿ometimes this drought and lightneÅ¿s proceed from its lying upon a clear Sand, eÅ¿pecially when it lyes too Å¿hallow, and conÅ¿equently has not a Bed Å¿ufficiently Å¿olid, and cloÅ¿e, to Å¿top the Waters that fall upon it, either by Rain, Snow, or other ways; thoÅ¿e Waters eaÅ¿ily penetrating the Body of thoÅ¿e Soils deÅ¿cend to that Sand, which being as it were, a kind of Sive lets them paÅ¿s, and go down lower, as to the place of their Center, whither their weight inclines them, and Å¿o no MoiÅ¿ture or CoolneÅ¿s is preÅ¿erved on the Bottom of that Earth, from thence to be Communicated to the Å¿uperior parts; and conÅ¿equently that Soil Å¿till relapÅ¿es into its Natural DrineÅ¿s and BarrenneÅ¿s, Å¿ince it cannot produce any thing, unleÅ¿s it be at once accompanied with Å¿ome MoiÅ¿ture and Temperate CumuloÅ¿que ruit male pinguts arenae. Georg. 1. Heat.

ThoÅ¿e that are at liberty to chooÅ¿e their Ground, will hardly be Å¿o ill adviÅ¿ed as to pitch upon one that is Å¿o defective; but when they are indiÅ¿penÅ¿ably obliged to it, three things muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be done.
The FirÅ¿t is to remove as much of that Clear Sand as will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to form that depth of three Foot, filling it up afterwards with as good Mould as can be conveniently got.

The Second is to keep all thoÅ¿e Places that are to be Cultivated a little lower than the Walks, to the End that the Waters which falls into thoÅ¿e Walks, may altogether incline and run into that Ground.

The Third and LaÅ¿t is to throw into thoÅ¿e Cultivated Plats, in the Winter, all the Snow that lies in the Walks, and other Parts, from which they may be eaÅ¿ily brought, which will make a ProviÅ¿ion of MoiÅ¿ture in the Bottom of that Ground, to help it to perform its Functions during the great Heats of Summer.

I have always us'd thoÅ¿e three Expedients, and have prevail'd with my Friends to put them in practice; and I atteÅ¿t with Truth, that we have all found a great Benefit by it, and that it is very Å¿afe to put them in practice.

No Body can be Ignorant, that when there lies Water at a moderate Depth within the Ground; for InÅ¿tance, about Three Foot deep (which is common at the Bottom of Vales, where there lies what we call a good Black Sand.) No Body, I Å¿ay, can be Ignorant, that in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e a Natural Philtration or DiÅ¿tillation, forms it Å¿elf in the Depth of that Earth, which raiÅ¿es part of that Water up to the Surface, which preÅ¿erving or maintaining the Earth in a good Temperature for Production, makes it extraordinary good; whereas on the Contrary, that Water lying in a great quantity too near the Surface; for Example, within a Foot or Å¿omewhat more, being Å¿top'd there by Å¿ome Bank of Å¿oft Chalk, Stone, or Å¿tiff Clay remains there, being hindred from deÅ¿cending lower, and thereby occaÅ¿ions too great a MoiÅ¿ture in the Earth; Å¿o that unleÅ¿s a DiÅ¿charge be made of thoÅ¿e Subterraneous Waters, or that the Ground be rais'd RidgewiÅ¿e, as I have heretofore Explain'd, in order to make thoÅ¿e Waters riÅ¿e, Å¿uch Soil will of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity grow Cold, Rotten; and, in a Word, Å¿tark Nought.

And, indeed, we may aÅ¿Å¿ure our Å¿elves, that the MoiÅ¿ture of Soils often proceeds from that CauÅ¿e, as well thoÅ¿e that are very ExceÅ¿Å¿ive as thoÅ¿e that are not: That MoiÅ¿ture proceeds Å¿ometimes from other CauÅ¿es, as we Å¿hall declare in the Sequel.

I think my Å¿elf oblig'd to Å¿ay in this Place, that in Relation to the difference of Earth, either Strong and Fat, or Dry and Light, this DiÅ¿tinction is to be made, that in Cold Countries light Earth is moÅ¿t to be deÅ¿ir'd, to the End that a Å¿mall Heat may be able to warm it; whereas pretty Stony and Fat Soil is beÅ¿t in Hot Countries, Heat not penetrating Å¿o eaÅ¿ily into the Bottom of it, or drying up the Plants. The Prince of Poets, who was Originally At quae pinguis humus, dulcique uligine laeta, quique frequens herbis & fertilis ubere campus. Georg. 2. & paulo poÅ¿t. Hic tibi praevalidas olim, multoque fluentes Å¿ufficiet Baccho vites hic fertilis uvae, &c. Georg. 2. DenÅ¿a, magis Cereri: rariÅ¿Å¿ima quaeque Lyaeo. Et Å¿uperlus. Alter a frumentis quoniam favet, altera Baccho. div.head: SECTION IX.

argument.p: Of Fallow Earth.

div.p: TheÅ¿e Terms of Fallows, or Earth that lies at ReÅ¿t and Unimploy'd, intimate, that the Grounds Å¿ometimes want ReÅ¿t, thereby to be recover'd or reinforc'd, whether the Influences of the Stars, and more particularly the Rains, cauÅ¿e that uÅ¿eful Reparation (as certainly they contribute much to it) or rather whether thoÅ¿e Earths have in themÅ¿elves a fund of Natural FruitfulneÅ¿s with a Faculty not indeed to render that FruitfulneÅ¿s undrainable, but to re-eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h it, and produce it again; when, after having been impair'd by continual Productions, we let it lie Fallow for Å¿ome time, as if we did abandon it to its own DiÅ¿cretion, and judg'd it capable of knowing its own DiÅ¿temper, and to remedy it. div.head: SECTION XI.

argument.p: Of New Earth, or Ground new broke open.

There Å¿till remains to Explain what New Earth is, I mean Earth never having Å¿een the

div.p: I have declar'd Å¿everal Times already, That the moÅ¿t eÅ¿Å¿ential and Å¿ureÅ¿t Mark of the goodneÅ¿s of the Ground, is that which is taken from the Natural Beauty of its Productions; Å¿ome would willingly beÅ¿ides this, Å¿ettle another certain mark upon the Colour of it, and Å¿ay, that a blackiÅ¿h Grey is a convincing Proof in that matter, beÅ¿ides its being moÅ¿t pleaÅ¿ing to the Eye.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Of the ExpoÅ¿ures of Gardens, as well in general as in particular; with the Explication of what may be good and ill in every one of them.
