Virgil. buc. Ecl. 3. by Raine as thoÅ¿e of the WeÅ¿t, &c.

BeÅ¿ides, thoÅ¿e Names of ExpoÅ¿itions likewiÅ¿e expreÅ¿s thoÅ¿e Winds Gardens are more, or leÅ¿s expos'd to, and conÅ¿equently can be more or leÅ¿s prejudicial to them; for the Winds in reÅ¿pect to Gardens, eÅ¿pecially for Trees, are almoÅ¿t all to be fear'd; but yet Å¿ome more, and others leÅ¿s, and that according to the different SeaÅ¿ons of the Year.

Although it may be urg'd, that whatever Situation a Garden be in, it has of neceÅ¿Å¿ity all the AÅ¿pects of the Sun, and conÅ¿equently is in a Condition to enjoy the Favors of all the ExpoÅ¿itions, as well as to fear the InÅ¿ults of all the Winds, yet every body agrees, that Å¿ome are better expos'd than others; which is particularly underÅ¿tood of Å¿uch as are upon Hills, or the Å¿ides of Mountains, of which Å¿ome have the RiÅ¿ing Sun, others the Setting; Å¿ome lye South, and others North; for as to the Gardens that are Å¿ituated in Plains, and are neither cover'd by Mountains, or high Woods, or lofty Buildings, the difference of thoÅ¿e ExpoÅ¿ures is not Å¿o Å¿enÅ¿ible.

The uÅ¿ual manner of Å¿peaking to expreÅ¿s the ExpoÅ¿itions in reÅ¿pect of every Garden, in the whole, and without any particular diÅ¿tinction of Å¿ides, muÅ¿t be underÅ¿tood in relation to the ExpoÅ¿itions of the whole coaÅ¿t where thoÅ¿e Gardens are Å¿ituated; as the manner of Å¿peaking of the ExpoÅ¿ures of Walls in particular, relates to the manner of the Suns Å¿hining upon every one of them in the courÅ¿e of the whole day; and Å¿o for Example, when in Å¿peaking of a Garden Å¿ituated upon a Å¿mall Hill, we Å¿ay that it lyes to the EaÅ¿t, we mean that the Sun Å¿hines upon it as Å¿oon as it RiÅ¿es, and Å¿hines but little upon it in the Afternoon: and when we Å¿ay that a Garden lyes full South, it is when the Sun Å¿hines upon it all the day, or at leaÅ¿t from Nine or Ten in the Morning till the Evening; and by the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on when we Å¿ay that Å¿uch a Garden lyes to the WeÅ¿t, we mean that the Sun does not begin to Å¿hine upon it till about Noon, and remains there till it Å¿ets.

Now the meaning of ExpoÅ¿itions is fully underÅ¿tood, in order to decide which is the beÅ¿t of the four, either in general for the whole Garden, or in particular for every one of the Å¿ides; it will be fit to know in the firÅ¿t place, that thoÅ¿e of the South and EaÅ¿t, are by the Opinion of all Gard'ners the two chief, and therefore to be preferr'd before the two others; it is likewiÅ¿e fit to know that the ExpoÅ¿ition of the WeÅ¿t is not amiÅ¿s, or at leaÅ¿t much better than the North, which conÅ¿equently is the worÅ¿t of all.

Secondly, In order to decide between the two firÅ¿t, which is the beÅ¿t, the temper of the Earth muÅ¿t firÅ¿t be diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h'd; for if it be Å¿trong, and conÅ¿equently cold, the South is beÅ¿t; but if light, and conÅ¿equently hot, that of the EaÅ¿t will be moÅ¿t favourable.

The ExpoÅ¿ures of the South in all Earths is commonly proper to Å¿ecure all Plants againÅ¿t the rigors of the Winter, to give a taÅ¿te to the Legumes and Fruits, and to forward all that is to be early in all SeaÅ¿ons; and therefore Å¿ince it is favourable to all Å¿orts of Earth, it muÅ¿t be Å¿o particularly to a Å¿trong cold Earth, which can hardly act unleÅ¿s animated by an extraordinary heat from the Sun, which is the moÅ¿t proper ExpoÅ¿ition for it: but not for light Earths, eÅ¿pecially in hot Climats, it being apt to Å¿corch the Plants in Summer to that degree, that the Kitchen Gardens become of no uÅ¿e, it engenders a thouÅ¿and Emots or kind of Fleas which gnaw and wrinkle the Leaves, it hinders the Fruits from growing to that bigneÅ¿s they Å¿hould do, and thereby leÅ¿Å¿ens the goodneÅ¿s of the TaÅ¿te, and even often makes them drop before their time, which happens Å¿ometimes by reaÅ¿on that it Å¿poils or drys up the Branches and Leaves, nay even the Å¿talks of thoÅ¿e Fruits, as we often Å¿ee it in MuÅ¿ctts and Peaches; and Å¿ometimes alÅ¿o in over-hard'ning the Rine of every Fruit, even to that degree that it often Å¿corches and chaps them; by which means abundance of Peaches and Figs growing againÅ¿t Walls periÅ¿h through exceÅ¿Å¿ive heats: therefore it is eaÅ¿ie to decide the choice of thoÅ¿e two ExpoÅ¿itions, in reÅ¿pect to the difference of Earth; the South is moÅ¿t deÅ¿irable in cold moiÅ¿t parts, but not Å¿o much in dry Å¿andy Grounds.

Generally Å¿peaking, this ExpoÅ¿ition of the South is free from the Northern Winds, which by their uÅ¿ual coldneÅ¿s are always cruel and fatal to all manner of Gardens, which is the reaÅ¿on it is generally choÅ¿en before that of the EaÅ¿t; but yet it is moÅ¿t certain that in light Grounds, the laÅ¿t being favour'd by Night Dews, and the firÅ¿t gentle and mild Rays of the RiÅ¿ing Sun, is incomparable for Maturity, Size and TaÅ¿te, as well as for the PreÅ¿ervation of Trees and Legumes, &c. and eÅ¿pecially becauÅ¿e over and above all this, it defends us from the North WeÅ¿t Winds; that Wind riÅ¿es between the WeÅ¿t and North, and as it regularly blows in the Spring, it is commonly attended by white FroÅ¿ts, which are very deÅ¿tructive to the BloÅ¿Å¿oms and Fruits of Trees, whereon it lights, which is the reaÅ¿on that People eaÅ¿ily
bear with that EaÅ¿tern ExpoÅ¿ition even in Å¿trong Earths, but Å¿till I do certainly believe it beÅ¿t for light Earth.

Although I have preferr'd the ExpoÅ¿ition of the WeÅ¿t before that of the North without any heÅ¿itation, the laÅ¿t being certainly the worÅ¿t of the two; yet in thoÅ¿e Climats where the heat being exceÅ¿Å¿ive, burns, and abÅ¿olutely ruins all that is too long expos'd to the Sun, the North ought to be choÅ¿en before the other; Å¿ince our Gardens only want a moderate heat to nouriÅ¿h gentle what they produce, eÅ¿pecially to conduct Fruits to a perfect Maturity, and therefore in thoÅ¿e Climats where the Sun Å¿eems too violent, I Å¿hould rather affect a Northern ExpoÅ¿ition, having but four or five hours of RiÅ¿ing Sun, and as much of the Setting as any other, whether that which Å¿corches it all the Day, or that which Å¿hines upon it but half the Day: And certainly thoÅ¿e kind of hot Climats are not in the leaÅ¿t proper on the South Walls for any of our kernel, or Å¿tone Fruits, which are too tender for it, they are only proper for Orange Trees, Citron Trees, Pomegranets, Figs, and MuÅ¿cats Grapes, &c. of which the greateÅ¿t part of the Leaves muÅ¿t be kept upon the Trees; the other ExpoÅ¿itions will be good enough, for thoÅ¿e tender Fruits which cannot bear that of the South.

After having examin'd the Advantages that may be expected from good ExpoÅ¿itions, let us now conÅ¿ider the Inconveniences that may be fear'd from them; but whereas they are not infallibly attended with them, we muÅ¿t indeed be prepar'd to bear them, but not diÅ¿comforted when they happen, Å¿eeing the impoÅ¿Å¿ibility of a Remedy.

The Southern ExpoÅ¿ition generally Å¿peaking is Å¿ubject to great Winds from the middle of AuguÅ¿t to the middle of October, which often blow down the Fruit, Å¿ome before their being ripe and full grown, and others after their being ripe, which are quite bruis'd by the fall; and thus the beÅ¿t part of the Fruit periÅ¿hes, inÅ¿tead of performing its duty, which is to nouriÅ¿h and recompence the MaÅ¿ter of the Garden; for which reaÅ¿on, in Å¿uch Gardens directly expos'd to the Southern Winds, which otherwiÅ¿e enjoy the Advantages that are Å¿o much valu'd in Gard'ning, Wall Trees are moÅ¿t proper; Dwarfs alÅ¿o defend themÅ¿elves pretty well, but Standards are to be pitty'd, eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch whoÅ¿e Fruit does not Å¿tick faÅ¿t to the Stalk, for inÅ¿tance, Virgoules, Vertelongues, the St. Germains, &c. which are not Å¿o proper for thoÅ¿e ExpoÅ¿ures, as thoÅ¿e that have the power to reÅ¿iÅ¿t better the violence of the Winds; for Example, the Thorn Pears, the Ambrets and LiÅ¿chalÅ¿erie, the dry Martins, &c. or elÅ¿e Å¿tick to the Summer Fruits which are good at the time of their fall, as the Lady Thighs, the Å¿mall MuÅ¿cat Pears, the Blanquets, or whole Pears, the Robins, the RuÅ¿Å¿elets or RuÅ¿Å¿etings, &c.

The EaÅ¿tern ExpoÅ¿ure, though otherwiÅ¿e incomparable, has its Imperfections too Å¿ometimes; In the Spring it is Å¿ubject to North EaÅ¿t Winds, which are dry, cold Winds that wither the Leaves and new Shoots, eÅ¿pecially of Peach-Trees; they likewiÅ¿e often blow down abundance of Kernel and Å¿tone Fruit, and particularly young Figs, at the time that by a reaÅ¿onable Å¿ize they began to give great hopes of plenty; thoÅ¿e Winds are not the only Enemies to that ExpoÅ¿ition, that which likewiÅ¿e is fatal to it, eÅ¿pecially for the EaÅ¿tern Wall Trees, is the not enjoying the benefit of Rains, which Å¿eldom coming but from the WeÅ¿t, cannot reach the foot of the Walls, whereby the Trees are lyable to a mortal drought, unleÅ¿s it be remedy'd by the Expedients explain'd in the TreatiÅ¿e of the Wall Trees.

The WeÅ¿tern ExpoÅ¿ure not only dreads North WeÅ¿t Winds in the Spring, which are Å¿o pernicious for Trees in BloÅ¿Å¿om, and in Autumn the Winds of that SeaÅ¿on, thoÅ¿e great throwers down of Fruit, but alÅ¿o, and that particularly in moiÅ¿t cold Grounds, the great Rains, which being commonly very frequent from the parts where the Sun Sets, often cauÅ¿es great DeÅ¿olations there; whereas on the oher hand, in dry light Earths, thoÅ¿e kind of Å¿howers repair the defects of Å¿terility, and amend the DiÅ¿orders caus'd by too much drought.

As to the Northern ExpoÅ¿ition in relation to Wall Fruit Trees, if on the one Å¿ide it be tolerable for all Summer Fruits, and for Å¿ome in Autumn, on the other Å¿ide, it is very dangerous for the beauty and good taÅ¿te of thoÅ¿e of the Winter; but then again, it is the moÅ¿t advantagious that can be during the great heats for Legumes and Red Fruits, which we would make to hold out, as Straw-berries, Rasberries, Currans, &c. I have likewiÅ¿e explain'd this matter at large in the TreatiÅ¿e of Kitchen-Gardens, as well as in the uÅ¿e that is to be made of every particular Wall in a Garden.

Finally, The reÅ¿ult of this Å¿mall TreatiÅ¿e about the ExpoÅ¿ition, is that all of them have their Perfections and Imperfections; we muÅ¿t endeavour to take our advantage of the firÅ¿t, and uÅ¿e all our InduÅ¿try to defend our Å¿elves from the laÅ¿t.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Of the Third Condition, which requires in our Gardens the Convenience of Waterings.

div.p: NOthing can be more certain, and more univerÅ¿ally granted, than that it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible Aqua nutrix omnium virgultorum, & diverÅ¿os Å¿ingulis uÅ¿us miniÅ¿trat, &c. Ex D. Hieronimo. to have fine and good Gardens, eÅ¿pecially Kitchen Gardens, without being able for a conÅ¿iderable part of the Year to Å¿ecure them from their Mortal Enemy, which is drought; the Spring and Summer are Å¿ubject to great heats and Å¿corchings, and conÅ¿equently the Legumes of the SeaÅ¿on, that Å¿hould be perfect and abounding can yield no pleaÅ¿ure, unleÅ¿s they be greatly moiÅ¿ten'd; they only improve and acquire the Perfections they ought to have, by the Vertue of Water, viz. largeneÅ¿s, thickneÅ¿s, Å¿weetneÅ¿s, and delicacy; therefore I Å¿ay that Legumes are in danger of being always Å¿mall, bitter, hard and inÅ¿ipid, without the help and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of conÅ¿iderable long Rains, which commonly are very uncertain, or elÅ¿e that of great and frequent Waterings, which we ought to be MaÅ¿ters of, and to have at command.

BeÅ¿ides, whatever Rain may fall, which indeed may be favourable to Å¿mall Plants, as Strawberries, Greens, PeaÅ¿e, Beans, Sallad, Onions, &c. There are Å¿till other Plants in our Gardens, which require Å¿omething more, for Example, Artichoks of a year or two's growth, which muÅ¿t be water'd regularly two or three times a week, a Pitcher at a time to every Foot; for if we think that a little Rain is Å¿ufficient to Å¿atisfie our Artichokes, we Å¿hall Å¿oon perceive that we are groÅ¿ly deceiv'd, Gnats will annoy them, the head will remain Å¿mall, hard and dry; and finally, the Suckers will only produce Leaves; the Experience of what is Å¿een among Å¿ubÅ¿tantial Å¿ale Gard'ners, Å¿ufficiently juÅ¿tifies the NeceÅ¿Å¿ity and Importance of Waterings; they Å¿eldom fail watering of their Gardens whatever Rains may fall during the Summer; and indeed their Ware is much finer than that of others who water leÅ¿s.

During Å¿even or eight Months of the Year, there is generally a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Watering all that grows in Kitchen Gardens, AÅ¿paragus only excepted, which only performing their Duty at the Entrance of the Spring are Å¿atisfied with the moiÅ¿tures of the Winter, and want none after the Months of April and May: But whereas thoÅ¿e two Months are the times of BlaÅ¿ting and Drought, there is often a NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of Watering even the new Planted Trees; nay, Å¿ometimes it is good to Water thoÅ¿e, which having brought forth a great Quantity of Green Fruit appear moderately Vigorous, and require Å¿ome help in order to a good Reaping, which they are preparing for us; eÅ¿pecially if the Earth be naturally dry and light, thoÅ¿e Waterings muÅ¿t not be neglected at the Time of the Summer SolÅ¿tice, and they muÅ¿t be renew'd in the Month of AuguÅ¿t, when the Fruits begin to form their Pulp, the SeaÅ¿on being very dry; otherwiÅ¿e they remain Å¿mall, Å¿tony and not pallatable.

From whence it naturally follows, that Water is abÅ¿olutely NeceÅ¿Å¿ary in Gardens, and that plentifully too, in order to perform the NeceÅ¿Å¿ary Waterings they require in due time; for indeed what can be made of any Ground without Water, it will remain altogether uÅ¿eleÅ¿s for Productions, and diÅ¿agreeable to Å¿ight; therefore the beÅ¿t way is to pitch upon Situations that have the Convenience of Water; and whoever does not make that one of Anima mea, Å¿icut terra Å¿ine aqua. PÅ¿al. Reg. his firÅ¿t ConÅ¿iderations, deÅ¿erves blame, or pity.

The moÅ¿t common, and at the Å¿ame time the moÅ¿t wretch'd recourÅ¿e for Waterings is that of Wells: It is true that they are neceÅ¿Å¿ary, when no better can be had, but at leaÅ¿t they Å¿hould be choÅ¿en Å¿hallow, for certainly it is to be fear'd, that the Waterings will be very InconÅ¿iderable, and conÅ¿equently of little uÅ¿e, when the Water is difficult to be drawn up; the advantage of Pumps, though often deceitful, may be look'd upon as Å¿omething in that CaÅ¿e; but the disburthening of Å¿ome Springs or Conduits, a Neighbouring Canal, or a Å¿mall Pond well Å¿tor'd, and well kept with Pipes and Tubs diÅ¿tributed into Å¿everal Squares, are, as it were, the Soul of Vegetation; without it all is dead, or languiÅ¿hes in Gardens, though the Gard'ner be not faulty; but with it the whole Garden muÅ¿t needs be Vigorous, and abounding in every SeaÅ¿on of the Year, which will redound to the Honour of him who has the Management of it, whereas it will utterly DiÅ¿grace Å¿uch as have nothing to plead for an ExcuÅ¿e.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: Of the Fourth Condition, which requires the Garden to be partly upon a level, in all the Surface of it.

div.p: IT is very difficult, nay very rare to meet with Situations that are Å¿o equal in all their Extent, as not to have any RiÅ¿e or Fall on any Å¿ide; but yet it is not impoÅ¿Å¿ible: I do not think it very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to look for any to be as Å¿mooth as Water, but yet it is a happineÅ¿s when Å¿uch are met with; great Inequalities are certainly troubleÅ¿om for Gardens. The Inundations or Overflowings which happen after long Rains, cauÅ¿e cruel DiÅ¿orders in them, and cut out a World of Work to repair them; moderate Inequalities do no great harm, but rather good, eÅ¿pecially in a dry Earth, when inclining to a Wall expos'd to the EaÅ¿t, that part, as we have already Å¿aid, being Å¿eldom Å¿oak'd by the Waters that fall from the Skies; they light moÅ¿t upon the ExpoÅ¿ure of the WeÅ¿t; and thus a fall guiding the Waters towards that EaÅ¿t part, is very favourable.

Therefore, in my Opinion, as much as is poÅ¿Å¿ible, a Å¿ituation that has but a little Inequality is to be preferr'd before another that has much; and if any be tolerable, 'tis only that I have been Å¿peaking of; inÅ¿omuch, that in Gardens that are too much inclinable to Drought, or lie Å¿omewhat high, and are of a perfect Level, it will be proper to allow them a little inequality: For Example, Å¿uch a one as may be Imperceptible, and yet perpetual in all the Walks that lie Southerly, to the end that the Water which is of no UÅ¿e in thoÅ¿e Walks may fall into the Feet of the Trees of thoÅ¿e two ExpoÅ¿itions.

Such an Artificial DeÅ¿cent produces two good Effects, the firÅ¿t in that it is to be wiÅ¿h'd that thoÅ¿e parts may never want a little moiÅ¿ture, in order to Correct their Drought, whether proceeding from the Nature of the Earth and Situation, or from the Heat of the Sun by thoÅ¿e Waters. The Å¿econd is to hinder thoÅ¿e Waters, by that means, from running into Å¿ome other parts of the Garden, where they might prove prejudicial.

But when there is an indiÅ¿penÅ¿able NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of making UÅ¿e of a Situation that is very unequal for a Garden. I explain hereafter in the Thirteenth Chapter what I think proper to be done, in order to Correct the Defects of it, as far as InduÅ¿try can reach.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.p: Of the Fifth Condition, which requires a pleaÅ¿ant Figure for a Garden, together with a well plac'd Entrance.

div.p: IT will not be difficult for me to prove, That the Figure of our Gardens ought to be agreeable; it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary the Eyes Å¿hould meet at firÅ¿t wherewith to be Å¿atisfy'd, without any thing FantaÅ¿tical to offend them: The fineÅ¿t Figure that can be deÅ¿ir'd for a Fruit or Kitchen-Garden, and even the moÅ¿t convenient for Culture, is without doubt that which forms a Beautiful Square, eÅ¿pecially when it is Å¿o perfect, and Å¿o well proportion'd in all its Extent, that not only the Corners may form Å¿treight Angles; but eÅ¿pecially, that the Length may be above once and a half or twice as long again as it is broad: For InÅ¿tance, Twenty Fathom to Ten or Twelve, Fourty to Eighteen or Twenty, or FourÅ¿core to Forty, Fifty or ThreeÅ¿core, &c. For it is moÅ¿t certain, that thoÅ¿e Å¿quare Figures afford the Gard'ner, wherewith to form fine Squares with EaÅ¿e, and to raiÅ¿e fine Beds; there is a great deal of Delight in Å¿eeing true Squares of Stawberries, Artichokes, AÅ¿paragus, &c. great Beds of Charvel, ParÅ¿ly and Sorrel, all very even, Å¿treight, exactly proportion'd out, &c. which cannot be done when the Figure is Irregular, or at leaÅ¿t, not without loÅ¿ing a great deal of Time, when in Å¿ome MeaÅ¿ure, to hide the Deformity of it, he endeavours to find or make Å¿omething approaching to a Square.

Whence it is eaÅ¿ie to conclude, how much I diÅ¿like in the CaÅ¿e of Kitchen-Gardens, all other Indented Figures, Diagonals, Rounds, Ovals, Triangles, &c. which are only proper for Thickets and Parterres, or Flower Gardens, in which Places they are at once both very uÅ¿eful, and of a great Beauty.

I do not queÅ¿tion but all People will be Curious to afford their Gardens the Beautiful Figure now in QueÅ¿tion, when at Liberty to pick and chuÅ¿e. It is a great Vexation
when an ill Neighbourhood reduces us to the NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of Å¿uff'ring imperfect Figures, Inlets, and unequal Å¿ides, &c. Happy are thoÅ¿e who meet with kind obliging Neighbours; Wo to them who meet with Å¿uch as are croÅ¿s and ill natur'd.

Although the Figure of an Oblong Right Angled Square, be the moÅ¿t proper, yet I have made a fine Kitchen Garden of one hundred and ten ToiÅ¿es or Fathoms in length, and Å¿ixty broad, Å¿omewhat reÅ¿embling the Figure A of a Lozenge; and whereas I have diÅ¿pos'd the chief Entrance in the middle of the narroweÅ¿t Å¿ide, it is not eaÅ¿ie to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the Å¿mall Irregularity a Geometritian would Å¿ind in it, and it is a very neceÅ¿Å¿ary Precaution to conceal as much as is poÅ¿Å¿ible, certain inconÅ¿iderable defects, which are met with in the Å¿pace of a Garden, and to diÅ¿poÅ¿e the Ally's, and the diviÅ¿ion of the Squares or Plats, as if the Ground was exactly of a Square Figure; for though neither the Angles or the four Å¿ides are perfectly equal, it does not hinder the Plats from appearing perfect in their Proportion.

Moreover, for the better Ornament of our Kitchen Garden, eÅ¿pecially if it be large, it is proper that the Entrance Å¿hould be plac'd juÅ¿t in the middle of that part which has moÅ¿t Extent, as it appears by the Figure at the Point A in order to face an Alley, which conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of the whole length of the Garden, may appear Å¿tately, and divide the Ground into two equal parts; each of thoÅ¿e parts, compoÅ¿ing Squares or Plats too long in proportion to their breadth, muÅ¿t afterwards be Å¿ubdivided into other Å¿mall parts, if neceÅ¿Å¿ary; the Entrance would not look Å¿o well in the middle of one of the broadeÅ¿t Å¿ides, as it appears by the Figure B. a long ProÅ¿pect, moderately broad on both Å¿ides is much more pleaÅ¿ing; than to have a long one on the Å¿ides, and a Å¿hort one before; however, it is Å¿ometimes impoÅ¿Å¿ible to diÅ¿poÅ¿e the Entrance otherwiÅ¿e, and in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e we muÅ¿t have Patience, and the Å¿ame when we are neceÅ¿Å¿itated to make it in one of the Corners, or thereabouts, though it be not Å¿o well; yet I have made very fine Gardens, which have their Entrance in one of the Corners, which I would not have done, had the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the Ground permitted me to place it better; and yet no body finds fault with it, by reaÅ¿on that it faces a fine Alley, which is border'd all along by one of the great EÅ¿paliers, or Walls full of Fruit, which is very agreeable to the Å¿ight, when it is kept in good Order, Å¿uch is the Entrance of the Kitchen-Garden of Rambouillet.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: Of the Å¿ixth Condition which requires a Garden to be well enclos'd with Walls and Doors that Å¿hut well.

div.p: THIS IncloÅ¿ure, I deÅ¿ire, Å¿ufficiently teÅ¿tifies, that for Fruit and Kitchen Gardens I am not very deÅ¿irous of thoÅ¿e open ProÅ¿pects which are Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary for other Gardens; not but when the Situation will permit, I am very glad to enjoy the benefit of it. But that which I deÅ¿ire above all things, is that my Garden may be Å¿ecur'd from Foreign as well as DomeÅ¿tick Thieves, and that the Eye may be Å¿o delighted in Å¿urveying all the things that Å¿hould be in it, that there may be no room left to wiÅ¿h for any thing beÅ¿ides to divert it.

A Wall well garniÅ¿h'd, Dwarfs well order'd, and very vigorous; all manner of fine good Fruits of every SeaÅ¿on, fine Beds, and fine Plats, well furniÅ¿h'd with all manner of neceÅ¿Å¿ary Legumes, clean Walks, of a proportionable largeneÅ¿s, fine Bordures, fill'd with uÅ¿eful things for the HouÅ¿e: In fine, a well contriv'd diverÅ¿ity of all that is neceÅ¿Å¿ary in a Kitchen Garden; Å¿o that nothing may be wanting, either early or late, or for the abundance of the middle SeaÅ¿ons; theÅ¿e indeed are the things we ought to covet in our Gardens, and not a Steeple, or Wood in PerÅ¿pective, a great Road, or the Neighbourhood of ãâã R â¢ v â¢ r. In my Opinion, the Cloth as it were, Å¿hould always be laid in a fine Garden, without mattering to Å¿ee what paÅ¿Å¿es in the open Fields.

A Kitchen Garden might have the fineÅ¿t ProÅ¿pect in the World, and yet appear to me very ugly in it Å¿elf, if wanting any thing of what it Å¿hould have, inÅ¿tead of finding it ãâ¦ã re, I Å¿hould be neceÅ¿Å¿itated to go without it, or to have recourÅ¿e to my Neighbours, or my PurÅ¿e.

So that preferably to all manner of ProÅ¿pects, I would have my Garden inclos'd with Walls, though I were to loÅ¿e Å¿ome fine point of ProÅ¿pect by it, beÅ¿ides that the Å¿helter they may afford againÅ¿t troubleÅ¿ome Winds, and Spring FroÅ¿ts, are very conÅ¿iderable: It is almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible to be truly delighted with a Garden, as for inÅ¿tance, to have early Legumes and fine Fruits without the help of thoÅ¿e Walls; beÅ¿ides, there are Å¿till many things, which dreading great heats, would hardly be able to grow in the hotteÅ¿t part of the Summer, unleÅ¿s a Wall expos'd to the North favour'd them with Å¿ome Å¿hadow.

In effect, Walls are Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary for Gardens, that even to multiply them, I make as many little Gardens as I can in the Neighbourhood of the great one, whereby I have not only more Wall-Fruit or EÅ¿paliers, and Å¿helter, which is very conÅ¿iderable; but am alÅ¿o thereby enabled to correct Å¿ome defects and Irregularities, which would render the Garden deÅ¿agreeable; for in fine, I will at any rate have a principal Garden, that may pleaÅ¿e in its Figure and Å¿ize, deÅ¿ign'd for large Legumes, and Å¿ome high Standards; a large Garden would without doubt be leÅ¿s pleaÅ¿ing, if for InÅ¿tance, it were too long for its breadth, or too wide for its length, if it had a corner, or Å¿ome viÅ¿ible wrineÅ¿s to disfigure it, which being retrench'd, would make all the reÅ¿t Å¿quare; and thus Å¿uch Gardens being leÅ¿Å¿en'd either on one, or on both ends, will afford ground to make little agreeable uÅ¿eful Gardens, as I have done in many great HouÅ¿es, in the Neighbourhood of Paris.

BeÅ¿ides the IncloÅ¿ure of the Walls, I am likewiÅ¿e for having good Locks to my Doors, that my Gard'ner may be able to anÅ¿wer for all that is in the Garden; I am Å¿enÅ¿ible that there are Å¿ome, who are very diÅ¿creet and careful, but then I likewiÅ¿e know that there are others who deÅ¿ire nothing more than to have Å¿ome Pretences.

div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.p: Of the laÅ¿t Condition, which requires that both the Fruit and Kitchen-Garden, Å¿hould not be far diÅ¿tant from the HouÅ¿e, and that the coming to it Å¿hould be eaÅ¿ie and convenient.

div.p: I Am not ignorant that the Countrey affords large and moderate HouÅ¿es, of which the firÅ¿t may be accompany'd with Å¿everal Gardens, and the other Å¿atisfy'd with one only.

As to thoÅ¿e which may have Å¿everal Gardens, it is proper that thoÅ¿e that are deÅ¿ign'd for Flowers and Shrubs, I mean the Parterres, Å¿hould face the principal AÅ¿pect of the HouÅ¿e, Å¿ince nothing can be more agreeable than to Å¿ee at all times on that Å¿ide the charming variety of a SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of Flowers whatever they be; they are Å¿o many different Scenes, or Decorations upon a Stage, of which the Figure never alters, they afford perpetual matter to delight the Eye, and charm us with their Sweets; but whereas generally thoÅ¿e Parterres are as publick, and as open to every body as the very Court of the HouÅ¿e, it is not fit to put any thing into them, the loÅ¿s whereof might diÅ¿compoÅ¿e us.

For theÅ¿e ReaÅ¿ons I allow that in Å¿uch HouÅ¿es, the Fruit and Kitchen-Garden Å¿hould not be Situated in the beÅ¿t Place, beÅ¿ides the laÅ¿t being Å¿ubject to have many things, which though neceÅ¿Å¿ary, are not always pleaÅ¿ing to the Eye or Smell; as alÅ¿o producing many things, deÅ¿ign'd for the PleaÅ¿ure and Satisfaction of the MaÅ¿ter, which might tempt Å¿ome licouriÅ¿h indiÅ¿creet PerÅ¿ons, and Å¿o occaÅ¿ion cauÅ¿e of DiÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure and Complaint, I think it very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to place thoÅ¿e Gardens out of the reach of the Publick.

Therefore as much as can be, we content our Å¿elves with placing them in the beÅ¿t Ground we can meet with, without prejudicing the place of the Parterre, pretty near to Optima Å¿tercoratio veÅ¿tigia domini. Ex Plntarch. the HouÅ¿e, being of a convenient eaÅ¿ie AcceÅ¿s; the Ancients were of this Sentiment, when they Å¿aid, that the Steps of the MaÅ¿ter, that is, his frequent ViÅ¿its, were of wonderful uÅ¿e for the NeatneÅ¿s, Abundance, GoodneÅ¿s and Beauty of Gardens; Å¿o that Gardens that are at a diÅ¿tance, or of difficult AcceÅ¿s, are liable to DiÅ¿orders, Filth and Sterility, &c.

I hope that whereas in the beginning of this Work, I have preÅ¿um'd to Å¿ay, that none ought to pretend to have one of our Gardens, unleÅ¿s he were paÅ¿Å¿ably well skill'd in the Culture of it; none will undertake to make one, unleÅ¿s he may be able to afford himÅ¿elf the PleaÅ¿ure of Å¿eeing it well Cultivated, and conÅ¿equently he will deÅ¿ire to Å¿ee it often, which cannot be done, the Garden being at a diÅ¿tance, or of a difficult AcceÅ¿s.

As to the HouÅ¿es, that can no wiÅ¿e afford above one Garden, I Å¿uppoÅ¿e it will hardly enter into any ones Thoughts to employ it wholly in Box or Bowling-Greens, inÅ¿tead of Imploying it in Fruits and Legumes: In Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, whether in the Town or Country, the Å¿pace of the Garden being reaÅ¿onably large, it will be proper to take part of that which is neareÅ¿t to make a Å¿mall Parterre, leaving the reÅ¿t for things that are of uÅ¿e and neceÅ¿Å¿ary; but if the Place be not large, my Advice is to make no Parterre; at leaÅ¿t I would make none, being perÅ¿uaded, that Flowers may be eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿pens'd with; reÅ¿olving then to employ ones Ground in Plants that are for uÅ¿e; that part of the Kitchen-Garden which is moÅ¿t pleaÅ¿ing, ought to be put moÅ¿t within Å¿ight of the HouÅ¿e, keeping Å¿uch as might offend the Sight or Smell, moÅ¿t at diÅ¿tance: Fine EÅ¿paliers, Dwarfs, Greens, Artichokes, Sallads and the perpetual Action of the Gard'ners, &c. being Å¿ufficient to employ the Neighbourhood of Å¿ome Windows, even for pretty conÅ¿iderable HouÅ¿es, as well as for ordinary ones.

I am Å¿o Å¿enÅ¿ible of the innocent PleaÅ¿ure, the Å¿ight of a fine Kitchen-Garden can afford, that I am for making Å¿ome fine Arbor in all large Gardens, not only to Å¿erve for Å¿helter in caÅ¿e of a Å¿udden Storm, which happens pretty often, but alÅ¿o for the Satisfaction of conveniently Å¿eeing the Culture of a Ground that is well employ'd.
NotwithÅ¿tanding all I have Å¿aid, I do not condemn thoÅ¿e, who having but a very Å¿mall Garden, affect Flowers, their Inclination leading them to it preferably to any other Plants.

Having Å¿aid what is to be wiÅ¿h'd for, when People are at liberty to chooÅ¿e the Place of a Garden, let us now conÅ¿ider what is to be done when within the Dependency of a HouÅ¿e, we find our Å¿elves reduc'd and neceÅ¿Å¿itated to make uÅ¿e of any Place, whatever it may be, regular or irregular, good, indifferent or bad; and let us follow the Å¿ame Order we have obÅ¿erv'd in the pretended choice I have explain'd.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

argument.p: Of what is to be done to correct a Defective Ground, either as to the Quality of the Earth, or the Lack of a Å¿ufficient Quantity.

div.p: WHereas the moÅ¿t material Article for Fruit and Kitchen-Gardens is to have a good Ground, if notwithÅ¿tanding the Ground where this Garden is to be Å¿ituated Å¿hould have Å¿ome conÅ¿iderable Defect, which might be corrected, I think I Å¿hould be blame-worthy to go on without explaining my Å¿elf upon what I think proper to be done in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e; in my Opinion, thoÅ¿e kind of Defects may be reduc'd particularly to Five.

list.item: The FirÅ¿t, is a very bad Earth.
The Third, a pretty good Earth, but not enough of it.
The Fourth, to have no Earth at all.
The Fifth and LaÅ¿t, That though never Å¿o good, the too great MoiÅ¿ture it may be Å¿ubject to, may render it incapable of Improvment by the Culture of a Skilful Gard'ner.

div.p: As to the firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, I cannot forbear pitying thoÅ¿e who Å¿tart Å¿o Ill, as to make a Garden in a place where the Ground is abÅ¿olutely defective, eÅ¿pecially if there were any poÅ¿Å¿ibility of placing it better. FirÅ¿t, I pity them, by reaÅ¿on of the great charge they expoÅ¿e themÅ¿elves to, which I dread of all things, eÅ¿pecially in Fruit and Kitchen-Gardens, being perÅ¿waded that the property of thoÅ¿e Gardens is to coÅ¿t little, and to yield much. Secondly, I pity them for the Å¿mall SucceÅ¿s, that infallibly attends Å¿uch an undertaking, eÅ¿pecially when thoÅ¿e Works that are neceÅ¿Å¿ary there, are only perform'd by halves: I wiÅ¿h none of the Curious may be expos'd to Å¿uch HardÅ¿hips; but yet Å¿uppoÅ¿ing an unavoidable NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of falling into the firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, to make a Garden in a very bad Ground, let us conÅ¿ider what remedy may be apply'd to it, and finally endeavour to make this Garden with as few Defects, and as Å¿mall a Charge as can be poÅ¿Å¿ible.

FirÅ¿t then, if the Earth be abÅ¿olutely defective, either in Å¿tinking or being abÅ¿olute Loam or Clay, or Å¿uch as is dug out of Quarries, or elÅ¿e Stony, Gravelly and full of Pebbles; or, laÅ¿tly, being only dry Sand of any Colour, but Å¿till as unfruitful as the Sand of Rivers, and yet as high as to the Surface, as can be deÅ¿ir'd for a Garden. I will explain hereafter what I mean by that height.

I Å¿ay, if this Earth happen to have any of theÅ¿e Defects, I know no better Expedient than to have it altogether taken away, in order to Å¿ucceed, and that within the Depth of three Foot in Å¿uch Places as are to be the chief Ornaments of the Gardens; viz. the Trees and long Rooted Plants, and two large Foot where the leÅ¿Å¿er Plants are to be, filling it up again with the Å¿ame quantity of the beÅ¿t Mould that can conveniently be brought to it; which being done, one may reÅ¿t Å¿atisfy'd for a long while, all will go well, without the trouble of any other Amendments; but in caÅ¿e Å¿o much good Mould as would be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to put every where, could not conveniently be had; at leaÅ¿t it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to endeavour to get as much as may Å¿erve for the Trees, making a Å¿hift with indifferent good Mould for the reÅ¿t of the Garden, that is, for Kitchen-Plants, it will not be difficult to amend it, as Å¿hall be declar'd hereafter.

I am Å¿enÅ¿ible, that the Charge of great TranÅ¿portations, frightens, eÅ¿pecially in the caÅ¿e of large Gardens, but then 'tis but Å¿eldom that People engage themÅ¿elves to the NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of it; thoÅ¿e are works for Kings, the Kitchen Garden of VerÅ¿ailles is a terrible InÅ¿tance of it: But as for Å¿mall City Gardens, the occaÅ¿ions of doing it are often met with, and whereas the Expence of it is not too great, the Undertaking of it is very tollerable. This then is all that is to be done, when the Surface of the Garden is no higher than it ought to be, and has no other Defect than the ill Quality of the Ground.

In order to Explain my Å¿elf as to this height, I Å¿uppoÅ¿e that the Matter in Hand only relates to the Garden that is immediately next the HouÅ¿e, for which it is, and no wiÅ¿e for others, which Lying at a greater diÅ¿tance do not want Å¿o much precaution; now, in my Opinion, this firÅ¿t Garden ought to lie Å¿omewhat lower than the HouÅ¿e, and thus the HouÅ¿e being upon a higher Ground, it ought to have a BalluÅ¿tre with Å¿ome Steps to come down into that Garden, which is an Ornament to be wiÅ¿h'd for in Å¿uch OccaÅ¿ions, and without doubt Å¿uch an aÅ¿Å¿ent of Two or Three Foot above the Surface of the Garden, renders it much more pleaÅ¿ant to Sight, than it would be, if it lay level with the Å¿tep of the Door, and conÅ¿equently much finer than thoÅ¿e that lay higher than the level or floor; which require an aÅ¿Å¿ent, and are thereby liable to great Inconveniences.

I return to the other CaÅ¿es heretofore propos'd to Å¿ay, That in caÅ¿e Å¿uch a Place full of ill Earth, were too low, of about Five or Six Foot in Surface, it is viÅ¿ible that half the Expence would be Å¿av'd, Å¿ince there would only be a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of raiÅ¿ing it higher, without taking any of it away; but however we muÅ¿t Å¿till reckon firÅ¿t on the Å¿mall deÅ¿cent the Garden ought to be Å¿ituated upon, in relation to the HouÅ¿e; and, Å¿econdly upon the Three Foot of Earth that muÅ¿t be brought thither, particularly for the Trees and large Plants, and in order not to be miÅ¿taken, it will be proper to meaÅ¿ure that Earth upon the place where it is to be taken with a rul'd Gage, by reaÅ¿on that this height of Three Foot, as it lies, being newly Å¿tir'd, will at firÅ¿t appear to make a greater DimenÅ¿ion, which afterwards being Å¿ettled will reduce it Å¿elf to the height propos'd, which I hold to be abÅ¿olutely neccÅ¿Å¿ary, and unleÅ¿s care has been taken to meaÅ¿ure the Earth before the moving of it, People muÅ¿t not flatter themÅ¿elves that there will be enough, unleÅ¿s there be Four Foot or thereabouts in the firÅ¿t Months, which the Rains and Time will Å¿oon reduce to Three; otherwiÅ¿e, having had but Three Foot at firÅ¿t, they will Å¿oon find it dwindled to Two at moÅ¿t; that is too little by a Foot: And thus People will be expos'd to the Vexationof Å¿eeing all their Trees periÅ¿h at the end of a few Years, and to be reduc'd to begin a new, if they continu'd in the mind of mkaing their Trees Å¿ucceed.

In the Neighbourhood of great Cities, great Conveniences may Å¿ometimes be met with to raiÅ¿e and fill up places in Gardens without much coÅ¿t, 'tis only allowing the Liberty of throwing the RubbiÅ¿h of the Foundations of HouÅ¿es there; but often Å¿uch Conveniences coÅ¿t a great deal of Time, which in the CaÅ¿e of Planting is much to be fear'd, and even coÅ¿ts a great deal of Money to have it Å¿ifted, otherwiÅ¿e the Garden will be in danger of having more Stones and ill Sand than real Earth, and conÅ¿equently the Owner of having an ill Garden; upon which every one may conÅ¿ult his PurÅ¿e and PleaÅ¿ure, and regulate himÅ¿elf accordingly.

The AnÅ¿wer I have made to the firÅ¿t Article, relating to a very ill Earth, where a Garden is deÅ¿ign'd, may likewiÅ¿e Å¿erve for the Fourth, in which we Å¿uppoÅ¿e a place for a Garden without any Earth at all; Three Foot of good Earth muÅ¿t be brought to it, getting it as near hand as can be to Å¿ave Money.

In the Second CaÅ¿e, in which the Ground having a Å¿ufficient depth, the Earth is notwithÅ¿tanding but Indifferent; that is, either a little too dry and light, or a little too tough and moiÅ¿t, which are the two common Defects; or elÅ¿e, that there may be cauÅ¿e to judge it too much â¢ orn or exhauÅ¿ted: In Å¿uch caÅ¿es, immediate care muÅ¿t be taken to mend it, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing one deÅ¿igns to have Å¿uch Things in it as good Earth produces; the beÅ¿t of all Remedies is Å¿till to mix Å¿ome new Earth with it, with this precaution, to mix loamy Earth with that as is light, and Å¿andy Mould with that as is tough; and, in fine, to take Å¿uch as is really good, to mix with that which is worn out or exhauÅ¿ted, unleÅ¿s you deÅ¿ign to give it time to amend it Å¿elf by ReÅ¿t: And in caÅ¿e, as I have already Å¿aid in the firÅ¿t Article, there be no Å¿ufficient convenience to get Mould enough for the whole Garden, it will be proper to begin with the place for the Trees which requires it moÅ¿t; and for the reÅ¿t, recourÅ¿e muÅ¿t be had to the common Amendments for Kitchen-Plants.

Thirdly, When the Earth is really good; but yet there is not enough of it to accompliÅ¿h Three Foot depth, two ConÅ¿iderations are to be had; the firÅ¿t to examine whether the Surface be of a proper height or not: When it is of a proper height, all that is nought in the Ground muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be removed, whether Sand, Gravel or Stones, putting as much good Mould in the Room of it, as will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to have the depth requir'd, Å¿till preÅ¿erving our Height.

Therefore the Å¿ame Operation muÅ¿t be perform'd, in removing all that is bad under good Earth, when the Surface being, too high compar'd to the level of the HouÅ¿e, there is a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Å¿inking it, in order to be one Å¿tep higher than the level of the Garden; upon which all People may eaÅ¿ily regulate themÅ¿elves, to do it more or leÅ¿s according to the Exigencies of their Ground and its wants; but Å¿till, keeping to the quantity of good Earth propos'd, as well as to the diÅ¿tance that muÅ¿t be from the Surface of the Garden to the Door which Å¿erves for an Entrance into it.

The Earth being according to our WiÅ¿hes, both as to quantity and goodneÅ¿s, and yet too low in the Surface; we muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e examin how much too low it lyes, in order to raiÅ¿e it conformably to our Wants and WiÅ¿hes; it might chance to lay Å¿o low, that there would be a neceÅ¿Å¿ity to raiÅ¿e it conÅ¿iderably above three Foot, in which caÅ¿e all the good Earth muÅ¿t be dug up, and laid aÅ¿ide, and the bottom rais'd Å¿ufficiently with what ever could be got good or bad; after which the good Earth muÅ¿t be laid over it again with the management and mixture heretofore explain'd. I could wiÅ¿h I had better Expedients to propoÅ¿e to avoid the Charges of TranÅ¿portation; but truly I know none.

There now remains to Examine what is to be done in the fifth CaÅ¿e, to correct the over great MoiÅ¿tures Å¿ome Gardens are Å¿ubject to, which rot every thing, and make the Production not only backward, but alÅ¿o inÅ¿ipid and bad; none but hot and dry Earths are forward; thoÅ¿e that are moiÅ¿t are always cold, and conÅ¿equently have no diÅ¿poÅ¿ition for At Å¿celeratum exquirere frigus difficile eÅ¿t. Georg. 2. Labor omnia vincit improbus, &c. Virg. Georg. 1. Novelties. This cold which is inÅ¿eparable from MoiÅ¿ture, is of all defects the moÅ¿t difficult to be cur'd: The Ancients knew it as well as we do, and have given it the Name of Deceiver. But Å¿till Å¿ince Earth has been Å¿ubmitted to the InduÅ¿try of Man, and that there are but few things labour cannot overcome; let us declare what a long Experience has taught us in this CaÅ¿e.
MoiÅ¿tures are either natural and perpetual in Earth, or only accidental and paÅ¿Å¿ing; in the firÅ¿t caÅ¿e we have two Expedients:

The firÅ¿t is, to turn aÅ¿ide at a diÅ¿tance, if poÅ¿Å¿ible, by Conduits or Gutters, the Waters that annoy us, and give them a diÅ¿charge to remove them from us, which being done, the Ground will not fail becoming dry; and when the firÅ¿t is impracticable,

The Å¿econd is, To raiÅ¿e the whole Plats, or only the great Beds upon Ridges, and to that end make deep Furrows to Å¿erve for kind of Paths: The Earth that is taken from thence will Å¿erve to raiÅ¿e the Plats or Beds.

But if thoÅ¿e MoiÅ¿tures are only TranÅ¿itory, and, for InÅ¿tance, only occaÅ¿ion'd by great Rains, and the nature of the Ground not proper to Å¿oak them in, recourÅ¿e muÅ¿t be had to the Å¿ame Expedient of raiÅ¿ing of the Earth to drain them, and to the making of Conduits or Gutters to carry thoÅ¿e Waters out of the Garden.

Finally, The MoiÅ¿ture not being extraordinary, the contrary of what we have preÅ¿crib'd for very dry Grounds muÅ¿t be done, that is, the Earth muÅ¿t be rais'd a little higher than the Walks, to the end that thoÅ¿e Walks may Å¿erve as a drain to thoÅ¿e elevated Beds, juÅ¿t as in the other CaÅ¿e the haughing of the Borders Å¿erves as a drain to receive and improve by the Waters of the adjacent Walks.

In order to raiÅ¿e Grounds, nothing can be better than what we have Å¿aid to raiÅ¿e the Surface; and in caÅ¿e Conveniences be wanting for the TranÅ¿portation of Earth, having abundance of great Dung at hand, it may be us'd inÅ¿tead of it, as I have Å¿aid about the Kitchen-Garden of VerÅ¿ailles, mixing it abundantly at the bottom of the Ground, or underneath the Earth, in order to raiÅ¿e it as much as is neceÅ¿Å¿ary; but Å¿till great Conduits are of great uÅ¿e.

I conclude what relates to the Preparation of Å¿uch Grounds as are defective, either in their quality, or too Å¿mall quantity, carefully exhorting thoÅ¿e who dig the Ground along Å¿ome Walls, to take care firÅ¿t not to approach too near the Foundations, and to leave always Å¿ome Å¿olid Banck undug, leÅ¿t the Wall might tumble down by its own weight, or by Å¿ome unexpected Å¿howers. I exhort in the Å¿econd place to fill up Å¿uch Trenches immediately after their being empty'd, or rather at the very Å¿ame time, one part after another; for want of which, and for the Å¿ame ReaÅ¿ons, the danger of tumbling is yet greater.

After having examin'd what relates to the Conditions that are neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the Fruit and Kitchen-Gardens that are to be made, viz. The quality and quantity of good Earth, the happy Situation, and favourable ExpoÅ¿ure, the convenience of Waterings, the level of the Ground, the Figure, Entrance and CloÅ¿ure of the Garden, together with the Proximity of the Place; having alÅ¿o propos'd the means to correct the defects of Drought and MoiÅ¿ture, there Å¿till remains to Å¿peak upon the Subject of the Acclivities and Declivities, when they are too Å¿leep for the Gardens we are abÅ¿olutely compell'd to chooÅ¿e.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

argument.p: Concerning the Acclivities and Declivities of every Garden.

div.p: WE have already Å¿aid what is to be wiÅ¿h'd for certain Inequalities, that may be favourable in Gardens, and InÅ¿inuated what is to be fear'd from the Inconveniences of the great ones; let us now Å¿peak of what may be proper to remedy Å¿uch as may be corrected; In order to which, as Å¿oon as the Place of the Garden is reÅ¿olv'd on, upon the ConÅ¿iderations heretofore eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, the Figure being either very Å¿quare, Å¿o that the Sides and Angles may be altogether, or at leaÅ¿t partly Equal and Parallel, which is moÅ¿t to be wiÅ¿h'd for; or elÅ¿e Irregular, the Angles or Sides being unequal, or having perhaps more or leÅ¿s than four Sides or Angles, both the one and the other differing in themÅ¿elves, either in length or overture, &c. are Defects fit to be avoided, if poÅ¿Å¿ible, or at leaÅ¿t endeavours muÅ¿t be us'd to rectifie them.

The Place of the Garden being, I Å¿ay, reÅ¿olv'd upon, either Voluntarily or out of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity, the EncloÅ¿ure muÅ¿t not be begun, until after having taken the Level of all the Ground, to know all the Acclivities and Declivities, in order to take MeaÅ¿ures accordingly; otherwiÅ¿e one might fall into many great Inconveniences, either as to the Walls that are to be made, or in reÅ¿pect to the Allies and Squares.

It is moÅ¿t certain; that every piece of Ground may chance to have different RiÅ¿ings and Falls, viz. One, Two or Three for as many Å¿ides; and One for every Diagonal: And 'tis almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible to know the true Level of a Garden, without having firÅ¿t taken, and afterwards regulated all the Inequalities.

The Diagonals, to Å¿peak more Intelligibly in Favour of Å¿ome Gard'ners, are, as it were, the two Arms of a St. Andrew's CroÅ¿s, which may and ought to be figur'd by Trenches carried from Corner to Corner a croÅ¿s Å¿ome Place.

There is no neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Å¿aying, that the Level of thoÅ¿e Inequalities are always taken from the higheÅ¿t part of the piece that is to be Level'd, to go to the loweÅ¿t which is oppoÅ¿ite to it, no Body being ignorant of it. Thus the Level of the Diagonals is taken, beginning from Corner, or Angle, to go to a lower oppoÅ¿ite Corner: For InÅ¿tance, the Diagonal A. B. begins at a Corner or Angles, which is form'd by the meeting of two Å¿ides, whereof the one is expos'd to the EaÅ¿t, and the other to the South, to go to a lower oppoÅ¿ite Å¿ide, which is form'd by the meeting of the Å¿ide expos'd to the WeÅ¿t, and the Å¿ide expos'd to the North; the other Diagonal Å¿hall be drawn from the one to the other of the two Corners, or Angles, C. D. which remain in the Figure we are examining, and is mark'd here. The
Level of the ExpoÅ¿ure is taken all along every Å¿ide, beginning, as we have Å¿aid, from the higheÅ¿t part to come to the loweÅ¿t.

In order to take every Level very true, it muÅ¿t be done upon a very Å¿treight Line, which Å¿hall be drawn either along the Å¿ide that is to be level'd, which is the beÅ¿t; or upon another Line very Parallel to that Å¿ide.

Every Level to be pretty true, though not Å¿o true as that of the Water of Fountains, in which even half a Line is very material; but, in fine, to be Å¿ufficient for the uÅ¿e now in queÅ¿tion, every Level, I Å¿ay, muÅ¿t be taken with the Rule and Leveller, which every body knows is a Triangular InÅ¿trument with a Lead, or other little Bowl hung to a Å¿mall
Cord, and that fix'd to the obtuÅ¿e Angle; this Leveller being fix'd upon the Rule, this Å¿mall Cord muÅ¿t meet the notch that is made on purpoÅ¿e, both on the Top of that Angle, and upon the middle point of the Å¿ide that Å¿erves for a BaÅ¿is to that InÅ¿trument, inÅ¿omuch, that that Level is never true until that Cord with its Lead naturally falls into thoÅ¿e Notches.

This is the manner of performing this Operation, which I might, perhaps, Å¿ave my Å¿elf the trouble of Explaining, it being already Explain'd in Å¿o many Books of Mathematicks and Mechanicks; but our Gard'ner perhaps having none of them, will be Å¿atisfy'd with what I Å¿hall tell him.

BeÅ¿ides the Leveller and the Rule, which muÅ¿t be very Å¿treight, and about Two or Three Fathom long, there muÅ¿t be three wooden Spikes to be driven into the Ground with a Mallet; and thoÅ¿e three Spikes muÅ¿t be of a very even equal length, about Three or Four Foot, all Å¿plit on the Top, in order to put white Paper in that Å¿lit.

I Å¿hould not need to Å¿ay (it being evident of it Å¿elf) That there muÅ¿t be at leaÅ¿t Three or Four PerÅ¿ons, that is, Three while the Rule and Leveller are us'd, and Four when it comes to the Spikes; one of theÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons muÅ¿t in all CaÅ¿es Å¿tand on the loweÅ¿t part of the Å¿ide that is to be Levell'd, holding a Perch to Å¿erve for a Mark, in order to raiÅ¿e or louer the Å¿aid Perch, according to the Direction of him who is to regulate the Line and Leveller.

To find the Level: Having choÅ¿en a calm Day without Wind and Rain, and, if poÅ¿Å¿ible, a little lou'ring; or, at leaÅ¿t, being Å¿o plac'd, that the great brightneÅ¿s of the Sun may not prejudice the Sight, one of theÅ¿e Spikes muÅ¿t be driven into the Ground even to the Surface, which muÅ¿t remain, and another in a Å¿treight Line a little below it; in order to place the Rule immediately and conveniently upon it, which being done, the Leveller muÅ¿t be put upon the Rule, raiÅ¿ing or Å¿inking the Å¿econd Spike, until the Lead falls directly, and of it Å¿elf, without any Motion of the Wind, or any thing elÅ¿e into the Notches.

This being perform'd, the Å¿econd Spike muÅ¿t be abÅ¿olutely fix'd, and the Leveller remov'd, after which, lying flat upon the Ground, one may aim or level with the Eye upon the Rule Å¿o fix'd and order'd towards the PerÅ¿on who holds the Perch below with a white or black Cloth on the Top of it, who perhaps may have had occaÅ¿ion to climb upon a Ladder, Wall or Tree, to raiÅ¿e or louer the Å¿aid Perch according to the direction of the Leveller, and that until the Extremity of it, having been obÅ¿erv'd by the Å¿aid Leveller, a Calculation may be made exactly how many Foot or Fathoms there are in a direct Perpendicular Line from that Extremity, which is the Top of the Perch or Spike, unto the natural Surface of the Ground, which lies immediately beneath the Å¿aid Perch, &c.

And whereas the poÅ¿ture of lying down is too Inconvenient; the Ground may and ought to be dug near the firÅ¿t Spike that is driven into the Ground, low enough for any one to level with the Eye, Å¿tanding, Å¿itting or kneeling in it; or elÅ¿e uÅ¿e may be made of two of the Spikes heretofore mention'd, to which end they muÅ¿t be plac'd aÅ¿under upon two others that are fix'd into the Ground, or upon Å¿ome other piece of Wood, or riÅ¿ing Ground made on purpoÅ¿e, where they muÅ¿t be kept very upright, after which the Rule muÅ¿t be plac'd upon the Å¿aid Å¿ticks, examining with the Leveller, whether the Rule lies
upon a true level, in order to level or aim with the Eye, and when there is occaÅ¿ion for a third perÅ¿on, and conÅ¿equently for a third Å¿tick, they muÅ¿t be plac'd with the Å¿ame ExactneÅ¿s as the two firÅ¿t; the third being plac'd at any diÅ¿tance whatever, having a piece of Linen, or Paper, or a Hat upon the top of that Å¿pike, Å¿erves to aim more conveniently; Å¿o that having met at the End of the proÅ¿pect, the extremity of the perch or Å¿tick that is held below, the borrow'd height of the Å¿ticks, as well as the height of the Rule, muÅ¿t be deduc'd upon the whole, and thus the Level will prove true. For InÅ¿tance, in aiming, Twelve Foot may be found from the top of the Perch to the Surface of the Earth, out of which may be deduc'd firÅ¿t the four borrow'd Foot of the Å¿ticks, upon the Top of which the Leveller had laid his Rule, for which muÅ¿t alÅ¿o be deduc'd Three or Four Inches, which altogether amounts to Four Foot, and Four Inches; by which Supputation will be found Å¿even Foot and Eight Inches declivity from that part of the Surface which is regulated, and to remain, from whence the Leveller aim'd, to the Surface of that part, where the laÅ¿t Å¿pike Å¿tuck, the level of which is look'd for.
TheÅ¿e Inequalities are either ConÅ¿iderable, or not.

ThoÅ¿e that are InconÅ¿iderable are tolerable; for InÅ¿tance, only half an Inch or an Inch and a half in a Fathom, which hardly wants, being corrected, if the Expence will amount to any thing conÅ¿iderable; Å¿o that a declivity of about a Foot or Two, or Two and a half to a length of Twenty Fathom, will do no great harm, and would hardly be perceptible, being only of half an Inch, or an Inch and half in a Fathom: Which ought to comfort one, eÅ¿pecially if there be a great length, Å¿ince a declivity of Twelve or Fifteen Foot upon FourÅ¿core Fathom in length, though pernicious, is not Å¿o Å¿enÅ¿ible nor inconvenient as one of Two Foot and a half upon Twenty Fathom, although the proportion be altogether equal.

If a deÅ¿cent of two, or two Inches and a half per Fathom is conÅ¿iderable, what would it be if there were three, four, five, or more, then it muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be corrected, which may be done four ways.

FirÅ¿t, in Å¿inking that part of the Ground which lyes too high, as much as will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to take away the roughneÅ¿s of the AÅ¿cent; and, in the Å¿econd place, in carrying to the lower part what Å¿hall be taken from the higher, whereby a deÅ¿cent of five Foot will be reduc'd to three, taking a foot from the upper part, and placing it upon the lower; Å¿o that the upper will be a Foot lower than it was, and the lower a Foot higher, &c.

But whereas, above all things, care muÅ¿t be taken to preÅ¿erve always three large Foot in depth of good Earth, before any thing be taken away from the upper part, holes muÅ¿t be made in different places of it, to examin how much good Earth we have there, in order to decide, whether we may really take any of it away, and how much; or whether we cannot take any part of it without prejudice to the Ground of the Garden; upon which it is eaÅ¿ie to reÅ¿olve; for the depth of good Earth being Å¿ufficient to bear a diminution, part of it muÅ¿t be taken away to moderate the declivity in queÅ¿tion.

But if, on the contrary, none of it can be taken away without prejudice to the depth or quantity that is neceÅ¿Å¿ary there, recourÅ¿e muÅ¿t be had to a third Expedient, which is, either not to meddle with the height at all, and to raiÅ¿e the lower part as well as we can for the beÅ¿t, in putting more good Earth over that which is good already, if it can be done conveniently, or elÅ¿e to take up that which is good, to put worÅ¿e at the bottom, nay even Stones or Gravel, if nothing better can be had; afterwards covering it all again with the good Earth that was taken up before; or if the Ground of the upper part may be Å¿unk, all the good Earth muÅ¿t be taken up and laid aÅ¿ide, until Å¿o much of the bad, which lay under it, as Å¿hall be thought proper, Å¿hall have been remov'd; which being done, that which is good Å¿hall be laid again in the room of the bad.

But in caÅ¿e none of theÅ¿e three Expedients be practicable, we muÅ¿t make uÅ¿e of the fourth, which is pretty chargeable, but yet abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary; and he who meets with Å¿o untoward a Situation, muÅ¿t comfort himÅ¿elf as well as he can, if he deÅ¿igns to have a profitable pleaÅ¿ant Garden, Å¿ince it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to compaÅ¿s it by any other means.

This fourth Expedient is to divide this great deÅ¿cent into different degrees, or different Portions, to make Å¿everal particular TerraÅ¿Å¿es of it, Å¿ome higher, and Å¿ome lower, and all of them more or leÅ¿s broad, according as the declivity is more or leÅ¿s conÅ¿iderable; after which every one of thoÅ¿e TerraÅ¿Å¿es Å¿hall be diÅ¿pos'd in themÅ¿elves, according to the Method aforementioned, in order to correct moderate Inequalities; but that is not all, for every one of thoÅ¿e TerraÅ¿Å¿es muÅ¿t be Å¿upported and Å¿tay'd to hinder them from tumbling down, which muÅ¿t be done by little Walls, or Å¿mall Banks well beaten and trampled, with Å¿ome Å¿teps proper to deÅ¿cend from the one to the other, or elÅ¿e by Å¿ome Banks that Å¿hall be Å¿odded on purpoÅ¿e, to make them the more Å¿olid and laÅ¿ting; and finally, as if they were
Å¿o many Å¿eparate Gardens, they muÅ¿t be accompany'd with Walks of a breadth proportion'd to their length, as we Å¿hall declare in the Sequel.

To end this matter, I am only to add, that the little Walls may Å¿erve for very good Wall-Fruit, the ExpoÅ¿ure being good, or elÅ¿e for Rasberry-buÅ¿hes, Goosberry Shrubs, or Bourdelais, the ExpoÅ¿ure Å¿tanding Northward; the Å¿mall Banks will not be uÅ¿eleÅ¿s neither, on the contrary, lying to the South or EaÅ¿t, they may be uÅ¿eful for Spring Plants, as Winter Lettuce, PeaÅ¿e, Beans, Strawberries, Artichokes, &c. and after the Spring they may be us'd for Purcelane, BaÅ¿il, &c. and if there be abundance of thoÅ¿e Banks well expos'd, a conÅ¿iderable part of them may always be employ'd in good Grapes, and other Fruits, as I have done in the King's Kitchen-Garden, on certain Banks made on purpoÅ¿e.

When our Banks look to the North, they will be good all the Summer for Charvel, or elÅ¿e to Å¿ow things that muÅ¿t be TranÅ¿planted, as Lettuce, Succory, Cabbaget, Celery, &c. Å¿ince there is no part of a Garden but may be uÅ¿eful for Å¿ome things or other.

ThoÅ¿e Banks require a neceÅ¿Å¿ary Precaution, which is not only to beat and trample them extream cloÅ¿e at the bottom at the time they are made; but eÅ¿pecially to keep the upper part of every Bank a little higher than the Neighbouring Alley to it, otherwiÅ¿e the Water running down from the Banks of the whole Terras, would Å¿oon ruin and demoliÅ¿h them; and, if notwithÅ¿tanding this Precaution, any accident Å¿hould befal it, it muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be repair'd in the Winter, by adding Å¿ome Earth to it, which muÅ¿t be well trampled and beaten anew, leaving only three or four Inches of good Earth looÅ¿e on the Surface, which muÅ¿t be afterwards cultivated, in order to make that Place fit for Production.

And whereas I do not expect that the great Inequalities of Gardens Å¿hould be abÅ¿olutely levell'd, I would have little Fences made from Å¿pace to Å¿pace in the Alleys or Walks, to turn the Water of great Showers into the adjacent Squares or Plats; which Fences muÅ¿t be made with boards Å¿tuck into the Ground a-croÅ¿s the Walks, about two or three Inches above the Surface of the Walks; and in caÅ¿e thoÅ¿e Fences or Stays Å¿hould not prove Å¿ufficient, I would have a drein made at the lower end of every Garden for the disburthening of thoÅ¿e Waters; or at leaÅ¿t, the Neighbourhood not allowing this diÅ¿charge, I would have a great hole made (that is a kind of Well) in ones own Ground, fill'd with dry Bricks; for thoÅ¿e Waters to loÅ¿e themÅ¿elves in, otherwiÅ¿e few Walls would be able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t long againÅ¿t great Inundations without demoliÅ¿hing, and conÅ¿equently, without cauÅ¿ing great diÅ¿orders.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.

argument.p: Of the DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition or DiÅ¿tribution of the whole Ground of every Fruit and Kitchen-Garden.

div.p: TWO particular ConÅ¿iderations are to be had in relation to every Fruit and Kitchen-Garden: The firÅ¿t is to order that Garden Å¿o, that it may be uÅ¿eful and abounding in its Production proportionably to its Extent, and the goodneÅ¿s of the Ground.

The Å¿econd ConÅ¿ideration is to order it Å¿o, that it may be agreeable to the Eye, and convenient either for Walks, or Culture, and for Gathering, thoÅ¿e being the two principal ends propos'd in the making of it, to which end it is not only Å¿ufficient to know what the Earth is capable of doing of it Å¿elf without much help, but alÅ¿o what it is capable of performing without Å¿uch and Å¿uch helps it may receive.

To attain the firÅ¿t Point, which is the advantage of its Productions, the beÅ¿t parts of the Garden muÅ¿t be employ'd with all the Occonomy and Prudence that can be, with Plants and Seeds, inÅ¿omuch that no part thereof may remain uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, putting into each Å¿uch things as are moÅ¿t proper to Å¿ucceed in them; and to attain the Å¿econd, which is Beauty and Convenience, the Ground muÅ¿t not only be agreeably diÅ¿tributed into Squares or Plats, but the Walks muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be made very neat, well plac'd, and of a Å¿uitable Å¿ize, to the extent of the Ground, or Place, it being moÅ¿t certain, that no Intelligent Man will make a Garden without convenient Walks, which muÅ¿t be Å¿uited both as to Å¿ize and number, to the largeneÅ¿s or Å¿cantineÅ¿s thereof.

What we call the beÅ¿t parts of a Garden are really thoÅ¿e which have the beÅ¿t Ground, in caÅ¿e, as it commonly happens, it be not equally good all over, as it were to be wiÅ¿h'd; but the goodneÅ¿s of the Earth being equal, the beÅ¿t parts or places of a Garden are thoÅ¿e particularly that are moÅ¿t Å¿helter'd from the Wind, and conÅ¿equently receive moÅ¿t benefit by the Reflexion caus'd by the Walls.

By neceÅ¿Å¿ary well-plac'd Walks or Allys, we mean Å¿uch as are commonly neceÅ¿Å¿ary either near the Walls, in order to Å¿ee the Trees, the better, to cultivate them with more eaÅ¿e, and have the convenience of gathering the Fruit; or in the whole body of the Garden, to divide the Ground in equal Squares, and to multiply the pleaÅ¿ure of Variety in Walking, to Å¿ee and viÅ¿it what thoÅ¿e Plats or Squares contain, as alÅ¿o that the Culture of them may be perform'd with more eaÅ¿e and convenience by the Gard'ner.
Therefore, as I have already Å¿aid, in our diÅ¿tribution we ought to look at once for the advantage of Production, and the Convenience of Culture of Walking.

As for the advantage of Production we will certainly find it, if, in the firÅ¿t place, we plant good Trees againÅ¿t all the Walls, even Å¿ometimes, without excepting the Face of the HouÅ¿e, eÅ¿pecially, in a Å¿mall Garden, planting Dwarfs alÅ¿o round about the Squares, inÅ¿tead of the Counter EÅ¿paliers or Polehedges that were formerly in uÅ¿e, but are now aboliÅ¿h'd, by reaÅ¿on that the keeping of them in good order was very troubleÅ¿om, and their Productions very InconÅ¿iderable.

Secondly, We will find thoÅ¿e Advantages, if our Squares are garniÅ¿h'd with uÅ¿eful Bordures, at a convenient diÅ¿tance from thoÅ¿e Dwarfs, and finally, if the Body of every Square be continually fill'd with good Legumes, inÅ¿omuch, that thoÅ¿e of one SeaÅ¿on be no Å¿ooner gather'd or pick'd, than the Earth be again prepar'd to receive others for, or of, another SeaÅ¿on.

The Third Part of this TreatiÅ¿e will Å¿hew what Trees will be proper to plant in all kind of Gardens, either for Wall-Fruit or Dwarf-Standards; the Fourth will Å¿hew the manner of Cultivating and Pruning of them; and the Sixth, which contains the TreatiÅ¿e of the Kitchen-Garden, will Å¿hew which are the Bordures I call uÅ¿eful, and which the Legumes of every SeaÅ¿on, together with the Culture that is proper for them, in order to be fine, good and Å¿eaÅ¿onable.

It is not Å¿ufficient to have Å¿et down in general, what relates to the Advantages of the Production, we muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e declare what relates to the Conveniences of Culture, and the PleaÅ¿ure of Walking; therefore we are now to regulate the Å¿pace that is to be allow'd before the EÅ¿paliers, or flat Bordures, when any are made; to regulate the largeneÅ¿s of the Squares, and finally the place and breadth of the Walks of every Garden, whatever Å¿ize it be of.

When I Å¿hall Å¿peak here of the Allies or Walks, I only mean the place deÅ¿tin'd for Walking, and nothing elÅ¿e, as Å¿ome do, who in their DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition give the name of Walks to all the Space that lies from the Wall to the Dwarfs of the Counter EÅ¿palier or Polehedge, or the DiÅ¿tance that lies from one Dwarf to another in the DiviÅ¿ion of the Squares or Ground Plats: This Space of Walks muÅ¿t never be narrower than five or Å¿ix Foot, though the Garden be never Å¿o Å¿mall, and ought Å¿eldom to exceed Eighteen or Twenty, though the Kitchen-Garden be never Å¿o large. This is what I had to Å¿ay, as to the breadth, with this ProviÅ¿o, That in the firÅ¿t place every Walk muÅ¿t be more or leÅ¿s broad in proportion to its length; and, in the Å¿econd place, that it muÅ¿t always be kept very Å¿mooth and gravell'd, and as firm as can be under Foot, otherwiÅ¿e it would not be convenient for Walking.

It will not be improper to declare here wherein the Difference between a Walk and a Path conÅ¿iÅ¿ts: A Walk muÅ¿t be broad enough for two PerÅ¿ons to walk a-breaÅ¿t at leaÅ¿t, and therefore cannot be allow'd leÅ¿s than five or Å¿ix Foot; without which it would no longer be a real Walk, but a large Path; and, as to Paths, provided one perÅ¿on can go through them they are large enough, and therefore do not require above a Foot, or a Foot and a half at moÅ¿t in breadth.

div.head: CHAP. XV.

argument.p: Of the DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition or DiÅ¿tribution of a very Å¿mall Garden.

div.p: I Proceed now to the particulars of every Garden, and Å¿ay, That commonly there are but few Gardens that have not at leaÅ¿t five or Å¿ix Fathom in breadth, with a proportionable length, Å¿ince the name of Garden could hardly be beÅ¿tow'd upon a narrower place; but however, whatever it be, it is certain, that Å¿uch a place being well Å¿ituated, that is, in the Face of the HouÅ¿e, is a great Ornament to it, whether immediately joining to it, or divided by Å¿ome Å¿mall Yard. In caÅ¿e then of Å¿uch a Å¿mall Garden, in my Opinion, in order to manage the Ground to the beÅ¿t Advantage, the Entrance muÅ¿t be made in the midÅ¿t of that breadth, with a Walk of about Å¿ix Foot, which muÅ¿t be the only Walk, leaving only Å¿mall Paths along the Walls and Bordures, about a Foot broad; and in caÅ¿e the Entrance Å¿hould chance to be at one of the Corners, as Å¿ometimes one is neceÅ¿Å¿itated to make it, we muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be Å¿atisfied with one Walk along the firÅ¿t Wall which preÅ¿ents it Å¿elf at that Corner; this Walk may chance to have the Sun one part of the Day, and be Å¿haded the reÅ¿t, whereby it will be Å¿ometimes pleaÅ¿ant for walking.

If Å¿uch a Garden being five or Å¿ix Fathom broad, Å¿hould happen to be as long again, it may very well be order'd, Å¿o as to contrive at every End, or, at leaÅ¿t, at one of them a Walk of an equal breadth with the former, eÅ¿pecially at that end which is neareÅ¿t to the HouÅ¿e, in which CaÅ¿e this walk may be allow'd a little more breadth than the other, which is an ObÅ¿ervation the Practice whereof is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary in all kind of Gardens, eÅ¿pecially great ones, to the end, that as it is cuÅ¿tomary to Å¿top at the Entrance of a Garden; to conÅ¿ider it, a place may be found at firÅ¿t paÅ¿Å¿ably large, and conÅ¿equently agreeable and airy: ThoÅ¿e Walks at the ends will afford room for two or three diÅ¿terent or Å¿eparate Companies, which is a thing to be wiÅ¿h'd for.

BeÅ¿ides this, I would have the Walks that are along the EÅ¿paliers or Walls, at leaÅ¿t at three or four Foot diÅ¿tance from the Walls, that the Trees may have at leaÅ¿t three or four Foot of Cultivated Earth, whereas their former allowance was not near Å¿o conÅ¿iderable, by which means this Bank being pretty large, as I would have it for all EÅ¿paliers, even Å¿o as to make it yet much larger, in great Gardens, the Trees will not only be better nouriÅ¿h'd, but yet, beÅ¿ides the Bordures which Å¿upport the Earth, and form an agreeable Figure in Gardens, Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e uÅ¿eful Plants that delight in the Neighbourhood of Walls, may be planted in them; I mean Å¿uch as love to be Å¿helter'd from cold dangerous Winds, which is a thing altogether neceÅ¿Å¿ary in order to have Å¿omething in the Spring.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.

argument.p: Of the Breadth that is to be allow'd the Bordures of EÅ¿paliers.

div.p: I DeÅ¿ire every Body to reflect upon this Article, in which I adviÅ¿e them to place the Walks at a pretty diÅ¿tance from the EÅ¿paliers, or Walls, by reaÅ¿on of the Advantages that may accrue from the Å¿helter of the Walls, which Å¿helter is of no uÅ¿e when it only favours Walks, which receive no benefit by it; for, in fine, what Inconvenience can attend the Cultivating of three or four Foot more to the right or left of the Walk, in reÅ¿pect to the good uÅ¿e that is to be made of the Mould of every Garden, whereas the three or four Foot I cauÅ¿e to be added to the Å¿mall Bank, to which EÅ¿paliers were commonly confin'd, will be much more profitable in that place, than if being imploy'd to Å¿ome part of the Walk, an equal quantity to it were Cultivated on the other Å¿ide of that Walk, by reaÅ¿on that it could not enjoy the benefit of the Å¿helter of the Wall.

I will not abÅ¿olutely decide, whether Dwarf Fruit-Trees ought to be planted in very Å¿mall Gardens, every Man is free in that to follow his own Inclination, though, in my Opinion, it were beÅ¿t to have none, unleÅ¿s they were Å¿mall Paradice Apple-Trees or GooÅ¿eberry Shrubs; I Å¿hould fear thoÅ¿e Dwarfs might grow Å¿o large as to offuÅ¿cate or Å¿hadow the Wall-Fruit or EÅ¿paliers, which I have a particular reÅ¿pect for in this Place; beÅ¿ides, they would certainly be inconvenient for walking, and take away the Beauty and PleaÅ¿ure of the Walk, not affording it room to breathe in.

Therefore I would employ the Å¿mallneÅ¿s of my Ground in other Things than Fruit-Trees; for InÅ¿tance, in Strawberries, Sallads and Pot-herbs, &c. or elÅ¿e one part one way, and the reÅ¿t of another, to have Å¿ome little thing or other to pick at all times; and thus the whole Å¿pace of our little Garden, of which we have divided the breadth by one only Walk in the middle, or made it narrower by a walk along one of the Walls or EÅ¿paliers, Å¿hould be cut croÅ¿s-wiÅ¿e by Beds about five or Å¿ix Foot broad, with Å¿everal Å¿mall Paths.

After having maturely examin'd the diÅ¿tribution I have now made, I find it Å¿o reaÅ¿onable that I would make no other, though it were for a Garden of Å¿even or eight Fathom broad, nay, not even of thoÅ¿e that conÅ¿iÅ¿t of eight or nine.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.

argument.p: Of the DiÅ¿tribution or DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of a Garden of a moderate bigneÅ¿s.

div.p: BUT if it were for a Garden of ten to eleven, or eleven to twelve Fathom, which compoÅ¿es a Garden of a moderate Å¿ize, whether it has been thought fit in regard to its Situation, to place the Entrance of it at the middle, or elÅ¿e at one of the Å¿ides; in both CaÅ¿es I would allow the Walks Å¿even Foot in breadth, nay, I would even allow eight or nine to that which is parallel to the Front of the HouÅ¿e, leaving, as I have already Å¿aid, a Bank of about five or Å¿ix foot for every Wall; Å¿o that in Å¿uch a DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition I Å¿hould only make Walks along all the Walls: and thus there would remain in the midÅ¿t of the Garden a Å¿quare about Å¿ix or Å¿even Fathom broad, or from Å¿even to eight upon the whole length, and if that length Å¿hould chance to be about fifteen or twenty, or more, it would be fit to divide it into two equal parts by a Walk partly like that of the EÅ¿paliers or Walls; but I would not allow it above three Foot, that Square not being above ten or twelve Fathom long.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.

argument.p: Of the DiÅ¿tribution or DiÅ¿poÅ¿ure of a Garden from fifteen to twenty Fathom in breadth, and one of five and twenty to thirty, and from thirty to forty.

div.p: I Proceed now to a Place from fifteen to twenty Fathom breadth, upon any length whatever, which I look upon as a fine Garden; and, in the firÅ¿t Place, I will examin whether that Garden joyns the HouÅ¿e, or not; Å¿econdly, Whether the HouÅ¿e be built with Free-Å¿tone, or only with a ragged Stone plaiÅ¿ter'd over, or new pargetted.

The HouÅ¿e not joyning to the Garden, Trees muÅ¿t be planted againÅ¿t all the Walls, the Garden being altogether inclos'd; nay, even though it were adjoyning, the Front being only plaiÅ¿ter'd, or new pargetted; the Å¿ame may be done, eÅ¿pecially to have the benefit of the breadth and of the height of the Å¿pace that lyes between the Windows, as well as of the lower part of the Windows; but if the Architecture be fine and rich, I would leave it naked and expos'd to the Eye of every body, Å¿ince it would be a pitty to hide Å¿o fine an Ornament, through the hope of a little more Fruit.

In Å¿uch a Place then, having fifteen or twenty Fathom in breadth, the length containing twenty five or thirty, I would have the Walks along the Walls eight or nine foot broad, nay, nine or ten, or more, the length amounting to five and thirty, or forty; and the Walk which offers it Å¿elf at the Entrance, and is parallel to the Front of the HouÅ¿e, Whatever
length the Garden conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of, I would allow five or Å¿ix foot more than the reÅ¿t, nay, it might be allow'd twelve or more, it being a Terras, as it happens Å¿ometimes, Å¿ince the TerraÅ¿Å¿es adjoyning to a I louÅ¿e can hardly ever be too broad.

BeÅ¿ides the Walks we have mention'd round about our Garden, there Å¿hould be another in the middle to divide the breadth in two equal parts, and the breadth containing twenty Fathom, or a little more, it might be allow'd four or five foot more than thoÅ¿e that are Parallel to the Walls to the right and left, eÅ¿pecially this Walk fronting the entrance of the HouÅ¿e.

As to the length of our Garden, which we Å¿uppoÅ¿e to be from thirty to forty Fathom, it muÅ¿t be divided in two by a croÅ¿s Walk, almoÅ¿t about the Å¿ame breadth with thoÅ¿e of the Å¿ides, or only Å¿ome feet leÅ¿s, conÅ¿idering the Extent is not Å¿o great, beÅ¿ides that generally it is cloÅ¿er by the Trees that edge it to the right and left, than thoÅ¿e of its Å¿ides, which being favour'd by the Banks, have more Air than that of the middle.
Such a Walk croÅ¿s-wiÅ¿e will form two Squares, which may have each about Å¿ix or Å¿even Fathom one way to nine, ten, or twelve on the other.

Whereupon I think it proper to Å¿ay that a Square in any Garden whatever, always looks Å¿ine, when it conÅ¿iÅ¿ts of twelve or thirteen Fathom in length, and Å¿ix, Å¿even, or eight in breadth; and conÅ¿equently much more when it is in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure equal on all Å¿ides, and eÅ¿pecially when it is a little longer than broad.

If it Å¿hould happen at any time that going about to make a Walk on one of the Å¿ides of the Garden, one Å¿hould meet with a Wall, which inÅ¿tead of being Å¿trait, Å¿hould chance to be on a crooked Line in part of its extent, in Å¿uch a caÅ¿e, in which we muÅ¿t not pretead to correct that defect abÅ¿olutely, I am of Opinion Å¿till to make the Walk regular with Å¿trait Angels, that is, Å¿quare, beginning it at four foot diÅ¿tance from that part of the Wall which advances moÅ¿t into the Walk, and making it Square on the Extremity where it is to end, it Å¿hall be garniÅ¿h'd to the right and left with fine Bordures that Å¿hall mark it; and as for thoÅ¿e parts which Å¿hall chance to be much broader with Earth than they Å¿hould be according to our uÅ¿ual DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition, it may be imploy'd uÅ¿efully either in Straw-berries, or other Plants, that are not capable to offuÅ¿cate the Wall-Trees.

There are Å¿ometimes lengths of three or fourÅ¿core Fathom, and even more to eighteen or twenty in breadth, which we are Å¿peaking of, in which caÅ¿e that length muÅ¿t needs be divided into three or four equal Portions by croÅ¿s Walks; and whereas Å¿uch a length bears no Proportion to the breadth, I would Å¿top the ProÅ¿pect of our Garden within forty or fifty Fathom from the HouÅ¿e by Å¿ome Wall, or, at leaÅ¿t, by Å¿ome PalliÅ¿ade; Å¿uch a Wall might be proper to multiply the EÅ¿paliers or Wall-Fruit, or that PalliÅ¿ade for Grapes, or other Fruit-Trees, and thus we Å¿hould gain on all Å¿ides, either as to the Advantage of Production, or the PleaÅ¿ure of the Eye.

Although the Å¿pace of a Garden Å¿hould contain five and twenty, thirty, or thirty five Fathom in breadth, I would make no other diÅ¿tribution of it, than what we have already made to a breadth of fifteen or twenty, unleÅ¿s it were to make the Walks Å¿omewhat broader, in proportion to their length.
