div.head: CHAP. XX.

argument.p: Of the manner of Cultivating Fruit-Gardens.

div.p: ALthough this Culture taken in the whole, contains all what we have Explain'd in Å¿everal particular TreatiÅ¿es, my Intention, notwithÅ¿tanding, is to reduce it here to Three Things only: FirÅ¿t, to the Tillage the Earth Å¿tands in need of; Secondly, to the NeatneÅ¿s Gardens require at all times. The remainder of the Culture of the Earth Å¿hall be examin'd in the TreatiÅ¿e of the Kitchen-Gardens.

Therefore we muÅ¿t conclude, that as the Earth, as often as it is hot and moiÅ¿t, always finds it Å¿elf in an approaching diÅ¿poÅ¿ition to Act, that is, of producing Å¿ome Plants good or bad, and Å¿ometimes of no uÅ¿e for Man, becauÅ¿e it can, as it were, never remain Idle, the Production it makes of one thing, muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be prejudicial to another.

The ReaÅ¿on is, FirÅ¿t, that the Interior Salt of it; that is, its Fertility, or Capacity of Acting is no wiÅ¿e Infinite, and is exhauÅ¿ted by often producing, as every Body knows: So that Å¿everal Plants lying near one another, it always happens that all, or a great part of them grow the Å¿maller, becauÅ¿e that which was to Å¿erve for the NouriÅ¿hment of all, being divided into many, the Å¿hare of each muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be the Å¿maller, and the NouriÅ¿hment of all of them the Å¿lenderer, or elÅ¿e it happens that Å¿ome of them being more lively, either by being grown Naturally, or being of a Temper more Å¿uitable to that part of the Earth which nouriÅ¿hes them; this Plant has Å¿uck'd a greater quantity of the NouriÅ¿hment that was in that Place ready prepar'd for Vegetation, than any of the reÅ¿t.

It is not only the InÅ¿ide of that Earth which appears exhauÅ¿ted to us in its Productions, when too great a quantity of different Plants have exhauÅ¿ted it by their Roots; we Å¿ay, beÅ¿ides, that this Earth is dry and wants MoiÅ¿ture, when it is hindred from receiving the Benefit of the Night-Dews, and of thoÅ¿e Å¿mall Show'rs which have the Gift of repairing and amending that Earth, provided they may be able to penetrate to the Internal Parts; thus when the Leaves of all thoÅ¿e Plants, which cover the Ground, come to receive thoÅ¿e kind of MoiÅ¿tures, they hinder them from deÅ¿cending lower, and Å¿o they remain expos'd to the Exigua tantum gelidus ros nocte reponet. Georg. 2. Sun, which rarifying them as Å¿oon as it lightens and heats them, converts them into Vapours, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently for that time prevents their being of any uÅ¿e to that Earth.

It follows from thence, that when we would have our Trees, and particularly our Dwarfs and Tall Standards well fed, and conÅ¿equently very Vigorous, and thereby agreeable to Å¿ight, we muÅ¿t take care.
FirÅ¿t, That they be not too near one another, to the end that the NouriÅ¿hment may be the leÅ¿s divided.
Secondly, That there may be no Å¿ort of Plants near them, which may inwardly Å¿teal their NouriÅ¿hment, or outwardly hinder the RefreÅ¿hings and Helps they are certainly to receive by Rain and Dew.

Thirdly, Care muÅ¿t be taken to keep the Earth always light, and conÅ¿equently often Cultivated, as well that the MoiÅ¿tures of Rains and Dews may eaÅ¿ily, and the Å¿ooner, penetrate to the Roots, as that the Earth may be duly heated by the Rays of the Sun, which it Å¿tands indiÅ¿penÅ¿ibly in need of.

Now to put that Earth in a Condition of producing advantageouÅ¿ly what we require of it, without allowing it time to imploy it Å¿elf in other Things, as alÅ¿o to preÅ¿erve cleanneÅ¿s in the whole extent, we muÅ¿t be careful to Till the Ground, to amend and cleanÅ¿e it when it requires it. Let us now examine thoÅ¿e four kind of Cultures, to Å¿hew the Manner, UÅ¿e, CauÅ¿e and SucceÅ¿s of them.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.

argument.p: Of Tillage.

div.p: TIllage, properly Å¿peaking, is nothing but a Movement or Stirring, which being perform'd on the Surface of the Ground penetrates unto a certain Depth, and makes the lower and upper parts reciprocally change place: Now it not being my Intention, to Å¿peak in this Place of the Tillage that is perform'd with a Plough in the open Fields, but only of the Tillage of our Gardens, it is proper to know that it is perform'd Å¿everal different ways.
FirÅ¿t, With the Spade and Haugh in eaÅ¿ie Grounds.

In the Second Place, with a Pitch-Fork, and French Mattock in Å¿tony and yet pretty Å¿trong Ground; Å¿ome are perform'd deeper; for InÅ¿tance, in the open Ground, and in the middle of the Squares or Plats; and others lighter, viz. about the Foot of Trees, upon AÅ¿paragus, among Å¿mall Legumes, &c.

It muÅ¿t be noted next, that in all likelihood the CauÅ¿e or Motive of Tillage, is not only to make the Earths appear more agreeable to Å¿ight, though they really thereby become Å¿o; but that it is, in the firÅ¿t place, to render Å¿uch eaÅ¿ie as are not Å¿o, or to preÅ¿erve thoÅ¿e in a good CaÅ¿e that are Å¿o naturally; and, in the Å¿econd place, that it is chiefly thereby to augment Fertility in Å¿uch Earths as have but little, or to preÅ¿erve it in Å¿uch as have a Å¿ufficient Store: Earths that are abÅ¿olutely barren, muÅ¿t not be Till'd.

When I talk of rendring Earth eaÅ¿ie, I mean to make it become Å¿andy and looÅ¿e, inÅ¿omuch, Et cui putre Å¿olum (namque hoc imi tamur arando.) Georg. 2. that the MoiÅ¿ture and Heat which comes from without, may eaÅ¿ily penetrate through it, and that it may be no wiÅ¿e compact or Å¿ticking together, like clayiÅ¿h, gravelly Earth, which by the ConÅ¿titution of their Nature, are no wiÅ¿e proper for Vegetation.

And when I Å¿peak of endeavouring to give FruitfulneÅ¿s, I mean, that the Tillage muÅ¿t Optima putri arva Å¿olo; id venti curant, gelidaeque pruinae, & labefacta movens, robuÅ¿tus jugera foÅ¿Å¿oÌr. Georg. 2. contribute to give a temper of Heat and MoiÅ¿ture to a Soil, that is already provided with that Salt, it Å¿tands in need of for the chief part of Fertility; this temper of Heat and MoiÅ¿ture being Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary to the Earth, that without it its Salt is altogether uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, inÅ¿omuch, that it can produce no manner of Plants, in the Å¿ame manner as Animals can enjoy no perfect Health, without the temper of Elemental Qualifications.

It is not enough to have given ReaÅ¿ons for the CauÅ¿e of Tillage, we muÅ¿t beÅ¿ides give Prima Ceres ferro mortales vertere terram inÅ¿tituit, cum jam glandes, atque arbuta Å¿acrae deficerent Å¿ilvae, & victum dodona negaret. Georg. 1. Rules, that may Å¿erve to procure this Temper in queÅ¿tion to Earth.

Upon which, I Å¿ay, that it is obÅ¿ervable, that Å¿ome Earths are eaÅ¿ily heated; for Example, Å¿uch as are light, to which we have but little to do in Relation to heat; but whereas they are commonly dry and parch'd, we muÅ¿t work carefully to procure them MoiÅ¿ture: Others are not eaÅ¿ily heated; for InÅ¿tance, thoÅ¿e that are Strong and Cold; and thoÅ¿e require but little Culture for an augmentation of MoiÅ¿ture; on the contrary, they have generally too much of it; but they require a great deal of help for an additional Heat.

Moreover, Å¿ome kind of Plants require more MoiÅ¿ture; for Example, Artichokes, Sallads, Cultaque frequenti in quaÅ¿cumque voces artes, haud tarda Å¿equentur. Georg. 2. Sorrel and thick Rooted Plants: The Earth which produces them muÅ¿t be diÅ¿pos'd in Å¿uch a manner, as to receive a great deal of Water from without: Others are Å¿atisfy'd with leÅ¿s, as Fruit-Trees, and AÅ¿paragus, &c. and we need not much trouble our Å¿elves to afford it them; but however, as we have nothing in our Gardens which requires either an exceÅ¿Å¿ive Heat or MoiÅ¿ture, Å¿o we have nothing but what requires Å¿ome. The Sun, Rains and Subterranean Waters provide for one part, and we ought to provide, by other means, for what may be wanting beÅ¿ides; which is, what we do by a well underÅ¿tood Culture, of which Tillage is one of the chief Parts.

ThoÅ¿e Tillages are to be perform'd at different Times, and even differently as to the multiplicity, Omne quot annis terque quater

Georg. 2. in reÅ¿pect to the difference of Earth and SeaÅ¿ons: Earth that is hot and dry muÅ¿t be Till'd in the Summer Time, either a little before, or while it Rains, or Å¿oon after it, eÅ¿pecially when there is any likelihood of more; at which time they can neither be Till'd too often, nor too deep when it Rains; as, by the ReaÅ¿on of Contraries, they muÅ¿t but Å¿eldom be Till'd in very hot Weather, unleÅ¿s they be water'd immediately after it. ThoÅ¿e
frequent breakings of the Ground make way for the Waters of Rain, and make them penetrate Et caeca relaxat Å¿piran enta, novas veniat qua, Å¿uccus in herbas. Georg. 1. towards the Roots, which Å¿tand in need thereof; whereas otherwiÅ¿e they would remain upon the Surface, where they would be of no uÅ¿e, and Å¿oon after evaporate: Tillage likewiÅ¿e makes a paÅ¿Å¿age for heat, without which MoiÅ¿ture can be of no uÅ¿e.

On the contrary, Cold, Strong, MoiÅ¿t Earth, muÅ¿t never be Till'd in time of Rain, but rather during the greateÅ¿t Heats, at which time they can neither be Till'd too often nor too deep, eÅ¿pecially to hinder them from parching and Å¿plitting on the Top, which, as we have often Å¿aid, does a great deal of prejudice to the Roots; and to the End, that it being Å¿oftned by Tillage, the heat may penetrate the eaÅ¿ier to them, and thereby may deÅ¿troy the Cold, which hinders the Action of the Roots, and makes Trees yellow.

The Nature of the Earth Å¿hews us in this, as well as in many other Things, that it will be order'd regularly, Å¿o that it anÅ¿wers our Intentions with Å¿ucceÅ¿s, when it is prudently manag'd; whereas, on the contrary, it oppoÅ¿es them when it is govern'd Ill: The SeaÅ¿on of putting moÅ¿t Coin into the Ground, which commonly are only Å¿own each in one SeaÅ¿on, the time of Graffing, of Pruning and of Planting Vines as well as Trees, &c. which likewiÅ¿e is only done in certain Months; all theÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, are Å¿o many InÅ¿tructions which Nature gives us, in order to teach us how to Å¿tudy well what the Ground requires, and preciÅ¿ely at what time. By thoÅ¿e ObÅ¿ervations, a great Application has taught me, that it is good to Till often about Trees, either in dry, light Earths, or in Å¿uch as are Å¿trong and moiÅ¿t; the one in rainy Weather, and the other in great Heats.

ThoÅ¿e frequent Tillings, which I adviÅ¿e, when Convenience will permit it, are of great

UÅ¿e; for, beÅ¿ides their hindring part of the GoodneÅ¿s of the Earth from being exhauÅ¿ted by the Production and NouriÅ¿hment of ill Plants; they, on the contrary, make thoÅ¿e Weeds which Rot, being laid under Ground, Å¿erve for an Amendment to fatten it; but moreover thoÅ¿e frequent Tilths partly deÅ¿troy the Ancient Maxims, which had EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd but one Tillage for every SeaÅ¿on; and what I like moÅ¿t in them is, that, at leaÅ¿t, they eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the NeceÅ¿Å¿ity, and conÅ¿equently the UÅ¿efulneÅ¿s of them: But I add, that they are not Å¿ufficient, unleÅ¿s, during their Intervals, care be taken to Å¿crape, or pull out thoÅ¿e ill Weeds, which eÅ¿pecially in the Summer and in Autumn, grow upon Earths, and then Multiply, ad Infinitum, when they are Å¿uffer'd to run up to Seed.

We muÅ¿t Å¿ay here by the by, that the times in which Trees bloÅ¿lom, and the Vine Å¿hoots are very dangerous for Tillage, it muÅ¿t never be performed at thoÅ¿e Times, neither about thoÅ¿e Trees or Vines; the Earth being newly Å¿tir'd in the Spring, exhales abundance of Vapours, which upon the leaÅ¿t white hoary FroÅ¿ts, which are common at that SeaÅ¿on, being Å¿topt near the Surface of the Earth, Å¿tick upon the BloÅ¿Å¿oms, Å¿often and moiÅ¿ten them, in Å¿o much that rendring them Å¿uÅ¿ceptible to the FroÅ¿t, they contribute to kill them; Earths that are not Till'd at that time, and conÅ¿equently are hard about the Surface, are not Å¿ubject to exhale Å¿o many Vapors, and therefore not Å¿ubject to Å¿o many Accidents of FroÅ¿t.

From what I have Å¿aid heretofore to favour the NouriÅ¿hment of our Trees, it follows, that I condemn thoÅ¿e who Sow or Plant, either many Pot-herhs, or Strawberries, or Flowers, near the Foot of their Trees, Å¿uch Plants being certainly very prejudicial to them.

The Rule I PractiÅ¿e for the Culture or Tillage, that is to be perform'd about our Trees, as well in the Winter as in the Spring, in dry light Earths, is to allow them a large one at the Entrance of the Winter, and the like as Å¿oon as it is paÅ¿t, to the end that the Rains and Snows of the Winter, and the Rains of the Spring, may eaÅ¿ily penetrate into our Earth; and as for the Å¿trong and moiÅ¿t Earths, I give them a Å¿mall Tillage in the Month of October, only to remove the Weeds, and tarry to give them a large one at the end of April, or the beginning of May, when the Fruit is abÅ¿olutely knit, and the great MoiÅ¿tures over; thus the Surface of that Earth being kept hard, firm and cloÅ¿e, has left but little paÅ¿Å¿age for the Waters of the Winter and Spring, which we have no occaÅ¿ion here, for the Snow being melted, without having been capable of penetrating, remains part upon the Surface, where it is converted into Vapors, and the reÅ¿t following the Declivities of the Place, deÅ¿cends into the Neighbouring Rivers.

I muÅ¿t needs Å¿ay, in this Place, that nothing moiÅ¿tens Å¿o much, and penetrates Å¿o far as the Water of melted Snow. I have Å¿eldom known Water to penetrate above a foot deep, whereas the Water of Snow will penetrate two or three Foot, as well becauÅ¿e it is heavier than common Rain Water, as by reaÅ¿on, that as it melts Å¿lowly and by degrees, and from the undermoÅ¿t part of the MaÅ¿s of Snow, it Å¿oaks in with more eaÅ¿e, without being hindred by the Wind, or by the heat of the Sun.

Therefore, as much as I dread abundance of Snow upon Å¿trong, moiÅ¿t Grounds, and cauÅ¿e it to be remov'd from about our Fruit-Trees; I like it, and cauÅ¿e it to be gather'd in dry Earths, there to make a kind of Magazine of MoiÅ¿ture; and eÅ¿pecially in thoÅ¿e
Earths I cauÅ¿e that which lyes, and is of no uÅ¿e, in the Walks, to be taken up and thrown into the Bordures of the EÅ¿paliers or Wall-Trees, and particularly to the ExpoÅ¿itions of the South, which in the Summer time want moÅ¿t moiÅ¿ture; and the Å¿ame into the ExpoÅ¿ures of the EaÅ¿t, even in Å¿trong Earths, by reaÅ¿on that the Summer Showrs Å¿eldom falling upon them, the ground of thoÅ¿e ExpoÅ¿itions remains commonly dryer than the reÅ¿t, and conÅ¿equently the Trees are thereby expos'd to Å¿uffer.

This NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of Tillage, which I recommend and adviÅ¿e, is Å¿ometimes contradicted by the Å¿ucceÅ¿s of certain Trees, which being cover'd with Pavement or beaten Gravel about the Foot, do notwithÅ¿tanding thrive well, though they are never Till'd; to which I have two things to Å¿ay in anÅ¿wer; the FirÅ¿t, That as commonly Å¿uch Trees are plac'd under Spouts or Gutters, a great deal of Water falls upon them, which penetrating through the Crany's of the Pavement, or through the beaten Gravel, furniÅ¿hes a Å¿ufficient NouriÅ¿hment for the Roots. The Second is, That the moiÅ¿ture which has thus penetrated into thoÅ¿e Grounds Rapidive potentia Å¿olis ac â¢â¢ or, aut boreae penetrabile frigus adurat. Georg. 1. cover'd with Pavement, preÅ¿erves it Å¿elf much better in it, and longer than in others, the wind and the heat of the Sun not being capable to deÅ¿troy it: yet notwithÅ¿tanding, I Å¿till recommend Tillage, as well for the good of the Earth and Plants, as for the PleaÅ¿ure of the Eye; the UniverÅ¿al Experience we have of it, can never be deÅ¿troy'd by Å¿o Å¿mall an Objection, no more than the uÅ¿e of Bread and Cloathing can be condemn'd, although the Savages do not underÅ¿tand it: Fig-Trees Orange-Trees, and other Plans and Shrubs in CaÅ¿es Å¿ufficiently juÅ¿tifie the UÅ¿e of Tilling, or breaking of the Ground to give a PaÅ¿Å¿age to the Water or Waterings, without which they Pine, and often PeriÅ¿h.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.

argument.p: Of Amendments or Improvements.

div.p: AFTER having explain'd the Motive, UÅ¿e and Manner of Tillage, we muÅ¿t do the Å¿ame thing about Amendments, which are nothing but a bettering, or recovering of Earth; we have already Å¿aid, that this Improvement might be done with all manner of Dung, of which we muÅ¿t now explain the Motive, UÅ¿e and Manner.

As to the Motive, it is likewiÅ¿e certain, that when we amend, or Dung the Ground, it is with an Intention of affording FruitfulneÅ¿s to that which wants it, that is, that which has many defects, and conÅ¿equently little DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition towards Production; or elÅ¿e to preÅ¿erve it when it has it, and might loÅ¿e it, unleÅ¿s it received from time to time Å¿ome neceÅ¿Å¿ary Reparations, according to the Productions we require of it, either beyond its Capacity, or conformably to its Power; and likewiÅ¿e to amend it more or leÅ¿s, according to its Temper, whether good or bad: For Example, There muÅ¿t be a great deal of Dung to produce Pot-herbs, which grow in a Å¿hort time abundantly, and Å¿ucceed each other quickly in a Å¿mall compaÅ¿s of Ground, which without that might grow barren; on the other hand, Trees require but little or none for their NouriÅ¿hment, by reaÅ¿on that being long a-growing, they make but inconÅ¿iderable Productions, compar'd to the Ground they take up: and LaÅ¿tly, Though they remain long in one and the Å¿ame Place, yet by means of their Roots which Å¿tretch out to the right and left, they make a Å¿hift to pick up the NouriÅ¿hment that is proper for them, far and near: I add, that the Earth which has a great deal of FruitfulneÅ¿s in it Å¿elf, requires leÅ¿s than that which has but little; and Finally, Cold moiÅ¿t Earth requires more than thoÅ¿e that are hot and dry.

Certainly, and no body can be ignorant of it, the great defects of Earth conÅ¿iÅ¿ts, as I have already Å¿aid, either in too much moiÅ¿ture, which is commonly accompany'd with cold, and great ponderouÅ¿neÅ¿s, or elÅ¿e in too much drought, which is likewiÅ¿e regularly accompany'd with an exceÅ¿Å¿ive lightneÅ¿s, and a great DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition to parching; We likewiÅ¿e find that among the Dungs we may imploy, Å¿ome are too fat and cooling, for inÅ¿tance, the Dung of Oxen and Cows; and the other too hot and light, for Example, the Dung of Sheep, HorÅ¿es and Pidgeons, &c. and whereas the Remedy muÅ¿t have Vertues oppoÅ¿ite or contrary to the DiÅ¿tempers it is to cure; we muÅ¿t imploy hot and dry Dungs in moiÅ¿t, cold, heavy Earth, in order to heat them, and make them lighter and eaÅ¿ier; and Oxen and Cow Dung in lean, dry, light Earths, to make them fatter, and more material, thereby hindring the great parchings or droughts of the Spring, and the great heats of the Summer from drying them up with too much eaÅ¿e.

There are at this time great ControverÅ¿ies in PhiloÅ¿ophy and ChimiÅ¿try, to endeavour to decide which are the beÅ¿t Dungs, and that with the Å¿ame exactneÅ¿s or accuracy Mathematicians uÅ¿e in deciding what is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to form a Å¿traight Line, &c. The World is certainly highly oblig'd to thoÅ¿e Gentlemen, who drive their CurioÅ¿ity and their ObÅ¿ervations Å¿o far into the Secrets of Nature; I hope, we may reap great benefits by it, but in the mean time, I am of Opinion for my Å¿elf, and for thoÅ¿e for whom I write, that we can do no better than to proceed in this as I do, orderly, plainly and groÅ¿ly, being perÅ¿uaded that the fertility of Earth does not conÅ¿iÅ¿t, as, I may Å¿ay, in an indiviÅ¿ible Point; and indeed I am Å¿o far from being willing to occaÅ¿ion the leaÅ¿t Å¿cruple in any body, and Fundit humo facilem victum juÅ¿tiÅ¿Å¿ima tel

To which end, I think I may Å¿ay once more, that we may form to our Å¿elves a certain Idea of richneÅ¿s in Earth, which certainly contains in its Bowels a Salt which occaÅ¿ions Fertility, and that this Salt is the only and real TreaÅ¿ure of this Earth. Thus we Å¿ay, That the Money of a MiÅ¿er (which makes his Riches and Plenty) is the TreaÅ¿ure he poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿es; yet this MiÅ¿er will Å¿till remain equally Rich and Pecuniary: If, in the firÅ¿t place, he Å¿pends nothing, or, if in the Å¿econd place, whatever Liberality he may affect, it happens Å¿o that he conÅ¿tantly receives as much Gold and Silver in one hand, as he Å¿pends with the other; he Å¿pent yeÅ¿terday fifty Shillings, to day he has increas'd his Store, either in Gold, Silver, or Goods, to the value of the Å¿ame Summ; he is then equally Rich, Å¿o that to morrow he Å¿hall be able to Å¿pend the Å¿ame Summ, and to take up the next day, either the Å¿ame Money in Bond, which is not common, or the value, &c. and thus, ad Infinitum, this Circulation is real and effective.

We muÅ¿t know for certain, that Earth has been created with a DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition to produce Germinet terra herbam vitentem, &c. GeneÅ¿e.
Plants, and that (excepting Å¿ome Stones and Mettals which are extraordinary Productions of Nature) there is nothing on the Earth which is not come out of its own BoÅ¿om, and that by the way of Vegetation, and conÅ¿equently all the Vegetative Plants we Å¿ee are part of that Earth, and thus we may affirm that there is nothing (whatever it may be, provided it be material) but what may Å¿erve to amend that Earth or Soil returning to it by way of Corruption, under whatever Figure it returns to it; becauÅ¿e that whatever reenters into that Earth, gives it back in Å¿ome manner what it had loÅ¿t, either in the Å¿ame Specie, or in Value, and in effect it becomes Earth again, as it was before; thus all manner of Stuffs, Linnen, the FleÅ¿h, Skin, Bones and Nails of Animals, Dirt, Urines, Excrements, the Wood of Trees, their Fruit, their Leaves, AÅ¿hes, Straw, all manner of Corn or Grains, &c. In Å¿hort, all in general that is palpable and Å¿enÅ¿ible on Earth (excepting perhaps as I have already Å¿aid, moÅ¿t Stones, and all Minerals) all this entring into the Ground, Å¿erves to amend and better it, Å¿o that having the Convenience and Facility of Å¿preading often upon Earths, as we have it in good Farms, and particularly in the Neighbourhood of Cities, as it is practis'd for the Å¿owing of Corn, and for Legumes, we put our Land in a Condition of being able to continue to produce always without IntermiÅ¿Å¿ion.

Moreover, our Ground, though good, not being permitted to produce, for InÅ¿tance, Å¿uch as are built upon; thoÅ¿e Grounds thus cover'd with Buildings, are, though againÅ¿t their Will, like a Rich Man who Å¿pends nothing, though able to Å¿pend much; they always remain, as the PhiloÅ¿ophers Å¿ay, equally Fertile in Power, that is, equally capable of producing, and would actually produce, if they were not hindred from Å¿o doing; as to the others which produce at all times, if in Tilling of them, the Plants they had produc'd be again put underneath them, as it happens often, eÅ¿pecially in thoÅ¿e parts that are the Seat of War; thoÅ¿e Plants thus put under the Surface of that Earth rot there, and Å¿erve to fatten it again to the Å¿ame degree it poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s'd before the producing of them, or elÅ¿e we may Å¿ay, that it is the Å¿ame Salt in Specie, which returns to it, and makes it as Rich, that is, as Fertile as it was before.

And when all the Productions of Å¿uch a Å¿pot of Ground are taken away, as it is very uÅ¿ual, and that in lieu thereof it be allow'd as many of the Productions of another place, and that by means of rotten Straw, Å¿eaÅ¿on'd, as it were, with the Excrements of Å¿ome Animals, which Excrements are likewiÅ¿e originally Å¿prung from the Earth, and make a part of it, that Earth having thereby repaired its loÅ¿s, becomes as Rich, that is, as Fertile as before.
We may then in Å¿ome manner look upon Dungs in relation to Earth, as a kind of Coin which repairs the TreaÅ¿ures of that Earth.

Upon which, I think I may Å¿ay, that Dung Å¿eems to be in relation to Earths that are of a different Temper, what Salt is in relation to different kinds of Meat, either Å¿uch as are fine and curious, as Partridges and Sheep, and Å¿uch as are material and groÅ¿s, as Beef and Pork, &c. theÅ¿e without doubt can bear a much larger quantity of Salt in the Å¿eaÅ¿oning of them, without Å¿poiling, than the others, Å¿ince a good piece of Beef, without doubt, requires a much greater quantity of Salt to reliÅ¿h it, than a piece of Mutton, though equally large; and indeed groÅ¿s Meats are made more pallatable by being well poudred, whereas Mutton being Å¿alted at the Å¿ame rate, would be Å¿poil'd.

Humida majores herbas alit, ipÅ¿aque juÅ¿to laetior, Georg. 2. Earths, which Å¿tand in no need of Å¿o much heat, it would prejudice them inÅ¿tead of doing them good; thoÅ¿e Dungs are too burning; but according to the Advice of the Poet, we might allow them a great deal of Cows-Dung, which is fatter, and not Å¿o hot: And on the contrary, what is not Å¿it for dry, hot Earths, is very proper for Å¿uch as are cold and moiÅ¿t; thoÅ¿e, which naturally produce but too many Weeds, want heat to be animated, as it were, to diÅ¿poÅ¿e them, to produce others that are better for us.

argument.p: Of Dungs.

div.p: IT will not Å¿uÅ¿fice to have Å¿poken of Amendments or Improvements in General, we muÅ¿t come to Particulars; to which end I think it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to examin five things, principally in the CaÅ¿e of Dung, which is the moÅ¿t uÅ¿ual of all Amendments.

list.item: Secondly, How many kinds there are of it.

div.p: As to the firÅ¿t Point, I cannot forbear Å¿aying, that Dung, being a vulgar thing, and Å¿o well known, it Å¿eems uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, and almoÅ¿t ridiculous, to endeavour to give an account of it; but yet in order to continue to follow exactly the deÅ¿ign I have propos'd in this TreatiÅ¿e, which is not to omit the leaÅ¿t Å¿ingularity of all that belongs to Gard'ning, I think my Å¿elf oblig'd to Å¿peak of this Dung, not indeed to make it known to Å¿uch as are unacquainted with it, Å¿ince it would be hard to meet with Å¿uch, but only to make Å¿ome ObÅ¿ervations upon it, which are very material for the matter in hand.

I Å¿ay then, that Dung is a CompoÅ¿ition of two things, of which, the firÅ¿t is a certain quantity of Straw which has Å¿erv'd for Litter for DomeÅ¿tick Animals; and the Å¿econd, the Excrements of Å¿ome Animals among it, which has in Å¿ome manner incorporated with that Straw; neither that Straw alone, though half rotten, is Å¿it to make good Dung; nor yet the Excrements of thoÅ¿e Animals without Straw, can be Å¿ufficient alone, to induce one to imploy them, they muÅ¿t of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity be mix'd together to be of uÅ¿e, which is a thing known by every body.

Neither can any body be ignorant that thoÅ¿e who keep thoÅ¿e Animals both for PleaÅ¿ure and UÅ¿e, have particular Places for them to feed and reÅ¿t in; which Places have peculiar and different Names; they are call'd Stables for HorÅ¿es and Mules, &c. And Pens, Stalls and Sties for Oxen, Cows, Sheep and Hogs, &c. Great Hunters have, beÅ¿ides, Kennels for Hounds, but thoÅ¿e afford but little of what we treat of in this Chapter. It is uÅ¿ual to place daily under thoÅ¿e Animals, and particularly under HorÅ¿es, a Å¿ufficient quantity of freÅ¿h New Straw, well Å¿pread, which is call'd making of Litter, which is, as it were, a kind of Bed, which Å¿erves for them to lye upon, and take their reÅ¿t, when they are weary, to put themÅ¿elves again in a Condition to go about their uÅ¿ual Service a-new; this Litter Å¿erves then to preÅ¿erve their Health, to help to recover their Vigor, as well as to keep them neater, and more agreeable to Å¿ight.

But that is not all, for after that it muÅ¿t be good for Å¿ome other thing; this Straw being thus imploy'd by the Name of Litter, becomes not only bruis'd and broken by the Trampling and Agitation of thoÅ¿e Animals, but their Excrements having imbib'd or Å¿oak'd it, changes the colour of it, and half rots it, Å¿o that it becomes, as it were, of a different Nature from what it was; and being altogether corrupted, and no longer proper to Å¿erve for Litter, there is a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of removing it, to put new into the room of it, which in its turn muÅ¿t undergo the Å¿ame Fate.

This firÅ¿t Litter being taken from under thoÅ¿e Animals, and laid aÅ¿ide, is not look'd upon as a heap of common Dirt, to be rejected, we give it the name of Dung, now in queÅ¿tion; and under that Name, it is found to be, not only a uÅ¿eful, but a very neceÅ¿Å¿ary thing for the good of Human kind.

Now that which is the CauÅ¿e of this new Service it yields, being grown Dung, is, that the Excrements of thoÅ¿e Animals have communicated unto it a certain quality, or rather a certain Salt, which being contain'd in it, cauÅ¿es it (being heapt up) to heat it Å¿elf conÅ¿iderably, and at the Å¿ame time to heat all that is round about it, as we Å¿hall explain more at large hereafter.

After having thus explain'd what Dung is, if it may be truly Å¿aid that that Explication was not very neceÅ¿Å¿ary, at leaÅ¿t it muÅ¿t be allow'd, that the other four Articles are very material to be explain'd, beginning by that which is to give us an Account how many Å¿orts of Dung we may uÅ¿e.

It naturally follows from what I have Å¿aid above, that as there are many HorÅ¿es every where, there likewiÅ¿e is a great deal of HorÅ¿e Dung, and a little of Mules, &c. that there The variety of Dungs. is a great deal of Cows, and that Sheep and Hogs afford a Å¿mall quantity, we may likewiÅ¿e Å¿ay that the Poultry that is kept in Å¿ome HouÅ¿es, as Pigions, Hens, GeeÅ¿e, &c. alÅ¿o produce Å¿ome Å¿mall manner of Dung, but it is Å¿o very inconÅ¿iderable, that it is hardly worth mentioning.

The great Animals in queÅ¿tion do not alone contribute by their Excrements, to the CompoÅ¿ition of Dungs, and the Amendments of the Earth, all the parts of their Bodies being once rotten, nay, their very Nails and Bones Å¿erve to fatten it. The Leaves of Trees which are gather'd in Autumn, being put in a moiÅ¿t Place, and eÅ¿pecially under the drein of a Stable or Pen, being alÅ¿o rotten, may likewiÅ¿e be of Å¿ome uÅ¿e in Places where Straw and Animals are not common.

The very AÅ¿hes of all combuÅ¿tible Matters are of a very good uÅ¿e in this CaÅ¿e, for the Å¿mall quantity that can be had of them, and not only AÅ¿hes, but alÅ¿o rotten Wood, and generally all things which being come out of the Earth, are corruptible, becomes Dung for the Ground, when put into it again, and there corrupts.

Nay, there are Å¿ome People, who, in order to multiply the number of Dungs or Amendments, maintain, that Turf, and the Earth of high Ways is proper for it; I will Å¿peak my Opinion of it in the Sequel, and will only Å¿ay in this Place, that that kind of whitiÅ¿h Earth which is met with in the Bowels of Å¿ome piece of Grounds, which we call Marle, and Å¿eems to be inclin'd to become Stones, muÅ¿t be conÅ¿ider'd as an amendment to help towards the Production of Å¿ome things, as I will explain in the Sequel.

Now we have explain'd the diverÅ¿ity of Dungs, it will be proper to Å¿ee what are their particular Qualifications, to the end that this knowledge may teach us to make a good The choice of Dung. Choice according to the occaÅ¿ions we have for it.

There are two peculiar Properties in the CaÅ¿e of Dungs; the one is to fatten, that is, to fatten the Earth, and better it, or render it more fruitful, and that is common to all manner of Dung, being well rotten, only Å¿ome more, and others leÅ¿s: The Å¿econd Property is to produce a certain Å¿enÅ¿ible heat, capable of producing Å¿ome conÅ¿iderable Effect: The Ancients knew the firÅ¿t, and have not known the Å¿econd; this laÅ¿t is Å¿eldom met with in any but HorÅ¿e and Mule Dung, when newly made, and Å¿till a little moiÅ¿t, and indeed thoÅ¿e
Å¿ort of Dungs are of a wonderful uÅ¿e in our Gardens, and particularly in the Winter; at which time they Å¿eem to perform the Office of the great Planet, which animates and enlive â¢ s all things, really performing there the Å¿ame Function which the heat of the Sun is us'd to diÅ¿penÅ¿e there in the Summer; as for InÅ¿tance, being laid in the form of Couches, it Å¿erves to afford us all the Novelties of the Spring, viz. Cowcumbers, RadiÅ¿hes, Å¿mall Sallads, and Melons, and all that, long before Nature can give it; it Å¿erves in great FroÅ¿ts to furniÅ¿h us with Greens and Flowers, and that which is yet more Å¿ingular, very green AÅ¿paragus, and thoÅ¿e better than the Common ones; it likewiÅ¿e Å¿erves to advance conÅ¿iderably the Maturity of Strawberries, of Figs in CaÅ¿es, PeaÅ¿e, &c. and finally, it Å¿erves to make MuÅ¿hrooms grow at all times.

And if new Dung has a peculiar GoodneÅ¿s and Faculty, when it Å¿tands poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s'd of its firÅ¿t heat, it has another when, without being Rotten, it is old and dry, the heat being altogether paÅ¿t, which is to preÅ¿erve againÅ¿t, or from, Cold, that which FroÅ¿ts might indamage and deÅ¿troy; and therefore it is us'd in the Winter time to cover Fig-Trees, Ar â¢â¢
chokes, Succories, Selery, &c. Which are all Manna's of great Value in Gard'ning, which would periÅ¿h without the help of Dung to cover them: Which is not all that Dung is uÅ¿eful for; for, after having Å¿erv'd in Å¿o many Places, as according to the Condition of all Sublunary Beings, it rots at laÅ¿t; it then Å¿erves again to the laÅ¿t UÅ¿e which I treat of here, and that is, to amend the Ground.
This Amendment or Improvement Å¿uppoÅ¿es two conÅ¿iderable Conditions, the one relating to the time which is proper for the doing of it, and the other to the manner of doing it well.

As to the time, we muÅ¿t not imagin that all the SeaÅ¿ons of the Year are proper to employ Proper times to turn Earth.
Dung, none but the five moiÅ¿teÅ¿t Months of the Year are good for it, viz. from the beginning of November till towards the end of March; thoÅ¿e Dungs would be of no uÅ¿e in the boÅ¿om of the Earth, unleÅ¿s they perfectly made an end of rotting there, and nothing but Rain can cauÅ¿e that ConÅ¿ummation; thoÅ¿e that are employ'd at other times, only grow dry and muÅ¿ty, and Å¿o far from being favourable to Vegetabels, they are pernicious and fatal to them, eÅ¿pecially when there is a conÅ¿iderable quantity of it; abundance of large white Worms engendring in it, which remain in the Earth, and gnaw all the tender things they meet with; whereas the great MoiÅ¿tures of Autumn and Winter making an end of rotting by the degrees, the groÅ¿s material Å¿ubÅ¿tance of that Dung, the Salt which lyes in it, paÅ¿Å¿es into the interior parts of the Earth; and thus this Salt Å¿preads it Å¿elf in thoÅ¿e Places, whence the Plants draw their NouriÅ¿hment, that is, in the Neighbourhood of the Roots, which alone have the Tallent of improving the benefit of Dung, and thereby Vegetables make an end of acquiring all the Perfection, which is proper for them, as thickneÅ¿s, largneÅ¿s, and the reÅ¿t, &c.

It follows then, that the Winter is the only SeaÅ¿on fit for great Amendments; therefore it behoves able Gard'ners, not to loÅ¿e a time which is Å¿o precious for their Occupation: In order to which, they need neither to mind the Quarters of the Moon, nor the Winds, whatever they be, notwithÅ¿tanding the Traditions of Å¿ome of the Ancients, and whatever may be Å¿aid in Å¿ome Books of Gard'ning; they are only troubleÅ¿om ObÅ¿ervations, and altogether UÅ¿eleÅ¿s, and are only proper to afford Matter towards the ImbelliÅ¿hment of Poetry, or, perhaps, to Å¿et off Å¿ome ViÅ¿ionary talkative Gard'ners.

Let us now proceed to the manner of Employing this Dung to the purpoÅ¿e: This matter ought to afford us two InÅ¿tructions; the one is to point out thoÅ¿e Parts where the Dung is to be laid, and the Å¿econd to mark out partly the true quantity.

As to the firÅ¿t, it is to be noted, that Å¿ometimes there is a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Dunging largely, and pretty deep into the Ground, and Å¿ometimes it Å¿uffices to turn the Surface lightly. As to the firÅ¿t, I am not of the Opinion of thoÅ¿e who make Beds of their Dung at the Bottom of Trenches, whatever care they take of Tilling every Bed largely, in order to mix the Earth and Dung together, and my ReaÅ¿on, confirm'd by a long Experience, is, that whatever is good in that Dung, Å¿o employ'd, Å¿oon becomes UÅ¿eleÅ¿s, Å¿ince it paÅ¿Å¿es too low with the MoiÅ¿tures which force it along, and drive it to Å¿uch Parts where the Roots cannot penetrate, beÅ¿ides that the Motion which is made in Tilling thoÅ¿e Three or Four Beds in the Trenches, inÅ¿tead of contributing to make the Earth lighter; which is one of the Et cui putre Å¿olum. Therefore, as I have already Å¿aid elÅ¿ewhere, I would have the Dung uÅ¿ed for Earth, in the Å¿ame Manner as AÅ¿hes are us'd in WaÅ¿hing, that is, that whereas the AÅ¿hes are only laid upon the Surface of the Linen, that is heaped up in the Tub, in order to cleanÅ¿e it; Å¿o the Dung Å¿hould only be laid on the Surface of the Earth that is to be Amended. I Å¿ay
it again, it is not the groÅ¿s SubÅ¿tance of the Dung which FertiliÅ¿es, as it is not the groÅ¿s SubÅ¿tance of the AÅ¿hes which cleanÅ¿es, it is that inviÅ¿ible Salt which is contain'd in thoÅ¿e Matters, Incorporating, wetted with the Waters that wet it, deÅ¿cends with them, whereever their Weight inclines them, and there produces what it is capable of performing.

But it is not Å¿ufficient to know the beÅ¿t Place where the Dung is to be laid, we muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e examine what quantity may be proper for it: In order to explain this Article, it is proper to know that as Å¿ome Dungs have a far greater quantity of Salt to Communicate than others; Å¿o there are Earths which require and want more Amendments than others: I Å¿till mean the Earth for Kitchen-Plants, and not that Earth in which Trees are to be Planted; for I will have none for theÅ¿e, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing always that if they have the leaÅ¿t No Dung for Trees. I Å¿uppoÅ¿e, for InÅ¿tance, that a Trench Å¿ix Foot deep is to be prepar'd, either along a Wall to plant againÅ¿t it, or about a Square to plant Dwarfs; FirÅ¿t, I would have the quantity of Dung one has Examin'd, either HorÅ¿e or Cow Dung, which are the two Å¿orts that are moÅ¿t Commonly us'd, and which are moÅ¿t plentiful; I muÅ¿t not forget minding thoÅ¿e who dig along a Wall, to take care not to come too near the Foundations, for fear of indamaging it, the Wall might be in danger of falling; a Å¿mall Å¿lope of hard Ground muÅ¿t always be left untouched againÅ¿t it.

When beÅ¿ides the Trench for Trees, there are to be others round about all the Squares or Ground Plots deÅ¿tin'd for Kitchen-Plants, in a Garden not having the good Qualifications that are to be wiÅ¿h'd for, the Å¿ame Method muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be us'd, multiplying only the number of thoÅ¿e that are to Till, proportioning the number of thoÅ¿e that are to Å¿pread the Dung accordingly; there muÅ¿t always be the Å¿ame depth of Earth, ever making the firÅ¿t overture of the Trenches about a Fathom broad, it being for Example of the length of the whole Square, to which end the Earth that Å¿hall be taken out of the Trench, muÅ¿t be laid along the Square that is to be fill'd, which Å¿hall Å¿erve to fill up

I would only have People obÅ¿erve, that in caÅ¿e the Earth which wants to be amended or improv'd, is naturally dry and Å¿andy, fat Dung muÅ¿t be imploy'd, for Example, Cow-dung, or elÅ¿e HorÅ¿e-dung, which Å¿hall have been rotten in a MoriÅ¿h Place; I Å¿eldom mention the Dung of Hogs, becauÅ¿e, that beÅ¿ides its being Å¿carce, it has an ill Å¿avour, which hinders People from deÅ¿iring it, it is capable of infecting the Ground, and giving it an ill taÅ¿te, which would infect the Fruit Å¿ooner than better it: When they are courÅ¿e, Å¿trong, moiÅ¿t Earths, the largeÅ¿t and dryeÅ¿t Dung will be moÅ¿t proper; for Example, HorÅ¿e and Mules Dung, never putting too much, nor too little, but a moderate quantity, exceÅ¿s being dangerous in theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es; on the other hand, putting none at all in the Earth in queÅ¿tion, is a defect that would Å¿oon be perceiv'd; as likewiÅ¿e putting but too Å¿mall a quantity, is a help, which not being Å¿ufficient, muÅ¿t be look'd upon as uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, eÅ¿pecially in lean Earths, from which more is requir'd than it is able to produce; that is, abundance of thick well fed Legumes.

AÅ¿hes of all kinds would be of great uÅ¿e to amend the Earth, if there was enough of it; but whereas we have but little of it, it is only us'd about the Feet of Å¿ome Fig-Trees, or Å¿ome other Trees, where they are not uÅ¿eleÅ¿s.

Some People have a particular Value for Turf to make Amendments, but I look upon it in a different Manner, that is, as being fit to produce of it Å¿elf, and not to Fertilize other Earth; and I have a great Value yet for the Earth that lies under that Turf which we call new Earth, the which having never been wrought, is conÅ¿equently full of all the Fertility that can be expected from New Earth, and therefore happy are thoÅ¿e who can make whole Gardens of Å¿uch:

But when People have not a Å¿ufficient quantity to compaÅ¿s this, and yet have a reaÅ¿onable Stock of it, I would have them employ it either wholly for Fruit-Trees, or, at leaÅ¿t, in the Å¿ame manner as I have caus'd Dungs to be Employ'd for deep Amendments.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV.

argument.p: To know whether it be proper to Dung Trees.

div.p: I Cannot approve the Sentiments of thoÅ¿e, who being Infected with the Vulgar Error in relation to Dungs, uÅ¿e it indifferently every where, even Å¿o far that to make a grand Maxim of it, they Å¿ay in a pretty popular manner, that, eÅ¿pecially in relation to Trees, it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to afford them too much KindneÅ¿s, which is the Å¿oft and Å¿parkiÅ¿h ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion they uÅ¿e in Å¿peaking of what we vulgarly call Dung.
But, in order to examin whether their Opinion is any wiÅ¿e reaÅ¿onable, I deÅ¿ire them to anÅ¿wer five Queries I propoÅ¿e upon that Subject.

list.item: FirÅ¿t, Whether they mean all manner of Trees?
Thirdly, Whether, if thoÅ¿e Fruit-Trees, they mean all of them in General, to preÅ¿erve Å¿uch as are Vigorous and re-eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h thoÅ¿e that are Infirm?
Fourthly, Whether they have a certain Rule for the quantity of Dung that is to be allow'd to each, and for the place where it is to be laid?
And Fifthly, Whether they Å¿hould be Dung'd in all manner of Earths, whether good or bad?

div.p: I dare not believe that their Opinion in relation to Dungs, extends to all Trees in General, Å¿ince every body knows that the Trees, of ForeÅ¿ts, thoÅ¿e in the open Fields, and thoÅ¿e that Å¿erve for Avenues to HouÅ¿es, thrive commonly very well without ever having been Dung'd: In caÅ¿e thoÅ¿e Gentlemen allow this to be true, as to Trees that bear no Fruit, they condemn themÅ¿elves unawares as to Fruit-Trees, Å¿ince both the one and the other receive their NouriÅ¿hment in one and the Å¿ame manner, that is, by their Roots; and indeed thoÅ¿e Roots working in a natural Ground, when it is paÅ¿Å¿ably good, never fail of finding enough of what is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for them to live.

But however, in all probability, thoÅ¿e Gentlemen only apply the Maxim in queÅ¿tion to Fruit-Trees; and yet really I cannot believe, that they dare own that they mean all thoÅ¿e Trees in General, Å¿ince it would be ridiculous to Å¿ay, that one and the Å¿ame thing can be equally good; for Å¿o many Trees of Å¿uch different ConÅ¿titutions, Å¿ome more or leÅ¿s Vigorous, and others more or leÅ¿s Infirm; Å¿ome Kernel, and Å¿ome Stone Fruit, &c. and yet they have never Explain'd themÅ¿elves upon that difficulty, and have never Å¿poken upon this Matter but in general Terms; in which, as we have already Å¿aid, they make uÅ¿e of the SparkiÅ¿h Term of KindneÅ¿s, to perÅ¿wade the more agreeably.

Neither do I believe, that if they were preÅ¿Å¿ed to declare their Opinion, they would Å¿ay, that they mean the moÅ¿t Vigorous, Å¿ince great Vigour appearing inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with the abundance of Fruit, it would be an ill Expedient, in order to get Fruit, to have recourÅ¿e to a thing they Å¿hould believe proper to maintain that Vigour, and perhaps to augment it; moreover Dung being only look'd upon as a Remedy, and Remedies being only us'd for the DiÅ¿eas'd, it follows from thence, that that Dung is not to be
us'd for thoÅ¿e Trees, which, far from being any wiÅ¿e Infirm, have all the Signs imaginable of perfect Health, throughout their whole Extent, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing then that Dung were capable of Improving Trees, Å¿till I do verily believe, that it would Å¿ooner harm theÅ¿e, than procure them the leaÅ¿t Advantage.

Therefore we may conclude, that their Opinion is, that Infirm Trees Å¿tand in need of the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Dungs: Now in order, if poÅ¿Å¿ible, to diÅ¿abuÅ¿e the World of Å¿uch an Error, I affirm Å¿incerely, that by a Å¿tudy'd Experience of a long Series of Years, I do know with certainty, that all the Dung in the World can operate nothing in Favour of any Tree whatever; I had liv'd long in that Common Error, my CurioÅ¿ity having begun by that, as well as by the Rote of the Declinings of the Moon, &c. but am now happily undeceiv'd, and all thoÅ¿e who will take the Pains to inform themÅ¿elves of the Truth thereof, without prejudice, will certainly conclude with me, that at beÅ¿t it is but a uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Labour and Expence; beÅ¿ides, I declare that it is a great HappineÅ¿s when it does not prove prejudicial; thoÅ¿e Dungs, as I have hinted elÅ¿ewhere, being apt to Ingender Worms which kill the Trees, and at moÅ¿t all the Vertue that is in them, extends no farther than to produce Å¿mall Roots, which Roots, though really good for Å¿mall Plants, can no wiÅ¿e contribute towards the forming of thoÅ¿e fine Shoots, by which we judge of the Vigour we deÅ¿ire in Trees.

But in order to enter a little farther into the convincing Proof of this Truth, which I eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h, I Å¿hould be glad to be inform'd exactly, what an Infirm Tree is, it is a matter I have enlarg'd upon Å¿ufficiently in the TreatiÅ¿e of the DiÅ¿tempers of Trees, &c. therefore I Å¿hall now only Å¿ay, that, for Example, an infirm Pear-Tree, is not always to be concluded Å¿o, by reaÅ¿on of its producing Yellow Shoots, Å¿ince there are Å¿ome that are very vigorous and yet produce Leaves of that Colour; they are only Å¿uch upon which Å¿ome thick old Branches die, or Å¿uch of which the Extremity of the new Shoots wither, or Å¿uch as produce none at all, and remain Å¿cabby, full of Cankers and MoÅ¿s, and yet bloÅ¿Å¿om exceedingly; yet little of the Fruit knits, and that which does knit, remains Å¿mall, Å¿tony and bad: And when the Tree happens to produce large Yellow Shoots, which happens frequently, to Å¿ome Pear-Trees Graffed upon Quince-Stocks, which being planted in a dry lean Ground are naturally in a good CaÅ¿e, this defect of Yellow Leaves proceeds from that, Å¿ome of the principal Roots lying level with the Ground, are parch'd by the great Heats of the Summer. Now the Dung which is imploy'd for Amendments, and is conÅ¿equently put pretty deep into the Ground, can no wiÅ¿e prevent this.

On the other hand, if any of the Branches of that Infirm Tree chance to die, that Defect may proceed from that, either the Tree may be overburthen'd with Branches, compar'd to the Å¿mall Vigour of it, Å¿o as not to be able to NouriÅ¿h them all, or elÅ¿e from its being planted too high or too low; or laÅ¿tly, from that the Earth, which is to NouriÅ¿h it, is either bad or worn out, and eÅ¿pecially, when the Foot of the Tree has many dead Roots.

As to the firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, Dung cannot diÅ¿charge that Tree from its Burthen: In the Second, it cannot make it to be better Planted: And in the Third, it cannot revive the dead Roots: And LaÅ¿tly, can produce no thick new ones; for Dungs have never been able to Effect that, neither great Dungs, though never Å¿o Rotten, nor the Å¿mall ones we call Soil. Thus as long as it produces no thick new Roots, we muÅ¿t expect no fine new Shoots; and while none of thoÅ¿e kind of new Shoots are produc'd, the Trees will always remain ill-favour'd, and the Fruit will never be well-condition'd in its kind, nor give us Satisfaction by the Abundance of it.

To this I add, that if Dung had the Faculty of rend'ring a weak Tree Vigorous; in the firÅ¿t place I Å¿hould have Experienc'd it at one time or another, after having try'd it Å¿o often; which being, I Å¿hould be much to blame to diÅ¿Å¿ent from an Opinion Å¿o well EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, and to endeavour at the Å¿ame time to introduce a new Doctrine in the Room of it, which, inÅ¿tead of doing me any KindneÅ¿s, would only Å¿erve to turn me into Ridicule. In the Second place, if Dungs could afford Vigour, eÅ¿pecially to old Infirm Trees, that Advantage would certainly be attended by a very great Inconvenience, which is, that it would occaÅ¿ion the Shooting of abundance of FalÅ¿e Wood or Suckers, and deÅ¿troy the DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of that Tree towards the producing of Fruit; Å¿ince, contrary to the MaÅ¿ters Intention, it would cauÅ¿e thoÅ¿e Buds which were grown round for Fruit to Å¿hoot out for Wood, which Wood muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be remov'd as being Ill-condition'd and ill plac'd.
I explain more particularly in another Place, what is moÅ¿t proper to be done in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, and that is at the End of the Fifth Book, where I propoÅ¿e Remedies for the Infirmities of old Trees.

But Å¿uppoÅ¿ing it were good to Dung Trees, which I do not allow, what true Rule can be had for the more or leÅ¿s quantity of Dung each Tree may require: Will a moderate quantity produce the Å¿ame Effect as a great one, or will not a great quantity perform more than a Å¿mall or moderate one? Moreover, in what place Å¿hall that Dung be plac'd, Å¿hall it be near the Stem or Foot, or at a diÅ¿tance from it? It will be uÅ¿eleÅ¿s near the Stem, Å¿ince the Extremities of the Roots, where all the Action is perform'd, being diÅ¿tant from it, can receive no Benefit by it, and yet it is commonly laid particularly in that place, therefore thoÅ¿e Amendments Å¿hould be plac'd near thoÅ¿e Extremities, but how Å¿hall one be certain in what part they lay, eÅ¿pecially Å¿ince thoÅ¿e Extremities Å¿tretching out Yearly, conÅ¿equently Yearly change their place, &c.

I conclude by this Vulgar ObÅ¿ervation, That Infirm Trees are met with in good Grounds, as well as in ill ones; will the Å¿ame Remedy be proper for both? There appears to me a great deal of difficulty to anÅ¿wer thoÅ¿e three laÅ¿t QueÅ¿tions juÅ¿tly; Å¿o that thoÅ¿e certainly engage themÅ¿elves in a great ConfuÅ¿ion, who will have the only Remedy for Fruit-Trees to conÅ¿iÅ¿t in Dunging, either to preÅ¿erve their Vigour, or to reÅ¿tore that which they have loÅ¿t. I find much more Advantage, and leÅ¿s Charge, in uÅ¿ing new Earth, than any Dungs, whatever they be: I explain in another place the manner of Employing thoÅ¿e new Moulds, which has occaÅ¿ion'd me to Å¿ay in another place, that one of the chief Conditions, to Å¿ucceed in the planting of young Trees, provided they be good, and the Roots well Prun'd, is to plant them in paÅ¿Å¿able good Earth, and Å¿uch as has never been Dung'd.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.

argument.p: What Sort of Earth is moÅ¿t proper for every kind of Fruit-Trees.

div.p: I Conclude this Second Part, after having Å¿aid that the Wildlings of Pear-Trees and Apple-Trees, Et quid quaeque fer at regio, & quid quaeque recuÅ¿et, &c. Georg. 1. and even thoÅ¿e we call Paradice, and likewiÅ¿e Plum-Trees and Fig Trees agree very well with all manner of Earth, whether hot and dry, or cold and moiÅ¿t, provided the Ground be deep enough, that is, at leaÅ¿t two good Foot and a half, or three Foot deep; Fig-Trees do not require near Å¿o much.

Quince-Trees do not thrive well in dry light Grounds, they grow yellow too eaÅ¿ily; Almond and Stone Peach-Trees thrive better in this than in Å¿trong Earth, in which they are too Å¿ubject to Gumm; thoÅ¿e Å¿trong Earths are fitter for Plums, MeriÅ¿iers, or Å¿mall bitter Cherrys, GooÅ¿e-berries, RaÅ¿pberry BuÅ¿hes, &c. Vines thrive better, and produce better Grapes and better Wine in certain dry Grounds, than in Å¿trong and cold Earth; Cherries thrive pretty well in dry light Grounds, but yet better in clear Mould.

After having Explain'd what Å¿ort of Earths are beÅ¿t for every kind of Plantations, one might think to draw neceÅ¿Å¿ary ConÅ¿equences for the kinds of Fruits that are Graffed upon thoÅ¿e kind of Stocks; for InÅ¿tance, for Pears Graffed upon free Stocks or Quince; for Peaches upon Plum or Almond-Trees, &c.

But yet, as we Å¿hall declare in the Sequel, Earth has not the Å¿ame Effect as to the good TaÅ¿te of Fruits, as it has as to the Vigor of Trees. Winter Bon ChreÅ¿tien Pears, Petitoin, LanÅ¿ac and Thorn Pears, &c. will always remain inÅ¿ipid, and moÅ¿t of them Å¿tony or meally in a cold moiÅ¿t Ground, whether Graffed upon a Wildling or Quince-Stock, eÅ¿pecially for Dwarf-Standards, the Å¿ame with Peaches and Pavies, &c. ThoÅ¿e kind of Fruits do particularly require a pretty dry Ground, or at leaÅ¿t Å¿uch a one as is drein'd well by Gutters, or Å¿tudied Declivities, the Ground being naturally moiÅ¿t: In fine, generally Å¿peaking Trees are commonly Vigorous in Å¿trong Earth, but the Fruit Å¿eldom acquires that delicacy of TaÅ¿te there, it Å¿hould have, the which they meet with in dryer Grounds.

It is not Å¿ufficient to have our Gardens well Cultivated by Tillage and Amendments, beÅ¿ides this, they muÅ¿t be kept very clean, that is, the Walks muÅ¿t always be kept very free from Stones and Weeds, always firm under Foot to walk conveniently and with eaÅ¿e, the Ground likewiÅ¿e clear from Stones and Weeds, the Trees always free from Caterpillars, Snales and MoÅ¿s, &c. Finally, uÅ¿eful Gardens, Å¿hould be as pleaÅ¿ing, when old made, as they are diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ing when new, in which particular they differ from Parterres or Flowey Gardens, which are never Å¿o neat, or agreeable to Å¿ight, as the very day
they have paÅ¿s'd through the Gard'ners Hands, being then adorn'd with Flowers newly planted, the Walks being newly Gravell'd and very Å¿mooth, the Green Turf freÅ¿h, &c. In Å¿ine, if I may uÅ¿e the ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion, at that time, they are not unlike a new Bride adorn'd with Powder, Patches, Ribbons, NoÅ¿egays, &c. to render them the more pleaÅ¿ing; whereas our uÅ¿eful Gardens which Å¿hould in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure reÅ¿emble a good HouÅ¿ewife, muÅ¿t have a natural unaffected cleanneÅ¿s, without any Å¿tudied conÅ¿train'd Adornments.

div.head: OF FRUIT-GARDENS AND Kitchen-Gardens. VOL. I. PART III.

argument.p: What is to be done in all Å¿orts of Gardens, as well in making a judicious Choice, as in proportioning and placing the beÅ¿t kinds of Fruit-Trees, whether Dwarfs, Wall-Trees, or Standards.

div.p:
AMONG the Fruits that are at preÅ¿ent in uÅ¿e in the World, It may without prejudice be Å¿aid, There are Å¿ome Å¿o ExquiÅ¿ite and Perfect, that nothing is known more Delicious to the TaÅ¿t, and perhaps, hardly any Thing more uÅ¿eful for the Health: And accordingly we are accuÅ¿tomed to make Å¿uch frequent uÅ¿e of them at all times, That we are almoÅ¿t perÅ¿waded to Rank them among Things abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Life; we hardly meet with any body that can be without them, Å¿o that there is nothing almoÅ¿t but People will do to have Å¿ome; which is the CauÅ¿e, That how Magnificent and Abundant Å¿oever any Great FeaÅ¿ts may be, they are Å¿till found Fault with, if Fair and Good Fruits be wanting to Å¿et out their LuÅ¿tre, and to help to leave behind them a certain Idea of GreatneÅ¿s in the Minds of the invited GueÅ¿ts; and thence it alÅ¿o comes to paÅ¿s, That the moÅ¿t Å¿umptuous and Å¿tately Country ManÅ¿ion in the World, is thought to want one of its principal Ornaments, if it be not accompanied with Fair and well Planted and Contrived Fruit-Gardens. And therefore Nature, which does nothing in vain, has been careful to provide us almoÅ¿t an infinite Number of different Å¿orts of Fruits, and at the Å¿ame time has inÅ¿pired us with a Å¿trong Inclination, not only to Cultivate thoÅ¿e of our own Climates, but alÅ¿o to multiply them, by adding to them, thoÅ¿e of
Foreign Countries, Å¿o that to Å¿peak Truth; we ought to look upon the abundance Å¿he has bleÅ¿t us with in this kind, as one of the greateÅ¿t Obligations we have to her; and it Å¿eems, as if all Å¿he had done beÅ¿ides, to make us Live and SubÅ¿iÅ¿t, would be thought very inconÅ¿iderable, if we were deprived of the TreaÅ¿ure the Gardens afford, a TreaÅ¿ure that is to us a very great AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance: For in effect, What is there more Precious or Commodious to Life, than to find good Fruit Planted in all inhabited Countries; and what is more Valuable to us, than to have abundance of them at all Å¿eaÅ¿ons of the Year?

And here a goodly Field offers it Å¿elf, were I minded to perÅ¿ue it, in praiÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e Rich PreÅ¿ents which the Earth furniÅ¿hes us of her own accord, even in the obÅ¿cureÅ¿t ForreÅ¿ts, and moÅ¿t horrid DeÅ¿arts: But that is a Task that belongs not at all to my ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion, and much leÅ¿s is it any part of my preÅ¿ent DeÅ¿ign, and therefore as I am Å¿enÅ¿ible how uncapable I am to undertake it with Å¿ucceÅ¿s, I Å¿hall not venture upon it, but Å¿hall rather confine my Å¿elf within the modeÅ¿t pleaÅ¿ure of Communicating to the World, what by long Experience I have found uÅ¿eful to InÅ¿truct Men to make the beÅ¿t Improvement of thoÅ¿e MaÅ¿ter-pieces of Nature, and to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t them to add Å¿till more and more Perfection to them by their InduÅ¿try.

Now, though under the Name of Fruits, we ordinarily comprehend all the productions of Gardens that go under that Appellation, yet I pretend not here to Treat of any of the Fruits of the LeÅ¿Å¿er ClaÅ¿Å¿is, Å¿uch as Strawberries, RaÅ¿pberries or GooÅ¿eberries, nor of Muk-Melons neither, though they be certainly Fruits moÅ¿t Excellent in their kind; they being Articles I reÅ¿erve to Å¿peak of in our Kitchen-Garden, of which they are to conÅ¿titute a Part, but I Å¿hall only Treat here, of Å¿uch as grow on Trees, and which, when they Excel in their kind, and are planted in a proper Seat, and well qualified, make the True Ornaments of Gardens; for unleÅ¿s they be indeed of Å¿uch Å¿orts, there are many kinds of Fruits that inÅ¿tead of doing Honour, do rather a DiÅ¿grace, to the MaÅ¿ter that Cultivates them.
And after I have diÅ¿courÅ¿ed of the good Fruits of all kinds of Trees, I Å¿hall alÅ¿o Å¿peak of thoÅ¿e Å¿orts of Grapes, which are Å¿o much EÅ¿teemed by all PerÅ¿ons of Quality.

I cannot proceed any further without taking Notice to you, how much I am Å¿urpriÅ¿ed at the Contemplation of all the Fruit I Å¿ee, as well in general, as particular: For as to particular kinds, I am very much, having made very exact DeÅ¿criptions of them, as well of their InÅ¿ide as OutÅ¿ide, and that both of Kernel-Fruits, and thoÅ¿e with Stones or Shells, as alÅ¿o of Figs and Grapes, as will be afterward Å¿een; inÅ¿omuch, that of Pears only, I can affirm with Truth, that I have Seen, TaÅ¿ted and DeÅ¿cribed above three hundred Å¿everal Å¿orts, all different one from another, without finding all this while above thirty Kinds that were Excellent enough to my TaÅ¿te, to merit the Character of having regularly more good Qualities than bad ones.

I expect to find Å¿ome curious PerÅ¿ons, whom my Opinion in matter of Choice, will not pleaÅ¿e in all things: But let them permit me, if they pleaÅ¿e, to make a moÅ¿t humble RequeÅ¿t, which is, that before they cenÅ¿ure the EÅ¿teem, or DiÅ¿like I expreÅ¿s for certain Fruits, they would firÅ¿t Examin very particularly my Intention, which chiefly tends to the EÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing a continual SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of choice good Fruits; and after that, they would Remember, that Peoples particular Palates are not to be diÅ¿puted; that being an inconteÅ¿table Point, and in the next place, that great allowances are to be made to the fickleneÅ¿s of SeaÅ¿ons, of which we are not the MaÅ¿ters, as alÅ¿o of the diverÅ¿ity of Soils and Climates, which is almoÅ¿t infinite, and to the Nature of the Stock of the Tree, which is Å¿ometimes Good, and Å¿ometimes Bad; and laÅ¿tly to the Manner or Figure in which the Å¿everal Trees grow and produce.

They are all points that require a great deal of ConÅ¿ideration, and very much Å¿erve to Ballance the Opinions of thoÅ¿e that would judge of them. There are Å¿ometimes ill Pears to be found among the Virgoulees, the LechaÅ¿Å¿erees, the Ambrets, and the Thorn Pears, &c. And but Scurvy Peaches among the Minions, the Maudlins, the Violets, the Admirables, &c. And in Fine, there are Å¿ome bad Plumbs among the Perdrigons, Å¿ome bad Grapes among the MuÅ¿cats, and Å¿ome bad Figgs among thoÅ¿e that are moÅ¿t EÅ¿teemed, &c. And is not that enough to aÅ¿toniÅ¿h any Curious PerÅ¿on that has applied himÅ¿elf Å¿o much as I have done, to Å¿earch into their Nature, and Å¿hould I be excuÅ¿able if I were Å¿o diÅ¿ingenuous as to Å¿uppreÅ¿s the great ObÅ¿ervations and uÅ¿eful Reflections I have made thereupon, from which I have at laÅ¿t drawn this ConcluÅ¿ion; That although in a certain Å¿ort of good Fruits, there may be Å¿ome defective, yet it follows not from thence, that the whole kind Å¿hould therefore be rejected, nor that on the other Å¿ide, we Å¿hould put any great value upon another kind, becauÅ¿e, though known, by competent Judges in matter of Fruits, to be of a bad Å¿ort, it may by Å¿ome lucky hit; have yielded Å¿ome tolerable good ones, which Å¿ome leÅ¿s delicate Palates
may be Enamoured with? For, in the firÅ¿t place, all the World is agreed, That of Fruits conÅ¿idered according to their Nature, there are three ClaÅ¿Å¿es, that is to Å¿ay, there are Å¿ome very good, and Å¿ome very bad ones, and laÅ¿tly, That there are Å¿ome again, that cannot well be comprehended under neither of thoÅ¿e, but can only be lookt upon as Fruits Å¿imply tolerable, and but indifferently qualified; And it is only thoÅ¿e of this laÅ¿t Rank, that finding here and there Å¿ome Friends and Patrons, give occaÅ¿ion to all DiÅ¿putes ariÅ¿ing about the Choice of Fruits, for Å¿eldom it happens, but that all are unanimous in PraiÅ¿ing the FirÅ¿t, and Rejecting the Second Sort, for we Å¿ee that a good RuÅ¿Å¿et, or Virgoulee Pear is generally EÅ¿teemed, and a Parmain Pear or Pear of Fontarabie, as much decried every where; But 'tis not Å¿o with a Doyenuee, or Dean Pear, or a St. Lezin, &c.

It is likewiÅ¿e granted, that, for Example, Å¿uch a Fruit may prove ill one year, or in Å¿uch certain ExpoÅ¿itions or Placings, which may have appeared good Å¿everal years before, or in other ExpoÅ¿itions, and again on the other Å¿ide, that Å¿uch or Å¿uch a Fruit may prove good this year, which was not to be endured Å¿ome preceding years.

And, in Fine, it is alÅ¿o agreed on all hands, That in one Å¿ort of Soli, Climate and Figure of a Tree, Å¿uch Fruit proves good, that always regularly proves bad in a different Climate, in another Å¿ort of Ground, and another kind of Figured Tree. For Example, That which perhaps produces good Fruit in a full and open Air, will not produce nothing nigh Å¿o good in the Form of a Dwarf Tree, &c. Nor every Plant that proÅ¿pers againÅ¿t a Wall, have the Å¿ame DeÅ¿tiny in a full Air, &c. Nor every Fruit that proves good in a Sandy Soil, arrive to the Å¿ame perfection in a moiÅ¿ter Ground, &c. And therefore I Å¿hall make as exact a DiÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ion of this matter as 'tis poÅ¿Å¿ible, that I may be the better able to come to a deciÅ¿ion in the point of Choice, and of the order of Preference, which is the Å¿cope of my preÅ¿ent diÅ¿courÅ¿e.

To be the firÅ¿t in any other Gardens, where there are more than one.

div.p: THough I doubt not but there may be a Å¿trong Party of Competitors formed among our beÅ¿t Pears, ready to vie Merits for the place of Preference here in QueÅ¿tion, yet I Å¿hall make no Difficulty, without further ConÅ¿ultation, to declare my Å¿elf in Favour of the Winter Boncretien-pear

div.p: So that what Complaints Å¿oever the other Pears may make againÅ¿t me, for not at A Winter Boncretien preferr'd to the firÅ¿t place. leaÅ¿t vouchÅ¿afing them a hearing; I cannot diÅ¿penÅ¿e my Å¿elf from maintaining and Å¿tanding by this Declaration, Å¿o powerful do thoÅ¿e ReaÅ¿ons appear to me that engaged me to make it.

For, FirÅ¿t, if, as I may Å¿o call it, the Antiquity of its known Extraction may be ReaÅ¿ons for the Preference of the Winter Boncretien. counted for any advantage to it in this CauÅ¿e, as it is in Å¿o many other more important Matters, then without doubt our Boncretien or good ChriÅ¿tian pear may in that particular pretend it Å¿elf much more Noble than all the other Pears. For though probably all Its Antiquity. Fruits were created in one and the Å¿ame Day, yet 'tis certain they were not all known at the Å¿ame Time, but Å¿ome Å¿ooner and others later: And this Pear was one of the firÅ¿t that by its Å¿ingular Excellencies, gain'd the Admiration and CourtÅ¿hip of the World: The great Monarchies, and principally that of Old Rome having known and cultivated it under the Name of CruÅ¿tumium or Volemum; Å¿o that in all appearance it often Its old Roman Name, Volemum or CruÅ¿tumium. made a noble Figure among thoÅ¿e Conquering People, in the magnificent Entertainments they uÅ¿ually made, as well to Å¿et out the Splendor of their Triumphs, as to do Honour to the Tributary Kings which often came to pay their Homage to thoÅ¿e MaÅ¿ters of the World.

In the Å¿econd place, the Great and IlluÅ¿trious Name which it has ever born ever Å¿ince Its Modern Name. Å¿o many Ages, and with which it Å¿eems to have been baptized at the very Birth of ChriÅ¿tianity it Å¿elf; how can it but imprint in all a Veneration for it, and eÅ¿pecially in all ChriÅ¿tian Gardeners?

In the third Place, To conÅ¿ider it in its Å¿elf, that is to Å¿ay, with reÅ¿pect only to its own proper Merit, which is that which is particularly in QueÅ¿tion, and can only intitle it to a preference in this place; it muÅ¿t be confeÅ¿Å¿ed, That among Kernel-Fruits, Nature preÅ¿ents us nothing Å¿o Beautiful, nor Å¿o Noble to behold as this Pear, whether we conÅ¿ider The DeÅ¿cription and PraiÅ¿es of this Pear. its Å¿hape which is long and pyramidical, or its bigneÅ¿s, which is prodigious, as being for Example three or four Inches thick, and five or Å¿ix long, and very commonly of a pound weight or more, nay, and Å¿ometimes exceeding two pounds, which is certainly a truth of rare and Å¿ingular Remark: Or particularly, if we caÅ¿t our Eyes upon its lively Carnation Colour, with which the ground of its natural Yellow is Å¿o charmingly Å¿et off, when it grows in a favourable Sun and advantageous ExpoÅ¿ition, that it attracts the Admiration of the whole World: Add to this, That it is the Pear which of all others gives the longeÅ¿t pleaÅ¿ure, as well upon the Tree, upon which it continues Å¿till increaÅ¿ing to the view of the Eye from May till the End of October, as in the Fruit-Magazine; where eaÅ¿ily preÅ¿erving its Å¿elf for four or five Months together, it daily pleaÅ¿ures the Å¿ight of the Curious that have a mind to look upon it, as much as the view of a Jewel or a TreaÅ¿ure rejoyces the MaÅ¿ter that poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿es it. It is the Pear that does the greateÅ¿t Honour at all Tables, and which in all Countries, and principally in France, where the Gardens produce a wonderful quantity of them has acquired the greateÅ¿t Reputation: It is that which is moÅ¿t commonly made uÅ¿e of when any conÅ¿iderable PreÅ¿ents of Fruits are made, and eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch as are Å¿ent to remote places, either within or without the Kingdom; and
laÅ¿tly, it is the Pear for the Beauty of which, the ableÅ¿t Gard'ners have always Laboured with the greateÅ¿t PaÅ¿Å¿ion, and that which yields the greateÅ¿t profit to thoÅ¿e which Cultivate it only to expoÅ¿e to Sale. It is always very good Å¿tewed or baked, when People have a mind to eat of it a little before 'tis full ripe, and it cannot be denied but it is moÅ¿t Excellent when we give it time to mellow, if it come out of a Garden where the Soil is naturally good, or, at leaÅ¿t, well Cultivated; and it has this Advantage over and above, That its mellowneÅ¿s is not like that of the moÅ¿t part of the Butter-fruits, which paÅ¿Å¿es, as one may Å¿ay, like Lightning; Å¿o that thoÅ¿e Sorts of Fruits are no Å¿ooner mellow, but they grow Å¿oft and pappy, and degenerate into RottenneÅ¿s; whereas the mellowneÅ¿s of each Boncretien-pear continues to maintain it Å¿elf in Vigour for Å¿ome whole Months together, as if Å¿eemed with Patience to wait the time when we Å¿hall be pleaÅ¿ed to do it the Honour to Employ it to thoÅ¿e UÅ¿es for which Nature deÅ¿ign'd it.

'Tis true indeed, That in the Order I have eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed for the Excellence of Pears, the firÅ¿t degree of GoodneÅ¿s is altogether wanting to this, becauÅ¿e it is not Buttery; and conÅ¿equently it may Å¿eem, that becauÅ¿e here our BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s is to give the firÅ¿t Rank to that Å¿ort of Pears only, that can vaunt it Å¿elf to have the moÅ¿t Excellent TaÅ¿te, I Å¿hould not grant it to this which, by my own ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, is but in the Å¿econd ClaÅ¿s of good Ones.

But though it has not the firÅ¿t degree of GoodneÅ¿s, it is certain, it wants not the Å¿econd; that is to Å¿ay, a Pulp that eats Å¿hort, and is often tender enough, with an agreeable TaÅ¿te, and a Å¿weet Å¿ugred Juice, indifferently abundant, and a little perfum'd; from the ConÅ¿ideration of which, without doubt, it was that our Fathers, to make a great DiÅ¿tinction between that and other Pears, added to its Name the Epithet of Good, without doing the Å¿ame Thing in Favour of any other Pear; which additional Name has remained to it every where in all Countries, but only in Poitou, where the People content themÅ¿elves with calling it only the ChriÅ¿tian-pear.

And, beÅ¿ides all the Advantages above-mentioned, it has likewiÅ¿e this, which appears to me a very great one, that is, when all other Pears are paÅ¿t, this Å¿till remains to Honour our Tables till the new Fruits of the Spring; and, by conÅ¿equence, protracts even Å¿o far as that time, the pleaÅ¿ure of thoÅ¿e that love raw Fruit. All which Å¿umm'd up together, excites in me Å¿o much ConÅ¿ideration for the Good ChriÅ¿tian or Boncretien-pear, that I think I Å¿hould do a kind of InjuÅ¿tice if I Å¿hould refuÅ¿e it the Place of a FirÅ¿t Dwarf-pear-tree.
I know very well it pleaÅ¿es not all the World, and that it is Å¿lighted by certain People, that accuÅ¿e it to have commonly a Pulp or FleÅ¿h, that is tough and Å¿trong, or, at leaÅ¿t, not very fine.

To which I anÅ¿wer, That thoÅ¿e are general AccuÅ¿ations, and Å¿uch as may in a manner be made againÅ¿t all Å¿orts of Fruits; it being but too true, that we are not to expect to find any that are abÅ¿olutely perfect, and therefore accordingly we call only thoÅ¿e good Fruits which have the feweÅ¿t Defects. I will not deny but that among Boncretien pears, there may be Å¿ome that may deÅ¿erve the Reproach caÅ¿t on them by thoÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons; but, in my Opinion, they deÅ¿erve it not always by their own Fault, Å¿ince it is true there very often are found moÅ¿t excellent Ones among them; and therefore thoÅ¿e Defects, when found in theÅ¿e Pears, are rather to be attributed to the badneÅ¿s of the Soil in which they grew, as not being proper for the producing of good Fruits, or of their ExpoÅ¿ition, as being Planted in a Quarter not bleÅ¿Å¿ed with a favourable AÅ¿pect from the Sun; or to the Negligence or UnskilfulneÅ¿s of the Gard'ner, who took not Å¿ufficient care of them, or to the over haÅ¿tineÅ¿s of thoÅ¿e that needs will be Å¿erving them up before they are come to a fit Maturity.

I know very well too, There are a great many PerÅ¿ons that think a Boncretien can never prove good upon a Dwarf-tree, and that 'tis abÅ¿olutely impoÅ¿Å¿ible to have any fine ones unleÅ¿s it be upon Wall-trees; and therefore, that they will highly condemn me for chuÅ¿ing it for the firÅ¿t to be Planted in a Scituation which they pretend directly contrary to it. But though I do ingenuouÅ¿ly grant it true, That the Boncretien Å¿ucceeds beÅ¿t upon a Wall-tree, eÅ¿pecially in acquiring that Vermilion that Å¿o well becomes it, and which the full Air on a Standard-tree cannot give it in Å¿uch Perfection, yet I believe I have hitherto pretty well Å¿ucceeded in diÅ¿abuÅ¿ing a great number of Curious PerÅ¿ons of the falÅ¿e ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion they had againÅ¿t a Boncretien upon a Dwarf-tree, by Å¿hewing them by the certain Experience of Å¿everal Years, eÅ¿pecially in Gardens of a midling Extent, well cloÅ¿ed and Å¿heltred from the great Colds, either by good Walls of their own, or by Å¿everal Buildings, and which conÅ¿equently are in a good ExpoÅ¿ition, and advantaged beÅ¿ides with a Soil indifferently good, either by Nature or by the help of Art; that upon Trees
of that Figure may be raiÅ¿ed very goodly Boncretien pears; that is to Å¿ay, very great ones well Å¿haped with a good fine Skin, a little bluÅ¿hed on that Å¿ide next the Sun, and in the reÅ¿t of their Bodies, of a green proper to take a yellow as they grow ripe; and, in a Word, very Excellent Pears, and Å¿uch as few Wall trees were Å¿een able to compare with.

And, to put an End to this ConteÅ¿tation, I think it not neceÅ¿Å¿ary to make here any other AnÅ¿wers, than, in the firÅ¿t place, to invite our AdverÅ¿aries to go in Autumn and Å¿ee the Dwarf-trees in Å¿everal Gardens at Paris, and at Vernon, where they rear Å¿uch â¢ ine ones; and, in the Å¿econd place, to ask them whether before the uÅ¿e of Wall-trees, which is not Ancient, there were no where in the open Air any fair Boncretiens? if they Å¿ay not, all the Back-Courts of the Provinces of Tourain, Angoumois, Poitou, Auche, &c. where they grow even upon Standard-trees, will evidence the contrary againÅ¿t any that Å¿hall deny it: To which add, That the invincible PerÅ¿ecution of the Tyger-babbs, keeps the Pears too far Tyger-babbs, a pernicious InÅ¿ect infeÅ¿ting Wall-pears. off from the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Wall-trees, and renders it impracticable almoÅ¿t in thoÅ¿e Parts, to raiÅ¿e any of them upon any other Trees but Dwarfs.

In fine, when the whole Matter is well examined, I am perÅ¿waded, That whoÅ¿oever Å¿hall count on one Å¿ide the Enemies of the Boncretien upon a Dwarf-tree, and the ReaÅ¿ons they think they have to condemn it for, and the other Å¿hall reckon up its Approvers, with the Experiences they have on their Å¿ide, will find the Number of theÅ¿e lat â¢ er greater than that of the other, or, at the leaÅ¿t, equal to it; and therefore I think I have enough wherewith to maintain the Preference here in QueÅ¿tion.

Away with all thoÅ¿e Different Kinds of Boncretiens which Å¿ome Curious PerÅ¿ons have No really different kinds o ãâ¦ã
Winter-Boncretien. fancied, and which they would perÅ¿wade us to be Real, as the Long, the Round, the Green, the Golden, the Brown, the Satin, that of Auche, that of England, that without Core, &c. For all theÅ¿e are to be found upon one and the Å¿ame Tree, and aÅ¿Å¿uredly make but one Å¿ingle and only kind, the general mutual likeneÅ¿s not only of the Wood, Leaves and Flowers of all theÅ¿e pretended Å¿orts of Boncretien-trees, but alÅ¿o more particularly the reÅ¿emblance of the Figure of the Pear, of the time of its ripening, and of its Å¿hort-eating Pulp and Å¿ugred Juice, &c. viÅ¿ibly confirm this Truth.

The Differences of Soils and ExpoÅ¿itions, of dry and wet Summers, and of Vigour and WeakneÅ¿s in a Tree, whether it be in the whole Tree, or only in a part of it, &c. ThoÅ¿e Differences, I Å¿ay, cauÅ¿e theÅ¿e other little External Differences of Colour, Figure, &c. The Wall-tree will produce Fruit more golden than green, and the Dwarf-tree more green than golden; and the Dwarf graffed upon a Free-Å¿tock will produce greener Fruit than that which is graffed upon a Quince-Å¿tock.

If the Tree be Å¿ick, whether it be young or old, it will bring Fruit without a Core, and upon that very Å¿ame Tree, if there be any vigorous Branch, as it often enough happens, there will be a Core in the Fruit that grows upon that vigorous Å¿ide, though there be none in the Pears that grow upon the infirm Branches; and if from that yellowiÅ¿h and languiÅ¿hing Å¿ide, a Branch be taken and graffed happily upon a Å¿ound and lively Stock, it will produce a Tree both green and brisk, which will Å¿hew not only the Conformity of its kind with that of other Boncretiens; but likewiÅ¿e its good Health, as well by the Core as the the green Colour of its Pear: Upon which occaÅ¿ion I Å¿hall tell you, That Å¿uch Boncretien-pears as grow yellow upon the Tree, and have a Skin that feels extraordinarily Å¿oft, are apt to have but a very indifferent goodneÅ¿s.

They might as well make different kinds of great and little, of horned and crumpled, of well Å¿haped and well look'd, &c. which would be a very ridiculous fancy, which is carefully to be avoided.

This Boncretien, I Å¿ay, Å¿hould be then the Dwarf-tree that I would Plant in a little Garden well qualified, where it Å¿hould be deÅ¿ign'd to Plant but only one Dwarf-pear-tree; and this Å¿ame Pear-tree Å¿hould be likewiÅ¿e the firÅ¿t I would chuÅ¿e, not only for a Garden in which I Å¿hould have room for a Å¿econd Dwarf, but alÅ¿o for all the other Gardens alike well qualified for it, in which I Å¿hould have room for many more Å¿uch Trees, and particularly if there were but little Walling for thoÅ¿e Trees that Å¿hould be deÅ¿igned for that Station. And this Boncretien-tree Å¿hould firÅ¿t be graffed upon a Quince: Å¿tock, chiefly becauÅ¿e the Boncretien-Dwarfs graffed on Free-Å¿tocks, commonly bring Fruit
Å¿potted, Å¿mall, crumpled, &c. And conÅ¿equently diÅ¿agreeable to the Å¿ight: In the Å¿econd place, it Å¿hould be Planted in that part of the Garden facing the Wall trees, neareÅ¿t the Wall expoÅ¿ed to the moÅ¿t favourable Sun; and laÅ¿tly, immediately after the End of AuguÅ¿t, I would have the leaves taken off that hindred the Sun from Å¿hining upon the Fruit, which are all Precautions extreamly important.
