argument.p: Concerning the Choice of a Second Dwarf-pear-tree, and after that, concerning the Choice of a Third, Fourth, Fifth and Sixth of the Å¿ame, &c.

div.p: NOW let us Å¿ee upon what Pear-tree our Choice will fall to be the Second Dwarf, as well of that little Garden where there can be but Two, as the Second of all others, where there is room for a greater Number; for truly it is a point not over-eaÅ¿ie to decide.

We have above all the reÅ¿t, Six different Å¿orts of Pears that put in briskly for this Second place, nay, and which can hardly brook without murmuring, that the Boncretien Å¿hould peaceably enjoy the Honour it has newly received, which are the Butter-pear, the Autumn Bergamot, the Virgoulee, the LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿erie, the Winter Ambret and Winter Thorn-pear: Nay, and beÅ¿ides there are, the ancient Petit-oin, the LouiÅ¿e-bonne or Good LouiÅ¿e, with four new Commers, namely, the St. Germain, the Colmar, the CraÅ¿anne, and the MarquiÅ¿s or MarchioneÅ¿s, which finding themÅ¿elves provided with Å¿ufficient Merit, want not the Ambition to enter into this DiÅ¿pute, every one of theÅ¿e Twelve pretending Å¿everally to have more Perfections, and fewer Defects than any one of its Rivals, or, at leaÅ¿t, to be nothing inferior to them; and accordingly pretending too, to win from them the Place that is here in QueÅ¿tion.

And I grant, they all have Å¿uch powerful Motives for their Å¿everal Pretentions, that we cannot be cenÅ¿ured to have made an ill Choice to which of them Å¿oever we Å¿hall give the Preference: However, my Judgment is, That theÅ¿e Six laÅ¿t ought to retire for a time, and leave the Six firÅ¿t to fight out this Quarrel; and I Å¿hall give, if I be not miÅ¿taken, Å¿uch good ReaÅ¿ons for it, that I hope their Patrons will be Å¿atisfied with them. But before I declare my Å¿elf for any one of theÅ¿e Six, it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to examine Å¿eparately, and without prejudice, all the Å¿everal ReaÅ¿ons pleaded by every one of them.

I begin with thoÅ¿e of the Butter-pear, concerning which I muÅ¿t firÅ¿t lay it down for a ConcluÅ¿ion, That as well the red Butter-pear, otherwiÅ¿e called the AmbroiÅ¿e or IÅ¿ambert of the Normans, as the grey Butter and green Butter-pears, are but one and the Å¿ame thing; for that oftentimes all theÅ¿e pretended Sorts are found upon one and the Å¿ame Tree, thoÅ¿e differences of Colour having no other Foundation in a manner than thoÅ¿e which we have remarked in the Boncretien; the fair ExpoÅ¿ition of them, or perhaps an indifferent weak Temper either in the whole Tree, or in any particular Branch, producing red Pears; and a Å¿hady Situation, and the vigour either of the whole Tree, or of any particular Branch of it, making grey or green ones: And the Quince and Free-Å¿tocks upon which theÅ¿e Pear-trees are graffed, Å¿hew themÅ¿elves by the different Colours with which they tinge their Fruit, the Colour of the Fruit of the Pear-trees on Free-Å¿tocks being quite another thing from that of the Boncretien graffed on a Quince-Å¿tock: BeÅ¿ides which, the dryneÅ¿s or moiÅ¿tneÅ¿s of the Soil in which they grow, fail not to imprint Å¿ome Marlts and Features of their own FaÅ¿hion.

This being firÅ¿t laid down as a neceÅ¿Å¿ary Remark, the ReaÅ¿ons of this Butter-pear are, The DeÅ¿cription and Commendation of the Butter-pear. firÅ¿t, That it is poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s'd in Å¿uch Perfection of the firÅ¿t Degree of GoodneÅ¿s, that is to be deÅ¿ired in Fruits, which is a Å¿mooth delicious melting SoftneÅ¿s, that the Name of Butter-pear
was for that Quality given it by way of Excellence; and, in effect, its name is borrowed to give to others whoÅ¿e Merit we would Extol, and therefore this Pear believes to The Conditions neceÅ¿Å¿ary to conÅ¿titute an Excellent Pear. have Right to pretend, that not one of the other Pears Å¿hould diÅ¿pute with it for an extream abundance of Juice, nor for a fine and delicate Pulp, and rich TaÅ¿te, which are all the Conditions neceÅ¿Å¿ary to conÅ¿titute an excellent Pear.
In the Å¿econd Place, it pretends to have the advantage to charm the Å¿ight, as well by the bigneÅ¿s of its Body, as the goodlineÅ¿s of its Figure, and Beauty of its Colour.

In the third place it is perÅ¿waded, It may hope all Things from the HappineÅ¿s it has to be extreamly fertile; Å¿o that commonly every Year, and in all Å¿orts of Ground it is loaden almoÅ¿t ready to break, and Å¿ucceeds as well upon a Free-Å¿tock, as upon a Quince one, and almoÅ¿t as well under the Hands of Ignorant as of Able Gard'ners; beÅ¿ides, that it is Å¿eldom or never apt to be Doughy, InÅ¿ipid and Mealy, as are moÅ¿t other tender Pears, and that not only, it is not Å¿o incommoded by the full Air as the Bergamot, but alÅ¿o bears Å¿ooner than the Virgoulee, and produces fairer Fruit than any of its Competitors. Here are without doubt a great many ReaÅ¿ons, and all of great Weight and Authority, Å¿trongly to prove and confirm the right of the Butter-pears claim in this CauÅ¿e.

TheÅ¿e two Pears do not think themÅ¿elves overcome by all that has been Å¿aid to the advantage of them that have firÅ¿t Å¿poken; they will not make it their BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s to deÅ¿troy one another, being agreed to Å¿erve alternatively at the Entrance of Gardens, and Å¿o their principal Ambition is to remain united, and allied in IntereÅ¿t and FriendÅ¿hip, that they may be able the more vigorouÅ¿ly to defend themÅ¿elves againÅ¿t the three precedent ones: And that which contributes the more to the Å¿trict Union they have made one with the other, is, That, in effect, they have Å¿ome reÅ¿emblance one with the other, firÅ¿t in their Shape, which appears roundiÅ¿h in both, though the Ambret be a little flatter, and hath its Eye or Crown hollower and deeper Å¿unk, whereas the LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿erie hath its Eye or Crown quite jetting out; and in that Å¿ome of them have the form of a Lemon; they alÅ¿o reÅ¿emble one another in the Å¿econd place, in their bigneÅ¿s, which is of a midling Å¿ize, and of about two Inches Extent every way; in the third place, in their Colour, which upon the Tree

The Winter Thorn pear, which well knows its own worth, will not let it Å¿elf be condemned neither without Å¿peaking for it Å¿elf: It is a very fine Pear that approaches nearera Pyramidical than a round Figure, though it has almoÅ¿t no part that is Å¿mall in its Å¿hape, Å¿o that it ends in very little or nothing of a bluntiÅ¿h Point towards the Stalk, which Stalk is pretty Å¿hort and Å¿mall, except where it comes out of the Pear, where it is a little fleÅ¿hy; every where elÅ¿e the Pear is all over in a manner of the Å¿ame bigneÅ¿s, being about Two or Three Inches thick towards the Head; it is particularly much bigger than the ordinary Bergamot, or than the Ambret and LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿erie; it has a Å¿atiny Skin, and a Colour between Green and White; it Å¿ometimes Ripens before the two laÅ¿t preceding ones, but moÅ¿t commonly at the Å¿ame time with them, and Å¿ometimes too after them; it is likewiÅ¿e of a tender and butter-like ConÅ¿iÅ¿tence, having ordinarily a very fine and delicate Pulp, an agreeable TaÅ¿te, and a Å¿weet Juice reliÅ¿hed with an admirable Å¿mack of Perfume; it alÅ¿o produces fine Dwarf-trees, and proÅ¿pers as well on Free as on Quince-tree-Å¿tocks, when the Stocks are good, and the Ground is well qualified, that is, of a dry rather than moiÅ¿t Temper. It is therefore now the QueÅ¿tion how to terminate this ConteÅ¿tation which has appeared but too long, upon which, having maturely examined all the ReaÅ¿ons alledged by each of them, I confeÅ¿s I have a very particular eÅ¿teem for every one of them; but yet, in regard to the Trees which give them us, we muÅ¿t not judge the QueÅ¿tion here under DiÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ion, altogether upon the Å¿ame Foundation as if we were only examining the Merit of each Fruit in particular, and by comparing them only one with the other; for upon the bare Foot of Merit, in what Garden Å¿oever it were, where there were to be but two Dwarf pear-trees, I Å¿hould ever incline to give the Å¿econd place to the Bergamot, which I honour infinitely, and that, methinks, cannot be too much honoured, as being as it were the Queen of Pears: For indeed it is like the Excellent Muskmelons, its Pulp appearing at firÅ¿t firm, without being hard or Å¿tony, and fine and melting without being Doughy or Mealy, and its Juice Å¿ugred and a little Perfumed without having any mixture of Å¿harpneÅ¿s or wildneÅ¿s; and laÅ¿tly, its TaÅ¿te rich, and wonderfully delicious, and accompanied with Å¿omething of Noble: For Å¿uch a Pear as that, may it not vaunt to have approached very near the Perfection of Fruits, and ought it not to Å¿erve for a Rule and Model to all thoÅ¿e that Å¿hall pretend to be entred into the Catalogue of good Fruits?

Yet that which may Å¿ometimes hinder the Bergamot from receiving the benefit of this my Declaration, is, the unhappineÅ¿s the Wood of its Tree has to be of Å¿o delicate a Temper, that inÅ¿tead of making an agreeable Spectacle in Gardens, it does often but vex its Owner with its ScabbineÅ¿s, which is an evil that every where almoÅ¿t perÅ¿ecutes both its Fruit and Tree. But yet it is of a great Importance to this Virgoulee-pear, that we Å¿hould not leave it How to prevent the ill TaÅ¿te in Virgoulee-Pears, and from what CauÅ¿e that TaÅ¿te proceeds. under the Defamation of the publick Reproach which the other Pears caÅ¿t upon it, becauÅ¿e of its odd TaÅ¿te. We cannot deny but there have been many of theÅ¿e Pears found with that Defect; but then 'tis not impoÅ¿Å¿ible to exempt them from it; for it proceeds from their having been too long kept upon Hay or Straw, or perhaps too long Å¿mothered up in Å¿ome Cupboard, where they had no Air, or in a kind of Cellar, which is never without Å¿ome TaÅ¿te of MuÅ¿t; or elÅ¿e in Å¿ome Fruit-Å¿tore-houÅ¿e too cloÅ¿e kept Å¿hut, when full of other Å¿orts of Fruits, and perhaps in Å¿ome part of it Infected with Å¿ome Å¿trong Smell whatever it be: For all thoÅ¿e Scents together make but a very diÅ¿agreeable Smell, of which this kind of Pear is unhappily very Å¿uÅ¿ceptible. The only Remedy in QueÅ¿tion is then, to put them up in Å¿ome place where none of theÅ¿e Inconveniences are to be met with, and conÅ¿equently having a Fruit-loft for that purpoÅ¿e, well Qualified againÅ¿t the great Cold and MoiÅ¿ture, the Boards of it muÅ¿t be covered with Å¿ome MoÅ¿s extreamly well dried; and then the Pears muÅ¿t be placed on it at a diÅ¿tance one from the other, and Air muÅ¿t be given them as often as the Weather is fair: With theÅ¿e kinds of Precautions, which are not very difficult, we may be aÅ¿Å¿ured to have all Winter long theÅ¿e Virgoulee-pears preÅ¿erved from any ill TaÅ¿te. They are, as we have Å¿aid, fair and large, and moÅ¿t excellent, provided firÅ¿t, that, without being too much wrinkled, they appear only a little The Marks of goodneÅ¿s or badneÅ¿s in Virgoulee-pears. withered; and Å¿econdly, that they be yellow almoÅ¿t all over the whole Extent of their Skin; and thirdly, if in Å¿queezing them a little with the Thumb near the Stalk, they give way without Å¿hewing any Å¿oftneÅ¿s at the Heart; that is to Å¿ay, in fine, if they come Å¿o well to ripen and mellow, that their Pulp is become tender and melting: For if, though in appearance ripe, they remain firm and hard, as it happens Å¿ometimes to them that have been laid up in moiÅ¿t Places, or which are of the Product of a very Rainy Summer, or of Å¿ome Northern ExpoÅ¿ition, or Å¿ome cold and watriÅ¿h Soil, then it cannot be denied but that theÅ¿e Å¿ort of Pears prove both mealy and inÅ¿ipid, and by conÅ¿equence diÅ¿agreeable. So it is, that among the Things of this World, that are the moÅ¿t perfect, there may be Å¿ome of them that may fall into Corruption, and at the Å¿ame time into Contempt; but the Fault of one particular thing ought not to be made a matter of Reproach to the whole general Kind.

One thing that is extraordinary enough, I have to remark concerning theÅ¿e Pears, is, A Å¿ingular Remark about Virgoulee-pears. That Å¿uch of them as perhaps fell off the Tree, or were gathered about Fifteen Days before they Å¿hould have been, and which becauÅ¿e of that grow a little withered (for if they were much Å¿o, they would be deÅ¿piÅ¿able in all manner of ReÅ¿pects) theÅ¿e Å¿ort of Pears, I Å¿ay, though a little unhandÅ¿om to look upon, yet at length being throughly mellowed, are almoÅ¿t always of an admirable TaÅ¿te, which can be hardly Å¿aid of any other Fruit: But yet I do not CounÅ¿el any to gather them very long before their time; as for Example, before the End of September, becauÅ¿e the ordinary Winds that Reign at that time, Å¿pare them, and Å¿ometimes more than they deÅ¿ire, the taking of that Pains; and therefore we may comfort our Å¿elves then, when any of them happen to fall, with the Expectation that they will mellow later than the reÅ¿t, and will be leÅ¿s Å¿ubject to grow doughy, and we Å¿hall be apt to wiÅ¿h it may happen oftner, that we may without fail have Å¿ome Pears that may be good, and at the Å¿ame time fair, Å¿ound and indifferently wrinkled. I Å¿hall in another place explain to you more particularly what time they are to be gathered, and what are the infallible marks of their true Maturity, as well as of that of all other Fruits; which are Articles of very great Importance, and in which conÅ¿iÅ¿t the principal Points of our CurioÅ¿ity.
The Virgoulee-pear-tree Å¿hall be regularly the Third Dwarf-tree.

div.head: The Third Dwarf-tree. A FirÅ¿t Virgoulee.
div.p: Which we will Plant in a Garden which is able to hold but three, and methinks now, November, December and January. this Pear-tree would be much in the wrong to complain, Å¿ince it may be affirmed with Truth, that it has the Honour to Å¿ee it Å¿elf preferred before other marvellous Pears, which are following after it; as namely, the LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿erie, the Ambret, the Winter Thorn-pear, the CraÅ¿anne, the St. Germain, the Colmar, the MarchioneÅ¿s, the Petit-oin, the St. AuguÅ¿tin, the RouÅ¿Å¿elet, the Robins, &c.

All the World muÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿arily grant, That the Name of Fruit-Garden cannot properly be given to any Garden whatÅ¿oever, in which are not to be found the Thirteen or Fourteen principaleÅ¿t Sorts of Pears we have; and likewiÅ¿e, that we cannot diÅ¿pute it that Title, when they all meet there in Company. Happy is he that has planted with Å¿o much Knowledge and diÅ¿cerning Judgment, as having no more room in his Garden but for Å¿uch a Å¿mall number of Trees, to have Å¿o wiÅ¿ely cull'd out and join'd together the beÅ¿t Fruits we know.
To continue the Order of my Choice, I place the LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿erie-pear immediately after the Virgoulee-pear.

div.head: The Fourth Dwarf-tree. A FirÅ¿t LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿erie. November, December and January.
div.p: Before which, perhaps, Å¿ome Curious PerÅ¿ons will make no Å¿cruple to prefer it, Å¿o true it is, That it often Å¿eems a Pear without Defect, and conÅ¿equently a Fruit of the moÅ¿t excelling goodneÅ¿s: I will Å¿ay in its Favour, That I never taÅ¿ted any thing better in matter of Pears, than Å¿ome LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿eries growing in the open Air upon Trees, as I may Å¿ay, abandoned. They were of a midling bigneÅ¿s, having a Skin and Shape that Å¿eemed quite wild; but, in truth, in eating them even with their Skin and all, they quite charmed me with their rich TaÅ¿te, their little delicate perfumed Scent, and their fine and melting Pulp: In fine, I cannot be Å¿ilent of the AÅ¿toniÅ¿hment they put me in, and of the pleaÅ¿ure I had, and continue to have every Year in eating them; and perhaps I might Å¿ay, That the beÅ¿t Bergamot in the World would have had much ado to have maintained its PoÅ¿t before them; for thoÅ¿e which I had of the Å¿ame Å¿ort from Wall-trees, came not near them any way of the World in point of goodneÅ¿s.

div.head: The Fifth Dwarf-tree. A FirÅ¿t Ambret. November, December and January.
div.p: And this follows it as near as 'tis poÅ¿Å¿ible; and indeed is ordinarily a moÅ¿t Excellent Pear in every point, having a fine melting Pulp, and a certain rich TaÅ¿te that is very charming, provided it be of the growth of a good Soil, and that without Å¿uffering any MiÅ¿carriage, or any other ill Accident upon the Tree, it come to its perfect Maturity; but yet I know not what greeniÅ¿h Tincture in its Pulp, and a faintiÅ¿h TaÅ¿te in its Juice, and particularly a Å¿trange kind of unknown, and Å¿ecret lurking dry rottenneÅ¿s found in Å¿ome of theÅ¿e Fruits, appear to me three Å¿orts of Defects, for which, in my Opinion, this Pear in general ought without Repugnance, to yield the precedence to the LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿erie, and might with good ReaÅ¿on enough do it likewiÅ¿e to the Winter Thorn-pear, when it attains all the Perfection 'tis capable of. For indeed, this Thorn-pear, when it grows in a Country hot enough, in a dry Ground, and a good ExpoÅ¿ition, in Years moderately rainy, and upon a Standard or half Standard-tree well placed, is Å¿o perfect in all its Qualities, that it equals the delicateneÅ¿s of the Pulp of good Peaches, and is of Å¿uch Excellence, that the name of Marvellous has been given it in the Provinces of Angoumois, Xantoigne and Poitou, Provinces Å¿ituated in a marvellous Climate, and which are known to be famous for the great number of Sorts of good Fruits they produce, and of PerÅ¿ons of Quality that divertiÅ¿e themÅ¿elves there in Gardenage: And I confeÅ¿s in good Truth, That among all Pears, I find none better than this, when it attains the full goodneÅ¿s of its kind; but, at the Å¿ame time. I cannot but confeÅ¿s likewiÅ¿e, That it is very hard to find any perfect ones of them; Å¿o that one may Å¿ay of them, and of the Petit-oins, Ambrets, LouiÅ¿e-bonnes and Colmars, &c. what is Å¿aid of new laid Eggs, That the leaÅ¿t Defect is enough to make them be rejected: Whereas it is not Å¿o with other Pears, they are not rejected, though they want Å¿ome degree of natural Perfection, for all Butter pears, RuÅ¿Å¿elets, Boncretiens, &c. are not every Pear of them of the moÅ¿t Excellent in their Kind, and yet that hinders not People from eating them, though but of a midling GoodneÅ¿s.

There truly Å¿till remains a Å¿mall Reproach to be made to this Thorn-pear, becauÅ¿e it ripens Å¿ometimes at the Å¿ame time with the other Pears which I have newly placed before it, and conÅ¿equently according to thoÅ¿e Regards I always have in making this Choice, and from which it will be convenient I Å¿hould never depart, it would be much better to Plant Å¿ome good Fruit of another SeaÅ¿on in this little Garden, rather than this Pear; but to this I anÅ¿wer, That Å¿ince this objected Inconvenience of over-haÅ¿ty ripening, happens but very Å¿eldom, inÅ¿tead of baniÅ¿hing the Thorn-pear from hence for Å¿uch a Reproach as that, we ought rather to be careful to plant it there, and eÅ¿pecially if there be already no Bergamot Dwarf-tree, becauÅ¿e it makes a very agreeable Dwarf-tree, and eaÅ¿ily takes to bear.
I perÅ¿iÅ¿t therefore to give to the Thorn pear at leaÅ¿t

div.head: The Sixth Dwarf-tree. A firÅ¿t Winter Thorn pear.
div.p: The Å¿ixth place in a Garden well qualified, and that can receive but Å¿ix Dwarf-trees. November, December and January. And there muÅ¿t a particular care taken of this Tree, to keep its Branches well Å¿pread, and to Å¿trip it of its Leaves too at the end of Autumn. So that the Pear, whoÅ¿e Colour is naturally green, may receive thereby an extraordinary Coction; and when it comes to be laid up, may grow a little yellowiÅ¿h, to Å¿ignifie the firÅ¿t Appearance of its mellowing; for to Å¿ay the Truth, when it Å¿till preÅ¿erves the Å¿ame ground of green in its Skin, it had upon the Tree, as do thoÅ¿e of this kind, that grow in a moiÅ¿t Ground, or upon a Dwarf-tree with a top too much tuffed, or in a bad ExpoÅ¿ition, it laÅ¿ts indeed till January or February, but 'tis only to vex him that took the pains to lay it up, and keep it; becauÅ¿e without mellowing, it grows Å¿oft all about the Stalk, and Contracts a cottoniÅ¿h dry Pulp, and a flat and inÅ¿ipid TaÅ¿te; and, in a word, proves the worÅ¿t Pear in the World; neither indeed is there any Pear which has need of greater care than this, to make it come to good. It requires to be graffed upon a Free-Å¿tock in dry Grounds, and upon a Quince one in thoÅ¿e which are moiÅ¿tiÅ¿h. It Å¿ucceeds not Å¿o well in the form of a Dwarf-tree, as in that of a Standard, in thoÅ¿e Grounds that are a little Å¿trong; and commonly is worth nothing in Soils that are fat and moiÅ¿t, having that Quality in common with Å¿ome others which I Å¿hall Å¿peak of afterwards. However, I muÅ¿t needs Å¿ay, that, with the care I have had to keep my Soil a little raiÅ¿ed, and timely to uncover my Thorn-pears by Å¿tripping off the Leaves of their Dwarf-trees, I have had very fair and good ones of them for near two Months together; and conÅ¿equently, that the Defects of this Pear are not always incorrigible, and that when we can preÅ¿erve it from them, It is a piece of InjuÅ¿tice not to give it place before the two laÅ¿t preceding ones.

I prefer it here before the St. Germain, the Perit-oin, the CraÅ¿anne, the MarchioneÅ¿s, the LouiÅ¿e-bonne, the Colmar, and the St. AuguÅ¿tin-pears; becauÅ¿e, that all things well conÅ¿idered, it is of more worth than they; and chiefly, becauÅ¿e the moÅ¿t part of thoÅ¿e other Pears mellow in the time of Å¿ome of the three preceding ones, that is to Å¿ay, in the Months of November and December; in which, with reÅ¿pect to the Å¿mallneÅ¿s of the Gardens we now treat of, we have other Fruits enough to give content.

I prefer it alÅ¿o before the two moÅ¿t valuable Summer-pears, which are the Famous RuÅ¿Å¿elet, and the IlluÅ¿trious Robine, but it is but one degree only to make it march immediately before them; and theÅ¿e latter in their turn Å¿hall be preferred before thoÅ¿e other five, which are of Å¿o great Reputation. And without doubt, this preference given them without any heÅ¿itation, ought to Å¿top their Mouths from murmuring, becauÅ¿e they were no Å¿ooner produced on the Stage. For my part, I make Å¿o great account of both of them, that I do not think a Garden that may contain Seven or Eight Dwarf-pear-trees, ought to be without one RuÅ¿Å¿elet and one Robine-tree; which when we have placed, we will proceed to examine what good and conÅ¿iderable Qualities the other Pears can plead, in order to the doing them that Å¿peedy JuÅ¿tice thereupon, which we think to be their Due.

Would to God, that in the matter of good Pears, the Months of January, February and March, were able to furniÅ¿h me as many Å¿ubjects of DiÅ¿putes and ConteÅ¿tation to determine, as I am plied with by the four preceding Months; for theÅ¿e latter being Å¿o poor and barren as they are, have great need of aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance; but when there will come any to them, I cannot tell. Certain it is, 'twould be a great good Fortune to them, if they poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed any of thoÅ¿e good Pears, which pour in in Shoals upon us, as I may Å¿ay, about the End of Autumn, and the beginning of Winter; I loÅ¿e not a moment of Time in Å¿tudying and uÅ¿ing all imaginable means, as I have before Å¿aid, to bring about Å¿o great a HappineÅ¿s.

But to return to my purpoÅ¿e, I proceed then to place theÅ¿e two laÅ¿t Pears, of which we were but now Å¿peaking, aÅ¿Å¿uredly expecting, that my Choice of them will be approved. For, methinks, we ought not to delay any longer to introduce here Å¿ome Summer-pears, having already placed Å¿ix Sorts of other SeaÅ¿ons: But what muÅ¿t I do to regulate the DiÅ¿pute that's like to riÅ¿e between theÅ¿e two Pears, which Å¿hall be the firÅ¿t? Why, I will not undertake to decide it of my own Head, it being a CauÅ¿e too dangerous to judge of in the preÅ¿ence of the Patrons of both the Parties, and therefore not to embroil my Å¿elf on either Å¿ide. The way I Å¿hall take with them, Å¿hall be either to give theÅ¿e Pears an alternative Precedence to be enjoyed by each of them, in their turns, or rather even to let them fairly draw Lots for it: 'Tis not the firÅ¿t ConteÅ¿t of Precedence that has
been determined this way and that, to the Contentment of both Parties too. So be it then, and accordingly they caÅ¿t Lots, &c.
The Lot falls upon the RuÅ¿Å¿elet, for the Garden of Å¿even Dwarf trees.

div.head: The Seventh Dwarf tree. A FirÅ¿t RuÅ¿Å¿elet.
div.p: And therefore that Å¿hall be the Seventh in Rank, and the Robine the Eighth.

And in theÅ¿e RuÅ¿Å¿elet-pears, I make no difference between the great Å¿ort and the Å¿mall Å¿ort, as do Å¿ome Curious PerÅ¿ons; for they are certainly both but one, and to prove it Å¿o without Contradiction, let us have but recourÅ¿e to our Eyes, and we Å¿hall Å¿ee one Tree very ordinarily produce both the pretended Å¿orts of them. 'Tis true however, that thoÅ¿e that are but of a midling bigneÅ¿s, are commonly better than the faireÅ¿t (which ObÅ¿ervation holds too in Å¿ome other Fruits, though not in all.) The great RuÅ¿Å¿elet-pears doubtleÅ¿s are of the Product of a fat Soil, whether they grow upon Dwraf-trees or Wall-trees, and the others of that of a dry Ground, or of a Standard-tree.

I Å¿hall begin my DiÅ¿courÅ¿e of this RuÅ¿Å¿elet-pear by telling you, There is hardly a Pear in the World more known, nor more eÅ¿teemed than it. I think it is hardly neceÅ¿Å¿ary to make a DeÅ¿cription of it by telling you, That 'tis a Pear of a midling bigneÅ¿s, of a handÅ¿om The RuÅ¿Å¿elet or RuÅ¿Å¿etin-pear deÅ¿cribed. Å¿hape, more long than round, with a pretty thick Stalk and pretty long, of a grey Colour, reddiÅ¿h on one Å¿ide, and of a dark red on the other, with Å¿ome greeniÅ¿h Parts interlac'd, which grow yellow very opportunely, to give us notice of the Time of its Maturity: Its Pulp is tender and fine, and without any earthy or Å¿tony Remains, and its Juice moÅ¿t agreeably perfumed, but with Å¿uch a Perfume as is to be found no where but in it Å¿elf. It commonly ripens about the End of AuguÅ¿t and beginning of September, and at that time, in reÅ¿pect of the good Qualities with which it is endowed, I believe all the World, without heÅ¿itation, is agreed, That it may be Å¿aid of the RuÅ¿Å¿elets, as of the Bergamots and LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿eries, that no Pears can pretend any place in the Rank of thoÅ¿e that are Excellent; but as they proportionably approach more or leÅ¿s to the goodneÅ¿s of the RuÅ¿Å¿elet, as well as of thoÅ¿e two other Pears. And certainly the Merit of this RuÅ¿Å¿elet is Å¿o great, that it is in nothing Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿ed by its great Reputation: All Ages have Experienced it to prove good in what manner Å¿oever one order it. In effect, let it be raw or baked, Å¿tewed or preÅ¿erv'd, or let it be prepared in form of a liquid Compote, or of a dry Å¿weet-meat, Compote, Fruit Å¿tew'd in Sugar, after a manner peculiar to the French. it equally maintains its good Character in every manner: And let it be planted in any Å¿ort of Ground whatÅ¿oever, it will proÅ¿per. Have we a mind to have it upon a Wall-tree? It will give Content: Or, is our Fancy to Plant it in form of a Dwarf-tree? It will be admirable that way, and Å¿till better upon a great Standard; nay, one may Å¿ay in its honour (which, among all Fruits, belongs, if I miÅ¿take not, only to this) that though among its Pears there are often found Å¿ome that are better than others, yet there is never Å¿een any of them that can be Å¿aid to be abÅ¿olutely bad, provided it be come to its full Maturity; for thoÅ¿e that have not that, and much leÅ¿s thoÅ¿e that have too much of it, are not at all agreeable.

It is good you Å¿hould know here, That nothing is more contrary to this Pear, to hinder it from being Excellent, than the planting it againÅ¿t a Wall, becauÅ¿e it certainly loÅ¿es in that Situation, a part of its Perfume; but it grows fair there indeed and large, and in great abundance, and by that, in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure, Repairs the Defect of extream GoodneÅ¿s: So that we may lay it down for a Rule, That we ought to Plant few Trees of this Fruit againÅ¿t Walls, unleÅ¿s we make more account of the bigneÅ¿s and quantity of its Fruit, than of the goodneÅ¿s and Delicacy of its TaÅ¿te; or, unleÅ¿s we think it better rather to have Å¿ome of them, though but indifferently good, than to have none at all, that being the ordinary Effect of a Wall-tree in reÅ¿pect of Pears and Peaches; for that is of the two, what I would counÅ¿el all PerÅ¿ons to chuÅ¿e, who have a great deal of Walling to garniÅ¿h, as I Å¿hall afterwards more particularly Å¿hew, this not being the place to Å¿peak of it here. I was not able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the Temptation which over-Å¿way'd me, nor to forget any thing that might Å¿et out the Excellence of this RuÅ¿Å¿elet; and therefore cannot but obÅ¿erve to you, that there is Å¿till one Å¿ingular Advantage belonging to it, which is, that whereas moÅ¿t other Fruits prove unÅ¿ucceÅ¿sful upon the Northern Wall-trees, yet thoÅ¿e of this Pear in that ExpoÅ¿ition, produce Fruit reaÅ¿onably good, Å¿o that it would not be amiÅ¿s to plant Å¿ome Trees of it in thoÅ¿e ExpoÅ¿itions which commonly are uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, or very bad for other Fruit.

O how happy Å¿hould we be, if firÅ¿t the RuÅ¿Å¿elet pear could keep a little longer than it does (it having the miÅ¿hap to be very Å¿ubject to grow Å¿oft and pappy, 'tis its only defect, and one may often be deceived by it, without taking very good heed) or, if chiefly it would change place with Å¿o many other pitiful Å¿orts of Pears, Å¿ome of which unprofitably
come in the firÅ¿t Summer-Months, and Å¿ome again yet leÅ¿s to the purpoÅ¿e, in the midÅ¿t of Winter; Å¿o that this RuÅ¿Å¿elet, inÅ¿tead of ripening as it does, at the end of AuguÅ¿t and beginning of September, that is to Å¿ay, in the time of the abundance of good Peaches and Plums, had but the Gift to come and feaÅ¿t us, either Å¿ome time before the Maturity of the principal Stone-fruits, or Å¿ometimes after they are paÅ¿t. I could not help making this wiÅ¿h, though it be Å¿o very inÅ¿ignificant, and beg your Pardon for it. I know well enough, That Peaches, when they attain their natural GoodneÅ¿s are, as one may Å¿ay, the precious Manna of our Gardens, and by the general ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of all, are more valuable than any Kernel-fruit whatÅ¿oever; Å¿o that few People make their Court to theÅ¿e laÅ¿t, Å¿o long as the Peaches with their largeneÅ¿s, fine Å¿hape, beautiful Colour, and the abundance of their Å¿weet and rich taÅ¿ted Juice, together with all the reÅ¿t of their admirable Qualities, continue in a condition to charm the Eye, and move the Appetite.

But yet for all that, the RuÅ¿Å¿elets and the Robines are eÅ¿teemed even in the SeaÅ¿on of Peaches, how plentiful Å¿oever theÅ¿e latter be: And likewiÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e Peaches are commonly more faulty, and more apt to fall Å¿hort of their due Perfection than Pears, and that Peaches of the growth of a moiÅ¿t Soil, are good for little, therefore 'tis neceÅ¿Å¿ary for them, whoÅ¿e Ground is not very good, to precaution and provide themÅ¿elves another way, at leaÅ¿t by a Å¿upply of RuÅ¿Å¿elet-pears in their Å¿tead, which Å¿eldom fails and is never to be rejected; that at the end of AuguÅ¿t, and in the Month of September, which is the SeaÅ¿on of Mens eager Appetite, and moÅ¿t paÅ¿Å¿ionate deÅ¿ire after Fruits, they may be furniÅ¿h'd at leaÅ¿t with Å¿ome pretty good Pears, in caÅ¿e they be Å¿o unhappy as to Å¿ee the moÅ¿t part of their Peaches miÅ¿carry, or prove not over good.

This Pear is indeed Å¿mall, but it affords this convenience, that it may be gathered while 'tis yet greeniÅ¿h, to mellow afterwards off of the Tree; Å¿o that by that means it may be kept Å¿ome Days, whilÅ¿t the perfection of its mellowneÅ¿s is coming on, and may, without any diminution of its goodneÅ¿s, be hazarded to make Å¿ome Å¿mall Journies; Å¿o that, for Example, one may carry Å¿ome about one, or Å¿end them from Province to Province, when the diÅ¿tance is not too great.

And now, after all theÅ¿e PraiÅ¿es I have given to the RuÅ¿Å¿elet, may it not Å¿eem to have Å¿ome ReaÅ¿on to complain of me, for giving it but a Seventh place? I certainly have for it as much ConÅ¿ideration as any curious PerÅ¿on can have; but, in fine, that which ought to juÅ¿tifie my Conduct in this CaÅ¿e, is, That when one can compaÅ¿s Å¿o much as to have a Garden big enough to contain Five or Six Dwarf-pear-trees, one may and ought, in all probability, to have a proportionable quantity of Wall-trees, for Figs, Peaches, Plums and Grapes. And that Å¿o it would be a piece of Imprudence, for Å¿uch very little Places as are the Gardens we are here planting, to CounÅ¿el any one to plant any conÅ¿iderable number of Trees, both of Stone-fruit and Kernel-fruit, to ripen in one and the Å¿ame SeaÅ¿on of the Months of AuguÅ¿t and September, which could not well be without running the hazard of having almoÅ¿t no Fruit at all for the moÅ¿t difficult SeaÅ¿ons: And therefore I have grounded my Expectations upon the Wall-trees, to be Å¿urely furniÅ¿hed with Summer-Fruits, and have deÅ¿ign'd the moÅ¿t part of the Å¿ix firÅ¿t Pear-trees for the making a ProviÅ¿ion for Autumn and Winter, two SeaÅ¿ons which we paÅ¿s but diÅ¿agreeably without a DeÅ¿ert to brisk them up; And therefore, I think, I have great ReaÅ¿on to Å¿ay, we ought to labour to provide for them before the reÅ¿t.
The RuÅ¿Å¿elet being thus plac'd, the Robine advances, and takes the Eighth place.

div.head: The Eighth Dwarf-tree. A FirÅ¿t Robine-pear-tree.
div.p:
This Pear is known in different Places, Å¿ometimes under the Name of the Pear of Averat,
AuguÅ¿t and September. The Å¿everal Names of the Robine-pear. Å¿ometimes under that of the MuÅ¿cat-pear of AuguÅ¿t, &c. and at the Court it Å¿elf by the name of the Pear-Royal, that Name being given it by the IlluÅ¿trious Father of the Curious, who believed, and not without reaÅ¿on, that, as among us, the Title of King is at preÅ¿ent appropriated to the PerÅ¿on of Him that, of all Men, has the moÅ¿t Merit; Å¿o the Name of Royal among Pears, ought to be given to that which appears to have the feweÅ¿t Defects; and, in Truth, may be look'd upon as an accompliÅ¿h'd Pear. Take here its Picture: It is near about the bigneÅ¿s and Å¿hape of a little Bergamot, that is to Å¿ay, between round The Robine-pear DeÅ¿cribed and Commended. and flat, its Stalk is pretty long, Å¿trait, and Å¿unk pretty hollow into the Pear, and its Crown or Eye is alÅ¿o a little hollow and Å¿unk inwards, its Pulp breaks Å¿hort in the Mouth without being hard, and its Å¿ugred and perfumed Juice charms all the World, and particularly the chiefeÅ¿t Prince of the Earth, and with him all the whole Royal Family. argument.p: Of Standard Pear-trees to Plant.

div.p: THere is nothing near Å¿o much ReaÅ¿on to oblige me to make Å¿o nice a DiÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ion about placing Standard Pear-trees, as I was about diÅ¿poÅ¿ing of the Dwarf Pear-trees: for they do not all accommodate little Gardens, as theÅ¿e latter do; the Shade of great Trees being deÅ¿tructive to every thing elÅ¿e we might plant there. Add to that, that all the World are particularly deÅ¿irous to have air round about their HouÅ¿es, and none care to Å¿uffer any thing near them that may hinder its free acceÅ¿Å¿ion; and that's one of the principal ReaÅ¿ons which makes every one deÅ¿ire at leaÅ¿t little Gardens, when they cannot have great ones.

We will therefore plant no Standard Trees any where but in great Gardens, and there too we will plant but a Å¿mall number, which ordinarily amounts not to above one Tree for every Square in a Kitching Garden. I have uÅ¿ed my Å¿elf to two Å¿everal Methods in this Matter, which Å¿ucceed not amiÅ¿s, one is to plant them all along the Å¿ides of thoÅ¿e great Alleys or Walks that croÅ¿s the Garden, and always at a good diÅ¿tance from any Walls, excepting thoÅ¿e of the North; and the other is, to place them in the midÅ¿t of the Squares, that is to Å¿ay, one in every Square.

In the firÅ¿t manner particularly, becauÅ¿e the greateÅ¿t part of their Å¿hadow falls commonly into the Walks, none of the Trees can do any harm to the little Plants growing underneath them, nor to the good Wall Trees which are far enough off of them: And in the Å¿econd manner, there is nothing to intercept or cloud the Å¿ight, becauÅ¿e the Squares extending ordinarily at leaÅ¿t ThreeÅ¿core, or ThreeÅ¿core and twelve Foot every way, and being Å¿eparated from one another by Å¿ome Alleys or Walks, the Standard Trees in them will be at a very conÅ¿iderable diÅ¿tance one from another, and the number of thoÅ¿e Squares being not very great, the number of the Standard Trees in them can be but moderate neither, there being very few Kitchen-Gardens Å¿o proportioned, and Å¿o deÅ¿igned out, as we have expreÅ¿Å¿ed, that can have above Thirty Å¿uch Trees.

Now for this purpoÅ¿e, I either chuÅ¿e Trees of thoÅ¿e Å¿orts of Fruits which are not very big, and yet are of great increaÅ¿e, and are good when they fall, that is to Å¿ay, of Å¿ome Summer Fruits, becauÅ¿e their Å¿mallneÅ¿s preÅ¿erves them from bruiÅ¿ing, and their ripeneÅ¿s which looÅ¿ens them from the Tree, makes them fit to be eaten preÅ¿ently with pleaÅ¿ure, when any of them happen to be battered in falling.

Or elÅ¿e I chuÅ¿e thoÅ¿e kinds which hold faÅ¿t by their Stalks, and Å¿uch whoÅ¿e Fruits are very hard in themÅ¿elves, as are the Å¿mall Winter Fruits and Baking-pears; Å¿o that they are not eaÅ¿ily Å¿haken down by Winds, nor when they fall Å¿o apt to be much endamaged thereby.

Among the Summer-Fruits proper to be planted in the form of Standard-trees, I do not comprehend the little MuÅ¿cat-pear, though for its bigneÅ¿s and Å¿eaÅ¿on it might Å¿eem fitter than any other; no, the Canker which is apt to Seize on its Wood, and quite Å¿poil it, hinders me to my great regret from planting any Trees of it in this faÅ¿hion; But that which I moÅ¿t willingly plant in this manner, is firÅ¿t, of Summer-Fruits (mark here the order of my choice) The RuÅ¿Å¿elet, the CuiÅ¿Å¿e-Madam, or Lady-Thigh, the Great Blanquet, What Summer-Pear Standards are fit to be Planted. or White-pear, the Musked-Blanquet, the Musked-Summer-Boncretien, the Bourdon, or Humble-Bee pear, the Musked-Robert, the Pendar, or Hanging-pear, the Melting-pear of BreÅ¿t, and in a very large Plantation, I would add too, Å¿ome Summer-Boncretiens, Å¿ome Admiral Pears, &c. For the Fruits of Autumn, thoÅ¿e which I chooÅ¿e, are the LanÅ¿acs, Vine-pears, RuÅ¿Å¿elins, What Autumnal ones, and what Winter ones. &c. And for Winter-Fruits, the Dry Martin, the Ambret, the Winter-RuÅ¿Å¿elet, the Ronville, and perhaps, Å¿ome BeÅ¿i de CaiÅ¿Å¿oy-trees, and in fine, for Fruits to Bake, PreÅ¿erve, &c. I will chooÅ¿e the little Certeau, the Frank-Royal, the Angober, the Donville.

There we have about twenty four Å¿orts of Standard Pear-trees to plant proÅ¿perouÅ¿ly enough in our Gardens; But becauÅ¿e in Important places, as for example, in fine Kitching-Gardens, Baking and PreÅ¿erving Fruits are not conÅ¿iderable enough to be allowed any Bakeing and PreÅ¿erving Pears, with Cherries, &c. and Apples, &c. beÅ¿t Planted apart in Å¿eparate Orchards. room, and becauÅ¿e (as it is expedient for all them that conveniently can) we may have Å¿ome of them in the Å¿eparate Orchards, deÅ¿igned only for Fruit, together with all Å¿orts of Cherry-trees, Agriots, Bigarros, Guignes, with all Å¿orts of good Apples, Pippins, Calvils, Apis, Fenouillets, or Fennel-Apple, Courpendus, or Short Hung, or Short Stalked Apples, &c. with Å¿ome good Å¿orts of Plums, that is to Å¿ay, of Damask Plums of all Å¿orts, of Mirabelles, St. Catherines, Diapred Damasks, &c. and laÅ¿tly with Mulberry-trees, Almond-trees, Azerol, or Garden Haw-trees, &c. Therefore I Å¿ay, Å¿ince for theÅ¿e ReaÅ¿ons, Fruits for Baking, &c. may without any diÅ¿honour to them, be planted elÅ¿ewhere, far off from our Kitching-Gardens, we Å¿hould in their Å¿tead, particularly Multiply Å¿ome Trees of the principal Å¿orts of our Summer-Fruits. I know the voice of all the World, as well as mine own will preÅ¿ently give the firÅ¿t choice to the RuÅ¿Å¿elet-pears; Å¿o that we Å¿hall not think much to have at leaÅ¿t four great Trees of them to one of each of the other Å¿orts: The RuÅ¿Å¿elin, the LanÅ¿ac, the Ambret, and the Dry Martin, are likewiÅ¿e Trees that require each of them to be doubled before we double the other Kinds. A Summer Pear-tree that has been planted ten or twelve Years, is capable of yielding Å¿o great a quantity of Fruit of its kind, that 'twill be all we can do to Å¿pend them before the RottenneÅ¿s that follows cloÅ¿e after their RipeneÅ¿s, makes them good for nothing: And therefore, when we are contriving Plantations of Fruit-trees, we Å¿hould Å¿till remember when we intermix in them any Standard-trees, that we muÅ¿t proportionably diminiÅ¿h the number of Dwarf-trees, which we Å¿hould otherwiÅ¿e be obliged to have of thoÅ¿e Å¿ame kinds.

Methinks 'tis not amiÅ¿s to add here this Caution, that in reÅ¿pect of theÅ¿e Standard-trees, Standards to be much leÅ¿s Trimmed in their Heads than Dwarfs, to make them bear Å¿o much the Å¿ooner. it is good in planting them, to leave them Å¿ome of the branches of their tops which they had when in the NurÅ¿ery Garden, becauÅ¿e they will bear Fruit Å¿o much the Å¿ooner, and becauÅ¿e the heighth of their Trunks is not Å¿o exactly regulated as that of the Dwarf-trees, whether that heighth begin a foot higher or lower, their Å¿hape will be never the leÅ¿s comly for that, and it is always a conÅ¿iderable advantage, this Å¿ort of Trees may be made to afford us of advancing their FruitfulneÅ¿s, which we can hardly ever draw from the Dwarf-trees.

I have hitherto examined only the Conduct we are to obÅ¿erve in diÅ¿poÅ¿ing the good Pear-trees, to have as many of them in our Gardens, as 'tis poÅ¿Å¿ible, as well in the form of Dwarf, as Standard-trees: But I have not yet Å¿poken of thoÅ¿e great Boncretien Pear-trees they have in the Courts of Å¿ome HouÅ¿es in many Provinces in the hotter Climates, nor of Å¿ome other more common Pear-trees which they have in other parts, in other Courts.

Nor have I yet Å¿poken any thing of the great Pear plantations, planted for the making of Perry in thoÅ¿e places where Vines cannot proÅ¿per. As to the two firÅ¿t points, becauÅ¿e I have nothing to Å¿ay to them, as being of no manner of conÅ¿equence, but only barely for the pleaÅ¿ure of Å¿ome particular PerÅ¿ons, I leave it wholly to each perÅ¿on to do in them what he Å¿hall find beÅ¿t for his own Å¿atisfaction; for the Å¿ucceÅ¿s he Å¿hall meet with may Å¿erve him for a Rule.

However, 'tis convenient to advertiÅ¿e you, that in places, which we Å¿ay, are much expoÅ¿ed to the That is, places near High-ways, where many People paÅ¿s. Secular Arm, we ought to have this fore-caÅ¿t, not to plant any Fruit there that is eatable whilÅ¿t on the Tree, otherwiÅ¿e 'tis certain, all the Fruit that will come to the Owner from thence will be only a great deal of Vexation, and little elÅ¿e.

As for what concerns the plantations of Pear-trees or Apple-trees deÅ¿igned for the making of Cyder or Perry; I Å¿hall content my Å¿elf with only telling you, that in them, the Trees are planted at threeÅ¿core, or threeÅ¿core and twelve foot, one from another, becauÅ¿e that proportion obÅ¿erved, hinders not the Grounds in which they grow, at leaÅ¿t for Å¿everal Years together, from being Å¿own Yearly with good Corn, the Plowing up, and other Culture uÅ¿ed for the latter, extreamly contributing to the well cultivating of the other: I leave what is more to be Å¿aid to this Article, to the DiÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ion of thoÅ¿e to whom thoÅ¿e Liquors are neceÅ¿Å¿ary, or at leaÅ¿t very convenient, or which as paÅ¿Å¿ionately love them as I do good Fruits which are the chief delights of the Nobility and Gentry.

It is now time to examine what Å¿orts of Pear-trees we Å¿hall plant againÅ¿t Walls, I know very well there is not any Å¿ort of them which that Situation would not very well accommodate by contributing much to the largeneÅ¿s of their Fruit, and the certainty of their bearing and bringing their productions to perfection, when the Å¿piteful Tyger-Babbs will give them leave to do it; But I likewiÅ¿e no leÅ¿s certainly know, that that there are Å¿ome of To what Pear-Trees the Wall is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary. them which Å¿tand Å¿o much in need of the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Wall, that they cannot live and thrive without it. And we have hinted in Å¿everal places in the foregoing part of this TreatiÅ¿e, that the Bergamots particularly lay under this neceÅ¿Å¿ity, and the little MuÅ¿cat-pears Å¿till more than they: The Wall is further indiÅ¿penÅ¿ably requiÅ¿ite for the raiÅ¿ing of well Coloured Boncretiens. But becauÅ¿e if we have never Å¿o few Walls expoÅ¿ed to a kindly Sun, we ought to have Å¿o much regard to them as to employ them as uÅ¿efully as they deÅ¿erve, and according to the importance of the Fruits that challange place there, I think I ought to treat of the Pears that may be planted in that Scituation, before I come to treat particularly of the order which is to be obÅ¿erved for the filling up every Wall with all Å¿orts of good Fruits, as well as 'tis poÅ¿Å¿ible to fill them; and that is the order I propoÅ¿ed to my Å¿elf at the very beginning of this TreatiÅ¿e: After I have drawn therefore a particular LiÅ¿t of the firÅ¿t Five Hundred Dwarf-pear-trees which I have placed here a little above, and after I have told you in particular, which, in my opinion, are the Good-pears, which the Indifferent ones, and laÅ¿tly which are they that are Å¿o bad, that I would adviÅ¿e no body to plant them at all, I will conclude this Chapter, with informing you what other Fruits, beÅ¿ides Pears, proÅ¿per well upon Dwarf-trees, and then proceed to Å¿peak of all Å¿orts of Wall-Fruits, and of the method of diÅ¿poÅ¿ing them, in a Å¿eparate DiÅ¿courÅ¿e.

argument.p: Treating of Apples.

div.p: SInce Apples make a part of our Kernel-Fruits, and a very conÅ¿iderable part too, as well in reÅ¿pect of their GoodneÅ¿s, and LaÅ¿ting Quality, as of the Convenience they afford us, of having them either growing upon little Dwarf Trees, grafted upon ParadiÅ¿e-Apple-Stocks, or upon larger Dwarf-Trees and Standards grafted upon Wild or Crab-Å¿tocks, I will take the opportunity in this place to Å¿et down what I would CounÅ¿el Gentlemen to plant of them, before I proceed to Å¿peak of Wall Trees, among which, I Å¿eldom or never admit them Entrance.

Among the Apples that are good to Eat Raw, or Baked, or otherwiÅ¿e prepared, (for Seven principal Å¿orts of Fating and PreÅ¿erving Apples. I meddle not here with Cyder-Apples,) I count Seven principal Å¿orts, that is to Å¿ay, the Gray-Pippin, the White, or Frank-Pippin, the Autumn Calvill, the Fennellet, or Fennell-Apple, the Cour-pendu, or Å¿hort-hung, or Å¿hort-Å¿talk'd-Apple, the Api, and the Violet-Apple. There are Å¿ome others which I prize not Å¿o much, tho' they are no bad Fruit, as the Rambour, Other Å¿orts leÅ¿s valuable, but yet good. the Summer-Calvill, the CouÅ¿inotte, the Orgeran, the JeruÅ¿alem, the Thick Pairmain, the Ice-Apple, the Francatu, the Hiute-BontÃ©e, or High-goodneÅ¿s, the Royalty, the Rouvezeau, the CheÅ¿nut-Apple, the Pigconnet, or Pigcon-Apple, the PaÅ¿s-pomme, or PaÅ¿Å¿ing-Apple, the Petit-bon, or Small-good, the Fig-Apple, &c.

All Apples pretty near reÅ¿emble one another in their flat figure, and Å¿hort Å¿talk, and Apples deÅ¿cribed in general. the moÅ¿t part of them in bigneÅ¿s too, and in their Å¿hort Eating Pulp, but they are very different in Colour.

I know not above two or three Å¿orts that are bigger than the others, namely, the Rambours, the Calvills, and the Ice-Applos, and but three or four that are more long
than flat, namely, the Calvills, the Violets, the JeruÅ¿alems, and the Ice-Apples, and they are thicker towards the Å¿talk than towards the head, Å¿o that we muÅ¿t conceive the moÅ¿t part of them flat, without any further DeÅ¿cription.

The Two Å¿orts of Pippins are diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed by the Two Names of Gray and White The Two Å¿orts of Pippins, Gray and VVhite. which they bear, being in other reÅ¿pects of an equal goodneÅ¿s; good CompÃ´tes, or Wet Sweet-Meats may be made of them at all times, and they begin to be eaten Raw towards the Month of January; before that time, they have a little point of Å¿harpneÅ¿s Their SeaÅ¿on and Character. which pleaÅ¿es not Å¿ome people, but unhappily aÅ¿Å¿oon as ever they begin to be entirely free of that, they contract a Å¿mell that is much more diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ing, and which is rendred Å¿till more diÅ¿agreeable, when the Å¿mell of the Straw upon which they are laid to Mellow, intermixes therewith. In Å¿ine, it may be Å¿aid, to the advantage of theÅ¿e Pippins, that they are very profitably made uÅ¿e of almoÅ¿t all the Year long; and to their diÅ¿advantage, it may be no leÅ¿s truly affirmed, that their Neighbourhood is infinitely diÅ¿agreeable and incommodious.

The Summer and Autumnal-Calvills reÅ¿emble one another pretty near in their longiÅ¿h Å¿hape, and in their Colour, which is of a Blood-Red, but yet the Summer-Calvill is The Summer and Autumn-Calvills. deÅ¿cribed. a little flatter, being likewiÅ¿e leÅ¿s Coloured without, and not at all within, whereas thoÅ¿e of Autumn are very Red both without and within, and eÅ¿pecially the beÅ¿t of them; that is to Å¿ay, thoÅ¿e that thave the moÅ¿t agreeable Violet-Å¿mell that renders them Å¿o conÅ¿iderable: I Å¿ay, theÅ¿e moÅ¿t excellent ones have always their pulp deeplier tinged with Red, and are alÅ¿o more beautiful to look upon than the others. They keep Their SeaÅ¿on and Character. moÅ¿t commonly from October, when they begin to come in, till January and February. It is a moÅ¿t excellent Fruit to Eat Raw, and no leÅ¿s excellent to uÅ¿e in CompÃ´tes, and Wet Sweet-Meats. It Å¿ometimes grows dry and mealy, but that is not till 'tis very old. The Summer-Calvills, both the White and the other, are gone as Å¿oon as September is paÅ¿t; they may at leaÅ¿t be Å¿aid not to be diÅ¿agreeable, and eÅ¿pecially in the Pyramids of their SeaÅ¿on.

The Fennellet, or Fennell-Apple, or Anis-Apple, is of a Colour not well to be expreÅ¿s'd: The Fennellet, Fennell-Apple, deÅ¿cribed. It is Grey, overcaÅ¿t all over with Å¿omething of a RuÅ¿Å¿et, coming near the Colour of the Belly of a Doc, never taking any Lively Colour. This Apple begins to be good from the beginning of December, when we have the pleaÅ¿ure to Its SeaÅ¿on and Character. Eat it with the Pears of the SeaÅ¿on, and keeps till February and March. The Cour-pendu, or Å¿hort-hung, or Å¿hort-Å¿talk'd, Apple, whoÅ¿e Ancient Name Å¿ome The Cour-pendu, or Å¿hort-Å¿talk'd Apple, deÅ¿cribed. would have changed, to give it that of Bardin, is perfectly of the regular figure of an Apple, and is of a reaÅ¿onable bigneÅ¿s; it is of a Grey-RuÅ¿Å¿et Colour on one Å¿ide, and Dyed with Vermillion on the other. March: We muÅ¿t not give it time to grow wrinkled, becauÅ¿e then it is inÅ¿ipid, and loÅ¿es its taÅ¿t. It is likewiÅ¿e a very pretty Apple.

The Rambour, as I have already Å¿aid, is a fair large Apple, Green on one Å¿ide, and whipt with Red on the other; it is Eatable as Å¿oon as AuguÅ¿t comes in, but laÅ¿ts but a The Rambour deÅ¿cribed. little while: It is very good Baked, or otherwiÅ¿e prepared, and requires particularly to grow on Standard Trees, the little ParadiÅ¿e-Apple Stocks being too weak to Å¿upport the weight of it.

The JeruÅ¿alem-Apples are almoÅ¿t Red all over, have a firm pulp, but of little taÅ¿t, though it be a little Å¿ugred, and have nothing of that ill Å¿mell that accompanies moÅ¿t JeruÅ¿alem-Apples deÅ¿cribed. Apples.

And theÅ¿e are all the Apples as near as I can reckon, that I know, after a very exact Scrutiny, and becauÅ¿e there is no great difference among them in goodneÅ¿s, I willingly content my Å¿elf with the Å¿even firÅ¿t Å¿orts, for which I have expreÅ¿t Å¿ome eÅ¿teem, and Å¿hall make no Å¿cruple to plant a conÅ¿iderable quantity of them, provided they be grafted upon ParadiÅ¿e Apple-Å¿tocks, that being a Tree that Å¿hoots forth little Wood, and conÅ¿equently ParadiÅ¿e-Apple-Å¿tocks, how commodious to graft the beÅ¿t Apple-Trees upon. produces but Å¿mall Dwarf-Trees, that give very little incumbrance, and that beÅ¿ides, is bleÅ¿t with the advantage of producing great increaÅ¿e, which makes it very conÅ¿iderable to our curious Gentlemen; to which may be added, That it equally agrees with all Å¿orts of Soils, both hot and cold, dry and moiÅ¿t.

I uÅ¿e often to place Å¿ome of them between all the Dwarf-Pear-trees I plant about every Square of our Kitchin-Gardens, and for that purpoÅ¿e, I Å¿et the Pear-trees at a pretty They may be fitly placed between the Dwarf-pear-trees planted about ãâã Squares in Kitchin-gardens. good diÅ¿tance one from another, without being at all afraid my Apple-trees Å¿hould defraud the Pear-trees of their nouriÅ¿hment, becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e latter draw theirs a good depth our of the Ground; whereas thoÅ¿e little Apple-trees which need but little, content themÅ¿elves with licking up thoÅ¿e Superfluities of it only, which were Å¿pending themÅ¿elves towards

argument.p: How to prepare a Tree for Planting.

div.p: THis preparation is of Å¿o great a conÅ¿equence for the making of Trees take new footing, and grow again, that very often they take, and produce a good effect only becauÅ¿e they were well prepared before they were replanted, and no leÅ¿s often fail taking, or producing a good head or top, becauÅ¿e they were ill prepared.

As to the head, there is but little myÅ¿tery in ordering that, either in Standard or Dwarf-Trees, it being needful only for that effect, to remember theÅ¿e two points.

Å¿hew.)

And theÅ¿e young ones are to be kept Å¿hort proportionably to their length, the longeÅ¿t Of what length the good Roots are to be left in Dwarfs, Standards, &c. in Dwarf-Trees, of what bigneÅ¿s Å¿oever it be, which is commonly not very great, never being to exceed eight or nine Inches, nor much above a foot in Standards: We may leave a greater length the roots of Mulberry and Almond-Trees, becauÅ¿e thoÅ¿e of the firÅ¿t are very Å¿oft, and thoÅ¿e of the Å¿econd, very dry and hard, and therefore will be in danger of periÅ¿hing, if they be cut too Å¿hort.

Trees, I made coice of fifteen Trees, among the great number that I have taken up and replanted theÅ¿e five and twenty or 30 years, which were Å¿uch in which I obÅ¿erved any remarkable difference in the Å¿ituation of their roots, by which I found, that generally all Trees in the Å¿preading of their roots imitated Å¿ome one of thoÅ¿e fifteen, Å¿o that having firÅ¿t cauÅ¿ed them to be drawn out in figures, exactly as they were when newly pulled up, and afterwards when they were cut and trimmed, ordering them to be drawn over again in other plates, in the condition they were in then, to Å¿how how they muÅ¿t be order'd before they be planted, any Gentleman may after that model, regulate the operations that are to be made upon the roots of all Å¿orts of Trees whatÅ¿oever.

argument.p: When and how to plant Trees when ready fitted and prepared for it.

div.p: THE firÅ¿t thing to be obÅ¿erved here, is, that in the Å¿eaÅ¿on of planting, which as all the world knows, laÅ¿ts from the end of October, to the middle of March, that is, from the time that the Trees quit their Leaves, till they are almoÅ¿t ready to begin to put forth new ones, we muÅ¿t chooÅ¿e dry, and mild weather, without troubling our heads to take any notice of the Age of the Moon, as formerly was practiÅ¿ed, rainy weather is not only incommodious to the Gard'ner in his Work, but alÅ¿o hurtful to the Trees that are then planted, becauÅ¿e the mold is then too apt to be reduced to a mortar-like conÅ¿iÅ¿tance, which makes it not Å¿o proper to Å¿ettle all cleverly down round about, and cloÅ¿e to the roots without leaving Å¿ome hollow between, which it is very expedient to prevent. Now, though all thoÅ¿e months be equally fit to plant in, Å¿o that it may Å¿eem, the Å¿ooner it be done, the better, yet as I willingly affect to plant preÅ¿ently after Martlemas, in dry and light Grounds, Å¿o I care not to plant neither till the end of February, in cold and moiÅ¿t ones; becauÅ¿e the Trees in theÅ¿e laÅ¿t can do nothing all Winter, and may more likely be Å¿poiled there, than be able to preÅ¿erve themÅ¿elves, whereas in lighter Grounds, they may begin even that very Å¿ame Autumn, to Å¿hoot out Å¿ome Å¿mall roots, which is a great advance to them to put them in the way of doing wonders in the following Spring.

Yet though I here make choice of the faireÅ¿t, it do's not follow that we are never to plant any but Å¿uch as are fair, and accompanied with all the hopeful appearances of thriving; Though it be true enough that after we have taken all the care we can to chooÅ¿e none but Å¿ine ones, yet Å¿ome of them will be always Å¿iner than the others.

The Trees then being all carried and laid every one near its aÅ¿Å¿igned place, if we be to plant Dwarfs, I begin with the corners of each Square, that they may Å¿erve to The Author's Method of Dwarf-Trees, &c. guide us to place the others direct in the Å¿ame Lines; and if the Soil has been newly dug up and moved, and mixed with a good quantity of long dung, Å¿o that it Å¿eems not to be Å¿o firm and cloÅ¿e as it Å¿hould be, I take care to Å¿ink my Trees but about half Of What Depth Trees are to be planted. a foot, meaning that the extreamity of the loweÅ¿t root of the Tree is but half a foot deep in the Earth, becauÅ¿e as I reckon, the Ground will Å¿ink at leaÅ¿t half a foot; and becauÅ¿e it is better to plant too high, than two low, at the end of Å¿ome months, my Trees will be found Å¿unk about a foot into the Earth, which is the juÅ¿teÅ¿t meaÅ¿ure we can aÅ¿Å¿ign them in that reÅ¿pect, Trees planted deeper, almoÅ¿t always dying in a few years.

When I have planted the corner Trees, then I place a man at that rank I have a mind to plant, to adjuÅ¿t the Trees with a line, that they may be Å¿ure to be planted in a right line, and I take another man with a Å¿pade to cover up the roots of the Trees as faÅ¿t as I preÅ¿ent them in their places, and be informed by my line manager that they are right in the line, and Å¿o in one morning I will plant four or five hundred Dwarf-Trees with eaÅ¿e.

It is yet more eaÅ¿ie to plant in a little time a great many Wall-Trees, becauÅ¿e there is no need of uÅ¿ing a line; but in forming a Quincunce, we cannot go Å¿o faÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e that, as every Tree muÅ¿t anÅ¿wer exactly to two ranks, there muÅ¿t be two Aliners, viz. one for each rank, and there is always Å¿ome time loÅ¿t before the Tree can be placed Å¿o exactly as equally to anÅ¿wer two Å¿everal ranks.

And we muÅ¿t not only be careful to plant our Trees a little high, and very Å¿traight, but we muÅ¿t be particularly mindful to turn their principal roots towards the good Soil; this being the moÅ¿t important point of all; Å¿o that though it be much to be deÅ¿ired, that all Trees deÅ¿igned for Dwarfs, Å¿hould appear Å¿traight upright upon their feet, after they are planted; yet if the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of their Roots which perhaps naturally incline to Pirot, or Å¿pread round, require that the Tree Å¿hould be a little Å¿tooped, to give that good Å¿ituation to its Roots which I deÅ¿ire they Å¿hould have, that is, to give them Å¿cope to Å¿pread rather between two Earths, than to Å¿hoot right downward, I not only make no difficulty to hold the head or the top of the Tree a little Å¿tooped, and that always over the line that is Å¿tretched out by it, but I counÅ¿el it as a thing neceÅ¿Å¿ary; otherwiÅ¿e, the roots that Å¿hoot from Å¿uch a Tree, being naturally inclined to follow the bent of thoÅ¿e out of which they Å¿prout, it will happen, that thoÅ¿e roots being forced to Å¿hoot downwards as low as the bad mold towards the bottom, or beyond the reach of the rain water, the Tree will thereupon grow Å¿ick, and languiÅ¿h, and will make an ill-favoured figure, and bring but Å¿curvy Fruit, and will at laÅ¿t die.

From what I have Å¿aid of the good Å¿ituation of the roots, it follows that if we be to plant any Trees along by the Å¿ides of any Walk or Alley, we muÅ¿t take care to avoid turning the principal roots towards the Alley Å¿ide, and with much greater reaÅ¿on, ought we to do the Å¿ame when we are planting Wall-Trees, and to take Å¿pecial care we leave not any good root of them, in vain to Å¿pend its force and vigour againÅ¿t the Walls.

This Å¿tooping of the head in low Trees, need not raiÅ¿e in us any Å¿curple, or put us in any apprehenÅ¿ion of Å¿poiling the beauty either of their figure in particular, or of that of the whole plantation in general, becauÅ¿e it is not the Å¿ame caÅ¿e with Branches that are to Å¿pring forth, as 'tis with roots; for the Branches do not at all follow the DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the Å¿tooping head; on the contrary, they grow regularly upright round about their trunk, and Å¿o becauÅ¿e their riÅ¿e is very near the Ground, their Trees make as a well Å¿haped figure, as if they had been planted upright upon their center.

It is the Å¿tandard Trees that are to grow in the full air, that we are neceÅ¿Å¿arily obliged to plant as upright upon their center as 'tis poÅ¿Å¿ible; for otherwiÅ¿e their Trunks would always remain Å¿tanding awry, and conÅ¿equently would make an unÅ¿eemly figure, and beÅ¿ides would be more Å¿ubject to the inÅ¿ults of violent winds, and be apt to be overturned by them; and therefore for that Å¿ame conÅ¿ideration, they muÅ¿t be planted a little deeper than other Trees, that is, they muÅ¿t be placed a full foot deep in the Ground, and though I caution people not to trample over the Ground where our Å¿mall Trees are planted, for fear of making them Å¿ink too deep, and becauÅ¿e they are in no danger of the Winds, on the contrary, I adviÅ¿e them to preÅ¿s the Ground as hard and cloÅ¿e as as they can, againÅ¿t the feet of theÅ¿e Standards, to faÅ¿ten them, and make them the firmer to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the violence of the winds.

After the planting of every Tree, if I have the convenience of any dung-hills, I put a bed of two or three Inches thick of dung over every Tree foot, and cover it over at The uÅ¿e of Dung about Trees. the Å¿ame time with a little Mold, to hide it from being Å¿een, as being no handÅ¿ome Å¿ight.

This bed of dung is not Å¿o much to improve the Ground, which I Å¿uppoÅ¿e already to be good, and well prepared, as particularly to hinder the burning heat of the Months of April, May, and June, from penetrating to their roots, and by conÅ¿equence from putting them out of due temper, and hindering them from performing their function, which would cauÅ¿e no leÅ¿s than the death of the Trees.

If I want dung, I content my Å¿elf during thoÅ¿e firÅ¿t dangerous Months, to cover the feet of my Trees with a bed of Weeds, or Fern; I hinder any thing from growing there A bed of Weeds or fern may Å¿erve in want of Dung. In very dry weather, to be watered every 15 days in the hot months. that may Å¿hade or cloud the young Å¿hoots, and if there be a great drought, as it often happens, I order a pitcher of water to be poured upon each Tree foot, every fifteen days during the three or four hot Months, making firÅ¿t a kind of circular trench round the Tree that the water may pierce quite down to it, and when the water is all imbibed, I fill and make up this circle again, even with the reÅ¿t of the Ground, Å¿o that 'tis not diÅ¿cerned.

But if the Å¿eaÅ¿on prove rainy, thoÅ¿e waterings will not be neceÅ¿Å¿ary. And after all theÅ¿e preparations, and precautions, yet we commonly think our Å¿elves happy enough if we can Stock our plantations Å¿o well, as to have but few Trees miÅ¿carry under our conduct.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.

argument.p: How to order Trees planted for ReÅ¿erves in OÅ¿ier CaÅ¿es, or Baskets.

div.p: BUT notwithÅ¿tanding all this, becauÅ¿e Å¿ome Trees may happen to die, and yet as far as 'tis poÅ¿Å¿ible, it is to be deÅ¿ired, our plantation Å¿hould be compleated the very firÅ¿t year, I uÅ¿e to prepare a greater number of Trees than I have actually need of to fill up my plantation, that I may always have Å¿ome as 'twere in a Body of ReÅ¿erve, and for that purpoÅ¿e, it is my practiÅ¿e at the Å¿ame time I am filling up my plantations, to plant Å¿ome Supernumenary Trees of every kind in OÅ¿ier CaÅ¿es, or Baskets, but more of Stone, than of Kernel Fruits, becauÅ¿e thoÅ¿e former moÅ¿t commonly are in greater hazard of dying than the others.

Accordingly I chuÅ¿e out Å¿ome good place in the Garden, (the moÅ¿t Å¿hady parts of it being the moÅ¿t proper for this effect) and there I plant Å¿ome Trees in OÅ¿ier Baskets, well ticketed, or at leaÅ¿t carefully Å¿et down in my Book according to the order both of their Ranks, and of the reÅ¿pective places allotted to them in thoÅ¿e Ranks, that I may have recourÅ¿e to them, when any Tree Å¿hall happen to die or languiÅ¿h in its place; Being deÅ¿irous, if it be poÅ¿Å¿ible, that my plantation Å¿hould continue finiÅ¿hed and compleat as well in its figure, as in the kinds of Trees, according to my firÅ¿t modelling of it.

In order to which, I keep in a leaning poÅ¿ture in the ReÅ¿ervatory Baskets thoÅ¿e Trees How to be pla
â¢â¢ d. that are deÅ¿igned for the Wall, and in a Å¿traight and upright poÅ¿ture in the middle of the Å¿aid Baskets, thoÅ¿e that are intended for Dwarfs, that when I have occaÅ¿ion for either of them, I may the more commodiouÅ¿ly remove and place them with Basket and all, Å¿o as the Tree may be every whit as well Å¿ituated, as if it had been firÅ¿t planted there, which it would not be, if the Tree deÅ¿igned for a Wall-Tree, were placed bolt upright in the middle of the Basket, becauÅ¿e we could not Å¿o eaÅ¿ily bend the Tree towards the Wall; the Å¿ame inconvenience almoÅ¿t happens if we be to plant for a Dwarf, a Tree that we find in a leaning poÅ¿ture in a ReÅ¿ervatory Basket, though of the two, that be eaÅ¿ier to place well than the Tree deÅ¿igned for a Wall-Tree.

This operation of the TranÅ¿porting of ReÅ¿erve Trees, may be done till Mid-Å¿ummer; and when we have a mind to go about it, we muÅ¿t firÅ¿t by way of preparation, water thoÅ¿e ReÅ¿erve Trees well that we deÅ¿ign to remove, (which probably will be the faireÅ¿t we have) and then move the Earth away neatly round about the Baskets, for fear of breaking the roots of the plants in caÅ¿e they have Å¿hot any beyond the compaÅ¿s of their Baskets; and we muÅ¿t ch ãâ¦ã rainy weather to do it in, or at leaÅ¿t weather that is mild and temperate, and a time when the Sun is low, or a little after he is Å¿et, or a little before he riÅ¿es; and he muÅ¿t be extreamly carefull not to Å¿hake or looÅ¿en the Tree in the leaÅ¿t manner in the World, neither when we are taking it up, nor when we are carrying it off, nor when we are replacing it in its deÅ¿igned Å¿tation, the Å¿haking and looÅ¿ening of it being in this caÅ¿e, very pernicious and often Mortal.

Now when in removing theÅ¿e ReÅ¿erve Trees, we perceive any roots of them to have begun to Å¿hoot out of the Basket, we muÅ¿t firÅ¿t in placing it, be very careful to preÅ¿erve the points of thoÅ¿e new Roots, place them well, and Å¿upport them with good mold, cover them immediately, and ramm the Earth cloÅ¿e againÅ¿t the Basket, and then water the Ground pretty plentifully round about the Basket, to make the Earth next to it, cleave the cloÅ¿er about it, Å¿o as there may remain no hollow, which may be known by the waters not Å¿inking Å¿o haÅ¿tily when you pour it on the place as before; And this watering is indiÅ¿penÅ¿ably neceÅ¿Å¿ary in what manner Å¿oever we remove our ReÅ¿erve Trees: And laÅ¿tly, on thoÅ¿e days when the Sun Å¿hines hot, we muÅ¿t cover the head of the Tree with Å¿traw Screens, till Å¿uch time as it begins to Å¿prout, and then we may begin to take them off a nights; But this laÅ¿t precaution is not neceÅ¿Å¿ary but when we Å¿ee any new roots Sprout out of the Basket, or when the Tree has been Å¿haken and looÅ¿ened.

The Å¿ame care and caution we uÅ¿e in placing againÅ¿t Walls Trees thus brought up in ReÅ¿erve Baskets: We muÅ¿t practiÅ¿e too in placing the Å¿ame Å¿ort of Trees for Dwarfs or Standards, and above all, we muÅ¿t have a Å¿pecial care to leave thoÅ¿e new roots as little as poÅ¿Å¿ible in the Air; otherwiÅ¿e they will preÅ¿ently grow Black, and conÅ¿equently die.

I have nothing elÅ¿e to add about this head, but only directions how to make theÅ¿e How the Baskets muÅ¿t be made and proportioned. Baskets, which muÅ¿t be made purpoÅ¿ely, and Å¿o looÅ¿e wrought that you may Å¿ee through them, as well becauÅ¿e the roots of the plants may the more eaÅ¿ily grow through them, as that taking up leÅ¿s Å¿tuff, they may coÅ¿t Å¿o much the leÅ¿s, and beÅ¿ides when there is Å¿o much Å¿tuff as to make them too thick and impenetrable, it do's but harm. They muÅ¿t be made of the greeneÅ¿t and freÅ¿heÅ¿t gathered OÅ¿ter that is to be had, that being put quite green into the Earth, they may laÅ¿t the longer without Rotting, that is, at leaÅ¿t a whole Year; for thoÅ¿e that have been made any time, rot Å¿ooner. They muÅ¿t not be very deep, becauÅ¿e then they would be too troubleÅ¿ome to remove, eight or nine Inches depth is enough, that when they are Å¿et into the Ground as deep as till their brims be covered, we may have room enough to put into them firÅ¿t about four or five Inches depth of Mold, and then the Tree, and after that, cover their roots with a little quantity of Earth more; and we may in removing theÅ¿e ReÅ¿erve Trees with their Baskets, take off Å¿ome of the uppermoÅ¿t Mold, if we find them too cumberÅ¿ome to carry; But as I told you before, we muÅ¿t be very careful to ramm down the Earth cloÅ¿e about the Baskets, that there remain no chink or hollow.

As to the bigneÅ¿s of the Baskets, it muÅ¿t be proportionable to the length of the roots of the Trees we deÅ¿ign to plant in them: They muÅ¿t be at leaÅ¿t big enough to afford us room to put in three or four Inches depth of Mold between the ends of the roots, and the Brim of the Basket, Å¿o that for Trees deÅ¿igned for Wall Trees, the Baskets need not be Å¿o large as otherwiÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e thoÅ¿e Trees are planted in them in a leaning poÅ¿ture, and therefore lie Å¿o near one Å¿ide, that all their roots are turned to the other, and Å¿o their new roots may find room enough provided the Basket be wide enough; But for Trees deÅ¿igned for Dwarfs, becauÅ¿e they muÅ¿t be planted in the middle, and therefore Å¿hoot out roots round about them, the Baskets for them muÅ¿t be a little Larger.

The Baskets likewiÅ¿e for Standards, muÅ¿t be proportionably greater than for low Trees. I need not tell you, that the Baskets muÅ¿t be round, becauÅ¿e every Body knows that, though they might be made Oval or Square too, but then they would coÅ¿t more and be never a whit the better.

The Difference therefore of the BigneÅ¿s of Trees obliges us to make Baskets of three different Sizes, viz. Little ones of about a foot Diameter, Midling ones, of about fifteen or Å¿ixteen Inches, and Great ones, of about eighteen or twenty. The principal Quality moÅ¿t to be look'd after in them, is, that their bottom be Å¿trong and Å¿olid enough to bear without burÅ¿ting, the weight of Earth to be charged upon them, and that the Edges both above and below be Å¿o well wrought as not to unravel; There muÅ¿t be alÅ¿o a Welt round about the middle for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on.

And I am not content to make uÅ¿e of this precaution of ReÅ¿erve-Trees at the time of my firÅ¿t planting any great plantations, but I practiÅ¿e it every year, for a certain finall number of Trees, according to the bigneÅ¿s of the plantation I have to cultivate, that when there happens any accident to any of the Trees placed in it, as there may happen many, I may remedy it aÅ¿Å¿oon as I am threat'ned with it, or aÅ¿Å¿oon as ever the accident happens; for in fine we Å¿hould always be in a condition to keep our plantation full and compleat without Å¿uffering any Tree in it that will not comply with our deÅ¿ign.
A little coÅ¿t will put our minds at eaÅ¿e in this reÅ¿pect; and for want of that, we may loÅ¿e much time and pleaÅ¿ure too.
It is now time for us to proceed to the MaÅ¿ter Work of Gard'ners, which is Pruning.
