div.head: OF FRUIT-GARDENS AND Kitchen-Gardens. VOL. II.
PART IV.

argument.p: Of Pruning of Fruit-Trees.

div.head: The INTRODUCTION.
div.p: GEnerally Å¿peaking, Pruning of Trees is Cutting off Å¿ome of their Branches; and Å¿o we commonly Å¿ay, that a Tree is prun'd, when many marks appear of Branches being cut off. We likewiÅ¿e Å¿ay, that a Gard'ner prunes, when he is cutting Å¿ome Branches from his Trees with his Pruning-Knife. This Pruning has been look'd upon in all Times, among the Curious in Fruit-Trees, as the MaÅ¿ter-piece of Gard'ning: And, indeed, the Practice of it began not in our Days, for it was held as a Maxim many Ages Å¿ince, as it appears by the TeÅ¿timony of the Ancients; Å¿o that, to Å¿peak the Truth, we only follow Columella, TheophraÅ¿tus, Xenophon. now, or perhaps improve what was practis'd by our Fore-fathers.

This CuÅ¿tom of Pruning does not commonly extend to all Å¿orts of Fruit-Trees, only to Å¿uch as are known in Gardens by the Names of EÅ¿paliers, or Wall-Fruit-Trees, Counter-EÅ¿paliers or Pole-Hedges and Dwarfs. As for thoÅ¿e that are called Tall-Å¿tandards, they are Å¿eldom prun'd, unleÅ¿s it be once or twice in their firÅ¿t Years, either to give them the firÅ¿t Turn of a Round Figure, and Overture, which is requiÅ¿ite at the time they firÅ¿t begin to form an Head; or to take away Å¿ome irregular Branches, which in proceÅ¿s of Time might intangle or diÅ¿figure that Head; which Pruning is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary. A kind of Pruning is likewiÅ¿e practis'd upon very old Tall-Å¿tandards, by cutting off the dead or languiÅ¿hing Branches, both large and Å¿mall; but that is rather called CleanÅ¿ing, or DiÅ¿-incumbring, than Pruning.

Although the firÅ¿t Idea People have of Pruning, is commonly in relation to the Heads of Trees, that is, their Branches, which frequently want Å¿ome Correction, to be put in a way of doing well, according to the Mind of their MaÅ¿ter; yet notwithÅ¿tanding, there is Å¿till another Trimming which is very material, and that is the Trimming of Roots; which is perform'd upon two OccaÅ¿ions; of which, the one, that is the moÅ¿t common, is generally practis'd upon all Trees, before they are planted; (which I have Å¿ufficiently mention'd in the TreatiÅ¿e of Plantations:) The other, which is extraordinary, is only made uÅ¿e of upon Å¿ome on the Place, according as one deÅ¿igns to make Å¿ome more, and others leÅ¿s vigorous than they are. This I will Å¿peak of at the End of this TreatiÅ¿e.

This Maxim, or NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of Pruning the Heads of all Trees, not being Tall-Å¿tandards, being well eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, tho there are Å¿ome Erroneous Opinions in it, in relation to very vigorous Dwarfs, which I Å¿hall eaÅ¿ily deÅ¿troy. I think my Å¿elf indiÅ¿penÅ¿ibly oblig'd to examine here, as much as in me lies, whatever relates to Å¿o renown'd a Practice in the Management of Fruit-Trees; therefore I proteÅ¿t, at firÅ¿t, that I will make no particular ReÅ¿erve to my Å¿elf; but on the contrary, that I will uÅ¿e my utmoÅ¿t Endeavour, not to omit any thing whatever of what I have been able to apprehend in it hitherto, and of what I have Å¿o long practis'd with SucceÅ¿s.

I am perÅ¿uaded that Pruning is not only a very uÅ¿eful, but alÅ¿o a very curious thing, and capable of affording PleaÅ¿ure to thoÅ¿e that underÅ¿tand it: But at the Å¿ame time it muÅ¿t be acknowledg'd, that it is likewiÅ¿e perpicious, or dangerous, when perform'd by unskilful Hands.

For, to Å¿peak properly, Pruning, in the SenÅ¿e we take it, is not barely Cutting; every Qui cum judicio putat Arborem, efficit, ut quod Arbor Å¿ponte voluit facere, JuÅ¿t â¢ iÃ¢ violentÃ¢ cogatur, ut id agat. CreÅ¿centius. Terrae imperamus, & Å¿oli nequaquam. body cuts, but few prune; nothing is more eaÅ¿ie than to cut: And it may even Å¿ometimes happen by chance, that what has been cut without diÅ¿cretion, may Å¿ucceed well enough, tho for the moÅ¿t part the ConÅ¿equences prove very bad; whereas there being a great deal of Judgment and Rule in Pruning skilfully, the SucceÅ¿s is generally certain, at leaÅ¿t, as to what may depend on the Gard'ner; for all does not depend on him: It is well known that he is neither MaÅ¿ter of Times, or SeaÅ¿ons; which muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity, and chiefly concurr to the perfecting His Work. And therefore, when People have not that Abundance of Fruit they deÅ¿ire, and did hope for, the Fault ought not always to be imputed to the Gard'ner: He is only blameable when his Trees are not-well Å¿hap'd, when they do not bloÅ¿Å¿om abundantly, and when the Fruit is not univerÅ¿ally and equally beautiful, Å¿o as to Å¿ee, upon one and the Å¿ame Tree, Fruit of very different Å¿izes; for he is partly MaÅ¿ter of that.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: Definition of the Pruning of Trees.

div.p: To let you underÅ¿tand what this Pruning is; I Å¿ay, that it is an Operation of Gardning for three Things, which are to be done yearly to Trees, betwixt the beginning of the Month of November, and the End of March:
The FirÅ¿t is, To take away all thoÅ¿e Branches that are naught, or might be prejudicial, either to the Abundance, or GoodneÅ¿s of the Fruit; as alÅ¿o to the Beauty of the Tree.
The Second, To preÅ¿erve all thoÅ¿e that may be of good uÅ¿e to thoÅ¿e Trees:
And the Third, Prudently to clip thoÅ¿e that are found too long, and not to cut any thing off thoÅ¿e that have not too much length.
And all this in order to make a Tree laÅ¿ting, to beautifie it, and at the Å¿ame time diÅ¿poÅ¿e it Å¿oon to bear a great deal of fine and good Fruit.

By Branches that are naught, I mean thoÅ¿e that are of falÅ¿e Wood, thoÅ¿e that are decay'd by having yielded much Fruit, and thoÅ¿e that are too Å¿mall, or have no diÅ¿poÅ¿ition to produce either Wood or Fruit.

By Branches that may be prejudicial, either to the Beauty of the Tree, Abundance, or GoodneÅ¿s of the Fruit, I mean Å¿uch as might cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion, or Å¿hadow the Fruit, as well as thoÅ¿e that take part of the Sap of the Tree, when it is over-charg'd with Wood, compar'd to its Vigour.
By Branches that may be of good UÅ¿e, I mean all thoÅ¿e that are Å¿o well condition'd, as to be fit to contribute to the beautiful Figure of the Tree, and Infallibly to produce Fruit.

By Branches that are too long, I mean Å¿uch as exceed nine or ten Inches in length, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently want to be Å¿horten'd; Å¿uch are all the thick Branches, which we call Branches for Wood; and Å¿ome of the Å¿mall ones, which we call Branches for Fruit.

In fine, By Branches that have not too much length, I mean certain little Branches, which being of a moderate ThickneÅ¿s, have Buds at the Ends of them, or are in a DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of having Å¿ome the following Year, and yet are Å¿trong enough to bear the Fruit they are to produce, without breaking.
This Å¿o material DiÅ¿tinction in point of Branches, Å¿hall be more particularly explain'd in the Chapters that treat of the Manner of Pruning.

I will Å¿ay nothing here of the Original of Pruning, by reaÅ¿on that what has been Å¿aid of it is fabulous, and ridiculous, and conÅ¿equently cannot at preÅ¿ent Å¿erve for InÅ¿truction. For Example, What Å¿ignifies it to know, that Å¿ome pretend to derive the Original of Pruning from that Province of Greece, which was called Nauptia; a Country abounding in Vineyards: An AÅ¿s having brouz'd or nibbl'd Å¿ome Branches of Vines, it was obÅ¿erv'd that the nibbl'd Branches produc'd a great many more Grapes, than thoÅ¿e that were untouch'd; which made them reÅ¿olve thenceforward to Å¿horten, or break, or cut, that is, to prune all the Branches of Vines. It is moreover reported, that Å¿o much SucceÅ¿s attended this Experiment, that to expreÅ¿s their Acknowledgment of Å¿o fine an Invention, they erected in one of the fineÅ¿t Places of that Province, a Marble Statue to that Animal, as to the Author of Pruning of Vines; that is to Å¿ay, to the Author of the Abundance of Wine. And our Books tell us, that this is the true ReaÅ¿on of Bacchus's being drawn mounted upon an AÅ¿s.

The UÅ¿efulneÅ¿s of Pruning Vines being viÅ¿ible; it was judg'd from thence, that it would not be leÅ¿s advantageous to prune Fruit-Trees; and thus, in the Beginnings, they did in this, as has been done in all other Arts and Sciences, they begun to cut groÅ¿ly, that is, to prune Å¿ome of the Branches of Trees, till by degrees they have Å¿tudy'd to refine upon it; and, even in theÅ¿e Days, People Å¿till Å¿tudy, by ReaÅ¿on and ObÅ¿ervation, to improve, and render themÅ¿elves more and more perfect in it. This is the Information we receive from Books, as to the Original of Pruning: It will eaÅ¿ily be granted, that this is not a very material Thing. But, What is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be known,
Are three principal Points; without the underÅ¿tanding of which, it Å¿eems impoÅ¿Å¿ible to me, either to Å¿peak well of this Pruning, or to perform it.

list.item: The FirÅ¿t relates to the ReaÅ¿ons for which it is done.
The Second, To the Time in which it muÅ¿t be done.
And the Third relates to the Manner of doing it with Skill and SucceÅ¿s.

div.p: Let us examine theÅ¿e three Points, one after another.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of the ReaÅ¿ons of Pruning.

div.p: I Will begin with the ReaÅ¿ons for which Pruning is uÅ¿ed, which, in my Opinion, are two. The FirÅ¿t, and chief, is, That which Pruning aims at, The Å¿peedy getting of abundance of fine and good Fruit; without which, no Fruit-Trees would be had, or cultivated.

The Second, which is pretty conÅ¿iderable, informs us, That Pruning Å¿erves to make Trees, in all SeaÅ¿ons, even in thoÅ¿e in which they have neither Fruit nor Leaves, appear more agreeable to Sight, than they would do if they were not prun'd.
Now, the Satisfaction of the Sight in this laÅ¿t Point depends wholly upon the well-underÅ¿tood, and well-proportion'd Figure, a skilful Hand is capable of giving to each Tree.

And, as to what relates to the Abundance of fine and good Fruit, as much as the InduÅ¿try of the Gard'ner can contribute to it, it depends firÅ¿t upon the Knowledge he muÅ¿t have of every Branch in particular, to know thoÅ¿e that are good, from thoÅ¿e that are not: It depends, in the Å¿econd place, upon the judicious DiÅ¿tinction which is to be made among the Branches, wholly to take away thoÅ¿e that are bad, or uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, and carefully to preÅ¿erve all the good ones, be they Branches for Wood, or Branches for Fruit; with this caution, that if among theÅ¿e laÅ¿t, Å¿ome be found not too long, they Å¿hall be left as they are: But as to the main, of the others which are too long, they muÅ¿t be Prun'd more or leÅ¿s, according as ReaÅ¿on may require, either as to the Abundance, or even to the Figure of the Tree. This abundance depends, in the third Place, upon the proper time of Pruning, all times not being fit for it.

In relation to the two firÅ¿t Heads, which relate to the Knowledge and DiÅ¿tinction of Branches in general, I Å¿hall Å¿hew hereafter in what Order, and to what UÅ¿e Nature produces them upon Fruit-Trees; how Å¿ome are uÅ¿eful for one thing, others for another, and
chiefly how Å¿ome have more DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition to Fructify, and others leÅ¿s; and Å¿hall conclude from thence, that it is according to that Order, and that Intention of Nature, and according to that more or leÅ¿s DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition, that thoÅ¿e Branches muÅ¿t be Order'd and Prun'd in a different manner, the one from the other.

But before I enter any farther into that matter, which has a great extent, Å¿ince I muÅ¿t therein explain, eÅ¿pecially the Manner, or Rules that muÅ¿t be practis'd in the Pruning of a great number of Trees, which commonly are very different the one from the other; I think, it will not be improper to Å¿ay firÅ¿t, and as briefly as I can, what I think of the Time of Pruning, Å¿ince that Article is Å¿ooneÅ¿t decided.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the Time of Pruning.

div.p: THere is but little to be Å¿aid upon the Time of Pruning, becauÅ¿e that by a general Approbation, it is commonly fix'd to the End of Winter, or at the Beginning of the Spring; that is, a little before the Trees Å¿prout, and partly about the time that the Buds begin to Å¿well, in order to become BloÅ¿Å¿oms, and the others to Å¿tretch out to become Branches: Which happens infallibly, after the great Colds (which generally attend the Months of November, December, January, and February, are paÅ¿t;) the Spring coming in, and conÅ¿equently the Air beginning to grow hot, and mild, the Plants, that had wholly ceas'd to act during four Months, begin, as it were, to waken, and really to enter into Action: That firÅ¿t Motion is conÅ¿tantly perform'd at the Head, before it begins at the Roots; that is to be underÅ¿tood, when the Cold has been Å¿o great, as to interrupt their Function; for among us, in mild Winters, there is not much more Interruption, than in very hot Countries. We Å¿hall Å¿hew this Order in another place. This External Renewing of Action is a certain Sign that it is time to prune.

People were formerly Å¿o Å¿crupulous as to the preciÅ¿e Time of Pruning, that they durÅ¿t not abÅ¿olutely labour about it, but in the DecreaÅ¿e of the Moons of February and March: It was almoÅ¿t the only Maxim, in that CaÅ¿e, that appear'd well eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, and was in effect inviolably obÅ¿erved. It may be Å¿aid, that it was a kind of Rote, which moÅ¿t Gardners affected with an incredible ObÅ¿tinacy; or rather, that it was a kind of Tyranny, which they exercis'd, when they were employ'd by Gentlemen who were Lovers of their Fruit-Trees. That CuÅ¿tom was grown to that heighth, that both the one and the other would have thought all loÅ¿t, had any thing been prun'd out of thoÅ¿e Declinings: It was an Epidemical DiÅ¿temper; of which, there are Å¿till but too many ill Remains. I grant that in other things that are above my Reach, and in which I have no InÅ¿ight, it may be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to obÅ¿erve the Motions of the Moon; but as to the Pruning of Trees, and whatever has any relation to Gard'ning, I will take upon me to Å¿hew hereafter, in a TreatiÅ¿e of Å¿ome Reflections I have made upon Husbandry, that thoÅ¿e ObÅ¿ervations are not only vain, but even Chimerical. And whereas I was formerly infected with that Opinion my Å¿elf, and am now fully diÅ¿abus'd of it, I do not deÅ¿pair of ridding Gard'ners of that kind of Notion, or Ignorance, and at the Å¿ame time cure the DiÅ¿quiets of Å¿everal ingenious Men upon that Subject.

'Tis true, that it is very good to prune at the End of February, and at the Beginning Omnis Arborum putatio quandocunque fieri poteÅ¿t Ã tempore caÅ¿us foliorum. CreÅ¿centius. of March, which are commonly Times of DecreaÅ¿e; but it is likewiÅ¿e as true, that without minding the Moon, one may begin to prune as Å¿oon as the Leaves of the Trees are faln; that is, at the End of October, or, at leaÅ¿t, about the Middle of November; which may be continu'd afterwards for the whole Winter, until all be done. And, becauÅ¿e that having commonly three Å¿orts of Trees to prune; the one too weak, the other too vigorous, and the others that are in as good a CaÅ¿e as can be deÅ¿ir'd, I am of Opinion that it may be both prudent and uÅ¿eful, not to prune them all at the Å¿ame time; and that it is proper to prune Å¿ome Å¿ooner, and others later. For Example, I am Å¿ufficiently perÅ¿uaded, that the weaker, and more languiÅ¿hing a Tree is, the Å¿ooner it ought to be prun'd, to take from it betimes thoÅ¿e Branches which, as noiÅ¿om and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, muÅ¿t be taken from it at another time; that is, towards the End of the Winter. And this is the ReaÅ¿on why the Pruning in November, December, and January is very good and wholeÅ¿om in relation to theÅ¿e; and even better than that of February and March. And, by the Rule of Contraries, the Å¿tronger and more vigorous a Tree is, the longer the Pruning of it may be deferr'd; I mean, as to Å¿uch an one, that the Pruning of it may not only Å¿afely, but alÅ¿o very uÅ¿efully be deferr'd until the End of April.

I advance in this, two Principles, which appear pretty new: ThoÅ¿e that are deÅ¿irous to Å¿ee the certain Proof of it, may continue to read what follows: As for thoÅ¿e who are willing to rely upon my Word and Experience, and are only deÅ¿irous to Å¿ee the Sequel of my manner of PractiÅ¿ing, they may skip over the Remainder of this Chapter, to proceed to that wherein I explain the ReaÅ¿ons why Pruning is neceÅ¿Å¿ary.

To eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the two Principles I have heretofore advanc'd, I make uÅ¿e of two CompariÅ¿ons, whereof the firÅ¿t, which relates to the Pruning of weak Trees, is drawn from the Conduct of certain frugal Millers, who, with a Å¿mall quantity of Water, find the Means to manage a Mill that requires a great deal. The Second, which relates to the Pruning of very vigorous Trees, is taken from other Millers, who knowing how dangerous great Streams of RiÅ¿ing Waters are to their Mills, for a Time Å¿uffer the Abundance of Water; which might annoy them, to flow gently by; and the Violence of it being over, they Å¿hut their Sluce, or Water-gate, and afterwards employ the Remainder of their Water; according as may be expedient for the Number of Wheels they are to ply.

For the UnderÅ¿tanding of theÅ¿e two CompariÅ¿ons, I Å¿ay, that the Sap in every Tree appears to me to be partly the Å¿ame as Water is in every River: I will Å¿ay in another place, what Water is in the Pipes of Å¿pouting Fountains.

Whether Rivers be large or Å¿mall, it is Å¿till certain that they are beautiful, provided that the Channel of each, whatever it may be, be commonly furniÅ¿h'd with a quantity of Water proportionable to it; without which, they are miÅ¿erable, and of no ConÅ¿ideration: So is a Tree likewiÅ¿e eÅ¿teem'd beautiful, whatever Size it be of, (there being both Great and Small,) provided that Tree yearly produces Å¿ufficient fine Å¿hoots; from all its Parts; and in quantity, proportionable to its preÅ¿ent heighth and thickneÅ¿s, or bulk; without which, a Tree is certainly both ugly and miÅ¿erable.

It is certain, that while a Tree is in a good Ground, and well, the Weather not being Å¿o cold, as to freeze the Ground as far as the Roots; for Å¿uch a Cold Å¿tops all manner of vegetation; in Å¿uch a caÅ¿e, the extremities of the old Roots, Å¿till produce other new ones, and conÅ¿equently Å¿till produce a new Sap, as I prove in my Reflections, and Å¿o there perpetually riÅ¿es a Sap, both into the Stem of the Tree, and in all the Branches which compoÅ¿e the head or top of it; and this, more or leÅ¿s in the whole extent of each, according as the Sap is in it Å¿elf more or leÅ¿s abounding; juÅ¿t as it is in a River, while the Source is good, and no ways obÅ¿tructed, the Water flows continually, not only in the Bed or Channel, which Art and Nature have provided for it, but alÅ¿o, generally into all the Branches into which it may divide it Å¿elf; that is to Å¿ay, into all the Brooks, or Rivulets, which may form themÅ¿elves along its courÅ¿e, and that more or leÅ¿s, according as that Water is in it Å¿elf more or leÅ¿s abounding.

When we find that a Tree has but little vigour, and produces no fine Shoots; or that having been vigorous the preceeding Years, it ceaÅ¿es to be Å¿o, Å¿o as to produce no more Shoots, or at leaÅ¿t, none but very Å¿mall and inconÅ¿iderable ones, we may Å¿ay that it is an Infallible mark, either, that the Source of the Sap is Naturally weak and Å¿mall, or that it is become Å¿o; Å¿o that being no longer capable of performing any effect in long Branches, nor in many, and yet it being neceÅ¿Å¿ary it Å¿hould produce Å¿ome for our Profit and Satisfaction; we muÅ¿t betimes eaÅ¿e that Tree of its burthen, which is too great, conÅ¿idering its want of Strength and Vigour, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently betimes, wholly cut off a great part of its Branches, to the end, that we may, as Å¿oon as poÅ¿Å¿ibly can be, Å¿top many of thoÅ¿e overtures through which part of the Sap of that Tree did enter; and Å¿o that, which for Example, being divided into forty boughs Å¿eem'd to produce but little effect in each, the Å¿ame being afterwards contracted, and diÅ¿tributed into half the quantity, will be found Å¿ufficient to perform much greater Productions upon that Tree, tho' indeed leÅ¿s numerous: It was like a River, whoÅ¿e Source or Spring, was either Naturally weak, or conÅ¿iderably diminiÅ¿h'd, and which, notwithÅ¿tanding that being yet divided into too many Branches; could not perform any thing conÅ¿iderable in any of them; but the Å¿ame being induÅ¿triouÅ¿ly contracted, or reduc'd, and kept within narrow bounds, Å¿o that for the future no part of it may be loÅ¿t, as it us'd to be; is thereby enabl'd, at leaÅ¿t to turn Å¿ome Wheel. A Dam, or Sluce made betimes, have perform'd in this, what the good Fortune of a more abounding River would have done, as to Å¿everal Wheels.
This ReaÅ¿on has induc'd me to advice the Pruning of weak Trees betimes, and the Å¿ame ReaÅ¿on informs us, that they muÅ¿t be cut very Å¿hort, as we will demonÅ¿trate hereafter.

Now, that which is a convincing Argument, in relation to the Pruning of theÅ¿e, muÅ¿t, in my Opinion, by the Rule of contraries, Å¿erve to direct us as to the Pruning of vigorous Trees; be it either to do it later, or to leave a greater burthen upon each of them.

It is moÅ¿t certain, that we only have Fruit-Trees, in order to have Fruit; and it is as
certain, that Fruit commonly grows upon thoÅ¿e weak Branches only; the large ones bear but little, their Function being to perform Å¿omething elÅ¿e, which is very conÅ¿iderable: Thus great Torrents are not fit to grind, on the contrary, they are apt to choak or Å¿top up a Mill, or to break all; their Function is to Å¿erve to other things; for inÅ¿tance, for the TranÅ¿portation of Travellers, Burthens, MerchandiÅ¿es, &c. So that none but thoÅ¿e that are moderate, can be uÅ¿eful for Grinding; So likewiÅ¿e, a Tree being very vigorous, generally produces none but large Branches, eÅ¿pecially at the beginning of the Spring, at which time the Sap riÅ¿es moÅ¿t, and can begin none of thoÅ¿e weak ones, which we Å¿tand in need of for Fruit.

Now to Å¿uch a Tree that muÅ¿t be Prun'd in order to yield Fruit, and yet retain a pleaÅ¿ing Figure; you muÅ¿t not only leave a great burthen, whether it be as to the number of Branches, or the length of every one of them, which is certainly abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary, but there muÅ¿t be Å¿omething more: And as it is particularly on thoÅ¿e extremities, that the new Sap performs moÅ¿t at the entrance of the Spring, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary, as one may Å¿ay, to let the heat and fury of its firÅ¿t Action diÅ¿charge it Å¿elf: And therefore it is fit to Prune Å¿uch a Tree later; that is, it muÅ¿t not be done until the firÅ¿t impetuoÅ¿ity of the Sap be paÅ¿s'd; there will yet remain enough in it, to make thoÅ¿e kind of Branches Å¿o Prun'd, afterwards Å¿hoot out, at the Å¿ame time, both large Shoots for the Figure, and of thoÅ¿e Å¿mall ones which we deÅ¿ire for Fruit.

Not but that, as I will Å¿hew hereafter, the beÅ¿t Expedient in relation to very vigorous Trees; and even, if I may expreÅ¿s my Å¿elf Å¿o, obÅ¿tinate in point of Fruit; I Å¿ay, the beÅ¿t Expedient, is to go to the Source of their Vigour, which are the Roots: It is that Vigour which muÅ¿t be weaken'd, and conÅ¿equently the moÅ¿t working Roots: diminiÅ¿h'd, and thereby you will diminiÅ¿h the effect which proceeds from Å¿everal good Labourers; which acting at one and the Å¿ame time, produce more Sap than is requir'd to Å¿uch a Fruit-Tree: For, in fine, that Tree muÅ¿t according to our intention, quickly bear Fruit in a conÅ¿train'd Figure, the which is in no wiÅ¿e Natural to it; which it cannot do, when the Sap, being over abundant, produces every where, none but over large Branches.

The Experience which every one may acquire in the practice of theÅ¿e two Maxims, and particularly that which relates to the Pruning of weak Trees; that Experience, I Å¿ay, will perfectly eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h them for ever; and as for other Trees, I engage that every body will find a benefit by it; and I affirm, above all things, that it will be a great help to all Gard'ners, who are to mannage great Fruit-Gardens; and who, as it is very much to be wiÅ¿h'd, will Prune the greateÅ¿t part of their Trees themÅ¿elves.

As I am of Opinion, that they can do no better than to follow this Advice, Å¿o they appear to me very blame-worthy, if they tarry to the end of Winter, and the time of thoÅ¿e decreaÅ¿es of the Moons, of February and March, to begin to Prune; becauÅ¿e, that is the greateÅ¿t time of hurry for all manner of work relating to Gard'ners: All comes at once at the entrance of the Spring; the Tillage of the whole Garden, the Sowing of moÅ¿t Kitchen-Plants, the Budding of Artichokes, the making of the different Beds, the cleanÅ¿ing of the Walks; Å¿o that it is a Å¿trange confuÅ¿ion, to have at the Å¿ame time, the moÅ¿t conÅ¿iderable of all Works to do; for it is the only one, in which no Å¿mall faults can be committed, they are all conÅ¿iderable and pernicious; it is the Pruning of many Trees, and perhaps large Trees, Dwarfs and EÅ¿paliers, or Wall-Trees; without omitting the firÅ¿t palliÅ¿ading of theÅ¿e; and whereas in that caÅ¿e, all things are done in a hurry, Å¿o they are commonly ill enough done: For to Å¿peak the Truth, every thing requiring an equal haÅ¿te to be done, there are but few to which a Man can give that time, and application, which they require.

I have Å¿aid by the by, that I did no ways matter the decreaÅ¿e of the Moon, &c. But I have not anÅ¿wer'd an Objection which Å¿ome Gard'ners pretend to be invincible, and in which, in my Opinion, they are infinitely deceiv'd; it is, Å¿ay they, That the Winter FroÅ¿t may Å¿poil the extremities of the Branch that is Prun'd; and that if it be not to be fear'd Å¿o much for Kernel-Fruits, yet at leaÅ¿t it is very dangerous for Stone-Fruit, they pretending that the Wood of thoÅ¿e Trees is very tender, becauÅ¿e it is very pithy; I will only deÅ¿ire thoÅ¿e Å¿crupulous PerÅ¿ons, to lay aÅ¿ide that apprehenÅ¿ion, and I aÅ¿Å¿ure them, that the Experiment they will make of it, without prejudice, will fully cure them of their Error; we have had within theÅ¿e Seven or Eighth Years, the hardeÅ¿t Winters in the Memory of any Living Man. I had Prun'd my Peach-Trees before that great Cold, and I never found the leaÅ¿t inconveniency by it.

I am fully perÅ¿waded, that it is Å¿afe to Prune as often as the Cold is not Å¿o violent, as perÅ¿onally to prejudice the Pruner; there are only certain days of white or hoary FroÅ¿t, in which the Wood being altogether cover'd with a rimy FroÅ¿t, the Pruning-knife, tho' never Å¿o Å¿harp, cannot cut through it cleverly; and Å¿o, whereas a Man ought to Prune
with delight; to do it well, 'tis certainly impoÅ¿Å¿ible at that time, and therefore it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to defer Pruning, until that FroÅ¿t be altogether melted and gone.
The proper times for Pruning being regulated, we muÅ¿t proceed to Å¿omething more Material and Curious.

As nothing is more creditable and Natural for a Workman, than to know certainly, why, and for what ReaÅ¿on, he does the Work he is employ'd about; Å¿o I am perÅ¿waded, that nothing can be more Å¿tupid, and below a Man, than to Act barely by CuÅ¿tom, and Habit: It is a fault which is but too common amongÅ¿t moÅ¿t Gard'ners; they Å¿eldom Prune for any other ReaÅ¿on, than that it is cuÅ¿tomary. I am convinc'd that there is an indiÅ¿pencible NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of knowing Å¿omething more; without which, it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible ever to attain to any perfection in Pruning, which in my Opinion is an undeniable Truth: I cannot endure that a Gard'ner Å¿hould be puzzl'd, and almoÅ¿t quite at a loÅ¿s, when any body deÅ¿ires to know the ReaÅ¿ons of his Pruning: And that is the Subject I intend to Treat of in the following Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: Of the ReaÅ¿ons that oblige to Prune.

div.p: WE have two principal ReaÅ¿ons, which PreÅ¿cribe and AuthoriÅ¿e Pruning.
The FirÅ¿t is, To be Å¿ure to have a greater abundance of fine Fruit, and Å¿ooner.

The Second is, To render the Tree at all times more agreeable to Å¿ight, than it would be, if it were not Prun'd: It is undeniable, that it is not only the Fruit and Leaves that render a Tree beautiful: They are indeed its greateÅ¿t Ornaments, but there is Å¿omething more requir'd; Å¿ince the Fruit not remaining upon it all the Year round, it were to be wiÅ¿h'd, that when it is Å¿tript of thoÅ¿e Adornments, or is not yet old enough to have them all; it may at leaÅ¿t be compos'd, and Å¿hap'd Å¿o, as to delight the Eye.

Now that which, beÅ¿ides the importance of Fruit, renders a Tree pleaÅ¿ing to the Eye, is nothing but the beautiful Figure a skilful Gard'ner can give to it: And whereas we have two Å¿orts of Trees, upon which particularly we ExerciÅ¿e Pruning, to wit Dwarfs, and Wall-Trees, we muÅ¿t eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h good Principles to proceed prudently upon both: ThoÅ¿e Principles relate particularly to the thick Branches, without which we cannot have beautiful Dwarfs; and by means of which it is eaÅ¿ie, and even Infallible, to attain to a perfection in it; the whole MyÅ¿tery of that Operation, Å¿hall be diÅ¿cover'd in the Chapters that Treat of the manner of Pruning Dwarfs; and Wall-Trees, there being no other Rules for the one than for the other.

I Å¿ay firÅ¿t, That for thoÅ¿e two Å¿orts of Trees, it muÅ¿t be granted, that their Figures being Å¿o oppoÅ¿ite the one to the other, the Beauty conÅ¿equently muÅ¿t needs be Å¿o too, therefore I think it will not be amiÅ¿s, to Å¿hew in what, particularly, I faney, that thoÅ¿e two different kind of Beauties may conÅ¿iÅ¿t.

And perhaps, after that, it will not be improper to compare, in that reÅ¿pect, a good Gard'ner, to a skilful Carver; For as the latter, conformably to the Idea which fills his Imagination, ought at firÅ¿t Å¿ight, to behold in his Marble, the Figure he deÅ¿igns to work out of it, and conÅ¿equently to behold diÅ¿tinctly in it, the place of every particular Beauty, of which it is to be compos'd.

So an UnderÅ¿tanding Gard'ner, conformably to the Idea he Å¿hall have fram'd to himÅ¿elf of a fine Tree, muÅ¿t at a view behold whatever is to be done in any Tree, either to beautifie it, when it is not Å¿o, or to preÅ¿erve it in its Beauty, when it has acquir'd it; whether it be to render it uÅ¿eful; or, for Example, to Å¿ee where the Fruit Å¿hall be, and conÅ¿equently the Branches that Å¿hall produce it; to obÅ¿erve the Branches that muÅ¿t be taken off, and thoÅ¿e that muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd, to give it an agreeable Figure, &c. And as from time to time, the Carver draws back from his Work, to Å¿ee whether he has perform'd or executed his Thought well; Å¿o a skilful Gard'ner, in Pruning his Tree, ought to do the Å¿ame thing; that is, to draw back from it, from time to time, to Å¿ee whether he has really hit upon the beautiful Figure he deÅ¿igns to give it.

But before we enter into the explication of that Idea, or Notion of Beauty in Trees, it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to remember, That, as I have Å¿aid in my TreatiÅ¿e of Plantations, we have but few of thoÅ¿e that are call'd Fruit-Trees, that Naturally remain Low, DwarfiÅ¿h, and, as I may Å¿ay, Creeping enough, either to make regular Dwarfs, or yet leÅ¿s, to make Wall-Trees: All Trees, following the Inclination which Nature has given them, endeavour
to riÅ¿e, and conÅ¿equently 'tis only the InduÅ¿try of the Gard'ners, who oppoÅ¿ing the CourÅ¿e of Nature, hinders them from forming long Stems, and from growing Tall.

TheÅ¿e Gard'ners knowing that, as we have already Å¿aid, the Sap which is to form thoÅ¿e Stems, lies partly in the Trees; much in the Å¿ame manner, as the water which is to form the Spouts of Water-Works, lies in the Pipes: They have concluded from thence, that if they Å¿topp'd the PaÅ¿Å¿age which carries this Sap upwards, which is eaÅ¿ie to do, by Å¿hort'ning the Stems of the Trees, there wou'd be no further likelyhood of its growing to be a Standard; and Å¿o that Sap which is in motion, or Å¿trives to get out, without any poÅ¿Å¿ibility of being prevented, finding no longer a paÅ¿Å¿age to riÅ¿e up, as it ought, will diÅ¿charge it Å¿elf at the place where its CourÅ¿e has been interrupted, and will produce the Å¿ame effect there, it would have done higher, had it had the liberty of aÅ¿cending further; Å¿o that this Sap Å¿pringing out of the Å¿ides, not only by many Overtures, which are already actually form'd there, but likewiÅ¿e by or through others, that it will make it Å¿elf, proportionably as it is abundant, it will produce to the right and left a pretty conÅ¿iderable quantity of fine Branches.

I muÅ¿t now tell you, that if the Tree that is Å¿horten'd be Planted in the open Air, it may be diÅ¿pos'd to make a fine Dwarf; and if near any Wall, to make a fine Wall-Tree. I have alÅ¿o explain'd in the Å¿ame TreatiÅ¿e of Plantations what is a Dwarf, and what a Wall-Tree. I have there Å¿hewn what was the Intention of thoÅ¿e that firÅ¿t made them, and of what uÅ¿e they may be to us. I have likewiÅ¿e declar'd in it, that when the Walls are high, you muÅ¿t Plant Long Body'd Trees to garniÅ¿h the top of the Wall; and that inÅ¿tead of leaving them there the liberty of forming a round Tree, as they wou'd do were they left at liberty, their Branches muÅ¿t be conÅ¿train'd, like thoÅ¿e of the Trees that are Å¿horten'd, as we will demonÅ¿trate; after having firÅ¿t explain'd wherein the Beauty both of the one and the others does conÅ¿iÅ¿t; I mean, of Dwarfs, and Wall-Trees.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: Of the Idea of Beauty which the Dwarfs Require.

div.p: THE Beauty of Dwarfs requires two Conditions, the one in reÅ¿pect to the Stem, and the other of the Head: According to the firÅ¿t Condition, Dwarfs muÅ¿t be low Stem; and according to the Å¿econd, they muÅ¿t have an open Head, that is, free from thick Branches in the middle; it muÅ¿t be round in its Circumference, and equally furniÅ¿h'd with good Branches on the Å¿ides.

I will explain more particularly hereafter what I mean by that Opening of the Middle, and it Å¿hall be in the place where I Å¿hall give Directions how to attain to it; but in the mean time a Man muÅ¿t have a right apprehenÅ¿ion of the four Conditions of that Figure, and be fully perÅ¿waded of it, in order to underÅ¿tand uÅ¿efully my Maxims of Pruning, and grow Skilful in them, in caÅ¿e he approves them Å¿o well, as to be willing to PractiÅ¿e them.

I Å¿ay nothing as yet of the heighth of the Head of thoÅ¿e Dwarfs; it depends on the Age of the Trees, being low in thoÅ¿e that are yet young, and riÅ¿ing in all according as they grow: But as much as is poÅ¿Å¿ible, I wou'd not willingly have it exceed Six or Seven Foot: It being better, in my Opinion, that thoÅ¿e Trees Å¿hou'd grow in extent of Circumference, and Breadth, than to let them riÅ¿e high. The PleaÅ¿ure of Sight, which dreads whatever Limits it too much, particularly in Gardens, beÅ¿ides the PerÅ¿ecution of the Winds, which eaÅ¿ily beats down the Fruit of High Trees, makes me fix to that meaÅ¿ure. As the Pruning of Dwarfs is incomparably more difficult, and conÅ¿equently contains a great many more Rules than the Pruning of Wall-Trees. I will begin with that, before I Å¿peak of the other.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Of the Idea of Beauty which Wall-Trees require; together with the Maxims of PalliÅ¿ading.

div.p: TO advance our Wall-Trees to that perfection of Beauty which beÅ¿t becomes them; I am of Opinion, that it muÅ¿t be our particular care, that all the Branches of each Tree, in Å¿preading over the Å¿ides of that part of the Wall which they are to garniÅ¿h; muÅ¿t be Å¿o well Å¿tretch'd, and Å¿o equally plac'd, both on the right and leÅ¿t; that in their whole extent, taking them from the place, whence they Å¿everally proceed, as far as all the extremities of their heighth and roundneÅ¿s, no part of the Tree may appear thinner or fuller than another; in Å¿o much, that at firÅ¿t Å¿ight, one may diÅ¿tinctly Å¿ee all the Branches that compoÅ¿e it, Å¿o far as to be able, to tell them with eaÅ¿e, if Å¿o minded: ThinneÅ¿s is the greateÅ¿t imperfection of Wall-Trees, as fulneÅ¿s is the greateÅ¿t fault of Dwarfs; when I Å¿ay, that I would have my Wall-Trees full, I do not mean, that they Å¿hould be full of ill Branches, old, worn, or uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, as a great many ignorant PerÅ¿ons affect to have them; neither on the other hand, in deÅ¿iring my Dwarfs to be open in the middle, would I have them empty, like the inÅ¿ide of a GlaÅ¿s, &c. I do particularly deÅ¿ire all Gard'ners, to be very mindful of theÅ¿e two Ideas of Beauty.

As to the Beauty of Wall-Trees, it is certainly diÅ¿agreeable, to Å¿ee their Branches croÅ¿Å¿ing one another, which muÅ¿t be avoided as much as is poÅ¿Å¿ible; but whereas thinneÅ¿s, as I have already Å¿aid, is in my Opinion, the defect the moÅ¿t contrary to the Beauty of thoÅ¿e kind of Trees, I am for endeavouring to avoid it above all things; Å¿o that for that ReaÅ¿on, I will have it allow'd, nay and order'd too, to run them over one another in Å¿ome occaÅ¿ions, and that particularly it may be allow'd for the great Branches, which are alone the foundation of all the Beauty of the Tree, to be Å¿ometimes drawn over Å¿mall ones, or the Å¿mall ones over them, otherwiÅ¿e it would be impoÅ¿Å¿ible to avoid the danger of falling into the diÅ¿agreeable inconvenience of that unlucky BarrenneÅ¿s.

ThoÅ¿e little Branches, which we may in Å¿ome manner look upon here, as Temporary Branches; are commonly, as we have Å¿aid, the only ones that muÅ¿t yield Fruit, and that is the ReaÅ¿on, why they have been carefully and preciouÅ¿ly preÅ¿erv'd; but whereas, after having given that Fruit, they muÅ¿t infallibly periÅ¿h; they will be Å¿oon retrench'd from our Wall-Trees, and conÅ¿equently they will Å¿oon Å¿upercede the reproach of croÅ¿Å¿ing, they may have drawn upon the Gard'ner; and he Å¿hall thereby be freed from another reproach, which is much more to be fear'd, and that is the want of Fruit.

So then, that croÅ¿Å¿ing muÅ¿t not be us'd, unleÅ¿s there be an abÅ¿olute neceÅ¿Å¿ity; inÅ¿omuch that when it can be avoided, I condemn the Gard'ners, who, either through Ignorance, or Negligence, have thereby deÅ¿troy'd the agreeable Simetry their Wall-Trees might have had.

And becauÅ¿e, that, in the firÅ¿t place, the only way of giving every one of thoÅ¿e Trees the Beauty, which I have been Å¿peaking of, is by means of Pruning; and that in the Å¿econd place, every Tree being compos'd of two Parts; of which the one is call'd the Stock or Stem, and the other the Branches; it is certainly upon thoÅ¿e two parts, that the Pruning is to be perform'd, but yet much more upon the Branches, than upon the Stem.

And becauÅ¿e, that chiefly in Trees, there are, as we have Å¿aid, Å¿everal kind of Branches, very different the one from the other, all having their particular ReaÅ¿ons, either to be taken away, or preÅ¿erv'd; and among thoÅ¿e that are to be preÅ¿erv'd, Å¿ome are to be Å¿horten'd, becauÅ¿e they are too long, and others to remain whole; Å¿o conÅ¿equently, there muÅ¿t be a great deal of care taken, for the well mannaging of them both.

I do think my Å¿elf indiÅ¿penÅ¿ably oblig'd, to endeavour to unravel, if poÅ¿Å¿ible, all the diÅ¿tinctions that are to be made among thoÅ¿e Branches; or otherwiÅ¿e it will not be poÅ¿Å¿ible to underÅ¿tand the Maxims I deÅ¿ign to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h for Pruning well.

I am of Opinion, that I muÅ¿t take the Å¿ame Method in this, as People do in Teaching to Read: The FirÅ¿t thing, is to learn the Letters of the Alphabet: The Second, how to uÅ¿e thoÅ¿e Letters, to joyn two or three together, to form Å¿illables; And, in fine, the Third, to Learn the Union of many Sillables, in order to make whole Words; and theÅ¿e Words following each other afterwards, compoÅ¿e both the Line and Page, &c.

In the Å¿ame manner, will I firÅ¿t Teach, how to underÅ¿tand well the Branches of our Fruit-Trees, giving them Names that may expreÅ¿s what they are, and then the UÅ¿e and peculiar Function of each of them; to the end, that Å¿everal of them, being well plac'd,
may render the Trees Beautiful, and diÅ¿poÅ¿e them Å¿oon to yield abundance of good Fruit. Perhaps on the occaÅ¿ion of this CompariÅ¿on, it would not be improper to Å¿ay; that as in Reading, Words are only form'd by the Reciprocal Function of the Vowels and ConÅ¿onants; Å¿o our Trees only become Beautiful, when they have at one and the Å¿ame time, a reaÅ¿onable proportion of Wood and Fruit-Branches; Å¿o that as the Vowels, or ConÅ¿onants aÅ¿under, can form no Words, or DiÅ¿courÅ¿e; neither can Wood, or Fruit-Branches aÅ¿under, compoÅ¿e a Beautiful Fruit-Tree.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Of Branches in General.

div.p: RIghtly to underÅ¿tand the Doctrine of Branches; Five material Things muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erv'd.

FirÅ¿t, That as they compoÅ¿e a conÅ¿iderable part of the Tree, they Å¿prout out of two parts of it; Å¿ome Å¿hoot directly out of the main body, and thoÅ¿e are the firÅ¿t, and may be Å¿til'd, the Elder, or Mothers; their number is not conÅ¿iderable; the others afterwards are produc'd by theÅ¿e, and are as it were the Daughters of theÅ¿e Mother-Branches: The number of theÅ¿e laÅ¿t is infinite; for Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively in their turns, they become every one Mother-Branches, to many others.

It muÅ¿t be noted, in the Å¿econd place, that from the Body of every Branch, when the Tree is in a good CaÅ¿e, there yearly grow new ones at the extremities of it; and that more or leÅ¿s, according to the Å¿trength or weakneÅ¿s of that Branch, which I Å¿hall call Mother-Branch, in relation to the new ones it produceth.

In the third place, you muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve that theÅ¿e new Branches grow in two different manners; the one in a Regular Order, which is the beÅ¿t, the moÅ¿t common, and moÅ¿t frequent; the others in an Irregular Order, which is the leaÅ¿t common, and leaÅ¿t frequent.

That Order, which is moÅ¿t common, and the beÅ¿t of the Production of the new Branches, when they produce more than one, is, that tho' both the one and the other at the Å¿ame time iÅ¿Å¿ue from the extremities of one that is more Ancient, whether Prun'd, or not, they are notwithÅ¿tanding regularly all of a different thickneÅ¿s, and length; for every one of the higheÅ¿t, are always both thicker and longer than any of thoÅ¿e that are immediately under them, drawing nearer to the Body: I Å¿aid, when it produces more than one; for when the Mother-Branch brings forth but one, the Daughter at the end of the Summer proves as large as the Mother, and is very good; when that Mother yields two, that which is grown from the extremity, which I call the firÅ¿t, or higheÅ¿t, is thicker and longer than that which is grown immediately beneath it, which I name the Å¿econd, or loweÅ¿t: And in the Å¿ame manner, when the Mother-Branch produces three, four, five, &c. As the firÅ¿t, that is the higheÅ¿t, is thicker and longer than the Å¿econd, Å¿o the Å¿econd in the Å¿ame manner exceeds the third, the third the fourth; and Å¿o by degrees, what ever quantity of new Branches the Mother-Branch may produce, as it appears by the Figures.

This being granted, it is eaÅ¿ie to judge, that the Order which is leaÅ¿t Common, and worÅ¿t in the Production of new Branches, is, when the Common Order is inverted, Å¿o that there are weak ones in the place where there ought to be thick ones; and that on the contrary, there are large ones, where they ought to be weak, and where perhaps there ought to be none; as it appears by the Figure of Branches mark'd with a *.

It is not enough to know whence the Branches proceed, nor the Order in which they come forth; it is requiÅ¿ite to know, in the fourth place, that as that greater or Å¿maller number of Branches, depends upon the force or weakneÅ¿s of the Mother-Branch; I think, that to make my Å¿elf the better underÅ¿tood, it will be Å¿it to call thoÅ¿e Å¿trong, which are thick; and to call thoÅ¿e weak, which are Å¿mall; every one of thoÅ¿e Branches having their Functions Regulated according to their Degrees of Force, or WeakneÅ¿s; Å¿o that they Å¿eldom incroach upon one another, being wholly apply'd to the diÅ¿charge of the firÅ¿t Duty which Nature Å¿eems to have impos'd upon them, in forming them.

In the fifth place, you muÅ¿t note, and this is the moÅ¿t Material Point; that among all the Branches, whether Å¿trong or weak; there are Å¿ome which have the real Character of good, of which a great many muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd: There are likewiÅ¿e Å¿ome which have the real Character of bad ones; for which reaÅ¿on, a Name of Reprobation is given them: In regularity, almoÅ¿t all theÅ¿e laÅ¿t ought to be expell'd; let us obÅ¿erve how to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the one certainly from the other.

figure.head: Different Situations of the first Branches produced sometimes, by a Tree newly planted

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: To know the difference of Good and Ill Branches.

div.p: WE have two Certain and Infallible marks in relation to Fruit-Trees, certainly to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the good and ill Branches from each other, either while they are Å¿till upon the Tree, or when they are cut off: The one depends upon the difference of their Scituation, and Original, and the other from the difference of their Eyes, or Buds.

I Å¿uppoÅ¿e that every body knows that there are Eyes upon every Branch, which are little knotty places, a little elevated above the reÅ¿t of the Bark; it is upon thoÅ¿e little places that the Leaves are actually fix'd, as they are Å¿een there in the Summer time; or at leaÅ¿t Å¿ome have been fix'd there Å¿ome time before, which may either have dropt of themÅ¿elves, or perhaps have been taken off.

What we learn by that difference of Scituation, and Original, is firÅ¿t, that the Branches to be good, muÅ¿t abÅ¿olutely, and only proceed from the extremities of thoÅ¿e which were remaining upon the Tree, at the entrance of the Spring, whether they were form'd in the laÅ¿t year, or Å¿ome years before; or likewiÅ¿e whether the one and the others have been Prun'd as is CuÅ¿tomary, or not; as it happens Å¿ometimes, for Example, in Standard-Trees. In fine, as we only Å¿peak here in relation to Trees that are liable to Pruning, it muÅ¿t be granted, that it is only from the extremity of Branches, tho' never Å¿o Old, which have been Prun'd, at the SeaÅ¿on of the laÅ¿t Pruning, that the New Branches muÅ¿t proceed: In the Å¿econd place, what we gather from the difference of Scituation, and Original of new Branches, is, That thoÅ¿e Branches, to be good, muÅ¿t have been produc'd in the moÅ¿t ordinary and moÅ¿t common Order of Nature, as we have heretofore explain'd it.

From thence two things muÅ¿t be concluded: The firÅ¿t, that any Branch which, inÅ¿tead of being grown from the extremity of that which had been form'd the preceeding Summer, or at leaÅ¿t from the extremity of that which had been taken Å¿horter at the laÅ¿t Pruning, proceeds from any other part of the Tree, be it either from the Stem, or Å¿ome other Old Branch, that had not been Prun'd: I Å¿ay it muÅ¿t be concluded, that Å¿uch a Branch, of whatever Å¿ize, thick or Å¿mall, is an ill Branch, as I will demonÅ¿trate hereafter.

And what muÅ¿t be concluded in the Å¿econd place, is, That any Branch which, inÅ¿tead of being grown in the good order of Nature, being either thicker or longer than that which is immediately beneath it, drawing towards the Superiour Extremity; it muÅ¿t, I Å¿ay, be concluded that Å¿uch a Branch is likewiÅ¿e nought: It is for thoÅ¿e kind of Branches that the name of falÅ¿e wood has been made, to expreÅ¿s that thoÅ¿e Branches are incapable of performing what we deÅ¿ire; they muÅ¿t be us'd altogether in a different manner from the good ones. We will Å¿et down particular Maxims to that effect.

But whereas I do not think it Å¿ufficient to have methinks, pretty intelligibly explain'd the difference of Branches, by that which is grounded upon the difference of their Scituation, and Original; I will moreover explain the other, which is founded upon the difference of their Eyes.

The Mark of the good ones by that difference of Eyes, requires that in the whole extent of the Branch, the Eyes Å¿hould be thick, and well fed, and very cloÅ¿e one to another; whereas the mark of the bad ones by thoÅ¿e Å¿ame Eyes, is that in all the lower part of Å¿uch Branches thoÅ¿e Eyes are flat, ill fed, and hardly form'd, and very diÅ¿tant the one from the other.
TheÅ¿e two different Marks, as well by Situations, as by Eyes, are eaÅ¿ily known in the Figures annex'd hereunto A. B. in which the ill ones are mark'd with a *.

You may Å¿ee both very good, and very bad ones, as well among the thick and Å¿trong ones, as among thoÅ¿e that are Å¿mall and feeble. As to theÅ¿e, their weakneÅ¿s, is Å¿ometimes Å¿o exceÅ¿Å¿ive, that like Å¿apleÅ¿s Branches, incapable of bearing Fruit, or at leaÅ¿t of nouriÅ¿hing and Å¿uÅ¿taining the weight of their Fruit, they muÅ¿t be wholly taken off from our Fruit-Trees, and eÅ¿pecially from the Dwarfs, of which the Branches are not tack'd; becauÅ¿e that to do well, we muÅ¿t Å¿uffer nothing that is not good.

The good weak Branches, I mean thoÅ¿e which being well plac'd, and of a mean thickneÅ¿s, and length, are as it were proper and certain InÅ¿truments to produce Speedy, Beautiful and Good Fruit, and are infallibly Å¿o, provided the FroÅ¿t Å¿poils nothing, either while they are in BloÅ¿Å¿om, or Å¿oon after the Fruit is knit; for Å¿uch Branches Å¿eldom fail of producing BloÅ¿Å¿om-Buds; and beÅ¿ides, cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly Å¿erve to any end but yielding of Fruit, unleÅ¿s contrary to the Natural and Common Order of Vegetation, they Å¿hou'd happen to have certain overflowings of Sap to thicken them in an extraordinary manner,
and Å¿o alter their Property; that is, convert them into Branches for Wood; which happens Å¿ometimes in all manner of Trees, particulaely in Å¿uch as have been ill Prun'd: I will explain in the Sequel, what Method is fit to be us'd in Å¿uch OccaÅ¿ions.

The good Å¿trong Branches, of which the Principal UÅ¿e is firÅ¿t to begin, and then continue to give the Trees a proper Figure, which they can receive by no other means, are particularly employ'd in producing yearly on their Extremities other good new Branches, Å¿ome Å¿trong, and others weak, as it appears by the Figure A. And the great Skill of the Gardner conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in making a good uÅ¿e of both.

And to that end, as it is material to preÅ¿erve the good weak ones for Fruit, which is the peculiar End of Fruit-Gardens, it is likewiÅ¿e very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to work prudently to mannage our Operations upon the good Å¿trong ones: It is true, that it is requiÅ¿ite to preÅ¿erve on the Extremities of every Old Branch Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e new Å¿trong ones that are grown there, but that commonly extends but to a Å¿mall Number; for Example, to one only; and Å¿ometimes the Mother-Branch being extraordinarily Vigorous, it may extend to two, or three; as I will demonÅ¿trate hereafter, in explaining the manner of Pruning, for which we muÅ¿t have very good ReaÅ¿ons; for if too many were preÅ¿erv'd, we Å¿hou'd certainly fall into the inconvenience of ConfuÅ¿ion, which inconvenience Å¿poils the whole diÅ¿poÅ¿ition towards Fruit, as well as the beauty of the Figure.

There is chiefly a great deal of Skill requir'd, to know how to take away entirely all the uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches, whether it be becauÅ¿e they are worn or Å¿pent, or becauÅ¿e they have no good qualifications; and the Å¿ame concerning thoÅ¿e that are to be preÅ¿erv'd, to know how to regulate their length proportionably to their Force, and the Vigour of the whole Tree; Å¿o that afterwards every one of them may be able to produce on its Extremity juÅ¿t as many good Branches as are neceÅ¿Å¿ary either for the Fruit, or for the perfecting the Beauty of the Tree, or for preÅ¿erving it when it is eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd: And this is what we call the Common Pruning of Trees.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.p: Of the Explication of the Words of Strong and Strength, of Weak and WeakneÅ¿s.

div.p: WHereas in this TreatiÅ¿e of Pruning, I am of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity oblig'd, to make uÅ¿e frequently of the Words of Strong and Strength, of Weak and WeakneÅ¿s; which Words bear a double meaning, and therefore might puzzle the Reader; I think it will be proper, before I enter into the particulars of that matter, to give a Å¿hort Account of the Sence, in which I take and uÅ¿e them; I muÅ¿t omit nothing of what may help me to avoid the ambiguity which thoÅ¿e Terms might create in my Maxims. LeÅ¿t that not being well underÅ¿tood, being Paradoxes, they might not at firÅ¿t meet with all the approbation I could wiÅ¿h them, and hope to procure them in the Å¿equel.

When ever then I Å¿peak here, of Å¿trong Branches, and Å¿trong Roots; I mean, as I have already hinted, Å¿uch as are thick; and likewiÅ¿e, Å¿peaking of weak Branches, I mean Å¿uch as are Å¿mall: Moreover, when I Å¿peak of a Å¿trong Tree, I mean a vigorous Tree; that is, a Tree that produces a great many fine thick Branches; and in Å¿peaking of a weak Tree, I mean a languiÅ¿hing Tree; that is, a Tree that yields but very few Å¿hoots, and for the moÅ¿t part all Å¿mall.

This being agreed on, and conformably to the Sence, in which the words of Strong and Strength, of Weak and WeakneÅ¿s, are commonly taken, when us'd in Å¿peaking Å¿ometimes of Animals, and Å¿ometimes of Timber to Build with, in relation to the burthens they are able to bear.

I Å¿ay, in Å¿peaking of the Pruning of Branches, that thoÅ¿e that are Å¿trong muÅ¿t be kept Å¿hort, I mean thoÅ¿e that are thick; and that the weak ones muÅ¿t be kept long, that is, thoÅ¿e that are Å¿mall; and in Å¿peaking of the Pruning of Roots, I preÅ¿cribe a clean contrary Method from the Branches; for we muÅ¿t keep them Å¿hort, that are weak and Å¿mall, and thoÅ¿e that are thick, Å¿trong, and better nouriÅ¿h'd, a little longer â¢ ; as I explain in the TreatiÅ¿e of the Plantations, in that part where I give directions for preparing Trees to Plant.

I likewiÅ¿e call Apple-Trees, graffed upon Paradice-Stocks, weak Trees; as alÅ¿o early Cherry-Trees, graffed upon common Cherry-Stocks; as I Å¿ay, that thoÅ¿e that are graffed upon free Stocks, that is, upon good Wildlings, are Å¿trong and vigorous Trees; theÅ¿e
being really capable' of producing and bearing a great deal, and the others but very little.

It is likewiÅ¿e in that SenÅ¿e, that after having regulated of what thickneÅ¿s partly the Trees of each kind ought to be, to be proper to be choÅ¿en and Planted by a skilful Gard'ner; I Å¿ay in that CaÅ¿e, obÅ¿erving the difference between the one and the other; that for Example, Å¿uch a Pear-Tree, or Å¿uch a Peach-Tree, in which I find a fitting thickneÅ¿s, is Å¿trong enough, and Å¿o will be fit to be Planted: I Å¿ay likewiÅ¿e that another Tree of that Kind, being of an exceÅ¿Å¿ive thickneÅ¿s, is too Å¿trong; and that on the contrary, another of that Kind, in which that neceÅ¿Å¿ary thickneÅ¿s is wanting, is too weak: It is likewiÅ¿e in that SenÅ¿e, that it may truly be Å¿aid, that the Trees which grow Å¿lowly, and never grow extream Tall, are the WeakeÅ¿t; witneÅ¿s the Quince-Tree, the Elder, the Medlar, the AÅ¿pices curvatos Pomorum pondere ramos. Ut Å¿ua quod peperit, vix ferat Arboronus. Hazzle, or Nut-Tree, the Paradice Apple-Tree, &c.
I maintain two things more in the Å¿ame SenÅ¿e.

The firÅ¿t is, That care muÅ¿t be taken that the weak Branch which is full of Buds, be however Å¿trong enough to bear the weight of its Fruit, becauÅ¿e that otherwiÅ¿e, if it be too weak, it will break under it; and therefore I maintain that no more muÅ¿t be left upon each, than in proportion to the Å¿trength it may have to bear it.

The Å¿econd thing I maintain, relates particularly to the Graffs that are made Cleft-wiÅ¿e, upon which, when a Branch, being Å¿mall at the time of its Graffing, becomes afterwards much thicker than before, methinks that it is hard forbearing to Å¿ay that it is grown the Å¿tronger by it, there being no likelyhood of maintaining, on the contrary, that the thicker it is, the weaker it is.

From all I have been Å¿aying, to explain the Å¿ignification of thoÅ¿e words Strong and Strength, Weak and WeakneÅ¿s, it follows, that they may, according to my Å¿ence, be uÅ¿efully employ'd, and diÅ¿tinctly underÅ¿tood in the TreatiÅ¿e of the Pruning of Trees.

Now, among theÅ¿e Trees, there are Å¿ome which yearly produce a great quantity of thick Branches, and few Å¿mall ones: There are Å¿ome that produce a reaÅ¿onable number of both; and in fine, there are Å¿ome which grow but little either from Foot, or Head; That is, that produce but few new Roots under Ground, and even thoÅ¿e all Å¿mall ones, and but few new Branches above ground, and thoÅ¿e likewiÅ¿e almoÅ¿t all Å¿hort and Å¿mall; which are conÅ¿equently far from appearing, as they Å¿ay commonly, Fine, Strong, and Vigorous Trees; but, on the contrary, look, if I may expreÅ¿s my Å¿elf Å¿o, Sick, and LanguiÅ¿hing.

This Production of different Branches, is only the Work of Nature, which is perform'd innocently, and without the leaÅ¿t dependance on the ReaÅ¿onings of PhiloÅ¿ophy; and tho' this Production has not been the work of the Meditation of Man, yet it has furniÅ¿h'd him a fair Subject to work upon; Å¿o that we pretend to have drawn great InÅ¿tructions from it, towards the Cultivating and Management of our Fruit-Gardens.

Being then certain, that all the Parts, of which all manner of Trees are Compos'd, do not receive an equal quantity of Sap, Å¿ince all the Branches are not of an equal thickneÅ¿s, and length; I mean, Å¿ome being conÅ¿iderably thicker, and harder to break, which conÅ¿equently may be Å¿aid to be Å¿tronger than others their Neighbours: Being likewiÅ¿e certain, that upon the Å¿ame Trees, there are certain Branches, which are conÅ¿iderably Å¿maller, and more eaÅ¿ie to break, and therefore may be Å¿aid to be weaker than other Neighbouring ones.

It is moreover certain, as I have heretofore offer'd, and 'tis what I have obÅ¿erv'd (which perhaps few had done before me) I Å¿ay it is certain, that very Å¿eldom Fruit-Buds form themÅ¿elves upon thick and Å¿trong Branches; Å¿o that, for InÅ¿tance, if a Pear-Tree produce none but Å¿uch, it will commonly bear no Pears; whereas, on the contrary, the Å¿mall and weak Branches produce generally a great deal of Fruit; inÅ¿omuch, that if Å¿ometimes in one and the Å¿ame Tree all one Å¿ide appears as it were Pining, in not having produc'd any new Branches, or at leaÅ¿t but very weak ones: It is obÅ¿ervable, that that Å¿ide grows ordinarily full of Fruit-buds, while the other part of the Tree, which by the abundance of Fine Branches appears very Healthy and Vigorous, produces but very few, and often none at all.

This ObÅ¿ervation has put me upon performing two Operations which I have found very Å¿ucceÅ¿sful. The firÅ¿t is, that when a Fruit-Tree remains Å¿everal years without producing hardly any thing beÅ¿ides theÅ¿e kind of Branches of an extraordinary thickneÅ¿s and length; and conÅ¿equently bears but little Fruit: In that caÅ¿e I have found no better and readier way to make it Fruitful, than by the extraordinary Pruning I have mention'd heretofore; that is, by applying my Å¿elf at the beginning of the Spring to the Source or Spring of that Force and Vigour, which are the Roots, in order to diminiÅ¿h their Action; and to that end I lay open half the Foot of that Tree, and wholly take away one or two,
and Å¿ometimes more of the thickeÅ¿t and moÅ¿t active Roots I meet with, and retrench them Å¿o well from the Place where they grow, that there does not remain the leaÅ¿t part capable of performing the leaÅ¿t Function of a Root; by that means I prevent the Luxuriance of the Sap for the future, and conÅ¿equently render the whole Head leÅ¿s Vigorous; whence it follows, that it Shoots leÅ¿s of theÅ¿e thick Branches, and more Å¿mall ones, and thus it is diÅ¿pos'd to bear Fruit.

The Å¿econd Operation is that, when in the Month of May a Branch Å¿hoots out of an extraordinary thickneÅ¿s, either in the ordinary CourÅ¿e of an old Planted Tree, or in the firÅ¿t Years of Graffing, and that conÅ¿equently it will be evident that Å¿uch a Branch will be at the Å¿ame time very long, and have no DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition to bear Fruit; this being grounded upon the ReaÅ¿on of its Strength, or ThickneÅ¿s, which proceeds from too great an abundance of Sap; in Å¿uch a caÅ¿e, I am of Opinion, that it is eaÅ¿ie for thoÅ¿e that are willing Å¿o to do; to divide, as I may call it, that Torrent of Sap; and whereas inÅ¿tead that its whole Tendency was only to the Production of a thick Branch, which for the moÅ¿t part would he of no UÅ¿e at all, it is eaÅ¿ie to reduce it, and as it were oblige it to make Å¿everal very good ones, whereof one part will be weak for Fruit, and others Å¿ufficiently thick for Wood.

And that is fit to be done in the Month of May: Therefore at that time I cauÅ¿e that young thick Shoot to be Pinch'd, that is broken with the Nail, and leave it no greater length than that of two, three, or four Eyes at moÅ¿t.
Hereafter I will explain the manner, and Å¿ucceÅ¿s of Å¿uch an Operation, after having explain'd what relates to Pruning.

But before I enter into the particulars of Pruning; I Å¿uppoÅ¿e, that we are to Prune either young Trees, which have never yet felt the Pruning Knife; and, for Example, have not been Planted above a Year or two; or Old Trees, which have already been Prun'd Å¿everal Years before.

I Å¿uppoÅ¿e beÅ¿ides, that theÅ¿e old Trees are in a good condition, as having been govern'd by PerÅ¿ons of UnderÅ¿tanding, Å¿o that they only want being preÅ¿erv'd; or elÅ¿e that they are in an ill caÅ¿e, either for having always been neglected; that is, not Prun'd; or elÅ¿e, for having been ill Prun'd; Å¿o that it may be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to endeavour the correcting of their defects.

I do not really believe, that I may Å¿o foreÅ¿ee all the CaÅ¿es of Pruning, as without forgetting one, be able to give Rules for every one that may happen; I am far from being Å¿o preÅ¿umptuous, knowing, that it is almoÅ¿t, in this caÅ¿e, as it is in PhyÅ¿ick, and in the matter of Law-Suits: Hypocrates and Gallen, with Å¿o many AphoriÅ¿ms for the one; Le Code and Le DigeÅ¿te, with Å¿o many Regulations and Ord'nances for the other, have not been capable of foreÅ¿eeing and providing againÅ¿t all, nor conÅ¿equently to decide all, Å¿ince there daily occur new CaÅ¿es: All I pretend, is to give you exact Information of the Method I have practis'd for theÅ¿e Thirty Years with an extraordinary application, in which I have been very Å¿ucceÅ¿sful; as well as thoÅ¿e who underÅ¿tand it, and who, in imitation of me, do me the Honour to PractiÅ¿e my Maxims.

To explain the particulars of this Method, I will divide what I have to Å¿ay into three ClaÅ¿Å¿is; and FirÅ¿t, in favour of the Curious, who begin to make New Plantations, I will Å¿peak of Trees newly Planted, upon which I will firÅ¿t give General Rules for the well Pruning of all the Shoots, which every Tree Å¿hall have produc'd; beginning with thoÅ¿e of the firÅ¿t Year, and Å¿hall continue in the Å¿ame manner from Year to Year, for five Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ive Years, in order to Å¿hew the effect of the Pruning of every one of theÅ¿e five Years; afterwards I will give other Rules to remedy certain defects, which will happen Å¿ometimes, notwithÅ¿tanding the firÅ¿t cares of a Skilful Gard'ner: With all theÅ¿e precautions, and this Method, I have ground to believe, that a Gard'ner, who will be tollerably induÅ¿trious, may be Å¿ufficiently inÅ¿tructed in this matter to underÅ¿tand it, to take pleaÅ¿ure in it, and laÅ¿tly, to perfect himÅ¿elf in it, by his own practice, as much as he Å¿hall have occaÅ¿ion for.

After having thus labour'd in favour of the Curious, who have made new Plantations, and will mannage them themÅ¿elves; I will proceed to the other Curious, who all on a Å¿udden find themÅ¿elves MaÅ¿ters of certain Gardens, wherein the Trees are old; whether thoÅ¿e Trees have been for a long time well mannag'd, or ill, either through Ignorance or want of Skill; and I will endeavour to make them apprehend what I would do to them, were I to have the mannagement of them; This will be particularly of uÅ¿e to all kind of Gard'ners, who in all SeaÅ¿ons, caÅ¿ting their Eyes upon any Trees whatever, Å¿hall not only be deÅ¿irous to judge of their good or ill Condition to Å¿atisfie others; but likewiÅ¿e, Å¿hall employ themÅ¿elves in Pruning of them; or at leaÅ¿t, to preÅ¿cribe what Å¿hould be done to them

for the good of the Tree, or the PleaÅ¿ure and Advantage of the owner: But firÅ¿t, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary, to Å¿peak of the Tools that are neceÅ¿Å¿ary for Pruning, and the manner of uÅ¿ing them.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: Of the Tools that are neceÅ¿Å¿ary for Pruning, and of the manner of uÅ¿ing them.

div.p: I Should not need to Å¿ay, that in order to Prune, either Branches or Roots, two good Tools are neceÅ¿Å¿arily requir'd, which are a Pruning Knife and a Saw, becauÅ¿e 'tis no Novelty, Å¿ince every body knows it as well as my Å¿elf: But whereas, I am not to omit any thing relating to my Subject, I Å¿hould think my Å¿elf blame-worthy, if I did not Å¿peak of theÅ¿e InÅ¿truments.

BeÅ¿ides that, as I always aim at rend'ring the work eaÅ¿ie, and that I am a mortal Enemy to confuÅ¿ion; I will deÅ¿troy certain Portative Shops, which are a large and great CaÅ¿e, Å¿tuft up with a multitude of pretty large Tools, and conÅ¿equently maÅ¿Å¿ive and heavy, which Gard'ners heretofore only us'd at the time of Pruning, and call'd it a Gard'ner's Budget: Now inÅ¿tead of all this Å¿tuff, I only deÅ¿ire theÅ¿e two little Tools, which may at all times be carry'd in the Pocket, without receiving the leaÅ¿t trouble from their bigneÅ¿s or weight; Å¿o that on all occaÅ¿ions, People may not be without Å¿omething about them, to take away in their Walks, whatever may be judg'd fit to be remov'd; otherwiÅ¿e it often happens, that certain things remain imperfect, for want of having about one, wherewith to correct it, as Å¿oon as it is taken notice of.

I Å¿ay then, with every body, that the Saw Å¿erves here, to take off dry and old Wood, which is conÅ¿equently very hard, and capable of Å¿poiling the Pruning-Knife, or elÅ¿e to take away that which is ill-plac'd, or Å¿o thick, that it cannot eaÅ¿ily, and at once be cut off with the Pruning-Knife. I Å¿ay next, that this being granted, the Pruning-Knife muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity Å¿erve to cut off, at one cut, young, lively, tender, and well-plac'd Wood, of a moderate thickneÅ¿s; Å¿o that the Pruning-Knife muÅ¿t never be us'd upon any thing that would preÅ¿ently blunt its edge, and for which the Saw is more proper than it; nor likewiÅ¿e employ the Saw to retrench any Branches, which one good cut of the Pruning-Knife may cleverly perform.

But it is not Å¿ufficient to be agreed upon the NeceÅ¿Å¿ity and UÅ¿e of theÅ¿e two Tools, for the different OccaÅ¿ions in which they are employ'd; perhaps it will not be uÅ¿eleÅ¿s beÅ¿ides that, to make the deÅ¿cription both of the one and the other. I begin by the Figure of the Pruning-Knives which I uÅ¿e, and which I look upon as the moÅ¿t convenient; for they are made Å¿everal ways which I do not approve of, Å¿ome being too hooked, in reÅ¿pect to their length, and others not enough; Å¿o that in my Opinion, neither the one nor the other are near Å¿o eaÅ¿ie to work with, as thoÅ¿e which keep a medium between theÅ¿e two Figures; I have often try'd them of all kinds, and have at laÅ¿t fix'd upon theÅ¿e that are figur'd here, which perhaps are of my own Invention; at leaÅ¿t I have taken a great deal of pains to bring the Workmen to make them exactly according to the Model which I had given them, they Å¿till made them too crooked or too Å¿treight, and conÅ¿equently inconvenient; Å¿o that in this CaÅ¿e, the Figure of the Pruning-Knife is conÅ¿iderable.

However, it is not enough to have the Pruning-Knives well Å¿hap'd; beÅ¿ides that, their matter muÅ¿t be of good temper'd Steel, Å¿o that the edge may neither turn, or notch eaÅ¿ily; they muÅ¿t be well whetted, often clean'd from the filth that faÅ¿tens upon them in working, and Å¿et as often as the edge is obÅ¿erv'd not to run Å¿moothly in cutting eaÅ¿ily, in proportion to the Å¿trength apply'd to them; and beÅ¿ides, when there are many Trees to cut, 'tis fit to have many Pruning-Knives, to change them often; for without doubt, with good Tools, more work is done in one Day, and with more PleaÅ¿ure, than could be done in two or three, having but indifferent ones, and yet worÅ¿e having bad ones.

BeÅ¿ides this, the Blade of theÅ¿e Pruning-Knives muÅ¿t be of a moderate length, that is, but about two Inches to the part where the bending of the back begins, and afterwards, the whole hooked part to the extremity of the point, muÅ¿t have two Inches more, inÅ¿omuch, that the extent of the outÅ¿ide, muÅ¿t not have above four Inches in all; beÅ¿ides this, the Handle muÅ¿t be more Å¿quare than round, and a little rugged: Buck's-Horn is very fit for it; this Handle muÅ¿t be of a reaÅ¿onable bigneÅ¿s, Å¿o as to Å¿it the hand, and to hold it firm without turning, or Å¿lipping out of it, in putting ones Å¿trength to it; the
thickneÅ¿s of two Inches and eight Lines, or at moÅ¿t three Inches, is that which is fit for the uÅ¿e of a Man who actually Prunes all manner of Trees, that is, to cut here and there Å¿ome Å¿mall Branches: Such are fit for Gentlemen to have, to cut, as they are walking, Å¿uch Branches as they obÅ¿erve to be ill-plac'd. This is all I can Å¿ay of the Conditions of a good Pruning-Knife.

As for the Saw, in my Opinion it does not require Å¿o much ado; however its moÅ¿t commendable quality is to be Å¿treight: It muÅ¿t be of a very hard Mettal, and well temper'd; old blades of Swords are very fit for it, and the Teeth muÅ¿t be of a good diÅ¿tance, and well open'd, the one turning towards one Å¿ide, the other on the 'tother, and the back muÅ¿t be very thin, or at leaÅ¿t not Å¿o thick nor Å¿o Å¿ubÅ¿tantial as the Teeth; otherwiÅ¿e the Saw will not move eaÅ¿ily, becauÅ¿e the Teeth will Å¿oon be fill'd up, Å¿o that it will Å¿oon tire him that uÅ¿es it, and make the Work advance but little.

It is not neceÅ¿Å¿ary that the Saws for the common uÅ¿e of Pruning Å¿hou'd be broad, half an Inch in breadth will Å¿uffice, they muÅ¿t not be very long neither, five or Å¿ix Inches in length will do; and as for the handle it may be round; Å¿ince it is to be puÅ¿h'd in a Å¿treight Line before one, that Å¿o its turning in the hand need not be fear'd, as a Pruning-Knife with a Round Handle wou'd do. It will be thick enough, provided in that part where it is thickeÅ¿t, which is the Extremity, where the point of the Blade meets when it Å¿huts, it has about two Inches, and Å¿even or eight Lines Circumference; and on the other Extremity, Å¿omewhat leÅ¿s than two Inches; and thus one Å¿hall have folding-Saws, which may be carry'd in the Pocket as eaÅ¿ily as the Pruning-Knives, the Blade cloÅ¿ing into the Handle, which will be very Convenient, and very NeceÅ¿Å¿ary for a Gard'ner.

I do think it a very great matter to have good Tools, but that is not enough, there is Å¿ome Skill requir'd to uÅ¿e them well, either for the expedition of BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s, or to avoid Å¿ome Accidents. This is a PrentiÅ¿hip which generally coÅ¿ts Å¿ome blood to thoÅ¿e who begin to work, without having had good Directions. There are Å¿ome neceÅ¿Å¿ary Precautions relating to the manner of placing the whole Body well, and particularly of placing the left hand well, without which, a Learner is in great danger of hurting himÅ¿elf; therefore I think it very proper to InÅ¿truct him in it at firÅ¿t.

To that end, I Å¿ay, firÅ¿t, that the PerÅ¿on muÅ¿t be diÅ¿pos'd and planted near his Tree, in Å¿uch a manner as to Å¿tand firm, Å¿o as to be able with eaÅ¿e to make uÅ¿e of his InÅ¿truments with his full Strength and Vigour: In the Å¿econd place, he muÅ¿t hold his Tools as firm as can be, that they may not turn in his hand: And, in the third place, as to his Pruning-Knife, he muÅ¿t always begin his Pruning, that is, to Cut, on that Å¿ide which is oppoÅ¿ite to the Eye, or the Branch upon which he cuts, which muÅ¿t after that make the extremity of the Branch which is cut: And in fine, whether he cuts to the Right, which is towards home, and is the moÅ¿t common; or whether he cuts with a back hand, as it is often neceÅ¿Å¿ary; and proper to be done, he muÅ¿t Å¿till take care, and uÅ¿e the precaution of putting his left hand underneath, and cloÅ¿e to the place which is to be cut, there to remain as it were fix'd, and to hold the part he graÅ¿ps Å¿o Å¿teady that it may not Å¿tir or move in the leaÅ¿t; and Å¿o conÅ¿equently reÅ¿iÅ¿t the force of the Right hand in cutting; otherwiÅ¿e if the left hand Å¿hould quit its hold, the Pruning-Knife would no doubt meet with it, and wound it dangerouÅ¿ly.

BeÅ¿ides this, that Right hand muÅ¿t be us'd, not only to hold the Pruning-Knife Å¿o, that the edge may be mov'd Flat-wiÅ¿e, and Horizontally, but alÅ¿o uÅ¿e it to Å¿top Å¿hort after the effort it has exerted in cutting, that you may cut nothing but the Branch or Root that you intend to Cut, without touching any of the Neighbouring ones, which muÅ¿t Å¿o carefully be preÅ¿erv'd, as neither to be any wiÅ¿e Cut, or Wounded; and therefore before you come to preÅ¿ent the Pruning-Knife, you muÅ¿t rightly obÅ¿erve the Situation of the Neighbouring Branches, and partly conÅ¿ider, not only how the hand muÅ¿t go in Cutting, for that hand in moving muÅ¿t give a certain turn to the Pruning-Knife, that the Point may meet with nothing; but you muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e feel how far the force you muÅ¿t uÅ¿e to carry off at once the part you deÅ¿ign to remove may carry you, leÅ¿t the Pruning-Knife in its way might harm Å¿ome of the Neighbouring Branches; and this we call Cutting Dry, as it muÅ¿t be done to Prune well, that is to Cut cleverly; Å¿o that if it be a Branch, the Cut may be in Å¿ome manner round, and flat; at leaÅ¿t it muÅ¿t in no wiÅ¿e be long, as Unskilful People do it; and if it happen to be made long-wiÅ¿e, you muÅ¿t make uÅ¿e of your Pruning-Knife again, to take away that Deformity; noting however, that it muÅ¿t be done in a different manner from Roots, which muÅ¿t be cut abÅ¿olutely like the Foot of a Hind, that is Å¿omewhat long-wiÅ¿e: We have given a ReaÅ¿on for it in the Chapter of Plantations.

When by a frequent ExerciÅ¿e, or habit of Pruning, a Man is become handy, and bold in Cutting, he may very well, eÅ¿pecially in the CaÅ¿e of certain green Branches, thick enough to be taken away, I Å¿ay he may very well place his left hand above the right, to
graÅ¿p, and gently bend Å¿uch Branches in drawing them towards him; and by that means, Å¿uch Branches will really prove more eaÅ¿ie to be Cut; in Å¿o much that a Man will often be Å¿urpriz'd to find Å¿o great a Branch Å¿o eaÅ¿ily cut off at one Å¿troak; but then this Left Hand muÅ¿t be at Å¿uch a diÅ¿tance from the Right, that the great Å¿trength he muÅ¿t uÅ¿e to cut at once the Branch in queÅ¿tion, may not carry it as far as that Left Hand; and it is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to obÅ¿erve, that as in Cutting, the Right hand moves towards the Left, Å¿o that likewiÅ¿e Å¿hould move away from it, in carrying off, as I may call it, the Booty which the Right Hand has newly prepar'd for it; or otherwiÅ¿e, as we have already Å¿aid, that Left Hand wou'd run a great hazard of receiving a dangerous wound, which happens but too often.

Let us Å¿ay moreover, that in order to Cut well, every Branch muÅ¿t be within reach of him that Cuts it; in Å¿o much that he may be able to Cut it without Å¿training himÅ¿elf; that is, that Å¿uch a Branch Å¿hou'd reach up to the Å¿tomach of the Gard'ner: If it be much lower, he muÅ¿t be forc'd to Å¿toop Å¿o as to put one knee to the ground, if it be needful; and if that Branch be too high, he muÅ¿t get upon Å¿omething, either a Ladder, or Steps, to the end that he may Cut it with eaÅ¿e, and without Å¿training himÅ¿elf; for he would run a great bazard of hurting himÅ¿elf, or of Å¿plitting the Branch in cutting it downwards: It is not Å¿o dangerous to cut upwards; provided, as I have Å¿aid, the Left Hand be below the Right.

I may Å¿ay by the by, that Vine-Leaves are a Natural Balm to Å¿top the Blood of the Wounds a Man receives in Pruning, they take away the Pain, and cloÅ¿e up the Wound in a very little time. The tendereÅ¿t Leaves are commonly the beÅ¿t, and for want of green Leaves, the old ones may Å¿erve: I have formerly Experienc'd that Remedy, and often upon my Å¿elf; and have always found Å¿o much benefit by it, that I willingly adviÅ¿e our New VirtuoÅ¿o's to uÅ¿e it upon occaÅ¿ion.

As for the Saw, thoÅ¿e that are to uÅ¿e it, muÅ¿t, contrary to what is done with the Pruning-Knife, as much as poÅ¿Å¿ibly can be, place the Left Hand above the Right, and lean hard upon the part which is to be Saw'd, to hinder it from Å¿tirring; otherwiÅ¿e the Saw would not play well. That done, they muÅ¿t hold the handle of the Saw in Å¿uch a manner that the But-end may not reach above the middle of the Palm of the Hand, and juÅ¿t underneath the Thumb, where it muÅ¿t in Å¿ome manner be Å¿tay'd, or Å¿upported, to move the Saw the better; in order to which, it is likewiÅ¿e proper that the Fore-Finger Å¿hould be Å¿tretch'd along the Handle, as far as the edge of the Blade, to conduct the motion of the Saw the Å¿treighter; and to that end, is requir'd, in the firÅ¿t place, a conÅ¿iderable application of the Mind to what is to be Saw'd, without the leaÅ¿t diÅ¿traction by any thing; and at the Å¿ame time, the Saw muÅ¿t be manag'd with an extream quickneÅ¿s and Vigour; for working Å¿lowly, or thinking upon any thing elÅ¿e, the Work wou'd not Å¿ucceed well, and the Saw would often bend, or break: You muÅ¿t not Saw quite through, but Å¿top juÅ¿t cloÅ¿e to the laÅ¿t Bark, otherwiÅ¿e you might be in danger of tearing the Bark from off the remaining Branch, and conÅ¿equently peel it dangerouÅ¿ly; Å¿o that the Pruning-Knife muÅ¿t always end the work of the Saw, both to cut off clean what has not been made an end of Sawing, and to Å¿mooth the part that has been Saw'd; that is, to cut off all that remains rough from the Action of Sawing, Å¿ince otherwiÅ¿e it would hardly recover, the Saw having in Å¿ome manner burnt the part Å¿o Saw'd.

There are likewiÅ¿e certain OccaÅ¿ions, in which the Left Hand, by gently bending the Branch to be Saw'd, makes the Saw play the better; and Å¿ooner, and more neatly finiÅ¿hes the Work: But you muÅ¿t be very exact in the Å¿trength you uÅ¿e, or apply in bending, leÅ¿t you Å¿hould make a dangerous Slit in the part that is to remain. This is what I had to Å¿ay, as to our Tools; let us now proceed to the application of the uÅ¿e that is to be made of them.
