div.p:
A Fruit-Tree of what kind Å¿oever, Pear-Tree, Apple-Tree, Plumb-Tree, Peach-Tree, &c. which Å¿eem'd to promiÅ¿e all the good and neceÅ¿Å¿ary Qualifications requir'd in order to be Planted, and has actually been Planted with all the Skill and ConÅ¿ideration which we have heretofore explain'd in the Chapter of Plantations: This Fruit-Tree, I Å¿ay, from the Month of March, until the Months of September and October following, will of neceÅ¿Å¿ity perform one of theÅ¿e four Things; either it will not Shoot at all, or little, or it will Shoot
reaÅ¿onably; that is, at leaÅ¿t One Fine Branch, or elÅ¿e it will Shoot much, that is, Two or Three Fine Branches, and perhaps more, as it appears by the Figures. We muÅ¿t exactly Explain what is to be done, in theÅ¿e Four Particulars.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

argument.p: Of the firÅ¿t Pruning of a Tree that has not Sprouted at all the firÅ¿t Year.

div.p: AS to the firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, in which we Å¿uppoÅ¿e the Tree to have Å¿hot forth nothing the firÅ¿t Year, perhaps it may be dead, and appears viÅ¿ibly Å¿o; and perhaps it is really dead, tho' it does not Å¿eem to be Å¿o, by reaÅ¿on of a little Green which the Pruning-Knife diÅ¿covers under the Bark; for without doubt it may Å¿eem alive at the Head, and yet be dead at the Root, and that is likewiÅ¿e call'd being quite dead, without however appearing Å¿o outwardly; or elÅ¿e it may Å¿eem dead, either becauÅ¿e it has produc'd nothing, or perhaps becauÅ¿e part of the Stem is really dead, tho' it be no wiÅ¿e dead in the Principal Place, which is the Place of the Principle of Life, and of the thick Roots, on which depends the whole Spring of Vegetation

When the Tree is dead on all Å¿ides, it is eaÅ¿ily known by the dryneÅ¿s, or blackneÅ¿s either of the whole Stem, or a main part of it; eÅ¿pecially if that blackneÅ¿s appears about the Graff; in which CaÅ¿e it is neither difficult of giving, nor of receiving good Advice; that is, Å¿uch a Tree muÅ¿t be remov'd as Å¿oon as you are convinc'd of its being Dead, but ever with an intention of putting another in the room of it, at the firÅ¿t moderate Shower of Rain: Provided the death of Å¿uch a Tree be perceiv'd in the Month of May, or at the beginning of June, 'till which time you may plant others in the room of it; but it is not Å¿o Å¿afe to be done during the reÅ¿t of the Summer.

This Re-implacement Å¿ufficiently Å¿hews, that I deÅ¿ign it Å¿hould be done by means of thoÅ¿e Trees which are brought up in Baskets; if, as I have Å¿o much exhorted People to do, the Curious have taken care to raiÅ¿e Å¿ome in that manner, not only in the firÅ¿t year of their Planting, but likewiÅ¿e all the following years; to the end that this firÅ¿t year, and even at all times they may have the Å¿atisfaction of Å¿eeing their Garden perfectly Stock'd: Without doubt Å¿uch Basket Trees in the Months of July and AuguÅ¿t would have Å¿hot their Roots beyond the Baskets, in caÅ¿e they had taken Å¿o well, as to produce very fine Shoots, which are the only ones you muÅ¿t re-implace, but it is very dangerous to take them out, to TranÅ¿port or Plant them in the Summer, when their Roots are thus Å¿hot out; for they either break in removing, or as their Extremities are White, they eaÅ¿ily blacken in a hot Air, and conÅ¿equently periÅ¿h; and cauÅ¿e the Tree to pine long, and even often kills it.

But if you do not uÅ¿e Baskets in the Months of May and June, you muÅ¿t Å¿tay until the return of the next SeaÅ¿on of Planting, which is from November, to the middle of March, and then they may be us'd; or having none, you muÅ¿t Re-plant a new Tree well qualify'd, in the Room of that which is dead.

In the mean time we muÅ¿t carefully examine how we happen'd to be deceiv'd in that Tree, in which we had obÅ¿erv'd all the appearances of a better fortune; Å¿ince without that it Å¿hould not have been Planted, to the end that if it be poÅ¿Å¿ible to diÅ¿cover or avoid the Inconveniencies that have kill'd it, we may endeavour to remedy it for the future.

For Example, it may be the great Cold during the Winter, which happens but Å¿eldom, FunduÅ¿que mendax Arbore nunc aquas culpante, nunc torrente agros Sidera. Horatius or elÅ¿e the great Heat during the Summer, which may happen: Then Å¿ince great Colds, and great Heats are capable of Å¿poiling and ruining the Roots of a Tree, the beÅ¿t way to prevent it is, to cover the Foot of that which is newly Planted with Å¿omething, for it is an ill Expedient to Plant it deeper than I have Å¿aid in the TreatiÅ¿e of Plantations, pretending thereby to preÅ¿erve the Roots from the Cold or Heat: It is better then to Plant it according to our Rules, and take care in the Summer to cover the Foot with Fearn, or dry Dung, or elÅ¿e new drawn Weeds, &c.

If the Tree be dead only for want of watering, the new one muÅ¿t be water'd; if for Nec Å¿en'ire Å¿itim patitur, bibulaeque recurvas radicis fibras labentibus i â¢ rigat undit. Ovid. want of good Mould, you muÅ¿t put Å¿ome freÅ¿h there; if it proceed from having been too often and maliciouÅ¿ly Å¿haken or looÅ¿en'd at the time of the firÅ¿t Sprouting, it muÅ¿t be prevented, by putting Å¿ome fence before it, or not Å¿uffering the unlucky Wags that have done it, to come near it.

If it proceeds from having been Planted too low, or in too moiÅ¿t a Ground, the Vim tamen agreÅ¿tum metuens pomaria claudit, Intus & acceÅ¿Å¿us prohibet. Idem. Juniperi gravis umbra, nocent & frugibus umbrae. Virgil. 10 Ecl. Hortus nullas amat umbras praeter umbrar â¢ domini. CreÅ¿entius. other muÅ¿t be Planted a little higher, or elÅ¿e the Ground rais'd to enable it to drain it Å¿elf.

If it preceeds from having been under the Å¿hade of other Trees, or in the Neighbour-hood of Å¿ome Wood or PalliÅ¿ades, which by an Infinity of Roots exhauÅ¿t all the Ground about them; you muÅ¿t reÅ¿olve to remove either thoÅ¿e Trees that make the Shade, or thoÅ¿e that waÅ¿te the Ground Å¿o much; and before you Re-plant any thing in their room, you muÅ¿t remove all the Earth that is worn out, to put better in the room of it, without imagining to better it with Dung, or elÅ¿e reÅ¿olve to Plant no more Fruit-Trees in that unhappy Place.

If, in fine, Å¿ome Moles have rais'd and Å¿haken them, you muÅ¿t endeavour to catch them; if the Worms have gnaw'd them, they muÅ¿t be look'd for, and deÅ¿troy'd; tho' as we have already Å¿aid elÅ¿ewhere, it be of all the Evils that may afflict Plantations the greateÅ¿t, moÅ¿t dangerous, and moÅ¿t incurable: All the Comfort that can be had in this is, That it is a kind of Torrent that muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity have its CourÅ¿e, but paÅ¿Å¿es, and does not return often; and this is what I have to Å¿ay as to a Tree which is, and actually appears dead the firÅ¿t year of its being Planted.

If the Tree remain green in the whole Stem, or at leaÅ¿t in a great part of it, without having produc'd any thing, and that perhaps it be only a kind of Lethargy, which has in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure benum'd the Vegetative Faculty, as it happens to Å¿ome Orange-Trees newly Planted, which remain Å¿ometimes two, three, or four years without coming to any thing, and yet at laÅ¿t perform Wonders. 'Tis Å¿trange and difficult to apprehend, that the Principle of Life of thoÅ¿e kind of Trees, which in effect are Å¿o eaÅ¿ie to take, and yet are Å¿o hard to dye, Å¿hou'd not withÅ¿tanding be Å¿o difficult to be mov'd to begin Å¿ome Roots: But this is not the Point in queÅ¿tion here; our Fruit-Trees are not Å¿o long without Å¿hewing the certainty of their Life or Death.

In caÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, this Fruit-Tree has preÅ¿erv'd its greenneÅ¿s all the Summer, without producing any Shoots; it may perhaps give Å¿ome hope of Å¿atisfaction for the time to come, but indeed that hope is very Å¿light; and if it may be done conveniently, the Å¿ureÅ¿t way is to replant as Å¿oon as can be another new one, that appears better, or at leaÅ¿t equally good in the room of it; but if no other can be had, I am Å¿till of Opinion that it will be proper in the Month of November to Å¿earch round about that Å¿uÅ¿picious Foot, to Å¿ee whether there appears any good beginning of thick Roots, or none at all.

In the FirÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, that is, if any good Signs be diÅ¿cover'd, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting in the beginning or growing of Å¿ome thick Roots, which is very extraordinary; for as Å¿oon as any new Roots grow in Summer, new Shoots appear at the Å¿ame time: If then, I Å¿ay, any beginning of thick Roots be diÅ¿cover'd, which perhaps only began to form themÅ¿elves Å¿ince the end of Summer, you muÅ¿t reÅ¿t there, without doing any thing more, and only cover the Place well again where you have open'd the Ground; and beÅ¿ides, the following Summer take Å¿ome extraordinary Carefrom time to time to Water it, if the Ground and the SeaÅ¿on Å¿eem to requireit: Such a Tree may very well make up the time it has loÅ¿t, and become fine the following years.

In the Second CaÅ¿e, that is when the Tree has perform'd nothing by its Root, it muÅ¿t be wholly taken out of the Ground, and Prun'd again, that is, according to the Term of a Gard'ner, all its Roots muÅ¿t be refreÅ¿h'd, doing the Å¿ame to the Head, of which the Extremity may perhaps be dead; and in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e it muÅ¿t be refreÅ¿h'd as far as the quick, and then the Tree may be re-planted at that very time, and in the Å¿ame place, if it be judg'd worth it, having preÅ¿erv'd its Roots Å¿ound and entire, or you muÅ¿t fling it quite away, if the principal Roots be defective, either in being dry, or black, or being actually rotten, or gnaw'd, as it happens Å¿ometimes, for in that CaÅ¿e no good can be expected from them: The CaÅ¿e is different, when there are only Å¿ome Å¿mall Roots tainted, tho' it be not a good Sign: but however, in that CaÅ¿e it wou'd be Å¿ufficient to Cut them again to the quick, and Re-plant the Tree in the Å¿ame place where it has given CauÅ¿e to believe its DeÅ¿tiny doubtful: I have pretty often Re-planted Å¿uch Trees in NurÅ¿eries, where they have thriven Å¿o well, that Å¿ome years after I have Å¿ucceÅ¿sfully given them Å¿ome of the Chief Places of the Garden, and yet I had Planted very good new Trees in the Places where thoÅ¿e could not thrive: It is very difficult to have perfect Plantations without all thoÅ¿e neceÅ¿Å¿ary ConÅ¿iderations.

The CoolneÅ¿s of a moiÅ¿t Ground is Å¿ometimes Å¿ufficient to preÅ¿erve for a year, or more, uncertain Å¿igns of Life, both in the Roots and Stem of a Tree, as well as it preÅ¿erves it in Cut Branches, and yet without any certainty of their performing afterwards any happy Operation; that is, to Operate in the Å¿ame manner as well qualify'd Trees uÅ¿e to do; therefore
it is fit to be very nice upon thoÅ¿e kind of appearances of Life, by which Å¿o many People Å¿uffer themÅ¿elves to be amuz'd and deceiv'd for Å¿o many Years. This is, what I had to Å¿ay upon thoÅ¿e appearances of Life, whether Good and Certain, or Ill and Doubtful.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

argument.p: Of the firÅ¿t Pruning of a Tree that has Å¿prouted weakly.

div.p: I paÅ¿s now to the Å¿econd Article of a Tree newly Planted, which is to Å¿prout but little, Vix unquam ãâã Å¿urculus proficit niÅ¿i primo anno valdÃ¨ proficiat. CreÅ¿centius. eÅ¿pecially if the Shoot be weak, Å¿mall, and yellowiÅ¿h, and Å¿ometimes accompany'd with Å¿ome Fruit-Buds.

Upon which I declare, that I have but little more value for that Tree, than for the Preceeding, which we have juÅ¿t examin'd, and found it either quite Dead, as well in the Roots, as in the Stem, or only dead as to the Roots, tho' it appear'd green at the Bark; or elÅ¿e have found it to have yet Å¿ome Å¿mall Å¿igns of Life in the Roots, as well as in the Stem; both theÅ¿e, and the others, having Å¿till preÅ¿erv'd Å¿ome Å¿igns of Life; that is, Å¿ome green, and a little Sap. Therefore when I am furniÅ¿h'd with good Trees, I never fail rejecting this, altho' it has Å¿prouted a little, as well as the preceeding which has not Å¿prouted at all: But when I find my Å¿elf in want, or unprovided, I am contented with cutting theÅ¿e little Shoots cloÅ¿e to the Stem, Å¿hortning that above by the half; and beÅ¿ides, I never fail to Å¿earch the Foot; and if I find that the Roots have Shot nothing, as it happens Å¿ometime, I pluck up the Tree quite, and refreÅ¿h the Roots, to Å¿ee if they are all Å¿ound; which being Å¿o, I plant them again, or elÅ¿e Å¿ome of the Principals being Å¿poil'd, I fling it away.

If in order to Replant Å¿uch a Tree, I fear the Earth be not good enough, I put better in the room of it, this is the only good expedient to be us'd; the help of Dung being too uncertain and deceitful to rely upon it: In fine, I do the Å¿ame thing to this Tree, as I do either to that, which did nothing, but remain'd Green both at the Head and Roots, which we Prun'd anew every where, and afterwards Replanted, either in the Garden, or in the NurÅ¿ery; or elÅ¿e like the other, whoÅ¿e Head is really in a pretty good Condition, that is Green, but yet has its principal Roots entirely Å¿poil'd, which, upon that account, we have rejected as dead therefore I ev'n look for a new Tree, to put in the room of that, which, as it were, only Å¿eem'd to Sprout, Å¿uch little Shoots being properly but falÅ¿e marks of its having taken new Root, they being only produc'd by the effect of Rarefaction, and without the help of the Roots, as I explain elÅ¿ewhere.

That pitiful Fruit-Bud, which appears upon the languiÅ¿hing Head of that Tree newly Planted, far from producing in me the effect it operates upon Å¿o many PhiloÅ¿ophers; that is, from raiÅ¿ing any Joy in me, or giving me the leaÅ¿t ConÅ¿ideration, either for the Father that has brought it to light, or for the Action by which it is produc'd, creates in me on the contrary, a real Å¿corn for both; which confirming me in the Maxims I have advanc'd, to prove that Fruits are only marks of weakneÅ¿s, puts me upon the reÅ¿olution of forÅ¿aking that Tree, and to fling it away like a piece of dead or uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Wood: This I do not only to low Trees, that are to make Dwarfs, or part of the Wall-Trees, but likewiÅ¿e to Standards, both the one and the other being a-like, in reÅ¿pect to their taking new Root.

I will Å¿ay here by the by, that this deÅ¿picable Bud, which I think I may call a Bud of Poverty, has rais'd a War between Å¿ome PhiloÅ¿ophers and I, becauÅ¿e I will not grant them, that the Production of it is a Å¿ign of Vigour in the Tree, as commonly the Generation of Animals, is a mark of it in the Fathers.

I explain this matter more at large in my Reflections, not having thought it proper to proceed any further here upon the ReaÅ¿onings I have had cauÅ¿e to make upon it, conformably to a thouÅ¿and irreproachable Experiences.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.

argument.p: Of the firÅ¿t Pruning of a Tree, that has at leaÅ¿t produc'd one fine Branch.

div.p: WE muÅ¿t now proceed to the Third Article, which relates to our low Trees, newly Planted, either for a Dwarf, or Wall-Tree, and declare what we are to do if they Sprout reaÅ¿onably; that is, at leaÅ¿t one Beautiful, and Å¿ufficiently thick Branch, which is commonly attended with Å¿ome weak ones.
In that caÅ¿e, we are to make Three particular ConÅ¿iderations, viz. Whether that fine Branch proceeds from the extremity of the Stem, the middle, or the lower part.

If altogether from the extremity, out of the fear of falling into the inconvenience I dread, which is a defect for a Dwarf, that is, its growing too high in the Stem, into which inconvenience I Å¿hould undoubtedly fall; if I perform'd my Pruning upon that new Shoot, I rather reÅ¿olve to Å¿horten the Stem of that young Tree about an Inch or two, and Å¿o put it back to the A. B. C. Being certain, that round the extremity where I Å¿hall lower it, it will produce fine new Branches, all well plac'd, and in a Å¿ufficient Number; and this is grounded upon that fine Shoot it has produc'd, which convinces me fully, that it has Å¿hot forth good Roots.

Thus in putting back perhaps the PleaÅ¿ure of a Year, becauÅ¿e I run the hazard of having my Fruit Å¿omewhat later; I avoid the diÅ¿Å¿atisfaction of having a Tree riÅ¿e too high, as it would do, if I permitted it wholly to Shoot out of that Branch, which would offend me perpetually, whereas in taking it a little lower, I put it in a way of appearing with all the advantage that can be deÅ¿ir'd in a well order'd Tree; and conÅ¿equently I put it in a condition of rewarding me yet better, as well by a fine Figure, as by the pleaÅ¿ure of abundance of Fruit.

But if the fine Branch Å¿hoot out of the middle of the Stem, you muÅ¿t without heÅ¿itation cut down the Stem to that Branch, and even Å¿horten that Branch within the compaÅ¿s of four or five Eyes at moÅ¿t, therein to place the whole foundation, and all the hope of a Beautiful figure in your Tree; it being certain, that at the place where you have Å¿horten'd it, it will produce in the Å¿econd Year at leaÅ¿t two fine Branches, oppoÅ¿ite to each other: This is Å¿ufficient to make a fine Tree, for thoÅ¿e who know how to order it well; but if that Å¿horten'd Branch Å¿hoots forth three or four, as it happens pretty often, the Å¿ucceÅ¿s will Å¿till be the more favourable, eaÅ¿ie, and agreeable.

I Å¿uppoÅ¿e Å¿till, that the Gard'ners who are any thing careful, will have taken care to order that only Branch we Å¿peak of, in Å¿uch a manner, that it may be very upright, in order to form a Å¿treight Tree upon its Center, as it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary it Å¿hould be.

If they have been wanting as to that Precaution, they muÅ¿t have recourÅ¿e to the grand Remedy, which is, to Å¿horten that Branch within the compaÅ¿s of two or three Eyes, which rough Treatment had not been neceÅ¿Å¿ary, had it been well rear'd up from the beginning.

In Pruning that Branch, which is come here by its Å¿elf, one may Å¿till preÅ¿erve, not the very Å¿mall Branches which I call SappleÅ¿s, and muÅ¿t be utterly exterminated from our new planted Tree; but only Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e that are either Å¿hort, or paÅ¿Å¿ably thick, or longiÅ¿h, and likewiÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ably thick, in whatever place either of them may be; provided they have pretty good Eyes, and are well plac'd, we may Å¿ecurely expect to have Å¿oon Fruit upon them, without fearing it might prejudice the vigour of our Tree, eÅ¿pecially in Å¿tone Fruit, and even in Kernel Fruit, taking care however to Å¿horten thoÅ¿e Branches a little, which are really too long, without medling with the others that are Å¿hort and paÅ¿Å¿ably thick.

The ReaÅ¿on why I do not hinder the preÅ¿erving of Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e weak Branches, is, that being very certain, as I have Å¿o often repeated, that it is the Å¿mall quantity of Sap which produces the Fruit, it follows from thence, that the little Sap that goes towards the making of it, cannot conÅ¿iderably prejudice our new Tree, and yet it will afford us a great deal of PleaÅ¿ure in giving us Fruit betimes.

It is not that I think it a great fault, the firÅ¿t Year, unmercifully to take away all thoÅ¿e hopes of the FirÅ¿t Fruits: The Curious may do in this as they think fit, but for my part, I preÅ¿erve them.

If our only Branch Å¿hoots out of the lower part of the Stem, we have ReaÅ¿on to rejoice at it, it is very well plac'd, provided the Gard'ner has taken care of it betimes, to keep
it upright, in caÅ¿e it were not Å¿o, as we have Å¿aid of the Preceeding: We may with aÅ¿Å¿urance Prune it the heighth we deÅ¿ire it at, to begin a Fine Tree, whether it be a Dwarf, or Wall-Tree; but if it prove not Å¿treight, or without a probability of being Å¿treightned by Å¿ome Å¿trong Ligature, it muÅ¿t be us'd like the other, that is, it muÅ¿t be Å¿horten'd quite low to make it produce another that may be Å¿treight, otherwiÅ¿e the Tree would always be a-wry, and conÅ¿equently of an ill Figure, Å¿till remembring that the Stem muÅ¿t be Å¿horten'd cloÅ¿e to the Å¿ingle Branch it has produc'd, and we have Prun'd.

I will Å¿ay here, by the by, that when we Plant a Tree, we may according to appearances, but not demonÅ¿tratively and infallibly aÅ¿Å¿ure that it will take Root: Yet leÅ¿s, in caÅ¿e it do's, can we aÅ¿Å¿ign in what part it will produce its firÅ¿t Shoot: But as for the Fine Branches produc'd by a Tree that has taken Root, which we have afterwards Prun'd, we may with Å¿ome certainty affirm, that they will produce New ones on the Extremities on them which we have Å¿horten'd, and partly gueÅ¿s at the quantity; Å¿o that this may be rely'd upon; and conÅ¿equently if our Tree has only produc'd the Å¿ingle Branch we Å¿peak of, we may with certainty expect that being Prun'd Å¿omewhat Å¿hort, it will at leaÅ¿t Å¿hoot two fine ones, capable of performing in all reÅ¿pects what we have above eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd for the beginning of the Beautiful Figure of a Tree.

I fancy then, that as to this Branch Å¿hot from the lower part of our Stem, we may partly allow it the Å¿ame length we had allow'd that Stem in Planting the Tree, that is, about Å¿even or eight Inches long, what ever place we have Planted it in, whether in Cold, or MoiÅ¿t Ground, or Hot, and Dry.

div.head: CHAP. XV.

argument.p: Of the firÅ¿t Pruning of a Tree that has produc'd more than one Fine Branch.

div.p: AS to the Fourth CaÅ¿e, in which our new Planted Tree has produc'd two Fine Branches, or three, or four, or more, with Å¿ome weak ones among them.

We are to make other great ConÅ¿iderations upon them, which will engage us into different Chapters, Viz. In the firÅ¿t place, to know whether that Plurality of Branches be produc'd to ones liking; That is, whether they grow round about Å¿ome part of the Stem, whether at the top, in the middle, or in the lower part; Å¿o that they may grow like a Branch-CandleÅ¿tick, for a Dwarf, or like a Hand Å¿pread open for a Wall-Tree.
To know, in the Å¿econd place, whether all thoÅ¿e Branches are grown on one Å¿ide, and all over one another.

Or whether in Degrees at a great diÅ¿tance from each other, tho' round about the Stem, or if Å¿ometimes they are all grown from one and the Å¿ame Eye, and likewiÅ¿e whether it be on the top, middle, or lower part of the Stem.
LaÅ¿tly, to know whether all thoÅ¿e Branches of themÅ¿elves are diÅ¿pos'd to open and Å¿pread, or all of them to keep cloÅ¿e together in a confus'd manner.

TheÅ¿e are almoÅ¿t all the different ways in which the firÅ¿t Å¿hort Shoots of every Tree newly Planted form themÅ¿elves, when it is Å¿o happy as to take Root again, as it appears by the Figures hereunto annex'd.

I repeat again, that I do not ConÅ¿ider here, as any thing ConÅ¿iderable, the little Å¿mall Branches, altho' they Å¿hould be good to produce Fruit the very next year, which is often true in Stone Fruit, but Å¿eldom in Kernel Fruit: Woe to that Tree, what ever it be, which produces many of theÅ¿e, or no others; however, I will Å¿ay what is fit to be done to them, after having ended the moÅ¿t material part of my Work.

They are only the great Branches I value in this CaÅ¿e, deÅ¿iring to have a fine and good Tree; theÅ¿e, in reÅ¿pect to this, have been the firÅ¿t Object of my WiÅ¿hes, and the only ones that can Å¿erve for the firÅ¿t foundation of my Tree, that is, in caÅ¿e they be Naturally well plac'd, and I can give them a Pruning proper for my Intention, and for the Beauty of the Tree I am to manage.

For as the firÅ¿t Branches, tho' happy in their Original, may very well be ill order'd, and conÅ¿equently give an ill beginning to a Tree, being handled by an Unskilful Hand; Å¿o likewiÅ¿e tho' thoÅ¿e firrÅ¿t Branches, at their firÅ¿t Sprouting, might happen to be found in a defective Situation, may very well with a little time, and good diÅ¿cipline be, as I have Å¿aid, Å¿o Skilfully turn'd, that the defect of their Birth may not hinder them from being Mothers to a Well-Å¿hap'd, and Sightly Tree.

figure.head: The different situations of the firÅ¿t Branches sometimes made by a Tree new planted Dwarfs

div.p: The firÅ¿t Caution I am to give here, is, that commonly all the thick Branches which grow the firÅ¿t year upon new Trees, are thoÅ¿e we call Branches of falÅ¿e Wood, their Eyes diÅ¿cover it; and therefore muÅ¿t be Treated accordingly by Pruning, and even the weak and Å¿lender ones are commonly in that reÅ¿pect of the Å¿ame Form with the thick ones, unleÅ¿s they did remain very Å¿hort.

The Å¿econd AdvertiÅ¿ement, is, that the firÅ¿t Pruning I perform upon the thick Branches of New Dwarfs, differs but little from that I uÅ¿e the firÅ¿t year upon New Wall-Trees: It is true, that in theÅ¿e I eaÅ¿ily conÅ¿train the moÅ¿t obÅ¿tinate Branches, that is the worÅ¿t grown, to put themÅ¿elves into the PoÅ¿ture I deÅ¿ire, to attain the Beauty requir'd in a Wali-Tree; it Å¿erves likewiÅ¿e to afford me more Fruit, and finer; it is likewiÅ¿e true, that Dwarfs are, if that ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion may be us'd, a kind of half Volunteers, which indeed do part of what they have a mind to themÅ¿elves; but yet commonly Å¿uffer themÅ¿elves at the Å¿ame time, to be conducted by my InduÅ¿try, as well for the Å¿atisfaction of my Eyes, as for the delight of my Pallate: Only the Fruit-Branches can not be left Å¿o long upon Dwarfs, as upon Wall-Trees, becauÅ¿e in thoÅ¿e we have the Convenience of Tacking and Propping, which we have not in others.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.

argument.p: Of the FirÅ¿t Pruning of a Tree that has produc'd two Fine Branches, and both well Plac'd.

div.p: AS for what relates then to this Fourth CaÅ¿e, in which a Tree newly Planted has happily and vigorouÅ¿ly produc'd more than one Fine Branch, with Å¿ome weak ones among them: If, for inÅ¿tance, it has on the top of the Stem two almoÅ¿t equally Å¿trong, and well plac'd, that is one on one Å¿ide, and another on the other, nothing can hardly be deÅ¿ir'd better, it is a very fair beginning to make a Fine Tree: The only thing in queÅ¿tion is, to Å¿horten them all equally within the compaÅ¿s of five or Å¿ix Inches in length: But above all, you muÅ¿t take care that the two laÅ¿t Eyes of the Extremity of each of theÅ¿e Branches Å¿o Å¿horten'd, look on the Right, and on the Left, upon the two bare Å¿ides, to the end, that each of them producing at leaÅ¿t two new ones, theÅ¿e four may be Å¿o well plac'd, that they may be all preÅ¿erv'd; and in order to that, if it be a Dwarf, they muÅ¿t all contribute to form the thin Round which we deÅ¿ire; and if it be a Wall-Tree, to form the flat and full Round, which we likewiÅ¿e deÅ¿ign.

It would be ill Pruning, if thoÅ¿e two laÅ¿t Eyes look'd, for Example, either on the inÅ¿ide of the Dwarf to begin to fill it, or the outÅ¿ide to begin to open too much; it being firÅ¿t requir'd well to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the firÅ¿t Beauty of the Figure of that Tree, which is to open in a Round equally garniÅ¿h'd: For the Å¿ame ReaÅ¿on, in relation to the Wall-Tree, the Pruning would not be Å¿ufficiently well perform'd, unleÅ¿s it were order'd Å¿o, that the two Eyes that are to be found on the Extremities of the two Branches that are to be Å¿horten'd, Å¿hould caÅ¿t upon oppoÅ¿ite Å¿ides the New Branches they are able to produce: for it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary that thoÅ¿e very Branches Å¿hould have of themÅ¿elves, and without the leaÅ¿t violence a Natural diÅ¿poÅ¿ition to place themÅ¿elves well upon thoÅ¿e parts of the Wall that we would cover, to the end that they may all be preÅ¿erv'd; and Å¿o the firÅ¿t Vigorous Branches of that Wall-Tree have perform'd their duty, as well as the firÅ¿t Vigorous ones of the firÅ¿t Dwarf will have done theirs: However, it will Å¿till be fitting to have Å¿uch neceÅ¿Å¿ary regards both towards the one and the other, as may tend firÅ¿t, and chiefly, to a RoundneÅ¿s, which muÅ¿t be continu'd to that end, until the Round be almoÅ¿t perfect, and then we muÅ¿t begin to have two other ProÅ¿pects to dwell upon; of which, the one is, to endeavour by all poÅ¿Å¿ible means to give a reaÅ¿onable opening to that Tree, if it be a Dwarf, having already attain'd its roundneÅ¿s; and to fill it equally throughout its whole extent, if it be a Wall-Tree, likewiÅ¿e having its roundneÅ¿s; The other ProÅ¿pect is, to preÅ¿erve in both that Round which is already form'd, and muÅ¿t yearly grow in Circumference, without ever, as much as in us lies, Å¿uffering it to loÅ¿e any thing of the Beauty of its Figure.

A particular Care muÅ¿t be taken, that if one of thoÅ¿e two Branches has any advantage in thickneÅ¿s over the other, Å¿o that likely the one may well produce two other thick ones, while his Neighbour can yield but one; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, care muÅ¿t be taken, that as well the two of the thickeÅ¿t, as the Å¿ingle one of that which is not Å¿o thick, may come forth Å¿o happily, that all three together may be preÅ¿erv'd as fit and neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the CompoÅ¿ing of the Beautiful Figure in queÅ¿tion: OtherwiÅ¿e, if there Å¿hould be a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of
removing Å¿ome, becauÅ¿e ill-favouredly grown, it would prove a vexatious LoÅ¿s, both in reÅ¿pect to the Tree, and Gard'ner. It is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Å¿ay here, that if, in theÅ¿e two kind of Trees in debate, a Fruit-Branch Å¿hou'd chance to be joyn'd to the two Wood-Branches, it may be preÅ¿erv'd without any ConÅ¿equence.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.

argument.p: Of the firÅ¿t Pruning of a Tree that has only produc'd two Branches, both beautiful and thick, yet both ill-plac'd.

div.p: IF one of thoÅ¿e firÅ¿t fine Branches the Tree has produc'd, be conÅ¿iderably lower than the other, or perhaps both on the Å¿ame Å¿ide; or may be the one on one Å¿ide on the top of the Extremity, and the other quite at the bottom of the oppoÅ¿ite Å¿ide; in that CaÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, you muÅ¿t fiercely and unmercifully reÅ¿olve to preÅ¿erve but one, and chuÅ¿e the fitteÅ¿t to begin a fine Figure; and conÅ¿equently, you muÅ¿t cut off the other Å¿o cloÅ¿e, that, in all probility, it may never be able to produce any thick ones in the Å¿ame place; it being moÅ¿t certain, that if both were preÅ¿erv'd, it cou'd never form a Tree of an agreeable Figure, the Å¿ight of which wou'd continually vex you, for not having order'd it well from its Infancy. The Ignorant perhaps may imagine, that this wou'd occaÅ¿ion the loÅ¿s of a Year; but I can aÅ¿Å¿ure them of the contrary, if they will confide in me. In this CaÅ¿e then you muÅ¿t take down the Tree to the loweÅ¿t branch, if you deÅ¿ign to preÅ¿erve that, which, indeed, is the moÅ¿t proper for our DeÅ¿ign, and an infallible Means not to fear any other Branch ill-plac'd on that Å¿ide: Or, if you muÅ¿t take off the loweÅ¿t, as not being fit to contribute to the Beauty of the Tree, it muÅ¿t be cut within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown-piece; for there Å¿eldom ariÅ¿es a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of cutting a thick new Branch, being ill-plac'd Å¿o cloÅ¿e, that nothing at all may grow from it. I explain this Å¿ort of Pruning, together with that which is to be perform'd Å¿loping, more at large in the 21. Chapter.

That Pruning within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown-piece, will either produce nothing, or only weak Branches, which, far from Å¿poiling any thing, will be fit to be preÅ¿erv'd for Fruit. This way of Pruning Å¿uppoÅ¿es the Branch to be thick and vigorous; for had it been a moderate one, it muÅ¿t have been preÅ¿erv'd entire, as a Fruit-Branch; if very thin, it muÅ¿t have been cut Å¿o cloÅ¿e to the Stem, that no paÅ¿Å¿age had remain'd for any thing new; and that particularly, it being very ill-plac'd, or the Tree having but a moderate Vigour.

This CaÅ¿e of a Å¿ingle Branch, which has been preÅ¿erv'd, and muÅ¿t be prun'd, reduces it Å¿elf to another heretofore explain'd, where our Tree at firÅ¿t produc'd but one fine Branch; and conÅ¿equently, in order to the Pruning of this, you muÅ¿t follow the Method preÅ¿crib'd for the other, which is uÅ¿eleÅ¿s to repeat here.

It happens Å¿ometimes, that from one and the Å¿ame Eye of a Tree newly planted, two fair Branches may proceed, without any others from any other part. In Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, they may both be preÅ¿erv'd very well, whatever part of the Stem they are in; that is, if they are likely to Å¿erve to form a beautiful Figure, as it is poÅ¿Å¿ible, if the Vigour of the Foot, or the Care of the Gardner, have made them Å¿hoot Å¿treight upwards: But if either of them cannot Å¿erve towards that Figure, it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to take it away, and be contented with that, of which a good uÅ¿e may be made; and that muÅ¿t be order'd according to the foregoing Method upon that Subject.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.

argument.p: Of the firÅ¿t Pruning of a Tree that has produc'd three or four fine Branches, well, or ill-plac'd.

div.p: IF our Tree has produc'd three or four fine, well-plac'd Branches, or elÅ¿e three or four ill-plac'd ones, and that all on the Extremity, or a little beneath it.

In the firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es, we Å¿uppoÅ¿e that the three or four Branches are grown on the Extremity of the Stem, and in a proper place to form at firÅ¿t a fine Tree: In that CaÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, they muÅ¿t, for the firÅ¿t time, be prun'd with all the Å¿ame Regards we have explain'd
One and the Å¿ame Tree differently Prund according to the different Branches it has Shot four years one after another
for the Pruning of the two firÅ¿t which were by themÅ¿elves, and likewiÅ¿e well plac'd. In caÅ¿e theÅ¿e three or four be partly all of an equal thickneÅ¿s, they muÅ¿t all be us'd alike: If one or two of them Å¿hould be Å¿omewhat leÅ¿s in thickneÅ¿s, but Å¿till fit to be Wood-Branches, or at leaÅ¿t half Wood, and conÅ¿equently capable of contributing to the Beauty of the Figure; in that CaÅ¿e thoÅ¿e Å¿hall only be prun'd, with a proÅ¿pect of getting one only new Branch from them, taking care at the Å¿ame time to have it on that Å¿ide which Å¿hall be found the moÅ¿t empty; and to that end, they muÅ¿t be Å¿horten'd to an Eye that looks on that Å¿ide; and Care muÅ¿t be likewiÅ¿e taken, that the two laÅ¿t Eyes of the others, which are Å¿tronger, may look towards the two oppoÅ¿ite Sides, in order to begin to fill them up the more.

But if thoÅ¿e three or four fine Branches Å¿hoot out a little below the Extremity, 'tis but Å¿hortning the Stem to them, and then do what I have been Å¿aying, when the Branches did at firÅ¿t Å¿hoot out from the top of the Stem.

In the Å¿econd CaÅ¿e, where we Å¿uppoÅ¿e that the Branches produc'd, are moÅ¿t of them ill plac'd, inÅ¿omuch that they cannot all conduce towards the forming a fine Tree, and conÅ¿equently cannot all be preÅ¿erv'd, you muÅ¿t examine whether, among the three or four, there are not at leaÅ¿t two pretty well Å¿ituated; that is, the one on one Å¿ide, and the other on the other, and whether the Degrees are not too diÅ¿tant to permit you to frame upon thoÅ¿e Å¿ome Foundation for your Figure; and that being Å¿o, thoÅ¿e may very well Å¿atisfie you, cutting off the others within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown-piece, as we have heretofore eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd.

The two that are preÅ¿erv'd, muÅ¿t be Prun'd with the Å¿ame Regards heretofore explain'd for the Pruning of the two fine Branches, whether we have them by Choice, or by the good fortune of Vegetation; which having given but two, has given them in Å¿uch a Situation as could be deÅ¿ir'd; and Care muÅ¿t be taken, that theÅ¿e two being Prun'd, they may be found afterwards of an equal heighth, though of a different length, to the end that thoÅ¿e that may Å¿hoot from them may begin our Figure happily; for after that, it will be eaÅ¿ie to go on with what has been Å¿o well begun.

I do not repeat what is to be done to the good weak Branches, having, in my Opinion, Å¿ufficiently obÅ¿erv'd, that they muÅ¿t be carefully preÅ¿erv'd for Fruit, only Å¿hortning them a little on the Extremity, when they appear too weak for their length; not failing to take away the Å¿apleÅ¿s ones, whatever quantity there be of them.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.

argument.p: Of the Pruning of Trees that have produc'd to the Number of five, Å¿ix, or Å¿even fine Branches.

div.p: IN fine, our new Planted Tree may, as it happens Å¿ometimes in good Grounds, and particularly on fine Trees, that have been Planted with all neceÅ¿Å¿ary Regards, whether they be graffed upon Tree-Stocks, or upon Quince, I Å¿ay, it may have produc'd to the number of five, Å¿ix, or Å¿even fine Branches, and even more. It wou'd be a good Fortune if they Å¿hou'd be all Å¿o happily plac'd, that they might be all preÅ¿erv'd, without cauÅ¿ing any ConfuÅ¿ion, as I have met with it Å¿ometimes; by which means it is eaÅ¿ie to have Å¿oon a fine and good Tree. But as it is a Rarety to find them all well plac'd, I am of opinion, that it will be Å¿ufficient to preÅ¿erve three or four of thoÅ¿e, that a skilful Gard'ner Å¿hall judge, both by their Å¿ituation and Å¿trength, to be the fitteÅ¿t for the Execution of our DeÅ¿ign, and Å¿o Prune them, as we have explain'd in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e. This being Å¿o, he muÅ¿t wholly cut off all the others, if they happen to be higher than thoÅ¿e that are preÅ¿erv'd, eÅ¿pecially if they be thick; for if they are weak, that is, fit for Fruit-Branches, he will do well to preÅ¿erve them until they have perform'd what they are capable of doing.

In caÅ¿e then there be a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of taking away Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e higheÅ¿t that are thick, they muÅ¿t either be cut off Stump-wiÅ¿e, to amuÅ¿e a little Sap in them during two or three Years, or elÅ¿e the Stem muÅ¿t be Å¿horten'd to them that are preÅ¿erv'd; eÅ¿pecially, the Tree not being very vigorous. But if there happen to be Å¿ome thick ones lower than thoÅ¿e which we preÅ¿erve for ever, it is likewiÅ¿e convenient to preÅ¿erve thoÅ¿e low ones for a while, provided they Å¿poil nothing in the Figure; becauÅ¿e that for the Å¿pace of two or three Years, they employ a little of that Sap, the Abundance of which is prejudicial to us, both to compaÅ¿s Fruit, and to arrive at a beautiful Figure. But if Å¿uch low Branches can annoy us, then, as we have already Å¿aid, they muÅ¿t be cut within the
thickneÅ¿s of a Crown-piece, or elÅ¿e take them off cloÅ¿e, when we find but a moderate Vigour in the Foot of the Tree.

I Å¿till forewarn, that if, among the thick ones, there chance to be a great many weak ones, you muÅ¿t be contented with two or three of thoÅ¿e that are beÅ¿t plac'd, and beÅ¿t condition'd, breaking off the Extremity of the longeÅ¿t a little, and not medling with thoÅ¿e that are naturally Å¿hort, and paÅ¿Å¿ably thick; and conÅ¿equently, you muÅ¿t wholly take away the others, which would only cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion.

This, in my Opinion, is all that can be done for the firÅ¿t Pruning of Trees; I mean, for the Pruning of the firÅ¿t Branches they Å¿hall have produc'd, in the place where they have been newly Planted.

div.head: CHAP. XX.

argument.p: Of the Second Pruning, which is to be perform'd the Third Year on a New Planted Tree.

div.p: THE firÅ¿t Pruning of thoÅ¿e New Planted Trees being perform'd, and that upon the firÅ¿t Shoots they have produc'd the firÅ¿t Year of their being Planted, we now muÅ¿t Å¿hew the SucceÅ¿s it ought apparently to produce, and what Conduct is to be held the following Year for the Å¿econd Pruning; I mean, for the Pruning of the Twigs, that Å¿hall Å¿hoot from the Extremity of thoÅ¿e that have been Prun'd the Year before: And to that End, I think it will be proper to follow the Å¿ame Order I have eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd for the firÅ¿t; that is, for the Pruning of the firÅ¿t Shoots they had produc'd.
But before I come to that, let us conÅ¿ider what is to be done to the Trees which had not Å¿ucceeded well the firÅ¿t Year.

If the Fruit-Tree, which, without having produc'd any Branches the firÅ¿t Year, has been preÅ¿erve'd, in hopes that, having Å¿till been green, and conÅ¿equently alive, it might do better the Å¿econd; I Å¿ay, if that Tree does not begin betimes, that is, even in the Month of April, to Å¿hoot very vigorouÅ¿ly, it is an infallible Sign, that it will never be good for any thing; and therefore, without loÅ¿ing any more Time, it muÅ¿t be thrown away, and one of thoÅ¿e that Å¿hall have been brought up in Baskets, in order to Å¿upply Å¿uch Accidents, plac'd in the room of it.

And likewiÅ¿e, if the Tree, which having only produc'd Å¿mall Shoots in the firÅ¿t Year, has been preÅ¿erv'd, the Stem of it being only Å¿horten'd; if that Tree, I Å¿ay, does not, at the very Entrance of the Spring, begin to Å¿hoot fine new Branches, I am alÅ¿o of Opinion that it Å¿hou'd, without any heÅ¿itation, be us'd in the Å¿ame manner with the fore-going, we have now been Å¿peaking of: It wou'd be a kind of Miracle, if ever it Å¿hou'd come to a Condition of affording any Satisfaction.

But if, as it happens pretty often in the CaÅ¿e of Pear-Trees, and Å¿ometimes, but not Å¿o often, in the CaÅ¿e of Stone-Fruit; if, I Å¿ay, that Tree, thus taken down lower, has Å¿hot fine Branches at its new Extremity, as well as that, which, having Å¿hot but one at the top of the Stem, has been likewiÅ¿e taken down lower than the place of that Branch; then both the one, and the other will fall in one of the CaÅ¿es heretofore explain'd for the firÅ¿t Shooting of thoÅ¿e new-planted Trees which have happily Å¿ucceeded; and Å¿o we have nothing particular to add to the Conduct that is to be obÅ¿erv'd for them.

Let us now proceed to the Tree, which had only produc'd one fine Branch, be it either about the middle of the Stem, or at the bottom; Å¿uppoÅ¿ing always, as we have Å¿aid, that even in that firÅ¿t Year Care Å¿hall have been taken, in both CaÅ¿es, to render both theÅ¿e only Branches Å¿treight, if they were not Å¿o naturally: For, if that Care has not been taken, the Gard'ner muÅ¿t have been oblig'd, as I have Å¿aid heretofore, not only to lower the Stem to thoÅ¿e Branches, but likewiÅ¿e to Å¿horten them within the compaÅ¿s of two or three Eyes of the place whence they grew; which being granted, we muÅ¿t in this CaÅ¿e only conÅ¿ider for the firÅ¿t Pruning that which Å¿hall be perform'd upon the Branches which are to Å¿hoot from thoÅ¿e two or three Eyes of a Branch Å¿o extraordinarily Å¿horten'd: And thus this firÅ¿t Pruning will fall in one of the CaÅ¿es of the Pruning of the firÅ¿t Branches of a new-planted Tree, without any neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Å¿aying any thing more upon that Subject.

The Tree, which in the firÅ¿t Year had only produc'd one Wood-Branch, having been Prun'd upon that Branch, never fails, as we have already Å¿aid, of producing others on the Extremity of that Branch; and, for Example, will, without doubt, have Å¿hot upon
it, at leaÅ¿t, one thick one, with Å¿ome weak ones, and perhaps two or three thick ones, which is pretty uÅ¿ual, and may be more. This great Multitude does not happen commonly; but yet it happens Å¿ometimes.

If unfortunately it had only produc'd one upon it, partly of the Å¿ame thickneÅ¿s with the Mother, which may happen by Å¿ome accident befaln to the firÅ¿t Roots, then you muÅ¿t be PoÅ¿itive either in re-cutting the New one very Å¿hort, leaving it only two Eyes, or in cutting it quite off, which is yet better; in hopes that the other, which we muÅ¿t call the Old one, may Shoot forth Å¿omething more conÅ¿iderable the following year, as it may happen: For the Tree may chance to have made better Roots the third year, than it had produc'd either the firÅ¿t, or Å¿econd; and conÅ¿equently, being grown more Vigorous, it may Å¿hoot a greater quantity of Fine Branches.

But yet, to Å¿peak the Truth in Å¿uch CaÅ¿es, there is no relying upon the SucceÅ¿s of Å¿uch a Tree, which Å¿hews Å¿o little Vigour in the beginning; and therefore it is my Opinion, and I think it very material, to have recourÅ¿e to the Magazine of Trees in BaÅ¿kets, not to languiÅ¿h in vain hopes, at leaÅ¿t beyond the Å¿econd year, otherwiÅ¿e you may chance to languiÅ¿h yet longer, and always to no purpoÅ¿e, as it happens to a great many of the Curious.

And if that Å¿ingle Branch, being well Prun'd, has perform'd its duty Å¿o well, as to have produc'd at leaÅ¿t two of thoÅ¿e fine ones, which we look upon as Wood-Branches, or perhaps three or four, beÅ¿ides Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e that are fit for Fruit.

In all theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es, nothing can be done beÅ¿ides what has been Å¿aid for the Trees, which in the firÅ¿t year of their being Planted have produc'd the Å¿ame quantity of Shoots, that is, Å¿ome Fruit-Branches may be preÅ¿erv'd; but among the thick ones, only Å¿uch as may conduce towards the Beauty of the Figure, cutting off all the others without any mercy, either cloÅ¿e, or within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown-piece.

So the Å¿econd Pruning of Å¿uch a Tree muÅ¿t be perform'd upon the fine Branches that are Å¿hot from that Å¿ingle Branch, and muÅ¿t differ in nothing from the firÅ¿t that is to be perform'd upon the fine Branches, which the firÅ¿t year have been happily produc'd from the Stem of a new Planted Tree.

The Precaution of keeping upright the Å¿ingle Branch grown upon a Wall-Tree would be good, but is not Å¿o abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary as upon a Dwarf-Standard; by reaÅ¿on of the Convenience of turning almoÅ¿t at pleaÅ¿ure the Branches that Å¿hall proceed from that, after having Prun'd it: The only thing then, is to take care in their youth of faÅ¿tning them to the Right and Left, according as may be neceÅ¿Å¿ary for laying the foundation of a Beautiful Figure; and in Å¿o doing, it is eaÅ¿ie to remedy certain defects which can hardly be remedy'd in a low Standard.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.

argument.p: Of the Å¿econd Pruning of a Tree that has Produc'd two Fine Branches in the FirÅ¿t Year of its being Planted.

div.p: AS to our Tree, which in the firÅ¿t Year has produc'd two Fine Well-plac'd Branches, we muÅ¿t Å¿uppoÅ¿e, and it is generally very certain, that both the one and the other having been Prun'd within the compaÅ¿s of four, five, or Å¿ix Inches, or thereabouts, with all the Caution heretofore obÅ¿erv'd, both as to their thickneÅ¿s and Original, as well as the Å¿ituation of the laÅ¿t Eyes that have been left at their Extremities; I Å¿ay, it muÅ¿t be Å¿uppos'd, that both theÅ¿e Branches Å¿hall each of them have produc'd at their Extremities, at leaÅ¿t two fine Å¿trong ones, both well plac'd, beÅ¿ides Å¿ome Å¿mall ones that Å¿hall be grown either beneath, or above them.
ThoÅ¿e two fine Branches, newly grown, fill up the two Å¿ides agreeably, which (to advance the perfection of the round Figure) Å¿tood in need of that help.

And if one of theÅ¿e two firÅ¿t, or even both had produc'd each of them above two, either according to the order of Nature, or againÅ¿t it; we muÅ¿t without doubt reÅ¿olve to cut off cloÅ¿e thoÅ¿e among theÅ¿e new-commers, which, in what Situation Å¿oever, are not favourably enough plac'd to conduce to our DeÅ¿ign; and therefore if they prove higher than thoÅ¿e which we preÅ¿erve, in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, if the Tree be but moderately Vigorous, you muÅ¿t take it down to theÅ¿e, to Å¿trengthen it the more: But if it be very Vigorous, thoÅ¿e higheÅ¿t may be cut Å¿quare, within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown-Piece, from the place where they iÅ¿Å¿ue; and likewiÅ¿e if thoÅ¿e unhappy Branches prove lower than thoÅ¿e
that are preÅ¿erv'd, and in a Å¿ituation inclining on the inÅ¿ide of the Tree, they muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be taken away, but no otherwiÅ¿e than in the manner I have juÅ¿t expreÅ¿s'd, which I call Pruning within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown Piece, as it appears by the Figure.

This Pruning perform'd within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown, often Å¿erves to give us the following year a Å¿mall Branch or two, which proceed from the Å¿ides of that thickneÅ¿s, and are commonly very good for Fruit; it happens likewiÅ¿e then, that as the Sap finds it Å¿elf Å¿topt thus at the Overture of the Branch in queÅ¿tion, and as it muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity move forwards, it not being able to return back, being puÅ¿h'd and preÅ¿s'd by Å¿ome other that follows it cloÅ¿e, to make it go out at the top; I Å¿ay it happens then, that this firÅ¿t Sap enters Å¿ometimes, or the greateÅ¿t part of it, into the Å¿uperiour Branch, which is neareÅ¿t to that thickneÅ¿s, and which, however, had already a Portion Å¿uitable to its thickneÅ¿s.

If it cannot enter altogether in it, as it happens pretty often, the remainder of it is divided, and burÅ¿ts out, as we have Å¿aid, upon the Å¿ides of that Å¿mall thickneÅ¿s, and furniÅ¿hes us with Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e good little Branches which vve deÅ¿ire, as it appears by the Figure.

Sometimes vve may alÅ¿o take avvay thoÅ¿e vvretched Branches Å¿lopingly, that is, cut them in Å¿uch a manner, that on the inÅ¿ide of the Tree there may not remain the leaÅ¿t part, and on the outÅ¿ide enough for Å¿ome Nevv Branches to Å¿hoot out of it, as it appears likevviÅ¿e by the Figure.

This Å¿loping way of Pruning is to be practis'd when the Branches, being neither altogether outward, nor yet wholly inward, they are a little upon the Å¿ide, on which part however they cannot be preÅ¿erv'd; but yet are plac'd Å¿o, that by that Å¿lope one may expect the following year a Branch Å¿hooting wholly outwards.

Now Å¿uch a Branch may chance to be thick, and conÅ¿equently capable of conducing to the Figure, or weak, and Å¿o fit to give Fruit; and in caÅ¿e, as it happens Å¿ometimes, nothing proceeds from that Å¿lope, the Figure of our Tree will be no wiÅ¿e alter'd by it.

I dare be bold to Å¿ay, that this Pruning in a Å¿loping manner, which is a New Invention, is an Excellent way of Pruning to be practis'd upon all Å¿orts of Trees that have a little Vigour, whether Old or Young, when Å¿ome Branches, unhappily plac'd, as we have juÅ¿t explain'd it, give us cauÅ¿e to do it with hopes of Å¿ucceÅ¿s: It is not indeed Infallible, but it Å¿ucceeds very often, and for certain never Å¿poils any thing: Therefore I adviÅ¿e others to uÅ¿e it as I do; I generally find a great deal of benefit by it, and am very well pleas'd with my Å¿elf for having invented it.

Perhaps it may not be improper to relate here what made me think upon it; I knew, as every body does, and as we have juÅ¿t obÅ¿erv'd it upon the account of the Pruning, which is perform'd within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown Piece; I Å¿ay I knew, that according to the Order of Nature, the Sap newly form'd in the Spring, regularly preÅ¿ented it Å¿elf at the entrance of all the Channels of the Branches form'd the preceeding year, to NouriÅ¿h, Thicken, and Lengthen them, &c. And Å¿o I knew that it was certainly to return to endeavour to perform its function in the Branch I took away, it being ignorant, as I may Å¿ay, of its being taken away; therefore I concluded from thence, that apparently part of the Sap would make its way at the Place where it found it Å¿elf dam'd up, provided it found room enough to get out: So that, in leaving Å¿uch a Place on the outÅ¿ide, a Branch would Å¿hoot from it to do me a kindneÅ¿s. SucceÅ¿s has confirm'd my ReaÅ¿oning, and Practice; and Å¿o from a Branch that was grown in an ill and troubleÅ¿om Å¿ituation, I put my Å¿elf in a way of drawing a conÅ¿iderable advantage for my Tree.

If it Å¿hould happen as, Å¿ometimes it does, that one of thoÅ¿e two firÅ¿t Branches, we Å¿peak of in this Chapter, Å¿hould have produc'd from its Extremity but one thick enough, with Å¿ome Å¿mall ones lower, whilÅ¿t her Neighbour has produc'd the two we expected; or this having really produc'd two, of which, one might be broken, or Å¿poil'd by Å¿ome Accident, Å¿o that only one remain'd on that Å¿ide: TheÅ¿e are two CaÅ¿es in which I think it very material to Explain what is to be done.

As to the firÅ¿t, which is the growing but of one Branch inÅ¿tead of two, which in Probability were to have grown; in that firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing there may be cauÅ¿e to judge, that the Prun'd Branch has not receiv'd Å¿o large a proportion of Sap as her Companion, which will appear in that, for Example, it Å¿hall not have thicken'd in proportion to the other, which proceeds from Å¿ome inward, un-fore-Å¿een, and inevitable defect; in that firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, this New Branch muÅ¿t be cut a little Å¿horter, and that with a ProÅ¿pect that apparently it will yield but one, which conÅ¿equently muÅ¿t be expected on that Å¿ide where it is moÅ¿t wanted for the Figure; with this ReÅ¿olve, that, if the following year the Original Branch Å¿hews no more Vigour than the fore-going year, neither it, nor its OffÅ¿pring
muÅ¿t hardly be look'd upon, but as Fruit-Branches, which cannot be laÅ¿ting, and Å¿o we muÅ¿t be neceÅ¿Å¿itated to endeavour betimes to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the foundation of the Beauty of our Tree upon the Branches that may proceed from its Neighbours.

In the Å¿econd CaÅ¿e, wherein one of the two New Branches which are grown from a Vigorous one, may have been torn off, or broken; in that Å¿econd CaÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, whether the remaining Branch prove that which was grown on the Extremity, or that which was grown from the Å¿econd Eye, we may apparently reckon that the Sap which made the two, and would have nouriÅ¿h'd them both, had they remain'd, will come altogether into the remaining; and that Å¿o it muÅ¿t be Prun'd, in hopes that it will at leaÅ¿t produce two, which will be well plac'd, according to our wiÅ¿h, if, in the Pruning of it, we obÅ¿erve all that is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be done; but above all, we muÅ¿t always take care not to let one Å¿ide of the Tree grow higher than the other, for fear of the Deformity which attends that Inequality, which muÅ¿t be avoided as much as is poÅ¿Å¿ible: And therefore in Pruning Å¿uch a Vigorous Branch, which is left alone by Å¿ome accident befaln to her SiÅ¿ter, we muÅ¿t regulate the length of the new Pruning we perform upon it, to that we make upon the oppoÅ¿ite Branch, which has not profited proportionably to what it had done the firÅ¿t year; and that in fine, until the whole Figure of Å¿uch a Teee comes to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h it Å¿elf entirely upon the Branches, which Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively muÅ¿t come from the vigorous Å¿ide, a Skilful Gard'ner is Å¿ufficiently the MaÅ¿ter of Å¿uch an Operation.

If from the laÅ¿t Eye of one of the two firÅ¿t Branches, from which Eye, according to the Order of Nature, a thick one Å¿hould have proceeded; if Å¿uch a one, I Å¿ay, Å¿hould bring forth a weak Branch, or even if the two laÅ¿t Eyes have produc'd two weak ones, which, as we have Å¿aid, regularly Å¿hould have given us two thick ones, and under theÅ¿e weak ones Å¿hould have grown one or two thick ones, or more, which happens Å¿ometimes; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, this, or theÅ¿e weak ones, muÅ¿t infallibly be look'd upon as Fruit-Branches, their weakneÅ¿s procuring them that Merit in regard to us; and Å¿o we Å¿hall preÅ¿erve them very preciouÅ¿ly, breaking them as little as can be on their Extremities, in caÅ¿e they appear too weak for their length, or leaving them untouch'd, if they Å¿eem well proportion'd of themÅ¿elves: And this without doubt is one of the moÅ¿t material Advices I could give.

Woe to thoÅ¿e Trees which Å¿hall paÅ¿s through the hands of Gard'ners who will not be able to make uÅ¿e of this Advice, or Å¿hall take away thoÅ¿e weak Branches' as cauÅ¿ing any deformity to the wretched Idea they have form'd to themÅ¿elves of a Tree, if they have really fram'd any, for the greateÅ¿t part of them Å¿eldom frame any; and cut pell-mell, whatever Å¿ort of Branches fall under their Hands: ThoÅ¿e Wretches, in the firÅ¿t place, do not obÅ¿erve or mind that Fine Fruit never Å¿poils any thing, what ever place it be in: In the Å¿econd, that it is a kind of Murther to take away a fine diÅ¿poÅ¿ition to Fruit when it is already form'd, although an ignorant Man does not know it; and that laÅ¿tly, the Beauty of the Figure of a Tree only conÅ¿iÅ¿ts, and depends abÅ¿olutely upon the thick Branches.

In the mean time, it is to be obÅ¿erv'd, that the thick Branches, that are thus grown below thoÅ¿e weak ones, which are found on the Extremity; that thoÅ¿e thick Branches I Å¿ay, Å¿hall commonly in that place have begun to follow the Order of Nature for the difference of their ThickneÅ¿s, and Length, in the Å¿ame manner as if they had grown on that Extremity, where Naturally they ought to be.

In that CaÅ¿e they muÅ¿t be Prun'd juÅ¿t as if they were really grown from that Extremity; that is, one or two of them muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing they may contribute to the Figure; which being granted, they muÅ¿t be Prun'd of a reaÅ¿onable length, according to their Strength, and the Vigour of the whole Tree, Å¿till preÅ¿erving the neceÅ¿Å¿ary regard that muÅ¿t be had for the Branches they are to Å¿hoot from the laÅ¿t Eyes of their new Extremity; and as for thoÅ¿e that might be prejudicial to the Beauty of the Tree; if there are really any Å¿uch, they muÅ¿t be taken away in the manner here above Explain'd; that is, within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown Piece, or elÅ¿e Å¿lopingly, according to what may be beÅ¿t for the advantage of the Tree.

I may begin to give notice here, that it happens Å¿ometimes, and even pretty often, that this Branch which was left long for Fruit, which in the order of Nature Å¿hould always remain weak, may, notwithÅ¿tanding, chance to thicken in an extraordinary manner, and perhaps produce one, or many thick ones on its Extremity, while that thoÅ¿e thick ones which had been Prun'd Å¿hort for Wood, remain almoÅ¿t in the Å¿ame Condition, and only produce weak ones, the Sap having, as I may Å¿ay, alter'd its CourÅ¿e, juÅ¿t as it happens Å¿ometimes in Å¿ome Rivers.

In Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, we muÅ¿t Å¿ubmit to that alteration, which cannot be prevented, nor hardly alter'd when once form'd; therefore we muÅ¿t begin the very next year after that alteration, to uÅ¿e that Branch like a Wood-Branch, which having alter'd its property, is
become a Wood-Branch, from being a Fruit-Branch; and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e alter our Method in reÅ¿pect to that which, from being a Wood-Branch, is become a Branch for Fruit.

There is nothing to be fear'd Å¿o much, as to Å¿ee a Tree grow thin towards the bottom, which part ought to be fulleÅ¿t; which is the reaÅ¿on that I am Å¿o very Å¿ollicitous, that no Branches for Wood Å¿hould ever be left long in the Pruning, unleÅ¿s it be perhaps on Å¿ome here and there, as we have Å¿aid, to let them take up, for a Year or two, part of that Sap which might prove troubleÅ¿om to us, and afterwards remove them when the Tree bears Fruit; that is, it muÅ¿t be done Å¿ometimes, when they are extraordinary vigorous Trees; but as it is never done without good Grounds, Å¿o it ever proves advantageous.

This Way of Pruning thick Branches long, is a Fault moÅ¿t Gard'ners are guilty of, and that for want of knowing, or taking notice, that as the greateÅ¿t part of our Fruit-Trees are not capable of furniÅ¿hing at one and the Å¿ame time a great Extent, that is, to fill at once both the Top and Bottom; and that naturally, contrary to our Intention, and the Beauty we affect, they all incline to grow upwards, and conÅ¿equently, that Bottom which Å¿hou'd be fulleÅ¿t, remains moÅ¿t bare, unleÅ¿s we uÅ¿e a particular Application to oppoÅ¿e in this the CourÅ¿e of Nature, which Å¿eeks, it Å¿eems, to deceive us: Therefore a great deal of Care muÅ¿t be taken to Å¿top, that is, to prune thoÅ¿e thick Branches Å¿hort enough, it being moÅ¿t certain that they never Å¿hoot much in the lower part, from whence they proceed; but only on their Extremity, whatever it be, high or low.

The Defect of ThinneÅ¿s, which is Å¿ufficiently minded in Dwarfs, is yet much more obÅ¿ervable in Wall-Trees; where, among unskilful Gard'ners, we Å¿eldom Å¿ee any thing but the top of the Wall well cover'd, and that even Garland-wiÅ¿e, Å¿o that commonly all the new Branches exceed the top of it, and there Å¿pend the Vigour of the Tree to no purpoÅ¿e; which obliges them to cut thoÅ¿e wretched Branches four or five times in a Summer, to prevent the DiÅ¿orders of the Wind; while the Heart of the Tree is only compos'd of long, blackiÅ¿h, moÅ¿Å¿y, wrinckled Branches, deÅ¿titute of thoÅ¿e other little ones that Å¿hou'd accompany them; and even often full of Scars, and conÅ¿equently, the Wall, which Å¿hou'd be cover'd every where, always beginning from the bottom, on the contrary, appears quite bare, and the Tree has none of thoÅ¿e Branches it ought to have.

Granting then, that a Branch for Wood muÅ¿t Å¿eldom, or never be left long at the firÅ¿t Pruning, unleÅ¿s it be in order to form a Tree, or to fill up Å¿ome parts of the fartheÅ¿t Å¿ides, it is yet leÅ¿s allowable the following Years, upon the thick new Branch, which is grown from that which having been left long for Fruit, is afterwards grown thick, by an unexpected and extraordinary abundance of Sap.

This is another dangerous Rock, from which few Å¿ave themÅ¿elves: Therefore I am of Opinion, that, inÅ¿tead of performing our Pruning upon a thick and long Branch, Å¿hot from one that had been left long for Fruit, we Å¿hou'd deÅ¿cend, or come down to that old one, and Å¿horten it, leaving it no more length than it might have been allow'd, had it been at firÅ¿t of the thickneÅ¿s it is grown Å¿ince.

And if Å¿uch an old Branch Å¿hou'd not prove of an exceÅ¿Å¿ive length, it will be Å¿ufficient to prune all the new ones that are grown from it Å¿o cloÅ¿e, that not the leaÅ¿t part of them may remain, whence any thing new might proceed.

In theÅ¿e two CaÅ¿es it is moÅ¿t certain, that Å¿uch an old Branch, Å¿o order'd, will not fail, at the very following Spring, to produce others on its Extremity; Å¿ome for Fruit, and others for Wood; among which, thoÅ¿e muÅ¿t be choÅ¿en that are fitteÅ¿t for the Figure, to the end that, according to the Maxims heretofore eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, they may be prun'd like thick Branches, and continu'd to be order'd as Å¿uch, while Nature cauÅ¿es no alteration in them.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.

argument.p: Of the Å¿econd Pruning of a Tree, that on the firÅ¿t Year had produc'd three fine Branches for Wood.

div.p: THE Tree, which had produc'd at firÅ¿t but two fine Branches, being prun'd the firÅ¿t and Å¿econd time it cou'd be Å¿o, we muÅ¿t now proceed to that which had produc'd three proper to make a fine Tree.

In regard to which, I do not think I need add any thing to what I have Å¿aid of the Pruning of the preceding, unleÅ¿s it be, that, to avoid ConfuÅ¿ion, every Branch may be allow'd two Inches more than thoÅ¿e we have been Å¿peaking of, in order to procure both
Overture and RoundneÅ¿s to the Dwarfs, as well as FulneÅ¿s and RoundneÅ¿s to the EÅ¿paliers; and therefore great regard muÅ¿t be had for the two or three laÅ¿t Eyes or Buds on the Extremities of the prun'd Branches, to the end that thoÅ¿e that are to proceed from thoÅ¿e Eyes may be happily diÅ¿pos'd to contribute to the Beauty of the Figure. It is a great happineÅ¿s, as we have already Å¿aid, when a new Tree produces three fine Branches the firÅ¿t Year: But it is yet better, when in the Å¿econd it produces two more on the Extremity of each of thoÅ¿e three.

I may inform you here, that if, on a Dwarf, the Prun'd Branch of a fitting length be capable of producing more than one thick new one on the Extremity of it, and yet we have occaÅ¿ion but for one, the laÅ¿t Eye may indeed be inward, but never the Å¿econd; and therefore the Å¿econd Eye muÅ¿t either be broken, or torn off, if required by the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the Branches that are to come, as we have Å¿aid, either within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown-piece, or Å¿loping, as Å¿hall be judg'd moÅ¿t convenient.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.

argument.p: Of the Å¿econd Pruning of a Tree which had produc'd the firÅ¿t Year four fine Branches for Wood, or more.

div.p: TO Prune for the Å¿econd time a Tree, which in the firÅ¿t Year had produc'd four fine Branches, and even more, it is certain, that as this Tree has a great deal more Vigour than all the others we have mention'd, Å¿o it requires more Application and Skill, not to let it fall into thoÅ¿e Inconveniences wherewith it is threaten'd.

I muÅ¿t Å¿ay here, that in Å¿uch a Tree, eÅ¿pecially in a Dwarf, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary Å¿ometimes to preÅ¿erve Å¿ome Branches upon it, which at that time are no ways conducing to the Beauty of the Tree, but Å¿erve to conÅ¿ume for a time part of the Sa â¢ , which might be prejudicial to the Branches that are to yield Fruit; but none of thoÅ¿e that might cauÅ¿e any ConfuÅ¿ion. ThoÅ¿e Branches which muÅ¿t be look'd upon as Temporary, may be prun'd without ConÅ¿equence; Å¿o they may be left long, Å¿ince they are to be wholly taken away as Å¿oon as the Tree is form'd, and produces a reaÅ¿onable quantity of Fruit.

As to thoÅ¿e that are eÅ¿Å¿ential for the Beauty of the Tree, I have begun to prune them all a little longer than thoÅ¿e of the preceding Trees; that is, about two or three Eyes at moÅ¿t; as well to avoid ConfuÅ¿ion, which is a very perniclous thing, and to be avoided at any rate, as to make an advantage of the Vigour of Å¿uch a Tree; which, without Å¿uch a precaution, wou'd not yield Fruit of a long time, becauÅ¿e the great abundance of Sap might convert into Branches all the Eyes that Å¿hou'd have turn'd into Flower-Buds, had their NouriÅ¿hment been more moderate.

Such a Tree, at the End of the Å¿econd Year, appears in a manner quite form'd, by means of all the new Branches that every one of the old ones that have been prun'd Å¿hall have produc'd on their Extremities; and, among the new ones, Care muÅ¿t be taken to chuÅ¿e thoÅ¿e that conduce to the Beauty of the Figure, to prune them again, partly of the Å¿ame length as thoÅ¿e had been prun'd for the firÅ¿t Time, from which they proceed; endeavouring, above all, to judge whether the Branch that has been prun'd may, at leaÅ¿t, produce two, in order to preÅ¿erve them both, if they prove fit to contribute to our DeÅ¿ign: Or in caÅ¿e one muÅ¿t be quite taken away, let it commonly be the higheÅ¿t, to the end, that, as much as poÅ¿Å¿ible can be, the loweÅ¿t may always be preÅ¿erv'd, as the fitteÅ¿t to form or preÅ¿erve the Beauty we look for; and by that means, not only the place which is cut Å¿hall be (to uÅ¿e the Gard'ners Term) quickly cover'd again, which is much to be deÅ¿ir'd, as an Ornament in a Tree; but beÅ¿ides, it will make no Wound upon the Branches that Å¿hall be preÅ¿erv'd; and conÅ¿equently, the Tree will thereby be infallibly handÅ¿omer and Å¿ounder.

But if the Vigour of that Tree be obÅ¿erv'd to continue, as it is very common, and even to augment viÅ¿ibly, in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e ConfuÅ¿ion is to be fear'd more than ever, either in the Heart of our Dwarf, or in reÅ¿pect to our Wall-Fruit-Tree, whatever Trees they be, of either kind, Pear-Trees, Apple-Trees, Plum-Trees, Peach-Trees, Cherry-Trees, Fig-Trees, &c. Therefore that Å¿econd Pruning muÅ¿t be perform'd yet a little longer than the firÅ¿t, particularly if the Tree appears inclinable to cloÅ¿e; and that length muÅ¿t be about a large Foot, or a little more, to employ that abundance of Sap, which, we judge, muÅ¿t not be reÅ¿train'd, nor contain'd in a Å¿mall Å¿pace.

Upon condition, that when, from the Å¿econd Pruning, other good Branches Å¿hall be grown, which Å¿hall begin to open the Dwarf reaÅ¿onably, or to fill Å¿ufficiently our Wall-Fruit-Tree, eÅ¿pecially the Tree beginning to yield Fruit; upon condition, I Å¿ay, that then we Å¿hall return to our ordinary Pruning of Å¿ix or Å¿even Inches upon the moÅ¿t vigorous Branches, and four or five upon the moderate ones.

This great Fury Å¿eldom fails of diminiÅ¿hing at the End of the firÅ¿t five or Å¿ix Years, if the Tree has been well govern'd; and then all thoÅ¿e little Branches which we have taken care to procure in a great number at the bottom, and have afterwards preÅ¿erv'd with Care, begin to give us an ample Recompence for all our Cares: And even pretty often, in Å¿uch OccaÅ¿ions, we come to prune over again here and there Å¿ome of the old Branches, which the great Vigour of the Tree had oblig'd us to leave of an extraordinary length; and at the Å¿ame time we aim Å¿till at extending, by way of Overture, on the Å¿ides, there to employ uÅ¿efully the Vigour of that Tree, and indiÅ¿penceably to preÅ¿erve its agreeable Figure.

It is upon thoÅ¿e very vigorous Trees that we muÅ¿t begin to perform Å¿ome MaÅ¿terly Strokes: We muÅ¿t, as is done in point of Fountains, make here and there a kind of Cupping, or rather, a kind of Superficial DiÅ¿charge; that is, for Example, leave upon that Tree, without any uÅ¿e, Å¿ome Branches cut Stump-wiÅ¿e, and even Å¿ome thick ones, though of falÅ¿e Wood, in which, for Å¿ome Years Å¿pace, that furious Sap, of which we have too much, may loÅ¿e it Å¿elf in vain, which otherwiÅ¿e might diÅ¿order Å¿ome of our principal Parts: And even, if upon thoÅ¿e Å¿ort of Trees any Branches of falÅ¿e Wood be found in a place where they may Å¿erve towards the Figure of the Tree, they muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd, and us'd as Å¿uch; being certain that, as they will take up the greateÅ¿t abundance of the Sap, the good Branches, which have produc'd thoÅ¿e falÅ¿e ones, will receive leÅ¿s, and conÅ¿equently will bear Fruit the Å¿ooner; theÅ¿e falÅ¿e Branches, in the mean time performing the Å¿ame Effect, as to the Figure, as good ones cou'd have done.

Such Branches may likewiÅ¿e be left, where-ever the Overture of the Tree Å¿hall not be prejudic'd by them; from whence, the Tree bearing Fruit, they may at pleaÅ¿ure be taken away without any prejudice to the Figure; provided always they cauÅ¿e not the leaÅ¿t ConfuÅ¿ion, that being the greateÅ¿t harm that can happen to a vigorous Tree.

And whereas, to moderate the great Fury of Å¿uch a Tree, in reÅ¿pect to our Å¿elves, that is, to make it bear Fruit the Å¿ooner, two things are particularly required, beÅ¿ides the Overture; which are, firÅ¿t, the length and multitude of good weak Branches, when they are plac'd Å¿o as to cauÅ¿e no ConfuÅ¿ion; and in the Å¿econd place, a conÅ¿iderable Plurality of Out-lets upon the thick Branches, through which that abundance of Sap may perform its Effect, Å¿ince we cou'd not hinder it from doing it in Å¿ome part of the Tree.

Therefore, when the Figure of my Tree will permit it, if Å¿ome Branch, prun'd the preceding Year, has produc'd three or four, all pretty thick ones, I often do not retrench them; Å¿o that having one or two of the beÅ¿t plac'd, I preÅ¿erve one or two of the others for the Pruning of the next Year, and leave them reaÅ¿onably long. BeÅ¿ides this, if I preÅ¿erve the loweÅ¿t, I cut the higheÅ¿t Stump-wiÅ¿e; and when I preÅ¿erve the higheÅ¿t, I leave under them, either on the out-Å¿ide, or upon the Å¿ides, one or two Stumps of the thick Branches, form'd like the Hooks of a Vine, each about two Inches in length, as it appears by the Figure annex'd hereunto; which Å¿ucceeds very well to me.

There infallibly happens in thoÅ¿e Stumps, or Hooks, a DiÅ¿charge of Sap, which produces Å¿ome favourable Branches, either for Fruit when they prove weak, or to become in time fit Branches for the Figure when they are Å¿trong.

The beÅ¿t way always is to lower the Tree, in taking away the higheÅ¿t Branches, to preÅ¿erve the loweÅ¿t; and not take away the loweÅ¿t, to preÅ¿erve the higheÅ¿t; to the end, that if the Tree cannot fill both at top and bottom, it may rather be diÅ¿pos'd to remain low, and well fill'd, than to riÅ¿e high, without being well fill'd.

TheÅ¿e kind of Stumps and Hooks will not pleaÅ¿e our Gard'ners at firÅ¿t, who neither know my Principles, nor the way of Cupping; which we have explain'd here above: But if, after having known my ReaÅ¿ons, and long Experience, they will neither approve, or try them, Å¿o much the worÅ¿e for them; they muÅ¿t give me leave to pity their Ignorance, or ObÅ¿tinacy.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV.

argument.p: Of the Pruning that muÅ¿t be perform'd the Third Year, upon all Å¿orts of Trees planted within Four Years.

div.p: THis CaÅ¿e does not require the preceding DiÅ¿tinctions we have made, to determine what was to be done to Trees, according to the Å¿maller or greater quantity of Branches they had produc'd the firÅ¿t Year: They muÅ¿t, at the end of four Years, be partly all of the Å¿ame ClaÅ¿Å¿is, though they be not all furniÅ¿h'd with an equal quantity of thick Branches: But however, both the one and the other muÅ¿t have produc'd a Å¿ufficient number, to Å¿hew a Head entirely form'd; and though even that, for Example, which had produc'd but one the firÅ¿t Year, Å¿hou'd have produc'd but four or five in the fourth, Å¿till there Å¿hou'd be nothing to be Å¿aid in reÅ¿pect to that, Å¿ince that, if it be vigorous, it will partly fall under the CaÅ¿e of a Tree which at firÅ¿t had produc'd four or five, or more; and if it be not of thoÅ¿e that are capable of producing more than one thick Branch on the Extremity of the Pruning, you muÅ¿t regulate your Å¿elf upon the meanneÅ¿s of its Vigour, both in keeping the thickeÅ¿t Branches Å¿hort, and expecting but one thick one on the Extremity of each, making it ever grow on that part where the Figure requires it moÅ¿t.

We muÅ¿t always inviolably follow the Idea of a fine Tree we have firÅ¿t of all propos'd to our Å¿elves, either in a Dwarf, or Wall-Tree, and never fail to proportion the Burthen of the Head to the Vigour of the Foot, in leaving more and longer Branches on a vigorous Tree, and leÅ¿s and Å¿horter on that which appears weak.

And whereas many old Branches muÅ¿t be carefully preÅ¿erv'd on a vigorous Tree, eÅ¿pecially for Fruit, provided there be no ConfuÅ¿ion; on the contrary, you muÅ¿t eaÅ¿e a weak Tree of the Burthen of the old Branches, as well thoÅ¿e that are for Wood, as thoÅ¿e that are for Fruit; and out them Å¿hort, in order to make it Å¿hoot new ones, if it can, with reÅ¿olution to pull it out of the Ground, if not able to perform it; which being done, a better muÅ¿t be plac'd in its room, after having taken away all the old Earth, which may be judg'd to be either ill, or worn out, and having put new in the room of it.

I Å¿till forewarn, that, in Pruning, ProviÅ¿ion muÅ¿t be made for thoÅ¿e Branches that may proceed from thoÅ¿e that are Pruning, in order to prepare Å¿ome that may be proper for the Figure, with this AÅ¿Å¿urance, that when a high Branch is taken down over a lower, this being Å¿trengthen'd by all the NouriÅ¿hment that wou'd have gone to the higheÅ¿t, which has been taken away; this low Branch, I Å¿ay, will produce more Branches than it Å¿hou'd have done, had it receiv'd no Re-inforcement.

In Å¿hort, when, according to my Principles, a young Tree Å¿hall have been conducted to a fourth Pruning, the Effect will infallibly have made good what I have promis'd, both as to the beautiful Figure, which muÅ¿t then appear in its prime, and as to the Fruit, of which, Pears then begin to Å¿hew a Sample, and Stone-Fruit abundance: After this, apparently every body muÅ¿t be capable thenceforward to manage all manner of Fruit-Trees, without needing any other InÅ¿tructions than the preceding; and indeed, I have no other new ones to give; and it wou'd be ridiculous and tireÅ¿om to repeat the Å¿ame things, which, in my Opinion, I have Å¿ufficiently eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd.

It Å¿eldom happens, that all the Trees of the Å¿ame Garden, though order'd alike, prove equally vigorous; no more than the Children of the Å¿ame Father, all equally healthy: Trees, as well as Men, are Å¿ubject to an infinite number of Accidents, that can neither be fore-Å¿een, nor avoided; but it is certain, that all the Trees of a Garden may be form'd agreeably in their Figure; and this is one of the principal things to which a Gard'ner is oblig'd.

Above all, I adviÅ¿e every body not to be obÅ¿tinate in preÅ¿erving Pear-Trees, which yearly, towards the end of Summer, grow extream yellow, without having produc'd fine Shoots; nor thoÅ¿e, of which the Extremities of the Branches likewiÅ¿e die every Year. They are commonly Trees graffed upon Quince; of which, Å¿ome of the principal Roots are dead, or rotrotten: They are Trees that produce but Å¿mall Roots at the upper part of the Foot, and conÅ¿equently, Roots that are expos'd to all the Injuries of the Air, and of the Spade.

The Å¿ame thing may be Å¿aid of the Peach-Trees that appear the firÅ¿t Years to gather Gum at the greateÅ¿t part of their Eyes, and of thoÅ¿e that are extreamly attack'd with certain little Fleas and PiÅ¿mires. Such Peach-Trees have certainly Å¿ome rotten Roots, and will never do well.

I am likewiÅ¿e of the Å¿ame Opinion for thoÅ¿e Trees that Å¿hoot on all Å¿ides an infinite number of little, weak, Å¿apleÅ¿s Branches, with Å¿ome thick ones here and there; both the one and the other, for the moÅ¿t part, of falÅ¿e Wood: In which caÅ¿e, a great deal of time may be loÅ¿t upon ill-grounded hopes.

That which is beÅ¿t to be done in all theÅ¿e OccaÅ¿ions, is, as Å¿oon as can be to remove Å¿uch Trees; and when they are not extreamly old, or Å¿poil'd by the Roots, venture to plant them again in Å¿ome other place, in good Ground, after having cleans'd them of all their RottenneÅ¿s and Cankers, in order to Å¿ee if they will come to any thing, to make uÅ¿e of them elÅ¿ewhere; which happens Å¿ometimes with Pear-Trees, but very Å¿eldom with Stone-Fruit, eÅ¿pecially Peach-Trees; Å¿till putting better in the room of them, with all the Conditions heretofore explain'd.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.

argument.p: Of the firÅ¿t Pruning of Trees that have been Planted with many Branches.

div.p: AFter having Å¿ufficiently explain'd, in the TreatiÅ¿e of Plantations, my AverÅ¿ion to plant little Trees with many Branches, I am willing at preÅ¿ent to believe, that as I Å¿eldom plant any, thoÅ¿e who will do me the honour to imitate me, will do the Å¿ame. However, ThoÅ¿e that will plant Å¿uch, muÅ¿t principally obÅ¿erve two things: The firÅ¿t is, to cut off whatever may cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion, and is not proper to begin a fine Figure. The Å¿econd, to leave a Length of about Å¿ix or Å¿even Inches to every Branch they preÅ¿erve upon them: And as for the other Branches that Å¿hall proceed from theÅ¿e, they muÅ¿t regulate themÅ¿elves upon the Principles which we have Å¿ufficiently eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd for the Pruning of other Trees:

It is certain, that Å¿uch Trees, planted with Branches, are not commonly Å¿o eaÅ¿ily turn'd to receive a fine Figure, as thoÅ¿e I affect to plant: The old Branches that are left upon them, are not often happy in producing others on their Extremity, yet leÅ¿s to have them well-plac'd; they generally produce them diÅ¿orderly, and conÅ¿equently muÅ¿t be often wounded, before what is deÅ¿ir'd can be met with; but when at laÅ¿t attain'd, 'tis but following what has been Å¿aid diÅ¿tinctly enough for the management of a Tree, which having been planted without any Branches, has Å¿ince produc'd Å¿ome very fine ones, and very well plac'd.

And when Trees have been planted with a great many more and longer Branches than they Å¿hou'd have been, Å¿o that there appears no manner of diÅ¿poÅ¿ition towards the Figure we ought to wiÅ¿h for, Endeavours muÅ¿t be us'd immediately to reduce them upon a fine Beginning, and that conformably to the Ideas of Beauty Å¿o often explain'd.
What we Å¿hall Å¿ay hereafter, for the firÅ¿t Pruning of old Trees, that have never been order'd well, may Å¿erve altogether for the firÅ¿t Pruning of theÅ¿e, without Å¿aying any thing more about it.

Though commonly, either as to low Standards, or EÅ¿paliers, I condemn the manner of Planting little Trees with many Branches, by reaÅ¿on of the Inconveniences which attend them, in reÅ¿pect to the Figure they ought to have, I am not, however, Å¿o Å¿evere in relation to high Standards, in which I do not condemn it Å¿o much, by reaÅ¿on that they do not require Å¿o great an ExactneÅ¿s for their Beauty: So that I allow they Å¿hou'd be planted Å¿ometimes with Å¿ome Branches on their heads, when Å¿ome are found well enough diÅ¿pos'd for it; they will certainly produce Fruit Å¿ooner than the others: But Å¿till I have a particular EÅ¿teem for thoÅ¿e that are planted without any.

There are Å¿ome other OccaÅ¿ions in which a Tree may be planted with many Branches; and that is, in a great Plantation, where Å¿ome other is dead; for Å¿uppoÅ¿ing the Ground to be very good, and other good Mould put into the Hole, made to plant the other, in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e a Tree may very well be planted with Å¿ome Branches, eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e Trees that are difficult to fructifie. For Example, your Lady-Thigh, Pears without Rinds, Virgoulez, &c.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
