argument.p: Of the Pruning of High-Standards, or Tall Body'd Trees.

div.p: AS the Number of Principles for the Pruning of Dwarf-Trees has been very great, Å¿o the number of Principles for Pruning of High-Standards Planted in open Wind, Å¿hall be very Å¿mall: For as to High-Å¿tandards Planted againÅ¿t a Wall, they all require the Å¿ame Precautions as the little ones; Å¿o that inÅ¿tead of medling yearly with thoÅ¿e Great Trees, I only deÅ¿ire, as I have Å¿aid in the beginning of this TreatiÅ¿e, that they Å¿hould be touch'd once or twice in the beginnings, that is, in the three or four firÅ¿t years, in order to remove Å¿ome Branches from the middle, which might cauÅ¿e a confuÅ¿ion there; or to Å¿horten a Å¿ide which riÅ¿es too much, or bring another nearer, which extends farther than in reaÅ¿on it ought to do: As for the remainder, we muÅ¿t refer it to Nature, and let her produce freely what Å¿he can, there would be too much pain and labour to order theÅ¿e with as much CircumÅ¿pection as the others.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.

argument.p: Of the firÅ¿t Conduct of Graffs in Slits made and multiply'd upon Old Trees, in place, either Dwarfs, or EÅ¿paliers.

div.p: NOthing is Å¿o common in our Gardens, as to Graff in Slits upon Old Trees, be it either to be rid of Å¿ome ill Fruit we are weary of, or to improve Å¿ome conÅ¿iderable Novelty that has been diÅ¿cover'd; Å¿o that often we do not even Å¿pare good kinds, of Å¿uch Trees of which we have a Å¿ufficient Number.

Now as many things are to be Å¿aid upon thoÅ¿e Å¿ort of Graffs, and firÅ¿t, if the Tree has Å¿o little thickneÅ¿s as not to be able to receive above one, as none are commonly apply'd without having three Eyes; it may very well happen that every Å¿uch Graff Å¿hall produce three fine Branches fit to lay the foundation of a fine Tree; in which CaÅ¿e, we muÅ¿t have recourÅ¿e to what we have Å¿aid heretofore of the firÅ¿t Pruning of a Tree, which in the firÅ¿t year had produc'd three fair Shoots; and may allow them about two or three Eyes more in length; if, as in all likelyhood it ought to happen, the Graff has produc'd very Vigorous Twigs, eÅ¿pecially if the Tree appears inclinable to cloÅ¿e.

In the Å¿econd place, if the Tree to be Graffed is thick enough to receive two Graffs, as it is when it has a good Inch Diameter, or a little more; and if the two Graffs produce each two or three fine Branches, as it happens pretty often, then it is fit to Å¿tudy hard to avoid the great confuÅ¿ion that is threaten'd here by the great Proximity of Graffs, and conÅ¿equently we muÅ¿t Å¿tudy to open; therefore among thoÅ¿e Branches, thoÅ¿e that being thick and inwards, form that defect which we muÅ¿t never Å¿uffer, muÅ¿t be taken away, either within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown Piece, or Å¿lopingly, according as the Prudence of the Gard'ner, and the occaÅ¿ion of the Tree Å¿hall preÅ¿cribe: After which, not only the firÅ¿t Pruning Å¿hall be perform'd a little longer than that of the Trees that have been Planted within a year or two, but a greater quantity of Branches muÅ¿t be kept upon them, as well quickly to finiÅ¿h the Figure, if the Matter be fit for it, as to imploy for a certain time the overplus of Sap we judge fit for our DeÅ¿igns, and that Plurality of Branches may comprehend thoÅ¿e Stumps and temporary Branches, as well as kind of Hooks that are on the outÅ¿ide, which I have Å¿poken of heretofore.

In the third place, the Å¿ame regards muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erv'd, and with more Å¿everity, as well for the Overture, as for the length of the firÅ¿t Prunings, if the Graffed Tree has been capable of receiving upon its head to the number of three or four Graffs, which happens when you Graff Crown-wiÅ¿e.

So much the rather, if the Tree having Å¿everal thick Branches all pretty near the one to the other, and all capable of receiving Å¿everal Graffs on the Head, it comes to be Graffed upon every one of them. Such a Tree is apparently a little Old, and yet vigorous enough, Å¿o that all the Sap which was prepar'd by the great number of its Roots, and was Å¿ufficient for the NouriÅ¿hment and Maintenance of a great quantity of long and Å¿trong Branches, finding it Å¿elf pent up in the little compaÅ¿s of thoÅ¿e Graffs, produces generally there Branches
of an extraordinary thickneÅ¿s and length, to that degree, that pretty often one Eye produces two or three Branches, moÅ¿t of them Å¿trong.

In Å¿uch CaÅ¿es, all the Prudence of a Skilful Gard'ner is requir'd to make a good uÅ¿e of that great Vigour thus reduc'd, to the end that by means of a wiÅ¿e Conduct in a Å¿hort time a Tree may be brought to a fine Figure, and to bear a great deal: Nothing is more common than to Å¿ee Å¿uch Graffs ill order'd, and, if I may Å¿ay Å¿o, Cobbled and MaÅ¿Å¿acred; and ConÅ¿equently woe to that Tree, which for the firÅ¿t time falls under the hands of an ignorant Gard'ner.

The great Overture of the Tree, the reaÅ¿onable length of certain Branches that are eÅ¿Å¿entially neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the Figure, the Plurality of Å¿uch as are not Å¿o; and that as well by the means of Å¿hort and long Stumps, &c. as by means of thoÅ¿e that are not imploy'd, and may be remov'd at pleaÅ¿ure, without harming the Tree, both by the way of Å¿uch Prunings as are perform'd within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown Piece, and by the great length of the weakeÅ¿t Branches for Fruit, &c. All theÅ¿e together are Soveraign Remedies, and pretty eaÅ¿ie againÅ¿t the diÅ¿orders that might ariÅ¿e from Å¿uch an abundance of Sap Å¿o reduc'd within a Å¿mall compaÅ¿s; but yet how many ill-favour'd Trees are daily Å¿een, for want of the Gard'ners having good Principles, or for not having Practis'd them from the beginning.

In the fourth place, the Å¿econd, third, and fourth years, and even longer, if it falls out Å¿o, you muÅ¿t labour in the manner aforeÅ¿aid, until the Tree begins to yield Fruit, and then you muÅ¿t not only return to the Pruning of Å¿ix or Å¿even Inches upon each Branch, but likewiÅ¿e take them lower from year to year, here and there, in order to have the lower part of your Tree always well fill'd, which you cannot arrive to by any other means.

What I have now Å¿aid in general upon Old Trees Graffed a-new in Place, may be indifferently apply'd as well to Dwarf-Å¿tandards as to Wall-Fruit-Trees; which being granted, we muÅ¿t ever propoÅ¿e to our Å¿elves the fine Ideas both of the one, and the other, which we have recommended at the beginning of this TreatiÅ¿e; knowing for certain, that confuÅ¿ion and thinneÅ¿s are of a dangerous ConÅ¿equence in point of EÅ¿paliers, as well as Dwarfs, tho' we muÅ¿t grant, that the conveniency of tacking the Branches of Wall-Fruit-Trees, and by that means of conÅ¿training them to lye as we would have them, renders the management of them much eaÅ¿ier, more Å¿ecure, and quicker for Å¿ucceÅ¿s, than it can be for Dwarf-Å¿tandards.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII.

argument.p: Of what is to be done in CaÅ¿es not foreÅ¿een, and yet pretty common to all manner of Trees, even to thoÅ¿e that have been manag'd according to all the Rules of Art.

div.p: I Think I may Å¿uppoÅ¿e, that whoever has with a Å¿ufficient application read over what I have eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd here for the Pruning of Trees, has acquir'd a Å¿ufficient Knowledge, either to underÅ¿tand it well, or to put it in Practice with PleaÅ¿ure and Advantage: To tell the Truth, I Å¿hould be infinitely deceiv'd if it were not Å¿o, having made it my Å¿tudy with all the Care imaginable, to render my Å¿elf intelligible, as well to the Ignorant, and the Novice, as to the Man of UnderÅ¿tanding, whether Gard'ner or not, who Å¿hall be deÅ¿irous to know my Sentiments upon this Matter. But I muÅ¿t add to this, that yet to arrive to a greater perfection of Knowledge, it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary, for two or three years, to endeavour the putting in Practice upon young Trees both the Principles and Manner I uÅ¿e: Experience far exceeding Theory, or Speculation in this CaÅ¿e, as well as in all other practicable Arts and Sciences.

I dare affirm, that hardly any difficulty would ever be found in the Application of theÅ¿e Principles, if, as I may Å¿ay, Nature was always wiÅ¿e in the Production of Branches and Fruits; or if Å¿he could be govern'd as the Carver governs his Marble, and the Painter his Colours; but it is certain, that whatever care we take for the Conduct of our Trees, yet we cannot always Labour about them with Å¿o much Å¿ucceÅ¿s, as to oblige Nature, which we are not altogether maÅ¿ters of, on all OccaÅ¿ions to anÅ¿wer our Intentions and Labour.

Nature is a particular Agent, but yet a neceÅ¿Å¿ary one, which in her Actions depends upon an infinite number of CircumÅ¿tances, either as to Times, and SeaÅ¿ons, or Grounds, of which, Å¿ome are Good, and others Bad; Å¿ome Hot, Å¿ome Cold, Å¿ome Dry, Å¿ome
MoiÅ¿t; or LaÅ¿tly, in relation to the different temper of Trees, of which Å¿ome are apter to bear Fruit than others; Å¿ome to produce more Branches, others leÅ¿s, Å¿ome for Stone-Fruit, others for Kernel; and Å¿ome others are even of a particular kind; as Figgs, Grapes, &c.

I do not know whether I might not Å¿ay, that pretty often the Rules for Pruning are in Å¿ome reÅ¿pects the Å¿ame in relation to Trees, as the Rules of ChriÅ¿tian Morality are in reÅ¿pect to the Conduct of Men; our Trees to me, Å¿eem impatient under the ConÅ¿traint we impoÅ¿e upon them, to keep them low; and Å¿ometimes tack'd againÅ¿t a Wall; they Å¿eem to aim conÅ¿tantly at their eÅ¿cape, and to Å¿urprize the Gard'ner, to Å¿hoot where he would not have them, and produce Branches where he would have none; juÅ¿t as the Corrupt Nature of Man often Rebels againÅ¿t the Divine Laws and ReaÅ¿on, and affects moÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e things which Morality forbids.

It is likewiÅ¿e true, that in our Trees there Å¿ometimes happen certain Inconveniencies, which we could neither foreÅ¿ee, nor hinder; but at leaÅ¿t, when they are come to paÅ¿s, we muÅ¿t apply our Å¿elves to avoid the ill ConÅ¿equences that might attend them; and moreover, if it be poÅ¿Å¿ible, as I have pretty often CauÅ¿e to believe it may; we muÅ¿t endeavour to draw Advantages from them.

There are in this certain Particulars, which may prove tireÅ¿om to Å¿ome Readers, I mean Å¿uch as have no occaÅ¿ion for them, or Å¿uch as do not care to underÅ¿tand Pruning to the bottom; but I hope they may prove of great uÅ¿e, or at leaÅ¿t afford Å¿ome PleaÅ¿ure to true Gard'ners, who are Å¿enÅ¿ible that nothing is Å¿o proper to improve in all manner of Sciences, as thoÅ¿e Å¿tudied and inÅ¿tructive Particulars.

I have in my time made many Remarks upon Å¿everal particular CaÅ¿es relating to the Pruning of all manner of Trees; which I look upon as proper to be added here, together with the Conduct I have held towards them.

But firÅ¿t, I think my Å¿elf oblig'd to Å¿ay that Stone-Fruit, and eÅ¿pecially Peuch-Trees, and even Apricocks, greatly require a Å¿econd Pruning, and Å¿ometimes a third, beÅ¿ides the firÅ¿t which is done at the end of Winter: ThoÅ¿e laÅ¿t Prunings muÅ¿t be perform'd towards the middle of May, when the Fruit is either knit, or blaÅ¿ted: At which time, I dare affirm, that they are not only advantageous, but even very neceÅ¿Å¿ary; at the Å¿ame time you muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e Trim the Buds and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches of Å¿ome others, which is no leÅ¿s neceÅ¿Å¿ary than thoÅ¿e kind of Prunings.

TheÅ¿e laÅ¿t Operations, Viz. the Å¿econd and third Pruning of Stone-Fruit, and the Trimming of the Buds and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches of all manner of Trees, are neceÅ¿Å¿ary, both to Å¿trengthen certain Branches, which may be of uÅ¿e for the future to make Branches for Wood, as well as to take away intirely Å¿ome that are grown uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, and inconvenient; their Function which was to bear Fruit, not having Å¿ucceeded, their BloÅ¿Å¿oms being deÅ¿troy'd. I will make a Particular Chapter of this hereafter, after having explain'd all the Particulars I have mention'd for Pruning.

All theÅ¿e I have divided into Four ClaÅ¿Å¿is; of which the firÅ¿t conÅ¿iÅ¿ts of thoÅ¿e Remarks that are generally common for the Pruning of all manner of Fruit-Trees, whether Dwarfs, or Wall-Trees: This ClaÅ¿Å¿is has a pretty large extent, and Å¿hall be the firÅ¿t I will Explain.
The Second of the Remarks that are peculiar in every Year to the firÅ¿t Pruning of Stone-Fruit, eÅ¿pecially Peach-Trees, and Apricocks.
The Third, of thoÅ¿e Remarks that relate only to the Second and Third Pruning of thoÅ¿e very Stone-Fruits, as well EÅ¿paliers, as Dwarfs.
And LaÅ¿tly, the Fourth is for the Trimming of the Buds and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches of both.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX.

argument.p: Common Remarks for certain Å¿ingular CaÅ¿es relating to the Pruning of all manner of Trees.

div.p:
I Shall Å¿et down the whole Matter of this Chapter without Order or Connection, by reaÅ¿on that it would almoÅ¿t be impoÅ¿Å¿ible to do it otherwiÅ¿e, every CaÅ¿e being Singular, and without the leaÅ¿t relation to the other; as well as that, in my Opinion, it would be of no uÅ¿e, tho' it might be done; BeÅ¿ides, I did Å¿et down things carefully in my Journal, according to the Singularities I obÅ¿erv'd by degrees in my Studies upon Vegetation, and
therefore I think it will not be improper to Communicate them in the Å¿ame Method I Collected them, which is as followeth.

div.head: 1 ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHen from any part of a Branch that has been couch'd and conÅ¿train'd againÅ¿t a Wall, or from Å¿ome part of the Branch of a Dwarf which Naturally Å¿tands Horizontally; that is, which inÅ¿tead of mounting upwards, like moÅ¿t of the others, has inclin'd Å¿idewiÅ¿e (I have a great value for Å¿uch which grow Å¿oon Branches for Fruit) I Å¿ay, when Å¿uch Branches have Å¿hot Å¿ome of falÅ¿e Wood, which can neither Å¿erve towards the Figure, nor for Fruit, I Cut them within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown Piece, or Å¿lopingly, according to my occaÅ¿ion, otherwiÅ¿e that falÅ¿e Wood would ruine that which is good, or at leaÅ¿t it would ruine it from the part it came from, to the Extremity of the Branch; and if in the Summer I perceive the Beginning or Birth of Å¿uch Branches, I break them off immediately, which is done with eaÅ¿e, preÅ¿Å¿ing them downward with the Thumb, where they begin to appear, or in drawing them towards one.

div.head: 2 ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: I LikewiÅ¿e remove all pretty Å¿trong Branches, Å¿hooting from a kind of hard knob upon which the Å¿talks of Pears did grow, and upon which there may perhaps Å¿till be new ones; there is Å¿eldom any Foundation to be laid upon Å¿uch Branches; therefore when I obÅ¿erve any Å¿uch in the Summer, I tear them off immediately.

div.head: 3 ObÅ¿ervation:
div.p: I Do the Å¿ame with thoÅ¿e Branches which proceed from thoÅ¿e which Originally were Å¿hort and Å¿treight, looking upon the Horizon, and plac'd in the form of a Spur upon certain Trees where theÅ¿e Spurs are common, and extraordinary good to be preÅ¿erv'd; Å¿uch as Ambret, Virgoule, Burgamots, &c. either in Dwarf, or Wall-Tree; thoÅ¿e Å¿ort of Branches grown from thoÅ¿e kind of Spurs will never be good for any thing, they will ruine both the Beauty of the Figure, and the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition to Fruit, which commonly attends thoÅ¿e kind of Spurs; and if, as it happens often, Nature Å¿eems obÅ¿tinate, in producing upon thoÅ¿e Spurs theÅ¿e kind of Branches which I am an Enemy to; it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary, finally, to cut thoÅ¿e Spurs within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown Piece, in order wholly to remove the great CourÅ¿e of Sap which throws it Å¿elf on that Å¿ide, and does it a prejudice; we have already Å¿ufficiently Å¿poken as to the effect of Å¿uch an extraordinary Pruning.

div.head: 4 ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: THe Pruning of weak long Branches may as well be perform'd by breaking them only on the Extremity, as in cutting them with the Pruning-Knife, and perhaps better, as well as faÅ¿ter; In my Opinion, in breaking of them we waÅ¿te more Sap, which may be of uÅ¿e to form Fruit-Buds the Å¿ooner, Å¿ince, as we have already Å¿aid, they only grow on thoÅ¿e places that receive little Sap.

div.head: 5 ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: A Skilful Curious Gard'ner ought never to Å¿uffer any dry or dead Argot, or Cock-Å¿pur upon any Trees, but cut them off cloÅ¿e when ever he perceives them, unleÅ¿s it be upon certain Peach-Trees that appear Å¿omewhat inclin'd to Gum, upon which it is dangerous to do it, by reaÅ¿on that the wound cannot Å¿oon be clos'd, and that the Gum Supurates through it; but it is certain that it is both a Beauty and Advantage, eÅ¿pecially in Kernel-Fruit, to cut off wholly all thoÅ¿e kind of Argots, by reaÅ¿on that the part infallibly cloÅ¿es again, provided the Tree be Å¿ound.

By this word Argot, I mean in this place, the Old Extremity of a Branch which has been formerly Å¿horten'd at Å¿ome diÅ¿tance from the Eye, Å¿o that this Eye has afterwards Å¿hot another Branch, and this Å¿ame Extremity is grown dry, and half dead without having profited Å¿ince the Pruning, which has given it Birth.

div.head: 6. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHen from Å¿ome good part of a Tree, which in the firÅ¿t Years had only produc'd Branches of a moderate Vigour, and thereby gave but little hopes of a long Continuance, we afterwards come to get one or two fine Branches, or more, though all of falÅ¿e Wood; if I find that I may lay the Foundation of a fine new Figure upon it for Å¿uch a Tree, I always do it conformably to the Rules heretofore eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, and in the mean time I Å¿till preÅ¿erve all the ancient weak ones, as long as they are capable of yielding Fruit, with a ReÅ¿olve to cut them as Å¿oon as they ceaÅ¿e to bear; and by that time, others Å¿hall have form'd themÅ¿elves in the new Figure, and thoÅ¿e Å¿hall inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly Å¿upply the room of the old Branches.

But in caÅ¿e Å¿uch Branches Å¿hou'd grow in a place whence I can draw no advantage to form a fine Tree, I take them off quite, in hopes that another Year may produce more favourable ones; Å¿uppoÅ¿ing that Å¿uch a Tree having been capable to Å¿hoot Å¿ome, though ill-plac'd, the Vigour of it not only Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿ts, but even increaÅ¿es Å¿till, and will certainly produce new ones, and probably better plac'd; Å¿uch kind of Branches will owe their Birth to Å¿ome new Roots, which Å¿hall have been form'd in an extraordinary manner.

div.head: 7. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IF likewiÅ¿e I find that an old Tree, and a little elevated, Å¿hoots finer Branches towards the bottom than on the top, and find the top in an ill CaÅ¿e, and almoÅ¿t forÅ¿aken by Nature, I abandon it likewiÅ¿e, and follow the Alteration which is happen'd, in order to begin a new Figure, and conÅ¿equently make a new Tree again. ThoÅ¿e Alterations happen pretty often, eÅ¿pecially in Peach-Trees that begin to grow old: 'Tis fit, in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, to improve the AdvertiÅ¿ement Nature gives us.

But if the top appears pretty good and vigorous, Å¿o that it may yet laÅ¿t long in the Condition it is in, I then cut off entirely the new Branches that Å¿hoot below, to preÅ¿erve the old ones, unleÅ¿s I find room in the Neighbourhood of the Foot to place theÅ¿e new Branches.

div.head: 8. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: I Never value certain Å¿mall Branches, little and weak, which Å¿hoot from other Å¿mall, weak Branches; from which, if thick ones chance to Å¿hoot, I only conÅ¿ider them as Branches of falÅ¿e Wood, and uÅ¿e them accordingly.

div.head: 9. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IN the Order Nature commonly obÅ¿erves for the Production of Branches and Roots, what is produc'd a-new is leÅ¿s thick than the place from whence it is produc'd: And if, contrary to that Order, the Branches or Roots that are Å¿hot prove thicker than thoÅ¿e whence they are produc'd, the new ones are commonly of falÅ¿e Wood, and muÅ¿t be us'd accordingly; Å¿till Å¿uppoÅ¿ing, in reÅ¿pect to the Branches, that thoÅ¿e which are of falÅ¿e Wood may be prejudicial to the Figure, or Fruit, as we have heretofore explain'd: For if, inÅ¿tead of being prejudicial, their Situation Å¿hou'd favour the Figure, or even be capable of waÅ¿teing for a time part of the Sap, which is too abounding here; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, they muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd according to our foregoing Rules; but in the CaÅ¿e of Roots, as the thickeÅ¿t are always the beÅ¿t, the diÅ¿tinction of falÅ¿e Wood not being eÅ¿Å¿ential here, we muÅ¿t always preÅ¿erve them, let them be grown how they will, and deÅ¿troy the old ones, which Å¿eem to be abandon'd.

div.head: 10. ObÅ¿ervation:
div.p: A Branch muÅ¿t never be Prun'd without conÅ¿idering firÅ¿t the place whence it proceeds, to judge whether it be good, and capable of anÅ¿wering our End: For Å¿ome Branches might be look'd upon as thick ones, if they proceeded originally from a weak place; which, notwithÅ¿tanding, ought to be look'd upon as weak ones, becauÅ¿e they proceed from a place being originally Å¿trong and vigorous; and Å¿o of the reÅ¿t.

div.head: 11. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: LIkewiÅ¿e, a Tree muÅ¿t never be Prun'd without having firÅ¿t examin'd the Effect of the preceding Pruning, in order to correct the Defects of it, if any; or elÅ¿e of preÅ¿erving its Beauty with Care.

div.head: 12. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IN point of Dwarfs, where we have not the convenience of Tying the Branches, as in Wall-Fruit-Trees; in order to judge of the quantity of Buds that muÅ¿t be left upon each Fruit-Branch, we muÅ¿t conÅ¿ider what the Å¿trength of Å¿uch a Branch is capable of bearing of it Å¿elf, without being expos'd to the hazard of breaking; and therefore it will be proper to lean upon the Extremity of Å¿uch a Branch, to the end that, by the great or Å¿mall ReÅ¿iÅ¿tance we find in leaning upon it, compar'd to the known Weight of Å¿uch a kind of Fruit, the Burthen may be proportion'd to the Å¿trength or weakneÅ¿s of the Branch.

div.head: 13. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: COmmonly in Peach and Plum-Trees, if a pretty old thick Branch be Å¿horten'd, there are Å¿eldom any new ones to be expected, either on the Extremity, or in the whole CompaÅ¿s of it; the Sap of Å¿uch a Tree can hardly penetrate Å¿o hard a Bark: But yet Å¿ometimes, the Tree having Å¿ome Vigour left, the Sap produces its Effect upon the youngeÅ¿t Branches, near to that old one in queÅ¿tion.

But the contrary as to Apricock-Trees, either old, or young; or young Peach-Trees, and all other kind of Trees; we may regularly expect new Branches from the old ones which have been cut Å¿horter, Å¿eldom meeting with any diÅ¿appointment.

div.head: 14. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHereas in vigorous Trees, either young or old, as we have Å¿o often declar'd, we only look for Fruit upon the weak Branches; on the contrary, in weak Trees, that have but little Vigour, we muÅ¿t look for Fruit upon the Å¿trong ones, and never upon the weak; thoÅ¿e having too much weakneÅ¿s to be able produce Å¿ine Fruit, and the others, which appear thick, and indeed are only Å¿o compar'd to the Å¿mall Vigour of the whole Tree, have no more Sap in them than is requir'd for the forming of fine Fruit: So that in Å¿uch weak Trees, all the Å¿mall Branches muÅ¿t be taken away; they always appear worn out, whether they have given Fruit, or not; and they often periÅ¿h without having fructify'd.

div.head: 15. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IN all Å¿orts of Fruit-Trees, being Å¿ound, a Å¿ingle Eye Å¿ometimes produces to the number of two, three, or four Branches, and for the moÅ¿t part pretty fine ones: It is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to judge prudently which are the fitteÅ¿t to be preÅ¿erv'd, either for Wood, or Fruit, and which are to be cut off quite: It Å¿eldom happens that above two are preÅ¿erv'd, and even thoÅ¿e muÅ¿t look upon two empty Sides, diÅ¿tant from each other; to that End the middlemoÅ¿t of the three is often taken away, and Å¿o the two remaining receive the better nouriÅ¿hment. This Operation ought to be perform'd in Trimming the Buds, and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches, which is in May, or June.

div.head: 16. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IN EÅ¿paliers, or Wall-Fruit-Trees, all the Branches may eaÅ¿ily be diÅ¿pos'd on one Å¿ide or other, provided they be tack'd while they are young, for then they are eaÅ¿ily bent; but if they be not order'd at that time, and Å¿hou'd make an ill Figure, they muÅ¿t be cut within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown-piece, at the SeaÅ¿on of the firÅ¿t Pruning, which Å¿hall be in February or March of the following Year; or, at leaÅ¿t, upon the firÅ¿t Eye, in hopes that the Å¿ides of that thickneÅ¿s may produce Å¿ome Branches which may prove more uÅ¿eful than the Mother.

div.head: 17. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: THough it be in Å¿ome manner diÅ¿agreeable, as well in a Wall-Fruit-Tree, as (eÅ¿pecially) in a Dwarf, to Å¿ee a thick Branch croÅ¿Å¿ing the middle of the Tree, yet it is fit to preÅ¿erve it when it contributes to the filling up of one of the Sides, which, without it, wou'd remain empty, and is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the Beauty of the Figure. Such Niceties need not be obÅ¿erv'd for Fruit-Branches; they are good in any part.

div.head: 18. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: OF all that depends upon Art, nothing Å¿eems Å¿ecurely capable of Å¿trength'ning a weak Branch, being within the extent of a thick one, but the taking away of all the other Branches which are Å¿uperior to it, and even that part from whence it Å¿hoots; Å¿o that this may arrive to be the higheÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e that proceed from the Å¿ame Mother, and conÅ¿equently forms an Extremity to it. All the firÅ¿t, Å¿econd and third Prunings, as well as the Trimming of the Buds and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches in the Month of May, are very proper for it; but when naturally a Branch is weak on the Extremity of a thick one, there is no certainty of Å¿trengthning it, unleÅ¿s it be by removing an old Branch, originally Å¿uperior to that whence that weak one Å¿prung.

Not but Nature Å¿ometimes effects Å¿uch things of her Å¿elf, without removing any Å¿uperior thing; as we have obÅ¿erv'd, Å¿peaking of Å¿ome Fruit-Branches, which, by an overflowing of Sap, thicken more than naturally they Å¿hou'd do; but we being ignorant how this is done, cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly imitate it.

div.head: 19. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IN order to Prune very vigorous Peach-Trees towards the end of the Winter, for the firÅ¿t time, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to tarry till they are ready to BloÅ¿Å¿om, in order to know with more certainty the Buds that will BloÅ¿Å¿om, for there are a great many BloÅ¿Å¿om-Buds which never BloÅ¿Å¿om, the coldneÅ¿s of the Winter, or the abundance of new Sap, and Å¿ometimes the Gum, deÅ¿troying a great quantity. ThoÅ¿e Buds being known, we muÅ¿t regulate our Å¿elves accordingly, both for the choice of thoÅ¿e Branches that are to be preÅ¿erv'd, and for the length that is to be allow'd to them.

div.head: 20. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WE obÅ¿erve, that the Fruit-Buds that are on the Extremities of the Branches are commonly thicker, and better fed than the others; which confirms what the Order of the Production of new Branches had taught us; which is, that the Sap always goes more abundantly to the Extremities, than elÅ¿ewhere; which has given a RiÅ¿e to the Maxim I have eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd in my Reflections for the Effect of the Strong and Weak, in relation to Fruit-Buds, which form themÅ¿elves upon all kind of Branches, Å¿trong or weak. From thence I concluded, that, eÅ¿pecially for weak Trees, it is good to Prune them betimes, not to let the Sap waÅ¿te it Å¿elf in vain on Extremities that muÅ¿t be retrench'd. This teaches us beÅ¿ides, that in the Winter both the Branches and Buds thicken: We know it Å¿ufficiently, by the Example of Almond-Trees Graffed at the end of Autumn, which, before the Return of the Spring, appear extreamly preÅ¿s'd by the Flax that had been apply'd to them in Graffing.

div.head: 21. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WE muÅ¿t never begin to Prune an EÅ¿palier, or Wall-Fruit-Tree, until it be quite untack'd; for, beÅ¿ides that the Pruning is perform'd with more eaÅ¿e, and quicker, it happens, beÅ¿ides, that in Tacking for the firÅ¿t time after the Pruning, the preÅ¿erv'd Branches are the better order'd; and that often, out of LazineÅ¿s, inÅ¿tead of undoing a Tack, to make a new one, a Branch is left as it was found, though ill-plac'd.

div.head: 22. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IT is often neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Untack; for the firÅ¿t Tacking of the Month of May, firÅ¿t, in order to equal the Figure; in the Å¿econd place, to remove from behind the Props or Stays Å¿uch Branches as were already flip'd behind them; which muÅ¿t never be Å¿uffer'd there: Therefore it behoves one to be careful in the Month of May, often to viÅ¿it Wall-Fruit-Trees, as well to prevent Å¿uch DiÅ¿orders, as to remove the languiÅ¿hing, wretched Shoots that wou'd only cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion.

div.head: 23. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: THE multitude of Branches in the firÅ¿t Year, is not always a Å¿ign of Vigour; on the contrary, when they prove all weak ones, it is an ill Omen, which Å¿hews an Infirmity in the Roots. And thus, for Example, RedneÅ¿s in the Cheeks is not always a Å¿ign of Health.

div.head: 24. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHen a Tree, either Dwarf, or EÅ¿palier, is great and old, it Å¿eldom Å¿hoots any green Branches; and conÅ¿equently, it is not likely that any Faults can be committed in Pruning of it; always Å¿uppoÅ¿ing, if a Dwarf, that it is open; if an EÅ¿palier, that the Figure of it be paÅ¿Å¿ably well eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd: Faults are only greatly to be fear'd upon very vigorous Trees, which perform more than the Gard'ner wou'd have them; that is, produce more Branches than he expected.

div.head: 25. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WE can only judge of the ThickneÅ¿s and WeakneÅ¿s of Branches, comparatively to thoÅ¿e that are adjoining to them in one and the Å¿ame Tree. For Example, Some are deem'd weak in one part of a Tree, or in certain Trees, which in another might paÅ¿s for thick ones: The Neighbourhood of a very thick one renders another, that is not Å¿o thick, weak, as well as many weak ones render another, that is not Å¿o weak, thick.

div.head: 26. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: THis Rule is very conÅ¿iderable, in order not to fail, affording Å¿ometimes an extraordinary length to certain Branches; which, though pretty thick, ought notwithÅ¿tanding to be look'd upon here as weak and Å¿mall, the length being neceÅ¿Å¿itated by the ConÅ¿ideration of other neighbouring Branches, and thicker; which in the Neighbourhood, are look'd upon, and us'd like Branches for Wood.

div.head: 27. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHen weak Branches are very Å¿lender on their Extremities, it is a certain Å¿ign of an extream WeakneÅ¿; wherefore they muÅ¿t be much Å¿horten'd: And when they are pretty thick there, they muÅ¿t be left Å¿omewhat longer, becauÅ¿e they really are not Å¿o weak.

div.head: 28. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: THE farther a weak Branch is diÅ¿tant from the Heart of the Tree, the leÅ¿s NouriÅ¿hment it receives; therefore, in Å¿uch OccaÅ¿ions, we muÅ¿t draw nearer upon the loweÅ¿t; whereas, on the contrary, the farther a thick Branch is diÅ¿tant from the Heart, the more NouriÅ¿hment it receives; for which reaÅ¿on it muÅ¿t be remov'd, in order to keep the Vigour in the middle, or in the lower part of the Tree.

div.head: 29. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: FRom Å¿ome Trees, either old or new-planted, eÅ¿pecially Pear-Trees, either Dwarfs, or Wall-Trees, Å¿ometimes proceed Horizontal Branches, of an ordinary thickneÅ¿s, which are admirable to be preÅ¿erv'd for Fruit, either Å¿hooting outwards or inwards: But regularly moÅ¿t Branches Å¿treighten again, and threaten a great deal of ConfuÅ¿ion, if Care be not taken to take away thoÅ¿e that are worÅ¿t plac'd; or elÅ¿e are apt to diÅ¿garniÅ¿h, unleÅ¿s one be Å¿evere in cutting Å¿ome of them Å¿hort.

div.head: 30. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: SOmetimes Å¿ome Branches are Prun'd like Branches for Wood, though in reallity they have no more thickneÅ¿s than a Fruit-Branch Å¿hou'd have; and therefore muÅ¿t not be look'd upon as being real Branches for Wood, proper to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h and preÅ¿erve long part of the Figure of a Tree, but rather as half Wood-Branches: They really are of Å¿ome uÅ¿e for the Figure, and to fill up Å¿ome Vacuity for two or three Years; after which, they muÅ¿t periÅ¿h, which muÅ¿t be expected; and, without relying upon them, endeavour to get others near them, to Å¿upply their Room; otherwiÅ¿e a Tree will Å¿oon grow defective.

div.head: 31. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p:
WHen a Tree, either Dwarf, or, particularly, a Wall-Fruit-Tree, eÅ¿pecially Peach, or Plumb-Tree, no longer Å¿hoots new Branches, it muÅ¿t be look'd upon as a decay'd Tree, and therefore another muÅ¿t be prepar'd againÅ¿t the next Year; and without
Pruning any of its Branches for Wood, all thoÅ¿e that are likely to produce fine Fruit, muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd to that end, retrenching all the SapleÅ¿s ones exactly, as being incapable of doing any good.

div.head: 32. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: YOU muÅ¿t never Prune a Branch for Wood, when you have no Å¿uch occaÅ¿ion for it; and therefore, for Example, when a high Standard begins to be preÅ¿s'd by the Neighbourhood of a lower Tree, Å¿o as to be partly neceÅ¿Å¿itated to cut off Å¿ome of the loweÅ¿t Branches of that high Standard, to make room for the higheÅ¿t of its Neighbour; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, thoÅ¿e Branches of the high Standard muÅ¿t be left long for Fruit, eÅ¿pecially if it be vigorous, and can nouriÅ¿h theÅ¿e without prejudicing the principal Branches: And thereby Endeavours are us'd to get Å¿ome Fruit, by the extraordinary length of Å¿uch Branches, before one be neceÅ¿Å¿itated to cut them off quite.

div.head: 33. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WE muÅ¿t cut Stump-wiÅ¿e, that is, entirely, all the thick Branches that are Å¿hot from the Extremity of another paÅ¿Å¿ably thick and long, which, if Prun'd according to the common Method of Pruning, wou'd grow too naked, and too long; and conÅ¿equently, wou'd look diÅ¿agreeable. By this manner of Pruning Stump-wiÅ¿e, we may commonly hope for Å¿ome new Branches from the Body of the old one, proper to maintain the Beauty of the Figure, in filling up every part.

div.head: 34. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WE likewiÅ¿e cut Stump-wiÅ¿e when, upon a very vigorous Tree, of two Å¿trong Branches, grown on the Extremity of a vigorous one, we think fit to uÅ¿e the Second preferably to the FirÅ¿t, and yet do not think it proper to Å¿trengthen that Second any more; and Å¿o we leave, for the Å¿pace of a Year or two, or more, a Å¿mall paÅ¿Å¿age for the Sap to the higheÅ¿t cut StumpwiÅ¿e, in order to take it quite away, as well as the new Branch that Å¿hall be Å¿hot from it, as Å¿oon as the Tree Å¿hall begin to bear Fruit.

However, I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s, that the moÅ¿t common UÅ¿e that is made of that way of Pruning Stump-wiÅ¿e, is Å¿eldom for any Branches, but Å¿uch that, from weak, and paÅ¿Å¿ably long as they were, are grown extraordinary thick and vigorous; inÅ¿omuch that they have Å¿hot from their Extremity one, or two, or many thick Branches. The original WeakneÅ¿s of Å¿uch Branches only proceeded from their length, which Å¿hou'd not have been allow'd them, had they been as thick as they are grown Å¿ince; and therefore, being grown thick, they muÅ¿t begin to be us'd like Branches for Wood; that is, they muÅ¿t be Å¿horten'd.

div.head: 35. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: AND in caÅ¿e that Branch cut Stump-wiÅ¿e has produc'd no Branches for Wood in its Extent, eÅ¿pecially drawing near to the place whence it proceeded, and on the contrary, has Å¿hot a thick Branch at the place of the Stump, or cloÅ¿e by it, this laÅ¿t thick one muÅ¿t again be cut Stump-wiÅ¿e, eÅ¿pecially the old one not being too long; for if it be too long, and has not been Å¿horten'd at a proper time, the Pruning muÅ¿t be perform'd upon the Body of that old one, and conÅ¿equently Å¿horten'd, according to the Rules heretofore eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd.

div.head: 36. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IF on an old, but pretty vigorous Tree, altogether diÅ¿order'd with falÅ¿e Wood, barely by the defects of an ill-perform'd Pruning, Care be not taken for three or four Years, one after another, to take it lower, by a Branch or two yearly, until it be quite Å¿horten'd, it will never yield any Å¿atisfaction; but by that means it may very well be brought to be a fine and good Tree. This is fit to be done, when a Tree is of a very good kind: If not, it were better to take it quite down, and to Graff a better kind upon it Slit-wiÅ¿e, either of Å¿uch as we have not already, or have not a Å¿ufficient number of.

div.head: 37. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: SOmetimes certain Trees are Å¿o vigorous, that they cannot, eÅ¿pecially the firÅ¿t Years, be reduc'd to a Å¿mall compaÅ¿s; therefore they muÅ¿t be allow'd to extend either upwards, or on the Å¿ides; otherwiÅ¿e they will only produce falÅ¿e Wood: Afterwards you may by degrees reduce them to the Standard of others, when they begin to bear Fruit. Such are commonly, VirgoulÃ©, Lady-Thighs, Saint-Lezin, Robine, RouÅ¿Å¿elets, or RuÅ¿Å¿ettings, &c.

div.head: 38. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: A Very vigorous Tree can never have too many Branches, provided they be well order'd, and cauÅ¿e no ConfuÅ¿ion; whereas, on the contrary, a weak Tree can never have too few, that the Burthen may be proportion'd to the Vigour of it; and therefore you muÅ¿t Å¿eldom leave any upon it, but Å¿uch thick Branches as it may have.

div.head: 39. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: THE Branches of falÅ¿e Wood, or Suckers, as to Peach-Trees, and other Stone-Fruit, are not commonly Å¿o defective as to the Eyes, or Buds, as thoÅ¿e that grow upon Kernel-Fruit-Trees; but are more Å¿ubject to periÅ¿h, and to have their Eyes extinguiÅ¿h'd with Gum, which is a peculiar DiÅ¿temper to them. As for the Pruning, they muÅ¿t partly be manag'd like the Branches of falÅ¿e Wood of Pear-Trees, when they are but in a Å¿mall number upon a Tree; but when there are a great many on the lower part of a Tree, they muÅ¿t be look'd upon as proper to renew that Tree; and therefore, a conÅ¿iderable length muÅ¿t be allow'd to Å¿ome, in order to take them away when the fury Å¿hall be over; and in the mean time, thoÅ¿e that Å¿hall be pitch'd upon for the Foundation of the Re-eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment of a fine Figure, muÅ¿t be Prun'd according to the common Method. We Å¿eldom meet with this abundance of thick Branches upon any but Peach-Trees, eÅ¿pecially Stone-Peaches, which begin to grow ancient, and worn out about the head.

div.head: 40. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: ALL manner of Trees have a Branch or two predominant over the others, and Å¿ometimes more; happy are thoÅ¿e in which the Vigour is divided, unhappy thoÅ¿e where the Torrent lies all on one Å¿ide.

div.head: 41. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: A Wood-Branch, growing on the in-Å¿ide of a Dwarf which you intend to cloÅ¿e, is ever welcome, and the Å¿ame, if favourably plac'd to Å¿upply a thin Å¿ide.

div.head: 42. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: FRuit-Buds of Pear and Apple-Trees Å¿ometimes form themÅ¿elves the very Å¿ame Years in which the Branch they are adherent to has been form'd, as generally all the Buds of Stone-Fruit do; but Å¿ometimes there are Å¿ome that are two or three Years, and even longer, before they come to perfection: Some arrive to it at the Entrance of the Spring, Å¿o that it happens that Å¿ome may be Å¿een at the time of the BloÅ¿Å¿om, which did no wiÅ¿e appear during the Winter.

div.head: 43. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: THE Extremities of the Shoots that come out when Autumn is almoÅ¿t Å¿pent, eÅ¿pecially after a great CeÅ¿Å¿ation of Sap, which happens Å¿ometimes, are always bad; their Colour, which differs from the reÅ¿t of the Branch, Å¿hews it Å¿ufficiently; and Å¿o, being good for nothing, they muÅ¿t be taken off, being likewiÅ¿e Å¿ubject to periÅ¿h: Gard'ners call them Branches of AuguÅ¿t.

div.head: 44. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WE Å¿ay, and with reaÅ¿on, that it is commonly in our power to make Fruit-Buds grow where we pleaÅ¿e; but it is not always Å¿o Å¿oon as we could wiÅ¿h.

div.head: 45. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHen it comes to paÅ¿s that a thick Branch being prun'd, Å¿hoots three, of which, the higheÅ¿t proves of a good thickneÅ¿s, the Å¿econd weak for Fruit, and the third thicker than the higheÅ¿t, two ConÅ¿iderations muÅ¿t be had to Prune them skilfully; that is, if the higheÅ¿t be fit enough for the Figure, it muÅ¿t be made uÅ¿e of, and the third, which is thicker, cut Å¿lantingly, or within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown-piece.

But if this third Branch be better plac'd for the Figure, it may be Prun'd, as being a Branch for Wood, and the higheÅ¿t left for a Fruit-Branch, or rather for one of thoÅ¿e that muÅ¿t be remov'd within a certain Å¿pace of time, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing it cauÅ¿es no ConfuÅ¿ion, and
that the Tree is very vigorous; for if it cauÅ¿es a ConfuÅ¿ion, or the Tree be but of an ordinary Vigour, it muÅ¿t only be cut Stump-wiÅ¿e, for fear of loÅ¿ing the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition which the weak one had for Fruit, if we Å¿hould wholly take away the higheÅ¿t over the weak one.

div.head: 46. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IT is always a happineÅ¿s, eÅ¿pecially in Stone-Wall-Fruit-Trees, when from the lower part of the thick Branch there Å¿hoots, that very Year, another thick one. Our Trees are commonly but too much inclin'd to Å¿hoot upwards.

div.head: 47. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: YOU muÅ¿t never, upon any ConÅ¿ideration whatever, preÅ¿erve your Å¿apleÅ¿s Branches; not even if they were on the top of the Pruning of a vigorous Branch.

div.head: 48. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHen Dwarf-Pear-Trees of BeurrÃ© bear Fruit, they muÅ¿t commonly be Prun'd Å¿horter than other Trees, by reaÅ¿on that as they produce a great deal of Fruit, and that that Fruit is large and heavy, they are apt to open, and Å¿pread too much; which Figure is not pleaÅ¿ing.

div.head: 49. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: DUring the Month of May one cannot be too careful in looking after EÅ¿paliers, eÅ¿pecially Pear-Trees, to hinder good Branches from Å¿lipping behind the Stakes or Props, from which they cannot be remov'd afterwards, without either breaking them or the Lattice-frame.

div.head: 50. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: A Young Pear-Tree languiÅ¿hing or decaying in one part, may Å¿ometimes be re-eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, if, after having taken it out of the Ground, and Prun'd it every where, it be put into better Ground: But there is no help for a decaying Peach-Tree, eÅ¿pecially Gum having appear'd upon it; thoÅ¿e kind of Trees Å¿eldom are reviv'd.

div.head: 51. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IF it happens that any Dwarf, planted within the Å¿pace of three, four, or five Years, or of a longer Å¿tanding, not having been well order'd in the Pruning, in order to form a lovely Figure; or perhaps having been Å¿poil'd by Å¿ome unexpected Accident, Å¿o as to be grown lower and thinner on one Å¿ide than the other; if, I Å¿ay, it happens fortunately that Å¿uch a Dwarf-Standard does Å¿hoot out of that defective Å¿ide a Branch, which being thick, though of falÅ¿e Wood, may Å¿eem proper to correct the defect aforeÅ¿aid, as it happens Å¿ometimes; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e it is fit to allow Å¿uch a Branch a greater length than my Maxims have for the general regulated for Branches of falÅ¿e Wood, to the end that this Branch being equal in heighth to thoÅ¿e of the other Å¿ide, the Figure of the Tree may acquire the Perfection it wanted. The defect of extraordinary length in a Branch is not certainly Å¿o great as that of being crooked, flat, or Å¿lender, which it has now corrected in a Dwarf-Standard.

div.head: 52. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: ALL the Sap of a Tree being employ'd in forming many Branches, Å¿ome Å¿trong, others weak, it will probably Å¿oon produce Fruit upon the weak ones: But when it abounds, and is confin'd within a very Å¿mall number of Branches, for the moÅ¿t part thick, it will produce no Fruit any where, until the great Vigour of it be in Å¿ome manner waÅ¿ted by the great number of Branches it will produce in SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of Time, which Branches muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd.

div.head: 53. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p:
WHen Trees are hard to produce Fruit, by reaÅ¿on of their being too Vigorous, as thoÅ¿e are we have Å¿o often mention'd; eÅ¿pecially certain Plumb-Trees that grow againÅ¿t a Wall, one of the things I commonly do affect, is to leave a great deal of old Wood upon them, particularly for Fruit-Branches, avoiding, however, ConfuÅ¿ion and ThinneÅ¿s, or Vacuity; but Å¿till, upon Condition, that when a Branch left long for Fruit the firÅ¿t
year, Å¿hall afterwards Å¿hoot another on the Extremity of it, which I likewiÅ¿e think Å¿it to preÅ¿erve; upon Condition, I Å¿ay, that in caÅ¿e that Second Å¿hould Å¿hoot a Third, the laÅ¿t muÅ¿t never be preÅ¿erv'd, which would cauÅ¿e a diÅ¿agreeable length, and yet would not anÅ¿wer our aim, which is to get Fruit.

In Å¿uch OccaÅ¿ions I do one of theÅ¿e things, viz. I perform my Pruning upon the Second, the two having a Å¿ufficient length; or elÅ¿e I Prune the Third, which is Å¿hot from the end of the Second, Stump-wiÅ¿e, the two firÅ¿t not being exceÅ¿Å¿ive in length.

div.head: 54. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: THere are Å¿ome moments in which a Skilful Man's Thoughts may be roving while he is Pruning, and Å¿o may chance to commit Å¿ome Faults, which commonly are not very material, and are eaÅ¿ily Corrected; as for Example, having left Å¿ome Branches too long, or having preÅ¿erv'd Å¿ome that Å¿hould have been taken away; therefore in my Opinion, a ReviÅ¿e is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be done the next day, if not that very day; without which, it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to be fully cerain of what has been done; it is with this, as with all other Works in the World.

div.head: 55. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHen one Å¿ide of an Old Tree, either Dwarf, or Wall-Tree, is extraordinarily Strong and Vigorous, and the other weak and Å¿lender; that is, properly Å¿peaking, when a Tree is Crooked, and diÅ¿agreeable to Å¿ight, it is hard to reduce it to a fine Figure; then a great deal of care muÅ¿t be taken about that Vigorous Å¿ide, in taking away the greateÅ¿t part of the Å¿trong Branches cloÅ¿e to the Stem, whence they Å¿hoot, or cut part of them Stump-wiÅ¿e, in expectation that at laÅ¿t the Sap which inclin'd altogether on that Å¿ide, may turn it Å¿elf towards that weak Å¿ide, at which time we Å¿hall be enabled to begin the Repairs which were wanting.

div.head: 56. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IN all Å¿ort of Trees care muÅ¿t be taken to allow leÅ¿s length to a Wood-Branch, that is Å¿omewhat weak, than to that Wood Branch which is thick and Å¿trong.

div.head: 57. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IT is pretty common in all manner of Trees, eÅ¿pecially when they are pretty Ancient, to find certain weak Branches, which, without having ever born any Fruit, are, as it were, threatned to periÅ¿h for want; therefore it is requiÅ¿ite every year, at the time of the grand Pruning, and even at the time of the Å¿econd, which is perform'd on Stone-Fruits, eÅ¿pecially Wall-Fruit; I Å¿ay it is requiÅ¿ite to take a Å¿pecial Care that Å¿uch Branches may not be without NouriÅ¿hment; to which end, they muÅ¿t be kept Å¿horter, and the number of them diminiÅ¿h'd, and Å¿ometimes it will be fit to take away Å¿ome of the thick ones that are Superior to them; or, if after Å¿uch Branches have BloÅ¿Å¿om'd, that is, have perform'd the main part of their duty, their BloÅ¿Å¿om happens to periÅ¿h, they muÅ¿t be wholly taken away, eÅ¿pecially when there appears no diÅ¿poÅ¿ition in them to Å¿hoot Å¿ome good Branches for the following year.

div.head: 58. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHen a High Branch is taken away over a Lower, that is, as we have already Å¿aid, what we call Lowering, or Shortning of a Tree, it muÅ¿t be cut Å¿o cloÅ¿e, that no part of it may remain; to the end that the place may Å¿oon be cover'd again, and neatly; but when the lower is taken away to preÅ¿erve the higher, we muÅ¿t keep of that low one, at leaÅ¿t the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown Piece, or cut it Å¿lantingly, as we have Å¿aid elÅ¿ewhere, in hopes of a good new Branch.

div.head: 59. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHen a Branch of a good thickneÅ¿s being Prun'd pretty cloÅ¿e, produces nothing but what is weak on its Extremity, it is a Sign that it is upon periÅ¿hing, and that Nature has withdrawn, in favour of another, the yearly Å¿ubÅ¿tance Å¿he us'd to afford it; Å¿o that you muÅ¿t no longer rely upon it for the Beauty of the Tree.

div.head: 60. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IF a Tree being crooked at the time of Planting, produces the firÅ¿t year a fine Å¿treight Branch, as it Å¿ometimes happens, you muÅ¿t Å¿horten the whole Stem to that Branch, there only to fix the Foundation of the Beauty of that Tree.

div.head: 61. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WE may better reÅ¿olve to preÅ¿erve upon a Wall-Fruit-Tree, a thick Branch, not being altogether well plac'd, than upon a Dwarf-Standard; where Å¿uch a Branch might chance to be ill Å¿cituated, by reaÅ¿on of the facility we meet with in Wall-Trees, of turning and winding Å¿uch a Branch at pleaÅ¿ure, or thoÅ¿e that Å¿hall Å¿hoot from it, which cannot be effected in Dwarf-Standards, in which we want the Conveniency of tacking to the Right and Left; and Å¿uch a Branch would make a Dwarf-Standard Å¿how awry: Therefore in a Dwarf-Standard Å¿uch a Branch muÅ¿t be remov'd, whereas with the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Ligatures it might Å¿erve to form a fine Wall-Tree, and therefore Å¿hould be preÅ¿erv'd.

div.head: 62. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: THE common length of Branches for Wood, which I willingly Å¿ix to five, Å¿ix, or Å¿even inches, tho it is to be regulated and proportion'd upon many things, in order to be either more or leÅ¿s extended; for Example, upon the Vigour or WeakneÅ¿s of the whole Tree; upon the ThickneÅ¿s or Mediocrity of the Branch, to be longer where it meets with Vigour and ThickneÅ¿s, and Å¿horter where it does not meet with it: This length is likewiÅ¿e to be regulated upon the Vacuity that is to be fill'd, to be either more or leÅ¿s long, according as the Vacuity is either great or Å¿mall: It muÅ¿t particularly be regulated upon the heighth of the other Branches for Wood of the Å¿ame Tree, to the end, that thoÅ¿e that are newly Prun'd, may be proportion'd to the Old ones.

div.head: 63. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: THere are Å¿ome People who fancy that the Pruning of a Tree does not require much Art; to juÅ¿tifie which, they cite Great Trees that are never Prun'd, as alÅ¿o the Trees of certain Gard'ners, who, without ever having known how to Cut, Prune Å¿o happily, that they do not fail of having abundance of Fruit.

I have no anÅ¿wer to make to thoÅ¿e People, or rather I have Å¿o many things to Å¿ay, that I do not think it worth my while to anÅ¿wer them. PhyÅ¿icians, Lawyers, and moÅ¿t of the Learned in moÅ¿t Arts, Å¿ometimes in their turns, meet with Å¿uch pretended Objections.

div.head: 64. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: WHen a Fine Fruit-Branch Å¿hoots many others, which likewiÅ¿e Å¿eem fit for Fruit, I am for preÅ¿erving of them, when they cauÅ¿e no ConfuÅ¿ion, and the Tree is Vigorous, particularly in Pear-Trees.

div.head: 65. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: IT happens Å¿ometimes, eÅ¿pecially in Wall-Fruit-Trees, that within the CompaÅ¿s of a Branch, which grows Thick and Vigorous the very Summer in which it is produc'd; I Å¿ay, it happens Å¿ometimes, that one or two Thick ones form themÅ¿elves, which are as it were after Shoots; Å¿o that whatever is beyond thoÅ¿e New-comers, drawing towards the Extremity, appears incomparably Å¿maller than what is on the other Å¿ide, drawing towards the Birth of that Mother-Branch; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, thoÅ¿e laÅ¿t Comers muÅ¿t be look'd upon as Branches that commonly will always augment in ThickneÅ¿s, and conÅ¿equently will become real Branches for wood, in the place where they are; for which reaÅ¿on, they muÅ¿t be Prun'd Å¿hort; and as for thoÅ¿e that draw towards the Extremity, they muÅ¿t be look'd upon as Fruit-Branches, which will thicken no more, Nature having directed her CourÅ¿e upon theÅ¿e laÅ¿t made.

div.head: 66. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p:
YOU muÅ¿t not in the leaÅ¿t Å¿cruple the taking lower, even in old Trees, eÅ¿pecially Pear, Apple and Apricock-Trees, certain Sides which, having been ill order'd, prove too long and thin: But I wou'd not, without an abÅ¿olute neceÅ¿Å¿ity, have many thick Branches cut over a very weak one, Å¿hot from the Å¿ame part, though never Å¿o well plac'd for the Figure; too many Inconveniences ariÅ¿ing from it, by reaÅ¿on of the falÅ¿e Wood that commonly grows about that weak Branch; which not being capable of receiving all the Sap that flows towards it, and was deÅ¿tin'd for the NouriÅ¿hment and Maintenance of thoÅ¿e
Å¿uperior Branches that Å¿hall have been cut, that Sap, being neceÅ¿Å¿itated to come out, and conÅ¿equently to force its way in an extraordinary manner, not finding any IÅ¿Å¿ue ready made; that Sap, I Å¿ay, being very abounding, flows out of it diÅ¿orderly and furiouÅ¿ly, like Water having overthrown a Dam that Å¿top'd its CourÅ¿e. Now all thoÅ¿e forc'd and violent IÅ¿Å¿uings produce thoÅ¿e kind of Branches we have heretofore explain'd, giving them the name of FalÅ¿e Wood, or Suckers, and are Å¿uch as do not grow in the moÅ¿t common and ordinary Order Nature follows in the Production of new Branches; and therefore it is fit, as much as poÅ¿Å¿ible can be, to avoid falling into Å¿uch Inconveniencies.

But if you chance Å¿ometimes to be neceÅ¿Å¿itated to cut Å¿uch thick Branches, the Å¿mall Branch not performing here the Operation of a cleft Graff, which Å¿ometimes it does, but often fails, in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e you muÅ¿t reÅ¿olve to make uÅ¿e of one of the Branches of FalÅ¿e. Wood Å¿hot from it, and chuÅ¿e that which is beÅ¿t plac'd, Pruning it according to the common Method, and by that means eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h upon it the Figure of the Tree.

div.head: 67. ObÅ¿ervation.
div.p: ALLthough the Branches that, according to the Order of Nature, Å¿hoot from the Extremities of other Branches are commonly of good Wood, yet Å¿ome of them happen Å¿ometimes not to be Å¿o, eÅ¿pecially growing from the lower part of Branches, which, being originally of FalÅ¿e Wood, have been cut very Å¿hort, or Å¿hooting from a Stump; or elÅ¿e, when in the very Year they only begin to Å¿hoot a long while after the others of the Å¿ame Tree, (this happens but Å¿eldom, unleÅ¿s in VirgoulÃ©-Pears,) which you muÅ¿t not wonder at, and only Prune thoÅ¿e kind of Branches that appear ill-condition'd, leaving them of a moderate length; for you muÅ¿t Å¿eldom allow much length to Å¿uch Branches of FalÅ¿e Wood.

div.head: CHAP. XXX.

argument.p: Particular Remarks for the firÅ¿t Pruning yearly to be Perform'd in February, and March, upon Trees of Stone-Fruit, eÅ¿pecially on Peach and Apricock-Trees, either Dwarf-Standards, or Wall-Trees.

div.p: I Shall not need to inlarge upon this Article, of the firÅ¿t Pruning; having already largely explain'd in General the Rules for all Å¿orts of Pruning: I Å¿hall only obÅ¿erve, that the Fruit-Branches of the Trees above-mention'd, are but of a Å¿mall Continuance, many of them PeriÅ¿hing the very firÅ¿t year in which they have produc'd Fruit, and even without it, their BloÅ¿Å¿oms having been Å¿poil'd, either by Gum, BlaÅ¿ts, or FroÅ¿ts in the Spring; in which CaÅ¿es, they muÅ¿t be wholly taken away, unleÅ¿s they be grown conÅ¿iderably thick, or have Å¿hot Å¿ome fine Branches fit to bear Fruit the following year; for in that CaÅ¿e, they may laÅ¿t two years, and even Å¿ometimes, though very Å¿eldom, three or four; provided they Å¿till Å¿hoot Å¿ome good Branches, either on the Extremity of the laÅ¿t Pruning, or in their extent: But after that, they muÅ¿t only be look'd upon as worn-out Branches, and conÅ¿equently of no uÅ¿e.

It is not Å¿o with the Fruit-Branches of Pear and Apple-Trees; and even Plumb-Trees, both the one and the other laÅ¿ting pretty long, that is, much longer than thoÅ¿e of Peach-Trees, by reaÅ¿on, that in their extent they Å¿hoot very good Å¿mall ones, which regularly produce Fruit; until at laÅ¿t, according to the Nature of Fruit-Branches, they all periÅ¿h intirely.

I may Å¿ay here, without any Vanity, that in following my Method of Pruning Peach-Trees, you may expect to have commonly much finer Trees, more laÅ¿ting, and without doubt much more Fruit, and even much finer than thoÅ¿e who Prune another way, which is Infallible; provided the Weather be fair at the time of the BloÅ¿Å¿om, and the Gum Å¿poil nothing about the Branches, and eÅ¿pecially, that the Trees be Planted in a good Ground. The Curious are much to be pity'd, when their Gardens happen to be in a cold ill Ground, or when the Mould is worn, becauÅ¿e that the Trees Å¿eldom produce any good new Roots there; and conÅ¿equently, abundance of the old ones periÅ¿h, Roots not being able to Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t without Action; which is the ReaÅ¿on that Å¿o much Gum grows both upon the Stem, and upon the Branches, and even upon the Foot, and in the Roots.

The ReaÅ¿on for which I Å¿ay that my Method of Pruning greatly preÅ¿erves and imbeliÅ¿hes the Trees, is becauÅ¿e it preÅ¿cribes the being very careful in keeping pretty Å¿hort all the thick Branches, &c. And as for the abundance of fine Fruits, it depends Infallibly on the other Caution I recommend, of preÅ¿erving all the good Branches for Fruit, without taking away any, and the leaving no more Fruit upon them than they are able to nouriÅ¿h, in order to its being very Beautiful.

When in the Months of February and March, you deÅ¿ign to perform the firÅ¿t Pruning upon Peach-Trees, and that, after having taken away all the Old dry Branches, or Å¿uch, which through an extream weakneÅ¿s, are of no uÅ¿e (for you muÅ¿t begin by this, in order to Å¿ee clearly and diÅ¿tinctly what is to be done) you find only two Å¿orts of good Branches remaining; of which, the one (which are weak ones) are to bear Fruit the following years, the Buds being already form'd; and the others (which are the Å¿trong ones) are not commonly to produce any, not having any Buds upon them, but are to Å¿erve us for another uÅ¿e, which is very material.

TheÅ¿e weak ones are to be preÅ¿erv'd with Care, and even of a great length, by reaÅ¿on of the viÅ¿ible appearance of preÅ¿ent Fruit, but without building any hopes upon moÅ¿t of them for the following year; Nature will afford us others, to Å¿upply the loÅ¿s of thoÅ¿e; but Å¿till care muÅ¿t be taken, that the length of thoÅ¿e Branches be proportion'd to their Å¿trength; being alÅ¿o perÅ¿waded, that a Branch of an ordinary thickneÅ¿s is capable of nouriÅ¿hing a conÅ¿iderable part of the Fruit it Å¿eems diÅ¿pos'd to bear: So that, at the firÅ¿t Pruning, there is no danger in venturing to leave much upon it, provided part be taken away at the Å¿econd, if there be ReaÅ¿on to believe there is too much.

As to the Å¿trong ones, they muÅ¿t particularly be look'd upon in relation to the future, and therefore muÅ¿t be cut Å¿hort, in proÅ¿pect, that, according to the Order of Nature, they will produce others of two kinds; Å¿ome thick ones for Wood, and many Å¿mall ones for Fruit; which will certainly come to paÅ¿s: But, above all, Care muÅ¿t be taken to provide for the Branches that are to fill up the room of thoÅ¿e Å¿lender ones, which, for the time being, produce Å¿o good an Effect, but are, as it were, no longer to be look'd upon as living, Å¿ince, after their having produc'd their Fruit, they muÅ¿t be taken away.

We have Å¿ufficiently explain'd the difference there is between weak Branches, and SapleÅ¿s ones; therefore it will Å¿uffice to Å¿ay, that no long Branches muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd, unleÅ¿s they be of a moderate thickneÅ¿s, and have at the Å¿ame time Fruit-Buds ready form'd for the preÅ¿ent Year. I commonly call none Buds but Å¿uch as are double, with an Eye for Wood in the middle; and I value no others for PreÅ¿erving, unleÅ¿s it be on Troy-Peaches, and early Peaches.

Moreover, no Branch muÅ¿t be Prun'd Å¿hort, unleÅ¿s it be, that, being incapable of bearing Fruit in the preÅ¿ent Year, their Strength or Vigour may promiÅ¿e other Branches for the following Year; or that the Tree having a vaÅ¿t quantity of Fruit-Branches, and very few for Wood, and all thoÅ¿e very high, there may be reaÅ¿on to fear, that Å¿ome of the lower parts, or the middle, may grow too thin for the following Years; in which CaÅ¿e, it is very proper to Å¿acrifice Å¿ome Buds; and to that End, Å¿horten Å¿ome of the fineÅ¿t and thickeÅ¿t among thoÅ¿e that are over-burthen'd by them, and Å¿o make them, as we have Å¿aid elÅ¿ewhere, Demy-Branches for Wood, which is of very good uÅ¿e.

In the mean time we muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve that there are Å¿ome very vigorous Peach-Trees, which commonly are hard to bear Fruit, upon which it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary, as well as upon Å¿ome furious Pear-Trees, to leave Branches of a moderate thickneÅ¿s, long, though they have no Fruit-Buds at all. Such furious Peach-Trees are your Magdalens, Å¿ome white BaÅ¿tard-Peaches, Bourdins, Brugnons, or Latter Violets, &c. that is, when thoÅ¿e Peach-Trees are young: Upon Å¿uch it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to leave Å¿ome long Branches, though without any appearance of Fruit, upon the apparent certainty of their producing a great many other weak Branches for the following Year â¢ ; and though thoÅ¿e Branches be pretty thick, and might be look'd upon as Branches for Wood, yet they are not cut Å¿hort, becauÅ¿e it is probable that in their Neighbourhood there may be other thicker that have been Prun'd for Wood, and that, according to the beÅ¿t Rules, many thick Branches muÅ¿t never be left very near one to another.

ThoÅ¿e different ways of Cutting long or Å¿hort, are the CauÅ¿e that it cannot, and muÅ¿t not be Å¿aid that a Peach-Tree is well Prun'd, unleÅ¿s every Branch; has one of thoÅ¿e two Properties, either actually fit to bear Fruit in the preÅ¿ent Year, or to produce fine Wood the Year following, in thoÅ¿e places where it may be requir'd; and when theÅ¿e two Conditions meet, and are perfectly obÅ¿erv'd, we may Å¿ay that a Peach-Tree is very well Prun'd.

ThoÅ¿e kind of Regards muÅ¿t not only be had at the time of the firÅ¿t Pruning, but, yet particularly, at the time of the Å¿econd and third, if perform'd; and likewiÅ¿e at the time of the Trimming of the Buds, and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches.

The MiÅ¿chief which attends Gum, to which every body knows Peach-Trees are commonly Å¿ubject, and even much beyond all other Stone-Fruits, hinders us from having any certainty that a thick Branch, being Prun'd, will produce others on its Extremity; which is almoÅ¿t infallible in Pear, Plumb, and Apricock-Trees, &c. When Peach-Trees appear attack'd with that Gum, and yet the Owners are willing to preÅ¿erve them Å¿ome Years longer, they muÅ¿t Prune them late, that is, about the time they begin to bloÅ¿Å¿om and Å¿hoot, to be certain of preÅ¿erving, at leaÅ¿t, Å¿ome good Eyes, and Å¿ome good BloÅ¿Å¿oms: There can be no Certainty before that time.

I add farther, that when a Peach-Tree has produc'd no Branch for Wood, it muÅ¿t no longer be conÅ¿ider'd as a Tree to keep, from the time the Fruit has been gather'd; and a SucceÅ¿Å¿or muÅ¿t be provided.

I add beÅ¿ides, that if it happens that an old Peach-Tree, having been Å¿horten'd, has produc'd Å¿everal Branches, which happens but Å¿eldom, unleÅ¿s it be a Tree grown from a Stone, you muÅ¿t begin to Prune it upon thoÅ¿e new Branches, in the Å¿elf-Å¿ame manner as a young Tree is Prun'd; excepting only, that the Branches muÅ¿t be left a little longer, for fear of the Gum.

It is almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible not to be very uneaÅ¿ie at the Pruning of Peach-Trees, either Dwarf-Standards, or Wall-Trees, by reaÅ¿on of an itching deÅ¿ire of preÅ¿erving all the Buds that are ready form'd for the preÅ¿ent Year, and of not depriving ones Å¿elf of a preÅ¿ent Good: But yet, unleÅ¿s you be a little hard-hearted for the preÅ¿ent, in proÅ¿pect of the future, you may aÅ¿Å¿ure your Å¿elves to Å¿ee thoÅ¿e kind of Trees periÅ¿h by your own Fault, or, at leaÅ¿t, become of no uÅ¿e. 'Tis true, that in Å¿o doing, you may perhaps get abundance of Fruit for two or three Years; but it is as true, that after that, you muÅ¿t expect a very great Scarcity, and very ugly Trees.

ThoÅ¿e UneaÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es, or Conflicts, I have mention'd, are only undergone by skilful Gard'ners: Others are not Å¿o much as Å¿enÅ¿ible of the Danger, and Å¿o are liable to no manner of Agitation. The chief CauÅ¿e of DiÅ¿quiet is, particularly, when a weak Branch, that had been left long for Fruit, is grown thick, contrary to the common Order of Vegetation; and that the thick one, which had been cut Å¿hort, in order to Å¿hoot abundance of new ones, is, as it were, abandon'd, and hardly produces any thing. This Alteration generally produces a great DiÅ¿order in a Tree; for thoÅ¿e kind of Branches that are grown thick, have probably Å¿hot a great many Branches for Fruit, which occaÅ¿ions a very great and juÅ¿t CauÅ¿e of Temptation and DeÅ¿ire of preÅ¿erving them all: So that, unleÅ¿s the DeÅ¿ire of having a fine and laÅ¿ting Tree oppoÅ¿es the Itch of preÅ¿erving thoÅ¿e Appearances of preÅ¿ent Fruit, there is a great deal of danger of being overcome by the Temptation; and conÅ¿equently, of making Å¿oon a very ugly Tree, as we have already inÅ¿tanc'd. Therefore it is very material to examine what is moÅ¿t proper to be done in Å¿uch Conjunctures.

It is Å¿ometimes neceÅ¿Å¿ary to take the advantage of Å¿uch a DiÅ¿order, to let the Tree Å¿hoot up, in order to cover the Top of a Wall, which may very well be allow'd of; and in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, there will be no need of taking any of theÅ¿e terrible ReÅ¿olutions: But Å¿ometimes there may be a great deal of danger in Å¿o doing; in which CaÅ¿e, there is a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of reÅ¿olving to Å¿acrifice part of thoÅ¿e fine Appearances of Fruit, without any Mercy, and conÅ¿equently, to Å¿horten Å¿uch Branches extreamly, in proÅ¿pect, that in the following Years you Å¿hall be recompenc'd a hundred times for thoÅ¿e Fruits which, as I may Å¿ay, have been thus cruelly deÅ¿troy'd. This DiÅ¿order happens but Å¿eldom, which is a Comfort; but yet, as it happens Å¿ometimes, I thought my Å¿elf oblig'd to give my Opinion about it.

When Walls are very low, for Example, about Å¿ix or Å¿even Foot high, and yet People deÅ¿ire to have Peach-Trees againÅ¿t them, which, in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, muÅ¿t be Planted at a great diÅ¿tance from one another; when, I Å¿ay, along Å¿uch low Walls Peach-Trees appear to be very vigorous, for the two firÅ¿t Years the thick Branches that are to fill up the Sides muÅ¿t be kept pretty long, becauÅ¿e, that in Pruning of them Å¿hort, they will only Å¿hoot FalÅ¿e-Wood, or Suckers, and Å¿eldom or never produce any Fruit, you may allow them twice the length of what is allow'd to common Wall-Trees, and Å¿ometimes even thrice; that is, a Foot and a half, or Å¿omewhat more.

When a Wall-Tree is reaÅ¿onably vigorous, it muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be allow'd at leaÅ¿t three Foot of Wall free, above the Pruning that is perform'd upon it in the Spring, for the placing of the new Shoots; otherwiÅ¿e the greateÅ¿t part of the principal Branches Å¿hould be of no uÅ¿e, growing over the Top; and there Å¿hould be a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Cutting them often during the Summer, leÅ¿t the great Winds Å¿hould break them: And, beÅ¿ides the Vexation of not enjoying the Benefit of the Vigour of ones Trees, thoÅ¿e Branches thus cut, ever look ungainly upon a Wall-Tree, by the quantity of Furzes that appear at the Extremity of Å¿uch a Tree.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI.

argument.p: Particular Remarks upon the Second and Third Pruning of Stone-Fruit.

div.p: THeÅ¿e Second and Third Prunings are altogether new, and yet are altogether as neceÅ¿Å¿ary and material as the firÅ¿t, and muÅ¿t be perform'd about the middle of May only upon weak Branches: They were left long by the Winter-Pruning, in proÅ¿pect of abundance of Fruit; but whereas they are Å¿ubject to certain CircumÅ¿tances we are going to examine, they made us bethink our Å¿elves of the neceÅ¿Å¿ity of a Å¿econd Operation, and Å¿ometimes of a third.

As to the thick Branches, that have been Prun'd Å¿hort in February or March, they have Å¿ufficiently undergone the DiÅ¿penÅ¿ation of the Knife, they require no more of it, their Function not being to produce any thing that wants Retrenching at this time; but, on the contrary, to Å¿hoot many precious Branches, that deÅ¿erve to be preÅ¿erv'd with much Care.

TheÅ¿e laÅ¿t Prunings, we are now explaining, are of great uÅ¿e for the grand Pruning that is to be perform'd the following Year, in cleanÅ¿ing a Tree from all Å¿uperfluous and half-dead Branches, which wou'd only create a ConfuÅ¿ion: They Strengthen other Branches that will be of uÅ¿e in the Sequel, by affording them the Sap, which wou'd be waÅ¿ted on thoÅ¿e Å¿curvy ones that can never be of any uÅ¿e, and muÅ¿t of CourÅ¿e be taken away the Winter following. It likewiÅ¿e contributes towards the Beauty and GoodneÅ¿s of the Fruit, and Å¿erves to keep a Tree equally well furniÅ¿h'd; Å¿o that, by that means, Å¿eldom, or never, any Defects wou'd appear upon any of thoÅ¿e Peach-Trees, unleÅ¿s they were perÅ¿ecuted by that curÅ¿ed Gum.
TheÅ¿e are the ConÅ¿equences of thoÅ¿e kind of Branches, upon which the above-mention'd Prunings are perform'd. I deÅ¿ire all Gard'ners to follow this DiÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ion exactly.
TheÅ¿e Branches, which I have a particular regard for, in relation to Fruit, Å¿hall have perform'd one of theÅ¿e Å¿ix things.

FirÅ¿t, They may either have produc'd, almoÅ¿t in their whole Extent, a great deal of Fruit and fine Branches, or much Fruit and ugly Branches. By fine Branches here, I mean, Å¿uch as are thick enough to prove Fruit-Branches the following Year, and in the mean time bear abundance of fine Leaves: And, on the contrary, I call thoÅ¿e poor and ugly, that are Å¿hort and Å¿lender, and are incapable of bearing Fruit, only producing Å¿mall Leaves.

Secondly, ThoÅ¿e Fruit-Branches may chance only to have born Fruit upon part of their Length; for Example, the fourth part, third, or half, &c. and to have Å¿hot either fine or ugly Branches every where, or in Å¿ome part; and all this, perchance, towards the upper end, and Å¿ometimes towards the lower.
Thirdly, They may chance to have produc'd no Fruit, but abundance of fine Branches; or many altogether ugly and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s.
Fourthly, They may only have produc'd a Å¿ingle Branch on the Extremity, with abundance of Fruit every where, or without any Fruit any where.
Fifthly, They may only have produc'd one Å¿ingle Fruit on the Extremity, with Å¿ome Branches in part of their Extent.
LaÅ¿tly, They may be kill'd with Gum or Cold in their whole Extent, or only towards the Extremity.
I have had the Experience of all theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es Å¿everal times, in all which I have held the following Method.

In the firÅ¿t part of the firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, in which the Fruit-Branches Å¿hall have produc'd Fruit and fine Branches in the beÅ¿t part of their Extent, we may rejoice at the Abundance; for, without doubt, all will go well, Å¿ince the Appearances are Å¿o fair as far as the Month of May: Some of the Fruit only muÅ¿t be taken away, where it lies Å¿o cloÅ¿e, that we may have cauÅ¿e to believe that, in growing, they might obÅ¿truct each other; for that wou'd Å¿poil it: And likewiÅ¿e, in caÅ¿e any ConfuÅ¿ion be threaten'd by that Multitude of new Branches, Å¿ome of the meaneÅ¿t, and worÅ¿t plac'd, may be remov'd. It is always to be wiÅ¿h'd, that the Lot of being retrench'd may fall upon the fartheÅ¿t.

In the Å¿econd Part of the firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, in which the Branch has produc'd a great deal of Fruit, but no fine Branches; on the contrary, all weak and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s; the beÅ¿t part of the Fruit muÅ¿t be taken away, Å¿ince it wou'd neither grow beautiful nor good; only Å¿ome of that which looks beÅ¿t, and is beÅ¿t plac'd, may be preÅ¿erv'd; that is, that which grows in
the loweÅ¿t part of the Branch. At the Å¿ame time the Å¿aid Branch muÅ¿t be very much Å¿horten'd, to reduce it to the Å¿econd or third Eye or Bud of the bottom, in order to Å¿trengthen Å¿ome of the beÅ¿t Branches that are upon it, for the next Year.

In the Å¿econd CaÅ¿e, in which the Fruit-Branch only produces Fruit upon part of its Length, if the Fruit be grown upon the lower part of it, the Branch muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd, and Å¿horten'd cloÅ¿e to that, among the new ones, which appears fineÅ¿t, and neareÅ¿t to that Fruit; it is enough when there remains one or two paÅ¿Å¿able good ones.

In caÅ¿e the Fruit be pretty abundant, and towards the upper Extremity, that having likewiÅ¿e pretty fine Branches, that Fruit muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be preÅ¿erv'd, and all the uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches remov'd, in the manner aboveÅ¿aid; only preÅ¿erving one or two of thoÅ¿e that appear the fineÅ¿t, whatever part they be in, eÅ¿pecially being in the lower part, where we are always deÅ¿irous of them; for, as to the Fruit, 'tis always well plac'd, where-ever it be, even at the end of the Branches; provided always, that in preÅ¿erving one or two fine Branches on the Extremity of a Fruit-Branch that has been kept of a great length, you muÅ¿t reÅ¿olve the following Year to retrench both the Mother and Daughter, or Daughters, otherwiÅ¿e one part wou'd grow too thin.

In the firÅ¿t part of the third CaÅ¿e, in which the Branch has really produc'd no Fruit, but, to make amends, has Å¿hot a great many fine new Branches; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, it is fit, as much as can be, to preÅ¿erve the beÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e Branches, being careful of not letting any of them grow Å¿tronger than the other, eÅ¿pecially towards the Extremity, for Å¿uch a Branch wou'd ruin all the lower; therefore Å¿uch a Branch muÅ¿t be wholly taken away, and Pinch'd or broken within two or three Eyes, or Buds, as we have heretofore explain'd.

In the Å¿econd Part of that third CaÅ¿e, in which the Fruit-Branch has neither been fortunate in Fruit, nor in Wood of a favourable Growth, you muÅ¿t wholly Å¿horten Å¿uch a Branch, to a Å¿ingle one of thoÅ¿e it has produc'd; and chuÅ¿e the loweÅ¿t, in hopes to Å¿trengthen it, to make it good for the next Year, or take it quite away, it not anÅ¿wering our Intentions.

In the firÅ¿t Part of the Fourth CaÅ¿e, in which the Fruit-Branch has only produc'd a Å¿ingle Branch on the Extremity, with abundance of Fruit every where, I am of Opinion that Å¿uch a Branch Å¿hou'd be preÅ¿erv'd, provided it does not incline to become a Branch for Wood, in which caÅ¿e it muÅ¿t be broken pretty Å¿hort: So that, in caÅ¿e Å¿uch a Branch be but moderately thick, it promiÅ¿es much for the following Year; and as for all the little diminutive Branches, that grow among the Fruit it bears, we Prune them, as we have declar'd in the ExpoÅ¿ition of the Å¿econd CaÅ¿e.

Therefore there is yet more reaÅ¿on to uÅ¿e all the little Branches we meet with here without Fruit in the Extent of the Branch in debate in the Å¿ame manner, being certain that, for the generality, they Å¿hoot no more, being all at a Å¿tand in the Month of June: So that all our Comfort for the following Year lies in the fine Fruit-Branch that offers it Å¿elf here, on the Extremity of the Branch that has bloÅ¿Å¿om'd to no purpoÅ¿e in all its Extent.

In the fifth CaÅ¿e, in which the Branch that was left long, to bear a great deal of Fruit, has yet been Å¿o unfortunate, or abus'd, as not to have retain'd above one or two on the Extremity of it, and yet has Å¿hot Å¿ome Branches in part of its Extent.

Several particular Regards muÅ¿t be had in this CaÅ¿e: For Example, If the Tree, on the other hand, has but little Fruit, for that being one will be tempted, and that with reaÅ¿on, to preÅ¿erve that which is known to be good, in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e it will be proper not to meddle with Å¿uch a Branch; or elÅ¿e, to obÅ¿erve whether the Tree has produc'd a great deal of Fruit in the main; in which CaÅ¿e, no great difficulty muÅ¿t be made of loÅ¿ing Å¿o little, and conÅ¿equently, of Pruning Å¿uch a Branch again Å¿hort, in order to Å¿trengthen Å¿ome other that appears pretty good, and is well plac'd; which we may Å¿tand in need of for the Beauty of the Tree, and for the hopes of future Years.

It will likewiÅ¿e be proper to conÅ¿ider whether the Year be univerÅ¿ally barren, which wou'd hinder the Operation I have been adviÅ¿ing; or whether it be a doubtful Fruit, of which, it wou'd be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to know the kind, either to Å¿uppreÅ¿s, or multiply it, &c. In which CaÅ¿e, it will be fit to preÅ¿erve this Å¿ingle Peach, or thoÅ¿e two Peaches, that are remaining on the top of the Branch in queÅ¿tion, though with Å¿ome Regret, out of a juÅ¿t fear of a future Deformity in that Tree.

For, in fine, the principal thing to be done in the Management of Peach-Trees, is, to prefer the Beauty of the whole Tree, in hopes of a future Abundance; I Å¿ay, to prefer the Beauty of that Tree to a Å¿mall quantity of Fruit, though really preÅ¿ent.

In fine, In the Å¿ixth CaÅ¿e, in which the Branches are deÅ¿troy'd by Gum, or Cold, it is neither difficult to give a good Advice, or to take it; for you muÅ¿t wholly take away all that is dead, and conÅ¿equently uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, and diÅ¿agreeable to Sight, in any part whatever, particularly on the Extremity.

This is my Method for the Second Pruning. If any thing has hinder'd the performing of it about the middle of May, it may be done until the middle of June; Å¿o that even a Third may be perform'd at that time, when on the Second of the middle of May, it has been thought fit to venture Å¿till Å¿ome Lengths of Branches, and Å¿ome Fruits.

It is likewiÅ¿e an Effect of the Second Pruning, to cut all the Å¿mall, Å¿apleÅ¿s Branches, that grow within the compaÅ¿s of the Å¿ine one, which has been produc'd that very Year; as alÅ¿o, to Å¿horten, in September, the Branches of Peach-Trees that are weak, and at a Å¿tand.

I add, that the performing of Å¿uch an Operation is very material, but that unfortunately it is hardly practis'd at all, or, at leaÅ¿t, Å¿o Å¿eldom, either out of LazineÅ¿s, or for want of time; the Gardner having, perhaps, too great a number of Trees, and other Works, that overwhelm him.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII.

argument.p: Of the different Manners of Ordering a Peach-Tree in the Summer-time.

div.p: I ObÅ¿erve, among Gard'ners, three different Methods of Ordering all manner of Peach-Trees in the Summer, in relation to the young Branches they produce. The FirÅ¿t tear or pull off indifferently all thoÅ¿e that grow before and behind, and leave but few others: ThoÅ¿e Å¿eem to me extreamly to blame, and unworthy the ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion they follow.

The Second cut all thoÅ¿e Branches within three or four Eyes, or Buds, and by that means occaÅ¿ion abundance of Fruz, among which there Å¿ometimes grows a little Fruit, but that is pretty rare: BeÅ¿ides that, this Method renders the Trees ugly, and diÅ¿agreeable; and therefore I diÅ¿approve it.

LaÅ¿tly, The Third preÅ¿erve in the Summer all the good Branches, and PalliÅ¿ado them neatly; tarrying to chuÅ¿e the beÅ¿t until the SeaÅ¿on of Pruning: ThoÅ¿e, in my Opinion, are in the right, and I imitate them as much as I can.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII.

argument.p: Of the Triming of Å¿uperfluous needleÅ¿s Buds and Sprigs.

div.p: WHereas Pruning only Å¿erves barely to Å¿horten, or wholly to take away Å¿ome old Branches, that, either by their length, Å¿ituation, or number, annoy a Tree; Å¿o this Triming or Picking, is only to deÅ¿troy, and entirely remove young Branches of the Year, either thick, or Å¿mall, growing improperly, and capable of cauÅ¿ing a ConfuÅ¿ion, or prejudicing either the whole Tree, or only the Branch on which they are grown.

The Time of Pruning, as we have declar'd, is from November, to the End of March; which Pruning muÅ¿t be perform'd regularly every Year; whereas the Time of the Triming is commonly about May and June, and Å¿ometimes July and AuguÅ¿t, and Å¿ometimes it is not done at all; but when there is CauÅ¿e for it, it muÅ¿t not be neglected; and generally it cannot be done too Å¿oon, to prevent the Growth of thoÅ¿e uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Shoots, and conÅ¿equently, the waÅ¿ting a great deal of Sap unprofitably, which might be employ'd to better UÅ¿es: So that when it has been neglected, or not perform'd Å¿oon enough, it muÅ¿t be done late, if poÅ¿Å¿ible, Å¿ince it is better to do a neceÅ¿Å¿ary thing late than never.
