It is not eaÅ¿ie to Å¿et down preciÅ¿ely what Branches muÅ¿t be Å¿o Prun'd, or Trim'd, particularly to Å¿atisfie thoÅ¿e, among the Curious, who know but little, and are only Beginners: But a skilful Gard'ner, who, by the Rules heretofore eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, has form'd to himÅ¿elf the Idea of a fine Tree, and conÅ¿equently muÅ¿t know partly what Branches are requir'd, as well for the Beauty of the Figure, as for Fruit; Å¿uch a Gard'ner, I Å¿ay, muÅ¿t needs, at firÅ¿t Å¿ight, know thoÅ¿e Branches that are no ways anÅ¿werable to the Idea he has conceiv'd, and conÅ¿equently take them away at their very Birth, or at leaÅ¿t from the Moment he perceives them, eÅ¿pecially before the End of Summer; that is, before the Trees have made an end of Å¿hooting, or that Å¿uch Branches are grown thick; otherwiÅ¿e they muÅ¿t remain until the time of Pruning: But, generally Å¿peaking, I may Å¿ay, that this Triming or
Picking, is to retrench or take off all ill-plac'd Branches Å¿hooting from any part whatever, whether good or bad: eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch as cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion, without being proper either for Wood, or Fruit. The Knowledge of the Order in which the Branches grow, whether good or ill, which we have clearly explain'd at the beginning of this TreatiÅ¿e, is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary for this.

Pear-Trees muÅ¿t particularly be look'd to, from the very Beginning of April, to the End, that if, from a Å¿lanting Cut, which was to produce a Branch for Wood outwardly, there Å¿hould grow a thick one inwardly, it may be taken away immediately, in ConÅ¿ideration of the two ReaÅ¿ons which ordain Trimming.

It is likewiÅ¿e neceÅ¿Å¿ary to take away the Branches which hinder others that are better plac'd, and Å¿hould be more uÅ¿eful, from receiving a due NouriÅ¿hment; For Example, Take away high Branches, to favour low ones; by which means they would grow conÅ¿iderable; whereas without Å¿uch a help, they would remain uprofitable, and the Tree would Å¿uffer, both as to the Figure, and the Fruit we expect from it.

This Trimming or Pruning, is perform'd upon young Trees, as well as old ones; and therefore, when a young Tree at once Å¿hoots high and low Branches, with a great Interval or Å¿pace between them, it is proper to take away the higheÅ¿t, when the loweÅ¿t are deÅ¿ign'd to be preÅ¿erv'd; or elÅ¿e the loweÅ¿t, when the others deÅ¿erve it better: Which is not only to be done by way of Trimming, but alÅ¿o by the real way of Pruning, that is, with the Pruning-Knife, when the bare Trimming or Nipping is not Å¿ufficient.

If, upon any Tree whatever, one and the Å¿ame Eye produces two or three Branches, Å¿ome of them muÅ¿t be taken away by way of Nipping off, to better the Condition of the others, as well as to avoid ConfuÅ¿ion.

So that upon a weak Branch, which, from one Eye or Bud, Å¿hoots, for inÅ¿tance, two or three, and all probably weak, I will only preÅ¿erve one, chuÅ¿ing that which appears to be the beÅ¿t, that is, the thickeÅ¿t.

But if, on the contrary, a very vigorous Branch Å¿hoots three from one and the Å¿ame Eye, and that the middlemoÅ¿t appears too Å¿trong, and the worÅ¿t plac'd, I Å¿hall, without doubt, take it away, to Å¿trengthen the two others a little; which may afterwards, the one on one Å¿ide, and the other on the other, prove very Å¿erviceable to the Tree.

So upon very vigorous Trees, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary, at the Nipping off or Trimming, to take away Å¿ome of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Branches, always preÅ¿erving Å¿uch as are Å¿omewhat leÅ¿s, provided they Å¿eem to be good; and eÅ¿pecially, when the thick Branch that has been Prun'd Å¿hoots many, whence ConfuÅ¿ion proceeds, the higheÅ¿t muÅ¿t be taken away, taking Care however not to diÅ¿burthen thoÅ¿e kind of Trees too much, which, by reaÅ¿on of their great Vigour, hardly produce any other but thick Branches; whereas, on the contrary, upon Trees that have not much Vigour, all the Å¿lendereÅ¿t and pooreÅ¿t muÅ¿t be taken off, in order to Å¿trengthen thoÅ¿e that appear Å¿tronger, and yet are not Å¿o Å¿trong as they Å¿hould be.

From thence it is eaÅ¿ie to conclude, that Å¿ome Trees may as well be prejudic'd by Nipping off of them too much, as others by not being Nipp'd off enough: The Gard'ner's Prudence muÅ¿t diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h between thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e great Vigour requires one kind of Nipping off, or Trimming, and thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e WeakneÅ¿s requires another.

I will Å¿ay by the by, that if it be judg'd that many Cyons may be requir'd to Graff Scutcheon-wiÅ¿e, it will be fit to be Å¿omewhat more cautious in the Nipping off of vigorous Trees, which may furniÅ¿h Graffs; Å¿till taking Care that it may not prejudice the Fruit of the following Year.

It happens pretty often, that for want of having Nipp'd off, or PalliÅ¿ado'd prudently, we Å¿ee that, in the ConfuÅ¿ion of Branches, Å¿ome long Å¿lender ones Å¿hoot out; which muÅ¿t be carefully taken away at the SeaÅ¿on of Pruning, or, at leaÅ¿t, Å¿horten'd to an Eye or Bud, being commonly naught.

It likewiÅ¿e commonly happens, that the Branch of a Peach-Tree Å¿hoots others in the very Summer, which has produc'd it, in which CaÅ¿e it muÅ¿t be examin'd and (if very poor) Nipp'd off, or taken away, in any part whatever: But if of a good thickneÅ¿s, having double Eyes, or Buds, Å¿o as to be fit to make a Fruit-Branch, it muÅ¿t be carefully preÅ¿erv'd, though only grown in July. And if the lower part of Å¿uch a Branch Å¿hould produce one of a reaÅ¿onable thickneÅ¿s, Å¿o as to be proper for a Branch for Wood, it muÅ¿t be look'd upon as a very good Omen for the Beauty and PreÅ¿ervation of the Tree: But if, on the contrary, the upper part of Å¿uch a Branch Å¿hould Å¿hoot any which Å¿hould grow Å¿o thick as to be only fit for a Branch for Wood, it muÅ¿t be taken away, as being in a place where we have no occaÅ¿ion for a Branch for Wood; beÅ¿ides, it would prejudice the Mother that produc'd it.

It is not much to be queÅ¿tion'd, but that, as in Pruning a Vine, while in Sap, we viÅ¿ibly loÅ¿e a great deal of Sap through the part Å¿o Prun'd, Å¿o in Fruit-Trees, Å¿ome of the Sap
evaporates, or is waÅ¿ted through the place that is cut at the time of Shooting, which is in the Summer.

It is likewiÅ¿e obÅ¿erv'd in the Pruning of Melons, that a Branch, being Prun'd, produces more new ones than that which was left Unprun'd; and therefore I adviÅ¿e the Pruning of too vigorous Trees late: For it is obÅ¿ervable in Peach-Trees, that a thick, young Branch, having been cut in the Summer-time, Å¿eldom Å¿hoots afterwards, or, at leaÅ¿t, very inconÅ¿iderably, inÅ¿omuch that the end of it blackens and dies; the ConÅ¿equence of which is, that the neighbouring Branches thereby commonly grow the more vigorous. But, indeed, neither this Nipping off, nor the Pinching, or Breaking, do waÅ¿te Sap at this rate; and are Å¿o far from being dangerous Operations to be perform'd in the Summer, as is the Pruning with a Knife, that they are very uÅ¿eful, and often very neceÅ¿Å¿ary.

Though this Nipping off properly relates only to the removing of Buds, it may likewiÅ¿e be underÅ¿tood for the Plucking off of Fruit, eÅ¿pecially Stone-Fruit, when there is too much in one place; this Plucking off being perform'd at the Å¿ame time with the Nipping off: Which Matter I treat of at large in another place, and Å¿o Å¿hall Å¿ay no more of it here.

When any Branch (which Å¿eem'd to be good at the time of Pruning it, and therefore was preÅ¿erv'd) grows poor, for want of a good Supply of new Sap, which happens Å¿ometimes by an inward DiÅ¿order, which could not be prevented; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, there is no other Remedy, than the taking away of Å¿uch a Branch, as Å¿oon as perceiv'd. Sometimes alÅ¿o Å¿ome uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches may have been left by Negligence, or want of Application; which muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be remov'd, as Å¿oon as obÅ¿erv'd: And Å¿uppoÅ¿ing Å¿ome fine Fruit may be left on the Extremity of a Branch that has produc'd no new Wood, which is not common, in that CaÅ¿e the Branch muÅ¿t not be taken off until the Fruit be gather'd; after which, it muÅ¿t be remov'd, Å¿ince it could never be good for any thing.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV.

argument.p: Particular Remarks for another material Operation, to be perform'd in the Summer upon Å¿ome Trees, which is called Pinching, or Breaking.

div.p: PInching, in relation to Gard'ning, is, to break deÅ¿ignedly a tender Sprig of any Plant whatever, and that without the help of any InÅ¿trument, only uÅ¿ing the Nails of two Fingers. This way of Breaking has ever been practis'd upon the Shoots of Melons, Cowcumbers, &c. but I do not know that ever it was practis'd upon any Fruit-Trees; yet I have thought â¢ it to make uÅ¿e of it, though only upon four kind of Fruit-Trees, viz. Pear, Peach, Fig, and Orange-Trees; and I Å¿hall only treat here of what relates to the thick new Branches of vigorous Peach-Trees, and the thick new Branches Å¿hooting from Å¿lit Graffs made upon old Pear-Trees, being Å¿till in a pretty good CaÅ¿e: I will treat in other places of what relates to the Pinching of Orange and Fig-Trees, and even of Strawberry-Plants, and RaddiÅ¿hes run up to Seed, &c.

The ReaÅ¿on which made me imagine this way of Pinching theÅ¿e two Å¿orts of Trees, and that makes me uÅ¿e it pretty often, is, that it being moÅ¿t certain that Fruit Å¿eldom grows upon thick Branches, and commonly upon the weak ones, I thought, if it were poÅ¿Å¿ible to order Matters Å¿o, that the Sap, which is wholly employ'd in producing but one thick Branch, which proves either uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, or cumberÅ¿om; I Å¿ay, if it could be order'd Å¿o, that this Sap might be Å¿o divided as to produce Å¿everal Branches, there is no QueÅ¿tion to be made, but in the Quantity there would be Å¿ome weak ones, or perhaps many, which conÅ¿equently would be proper to bear Fruit inÅ¿tead of that, and, as we have already Å¿aid, the thick Branch would have produc'd no good Effect.

I have found the thing poÅ¿Å¿ible, and that it is requir'd, not only in May, but Å¿ometimes in June and July, to break the thick new Shoots of thoÅ¿e kind of Trees, while yet tender, and as eaÅ¿ie to break as GlaÅ¿s; which is moÅ¿t true.
This Operation is founded upon a ReaÅ¿on which I have explain'd in my Reflections, and therefore is not neceÅ¿Å¿ary here.

Having then, at the time heretofore mention'd, broken Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e thick new Shoots within two or three Eyes, or Buds, I have often obtain'd what I deÅ¿ir'd by it, that is, as many Branches as I had left Eyes; and, indeed, a vigorous Tree cannot have too many,
provided they be good, and well plac'd. Among the Branches proceeding from Å¿uch Pinching, if I may uÅ¿e the ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion, commonly Å¿ome have prov'd weak, and thoÅ¿e have born Fruit; Å¿ome have prov'd pretty Å¿trong, and have been Branches for Wood: If the Sap, which produc'd Å¿uch thick Branches, and form'd them with a lively, vigorous Action, met in its way an ObÅ¿tacle, to Å¿top it Å¿hort in the heighth of its Action, and conÅ¿equently hindring it from following its CourÅ¿e in continuing to riÅ¿e, as it would do, not being hinder'd; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, this Sap, which, in the mean time, cannot ceaÅ¿e acting, being forc'd to get out one way or other, would burÅ¿t out by as many Cranies, or Overtures, as it would find near that place where it was Å¿top'd; or, upon neceÅ¿Å¿ity, would make Å¿ome of it Å¿elf.

But it muÅ¿t be noted, that this Pinching is Å¿eldom to be practis'd upon any but the thick Branches of the Top, which would remain uÅ¿eleÅ¿s by their Situation, and yet would conÅ¿ume abundance of good Sap Å¿uperfluouÅ¿ly; and therefore it ought to be very Å¿eldom us'd upon the thick Branches of the lower part, it being always very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to preÅ¿erve them until the Winter-Pruning, in order to their Å¿hooting Å¿ome others the following Year, Å¿it to fill Å¿uch places as naturally, and for the moÅ¿t part, are but too Å¿ubject to be thin.

It is likewiÅ¿e to be obÅ¿erv'd, that this Pinching, or Breaking off, muÅ¿t never be perform'd upon weak Branches; which, having no more Sap than they want, to be good, would only produce Å¿lender, SapleÅ¿s ones in that place, where the Å¿mall Portion of Sap which Nature allows them Å¿hould be divided.

And therefore nothing muÅ¿t be broken upon Å¿uch Trees as produce but too many of thoÅ¿e weak Branches, and few of thoÅ¿e good thick ones: There are Å¿ome of this Character to be found among all kind of Peach-Trees.

The beÅ¿t time for Pinching, particularly in cold Climes, like ours of Paris, and the Neighbourhood of it, as we have already Å¿aid, is, at the End of May, and the Beginning of June; and when neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be perform'd a Å¿econd time, the time of the SolÅ¿tice, or longeÅ¿t Days of the Year, is admirable for it, as well as to Water Å¿ome Trees in a dry Soil, when Rain is wanting; at which time there is a wonderful re-doubling of Action in the Roots, and conÅ¿equently in the Branches; that being, indeed, the time of the greateÅ¿t Effort of all the Spring.

We have already obÅ¿erv'd, that the firÅ¿t Fury of Stone-Fruits begins to appear at the Full-Moon of April, which commonly falls out in May; and we are going to Å¿ee another kind of Fury at the FirÅ¿t Quarter of the Moon of the Å¿aid Month of May; both which times are good for Pinching: And, indeed, we obÅ¿erve, that all the Branches of every Tree do not begin to Å¿hoot vigorouÅ¿ly at the Å¿ame time; Å¿o that what has not been Pinch'd or broken off at the firÅ¿t SeaÅ¿on, may be done at the Å¿econd.

I have Å¿aid, that the beÅ¿t time to Pinch the thick new Branches of Peach-Trees, was, at the time they are eaÅ¿ie to break at the leaÅ¿t pull, without being oblig'd to uÅ¿e a Knife to Å¿horten them: From thence it is eaÅ¿ie to judge, that I have found it dangerous to uÅ¿e InÅ¿truments to cut Å¿uch Branches, which is true; for, as I have Å¿aid heretofore, the Extremity or End of Å¿uch Branches Å¿o cut, is apt to blacken and die, it certainly not producing the Å¿ame Effect with that which proceeds from the Action of Pinching. The Å¿ame thing may be Å¿aid of the thick, tender Branches, proceeding from the Graff's of Pear-Trees, made upon a thick, vigorous Stock; however, Experience teaches us, that the Knife is not Å¿o dangerous upon theÅ¿e, as upon thoÅ¿e of Peach-Trees.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV.

argument.p: Of what is to be done to Å¿ome Trees, being extraordinarily vigorous, not Bearing of Fruit.

div.p: THere Å¿till remains to Å¿ee what is to be done in relation to Å¿ome Trees being extraordinary vigorous, to that degree, that they remain Å¿ometimes many Years, only producing much Wood, and little Fruit, and pretty often none at all, as moÅ¿t Pear and Apple-Trees are, being Graffed upon free Stocks; and particularly, how to preÅ¿erve a Tree producing only Å¿mall Shoots, and moÅ¿t of them of falÅ¿e Wood, or which yearly Å¿hews its Infirmity at the end of iss Branches, and by the colour of its Leaves.

As to the very vigorous Tree, particularly in queÅ¿tion here, many People propoÅ¿e, as Å¿overaign and infallible, abundance of Expedients and Remedies, which I have tried a long while, with great Application; yet, upon my Word, without the leaÅ¿t SucceÅ¿s.

To bore a Hole through the Stem of a Tree, and put a Peg of dry Oak into it; to Å¿plit one of the main Roots, and put a Stone into it; to Prune at the time of the Declinings of the Moon, &c. are wretched Secrets of good old People, infatuated with old Maxims; People who have but little Skill in Vegetation, and are eaÅ¿ily Å¿atisfy'd.

For my part, beÅ¿ides my being perÅ¿uaded by Experience, that my manner of Pruning often prevents the Difficulty now in queÅ¿tion, I have moreover, in caÅ¿e of great ObÅ¿tinacy, recourÅ¿e to what I have Å¿aid elÅ¿ewhere, it being really the beÅ¿t thing that can be done; which is, that, as conÅ¿tantly the Fruit on Trees, is only an Effect, or, at leaÅ¿t, a Mark of a certain moderate WeakneÅ¿s, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary, without minding a thouÅ¿and Trifles, to go to the Source of the Vigour of the Tree, that is, to the Roots, uncovering half of them, and cutting off one, two, or three of the thickeÅ¿t on that Å¿ide, and conÅ¿equently the moÅ¿t active; inÅ¿omuch that the leaÅ¿t part of them may not remain, to be capable of acting, or producing the leaÅ¿t Thread of a capilar Root: The Roots of the other Moity, (for I Å¿uppoÅ¿e there may be good ones; otherwiÅ¿e, Å¿o many muÅ¿t not be taken away from the Side uncovered;) the Roots, I Å¿ay, of the other Moity, left untouch'd, will be Å¿ufficient to nouriÅ¿h the whole Tree.

This Remedy is infallible to prevent Å¿uch Trees from being, as it were, reÅ¿ty to our Cares and InduÅ¿try, and will Å¿oon make them produce Fruit; by reaÅ¿on that this will put a Å¿top to the Production of the Sap, Å¿o that it Å¿hall not be Å¿o abounding as before, one, two, or three of the chief Workers being remov'd; and thus the weak Branches will only receive a moderate NouriÅ¿hment, and the Buds begun, inÅ¿tead of extending, will grow round, and conÅ¿equently turn to Fruit-Buds, will BloÅ¿Å¿om, and finally yield what is deÅ¿ired of them.
PhiloÅ¿ophers may CriticiÅ¿e upon, and explain this as they pleaÅ¿e; but Å¿till it is moÅ¿t certain, that the thing happens as I have Å¿aid.

To Root up Å¿uch Trees, and re-plant them immediately, with the main part of their Roots and Branches, either in the Å¿ame place, or in another, as Å¿ome Authors propoÅ¿e it, is Å¿ometimes an effectual Remedy; but it Å¿eems to me Å¿omewhat too violent, Å¿ince Å¿ometimes it threatens Death, and often makes an ugly Tree, which, in my Opinion, is as great a Defect as the other; for which reaÅ¿on I uÅ¿e it but Å¿eldom, though Å¿ometimes I do.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI.

argument.p: Of the Conduct, or Culture of Fig-Trees.

div.p: AFter having Å¿aid in another place, and that after a long Experience, that a ripe Fig, according to my Pallat, is the beÅ¿t of all the Fruits growing upon Trees, that hitherto I have met with; and, indeed, is look'd upon as being the moÅ¿t delicious, by all judicious PerÅ¿ons; I thought my Å¿elf oblig'd, in this general TreatiÅ¿e of the Culture of Fruits, to make a particular one for the Conduct of this.

Before I enter upon this matter, I cannot forbear expreÅ¿Å¿ing my AÅ¿toniÅ¿hment, conÅ¿idering that notwithÅ¿tanding the Å¿ingular EÅ¿teem moÅ¿t People have for good Figs, it was a general CuÅ¿tom in this Country to have but a very Å¿mall quantity of them in each Garden, not exceeding two or three at moÅ¿t, and even thoÅ¿e commonly abandon'd in Å¿ome inner Yard, expos'd to all manner of ill Treatment, without the leaÅ¿t Culture. Indeed, in warmer Climates they are better, and more honourably treated; there are always abundance of them, not only in Gardens, and under the Å¿helter of a HouÅ¿e, but particularly in Vine-yards, in Hedges, and in the open Fields; and they make a conÅ¿iderable Trade of thoÅ¿e that are preÅ¿erv'd, and dry'd, which I do not mention here.

I am Å¿enÅ¿ible, that the difficulty of preÅ¿erving Fig-Trees from the great Colds of the Winter, is the chief ReaÅ¿on for which we have Å¿o few of them in our Climates; but yet, conÅ¿idering the ConÅ¿equence and Merit of their Fruit, in my Opinion, People Å¿hould have made it their Study, a little more than they have done, to enjoy, to a higher degree, that rich PreÅ¿ent of Nature.

It is not neceÅ¿Å¿ary to repeat here what I have Å¿aid at large in the TreatiÅ¿e of the Choice and Proportion of Fruits, touching the DiverÅ¿ity of the Kinds of Figs, nor of my preferring the white ones, whether long, or round, for this Country, to all the others: Neither will I repeat what I have Å¿aid, as to the Situation which is moÅ¿t proper for them.

I Å¿hall only relate the manner of my Cultivating of them; and eÅ¿pecially, how that, notwithÅ¿tanding the ill CuÅ¿tom, which made us be Å¿atisfy'd with a few of them, I have
apply'd my Å¿elf to the breeding of many; and that not only by the common Way of Planting them in EÅ¿paliers, or againÅ¿t Walls, but alÅ¿o in an extraordinary manner, that is, in CaÅ¿es, which is both pretty new, pleaÅ¿ant and uÅ¿eful; which, if I may be allow'd to introduce a new ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion, may be call'd a Figuerie, in imitation of Orangeries.

The Delight His MajeÅ¿ty takes in that Fruit, and the danger of Dying, to which all Fig-Trees are expos'd in the open Ground, in great FroÅ¿ts, or, at leaÅ¿t, of bearing no Fruit that Year, have been two powerful Motives for me, who am honour'd with the Place of Director of all the Fruit and Kitchen-Gardens belonging to the Royal Family, to induce me to bethink my Å¿elf of the Means of Certainly having a great many Figs every Year.

In the performance of which, I have met with very little difficulty; for, in the firÅ¿t place, the common Mould of every Garden, mix'd with an equal quantity of Soil or Å¿mall Dung, turn'd to Mould, is extraordinary good for it. Secondly, The Roots of Fig-Trees, inÅ¿tead of being hard and thick, like thoÅ¿e of other Fruit-Trees, either Stone, or Kernel, on the contrary, remain Å¿oft and flexible, and commonly Å¿lender, and Å¿o are eaÅ¿ily order'd in CaÅ¿es, and even with more caÅ¿e than thoÅ¿e of Orange-Trees, which thrive Å¿o well in them. Thirdly, TheÅ¿e kind of Trees naturally produce abundance of Roots; Å¿o that it is very caÅ¿ie for them to live fatly and vigorouÅ¿ly in a Å¿mall quantity or Å¿pace of Ground, provided MoiÅ¿ture be not wanting. BeÅ¿ides, the univerÅ¿al Approbation I have met with in this Undertaking, and the Imitation that has follow'd it by many of the Curious, have encourag'd me to make a conÅ¿iderable progreÅ¿s in this Figuerie, or Fig-Garden; and that which has moÅ¿t induc'd me to proceed in it, is, that the Fruit ripens a great deal Å¿ooner here than in the main Ground, and is Å¿omewhat better, and yellower, the Earth which is eaÅ¿ily heated in the CaÅ¿es, producing the firÅ¿t good Effect, and the open Air the two others.

To which I might add, the pleaÅ¿ure of Å¿eeing in this Country abundance of Fig-Trees in the open Air, (which Å¿eem'd to be altogether reÅ¿erv'd for hot Countries,) and that of being, in the Summer, in the middle of a Wood, abounding with Figs; there to chuÅ¿e and gather the Å¿ineÅ¿t and ripeÅ¿t, without any trouble.

Therefore I have bred abundance of Fig-Trees in CaÅ¿es, having found that, beÅ¿ides the Advantages above related, there was yet another which is very conÅ¿iderable; and that is, that, to preÅ¿erve them Å¿ecurely, and with EaÅ¿e, in the Winter, an ordinary Covering to keep off the great FroÅ¿t is Å¿ufficient, that Covering or Shelter not being near Å¿o conÅ¿iderable as thoÅ¿e for Orange-Trees and JeÅ¿Å¿emins, theÅ¿e both Å¿tripping or caÅ¿ting their Leaves at the leaÅ¿t Cold, by which they are almoÅ¿t utterly Å¿poil'd; every body knowing, that a Fall of Leaves, proceeding from the Rigour of Cold, or too much MoiÅ¿ture, denotes, in thoÅ¿e Trees, at leaÅ¿t, a great Infirmity in the Branches Å¿o Å¿tripp'd, inÅ¿omuch that it is almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible to recover them; whereas we have no Leaves to preÅ¿erve on our Fig-Trees, it is only Wood, I mean Branches, of which the Wood is pretty courÅ¿e, though extreamly Pithy, or Sappy; inÅ¿omuch, that it reÅ¿iÅ¿ts the Cold much better than Orange-Trees, it being certain that this Wood, which of it Å¿elf is pretty tender, notwithÅ¿tanding, dries up at the uÅ¿ual Fall of the Leaves, and conÅ¿equently grows hard; the reaÅ¿on of which is, that the Roots of Fig-Trees ceaÅ¿ing to act within, from the time the Leaves begin to fall on the out-Å¿ide, the Wood no longer receiving any new Sap, ceaÅ¿es to fear the Rigour of the SeaÅ¿on; whereas the Wood of the Orange-Trees and JeÅ¿Å¿amins, by the perpetual Operation of their Roots, remains as tender in the Winter as it is all the reÅ¿t of the Year: Which is the reaÅ¿on that, as the Sap continually riÅ¿es, particularly for the NouriÅ¿hment of thoÅ¿e Leaves that remain upon the Branches, as well as for the NouriÅ¿hment of the Branches themÅ¿elves; that Sap, at that time, as it were, keeps both the one and the other Å¿o Å¿enÅ¿ible to FroÅ¿t and MoiÅ¿ture, that thereby they often fall into thoÅ¿e great DiÅ¿orders, known by every body, which are almoÅ¿t the greateÅ¿t they are liable to.

It being then granted, that, for the preÅ¿ervation of our Fig-Trees, it is Å¿ufficient that the great FroÅ¿t Å¿hould not light directly upon their Branches, it follows from thence, that it is Å¿ufficient for the ConÅ¿ervatory to be reaÅ¿onably cloÅ¿e, as well at the top, as at the Doors and Windows; inÅ¿omuch that the Ground may have been pretty well frozen in the CaÅ¿es, and yet the Fig-Tree receive no prejudice by it: So that a moderate low Cellar, or a Stable, or a Common-Hall, which would be Å¿o pernicious to Orange-Trees and JeÅ¿Å¿emins, may not be amiÅ¿s for our Fig-Trees; not but if that place were very moiÅ¿t, it might harm them: As alÅ¿o a Cas'd Fig-Tree, remaining in the Winter without a Covering, would be much more endanger'd than another in the main Ground; for a thick FroÅ¿t would kill the Roots, as well as the Head; whereas a Fig-Tree, planted in open Ground, would, at leaÅ¿t, be preÅ¿erv'd towards the Roots.

The Time of putting Fig-Trees in the ConÅ¿ervatories, is the Month of November; that is, they muÅ¿t be plac'd there as Å¿oon as the thick or great FroÅ¿ts are coming on, there to re|
without wanting the leaÅ¿t Culture, or any Care, beÅ¿ides the keeping of the place as cloÅ¿e as can be, and that only during the great Colds; for, excepting that time, they need not be kept Å¿o cloÅ¿e.

LaÅ¿tly, They may be taken out again about the middle of March, and Å¿ometimes at the very beginning, the Weather being very fair, and the SeaÅ¿ons of great FroÅ¿ts appearing, in Å¿ome manner, paÅ¿t: There is no need of Å¿taying, till there is nothing at all to fear, for the new Figs; for then there would be a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Å¿taying until the end of April; it happening pretty often, that, until that time, there are certain FroÅ¿ts, which blacken and kill them, though reaÅ¿onably thick. The reaÅ¿on which obliges to take them out Å¿ooner, is, that it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary Fig-Trees Å¿hould immediately enjoy the Rays of the Sun, and Å¿ome Å¿oft Showers of March and April, in order to be able to Å¿hoot their firÅ¿t Fruit with Å¿ucceÅ¿s, to the end, above all things, that thoÅ¿e Fruits may inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly be us'd to the open Air; which muÅ¿t make them grow, and ripen betimes; it being moÅ¿t certain, that the Figs which grow under Covert, coming into the open Air, are apt to blacken, and Å¿o periÅ¿h, even without any FroÅ¿t, or conÅ¿iderable Cold; a North-EaÅ¿t Wind, or exceÅ¿Å¿ive Heat, in the firÅ¿t Days of their coming out, deÅ¿troying them without Redemption: Whereas thoÅ¿e Figs that have been a little enur'd to the Air, have harden'd themÅ¿elves Å¿o, as to be able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t, notwithÅ¿tanding the Intemperature of the SeaÅ¿on.

In taking the Fig-Trees out of the ConÅ¿ervatory, at the time prefix'd, there are only two things to be done: The firÅ¿t is, to put them immediately along, and as cloÅ¿e as can be to Å¿ome good Walls, expos'd to the South or EaÅ¿t; and there leave them, until the Full-Moon of April be paÅ¿t, which is about the beginning of May. This Å¿ituation is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary for them, to enjoy the AÅ¿pect of the Father of Vegetation, and be Å¿oak'd by the Rains of the Spring, as well as to find Å¿ome Shelter againÅ¿t the Morning-FroÅ¿ts of the Remains of Winter, which are thoÅ¿e of March and April; becauÅ¿e that, whereas this wonderful Fruit Å¿hoots out at that time, ready form'd, from the Body of the Branch; preÅ¿enting it Å¿elf thus, all on the Å¿udden, without the help of any Covering, or being accompany'd with BloÅ¿Å¿oms, or Leaves, it muÅ¿t needs be very tender in the firÅ¿t Days of its Birth; and therefore Å¿uch FroÅ¿ts, which are very common and frequent at thoÅ¿e times, falling then upon them, would prove very dangerous, or rather mortal; inÅ¿omuch that, though this Shelter be favourable to Fig-Trees, both to Å¿uch that are planted in the Ground, as well as to thoÅ¿e that are in CaÅ¿es, yet, notwithÅ¿tanding, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to cover them with Sheets, or Straw, or long dry Dung, or Peas-Cods, when-ever they Å¿eem to be threaten'd by Å¿ome FroÅ¿t: The cold North-WeÅ¿t Winds, North, and North-EaÅ¿t, or Å¿ome Ha â¢â¢ , or melted Snow, Å¿eldom fail to occaÅ¿ion it in the Night, after having commonly fore-told it the Day before: Woe to the Gard'ner who neglects, or does not improve the Signal of Å¿uch an ill Omen.

The Å¿econd thing that is to be done, after having remov'd Fig-Trees out of the ConÅ¿ervatory, and having thus plac'd them under Å¿helter, is, (to uÅ¿e the PhraÅ¿e of Gard'ners) to give them a good Wetting in every CaÅ¿e; which is, one good Å¿ubÅ¿tantial Watering; inÅ¿omuch that all the Moat may be Å¿oak'd by it; and there Å¿hall hardly need any more Watering, until, with Å¿ome Leaves, the Fruit begins to appear all together, and even a little thick, which is about the middle of April; the Spring-Rains will Å¿upply other Waterings, but this firÅ¿t Watering is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary, to Å¿oak the Ground a-new, which, after four or five Months Confinement, was grown quite dry; otherwiÅ¿e the Roots, at the coming in of the hot Weather, Å¿hould not be capable, for want of MoiÅ¿ture, to renew their Action; and conÅ¿equently, there Å¿hould be no good Motion of Vegetation, either to nouriÅ¿h and thicken that new Fruit the Å¿ooner, or to afford us the Å¿ooner Leaves, and new Wood; with a Certainty, that the Å¿ooner Fig-Trees Å¿hoot in the Spring, the Å¿ooner we Å¿hall have the Å¿econd Figs of Autumn. I will take notice by the by here, that the firÅ¿t Figs grow independently from the Action of the Roots, juÅ¿t as the BloÅ¿Å¿oms of other Fruit-Trees open; and produce their firÅ¿t Buds independently, from the Action of their Roots.

LaÅ¿tly, The Cold, that is the great Enemy of thoÅ¿e Figs, being gone, which happens commonly about the middle of May, the CaÅ¿es muÅ¿t be remov'd from that Shelter, and put Å¿omewhat at large, to be in the open Air, eÅ¿pecially in Å¿ome little Garden, well Å¿urrounded with good Walls; they may be diÅ¿pos'd Å¿o, as to border, or form Allies on both Å¿ides, or elÅ¿e a little green Wood, as I do, when there are enough for it; which is that I call, and ought to be call'd, a Figuerie, or Fig-Garden.

As Å¿oon as theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es are thus diÅ¿pos'd of, they muÅ¿t be allow'd another good Watering, the Å¿ame to be continu'd once a Week, until the end of May; after which, they muÅ¿t be Water'd, at leaÅ¿t, twice a Week; and laÅ¿tly, towards the middle of June, they muÅ¿t receive great and frequent Waterings, almoÅ¿t once a Day.

But, before I come to this, in order to gain Time, and to get with eaÅ¿e a great many Fig-Trees, for the EÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment and Maintenance of my Fig-Garden, I begin by making, towards the middle of March, an ordinary Bed, or Colich, of good Dung, of about three Foot high, in proportion to four or five Foot in Breadth, and as much in Length as my OccaÅ¿ion requires: I let the great Heat of it paÅ¿s, which commonly laÅ¿ts five or Å¿ix Days; after which, having provided Earthen Pots about five or Å¿ix Inches Diameter, or Å¿mall CaÅ¿es about Å¿even or eight: I fill thoÅ¿e Pots, or CaÅ¿es, with the Mould of the Garden, mix'd, as I have Å¿aid, with an equal quantity of Soil or Å¿mall, old, conÅ¿ummated Dung, or with nothing elÅ¿e; that Soil being very good for the firÅ¿t Multiplication of Roots, but would not be Å¿o good for the other CaÅ¿ings. Care muÅ¿t be taken to preÅ¿s that Earth very cloÅ¿e into the bottom of the Pot, as well as in the bottom of the CaÅ¿e; it will Å¿uffice to have two or three Inches looÅ¿e on the top.

After this, I take Å¿mall Fig-Trees, altogether Rooted, and after having extreamly Å¿horten'd all their Roots, I put them, about three or four Inehes deep, into the Å¿aid Pots, or CaÅ¿es, allowing each but about four or five Inches Stem: (Fig-Trees in CaÅ¿es cannot be too Å¿hort body'd:) Afterwards I put the Å¿aid Pots, or CaÅ¿es, up to the Middle in the aforeÅ¿aid Bed. A conÅ¿iderable part of thoÅ¿e Fig-Trees, Å¿o Planted, commonly take, and produce, that very Year, Å¿ome pretty fine Shoots, and in a pretty good number; provided, as is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary, they be well Water'd during the Summer, and that the Bed has been heated twice or thrice on the Å¿ides, to keep it always reaÅ¿onably hot.

When I make uÅ¿e of Pots, I take out of the Pots, that very Summer, or, at leaÅ¿t, in Autumn, or the following Spring, thoÅ¿e little Fig-Trees that have Å¿hot well in thoÅ¿e Pots, to put them together, with the Mote into CaÅ¿es, of about Å¿even or eight Inches, fill'd up with the prepar'd Earth; which, above all, as I have already Å¿aid, muÅ¿t have been preÅ¿s'd cloÅ¿e into the bottom, to hinder that Mote, and the new Roots that Å¿hall grow, from deÅ¿cending too Å¿oon, and too eaÅ¿ily, into that Bottom; and to do it yet more effectually, in CaÅ¿ing of them, I obÅ¿erve the Å¿ame Method as in CaÅ¿ing of Orange-Trees, excepting only RubbiÅ¿h, and pieces of old and dry PlaiÅ¿ter, which are no wiÅ¿e neceÅ¿Å¿ary here; that is, I Plant theÅ¿e Fig-Trees in Å¿uch a manner, that the Superficies of the Mote, may exceed the Edge of the CaÅ¿e about two or three Inches; and, with Douves put on the Å¿ides, I keep in the Earth, and the Water of the Waterings, Å¿o that none of it can be waÅ¿ted; the weight of the CaÅ¿es, and eÅ¿pecially the frequent Waterings, together with the moving or tranÅ¿porting of the Fig-Trees Å¿o CaÅ¿ed Å¿inking the Surface but too Å¿oon.

Great Care being taken to Water thoÅ¿e young Fig-Trees, in thoÅ¿e little CaÅ¿es, they begin pretty often to produce Fruit in them the very Year of their being Cas'd; at leaÅ¿t, they are in a Condition to produce Å¿ome the following Years. They muÅ¿t be kept two Years in thoÅ¿e kind of little CaÅ¿es, in order to be put next into larger, of about thirteen or fourteen Inches in the in-Å¿ide; in order to which, two thirds of the Mote, muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be taken away, Planting them eÅ¿pecially, as I have already Å¿aid, a little high, and preÅ¿Å¿ing the Ground, as cloÅ¿e as can be, into the Bottom: Which things muÅ¿t all be done of neceÅ¿Å¿ity, at every Removal out of the CaÅ¿es.

They are to remain in theÅ¿e, until there be a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of changing them a-new: which muÅ¿t be done as Å¿oon as the Fig-Trees are obÅ¿erv'd to Å¿hoot no more thick Wood, which commonly happens at the end of the third or fourth Year after their being Cas'd: At which time they muÅ¿t be taken out of thoÅ¿e CheÅ¿ts, and, after having perform'd the Operations heretofore explain'd, put again either into the Å¿ame CaÅ¿es, if, after having Å¿erv'd three or four Years, they are Å¿till good enough; which happens but Å¿eldom, the great Waterings rotting many of them; or into other new CaÅ¿es of the Å¿ame Size.

ThoÅ¿e Fig-Trees muÅ¿t be left three or four Years longer in thoÅ¿e kind of CaÅ¿es, being about thirteen or fourteen Inches in the in-Å¿ide; and afterwards, as Å¿oon as it is obÅ¿ervable, by the Marks above explain'd, that there is a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of changing them, the Å¿ame Method as before muÅ¿t be us'd, to put them into other CaÅ¿es of Å¿eventeen or eighteen Inches; in which they muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be preÅ¿erv'd for the Å¿pace of three or four Years; at the end of which, they muÅ¿t be remov'd again, for the fourth time, in the manner aforeÅ¿aid, either into the Å¿ame CaÅ¿es, or into others of the Å¿ame Size.
