But then, the only Remedy, when the bottom of the CaÅ¿es has touch'd the Ground in the Summer time, the Roots of the Fig-Tree having extreamly multiply'd there, and the Trees being really the better for it, Å¿o as not to Å¿tand in need of Å¿uch frequent Waterings, though, at the Å¿ame time, it rots the CaÅ¿es the Å¿ooner; the bottom of the CaÅ¿es having thus touch'd the Ground, it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary, before they are put in the ConÅ¿ervatory, to cut all thoÅ¿e Roots well; or, at leaÅ¿t, it muÅ¿t be done at the Taking them out again, before they are carry'd to the place where they are to remain all the Summer; for whatever part of them has been expos'd to the Air, abÅ¿olutely Å¿poils: But, after having taken off what is Å¿poil'd, thoÅ¿e very CaÅ¿es, being again put upon the Ground, the Roots will multiply again, more than the Year before. And it is not amiÅ¿s to Å¿acrifice thus Å¿ome CaÅ¿es, eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch as begin to be old, and of which the Fig-Trees have been long Cas'd.

Moreover, Whereas the firÅ¿t Figs may always ripen, whatever Situation they be in, the Heats of the Summer being Å¿ufficient for that, it induces me to place Fig-Trees willingly into the WeÅ¿t Part, and pretty often likewiÅ¿e to the North; by which means I have Figs much longer, thoÅ¿e that are plac'd in thoÅ¿e indifferent Situations ripening after the others; Å¿o that they almoÅ¿t Å¿upply the Interval, between the FirÅ¿t, and the Second: In which I adviÅ¿e others to imitate me; but yet, upon condition, not to expect Autumn-Figs from Å¿uch Situations, unleÅ¿s the SeaÅ¿on proves extraordinary fine and dry. And when Fig-Trees have been plac'd in Å¿uch ExpoÅ¿itions, or Situations, great Care muÅ¿t be taken to cover them yet better in the Winter, than thoÅ¿e that were plac'd in the other Situations.

Particular Precautions muÅ¿t be had for Fig-Trees Planted in the Ground; eÅ¿pecally, not to place them under the Spouts of great Coverings, which might threaten them with too much Water, and particularly, with a great deal of mizling FroÅ¿t, as well in the Winter, as in the Spring: And in caÅ¿e there be no other place proper to Plant them in, thoÅ¿e Spouts muÅ¿t be turn'd Å¿ome other way, by means of Å¿ome Wooden or Leaden Gutter.

As to the Method of Pruning Dwarf-Standard Fig-Trees, there is nothing to be added to what we have already Å¿aid of thoÅ¿e that are Planted againÅ¿t Walls, or in CaÅ¿es. The Dwarf-Standards will not produce Figs, altogether Å¿o Å¿oon as thoÅ¿e Fig-Trees that are well Expos'd, and even later than thoÅ¿e that are in CaÅ¿es: which being heated by the Sun, on all Å¿ides of the CaÅ¿e, ripen, as we have already Å¿aid, a little Å¿ooner than the Dwarf-Standards, and even Å¿ooner than the EÅ¿paliers. ThoÅ¿e Dwarfs will likewiÅ¿e be a little troubleÅ¿om for the Coverings of the Winter, and therefore it is dangerous to have any of thoÅ¿e, unleÅ¿s it be in very little, private places, and thoÅ¿e Å¿helter'd from great FroÅ¿ts: they will likewiÅ¿e be apt to cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion, if, being in a good Soil, Endeavours be us'd to keep them low, and to hinder them at the Å¿ame time, from producing great Shoots: For which reaÅ¿on, it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Pinch them carefully, and to have always Å¿ome thick Branches, Prun'd low; and finally, to clear and free them often, as well from Å¿o many old worn out Branches, as from all new Suckers.

To that End, Å¿uch Dwarf-Standards muÅ¿t always be kept at a very conÅ¿iderable diÅ¿tance from each other, in order to lay a great many Branches yearly into the Ground, thereby to eaÅ¿e the whole Body of the Tree, Å¿uffering it to grow in breadth as much as it pleaÅ¿es. As to their Coverings, Care muÅ¿t be taken, at the End of Autumn, firÅ¿t to aÅ¿Å¿emble and cloÅ¿e their Branches together with Oziers, and Poles, fix'd into the Ground, that they may form a kind of Bowl, or Pyramid; cloÅ¿ing it afterwards with long, dry Dung, as we have done to Fig-Trees in EÅ¿paliers; but yet they muÅ¿t not be uncover'd quite, altogether Å¿o Å¿oon as the others that are Å¿helter'd by a Wall; and the Coverings muÅ¿t, by all means, be renew'd, during the Spring.

After having explain'd my Method, as well as poÅ¿Å¿ible I can, as well for the Pruning of all kinds of young Trees, during the four or five firÅ¿t Years of their being Planted, as for the Trimming for the Buds, and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Sprigs, and Pinching of Å¿uch as may Å¿tand in need of it, having alÅ¿o explain'd my Method, as to the Culture of Fig-Trees, planted either in the open Ground, or CaÅ¿es; I now proceed, according to my PromiÅ¿e, to explain, with the Å¿ame ExactneÅ¿s, my Opinion, as to the Pruning of old Trees.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII.

argument.p: Of the Manner of Pruning pretty old Trees.

div.p: SInce Pruning may be look'd upon as a kind of Remedy for Fruit-Trees, and that really we have made uÅ¿e of the Rules and Principles thereof, in order to render the young Trees in our Gardens more agreeable as to their Figure, as well as more Fertile in fine and good Fruit, than they would have been without being Prun'd; being now to treat about a proper Remedy for Old Fruit-Trees, I am of Opinion, that, to make my Å¿elf the better underÅ¿tood, I muÅ¿t firÅ¿t of all Å¿uppoÅ¿e two things; the one in relation to their Vigour, or WeakneÅ¿s: And I am likewiÅ¿e of Opinion, that it will be proper for me to explain this laÅ¿t Part, before I meddle with the firÅ¿t, this being altogether grounded upon the other; and thoÅ¿e vigorous Trees requiring abÅ¿olutely to be treated in a different manner from thoÅ¿e that are not Å¿o.

As to what relates to the Vigour or WeakneÅ¿s of Trees, we are to Å¿ay, that thoÅ¿e Trees are either very vigorous, producing abundance of thick Shoots, or very weak, hardly producing any, or at moÅ¿t but very Å¿mall ones; or in fine, neither incline too much to an exceÅ¿s of Vigour, or of WeakneÅ¿s, Å¿o as to be in the CaÅ¿e we may wiÅ¿h to have them: TheÅ¿e are abÅ¿olutely the three different CaÅ¿es Trees can be in.

When they are very Vigorous, and as it were Furious, whether the Beauty of their Figure be already form'd, or not, we muÅ¿t Å¿till propoÅ¿e to our Å¿elves, that whenever we go about to Prune them, it will be proper above all things, to leave a great Burthen upon them, that is, to leave a great many out-lets upon them, not only for Fruit-Branches, but alÅ¿o for Branches for Wood; which is perform'd two ways; of which the firÅ¿t is to allow thick Branches preÅ¿erv'd for the eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing or preÅ¿erving of a Beautiful Figure, Å¿omewhat of an extraordinary length: The Å¿econd is, not wholly to take away hardly any of their thick new Branches, eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch as Å¿hoot outward; but after having choÅ¿en in each part of the Tree, among the thick ones, that which appears the beÅ¿t plac'd to Contribute to the Beauty of the Figure, and that with an intention to Å¿horten it moderately, according to its Situation, which I explain elÅ¿ewhere; after that, I Å¿ay, the adjacent Branches to that muÅ¿t be cut very Å¿hort, that is, if they Å¿hoot outwards they muÅ¿t be Cut Å¿lantingly, within one or two Eyes of the place whence they proceed; if altogether inward, within the thickneÅ¿s of a Crown Piece.

When I Å¿peak of allowing Å¿omewhat of an extraordinary length in Praning to a Branch for Wood, I mean a Foot and a half, or two Foot at moÅ¿t, and yet I Å¿eldom Practice this my Å¿elf; but whenever I do, 'tis always with an intention of reducing that extraordinary length to a more moderate one, as Å¿oon as the Tree bears Fruit.

In order to underÅ¿tand what is meant by Å¿hortning a Thick Branch moderately, it will be proper to remember, that whereas from the Extremity of a thick Branch being Prun'd, Å¿everal other new ones will proceed, Care muÅ¿t be taken to leave room, that is, an empty Place, where theÅ¿e New Branches may eaÅ¿ily lodge themÅ¿elves, without cauÅ¿ing any ConfuÅ¿ion among one another, or with thoÅ¿e that are there already, or Å¿uch as are to come; which is the Point upon which I would have People regulate themÅ¿elves as to the moderate length which is to be allow'd to Å¿uch thick Branches that are to be Prun'd; but yet, in Regularity, a Vigorous Tree muÅ¿t Å¿eldom be allow'd thick Branches, unleÅ¿s they be at leaÅ¿t Å¿even or eight Inches in length, and Å¿ometimes in CaÅ¿e of neceÅ¿Å¿ity they may be allow'd to the number of Eleven or Twelve, always remembring, that the Å¿aid Branches muÅ¿t be cut Å¿horter, whenever the Tree Å¿hall Å¿atisfie us with Fruit; Å¿o that it depends on the Gard'ners Prudence to allow more or leÅ¿s length to Å¿uch a Branch that is to be Å¿horten'd, and that as well in reÅ¿pect to the Vigour it appears to be of, as to the Place that is to be fill'd up in the Neighbourhood thereof.

When Old Trees are very Weak, commonly the beÅ¿t Expedlent is to take them away, and put young ones in their room, after having us'd all the Precaution neceÅ¿Å¿ary in Å¿uch CaÅ¿es; but if, on the Contrary, People will preÅ¿erve them, they muÅ¿t reÅ¿olve to disburthen or clear them extreamly, either in giving them the Figure which is proper to them, which perhaps they want, or in order to preÅ¿erve it, if already acquir'd; to which end, they muÅ¿t reÅ¿olve to leave very few Branches for Wood upon them, and to Prune them all Å¿hort, that is, five or Å¿ix Inches in length at moÅ¿t, even reÅ¿olving to leave but very few weak ones, and conÅ¿equently no uÅ¿eleÅ¿s ones, eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch as Å¿eem to be waÅ¿ted with Air, without having born any Fruit, or Å¿uch as are waÅ¿ted by having produc'd much; for as we have already obÅ¿erv'd in Å¿undry Places, Branches periÅ¿h in Bearing, and even Å¿ome PeriÅ¿h Å¿ometimes after having born: Therefore thoÅ¿e Branches muÅ¿t be conÅ¿iderably Å¿horten'd, or even taken away quite, when they appear altogether waÅ¿ted, and conÅ¿equently uÅ¿eleÅ¿s.

But when Trees are moderate, Å¿o as neither to fall into the exceÅ¿s of Vigour, or WeakneÅ¿s, but on the contrary, bear a reaÅ¿onable quantity of Fruit, and at the Å¿ame time produce Wood in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure, according to our deÅ¿ires, both for us, and for themÅ¿elves; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, thoÅ¿e Trees being pretty well Å¿hap'd, it will be fit, in relation to them, to follow as well the Rules heretofore preÅ¿crib'd for young Trees, as thoÅ¿e we are going to preÅ¿cribe; and if thoÅ¿e Trees are ill Condition'd, or ill Shap'd, endeavours muÅ¿t be us'd to order them better, which we will viÅ¿ibly diÅ¿cover, after having firÅ¿t Explain'd what concerns the Figure, which is proper for all manner of Old Trees.

Upon this CaÅ¿e, we muÅ¿t moreover Å¿uppoÅ¿e, that thoÅ¿e kind of Trees are either already Perfections of the Figure of a Dwarf-Tree. defective, and in diÅ¿order, or perhaps are upon the point of becoming Å¿o: This is the firÅ¿t Reflection to be carefully made at firÅ¿t Å¿ight of a Tree that is to be Prun'd, whatever it may be, Wall-Tree, or Dwarf, in order to reÅ¿olve with more eaÅ¿e upon what is to be done in relation to the Figure.

If the Defects are already happen'd, that is, if the Tree, inÅ¿tead of having an agreeable A. FirÅ¿t Perfection. B 2d. Perfection. C. 3d Perfection. D 4th. Perfection. Figure, according to the Idea I have heretofore Explain'd, it has an ill diÅ¿agreeable one, either in the whole, or in Part.

For Example, if it be a Dwarf, inÅ¿tead of being low in the Stem, A. which is the Perfection of it, of being open in the middle B. which is the Å¿econd, of being round in the Circumference C. which is the third; and in fine, inÅ¿tead of being equally furniÅ¿h'd with many good Branches round about its roundneÅ¿s D. which is the Fourth; it Å¿hould on the contrary, be too high in the Stem E. which is the firÅ¿t Defect of it; full and ConfuÅ¿e in the middle F. which is the Å¿econd; having one Å¿ide high, G. and the other low, G. or Imperfections of the Figure of a Dwarf-Tree. E. FirÅ¿t Imperfection. F. 2. Imperfection. G. 3. Imperfection. H. 4. Imperfection. one Å¿ide flat, H. or weak, H. while the other is pretty round, and very full, which are the third and fourth Defects.

If it be a Wall-Tree, whether high in the Stem, or low, and Å¿hort, for as to the Branches, the Å¿ame Rules Å¿erve for both; I Å¿ay if it be a Wall-Tree, which inÅ¿tead of being furniÅ¿h'd to the Right, and Left, as it ought to be with good Branches, from the Place where it begins, to the Place where it ends; and that in Å¿uch a manner, as to be equally garniÅ¿h'd on both Å¿ides, without the leaÅ¿t ConfuÅ¿ion in the World; inÅ¿omuch that every Branch might eaÅ¿ily be diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h'd, and reckon'd (in which the Great Perfection, and Beautiful Figure of a Wall-Tree conÅ¿iÅ¿ts) Å¿hould on the contrary, be quite unprovided in the middle, Å¿hooting altogether upwards, Å¿o as to reach the top of the Wall in two or three years time, which it ought not to do in leÅ¿s than Eight or Ten; and perhaps, altogether ConfuÅ¿e beÅ¿ides, and intangled on the one Å¿ide, while the other appears thin, and unfurniÅ¿h'd, which are the grand defects of Wall-Trees.
Let us now run over all thoÅ¿e Defects one after another, beginning by the Dwarfs, in order to Å¿peak our Opinion preciÅ¿ely, as to the means of Correcting of them, if it be poÅ¿Å¿ible.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII.

argument.p: Of the Defects of Pruning, in Relation to Old Dwarfs.

div.p: AS to the firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, which Å¿uppoÅ¿es a Dwarf to be too high in the Stem, I think it need not trouble us much, if the Tree has been Planted long, becauÅ¿e it cannot be remedy'd without falling into conÅ¿iderable Inconveniencies, which Å¿hould be wholly to deÅ¿troy the head of the Dwarf, and conÅ¿equently Å¿et it back for the Å¿pace of three or four years from bearing Fruit: The Remedy would be violent, and therefore I do not think it fit to meddle with the Stem of Å¿uch a Dwarf, tho' too high, and in that reÅ¿pect defective: In that CaÅ¿e, I am only for Correcting the Defects of the Head.

But when the Tree has not been Planted many years, to wit, two or three years, eÅ¿pecially the Head being ill begun, and not according to the Rules of Art, my Opinion is to Å¿horten it quite, to reduce it to the Rule, which preÅ¿cribes it to have a low Stem, as it is declar'd in the TreatiÅ¿e of Plantations; which I had rather do, than expoÅ¿e my Å¿elf to leave it always with Å¿uch a Defect, which muÅ¿t offend the Å¿ight perpetually: A Tree well Rooted again, and afterwards Å¿horten'd, Å¿oon recovers it Å¿elf, Å¿o as to afford a great deal of pleaÅ¿ure, and upon that account we are not only Comforted, but even very much Å¿atisfy'd with having Å¿horten'd it in that manner.

As to the Å¿econd Defect of a Dwarf, which is its being confus'd in the middle; when I meet with a Tree thus confus'd in the Figure, and conÅ¿equently not very proper to bear Fruit, I commonly look upon it as I would do upon a Great Lord, who really has a great EÅ¿tate, and yet is not eaÅ¿ie, by reaÅ¿on of the great Incumbrances that lye upon it: The Selling of Å¿ome part of his EÅ¿tate, or of a Place, might be capable to clear his Debts; whereas on the contrary, when I Å¿ee a Tree well Å¿hap'd, and well diÅ¿pos'd, I fancy I Å¿ee another Man, who by the wiÅ¿e Management of a Moderate EÅ¿tate, wants for nothing, and lives at eaÅ¿e and quiet.

Therefore I am for Correcting that Å¿econd Defect intirely, as well to afford the Tree the Beauty it ought to have, as to facilitate the means of making it bear Fruit, and that Å¿o much the rather, becauÅ¿e the Remedy is eaÅ¿ie, and the SucceÅ¿s Å¿peedy, certain, and without the leaÅ¿t danger.

'Tis only removing altogether a thick Branch from the middle, or perhaps two or three that cauÅ¿e that fullneÅ¿s; that is, this ConfuÅ¿ion; and remove them Å¿o, that the Sap which had form'd them, nouriÅ¿h'd them, and made them grow, may no longer find any
paÅ¿Å¿age to riÅ¿e up to the Å¿ame place, there to perform the Functions it was us'd to do; but Care muÅ¿t be taken that this very Sap in its common way, or road, cloÅ¿e to the firÅ¿t PaÅ¿Å¿age which is Å¿topp'd, may find another as good, and as eaÅ¿ie, Å¿o that it may be capable of uÅ¿ing it, and thereby fully to enter into Å¿ome thick adjacent Branches, juÅ¿t beneath thoÅ¿e that have been retrench'd, as it appears by the Figure.

And Å¿o there will be no fear of the growing of any falÅ¿e Wood, or Suckers there, nor of any new ConfuÅ¿ion, which would certainly happen, if, in the firÅ¿t place, thoÅ¿e thick Branches had been cut from the top, over Å¿ome weak Å¿mall Branches, and conÅ¿equently incapable of receiving in their Å¿mall Mouth all the Sap which us'd to enter into thoÅ¿e that have been retrench'd.
Or, if in the Å¿econd place, part of the Å¿aid thick Branches of the middle had been left, whereas they ought to have been wholly taken away, or elÅ¿e would make a kind of Stump there.

For the Sap returning Å¿till from the Foot with its uÅ¿ual abundance, and returning through the Å¿ame Channel it was us'd to, either to the Stem, or Å¿ome thick Branch, and finding no Overture large enough to receive it; or perhaps finding none at all, this Sap, I Å¿ay, burÅ¿ts of neceÅ¿Å¿ity round about that Å¿mall Branch, over which the thick one was cut off, or elÅ¿e round about that Stump, or thoÅ¿e Stumps which were left, and in burÅ¿ting, makes a great many new Branches in that middle, and conÅ¿equently forms there the Å¿ame defect we endeavour'd to Correct.

I have Å¿hown heretofore, that on Å¿uch OccaÅ¿ions, there are Å¿ometimes Å¿ome MaÅ¿terÅ¿troaks to be perform'd, to leave for a certain time a thick Branch over another thick Branch, which muÅ¿t be taken away; to the end that, as in the CaÅ¿e of Fountains, which are Å¿ometies vented, leÅ¿t the Winds might hinder the Water from performing its Function as well as it ought to do, a conÅ¿iderable part of Sap may be waÅ¿ted into thoÅ¿e kind of thick uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches, which otherwiÅ¿e would ruine Å¿ome diÅ¿poÅ¿itions for Fruit, ready form'd, or others which might form themÅ¿elves: But after the Tree Å¿eems to perform its duty in relation to Fruit, we may without any Å¿cruple wholly take away Å¿uch thick Branches, that are of no uÅ¿e for the Figure, and have only been left two or three years to waÅ¿te, as we have Å¿aid, an abundance of Sap which would have been troubleÅ¿om to us: BeÅ¿ides, the Overture of the Tree being made by means of Å¿ome thick Branches that has been taken out of the middle: It will be fit next to examine the remaining Branches, whether good, that is, grown according to the moÅ¿t common Order of Nature, or bad, being grown contrary to the Å¿aid Order; and conÅ¿equently Branches of falÅ¿e Wood, in order to preÅ¿erve as many as can be of the firÅ¿t, which may be uÅ¿eful for Wood, or Fruit, at the Å¿ame time, aÅ¿Å¿igning to each the length that may be proper for it, thereby to ruine the Ill ones, all, if the Beauty of the Figure requires it, conformably to the Idea we Å¿hall have form'd of it, or only part, which may happen when Å¿ome thick one chances to be Å¿ufficiently well plac'd to contribute to that Figure, which without it would prove imperfect.

As for the third defect, which relates to the roundneÅ¿s, it is not Å¿o eaÅ¿ily remedy'd, as the foregoing; it proceeds from that, when the Dwarf was firÅ¿t form'd, Care was not taken to order the Matter Å¿o, that the Head of the Tree might at leaÅ¿t be compos'd of two Branches, partly of an equal Å¿trength, or thickneÅ¿s, the one on one Å¿ide, the other on the other, to keep the Vigour of it in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure divided, or as it were in an Equilibrium, (when there happen to be three or four, the thing is yet eaÅ¿ier.)

But yet, two may be Å¿ufficient to that end, by reaÅ¿on that, as we have Å¿aid, each of them being afterwards Prun'd, as it ought to be, will Å¿hoot others on the Extremity of it upon the Å¿ides, which others being likewiÅ¿e Prun'd, will in their turn likewiÅ¿e Å¿hoot others.

And thus, from year to year, ad infinitum, Å¿till performing a new Pruning, good new Branches will Å¿till form themÅ¿elves, which will contribute to form, and afterwards preÅ¿erve in our Trees that agreeable roundneÅ¿s, and that abundance of fine Fruit we deÅ¿ire.

This defect in the roundneÅ¿s, probably proceeds then from that the Tree when it was firÅ¿t Planted, having at the beginning only produc'd one thick Branch on one Å¿ide, with a weak one on the oppoÅ¿ite Å¿ide, as it appears by the Figure; the Gard'ner inÅ¿tead of looking at firÅ¿t on that thick Branch as the only one, capable of forming a Å¿ine Head, according to the Method I have preÅ¿crib'd for the Conduct of thoÅ¿e kind of Trees, when they are newly Planted; inÅ¿tead of that, I Å¿ay, has indifferently cut both this thick one, and at the Å¿ame time, this other Å¿mall one, leaving them perhaps each of an equal length, without any ProÅ¿pect as to the Figure, which I hold neceÅ¿Å¿ary, and thus the Å¿trength of the Sap Å¿till continuing its firÅ¿t road, which inclines it only to the thick Branch, Å¿till produces many new fine ones on that Å¿ide; and, whereas there enters but a very inconÅ¿iderable quantity of Sap in the Å¿mall Neighbouring Branch, tho' it grew at the Å¿ame time with the thick one, Å¿o it produces but a very Å¿mall number of Å¿mall new Branches, which periÅ¿h Å¿oon
after; that is, perhaps, after having born a little Fruit: Thus one Å¿ide grows Å¿till in Vigour, being extreamly well furniÅ¿h'd, while the other remains weak, languiÅ¿hing, and thin; and conÅ¿equently the Tree being only well on one Å¿ide, makes a very ugly Figure, half flat, and half round, not in the leaÅ¿t anÅ¿wering the Figure that is requir'd in a Tree to be perfect, either in it Å¿elf, or for the pleaÅ¿ure of Å¿ight.

From thence it is eaÅ¿ie to judge that this defect in point of roundneÅ¿s is great, and even Bonum ex integrÃ¢ cauÅ¿Ã¢; malum ex quolibet defectu. difficult to Correct, at leaÅ¿t to be Corrected in few years; however, provided the Gardner takes Care in Pruning, as he eaÅ¿ily may, to order it Å¿o, that yearly the thick Branch he Prunes may produce Å¿ome other likewiÅ¿e thick, Å¿hooting towards the Å¿ide that wants filling, furniÅ¿hing, and being made round; he may in time, in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure attain to that round Figure.

Now, in order to underÅ¿tand how this may be perform'd with a little Cate and ForecaÅ¿t, it is fit to remember, that, as we have already Å¿aid, every Branch being Prun'd, muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity Å¿hoot Å¿ome new ones on the Extremity of it, and that more or leÅ¿s, according to its thickneÅ¿s, and Å¿trength, and the length that has been allow'd to it: A thick, Å¿trong, and Å¿hort one producing commonly a greater quantity, and thoÅ¿e finer than either the thick and Å¿trong one that has been left long, or the weak one, whatever way it was Prun'd.

So that it is moÅ¿t true, that it is poÅ¿Å¿ible to Prune in Å¿uch a manner, from year to year, that among the thick new Branches (that are to come, and are to grow out of thoÅ¿e Eyes, or Buds that are on the Extremity of the Old one that has been Prun'd) there may always be Å¿ome Principal one, Å¿hooting toward the defective Å¿ide, which conÅ¿equently muÅ¿t be carefully preÅ¿erv'd, and Prun'd alÅ¿o with the Å¿ame regards, and thus this defect diminiÅ¿hing by degrees, the Perfection of roundneÅ¿s, which is wanting in the Figure, will be inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly Introduc'd.

In Correcting the third Defect of this Dwarf, the fourth is Corrected at the Å¿ame time, which conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in not being equally furniÅ¿h'd round about its Circumference; Å¿o that this Dwarf in loÅ¿ing the Defect it had in wanting of roundneÅ¿s, at the Å¿ame time acquires the fourth Perfection it ought to have, that is, it becomes as full on one Å¿ide, as it was on the other.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX.

argument.p: The Defects of Pruning, in Relation to Old Wall-Trees.

div.p: WE muÅ¿t impute the Defects of Wall-Trees to the Å¿ame CanÅ¿e, which is a failure in the firÅ¿t years againÅ¿t the Å¿ame Principles of Pruning, which had been tranÅ¿greÅ¿s'd in the forming of Dwarfs, and has now been Corrected by us: That which hinder'd the roundneÅ¿s of thoÅ¿e, is abÅ¿olutely the Å¿ame thing with that which has hinder'd the EÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing of that equality of Å¿trength, without which the Å¿ides of a Wall-Tree cannot be equally furniÅ¿h'd.

That is, the Wall-Tree muÅ¿t have produc'd the firÅ¿t year, Å¿ome Branches equally Å¿trong, oppoÅ¿ite one to another; or if it has Å¿hot but one Å¿trong one, the whole Beauty of the Tree muÅ¿t be founded alone upon that, without truÅ¿ting to the weak ones that are grown at the Å¿ame time for any thing, but Fruit, and then their Death.

This Å¿ingle thick one, being at the Spring Prun'd Å¿omewhat Å¿hort, that is, within five or Å¿ix Inches, Å¿eldom fails, as we have Å¿aid, of Producing that very year at leaÅ¿t two thick ones, with Å¿ome Å¿mall ones; which two thick ones will be partly of an equal Å¿trength, and oppos'd to each other.

Now each of them having a Å¿ide to fill, will perform it well, provided the Gard'ner Å¿till remains MaÅ¿ter of the Extremity of them, Å¿o as not to let either Å¿lip up, as we have fully explain'd in the Conduct of our young Wall-Trees; and conÅ¿equently this Wall-Fruit-Tree is commonly only defective by the Negligence, or rather want of Skill of the Gard'ner, who being intruÅ¿ted with the Conduct thereof, has not had all the Regards we have explain'd in this TreatiÅ¿e for the Pruning of thick Branches: And therefore, whereas he may have been deficient for many years together in thoÅ¿e Wall-Trees, againÅ¿t the good Principles of Pruning; it follows, that to repair the Defects of them, there are as many Inconveniencies to be fear'd, as we have demonÅ¿trated, in order to the repairing of thoÅ¿e of a Dwarf, being Å¿hot too high.

When the Trees are not too Old, I am for Å¿hort'ning the thick Branches that are, for Example, Å¿hot up within two or three years, as well in the CaÅ¿e of Kernel, as of Stone-Fruit; thoÅ¿e thick Branches being Å¿hort'ned, will produce new ones on their Extremities, which will begin a-new to form the agreeable Figure Wall-Trees ought to have; and together with that Figure, will not only bear abundance of Fruit, but will bear long, which thoÅ¿e kind of Wall-Trees Å¿hot up too high cannot perform, the common heighth of the Walls not allowing it: And as for thoÅ¿e Trees that are Older, perhaps Å¿ome thick Branches may be Å¿hort'ned, which Expedient is pretty Å¿ecure in all Å¿ort of Fruit-Trees, excepting Peach-Trees being Graff'd; for it is certain, that Peach-Trees growing from a Stone, live much longer than others, but then they do not bear Fruit Å¿o Å¿oon; but in recompence, being Cut again, they Å¿till Å¿hoot VigorouÅ¿ly, which the others that have been Graff'd do not do, being Old, Infirm, and Weak, at the end of Ten or Twelve years: This is the reaÅ¿on why they can hardly Å¿hoot any new Branches through the hard dry Bark of an old Branch that Å¿hall have been Å¿horten'd upon them.

Therefore, in my Opinion, the beÅ¿t way is to leave thoÅ¿e Old Peach-Trees in the Condition they are, without Performing the Grand Remedy upon them, which is to Å¿horten them; only Pruning them as if they were well-Condition'd, in order to get Fruit from them, as long as they are capable of affording Å¿uch as is Good, and Fair, with a ReÅ¿olve to deÅ¿troy them as Å¿oon as they ceaÅ¿e to bear Å¿uch. In the mean time, I think it very proper to remove the Earth from the Å¿ides, which I believe may be waÅ¿ted; at the Å¿ame time taking away the greateÅ¿t part of the Old Roots that may be found in moving of the Earth, putting afterwards good new Mould in the room of it, then Plant new Trees there, that may be young, and fine, and of the ChoiceÅ¿t Fruits.

As for the other kind of Trees that have been Stock'd up, or Shorten'd, either Pear, Fig, Abricot, or Plumb-Trees, their new Branches muÅ¿t be order'd according to the Rules heretofore EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd in the management of young Wall-Trees, which without doubt will Å¿ucceed well.

The firÅ¿t Defect of a Wall-Tree being Corrected, which, as we have Å¿aid, conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in not being Å¿o well garniÅ¿h'd with good Branches on the Å¿ides, as to have an equality without the leaÅ¿t appearance of ConfuÅ¿ion; The Second, which conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in having thick Branches Å¿hot up too high, being but a Sequel of the firÅ¿t, or rather the Å¿ame thing, will conÅ¿equently be Corrected by the Å¿ame means.

The thick Branches which a Negligent or Unskillful Gard'ner has Å¿uffer'd to grow too long, have occaÅ¿ion'd all this diÅ¿order, for want of ConÅ¿idering, that whereas the New Branches commonly grow only on the Extremity of thoÅ¿e that have been Prun'd, and never on the lower part; it follows of CourÅ¿e, that the lower part of Å¿uch as have been left too long of a Foot and an half, and more, muÅ¿t needs from a great Vacuity, or ThinneÅ¿s, and conÅ¿equently Å¿uch a Tree having been thus ill order'd, can never acquire the Beauty a Wall-Tree ought to have, to be effectually in a good CaÅ¿e.

As for the next Defect, which conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in having one part ConfuÅ¿e, that is, too full, while the other wants fullneÅ¿s; it commonly proceeds, either from Old, Small, Wither'd, UÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches, left by the Ignorant, or Negligent Gard'ners, or elÅ¿e from having Å¿uffer'd and Cut two, three, or four thick Branches cloÅ¿e by one another, of an equal length, contrary to a good Maxim which forbids it; it being certain, that Å¿ince every Branch that is Prun'd, produces new ones, and often many; it being certain, I Å¿ay, that if many Cut Branches be left near one another, Å¿everal New ones will of CourÅ¿e Å¿hoot from them, which not finding empty places enough to fill up, will cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion where they are, while another part of the Tree, to which that Sap might have been directed, which occaÅ¿ions a great Defect here, becomes wretched, and forÅ¿aken, and as it were Å¿tarves.

The Rule which forbids this multiplicity of Thick Neighbouring Branches of an equal length, wills one only to be left in every Part, and that of a moderate length; to the end that the New ones it will produce, may Å¿everally GarniÅ¿h Å¿ome Places, which certainly without this ForecaÅ¿t, might prove empty, and thin: And in CaÅ¿e it be thought fit in one place, to leave two or three in proportion, as it proves more or leÅ¿s Vigorous, or Thin in that place, they muÅ¿t all differ exceedingly in length, and look on different Å¿ides, which may require being GarniÅ¿h'd; to the end that the new ones that are to grow, may cauÅ¿e a good Effect, inÅ¿tead of being cumberÅ¿om, Å¿o as to force one to take them away as Å¿oon as they are grown.
I have now declar'd in General what I think proper to Remedy by Pruning, the Grand Defects that are happen'd, and Å¿till happen daily in Old Trees, either Dwarfs, or Wall-Trees.
There now remains to tell, what I think proper to Remedy the Inconveniences that are like to befall Old Trees.

Perhaps it may be Å¿ufficiently known by the Remarks I have juÅ¿t made, without any neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Å¿aying more preciÅ¿ely, that it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary betimes to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the equality of Vigour, which being once Å¿o eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erv'd; and above all things, it is fit to be diffident of thick Branches, which never fail of UÅ¿urping a MaÅ¿tery wherever they begin to form themÅ¿elves.

The Truth is, that theÅ¿e are the only ones that Å¿poil all, by the ill uÅ¿e that is made Non nunquam in Arbore unus ramus c â¢ teris eÅ¿t Latior, quem niÅ¿i reÅ¿cideris tota arb â¢ r contriÅ¿tabitur. Columella. of them; they cauÅ¿e all the Defects we have now ObÅ¿erv'd, and Combated, whereas they are the only ones, which, being made a good uÅ¿e of, according to the Rules we have heretofore Explain'd, muÅ¿t not only Contribute to the Beauty of the Figure of Trees, and to make them laÅ¿ting, but likewiÅ¿e to the abundance of the good and fine Fruit they are to produce. And therefore the firÅ¿t thing to be done, is to Examine at firÅ¿t, whether the Tree be Conformable to the Idea of Beauty it ought to have, and muÅ¿t be very well underÅ¿tood; or if not, in the firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, 'tis but following what is EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd for young Trees; but particularly, when they Å¿eem to Å¿werve from a fine Figure, Care muÅ¿t be taken to oppoÅ¿e it with Vigour, and ExactneÅ¿s: So that if one Å¿ide Å¿eems to weaken, Endeavours muÅ¿t be us'd to Å¿trengthen it again, by retrenching Å¿ome thick Branches that are Å¿uperiour to it; that is, when the Condition of the Tree can permit it: For as one Å¿ide never weakens conÅ¿iderably, without the others Å¿trengthning at the Å¿ame time, as Å¿oon as it is obÅ¿erv'd that the other Å¿ide Å¿eems to Å¿trengthen in an extraordinary manner; inÅ¿omuch, that Å¿ome Branch Å¿hall have thicken'd ConÅ¿iderably, and have produc'd a great number of others, that thick one muÅ¿t immediately be Cut off, over one looking on the weaker Å¿ide, thereby going to the Exteriour Source of that Defect, and Å¿topping it, even in the Original; and Å¿o ConÅ¿equently, whether one Branch only, or more, Å¿hoot out too much, the current of the Sap is turn'd aÅ¿ide; and whereas that Sap muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity have a CourÅ¿e, if it be Å¿top'd on one Å¿ide, it will incline to another, and by thus dividing it, we contribute to the equality of Vigour, without which, a Tree can never have the Beautiful Figure that is proper to it, and which we ought to Endeavour to procure.
This is for the preÅ¿ent all I have to Å¿ay in Relation to the Pruning of Trees, either Dwarfs, or Wall-Trees: Let us now proceed to the Vine, which is not near Å¿o long, or difficult to Explain.

div.head: CHAP. XL.

argument.p: Of the Pruning of Vines.

div.p: OF all the things the Art of Husbandry Å¿ubjects to Pruning, and are commonly Prun'd once a year; nothing to me Å¿eems to require it Å¿o much as Vines, and nothing more eaÅ¿ily Perform'd: Both which PropoÅ¿itions I am perÅ¿waded of, and will prove hereafter. In the mean time, I may Å¿ay by the by, that Earth hardly nouriÅ¿hes any thing that is Å¿ubject to more Accidents, or is oftner afflicted, than a Vine; but then, on the other Å¿ide, I may likewiÅ¿e affirm, that nothing on Earth would be happier in its Productions, if the wiÅ¿hes of Men could PreÅ¿erve it from all manner of Misfortunes. It will not be proper to make the Apology of it here, it not being the deÅ¿ign of this TreatiÅ¿e; it is daily Å¿ufficiently prais'd by others: And tho' I were Å¿o minded, I could hardly Å¿ay any thing in favour of it, that were not tireÅ¿om.

The Proof of my firÅ¿t PropoÅ¿ition is grounded upon this, That conÅ¿tantly a Vine wanting to be Prun'd, PeriÅ¿hes Å¿oon after; not in relation to the Foot, which works as it us'd to do, without regard to what relates to the Head, but in relation to the Fruit; Å¿ince it neither produces any Å¿o good, Å¿o fine, or Å¿o well fed, as that which is regularly Prun'd, by reaÅ¿on that (Lively and Sprightly as it is, perhaps beyond any Plant we are acquainted with) when it is well, it commonly Å¿hoots Wood furiouÅ¿ly, even Å¿everal Branches in one Summer, and thoÅ¿e thick enough, each five or Å¿ix Fathom long, every one of thoÅ¿e Å¿hooting at the Å¿ame time a vaÅ¿t number of bad Å¿mall Branches all along the thick ones, which is a thing Å¿ufficiently known by every body.

Now theÅ¿e Å¿mall Branches in relation to Vines, no more than the too great quantity of large, thick, long ones in relation to Pear-Trees, have no-wiÅ¿e the Gift of Fertility: On the contrary, they remain uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, and Å¿o conÅ¿ume to no purpoÅ¿e, a conÅ¿iderable quantity
of Sap, which might be imploy'd to produce Fruit; therefore it is fit to avoid that great quantity of uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches upon Vines, which can be done no otherwiÅ¿e than by Pruning, and conÅ¿equently it is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Prune a Vine; inÅ¿omuch, that it is leÅ¿s pernicious for a Vine to be ill Prun'd, than not Prun'd at all: For at leaÅ¿t this Pruning, tho' ill perform'd, occaÅ¿ions a great benefit, in hindring the Sap from waÅ¿ting, or being diÅ¿Å¿ipated, as it would be in the long Branches that we retrench in Pruning, it producing at the Å¿ame time other Branches from the Foot, which will prove more uÅ¿eful: From whence it follows, that in our Husbandry nothing requires Å¿o much being Prun'd as a Vine; and indeed, as we have already obÅ¿erv'd, we Å¿tand indebted to the Vine for the firÅ¿t beginnings of Pruning, which is now practis'd Å¿o uÅ¿efully by Gard'ners, and Vine-DreÅ¿Å¿ers.

The ReaÅ¿on which made me affirm, that nothing appears Å¿o eaÅ¿ie to be Prun'd as a Vine, (and this is my Å¿econd PropoÅ¿ition) is, that in my Opinion nothing puniÅ¿hes the Defects that are committed in Pruning leÅ¿s than a Vine does. We have daily a thouÅ¿and Examples of it in common Vineyards, where we Å¿eldom meet a Vine-DreÅ¿Å¿er Skillful enough to underÅ¿tand the true method of Pruning a Vine, and conÅ¿equently of giving a good ReaÅ¿on for what he does; and yet thoÅ¿e very Vine-DreÅ¿Å¿ers Å¿eldom fail of having yearly a pretty good Vintage, provided the SeaÅ¿ons do not hinder it.

Thus we Å¿ee that Vines, tho' ill Prun'd, provided the Foot be in a good Condition, do not fail of producing abundance of fine Wood, and conÅ¿equently a great deal of Fruit; therefore I had reaÅ¿on to Å¿ay, that nothing is more eaÅ¿ie to Prune than a Vine: For indeed, whereas the Roots of it are extreamly Active, they produce abundance of Sap, which of CourÅ¿e makes a great many large new Branches, eÅ¿pecially upon thoÅ¿e that have been Prun'd the year before. Every one of thoÅ¿e new Branches commonly Å¿hoots Fruit on the fifth and Å¿ixth Eye or Bud, and even pretty often on the Å¿eventh; and that which is Å¿ingular in a Vine, is, that it produces its Fruit at the Å¿ame time with the Branches; for the Fruit does not grow afterwards here, as it does on the Branches of other Fruit-bearing Plants: And indeed, no Fruit muÅ¿t be expected on a Vine, unleÅ¿s it comes out at the Å¿ame moment with the Branches, which is a truth known by every body.

Commonly every good new Branch produces at leaÅ¿t two fine Bunches of Grapes, which Å¿eldom fails; and this furniÅ¿hes a pretty conÅ¿iderable quantity of Wine; but when every Branch, or at leaÅ¿t the Major part produces Three, which happens Å¿ometimes, then we have a full Vintage; Å¿uppoÅ¿ing always, that neither Hail, FroÅ¿t, or bad Rains, eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e, which falling at the time of the BloÅ¿Å¿om, make the Grapes run; I Å¿ay, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing thoÅ¿e Enemies to Vines have Å¿poil'd nothing in its Productions.

I need not mention in this TreatiÅ¿e of the Pruning of Vines, the manner of Planting, or Multiplying it; for beÅ¿ides that, it is not a proper place for it, nothing can be more generally known, than thoÅ¿e two Articles are: So that I Å¿hall only inÅ¿iÅ¿t upon the Pruning part, which I look upon to be very neceÅ¿Å¿ary, by reaÅ¿on of four or five Å¿orts of Grapes, that are commonly introduc'd in our Gardens, and are indeed the Chief Adornments of them, I mean MuÅ¿cadins, which are the moÅ¿t ConÅ¿iderable; the others are ChaÅ¿Å¿elas, PrecoÅ¿es, or early Grapes, Currans, even Bourdelais not being excluded; not indeed for the Å¿ame ReaÅ¿ons proper to the others, but for the ReaÅ¿ons explain'd in that part, which Treats of the good uÅ¿e that is to be made of the Walls of every Garden; and Å¿hews that Bourdelais are uÅ¿eful both for Leaves, and Verjuice.

I Å¿hall begin this Å¿mall TreatiÅ¿e of the Pruning of Vines, by Å¿aying, that among the good Grapes, which CompoÅ¿e part of our Gard'ning, and the common Grapes that grow in Vineyards, there is particularly this great difference; that in our Gardens we neither require abundance of Bunches, or abundance of Grapes upon thoÅ¿e Bunches; we deÅ¿ire thin Bunches, with few Grapes upon them, provided they be large, firm, and crackling; to the end that the SeaÅ¿on for Maturity being favourable, we may have the pleaÅ¿ure we had propos'd to our Å¿elves; which never happens when the Grapes are too cloÅ¿e; whereas in Vineyards they have different ProÅ¿pects, and with reaÅ¿on, deÅ¿iring nothing Å¿o much, as the abundance of Bunches, and quantity of Grapes upon each of them.

I Å¿ay, moreover, that a good and well amended Soil is not proper to produce good Grapes in our Gardens, eÅ¿pecially for MuÅ¿cadins; we rather want a Soil moderately fat, provided it be not too much worn, and be well Å¿ituated; and laÅ¿tly, provided the Plants are neither too old, nor too young; And, in caÅ¿e they be very Vigorous, not too cloÅ¿e one to another, Å¿o as to cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion; all which Conditions are very neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the goodneÅ¿s of MuÅ¿cadin, and without doubt to contribute conÅ¿iderably to it, nothing can be of more uÅ¿e, than a Skillful Pruning.

In Order to Perform it skillfully, we are to Examine two Principal Things; firÅ¿t, the Vigour of the whole Plant that is to be Prun'd; and Å¿econdly, the ThickneÅ¿s or Strength of every Branch upon which the Pruning is to be perform'd; for as to the time of Pruning, nothing is to be added to what has been Å¿aid of the time of the Pruning of Trees, Å¿ince all the Å¿ame ConÅ¿iderations are to be had in the Pruning of Vines, as have been had in the Pruning of Fruit-Trees.

As to the firÅ¿t Point in queÅ¿tion, viz. the Vigour of the Plant (which is known by the thickneÅ¿s, and number of new Shoots) the Chief thing to be done, is always to leave a great burthen to thoÅ¿e Plants, that are very Vigorous; I mean a great many Prun'd Branches, whether thoÅ¿e Plants have as yet but one Arm, as when they are very young, or have many, as they may have after the fifth or Å¿ixth year of their being Planted: But yet, in either CaÅ¿e, that great Burthen muÅ¿t be Å¿o well mannag'd, that it may have no ConfuÅ¿ion: And whereas very Vigorous Plants muÅ¿t be greatly burthen'd, Å¿o always in proportion, few Cut Branches muÅ¿t be left upon Å¿uch as are but moderately Å¿trong, and yet leÅ¿s upon thoÅ¿e that are very weak.

As to the Å¿econd Point, which relates to the thickneÅ¿s of every Branch upon which the Pruning is to be Perform'd; always Å¿uppoÅ¿ing the regards I adviÅ¿e for the beÅ¿t Plac'd, which I will explain in the Sequel. That being done, I am always for Pruning upon the thickeÅ¿t Branches, which indeed are the beÅ¿t; at leaÅ¿t it muÅ¿t never be perform'd upon the Weak ones; Å¿o that if the Trimming of the Buds, and uÅ¿eleÅ¿ Branches, that is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be done yearly in the Month of May, had not taken away abundance of Å¿mall Shoots that commonly grow upon the Stock, or upon Å¿ome Old Branch, they muÅ¿t be remov'd at the time of Pruning, weak Shoots not producing near Å¿o much as the thick ones.

The Branches to be Prun'd being choÅ¿en, which, as we have already declar'd, muÅ¿t always be the thickeÅ¿t, and beÅ¿t plac'd, we muÅ¿t now regulate the length that is proper to be allow'd to each of them: This Length ought commonly to be limited to four good Eyes, or Buds, (which are the four firÅ¿t to be reckon'd from the Place whence the Branch has taken its Birth) unleÅ¿s it be with a deÅ¿ign to make the Plant of that Vine riÅ¿e all on a Å¿uddain, or elÅ¿e in the Å¿pace of two or three years, a great deal higher than it is, or elÅ¿e to make it garniÅ¿h Å¿ome diÅ¿tant place, in a Å¿hort Å¿pace of time; in which CaÅ¿e, it may be allow'd a great deal more length than we have now Regulated; but Å¿till on Condition, that when it Å¿hall once have reach'd that heighth, or propos'd diÅ¿tance, it muÅ¿t, if it prove well, always be kept to that, as it may be done with eaÅ¿e, by means of the Pruning I PractiÅ¿e, only yearly performing that Pruning, within the compaÅ¿s of the moderate length above mention'd.

In the performing of this, as well as all other manners of Pruning of Vines, theÅ¿e two Precautions muÅ¿t be had; both of which are pretty Material: The FirÅ¿t is, to Cut within a large Inch of the Eye or Bud that is to be the laÅ¿t, I mean on the Extremity of the Branch that is Prun'd, by reaÅ¿on that if it were cut cloÅ¿er, that Eye would be wounded by it, and would not produce Å¿o fine a Å¿hoot: And the Å¿econd is, to order the Cut Å¿o, that the Å¿lope may always draw towards the Å¿ide that is oppoÅ¿ite to that laÅ¿t Eye, for fear the Water, or Bleedings which never fail dropping from that part that is Prun'd, when the Sap begins to riÅ¿e, Å¿hould fall upon that laÅ¿t Eye, becauÅ¿e it might prove prejudicial to it.

From thoÅ¿e four Eyes or Buds left upon the Pruning of a Vigorous Plant, eÅ¿pecially againÅ¿t a Wall, may always be expected four new Branches, one from each; each of which, as we have already Å¿aid, will be furniÅ¿h'd with two or three Bunches of Grapes; that is, every good Branch being Prun'd within the compaÅ¿s of four Eyes, provided, no ill accident befall either of them, which happens Å¿ometimes, may produce four good new Branches together, with eight, ten, or twelve Bunches of Grapes for Autumn; Å¿o that one Plant of Vine, upon which, at the Spring, Å¿hall have been left two good Branches Prun'd, may yield that very year twenty, or twenty four Bunches of Grapes; and another having four good Branches, may yield to the number of forty, and Å¿o it might riÅ¿e ad infinitum; always remembring to proportion the burthen in Pruning, to the Vigour of the Plant; likewiÅ¿e noting, that Å¿uch an abundance can only Å¿uit with Vines Planted againÅ¿t Walls.

I repeat again, that in Pruning, a great difference is to be made between a Branch Å¿hot from the Pruning of the preceeding year, and another; for indeed the firÅ¿t can only be look'd upon as a Branch of falÅ¿e Wood, and conÅ¿equently, muÅ¿t be abÅ¿olutely remov'd, unleÅ¿s there be no other upon the Stock, or that it may be of uÅ¿e, as it is pretty often, in order to Å¿horten the Stock cloÅ¿e to it, being neceÅ¿Å¿itated Å¿o to do, both to keep within the bounds of the heighth we affect, and becauÅ¿e Old Branches periÅ¿h, in fine, at the end of a
certain time, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently the old Wood being grown infirm, and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, it muÅ¿t needs be remov'd, as Å¿oon as it is perceiveable.

Now, Å¿ince for the ReaÅ¿ons aboveÅ¿aid, it has been thought fit to preÅ¿erve Å¿ome Branches Å¿hot from the Å¿tock, for inÅ¿tance, one or two in one and the Å¿ame place; in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e they muÅ¿t be Å¿hortned within the compaÅ¿s of two Eyes, in hopes of two fair good Branches, upon which we may lay the foundation of our hopes, for the re-eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing of Å¿uch a Vine, whether it be the whole Plant, or only part of it, continuing during that year the common Pruning upon Å¿ome higher Branch, in order to have Fruit that year, reÅ¿olving to ruine it intirely, the Fruit being gather'd.

We have declar'd elÅ¿ewhere, that MuÅ¿cadin requires a pretty deal of heat, adding thereunto, that it dreads the exceÅ¿s, as much as the Mediocrity, or want of it: Therefore, as in Moderate Climes, like France, MuÅ¿cadin requires being plac'd to the South, or at leaÅ¿t to the EaÅ¿t, againÅ¿t Walls: So in very hot Countries, like Languedoc, and Provence, it dreads thoÅ¿e kind of Scituations, by reaÅ¿on that the heat being too Å¿corching, the Grapes wither, and burn, inÅ¿tead of ripening, and therefore only thrive there in the open air, where indeed they attain a miraculous Perfection, inÅ¿omuch, that all the InduÅ¿try of Man can never reach that Perfection, in Countries that lye Å¿omewhat to the North; for which ReaÅ¿on, we are oblig'd to confeÅ¿s, that tho' we need not envy other Climes for all other Fruits, viz. Peaches, Plums, Pears, Apples, and even Figs, and Melons, &c. yet in our Climes we can never approach the happineÅ¿s of Meridional Countries for MuÅ¿cadins.

It is to be obÅ¿erv'd particularly, that MuÅ¿cadin never thrives well againÅ¿t a high Treillis, it is always cloÅ¿e, Å¿mall, and flabby; wherefore I am not for placing it againÅ¿t Å¿uch, neither muÅ¿t it (eÅ¿pecially in EÅ¿paliers) be kept Å¿o low that the Grapes may touch the ground, or for the water of Spouts to Å¿purt gravel againÅ¿t it: For which reaÅ¿on, I affect a heighth of three, four, or five foot at moÅ¿t, particularly for MuÅ¿cadin, inÅ¿omuch, that the Fruit on the EÅ¿palier may neither be much higher, nor much lower; this is what I meant heretofore, when I Å¿poke of a Branch, which being thick, is fit for Pruning, provided it be well plac'd.

The Å¿ame heighth is likewiÅ¿e very proper for ChaÅ¿Å¿ellas, Currans, and early Grapes, &c. but not Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary: Grapes that do not grow againÅ¿t Walls, indeed may, and ought to be kept much lower, whatever they be, but Å¿till we muÅ¿t not Å¿werve from the Maxim which forbids that Grapes that are to be eaten raw, Å¿hould touch the ground.

The length for the Pruning of every Branch of Vine being regulated, it will now be proper to examine to the bottom the burthen that is fit to be left upon every Plant, which is the moÅ¿t difficult, and moÅ¿t material Point.

When the preceeding years Pruning has produc'd three, or four Branches, as it may do, and often happens; then Å¿uppoÅ¿ing the Vine to be of the heighth above-mention'd, I begin, by removing wholly all the weak ones, and as to the others, unleÅ¿s the Mother Branch, be very Vigorous, I never preÅ¿erve above two of them, and chuÅ¿e the thickeÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e that, as we have already Å¿aid, they are doubtleÅ¿s the beÅ¿t, always chuÅ¿ing, as much as can be, the loweÅ¿t, provided they be thick, otherwiÅ¿e I keep to the higheÅ¿t; after that, I Prune them both, tho' not of an equal length, that is, allowing them each four Eyes, I only allow it the higheÅ¿t of the two, which I call the Pruning, and leave but two upon the loweÅ¿t, which I call a Stump; reÅ¿olving at the Å¿ame time, to remove the higheÅ¿t quite the following year; together with all thoÅ¿e that Å¿hall Å¿hoot from it, reducing my Å¿elf wholly to the two that Å¿hall grow from that Å¿horteÅ¿t Branch, provided the Å¿aid Branch Å¿ucceeds according to my hopes, and appearances; for if any accident Å¿hould happen to it, Å¿o as not to produce two fine Branches, it Å¿hooting perhaps but one, I fix Å¿till to the fineÅ¿t, and loweÅ¿t of the Pruning, either to keep two of them, in caÅ¿e the Å¿hort Branch has fail'd quite; or at leaÅ¿t, I preÅ¿erve one for Pruning, the Å¿hort one having Å¿hot one, that may Å¿erve for a Å¿hort one the following year: This is the Method I daily attempt, not to Å¿werve from the heighth I affect, as good, and neceÅ¿Å¿ary.

I affirm, that by this Method, accompany'd with Å¿ome Culture, and the common CuÅ¿tom of Couching Branches from time, to time, in order to get new Wood, when the old begins to appear waÅ¿ted; as alÅ¿o with the help of a little Dung, or rather Å¿ome renewing of Soil, when any diminution of Vigour is perceiv'd; I Å¿ay, I affirm that Å¿uch a Method will conÅ¿tantly preÅ¿erve every Plant of Vine in a good CaÅ¿e, Vigorous, and without any Wounds, it will produce fine Grapes; and conÅ¿equently, if the SeaÅ¿on, and Clime contribute to afford it due Maturity, it will yield the Satisfaction that was expected from it.

But when the Plant of Vine, eÅ¿pecially of MuÅ¿cadine, is extraordinary Vigorous, as it happens pretty often, inÅ¿omuch that the three, or four Branches it has Å¿hot from every
Branch that has been Prun'd prove very thick; I am for preÅ¿erving of them all, Pruning both the one and the others of the Length heretofore Å¿pecifi'd, as well the higheÅ¿t for Pruning, as the loweÅ¿t for a Stump; and in order to have room to place without ConfuÅ¿ion all the Young ones that are to proceed from that, I pull up Å¿ome Neighbouring Plant that might Å¿tand in my way: I likewiÅ¿e affect Å¿ometimes to chooÅ¿e for my Pruning the meaneÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e Branchss, always forming my Stump upon the loweÅ¿t of the thick ones, after which I cut the thickeÅ¿t that are near that mean one, that may be fit for Pruning within one Eye; in order that thoÅ¿e kind of Stumps may waÅ¿t part of the Fury of the Foot, and that the mean Branch I have choÅ¿en for the beÅ¿t may not be inconvenienc'd by it, and made to bear CloÅ¿e Fruit, as it would certainly do, if it receiv'd the Vigour of all of them; Å¿o that in Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, I do not Cut the higheÅ¿t over the loweÅ¿t, as I uÅ¿e to do, when the Plant is but moderately Vigorous.

When our MuÅ¿cadines are in BloÅ¿Å¿om, the thing in the World I am moÅ¿t deÅ¿irous of, is, that which, excepting FroÅ¿t and Hail, is moÅ¿t to be dreaded for Vines, and that is Rain, in order to make part of the Grapes weep away, without which they would be too cloÅ¿e, as well as too Å¿mall and flabby; therefore when Nature does not allow me that Rain according to my deÅ¿ire, I endeavour to Å¿upply it with Waterings, which for the moÅ¿t part Å¿ucceeds well: I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s that it is very TroubleÅ¿ome for Å¿uch as have a great many Plants of MuÅ¿cadine, but yet the Experiment may be try'd upon a Å¿maller Number.

When the Year proves Extraordinary Drie at the Å¿eaÅ¿on of Maturity, if my Soil be naturally very Drie, I Water the Foot of my Vine largely, eÅ¿pecially when the Fruit begins to turn; Å¿uch a Watering, when neceÅ¿Å¿ary, and well perform'd in the Month of AuguÅ¿t, Contributes certainly to the largeneÅ¿s and firmneÅ¿s of the Grapes.

When the Fruit-Bearing Branch, I mean the new Branch of that Years growth, is not of a MonÅ¿trous thickneÅ¿s, as Å¿ome of them prove Å¿ometimes, I Cut it in the Month of July, cloÅ¿e to the Fruit, being careful at the Å¿ame time, by means of Å¿ome Neighbouring Leaves, to Å¿helter the Fruit from the great heat of the Sun, until it be at leaÅ¿t half ripe; for when it draws near Maturity, and this is a general Rule, it is proper to keep it a little bare, in order to afford it that Yellow Colour, which becomes it Å¿o well: The Cutting I juÅ¿t mention'd, augments the NouriÅ¿hment of the Fruit, and commonly contributes to make it larger, and more crackling, but it is not always certain nor infallible, neither muÅ¿t it be done, when the Branches are very thick; for whereas in the Summer they Å¿hoot almoÅ¿t as many Å¿mall new Branches, as they have Eyes or Buds, thoÅ¿e Branches growing thick, would in courÅ¿e occaÅ¿ion a great ConfuÅ¿ion, for even when the Branches are not Å¿hortned, they notwithÅ¿tanding Å¿hoot, during the Summer, abundance of thoÅ¿e Buds, which muÅ¿t be carefully pull'd off, as being very UÅ¿eleÅ¿s.

Happy are thoÅ¿e who are in Å¿uch Situations, where MuÅ¿cadine yearly ripens well, I cannot forbear envying their good Fortune a little. Happy likewiÅ¿e are thoÅ¿e, who having MuÅ¿cadine in an indifferent Climate, and pretty ill Ground, are favour'd with Å¿uch a Summer as we had in the Year 1676, for it is moÅ¿t certain, that we have ReaÅ¿on to be contented with that Years MuÅ¿cadine.

But it is not Å¿ufficient for our Vines to have abundance of fine Bunches, and thoÅ¿e not over Å¿tock'd with Grapes, nor for the SeaÅ¿on to be favourable to make them Ripen well, we have beÅ¿ides other conÅ¿iderable Enemies to dread for thoÅ¿e Grapes, as well as for Fig-Trees, which are, beÅ¿ides Å¿ome FroÅ¿ts which make the Leaves fall, and long Cold Rains, which Rot the Grapes; Birds and Flies of Å¿everal kinds; as to the firÅ¿t, the firÅ¿t, the beÅ¿t way to prevent their MiÅ¿chief, is to hang Nets before thoÅ¿e Grapes which will hinder the Birds from coming near it; but that remedy is not very eaÅ¿ie, when there is abundance of MuÅ¿cadine to be preÅ¿erv'd: As to the Flies, we have the Remedy of Viols, that muÅ¿t be half filled with Water mix'd with a little Hony, or Sugar, which Expedient is Å¿ufficiently known by every Body; thoÅ¿e Viols muÅ¿t be hung up in divers Places about the Vines with Å¿ome Pack-Thread, and thoÅ¿e Infects Å¿eldom fail of getting into them, being attracted by the SweetneÅ¿s of the Honey and Sugar, and there certainly periÅ¿h, as Å¿oon as they are got in, not being able to find the way out again; at leaÅ¿t abundance of them are deÅ¿troy'd that way, tho' it is almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible to deÅ¿troy them all: Care muÅ¿t be taken beÅ¿ides, to empty thoÅ¿e Viols, when any ConÅ¿iderable number of thoÅ¿e Flies are taken, otherwiÅ¿e no more of them would be taken, the Corruption and Stink they are Subject to, hinder the others from coming there: Then the Å¿aid Viols muÅ¿t be fill'd up again, as before, and plac'd a-new in proper Places.

Paper bags, and Linnen Cloths, are likewiÅ¿e us'd to cover every Bunch, but beÅ¿ides that it is a kind of Slavery, if on the one Å¿ide it Å¿erves to preÅ¿erve the Grapes Å¿o inclos'd from the Birds and Flies, on the other Å¿ide, it hinders the Sun from affording them that Å¿ame Yellow Colour, which is Å¿o agreeable to Å¿ight, and Contributes to make them better, as well as
to Å¿how their perfect Maturity: For to imagine that it preÅ¿erves the Grapes the longer ripe, is an Error I have experienc'd; The ReaÅ¿on is, that Fruit begins to Rot, as Å¿oon as it is throughly Ripe, and even Å¿ometimes before; and as Å¿oon as one Grape is tainted, it Å¿poils the next, ãâã next another, and Å¿o ad infinitum, which is a very conÅ¿iderable Inconveniency, not Å¿o eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cover'd when the Grapes are enclos'd, as when they are bare; as Å¿oon as a Grape looks tainted, it muÅ¿t be pick'd, to hinder it from infecting the reÅ¿t.

I muÅ¿t not omit adding, that in Å¿uch years as produce an infinite quantity of Bunches, as the year 1677. it will be fit to take away part of them in thoÅ¿e places where they are too thick, as alÅ¿o too thin, thoÅ¿e Bunches that appear too cloÅ¿e, or too full, as well as to Å¿horten on the lower Extremity Å¿uch as Å¿eem too long, that Extremity never ripening Å¿o well, as the Top, which always ripens the beÅ¿t of any other part.

I Å¿hould likewiÅ¿e add, that no Grapes muÅ¿t be gather'd, eÅ¿pecially MuÅ¿cadine, until it be perfectly ripe, Å¿ince perfect Maturity is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary to afford it that Å¿weetneÅ¿s, and flavour, without which, nothing can be leÅ¿s agreeable than MuÅ¿cadin: But this Advice Å¿hall be compos'd in one of the Chapters of the following Part; wherein I Å¿hall examine whatever relates to the maturity of every particular Fruit.

div.head: OF FRUIT-GARDENS, AND Kitchen-Gardens. VOL. II. PART V.
CHAP. I.

argument.p: Concerning the Care that is Requir'd to Pick Fruits, when they are too abounding.

div.p: WHereas the Intention of our Culture is not only to promote fair Fruit, but eÅ¿pecially to have it fine, and large; hoping thereby, and with ReaÅ¿on, that it will be the better for it, goodneÅ¿s Å¿eldom failing to attend Beauty, and LargeneÅ¿s of Size: And, whereas neither Pruning, nor the Trimming of the Buds, and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Branches, the Tillages, or Improvements of the Ground are always Å¿ufficient to afford us this Beauty, and Size; it follows from thence, that there is Å¿omething elÅ¿e to be done, which is that I am to Treat of here.

It is certain, that when we neither meet with FroÅ¿ts, or North-EaÅ¿t Winds, at the time that the Trees BloÅ¿Å¿om, and the Fruit knits; that is, in the Months of March, April, and May; I Å¿ay, it is certain, that pretty often in Å¿ome parts of the Tree there remains too much Fruit for it to be very Beautiful; for in the firÅ¿t place, in Relation to Kernel-Fruits, whether Pears, or Apples, it is moÅ¿t certain that every Bud commonly produces many BloÅ¿Å¿oms, and conÅ¿equently may produce many Fruits; that is, to the number of Seven, Eight, Nine, and Ten, &c. In the Å¿econd place, as to Å¿tone Fruits, altho' every Bud, excepting only plain Cherries, Morello's, white and black Hearts and Bigarreaux, produce but one Å¿ingle Fruit, (for indeed, one Peach-Bud, and one Plum-Bud only produce one Peach, and one Plum,) yet, as every one of their Fruit-bearing Branches, is commonly
burthened with a great number of Buds, all cloÅ¿e to one another; it follows, that upon every one of thoÅ¿e Branches there may remain an exceÅ¿Å¿ive quantity of Fruits, and therefore the Å¿ame Argument we uÅ¿e for the Buds of Kernel-Fruits, may Å¿tand good for this; which is, that the more Fruit there knits upon one Bud, the Å¿maller the Portion muÅ¿t be; which at the Å¿hooting out of the Stalk out of that Bud, diÅ¿tributes it Å¿elf to every individual Fruit; inÅ¿omuch, that if the quantity were leÅ¿s, 'tis moÅ¿t certain that the Portion of every one of the remaining would be the larger, and conÅ¿equently, the Fruit being the better fed, would be larger, and commonly better.

So likewiÅ¿e, the more Fruit there is upon a Branch of Stone-Fruit, Peach, Plum, or Apricock-Trees, &c. the Å¿maller is the portion of NouriÅ¿hment, which diÅ¿tributes it Å¿elf to every Peach, and every Apricock, on Å¿uch Branches; Å¿o that had there been leÅ¿s upon every Branch, the Fruit would certainly have been better fed, and conÅ¿equently larger, and commonly better; Å¿ince indeed, it is almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible to have at once LargeneÅ¿s, Beauty, and GoodneÅ¿s, when there is too much Fruit, either upon one and the Å¿ame Bud, or upon one and the Å¿ame Branch.

It follows from thence, that a Skillful Gard'ner, who takes care to make his Trees BloÅ¿Å¿om (which is in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure in his Power to do) it follows, I Å¿ay, that he muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e take yet more care to leave no more Fruit on every Tree, and particularly on every Bud, and on every Branch, than in proportion to what he may judge, that the Tree, or rather the Branch, is capable to NouriÅ¿h, in order to have that Fruit Beautiful.

I Å¿ay, particularly the Branch; for, whereas the diÅ¿tribution of the NouriÅ¿hment which is deÅ¿tin'd to every one, is perform'd at the firÅ¿t entrance of the Branch, according to the largeneÅ¿s of the Overture thereof, and not according to the multitude of the Fruit it is burthen'd with, nor the meaÅ¿ure of NouriÅ¿hment it may Å¿tand in need of; it follows, that the Fruit of every one only receives the benefit of that which Nature allows the Branch it grows on, without receiving the leaÅ¿t benefit of that which it allows the Neighbouring Branches, every one of them having their peculiar Functions, and Å¿eparated Works, which is Å¿o certain, that a Tree Å¿ometimes bearing but one or two Fruits, or at leaÅ¿t, but a Å¿mall quantity, that Fruit is no finer than if it had produc'd a far greater quantity.

It likewiÅ¿e follows from thence, that the encreaÅ¿e of Sap, or NouriÅ¿hment, which may happen to every individual Fruit, only proceeds from the retrenchment that is made of the too great quantity of Fruit, which grew on every Bud, or upon the Å¿ame Branch upon which it is found; as if every Bud, or every particular Fruit-Branch made particular Families, having every one their particular Income, and each their Servants to nouriÅ¿h; inÅ¿omuch, that as the one receives no benefit from the abundance of the others, Å¿o the Children of every one in particular, have a greater Å¿hare of nouriÅ¿hment; when the Å¿ame food, which, for Example, might have been divided, or Å¿har'd among Ten, is only divided among Two or Three.

Therefore it is certain, that we muÅ¿t leave but few Fruits upon every Bud, and upon every Branch, if we deÅ¿ign to have them all both larger and finer; and whereas in Pruning every Tree, I leave as many, and Å¿ometimes more good Buds, and good Fruit-Bearing-Branches upon it, than it Å¿eems capable to NouriÅ¿h, being Å¿enÅ¿ible of the hazards that are to be fear'd, before the Fruits of every one are Å¿afe; and being likewiÅ¿e deÅ¿irous that all the Fruits of every Tree Å¿hould be partly equally Beautiful, I never fail, after the Fruit is knit, to make an exact review of that which every Bud and every Branch contains, in order to leave no more on each Place, than it is likely to be able to NouriÅ¿h plentifully.

It is likewiÅ¿e certain, that, pretty often, Nature Å¿eems to take care to purge, or disburthen it Å¿elf of what it is over-burthen'd with; at leaÅ¿t the Spring Å¿ometimes produces of thoÅ¿e FroÅ¿ts, and North-EaÅ¿t Winds, we have already mention'd, which happen alÅ¿o pretty often between the Months of July and AuguÅ¿t; thoÅ¿e kind of North-EaÅ¿t Winds are Terrible Å¿hakers of Fruits; they beat down abundance of it, and Å¿ome times too much, and that without the leaÅ¿t diÅ¿cretion or meaÅ¿ure, either in reÅ¿pect to the whole Tree, or to Every Branch, in Å¿o much that Å¿uch years have a great Scarcity of Fruit, and often to ExceÅ¿s; But yet whatever Misfortune it may have caus'd, we muÅ¿t not fail Å¿till to make a review of what is remaining, to take away Å¿uch from Å¿ome Places, which in Prudence we Judge to be overburthen'd.

But then again, thoÅ¿e FroÅ¿ts and Stormy Winds do not always happen, and then the greateÅ¿t part of the Fruit, which has knit, remains upon the Trees, and thus in the midÅ¿t of Plenty, as to Number, we may really call our Å¿elves poor as to Beauty, and goodneÅ¿s, having nothing fine enough to Honour our Culture.
In Å¿uch a CaÅ¿e, I think it very proper, to eaÅ¿e Nature of a CouÅ¿iderable part of its Burthen, in the following manner.

FirÅ¿t, It is fit to tarry, until the Fruits be pretty large and well form'd, in order to take away Å¿uch as are Å¿uperabundant, and particularly to preÅ¿erve the moÅ¿t Beautiful and moÅ¿t Å¿izeable; Å¿ince that great Number conÅ¿iÅ¿ts both of good and bad, to which end we muÅ¿t commonly tarry until the end of May, and the begining of June, at which time Fruit is large enough to facilitate our Choice.

But this Picking or Culling muÅ¿t be Perform'd Å¿ooner for Apricocks than any other Fruits: Whereby we derive an advantage, which is not met with on other Trees, a very good uÅ¿e being made of Å¿mall green Apricocks, which we cannot make of other Å¿mall green Fruits, at leaÅ¿t hitherto we have not found the way of it, tho it were perhaps to be wiÅ¿h'd we might.

Secondly, We muÅ¿t be careful to allow every Fruit, as near as we can, as much Room as it may require, for the Å¿ize we know it is to be of, when it approaches to Maturity, and that particularly for thoÅ¿e kind of Principal Stone-Fruits, which have Å¿hort Stalks, viz. Peaches, Pavies, or Purple-Peaches, Apricocks, &c. otherwiÅ¿e they would obÅ¿truct each other in growing, and it often happens that thoÅ¿e that are equally large deÅ¿troy each other, or at leaÅ¿t the Å¿trongeÅ¿t get the better, that is, the largeÅ¿t deÅ¿troys the Å¿malleÅ¿t, and thus the NouriÅ¿hment which thoÅ¿e Wretches have receiv'd during two or three Months, is loÅ¿t in vain; whereas it might have been imploy'd to advantage, had care been taken to take off Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e that were worÅ¿t plac'd betimes; for by that means thoÅ¿e that Å¿hould have been preÅ¿erv'd, would have receiv'd the benefit of the NouriÅ¿hment which was waÅ¿ted on their Neighbours.

It follows from thence, that you muÅ¿t never leave thoÅ¿e kind of Fruits near one another, tho' they are Commonly Å¿o, Å¿everal of them growing together, witneÅ¿s Apricocks, or at leaÅ¿t two and two, witneÅ¿s Peaches: For commonly the BloÅ¿Å¿om Buds of Peach Trees only grow two and two, both very cloÅ¿e to one another, being only divided by a Å¿mall Eye, for Wood, which is a Å¿mall beginning of a Branch, which Places it Å¿elf between the Two, and for the generality only Å¿hoots a few Leaves, and no Wood; but when it Å¿hoots VigorouÅ¿ly and Forms a pretty fair Branch, then there is no neceÅ¿Å¿ity of removing one of thoÅ¿e Fruits which on both Å¿ides accompany the Branch; their Natural Situation keeping them at Å¿ufficient diÅ¿tance, and without doubt both of them will prove very Fine, provided nothing elÅ¿e preÅ¿s them while they are thickning, which as I have Å¿aid, muÅ¿t be carefully look'd to; but in caÅ¿e the Shoot be but weak, and Å¿lender, it muÅ¿t not hinder the removing of one of the two Peaches: Moreover, as thoÅ¿e kind of Å¿mall Shoots are commonly at a Å¿tand even in June, it is very proper to Å¿horten them at that very time to an Eye or Bud, in order to Å¿ave the NouriÅ¿hment, which would be waÅ¿ted in them to no purpoÅ¿e; beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e are the Shoots which generally cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion; it will Å¿uffice to leave a Leaf or two upon each, to Å¿helter the Peach from the Heat of the Sun, and that during all the time, of it's TendereÅ¿t Infancy; Shade being Å¿o very neceÅ¿Å¿ary at that time, that without it the Peach might periÅ¿h, being uncover'd, before its being come to Å¿ome Maturity.

Autumn and Winter Pears, eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch as are recommendable for the largeneÅ¿s of their Size, for inÅ¿tance, Beurre or Butter-Pears, Bon Chretiens, Virgoulee, &c. do likewiÅ¿e Å¿tand in need of that Picking or culling of Fruits; by reaÅ¿on that too many of them being left together upon one Knob, they will Å¿eldom prove very fine, one will Å¿uffice upon each, or two at moÅ¿t, and even thoÅ¿e muÅ¿t appear pretty large, according to the SeaÅ¿on, and both of an equal Size, for the one being leÅ¿s than the other, will always remain Å¿o, and conÅ¿equently ill favour'd, which far from deÅ¿erving to be preÅ¿erv'd, Å¿ince it could not attain the Size it ought to have, only Å¿erves to wrong the other, which would have thriven the better had it remain'd alone upon that Bud.

As for Summer Pears, for inÅ¿tance Å¿mall MuÅ¿cat, Robins, CaÅ¿Å¿olets, RouÅ¿Å¿elets, &c. there is no Å¿uch abÅ¿olute neceÅ¿Å¿ity to Pick them, they muÅ¿t only be us'd like Plums and Cherries; they are Fruits of an Ordinary and Regular Size, and are commonly good of all Sizes, provided they be Ripe, and not tainted by Worms.

Thirdly, It muÅ¿t be noted, that, when the Branches of Peach-Trees, upon which in Pruning we have left as many BloÅ¿Å¿oms, as we thought fit, which, as we have already noted, is always to Å¿ome Kind of exceÅ¿s; when thoÅ¿e Branches, I Å¿ay, do not appear in the Month of May to receive ConÅ¿iderable Succors of new Sap, Å¿o as to thicken, or to Å¿hoot fine Branches on their extremities: In that CaÅ¿e, as I have declared more at large in the
TreatiÅ¿e of Pruning, we muÅ¿t not only take away a great part of the Fruit which is aready knit upon them, but even Å¿horten the Branch extreamly, and that to that part from which the fineÅ¿t Shoot proceeds; for otherwiÅ¿e certainly the beÅ¿t part of the Fruit would drop before its being Ripe, or at leaÅ¿t would remain very Å¿mall, and ConÅ¿equently bad, it being moÅ¿t certain, eÅ¿pecially as to Stone Fruit, that unleÅ¿s they approach to that Size which is proper to their kind, they never attain the delicacy they ought to have. The Peaches remain Shaggy and Green, and do not quit the Å¿tone; they are SowriÅ¿h, and BitteriÅ¿h, the Pulp is Rough and CourÅ¿e, and often Mealy, the Stone is much larger than it Å¿hould be, all which are certain Marks of an ill Peach.

Fourthly, The Pears which remain in too great a Number, are apt not only to hinder each other from thickning, but likewiÅ¿e to Rot, the Air and the Wind not having a free paÅ¿Å¿age about them; this Inconveniency is Å¿ufficient to Inform us, that part of them muÅ¿t be taken away, that the remainder may be at more Liberty and EaÅ¿e.

In my Opinion, it is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to ObÅ¿erve in this Place, that it is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary, eÅ¿pecially in relation to Winter Bon ChreÅ¿tien Pears, in the Months of April and May, which is the time in which they begin to appear Knit and Form'd, to be greatly Careful to deÅ¿troy Å¿mall Black Caterpillars which are very numorous at that SeaÅ¿on, which otherwiÅ¿e would gnaw the Rind of thoÅ¿e Pears, which is the ReaÅ¿on we often meet with them crooked and uneven.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: To Learn to uncover, at a proper Time, certain Fruits which require it.

div.p: FRUITS being thus pick'd upon every Tree, they thicken by degrees under the Leaf, Å¿ome more, others leÅ¿s, every one according to its kind, Å¿ome Å¿ooner and others later, each according to the time Nature has deÅ¿ign'd for their Maturity; but whereas the Red, or Carnation Colour are neceÅ¿Å¿ary to certain Fruits, which may receive it, if not hinder'd, or not have it if hinder'd, (for there are Å¿ome which abÅ¿olutely can never attain it, what ever may be done, for InÅ¿tance, White Peaches, Verte Longue, or Long-Green, Green Sugar Pears, White Figs, &c. there are likewiÅ¿e others, which, thonever Å¿o cover'd, ever receives the Colour of their Kind, for example Cherries, Rasberries, Strawberries, &c.

Whereas, I Å¿ay, Colour as to certain Fruits, is a very material condition, in order to render them the more valuable, and that they can never attain that Colour in Ripening, unleÅ¿s the Rays of the Sun light directly upon them, it is proper at certain times to remove Å¿ome Leaves which Å¿hade them too much, and conÅ¿equently are prejudicial to them, in relation to that Colouring; nay more, they are prejudicial as to the Maturity of thoÅ¿e Fruits, it being moÅ¿t certain for the generality, that a Fruit, much cover'd with Leaves, cannot Ripen altogether Å¿o Å¿oon as another, which is more expos'd, and moreover has not Å¿o much delicacy.

But a great deal of Prudence and DiÅ¿cretion muÅ¿t be us'd in this caÅ¿e; and care taken not to uncover Fruits until they have almoÅ¿t attain'd their proper Å¿ize, and begin to loÅ¿e the great GreenneÅ¿s they had till then; Fruits begin to thicken from the moment they are Knit, until the beginning of June; and afterwards, as Gard'ners Å¿ay, they remain for a conÅ¿iderable Å¿pace in a kind of Lethargy without thickening, at leaÅ¿t ViÅ¿ibly; for I do not queÅ¿tion but they thicken a little, and that above all Å¿ome Matter enters into the InÅ¿ide of the Body of the Fruit, Å¿ince the Roots are continually preparing Å¿ome, and Å¿ending it immediately upwards; this matter indeed remains preÅ¿s'd under the Rind, which is the reaÅ¿on Fruit is Å¿o hard at that time; but finally the time which is regulated for their Maturity approaching, this very matter, tho' condens'd, begins to rarify, and to extend in few days, whereby the Fruits begin to Å¿oÅ¿ten and thicken more, and conÅ¿equently to approach to Maturity.

This is the only proper time to uncover them, at two or three different times, and that during the Å¿pace of five or Å¿ix days; for if they wereuncover'd Å¿ooner, or all at once, the great heat of the Sun would certainly occaÅ¿ion a great diÅ¿order upon that tender
Rind, not yet accuÅ¿tom'd to the open Air; this truth is confirm'd by too many Experiences, when either through the Ignorance of an unskilful Gard'ner, or by Å¿ome unlucky FroÅ¿ts, the Fruits are uncover'd before that time; the Å¿ame cauÅ¿e which Å¿plits the Rind of Fruits, likewiÅ¿e dries up the Stalks, and ConÅ¿equently the Fruit Withers and Rots, as it happens pretty often in Vinyards, which at the beginning of Autumn, are afflicted with Å¿ome over haÅ¿tly FroÅ¿ts.

Let us return to the Colour, which is deÅ¿irable for moÅ¿t Fruits, and Å¿ay that it Imprints it Å¿elf in few days on thoÅ¿e that have been long cover'd, as it appears by Peaches, Apricocks, and eÅ¿pecially on the Quince Apples, &c. and that therefore thoÅ¿e are much to blame, who neglect the procuring of Å¿o great an advantage to their Fruit, when it is Å¿o eaÅ¿ily done. Moreover, in order to render that Colour more Bright and Lively, it is not improper, to uÅ¿e a kind of Seringe made on purpoÅ¿e, with Å¿everal little holes at the end of the Spout, like thoÅ¿e of a Watering Pot, to water them twice or thrice a day, during the greateÅ¿t heat of the Sun: Such a watering Å¿oftens the Rind, and is of wonderful uÅ¿e to that end; eÅ¿pecially for Apricocks and Peaches, and it likewiÅ¿e Å¿ucceeds well for Bon Chreten Pears, and Vergoules, &c. Which remain Å¿omewhat WhitiÅ¿h, and which having a fine thin Rind, are ConÅ¿equently Å¿uÅ¿ceptible to receive that fine Colour, which becomes them Å¿o well.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the Maturity of Fruits, and the Order Nature obÅ¿erves in it.

div.p: IN fine Fruits, having attain'd their Size and Colour, and the time of their Maturity being arriv'd, it behoves us to improve thoÅ¿e rich PreÅ¿ents which Nature treats us with; it is a Liberality, or rather a ProfuÅ¿ion it yearly beÅ¿tows upon us, as if it thereby delighted to recompence the Cares, and InduÅ¿try of the skilful Gard'ner which Cultivates it.

Two things are to be ConÅ¿ider'd in every Fruit, the Pulp of the Fruit and the Seed of the Fruit, the Pulp which is proper for the NouriÅ¿hment of Man, and the Seed which lying in the heart of that Fruit as in a Sccabberd, receives its perfection by degrees, as the Pulp makes an end of Ripening; this perfection of Seed being apparently deÅ¿ign'd for the Multiplication of the Specie of that Fruit; but this I only Å¿peak by the by, yet it appears often that the Seed is of no uÅ¿e at all.

Perhaps it may be urg'd in relation to that Seed or Fruit, that Nature Å¿eems to perform in Trees, in reÅ¿pect to its Fruits, the Å¿ame thing in part, which it performs in Animals, in relation to their Young ones; No body can be Ignorant of the extraordinary earneÅ¿tneÅ¿s of Animals to NouriÅ¿h and PreÅ¿erve their Young, and that to a certain Point, that is until they attain that perfection of Size, and Strength, which every one Å¿tands in need of, either to SubÅ¿iÅ¿t of themÅ¿elves, or to labour afterwards to perpetuate their kind at the times which Nature preÅ¿cribes

InÅ¿omuch, that till then thoÅ¿e Animals Fathers and Mothers, can hardly Å¿uffer, without reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, nay Å¿ometimes without Fury and Cruelty, any Body to touch, much leÅ¿s to take away their Young ones; but when thoÅ¿e Young ones are grown big, Nature endeavouring on one Å¿ide to Employ thoÅ¿e Fathers and Mothers with the Care of a new Multiplication, and on the other hand to excite thoÅ¿e Young ones, as it were, to make a Figure in their kind, inclines thoÅ¿e Fathers and Mothers to abandon them, and to ceaÅ¿e NouriÅ¿hing and Protecting of them; inÅ¿omuch that thoÅ¿e Young ones being grown big, Å¿hift for themÅ¿elves, no longer looking upon the Authors of their Being, or keeping them Company, otherwiÅ¿e than as indifferent Strangers.

Thus we Å¿ee that Trees, which are really the Fathers of the Fruits, take care for a while to nouriÅ¿h thoÅ¿e Fruits, and to preÅ¿erve them, as if, if I may uÅ¿e the ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion, they Suckled, or Hatch'd, or Heated them with their Leaves, and that to a certoin Point, that is, until they are come to the full Perfection of their Size, and Maturity: But then, Nature Å¿eeing them in a Condition not only of SubÅ¿iÅ¿ting without the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Father that has produc'd them, but likewiÅ¿e of Perpetuating and Multiplying their different kinds, Å¿eems to withdraw the affection of the Tree; InÅ¿omuch, that before that time the Fruit Å¿eems to Å¿tick cloÅ¿er to the Tree than it does afterward: But when thoÅ¿e Fruits ceaÅ¿e
to receive the wonted help, they no longer Å¿tand in need of, and Å¿ticking no longer to the Tree by the former Tye, they quit their Father and Mother, they drop, they keep aÅ¿under, and laÅ¿tly are abandon'd to themÅ¿elves, &c.

As to the Pulp of thoÅ¿e Fruits, it is to be Noted, that the degree which approaches neareÅ¿t to what we call RotteneÅ¿s, (which is their deÅ¿truction,) is the perfection of their Maturity, inÅ¿omuch, that they are never perfectly good to Eat, until being abÅ¿olutely Ripe, they are near Å¿poiling.

Therefore, unleÅ¿s the Gard'ner be careful to gather his Fruits, and make uÅ¿e of them, when they are entirely Ripe, he will be in danger of Å¿eeing them periÅ¿h, Å¿ome through a RotteneÅ¿s, which begins at firÅ¿t in Å¿ome part of the Body, as it happens with moÅ¿t Apples, and others by growing Mealy, as Peaches, Å¿ome by growing Soft firÅ¿t, as many Pears do, eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch as are Tender, as Butter-Pears, others by growing Dry and Shaggy, as moÅ¿t MuÅ¿c-Pears do; all which are different ways Conducing to RotteneÅ¿s and DeÅ¿truction. When this happens, Man is Subject to Å¿ome inward checks of Nature, which Å¿eems to reproach him for his not having been Capable of Improving her Liberalities towards him.

It might be queÅ¿tion'd in this Place what Maturity is, and how it is perform'd, both which queÅ¿tions are pretty agreeable, but of no great uÅ¿e to a Gard'ner.
