FirÅ¿t, as to the Definition of Maturity, perhaps conÅ¿idering the great Proximity between it and Corruption, we can hardly give a better, than to Å¿ay, that it is a beginning of Corruption.

The Truth is, that in Å¿peaking of a thing which paÅ¿Å¿es for a Perfection, it Å¿eems pretty odd to make uÅ¿e of a Term, which expreÅ¿Å¿es defect, and is really diÅ¿guÅ¿ting; but then to Å¿often the Å¿ignification of that ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion, it will Å¿uffice to Å¿ay, that there are Å¿everal degrees of Corruption; many Fruits are Corrupted and Rotten, without ever having been Ripe, which Corruption is a real defect, without the leaÅ¿t Perfection. On the Contrary there are other Fruits, which never begin to Corrupt unleÅ¿s they have attain'd the utmoÅ¿t degree of Perfect Maturity, which Corrupion is really a defect for the Fruit, but is at the Å¿ame time a Perfection for the Eater: Thus we may Å¿ay, that a Piece of Wood which becomes a Circle, receives a degree of Corruption in relation to it Å¿elf, Å¿ince it ceaÅ¿es to have the Figure which Nature had given it, but it receives a Perfection in relation to the Workman, who forces it to take that bend, which it Å¿tands in need of for his uÅ¿e.

As to the manner, how Maturity is perform'd, the difficulty is much greater, and more puzling; for tho the Sun Å¿hining directly upon the Trees Å¿eems the only Author of the Maturity, of the Summer Fruits, by means of the Air, to which it has given a proper degree of Heat; yet we cannot Å¿ay in general, that it is the only and laÅ¿t Author of the perfect Maturity of all manner of Fruits, Å¿ince thoÅ¿e which are gather'd without being Ripe, Ripen of themÅ¿elves in the Store-HouÅ¿e, where the Sun no longer Å¿hines directly upon them.

Therefore, it will be more proper and more likely to Å¿ay, that the Sun indeed begins the Maturity of thoÅ¿e Fruits, which remain upon the Tree, to a certain degree of Perfection, without which the Fruits Å¿hrink and Å¿poil, without having enjoy'd the benefit of the real way of a good Maturity, and that after this the greateÅ¿t Crudity having been thus conÅ¿um'd by the Heat of the Sun, as all Natural Bodies are Subject to Corrupt, Å¿ome Å¿ooner, others later; one part of the Fruits of the Store-HouÅ¿e arrive at laÅ¿t to the Period of their ExiÅ¿tance, which often proves the Point of an agreeable Maturity; another part likewiÅ¿e meets its end in a precipitated RottenneÅ¿s, which may proceed either from too much Cold, or too much Heat, or too much MoiÅ¿ture, &c.

We might likewiÅ¿e PleaÅ¿e our Å¿elves with asking, whether thoÅ¿e Fruits, which are Å¿ooneÅ¿t Ripe, are better for the Health of Man, than thoÅ¿e which are longer before they attain their Maturity. The like queÅ¿tion might be made, as to thoÅ¿e that are Perfum'd, and thoÅ¿e that are not; Å¿uch as have Kernels, and Å¿uch as have Stones, &c. But whereas thoÅ¿e Gallantries are of no uÅ¿e to the matter in hand, I Å¿hall Wave them, and proceed to the InÅ¿tructions that are neceÅ¿Å¿ary, in order to learn to gather Fruits SeaÅ¿onably, without loÅ¿ing my Time in needleÅ¿s PhiloÅ¿ophy.

FirÅ¿t, Then, Care muÅ¿t be taken to underÅ¿tand that Maturity rightly, as alÅ¿o that not only every kind of Fruit has a time, or regulated SeaÅ¿on for its Maturity, but likewiÅ¿e that of every Particular Fruit in its SeaÅ¿on, Å¿ome have as it were, about Week to be good in, and no more, as the RouÅ¿Å¿elets or RuÅ¿Å¿etins, Beurre or Butter-Pears, Burgamets, Verte-Longue or Long-Green, &c. others not above a Day or two, and nothing beyond it, as Figs, Cherries, moÅ¿t Peaches, &c. Å¿ome have a great deal longer, as Grapes,
Apples, and moÅ¿t Winter Fruits, for InÅ¿tance, an Apple or Bon ChreÅ¿tien Pear, will be good to Eat for a Month or Å¿ix Weeks together.
Moreover, it muÅ¿t be Noted, that every kind of Fruit has its peculiar marks of Maturity, either Å¿uch as Ripen upon the Tree, or Å¿uch as only Ripen Å¿ome time after their being gather'd.

Altho Generally the Common time of Maturity of every kind, is within the CompaÅ¿s of the knowledg and underÅ¿tanding of Common Gard'ners, who commonly are pretty able to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h which are Summer, which Autumn, and which Winter Fruits, &c. Yet it is certain that the Å¿ingular Marks of the Maturity of every Fruit in particular, to take them in the very nick of time, that is, the preciÅ¿e time of their Maturity, thoÅ¿e Marks, I Å¿ay, are properly reÅ¿erv'd for the knowledg of a Gentleman who will uÅ¿e Å¿ome Application about it, without which nothing is more Common than to Å¿ee Fruits Å¿erv'd, either before their being Ripe, that is before they are good, or elÅ¿e paÅ¿s'd Fruits, that is, too Ripe, and ConÅ¿equently nought, and that at a time too, when without doubt, there are others, which having attain'd a juÅ¿t Maturity might Å¿upply the Room of thoÅ¿e, and which for want of being us'd at that time, have the misfortune to loÅ¿e their Delicacy, and the Value they deÅ¿erv'd.

One would think that there were but little to be Å¿aid upon the Subject of this Maturity of Fruits, and yet the extream Application I have us'd about it for a long while, has couvinc'd me of the Contrary. And whereas all the Expence, all the Care, and all the Pains People have been at, to get Fruit, would prove vain, if having CompaÅ¿s'd it, they were Å¿till at a loÅ¿s, not knowing how to make the good â¢ Å¿e of it they propos'd, I think my Å¿elf Oblig'd not to Omit the leaÅ¿t CircumÅ¿tance of any thing that may Å¿eem UÅ¿eful to that End.

I have already fully Explain'd in the TreatiÅ¿e of the Choice and Proportion of Fruits, which are the Fruits not only of every SeaÅ¿on, but even thoÅ¿e which are of every Month, Å¿o that perhaps it would be tireÅ¿ome and needleÅ¿s to Repeat it here; Å¿o that the only thing in QueÅ¿tion now is, to give a true Explication of what Relates to the Particulars of the Maturity of every Fruit, and if PoÅ¿Å¿ible to give the World a greater InÅ¿ight into that Knowledg, than it has had hitherto.

Above all things, I would have an Ingenious Gard'ner Å¿o well Skill'd in that Point, as never to PreÅ¿ent any of his Fruits, EÅ¿pecially of thoÅ¿e that are Tender and Mellow, as Peaches, Figs, Plums, or Pears, unleÅ¿s they were in a juÅ¿t degree of Maturity, in Å¿o much that thoÅ¿e they are preÅ¿ented to, may take the very firÅ¿t, without the leaÅ¿t fear of being DiÅ¿appointed, or at leaÅ¿t may be able to chuÅ¿e with the Eye, without being reduc'd to Picking, and Squeezing, that is to Å¿poil the Fruit, before they can meet with any to their liking.

My Intention is, that this Picking and Squeezing, which hitherto may have been Pardonable, or Tollerable, Å¿hall no longer be allowable, unleÅ¿s it be at the Tavern, or among ordinary People, and Å¿uch as have little or no nicety, or elÅ¿e Å¿uch as have no Fruit but what they Buy at the Market: And even there I would not have thoÅ¿e Squeezers, Squeeze any where but near the Stalk, and that gently too, Sticking to the firÅ¿t which yields to the Thumb, to the End that one Part only may be tainted by this Squeezing (which occaÅ¿ions a beginning of RottenneÅ¿s) beÅ¿ides they may aÅ¿Å¿ure themÅ¿elves, that whatever Fruit is Ripe near the Stalk, is Å¿ufficiently Å¿o every where.

One of the moÅ¿t ConÅ¿iderable Defects I am to Combat here, is the Precipitation wherewith I obÅ¿erve moÅ¿t of the Curious are inclin'd, to begin betimes to CauÅ¿e the Fruits of every SeaÅ¿on to be Eaten; nothing is more Common than to Å¿ee that when People have begun ill, they continue during all the SeaÅ¿on to Eat their Fruit ill Condition'd, by reaÅ¿on that as Naturally the deÅ¿ire of Eating Fruit continues from the Moment we have begun to do it, it commonly happens, that in gathering the Second or Third time we commit the Å¿ame Fault we had been guilty of at the FirÅ¿t; whereas if we tarry to Eat thoÅ¿e that are in SeaÅ¿on until we have a Å¿ufficient quantity Ripe to give, we have ever after the Å¿atisfaction of Eating none but Å¿uch as are incomparably good.
Therefore, I adviÅ¿e all Gard'ners never to begin gathering until there be a viÅ¿ible Appearance of a happy Continuance.

I am likewiÅ¿e to Combat another great Defect, of Å¿ome of the Curious, which is Å¿eldom or never to Å¿erve any Fruits until they be paÅ¿s'd, the Number of thoÅ¿e is very conÅ¿iderable: Their fear of its not laÅ¿ting long enough, or of not having enough for Å¿ome occaÅ¿ion or other, or rather their Ignorance in point of Maturity, occaÅ¿ions all this diÅ¿order: Therefore I will Endeavour to Remedy thoÅ¿e two Defects.

But firÅ¿t, I cannot forbear to admire, in this place, the Providence of Nature, not only in what relates to the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of that Maturity, which we Å¿ee in relation to every kind of Fruit, commonly to make the one Ripen in one SeaÅ¿on, and the other in another; but alÅ¿o in what relates to the Order of the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of the Maturity of the Fruits of every Tree in particular, which it conducts to Maturity by degrees; as if it really intended to allow Man, for the NouriÅ¿hment of whom it Å¿eems to have produc'd them, time to conÅ¿ume them all, without Å¿uffering any to periÅ¿h: And, indeed, it is obÅ¿ervable, that Nature likewiÅ¿e obÅ¿erves the Å¿ame Order for the forming, and the opening of the BloÅ¿Å¿oms of Trees, and Plants, which produce Fruit, as it does for Plants which only produce Flowers; for inÅ¿tance, Hiacints, TuberoÅ¿es, Carnations, &c. the Buds whereof only open by degrees, as if deÅ¿ign'd thereby, the longer to delight the SenÅ¿es of Humane Creatures.

In effect, tho' every BloÅ¿Å¿om of a Tree does not commonly laÅ¿t above four or five days in its perfection, yet every Tree appears in BloÅ¿Å¿om for a Fortnight, or three Weeks together, which certainly proceeds from that the BloÅ¿Å¿oms are Originally form'd, and afterwards open one after another; thoÅ¿e that are form'd firÅ¿t, open firÅ¿t, as thoÅ¿e that BloÅ¿Å¿om firÅ¿t, have the advantage of producing thoÅ¿e Fruits which ripen firÅ¿t; thus the Å¿econd and third BloÅ¿Å¿oms, which are like Å¿o many younger SiÅ¿ters, Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively form'd after the Elder, Å¿eem to perfect themÅ¿elves, while thoÅ¿e delight our Eyes; thoÅ¿e Å¿econd, and third BloÅ¿Å¿oms, I Å¿ay, in imitation of a well-regulated Family, are not to open, and Å¿hew themÅ¿elves, until the Elders have had their Career; Å¿o that thoÅ¿e Elder fading, in order to produce the firÅ¿t Fruits of their SeaÅ¿on, the young ones appear, to form thoÅ¿e Fruits which are to be the Å¿econd, and third, in Ripening, &c.

Although we have obÅ¿erv'd in every Tree an order in the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of the Maturity of the Fruits, in relation to each other; we do not find this Å¿ame Order of SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of Maturity obÅ¿erv'd for the Fruits of another Tree, of a certain kind, in reÅ¿pect to the Fruits of another Tree, which is of another certain kind, whether both have BloÅ¿Å¿om'd at one and the Å¿ame time, or whether the one have BloÅ¿Å¿om'd Å¿ooner, the other later: For inÅ¿tance, all Peach-Trees BloÅ¿Å¿om at the Å¿ame time, and yet Å¿ome Peaches Ripen about the middle of AuguÅ¿t, and others do not Ripen 'till towards the end of October; and likewiÅ¿e other Fruit-Trees, either Pear, Apple, or Plum-Trees BloÅ¿Å¿om almoÅ¿t all in one and the Å¿ame Month, and yet that kind which BloÅ¿Å¿oms firÅ¿t, does not always Ripen firÅ¿t; Nature Orders it otherwiÅ¿e, which I can give no ReaÅ¿on for: The Pear of Naples for InÅ¿tance, is the firÅ¿t that BloÅ¿Å¿oms, and almoÅ¿t the laÅ¿t which comes to Maturity.

Therefore, as it is moÅ¿t certain, that Fruits ripen one after another, Å¿o it is likewiÅ¿e true, that, as Aurora UÅ¿hers in, or declares the coming of the Sun, Å¿o the Maturity of Fruits is declar'd, or preceeded by Å¿ome particular marks, the knowledge of which, I have made it my buÅ¿ineÅ¿s to Å¿tudy; and I am of Opinion, that I Å¿hall oblige the Curious, by acquainting them with my ObÅ¿ervations.

'Tis certainly very difficult to be very exact as to the preciÅ¿e time of the juÅ¿t maturity of Fruits: Nothing is Å¿o common as to be deceiv'd therein, as we have already declar'd, either in gathering them too Å¿oon, or too late; beÅ¿ides, there are Å¿ome in which the Point of Maturity is Å¿o momentary, as the white Butter-Pear, the Maudlin-Pear, the DoyeinnÃ©, the White of Andilly, &c. that whatever Care be taken, it is almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible to hit that Point of Maturity exactly, it paÅ¿Å¿es Å¿o Å¿wiftly, when once 'tis come; neither am I fond of having many of thoÅ¿e kind of Fruits.

As nothing is more delightful than to eat well-condition'd Fruits, nothing can be more diÅ¿agreeable than to eat them green, or over-ripe: Not but in my Opinion, this laÅ¿t defect is leÅ¿s tolerable than the firÅ¿t, by reaÅ¿on that all Fruit that is over-ripe, far from having any taÅ¿t, is commonly inÅ¿ipid, and mealy; whereas Fruit that is not quite ripe enough, though on the one Å¿ide it may Å¿et the Teeth on edge, yet on the other it diÅ¿covers part of its Vertue, by the briskneÅ¿s of its taÅ¿t, and by its Pulp drawing near perfection; moÅ¿t Women in this, will be of my Opinion.

Moreover, as in this particular CaÅ¿e of Maturity we have two Å¿orts of Fruit, of which, the one are good, from the moment they are gather'd; for inÅ¿tance, all Stone Fruits, Å¿ome Summer-Pears, and all Red-Fruits, &c. it follows, that none of thoÅ¿e Å¿hould be gather'd until they be ripe, by reaÅ¿on, that how little time Å¿oever their Maturity may laÅ¿t, they preÅ¿erve themÅ¿elves much better, and longer upon the Stock than they would do being gather'd: There are other Fruits which are only good Å¿ometime after their being gather'd; for Example, moÅ¿t Kernel-Fruits that are Mellow, and conÅ¿tantly all Autumn, and Winter-Fruits. In Order to give true Rules to underÅ¿tand the Maturity of all manner of Fruits, I think it will not be improper to begin here with thoÅ¿e that are fit to be eaten as Å¿oon as gather'd; I Å¿hall not mention the others, until I come to the TreatiÅ¿e of the Store-HouÅ¿es, or Fruit-Rooms.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: How to judge of the Maturity and GoodneÅ¿s of Fruits.

div.p: THree of our SenÅ¿es have the gift of judging of the appearances of the Maturity of Fruits, Viz. Sight, Feeling for the moÅ¿t part, and Smelling for Å¿ome, I Å¿ay only to judge of the appearances, for the TaÅ¿t is the only and real Judge to whom it belongs to Judge Solidly, and without appeal, as well of the Maturity, as of the GoodneÅ¿s, it is Å¿ufficiently known that there are Å¿ome Fruits which are neither good nor agreeable to the Pallat, tho' actually ripe.

Sometimes one SenÅ¿e alone is Å¿ufficient, to Judge certainly of the appearances, and even of the reality; for inÅ¿tance, the Eye alone Å¿uffices for all Red Fruits, and for Grapes, &c. it Judges with certainty of the RipeneÅ¿s of a Cherry, a Strawberry, a RaÅ¿pberry, a Bunch of Red, or Black Grapes; when both the one and the other are all over Painted with that fine Colour, which is natural to them: And on the contrary, when any part does want it, the Eye thereby judges, that it is an infallible Mark, that all the reÅ¿t is not yet arriv'd to its juÅ¿t Maturity.

So likewiÅ¿e, Feeling alone judges very well of the apparent and effective Maturity of Tender Mellow Pears, whatever they be; Å¿o that even the Blind are as able to judge of it by feeling, as the moÅ¿t clear Sighted, both by Å¿eeing, and touching.

Sometimes it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to imploy two of our SenÅ¿es, Seeing, and Feeling, barely to Judge of the appearance of Maturity; for Example, for Figs, Plums, and Peaches, and even Apricocks, it not being Å¿ufficient for a Peach to appear ripe upon the Tree by its Beautiful Colour, red on the one Å¿ide, and yellowiÅ¿h on the other, thereby to judge that it is fit for gathering; neither does it Å¿uffice after their being gather'd, for them to be without Stalks, beÅ¿ides this fine Colouring, though commonly it is a good Mark, the Stalk always Å¿ticking to thoÅ¿e kind of Fruits, until their being ripe, at which time the Fruit quits it with eaÅ¿e, and the Stalk remains fix'd to the Tree; but whereas this Stalk may have been Å¿ever'd violently, their appearing without a Stalk, may chance to prove a falÅ¿e Mark of Maturity.

ThoÅ¿e Signs alone, as to thoÅ¿e kind of Fruits, I Å¿ay are not Å¿ufficient, to Judge abÅ¿olutely by the Eye of their Maturity, the Hand muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e act its part, and concur therein, tho' not to touch it roughly upon the Tree (nothing is more offenÅ¿ive to me than thoÅ¿e Gropers, who, to gather one according to their Mind, will Å¿poil a hundred by the violent impreÅ¿Å¿ion of their Unskillful Thumb) but I would have the Hand play its part in the manner I Å¿hall explain hereafter.

The Hand muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be us'd for a Peach that is ready gather'd, when we are not certain it was gather'd by a Skillful Hand, but then it muÅ¿t be perform'd very gently, and that, as I have already Å¿aid, near the Stalk.

In caÅ¿e it be a Fig, whether gather'd, or not, it is allowable to touch it gently with the end of the Finger, almoÅ¿t in the Å¿ame manner as a Chyrurgeon feels for the Vein in order to Bleed; for in caÅ¿e that Fig, after having appear'd to the Eye of a yellowiÅ¿h Colour, a Å¿hrivel'd Rind, with Å¿ome Crannies, the Head hanging down, and the Body Å¿hrunk, likewiÅ¿e appears very Mellow under the Finger, and that being Å¿till upon the Tree, may be looÅ¿en'd by the leaÅ¿t motion, it is very Å¿it for gathering, and without doubt ripe, and good: But if, notwithÅ¿tanding all thoÅ¿e fine appearances, and all this MyÅ¿tery, it does not eaÅ¿ily quit the Tree, the gathering of it muÅ¿t be deferr'd for Å¿ome days, it is never perfectly good, while it reÅ¿iÅ¿ts in gathering.

When a Fig having all the good Marks of Maturity, has been gather'd by a Skillful Gard'ner, and is afterwards preÅ¿ented to any body, they may freely, and without any rough feeling, judge it to be fit to receive, and eat.

We may Å¿ay the Å¿ame thing of a Plum ready gather'd, that is, that if beÅ¿ides the Beautiful Colour it ought to have, which Å¿atisfies the Eye, and the MellowneÅ¿s which Skillful Fingers have diÅ¿cover'd, without offering it any violence, it proves without a Stalk, being a little Å¿hrivel'd, and wither'd on that Å¿ide; it may be inferr'd from thence, that it is perfectly ripe, and conÅ¿equently fit to take.

LikewiÅ¿e if this Plum being Å¿till upon the Tree, finely Colour'd for the Eye, and Mellow for the Finger, comes off with eaÅ¿e, without a Stalk, it is without doubt fully ripe, but if not, like the Fig, itmuÅ¿t be left Å¿ome days longer upon the Tree.

Two things may be inferr'd from this remark about the Stalk, the firÅ¿t is, that it muÅ¿t not Å¿tick to Å¿ome kind of Fruits when they are ripe; for inÅ¿tance, Peaches, Plums, Straw-berries, RaÅ¿pberries, &c. inÅ¿omuch that none of thoÅ¿e Fruits Å¿hould be eaten, while the Stalk Å¿ticks cloÅ¿e to them; and the Å¿econd, that it may, and ought to Å¿tick to others, tho' never Å¿o ripe; for Example, to Figs, Cherries, Pears, Apples, &c. to which, the Stalks Å¿erve as an agreeable Ornament, and their being without it, would be a kind of Defect.

After having demonÅ¿trated, that in Å¿ome Fruits, for Example, Red Fruits, the Eye alone is Å¿ufficient to judge of their Maturity, and in others, as Tender Mellow Pears, the feeling only; as alÅ¿o that Å¿ome others require both Seeing, and Feeling, Viz. Peaches, Plums, Figs, &c. we may add, that there are Å¿till Å¿ome others in which Smelling may be admitted with Sight, in order to Judge with more certainty, for inÅ¿tance, Melons, after having approv'd their Colour, Stalk, and Beautiful Figure, and examin'd their PonderouÅ¿neÅ¿s, it is not improper to Å¿mell to them before we cut them, to be able, as 'tis thought, thereby to judge with more certainty of their Maturity, and GoodneÅ¿s, tho' at the Å¿ame time I am convinc'd, that thoÅ¿e which have the beÅ¿t Å¿cent, or Å¿avour, are not commonly the beÅ¿t: This Maxim is Å¿ufficiently well eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd.

But, in fine, generally Å¿peaking, all the Marks above explain'd, to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h Maturity, may chance not to be certain, and infallible; they are Exteriour Signs, which might be term'd Signs of PhiÅ¿iognomy, and ConÅ¿equently deceitful, Å¿omething more is neceÅ¿Å¿ary in this CaÅ¿e, it requires matter of Fact; and therefore, as we have already declar'd, TaÅ¿t only can decide in this Point; and, if I may uÅ¿e that ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion, that only can affix the Seal, and the Character of an abÅ¿olute Decree, as a Judgment, which is to be Pronounc'd, particularly in the CaÅ¿e of GoodneÅ¿s; for let the Exteriour Marks be never Å¿o favourable, unleÅ¿s the Peach, Plum, and Melon pleaÅ¿e the Pallat, after having pleas'd the other SenÅ¿es, as it happens Å¿ometimes, all the Preliminaries are uÅ¿eleÅ¿s; therefore we muÅ¿t Å¿ubmit all to the Pallat, however with this Å¿cruple, which I cannot remove, for the eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing of real goodneÅ¿s, which is, that TaÅ¿ts are very different in themÅ¿elves, and that a thing which may pleaÅ¿e one Man's Pallat, may diÅ¿pleaÅ¿e another's: But this diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ion is out of my Province; the Ancient Maxim (de GuÅ¿tibus) forbids my medling with it, and thus I can only Å¿peak of my own in particular, and at the Å¿ame time applaud thoÅ¿e who have the good Fortune of liking that which does not Å¿eem good to me: It would be Ridiculous in me to endeavour diÅ¿abuÅ¿ing of them, Å¿ince probably I Å¿hou'd only loÅ¿e my labour.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: Of the CauÅ¿es of the forwardneÅ¿s, or backwardneÅ¿s of Maturity, in all manner of Fruits.

div.p: Fruits Ripen Å¿ooner, or later, firÅ¿t, according as the Months of April, and May are more or leÅ¿s warm, to cauÅ¿e the Trees to BloÅ¿Å¿om, or Knit.

Secondly, according as thoÅ¿e Fruits grow againÅ¿t a good Wall, or good Shelter, that is, expos'd to the South, or EaÅ¿t; and, in fine, particularly according as they are in a hot Climate, and light Earth.

All which ConÅ¿iderations are very material for the forwardneÅ¿s of Fruits; for the Months of April and May proving hot, the Fruits knitting the Å¿ooner, they will conÅ¿equently ripen the Å¿ooner; witneÅ¿s the maturity of Melons, which is an undeniable Truth; Fruits being, as it were, in reÅ¿pect to their Maturity, like Bread, in reÅ¿pect to its being Bak'd the Å¿ooner, or later, according to the time of its being put into the Oven.

When Fruits, tho' knit betimes, are in the open Air, or only againÅ¿t Å¿ome Walls expos'd to the WeÅ¿t, or North, &c. they will advance but little, for want of the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the heats of the Spring, and likewiÅ¿e, if notwithÅ¿tanding the advantage of a pretty hot SeaÅ¿on, and happy expoÅ¿ure, they are in a Cold Climate, nay, tho' in a moderate Clime, the Earth being CourÅ¿e, and conÅ¿equently Cold, they will not ripen Å¿o Å¿oon, as thoÅ¿e which have all things favourable.

For Example, all manner of Fruits ripen Å¿ooner, in Languedoc, and Provence, which are hot Soils, than in the Neighbourhood of Paris, and even in thoÅ¿e parts of Paris Fruits Ripen much Å¿ooner within the City it Å¿elf, and in the Subburbs of St. Anthony, and St.
Germans, as well as at Vincennes, at MaiÅ¿ons, Carriere, &c. where the Earth is light, and hot, than they do at VerÅ¿ailles, where the Ground is cold, and courÅ¿e.

All thoÅ¿e places are too near one another, to impute thoÅ¿e differences in point of Maturity to the Sun; beÅ¿ides, there is a difference between the immediate heat of the Sun in reÅ¿pect to the maturity of Fruits, and the immediate heat of the Fire, in reÅ¿pect to the Meat it RoÅ¿ts, or Boils, Fire firÅ¿t affecting the Exteriour parts of the Meat which are neareÅ¿t to it, before it performs its Function on the inÅ¿ide, which is at more diÅ¿tance; whereas the Sun Ripens the inward parts, before the Exteriour; in effect, the inward part of Fruits always Ripens firÅ¿t, and Å¿often firÅ¿t, and likewiÅ¿e commonly is the Å¿ooneÅ¿t Å¿poil'd.

If I may be allow'd to declare the ReaÅ¿on which to me Å¿eems moÅ¿t plauÅ¿ible in this Point, I Å¿hall Å¿ay, in the firÅ¿t place, that Maturity proceeds from two CauÅ¿es, the one near and immediate, which is the heated Air, the other not indirect, and diÅ¿tant, and that is the Sun which heats that Air; Å¿o that the Function of the Sun is to heat the Air as much as the Winds will allow; and the Function of the Air Å¿o heated, is to impart its heat to the Earth, and Å¿o to all the Plants; this Earth thus heated, cauÅ¿es firÅ¿t the Principle of Life which lies near the Root to Act, and then the Root it Å¿elf, which conÅ¿equently prepares Sap as Å¿oon as it is put in Action; and that Sap, at the Å¿ame time, riÅ¿es to perform its Function into all the Superiour parts, where it can penetrate.

In the Å¿econd place, I Å¿hall Å¿ay, that the Air of every Climate is in probability compos'd, or at leaÅ¿t conÅ¿iderably mix'd with the Vapours, and Exhalations which riÅ¿e from the Earth of that Climate, which in my Opinion, is the ReaÅ¿on of Peoples Å¿aying, that the Air of Å¿uch a Country is good, and the Air of Å¿uch another is bad.

Thirdly, I Å¿hall Å¿ay, that it follows from thence, that that Air is more or leÅ¿s eaÅ¿ie to be heated, according as the Earth, from which thoÅ¿e Vapours riÅ¿e, is more or leÅ¿s cold, and material; for thoÅ¿e Vapours participate altogether to the Nature of that Earth, and therefore that as in light Earths the Air Å¿ooner receives the impreÅ¿Å¿ion of heat, by reaÅ¿on of its being form'd by more Å¿ubtle Vapours, it conÅ¿equently the Å¿ooner heats both that Earth, and the whole Body of the Tree, and the Plant it nouriÅ¿hes; which is the ReaÅ¿on that it is the Roots being Å¿ooner heated at Å¿uch times, and in Å¿uch Earth, and conÅ¿equently the Saps being Å¿ooner prepar'd, which form inwardly in thoÅ¿e Fruits the firÅ¿t degrees of Maturity.

Therefore it is certain, that the Air, according to its being more or leÅ¿s thick, is alÅ¿o more or leÅ¿s apt to receive heat; and that according to its degrees of heat, it either advances, or does not advance Maturity, as it has advanc'd, or not advanc'd the heat of the Earth.

Therefore the forwardneÅ¿s, or backwardneÅ¿s of Maturity, depends on the Conditions above explain'd, in Å¿o muuch, that they muÅ¿t all Combine; that is, that Fruit in order to Ripen betimes, muÅ¿t Knit betimes; and next, muÅ¿t meet with a favourable ExpoÅ¿ure, a hot Clime, and light Earth.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Of the Particular Marks of Maturity in every kind of Fruit, and firÅ¿t of Summer-Fruits, which Ripen altogether upon the Tree.

div.p:
ACcording to the Natural Order of the Maturity of Fruits of every SeaÅ¿on, the Honour of ElderÅ¿hip certainly belongs to early Cherries, and next to Strawberries, RaÅ¿pberries, and Goosberries, &c. The firÅ¿t commonly begin to appear in the Month of May, and that a little Å¿ooner, or a little later, according as the Conditions we have Explain'd, are more or leÅ¿s favourable: Strawberries begin to BloÅ¿Å¿om about the middle of April, or a little before, in good Situations, and in cold places, not before the latter end of April, or in the beginning of May; and happily, none of thoÅ¿e Å¿mall FroÅ¿ts which are apt to blacken, and Å¿poil thoÅ¿e firÅ¿t BloÅ¿Å¿oms intervening, Ripe Strawberries may be expected at a Months end: And as for early Cherries that have BloÅ¿Å¿om'd about the middle of March, we may expect to have them about the beginning of May, not altogether Ripe, but half Red, with which Colour they may Å¿erve as well, as if they had attain'd a full Maturity, Å¿ince they are only conÅ¿iderable, and valued for their Novelty, eÅ¿pecially by Ladies;
for after all, at that time it is only a little colour'd Cloak, which only Å¿erves to cover a little Å¿ower Pulp, and a large Stone; and therefore they Å¿tand in need of the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of a Confectioner, to require an Excellency, which the Gard'ner, or rather the Sun has not had time to afford them.

The Trees of a pretty Cold Climate BloÅ¿Å¿om almoÅ¿t as Å¿oon as thoÅ¿e of a Climate that is Å¿omewhat hotter, by ReaÅ¿on that the opening of thoÅ¿e BloÅ¿Å¿oms Å¿eems to be perform'd independantly from the Action of the Roots, witneÅ¿s the Branches that BloÅ¿Å¿om, being Cut, (the bare force of the Rarefaction caus'd in the Bud, by the preÅ¿ence of the firÅ¿t Rays of the Sun, is capable of producing this Effect) but as for the maturity of every Fruit, it can only be perform'd, and perfected; FirÅ¿t, by a great Concurrency of the Operation of the Roots, and Secondly, by a certain degree of Heat in the Air, which is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the Perfection of that MaÅ¿ter-piece: Now this Heat, both in the Earth, and in the Air, can only proceed regularly from the Rays of the Sun; and yet I dare affirm, that I have been Å¿o happy as to imitate it in little for Å¿ome Å¿mall Fruits; I have made Å¿ome to Ripen five or Å¿ix Weeks before their time; for inÅ¿tance, Strawberries at the end of March, and PeaÅ¿e in April, Figs in June, AÅ¿paragus, and Cabbage-Lettuce in December, January, &c. But we can find no facilitations to imitate this Heat in Great, to cauÅ¿e the Fruits of Large Trees to Ripen in an extraordinary manner; therefore it is apparent, that tho' Nature has abandon'd the Earth to us, leaving it in our Power to Heat Å¿ome Portion thereof, to make it produce againÅ¿t its will, by means of a Foreign borrow'd Heat, what we have a mind to; has, notwithÅ¿tanding, reÅ¿erv'd to it Å¿elf in a particular manner, the UniverÅ¿al Faculty of the maturity of Fruits; this maturity in relation to us, is the FiniÅ¿her, and Perfection of the production of the Earth; in Å¿o much, that without it, all our Cares and InduÅ¿try for the generality, only afford us Å¿ome hopes, which often prove falÅ¿e, and deluding.

I have Å¿aid heretofore, that we may begin to have Å¿ome early Cherries, in the Month of May, thoÅ¿e Å¿mall Fruits have an open Field at that Time, they are the only that appear in our Gardens, and that grace our Tables; they are Rival'd by no others until the end of the Month, which is the time of the diÅ¿playing or opening the Grand Magazine of the other Red Fruits; and theÅ¿e remain in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion until the end of June, and towards the middle of July; for the early Cherries which Å¿eldom appear but in China-DiÅ¿hes, and in Å¿mall quantity, are follow'd cloÅ¿e by Strawberries, with this difference; that theÅ¿e, to endear themÅ¿elves the more, above the Cherries that have preceeded them, appear with a Charming Å¿cent, and in prodigious quantity; that is, in full BaÅ¿ons, and would think themÅ¿elves diÅ¿grac'd to appear as poorly attended, as their PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors.

Among theÅ¿e Strawberries Å¿ome are Red, and others White, the laÅ¿t are Å¿eldom Ripe until they are grown yellowiÅ¿h, and the others are never good, until they are perfectly and UniverÅ¿ally Red; and neither of them are eatable, until they have attain'd a ConÅ¿iderable Å¿ize.

I may Å¿ay by the by, that thoÅ¿e Strawberries that are Å¿ooneÅ¿t Ripe, are thoÅ¿e that have BloÅ¿Å¿om'd firÅ¿t, and that thoÅ¿e that are neareÅ¿t to the body of the Plant, are thoÅ¿e that BloÅ¿Å¿om'd firÅ¿t; I will draw Å¿ome InÅ¿tructions in the TreatiÅ¿e of the Kitchen-Garden, in order to our getting of them always Finer, Larger, and Better, from that part, than otherwiÅ¿e we Å¿hould do.

The Strawberries that grow Naturally, and of themÅ¿elves, which moÅ¿t People are fond of, are accompany'd towards the middle of June with Red and White RaÅ¿pberries, Currans, Hearts, and Plain Cherries, of which, Å¿ome are Å¿omewhat earlier, and not Å¿o good; others later, which are larger, and Å¿weeter, and better, either PreÅ¿erv'd, or Raw: Bigarreaux alÅ¿o come in among them, and even Morrello's, but commonly they both tarry until the hurry of Red Fruits is Å¿omewhat over; not but they might appear Å¿ooner, for really thoÅ¿e Bigarreaux, and Morrello's are admirable Fruits: The firÅ¿t are Ripe, as Å¿oon as they are half Red, but the others do not attain their perfection of maturity, until they are almoÅ¿t Black. The order of the maturity of all thoÅ¿e Fruits is the Å¿ame with what we declar'd for the Strawberries, that which has BloÅ¿Å¿om'd firÅ¿t in every Tree, likewiÅ¿e Ripens Å¿ooneÅ¿t.

Here's the Month of June provided for, it is call'd the Month of Red Fruits, and with ReaÅ¿on: For thoÅ¿e kind of Fruits are met with wherever one goes; we have Å¿aid that the marks of their maturity is that Red Colour which Å¿urrounds them; it commonly begins at that part which is moÅ¿t immediately expos'd to the Sun, and is Å¿ooneÅ¿t Ripe; In fine, by degrees that Colour Å¿preads all over, and when the livelineÅ¿s of that Red begins to turn to an obÅ¿cure Red, excepting only the Morello's, they draw towards Corruption.

Among Red Fruits, thoÅ¿e that have Stones, tho' never Å¿o ripe, do not eaÅ¿ily looÅ¿en from the Branch, as other Fruits do, they wither upon it, inÅ¿tead of falling, they muÅ¿t be pluck'd off, and that with Å¿ome Violence.

All thoÅ¿e kind of Red Fruits Å¿hould be the only ones during the whole Month of June to fill up the Stage of the maturity of the Fruits of that SeaÅ¿on, but that Å¿ome EÅ¿paliers, expos'd to the South, in Dry Sandy Grounds, begin to produce towards the end of June Å¿ome little MuÅ¿cat-Pears, and Å¿ome early MuÅ¿ck-Peaches.

ThoÅ¿e Å¿mall Pears are Extraordinary good, if they be allow'd the time of Ripening; the firÅ¿t marks of their maturity appear in them as in all other Pears of every SeaÅ¿on, that is near the Stalk, which part muÅ¿t appear a little yellowiÅ¿h, and Å¿omewhat TranÅ¿parent; and afterwards, for a greater mark of full maturity, that yellowneÅ¿s muÅ¿t appear a little through a certain Tan'd Colour, and a certain Red, which covers the remainder of the Rind; and LaÅ¿tly, they muÅ¿t begin to drop of themÅ¿elves, without any exterior violence; at which time it will be proper to gather, and eat them. I have Å¿ufficiently declar'd my Opinion as to the goodneÅ¿s of that Pear, in the Choice of Fruits.

When People do not allow themÅ¿elves the time of examining about the Stalk of the Pears, to judge of their maturity; they muÅ¿t, as I have Å¿aid, judge by the natural dropping of thoÅ¿e kind of Pears, but then the Worms muÅ¿t have no Å¿hare in it, and they muÅ¿t neither be grown upon a Å¿ick Tree, nor upon a Å¿ick Branch; Pears that are infected with Worms drop Å¿ooneÅ¿t, and Å¿ooneÅ¿t Å¿eem Ripe, without really being Å¿o, their defect is not much conceal'd, it appears generally in the middle of the Eye of the Pear, and when it does, there's no depending upon it for good Fruit.

All manner of Fruits, borh Stone, and Kernel, Ripen Å¿ooner upon Å¿ickly Trees, than upon Å¿ound ones; but we muÅ¿t not Å¿uffer our Å¿elves to be deceiv'd by the Å¿ize, for it often happens, eÅ¿pecially in relation to Peach-Trees, that the Fruits of thoÅ¿e languiÅ¿hing Trees are larger than thoÅ¿e which grow upon Vigorous Trees; but then that LargeneÅ¿s, as I may Å¿ay, is only a Å¿welling, or a kind of DropÅ¿ie, which is the ReaÅ¿on that the Pulp of thoÅ¿e Fruits, that are larger than they Å¿hould be, is generally inÅ¿ipid, or bitter, and diÅ¿guÅ¿ting.

Peaches that drop of themÅ¿elves, are contrary to what we have been Å¿aying of Pears; by reaÅ¿on that Peaches which drop thus of themÅ¿elves, or looÅ¿en, are commonly paÅ¿s'd, and conÅ¿equently naught, in Å¿o much, that they Å¿hould not be preÅ¿ented as good to any body, tho' not bruis'd by the fall, as it happens commonly.

But that Rule does not commonly extend to Å¿mall Peaches in their kind, nor eÅ¿pecially to early or late Purple Peaches, nor to Pavies; thoÅ¿e kind of Fruits which can hardly ever be too ripe, are commonly very good when they drop, inÅ¿omuch, that when they drop without being Å¿hook, it is a good mark of their Maturity, as well as GoodneÅ¿s.

The Å¿ame thing may be Å¿aid of Plums, Å¿ince we always Å¿hake Plum-Trees in order to get good Plums; tho' indeed this Method is more particularly for common Plums, than for Perdrigons, Rochecourbons, and other Principal Plums, by reaÅ¿on that one of their Chief Excellencies conÅ¿iÅ¿ting in the Flowry Beauty of their Complexion, the which excites the Appetite of the moÅ¿t moderate: A fall, or their being finger'd too much, Å¿poils that Flower which Å¿hould be preÅ¿erv'd carefully; therefore thoÅ¿e that are really Curious, never touch them otherwiÅ¿e than with the extremity of two Fingers.

Let us now return to our early Peaches, and Å¿ay, that the Part which ripens firÅ¿t in them, as well as in all other Fruits, Pears, Peaches, Plums, Apricooks, Melons, &c. is commonly the inward part, I mean, that which is neareÅ¿t to the Stone, and moreover, that which in relation to them appears firÅ¿t ripe to the eye, is directly contrary to what we have Å¿aid of Pears; for whereas in Pears that part which is neareÅ¿t to the Stalk ripens firÅ¿t, in theÅ¿e it is commonly the Extremity which is oppoÅ¿ite to the Stalk, by reaÅ¿on that that part enjoys the benefit of the Sun Å¿ooner, and longer than any other; but when the Beams of the Sun lay upon no part of theÅ¿e early Peaches, it Å¿eems that the heat which Reigns in the Air, ripens them all over equally.

We begin to Judge of their approaching Maturity, when we perceive that they begin to thicken extreamly (which we call taking Pulp) and when at the Å¿ame time, their green whitens conÅ¿iderably, and their down begins to fall; but unfortunately for thoÅ¿e poor Fruits, or rather for Nice Pallats, and Å¿uch as have Skill; thoÅ¿e firÅ¿t appearances of maturity are commonly miÅ¿taken for perfect maturity, and Å¿o they are gather'd, while they are Å¿till as hard as Stones, inÅ¿tead of Å¿taying until they are grown Mellow, as they Å¿hould be; and therefore, excepting a few of the firÅ¿t, which are Å¿erv'd pretty unÅ¿eaÅ¿onably, moÅ¿t of them paÅ¿s through the fire, before they appear at Table.

I muÅ¿t not omit Å¿aying in this place, that the Peaches which do not attain the Å¿ize their kind requires, commonly drop before their being ripe, and when they Å¿eem to ripen,
their Rind remains downy, their Pulp green, their Water bitter, and the Stone Larger than thoÅ¿e which have taken more Pulp.

Neither muÅ¿t I forget to Å¿ay, that as a little after the knitting of the Fruit, generally a conÅ¿iderable part of it drops, Å¿o it often happens that at the time the maturity approaches, a great number of the Fruits fall, and that about a Fortnight, or Three Weeks before that maturity, as if the Tree was Å¿enÅ¿ible of its being over-burthen'd, and would thereby give us notice that the good time is approaching; and indeed it is commonly obÅ¿erv'd at that time, that a good number of Large Fruits drop, whereby thoÅ¿e that remain, grow the finer, and the better; and as we have already Å¿aid, it had been much the better for them, had the Gard'ner taken Care to perform what time has now done.

People are overjoy'd to Å¿ee thoÅ¿e early Peaches ripe at the end of June, and to enjoy them long, which is not difficult, provided we have Å¿everal Trees of them in different ExpoÅ¿ures; they are incomparable, when they are well-Condition'd, both as to Å¿ize, and maturity; but then we are commonly expos'd to the vexation of tarrying until towards the end of July, for the Peaches that Å¿ucceed theÅ¿e firÅ¿t, and thoÅ¿e we call Troy-Peaches; which Peaches, provided they be throughly ripe, charm every body by the fineneÅ¿s of their Pulp, the perfume of their Water, and the deliciouÅ¿neÅ¿s of their TaÅ¿t; their maturity is known as in other Fruits, FirÅ¿t by the Å¿ize, Secondly by a fine red Colour on that Å¿ide which is expos'd to the Sun, and a light TranÅ¿parent Yellow in the other parts: Thirdly, by a thin, Å¿oft, mellow Rind, Å¿omewhat like Satin; any of theÅ¿e marks being wanting, the Fruit cannot be ripe, and therefore Å¿hould not be gather'd.

ThoÅ¿e Troy-Peaches are often abus'd as well as the early Peaches, and all other Peaches at the entrance of their maturity; that is, they are gather'd upon the leaÅ¿t Symptoms, without Å¿taying until they have attain'd that degree of goodneÅ¿s, they never obtain 'till they are throughly ripe; and this defect proceeds, either from the ignorance, or liquoriÅ¿hneÅ¿s of the PerÅ¿on, who gathers them out of deÅ¿ire to eat, or elÅ¿e out of a Å¿illy avidity of gain, which reigns in the Heart, and Eyes of thoÅ¿e who are uneaÅ¿ie until they expoÅ¿e them to Å¿ale in the Market.

The Month of July affords us many other Fruits beÅ¿ides Troy-Peaches, but the Month of AuguÅ¿t Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿es it in point of abundance, for it affords us not only an infinity of Plums, but alÅ¿o a vaÅ¿t quantity of Kernel-Fruits; among which, are the CuiÅ¿Å¿e-Madame, or Lady-Thigh, the Gros-Blanquet, the Sans-Peau, or without Rind, The EÅ¿pargne, or Sparing, the Orange-Pears, the Summer-Bon-Chreitien, the CaÅ¿Å¿olets, the Robins, the RuÅ¿Å¿ettings, &c. the maturity of which is known, either by their dropping, or not reÅ¿iÅ¿ting when they are gather'd, or elÅ¿e by a certain yellow colour, which appears in the Rind, eÅ¿pecially near the Stalk. Among Plums we reckon the Perdrigons, the Mirabelles, Imperials, St. Catherine, Roche-Courbon, Queen Claude, Apricock-Plums, &c. To thoÅ¿e Plums are joyn'd about the middle of AuguÅ¿t Å¿ome fine Peaches, Viz. FirÅ¿t, the two Magdalens, the white and red, the Mignonne, the Bourdin, the RoÅ¿Å¿ane, &c. all which are large: In the Å¿econd place, the Alberges, both red, and yellow, the Cherry-Peach, the one with white Pulp, the other with yellow, &c. thoÅ¿e Peaches, as well as thoÅ¿e that are to Å¿ucceed them, have no other particular marks to diÅ¿cover their maturity, than thoÅ¿e I have already mention'd for early, and Troy-Peaches, which are a reaÅ¿onable Å¿ize, a red and yellowiÅ¿h colour without any mixture of Green, and eÅ¿pecially their coming off with eaÅ¿e at the leaÅ¿t pull or motion of a Skilful hand; all theÅ¿e Fruits are fit to eat as Å¿oon as gather'd, and require no Store-HouÅ¿e, at leaÅ¿t to ripen, Peaches never ripening off the Tree, Å¿o that it is in vain to gather them before they are perfectly ripe; but as I have Å¿aid elÅ¿ewhere, a day or two's repoÅ¿e in the Store-HouÅ¿e, far from injuring of them, affords them a certain coolneÅ¿s which is very proper for them, and which they cannot acquire, while they remain upon the Tree.

The Month of September is famous for a world of the Principal Peaches, the ChevreuÅ¿e, HaÅ¿ty Violet, PerÅ¿ique, Admirable, Pourpree, or Purple-Peach, Bellegarde, White d'Andilly, beÅ¿ides Brugnons, and white Pavies, &c. There are alÅ¿o Å¿ome Summer Calville Apples, and Å¿ome good Pears, which keep theÅ¿e Peaches Company, and may be eaten off the Tree, Viz. The Melting-Pear of BreÅ¿t, brown Orange-Pears, &c. At leaÅ¿t they will not keep long, the Pears grow too mellow, and the Apples grow downy; but yet at this time Kernel-Fruit will begin to require a little reÅ¿t in the Store-HouÅ¿e, or ConÅ¿ervatory, and the beÅ¿t way to judge of their maturity, is to Å¿queeze them gently with the Thumb about the Stalk, to try whether they yield, or no.

The Month of October is likewiÅ¿e to be valued for the laÅ¿t Admirable Peaches it produces in the open Air, or in the WeÅ¿t, Viz. The Nivet, and latter Violets, beÅ¿ides the Large Red, as well as Yellow Pavies, without omitting the fine latter yellow Peaches, all growing in good ExpoÅ¿itions. The Butter-Pear, Verte Longue, or Long Green,
DoycnneÃ©, or Deanery, LanÅ¿ac, Green Sugar-Pear, Burgamot, Vine-Pears, MeÅ¿Å¿ire John, &c. begin to Signalize themÅ¿elves at this time, but then they muÅ¿t be kept Å¿ome time in the Store-HouÅ¿e; we will Å¿peak more particularly of this, in the TreatiÅ¿e of Store-HouÅ¿es; in the mean time, it will not be improper to Å¿peak about the means of preÅ¿erving, and tranÅ¿porting the tender Fruits we have mention'd, Å¿ound, and unbruis'd.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Of the Situation that is proper for the Fruits that are gather'd, in order to PreÅ¿erve them Å¿ome time.

div.p: IN Order to end what I have begun, I am now only to Å¿peak of the means of PreÅ¿erving, as much as can be, good Fruits after their being gather'd, and of the means of tranÅ¿porting them when it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary: As to the preÅ¿ervation, I mean Å¿uch in particular, as are not gather'd until they have attain'd a full maturity, and Å¿uch as being extream tender and puny, make an end of acquiring it after their being taken out of the Garden, both the one and the other loÅ¿ing their LuÅ¿tre and Beauty to a high degree, by being either bruis'd, rub'd, Å¿cratch'd, or Å¿potted with little black Spots; Å¿uch are your Figs, and Peaches with their fine Colour, and delicate Pulp; Å¿uch are Plums with the fine flower that covers them, and Butter-Pears that are perfectly ripe; This has no relation to other Fruits that are neither Å¿o choice, as Cherries, Morello's, Bigarreaux, &c. Nor Å¿o eaÅ¿ily Å¿poil'd, as Melons, Pavies, hard Pears, baking Pears, all Apples, &c.

I Å¿uppoÅ¿e that every Fig, every Peach, and every Plum has been gather'd with all the Caution I have heretofore explain'd, inÅ¿omuch, that in the taking them off the Tree, nothing was wanting to their perfection; I alÅ¿o Å¿uppoÅ¿e, that in the gathering of them, care has been taken to lay them in Sives, with tender Å¿oft Leaves, as Vine-Leaves, &c. And to place them all aÅ¿under, that they may be no wiÅ¿e Å¿queez'd, nor any laid a top of one another, by reaÅ¿on that the weight of the upermoÅ¿t would be capable of bruÅ¿ing the undermoÅ¿t, and that particularly for Peaches, and Figs, for Plums are not Å¿o heavy as to hurt one another.

Now, in order to preÅ¿erve thoÅ¿e kind of Fruits Å¿ome days, that is, two or three days, eÅ¿pecially the Peaches; they muÅ¿t be laid either in CloÅ¿ets, or Store-HouÅ¿es, which muÅ¿t be very dry, and clean, and full of Shelves, the Windows being always open, unleÅ¿s it be in very Cold weather: Hereafter I will explain the Conditions of a good Store-HouÅ¿e, or ConÅ¿ervatory; you muÅ¿t lay a finger thick of MoÅ¿s upon thoÅ¿e Shelves, which may Å¿erve, as it were for a kind of Quilt, taking care that the MoÅ¿s be very dry, and has no ill Å¿cent; the ReaÅ¿on of which is, that every Peach Å¿o plac'd, Å¿inks of it Å¿elf into the MoÅ¿s, and lies Å¿oftly, without being Å¿queez'd by any of the others. I dare affirm that it is with Peaches, as with Melons, which are better to eat a day after their being gather'd, and left at a diÅ¿tance from the Sun, than JuÅ¿t after their being gather'd, at which time they are lukewarm: Altho' it is not good to touch Fruit much, either upon the Tree, or in the Store-HouÅ¿e, yet, provided it be perform'd by a Skilful hand, it will not prejudice it; therefore, while thoÅ¿e Peaches lay in the Store-HouÅ¿e, they muÅ¿t be carefully viÅ¿ited once a day, to Å¿ee whether there appears no marks of rottenneÅ¿s, at the Å¿ame time removing all Å¿uch that are in the leaÅ¿t tainted, otherwiÅ¿e they would Å¿poil others.

It is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to place Fruits well in the Store-HouÅ¿e, thoÅ¿e that have not thoÅ¿e regards, loÅ¿e abundance of them by their own fault: the beÅ¿t Å¿ituation for Peaches, is, to be plac'd, not only upon MoÅ¿s, but upon the part which Joyn'd to the Stalk, otherwiÅ¿e they are apt to bruiÅ¿e; Figs muÅ¿t be laid Å¿idewiÅ¿e, by reaÅ¿on that if they were laid upon the Eye, they would loÅ¿e their beÅ¿t juice; as for Plums, whereas they have no great weight they may be laid any how, as well as Cherries.

The beÅ¿t Å¿ituation for Pears, their Figure being Pyramidal, is to be plac'd upon the Eye, with the Stalk upwards; it is indifferent whether Apples, the Figure of which forms a perfect Cube, lay upon the Eye, or Stalk, which is always very Å¿hort, both theÅ¿e Fruits will preÅ¿erve themÅ¿elves well enough upon the bare boards, beÅ¿ides, for a while they may lie upon one another, when firÅ¿t brought out of the Gardens, until they approach to maturity; but above all, I would not allow them any Bed or Covering of Straw, or Hay, by reaÅ¿on, that commonly it gives them an ill Å¿cent.

The beÅ¿t way for Grapes is to hang them up in the Air faÅ¿ten'd to a packthread, or about a Hoop, or Å¿ix'd to Å¿ome Beam; beÅ¿ides, they may be laid Å¿afe enough upon Straw,
and when any body deÅ¿ires to preÅ¿erve them until February, March, or April, they muÅ¿t be gather'd before they are perfectly ripe, otherwiÅ¿e they are apt to rot too Å¿oon; beÅ¿ides, Care muÅ¿t be taken once in two or three days to pick all the rotten ones carefully.

All manner of Apples will laÅ¿t until March, and Å¿ome until May, and June; for inÅ¿tance, the Reynettes, or French Peppins, Apis, RoÅ¿e-Apples, Francatie, &c. Care being taken that the greateÅ¿t Mark of their maturity commonly conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in being Å¿omewhat wrinkled, excepting the Apples of Api, and the RoÅ¿e-Apples, which never wrinkle; they are known to be ripe when all the green which appear'd in the Rind is turn'd yellow.

The deÅ¿tiny of Pears, as to their laÅ¿ting, is very different, thoÅ¿e that laÅ¿t longeÅ¿t, are the Bon-ChreÅ¿tiens, St. Lezin, Dry-Martins, Martin-Sires, Baking-Pears, Double-BloÅ¿Å¿oms, and Å¿ome Franc-reals, &c. I will Å¿peak more at large of them in the TreatiÅ¿e of the Store-HouÅ¿es.

We have Å¿et down elÅ¿ewhere which are commonly the Pears of every Month, and therefore it would be uÅ¿eleÅ¿s to repeat it here: Red Fruits laÅ¿t but little after their being gather'd, Strawberries, and RaÅ¿pberries are Å¿eldom good after a day, Cherries, Morello's, Bigarreaux, and Currans may perhaps laÅ¿t a day longer; good Fruits Å¿hould be Å¿erv'd upon the Table in the Å¿ame Å¿ituation they are plac'd in the Store-HouÅ¿es, in order to make a pretty Å¿how, excepting only Pears, which in that CaÅ¿e require Å¿ome agreeable Cimetry for the ConÅ¿truction of the Pyramids.

With all theÅ¿e Precautions, Fruits may be eaÅ¿ily preÅ¿erv'd as long as they can laÅ¿t, nothing can prejudice them, but great Winter FroÅ¿ts, which are very dangerous, by reaÅ¿on that they may penetrate into the Store-HouÅ¿es, and Å¿o reach the Fruits, and Fruit that has once been Frozen, preÅ¿erves no manner of goodneÅ¿s, and immediately decays; thoÅ¿e that have no Store-HouÅ¿es made on purpoÅ¿e, with all the neceÅ¿Å¿ary regards, I Å¿hall explain in the Å¿equel, and who have only a CloÅ¿et, or Å¿ome ordinary room, are in danger of loÅ¿ing all their Fruit in bad Weather, unleÅ¿s they take a great deal of care to cover them well with good Blankets, or place them between two Quilts, or elÅ¿e carry them into Å¿ome Cellar, until the danger be paÅ¿t, at which time thoÅ¿e poor PriÅ¿oners are taken out of their Dungeons, to be put at Liberty again in their former Places.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: Of the TranÅ¿portation of Fruits..

div.p: THE Difficulty in queÅ¿tion has no relation to any Pears, being newly gather'd, nor to any hard Baking Pears, tho' ripe, provided, in caÅ¿e they be Winter Bon-Chretien Pears, every Pear be wrapt up in a piece of Paper; neither has this difficulty any relation to any Apples whatever; thoÅ¿e kind of Fruits tho' laid pell mell in Baskets, or Panniers, will indure the being carry'd, either upon a HorÅ¿e, or in a Cart; but we cannot do Å¿o with tender mellow Pears when they are ripe; in that caÅ¿e they are like the Figs, and Peaches, &c. their delicacy and tenderneÅ¿s requires a gentle uÅ¿age, like Beautiful young Ladies, otherwiÅ¿e the agitation of the Carriage would bruiÅ¿e and blacken them, and conÅ¿equently would deprive them of their greateÅ¿t Ornaments, and even of their chief goodneÅ¿s.

This Prelude conducts us inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h, that Peaches, Figs, Strawberries, Morello's, &c. in order to their being tranÅ¿ported from one place to another, require Water-Carriage, or the Back or Arms of a Porter without any jogging, and above all, if they be Peaches, they muÅ¿t be laid upon that part which is fix'd to the Stalk, without touching one another, and be laid firÅ¿t upon a Bed of MoÅ¿s, or tender Leaves laid pretty thick; and in the Å¿econd place, wrapt up in Vine-Leaves, and Å¿o well order'd, that they may not move out of their places; and finally, in caÅ¿e Å¿everal Beds be laid over one another, a good Å¿eparation muÅ¿t be made between them of MoÅ¿s, or of a reaÅ¿onable quantity of Leaves, the laÅ¿t Couch muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be pretty well cover'd with Leaves, and the whole wrapt up with a Cloth, well faÅ¿ten'd, in order to keep all that is contain'd in the Basket cloÅ¿e, and in good order: The Å¿afeÅ¿t way would be to do with Peaches, what I am going to preÅ¿cribe for Figs, but then the inconvenience is, that it would be impoÅ¿Å¿ible to carry any conÅ¿iderable quantity at a time. For Figs you muÅ¿t have Sives not above two inches deep, and lay a bed of Vine-Leaves at the bottom of them, and place the Figs Å¿idewiÅ¿e, wraping them up firÅ¿t, aÅ¿under, each in one of the Å¿aid Leaves, taking care to order them Å¿o well, and Å¿o
neatly cloÅ¿e to one another, that the motion of the tranÅ¿portation may not be able to remove them, and never lay two a top of one another: This firÅ¿t and only Bed being made, it muÅ¿t be cover'd with Leaves, and next with a Sheet of Paper, neatly fix'd round about the Sive, and moreover Å¿tay'd with Å¿ome Å¿mall Packthread, in order to keep the Fruit cloÅ¿e into the Å¿aid Sive.

Good Plums being laid up, without any Ceremony, in any Basket, or Sive, with a good Bed of Leaves or Nettles at the bottom of it; the top muÅ¿t alÅ¿o be cover'd with Nettles, after having firÅ¿t taken off the thickeÅ¿t down, which being done, the whole muÅ¿t be Cover'd with a Linen Cloth, or Å¿ome Sheets of Paper, faÅ¿ten'd with Å¿ome Pack-thread:
Common Plums may be tranÅ¿ported in great Baskets, barely putting Å¿mall Leaves under, and over them.

Apricock-Plums are Å¿ent from Tours to Paris upon MeÅ¿Å¿engers HorÅ¿es, with a great deal more precaution apart, for they are put in Boxes Å¿tuff'd with Houads, every one of them being moreover Å¿eparately wrapt up in Houads; but that Expedient is Chargeable, beÅ¿ides it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to carry many at a time.

Strawberries being likewiÅ¿e order'd in double ridges, in Baskets made on purpoÅ¿e, Å¿tuff'd with leaves at the bottom, and round about; it will Å¿uffice to cover them with a fine Wet Piece of Linnen, abundance of them are carryd thus, according to the bigneÅ¿s of thoÅ¿e Baskets.
Grapes, either MuÅ¿cat or ChaÅ¿Å¿elas, are partly carry'd in the Å¿ame manner I have noted for Peaches; nay with leÅ¿s Ceremony, Å¿ince it is not very material to Å¿eparate every Bed with Leaves.

MuÅ¿cat Grapes, are Å¿ometimes Å¿ent into diÅ¿tant Countrys, and they are put in CaÅ¿es fill'd with Bran, and carry'd upon HorÅ¿es or Mules, care being taken that the Bunches may not touch one another; But that is an Expence only proper for Kings, or very great Lords.

For the TranÅ¿portation of our Principal Fruits, when they are only to be Å¿ent a Days Journey at moÅ¿t, I commonly uÅ¿e certain Å¿quare Baskets, divided in the InÅ¿ide into Å¿everal Stories, which are at a convenient diÅ¿tance from one another, to place our Sives full of Fruit; thoÅ¿e are either made of very CloÅ¿e Ozier, and then they need no other covering to Å¿ecure them from DuÅ¿t, or elÅ¿e of looÅ¿e Ozier, and then they muÅ¿t be cover'd with Sere-Cloath; moreover, thoÅ¿e Baskets open Å¿idewiÅ¿e like a kind of PreÅ¿s, or elÅ¿e at the top, and then the loweÅ¿t Story muÅ¿t be fill'd firÅ¿t, and a little covering laid over it which Å¿erves to cloÅ¿e this firÅ¿t, and to bear the Second, and thus to the uppermoÅ¿t; a Å¿mall Pad-lock may be fixed to it, at pleaÅ¿ure, to which two Keys may be made, the one for thoÅ¿e to whom the Fruit is Å¿ent, and the other remaining with the PerÅ¿on who Å¿ends it, by which means the Fruit is convey'd Å¿afely.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.p: Of Store-HouÅ¿es, or ConÅ¿ervatories for Fruits.

div.p:
IF in that very Å¿eaÅ¿on, when Kitchen-Gardens Charm moÅ¿t by their GreenneÅ¿s, and neatneÅ¿s, Fruits are notwithÅ¿tanding their chief Ornament, what advantages, or rather what ConÅ¿olations are not thoÅ¿e Fruits capable of affording us, when in the middle of a diÅ¿mal, Melancholy Winter, we are provided with a ConÅ¿iderable Å¿tore of them, and even Å¿ome of them Infinitely better than any the Summer had Å¿upplied us with. There is no denying that we are all naturally inclined to have a Violent PaÅ¿Å¿ion for Fruits, and by that very reaÅ¿on, as they are delicious to the Palate, we eaÅ¿ily perÅ¿wade our Å¿elves that they are of uÅ¿e for our Health; PhyÅ¿itians who are to give no Rules againÅ¿t Infirmities, are Å¿o far from oppoÅ¿ing this Opinion, that they EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h it as Infallible, and often preÅ¿cribe the uÅ¿e of Fruits as Soveraign Remedies; for which reaÅ¿on moÅ¿t People are at preÅ¿ent Curious of Fruits, and many Gentlemen are proud of expreÅ¿Å¿ing their EarneÅ¿tneÅ¿s in Rearing them: Nature Å¿eems to delight in favouring that CurioÅ¿ity, it yearly produces abundance of Fruits; the Summer produces but too many, and Autumn yields a Å¿ufficient quantity; but the difficulty is to have Å¿ome in the Winter, which is a Dead, Infertile SeaÅ¿on; therefore we Å¿hould make it our Å¿tudy to preÅ¿erve Å¿uch, as are only good a conÅ¿iderable while after their being gather'd; they are Expos'd to a long Journey, in which they are to run many hazards: It does not only require a careful man, but alÅ¿o a Place that may be altogether proper to preÅ¿erve
them; we muÅ¿t on one Å¿ide Combat Cold which deÅ¿troys all thoÅ¿e it reaches, on the other hand we muÅ¿t prevent all ill Å¿cents, which would Å¿poil what the Weather had Å¿par'd: This Place is commonly call'd a Store-HouÅ¿e or ConÅ¿ervatory, which without doubt muÅ¿t have its Rules, and particular properties, Å¿ince it is Å¿o uÅ¿eful, and is to produce Å¿uch good Effects. It is to be Å¿uppos'd that I muÅ¿t needs be skill'd in that Point, conÅ¿idering the Great and Ancient uÅ¿e I have made of it in Gardens; and ConÅ¿equently I Å¿hould certainly be blam'd, unleÅ¿s I declar'd what my Experience has taught me in relation to Store-HouÅ¿es, either to avoid the defects that are to be fear'd in it, or to attain the Å¿ucceÅ¿s that is to be hop'd for.

Let other CurioÅ¿o's, which are in Å¿o great a Number, cry up their CloÅ¿ets as much as they pleaÅ¿e, let them Invite every body to come and Å¿ee them, let them be careful in making rich DeÅ¿criptions of them, I am Å¿o far from finding fault at it, that I am one of the firÅ¿t to Commend them, I ViÅ¿it them with a Å¿ingular Å¿atisfaction, and take great delight in looking upon Å¿uch things as are moÅ¿t Extraordinary, not only for the matter, but likewiÅ¿e for the WorkmanÅ¿hip; I Å¿ay, let People cry up thoÅ¿e Collections of Miracles of Art, but at leaÅ¿t let them allow thoÅ¿e that are Curious in Gard'ning, the liberty of boaÅ¿ting of their Store-HouÅ¿es of Fruits, which are their CloÅ¿ets; not that they contain any Originals, or Antiquities, far from it, their greateÅ¿t Value conÅ¿iÅ¿ts altogether in Novelty, but then they are excellent Novelties; that is, they are productions of Nature, which renew, and take new Vigour Yearly: Productions which indeed are only, if I may uÅ¿e the ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion, Å¿o many Copies of its firÅ¿t Productions at the Birth of Time, which at the Å¿ame time Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿es the Merit of thoÅ¿e Originals: By reaÅ¿on that this Nature having been Charm'd at firÅ¿t, with the Beauty of its firÅ¿t EÅ¿Å¿ays, has taken delight in repeating them as often as it could, as if it really Study'd more and more to improve, even to that degree, that it Å¿uffers it Å¿elf to be Conducted a little by Culture, Å¿eeing that Culture really contributes to the Perfectioning of its new Productions.

This being granted, I am of Opinion, that no Body will deny that this CloÅ¿et deÅ¿erves to be Å¿een, and in truth nothing can be more agreeable to Å¿ight than this Store-HouÅ¿e, where at the firÅ¿t Entrance you diÅ¿cover a kind of well contriv'd Room, of which the Å¿ize is proportion'd to the OccaÅ¿ion for which it was Built, where you diÅ¿cover in the next Place, a fine Edg d-Table, which takes up the middle of the Place, and is convenient and neceÅ¿Å¿ary to order the Baskets, or China-BaÅ¿ons that are to be Å¿erv'd, where finally you diÅ¿cover the four Walls GarniÅ¿h'd, and Å¿ee all the Shelves well Order'd, and fill'd both in Autumn and Winter with fine Fruits; thoÅ¿e Fruits differently plac'd with flying Labels, to expreÅ¿s their kinds, and Maturity in relation to the Sequel of Months; thus Burgamots are order'd in one Place, Virgoules in another, Ambrets here, Thorn-Pears there, LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿erirs here, the St. Germans there, Bonchretien here, Bugy there, Baking Pears here, there the Apples, with the Å¿ame DiÅ¿tinctions obÅ¿erv'd for the Pears; here Fruits that drop of themÅ¿elves, there Å¿uch as have been gather'd in SeaÅ¿on, here thoÅ¿e of the North, there thoÅ¿e of good EÅ¿palies; here thoÅ¿e of High-Standards, there thoÅ¿e of Dwarfs, there the Fruits that are Ripe in Å¿uch a Month, there thoÅ¿e that do not Ripen Å¿o Å¿oon, &c. with this ConÅ¿tant order, that thoÅ¿e that are Ripe are always moÅ¿t within reach, both for the Hand and Eye, and thoÅ¿e that are not Ripe yet, according to their Degree, plac'd upon higher Shelves, where they expect the SeaÅ¿on that is to ripen them, and ConÅ¿equently to be remov'd in the Room of thoÅ¿e that are PaÅ¿s'd; thoÅ¿e firÅ¿t DiÅ¿appear after having perform'd their Part, and finiÅ¿h'd their Career; and others are ready to Succeed them, and as it were, to come each to their turn to Å¿erve the quarter which is deÅ¿Å¿ign'd for them.

Finally, do's not the Liberality of our CurioÅ¿o towards his Friends (for he loves to Impart what he has) deÅ¿erve Å¿ome privilegde to raiÅ¿e the Merit of his CloÅ¿et above others, out of which we only bring bare Ideas, and were far from receiving any Liberaliteis, on the contrary the CurioÅ¿o makes profeÅ¿Å¿ion of being cloÅ¿e FiÅ¿ted; he never makes a Å¿how of his TreaÅ¿ure unleÅ¿s it be againÅ¿t his Will; there conÅ¿tantly appears a great deal of diÅ¿guÅ¿t in him, which Å¿ometimes proceeds from the fear of being Robb'd, but more commonly out of fear of not being thought as Rich, as he pretends to be.

Let us now Proceed to EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the principal Conditions of a good Store-HouÅ¿e; In my Opinion the FirÅ¿t conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in its being inpenetrable to FroÅ¿ts; great Cold as we have already often declar'd being a mortal Enemy to Fruits, thoÅ¿e that are once Frozen, are never after good for any thing.
It follows from thence, for the Second Condition, that this Store-HouÅ¿e muÅ¿t he expos'd to the South or EaÅ¿t, or at leaÅ¿t to the WeÅ¿t; the Northern ExpoÅ¿ition would be very perninicious to it.
It alÅ¿o follows for the Third Condition, that the Wall of the Å¿aid Store-HouÅ¿e muÅ¿t be at leaÅ¿t Twenty Four Inches thick, or elÅ¿e the FroÅ¿t could not be kept out.

It likewiÅ¿e follows for the Fourth Condition, that the Windows beÅ¿ides the Common Quarrels, Å¿hould have good double Paper Saches, Very cloÅ¿e, and very well Å¿topt, together with a Double Door, inÅ¿omuch that the Cold Air from abroad, may not be able to enter in, for it would certainly deÅ¿troy the Temperate Air which has been preÅ¿erv'd of Old in the InÅ¿ide, it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to be too exact in this care, Å¿ince the leaÅ¿t or any, might occaÅ¿ion a great deal of diÅ¿order in one FroÅ¿ty Night; I do not in the leaÅ¿t approve the making of Fire in the Store-HouÅ¿e, for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on, I have Å¿ufficiently EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd in the TreatiÅ¿e of Orange-Trees.

NotwithÅ¿tanding all theÅ¿e Conditions, which perhaps have not been exactly ObÅ¿erv'd the thing being pritty difficult, it is abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary to have Å¿ome Å¿mall VeÅ¿Å¿el full of Water in the Store-HouÅ¿e, to be certain, It is a faithful Incorruptible Centry, which is to give us notice of all that may Prejudice us; when that Water does not Freeze there is nothing to be done; but when it Freezes in the leaÅ¿t, a remedy muÅ¿t Immeadiately be apply'd: The Colds of the Month of December 1670, 1675, 1676, 1678, that of January, and February, 1679. and eÅ¿pecially that of December 1683, and of January 1684, which laÅ¿ted a whole Month, without diÅ¿continuation the laÅ¿t time, muÅ¿t needs Å¿erve for a great InÅ¿truction in this Matter; it required a great deal of Care, and forecaÅ¿t, not to be caught by it. A good Weather-GlaÅ¿s plac'd on the out-Å¿ide at the Northern-ExpoÅ¿ure is of great uÅ¿e; we have reaÅ¿on to Judge the Peril great, when this Weather-GlaÅ¿s continues for two Nights together to be, at the fifth and Å¿ixth Degrees, and even the Å¿eventh and eighth; the firÅ¿t Night may have done no harm, the Å¿econd is much to be fear'd, and therefore it is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary the very next Day after Å¿uch a Night to uÅ¿e good Quilts, or good Blankets, or elÅ¿e a great deal of dry MoÅ¿s to Å¿ecure our Fruits from FroÅ¿t; nay more, having a good Cellar, it will be very proper to remove our Fruits into it, and leave them there until the great Cold be paÅ¿s'd, and in all theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es care muÅ¿t be taken to replace all thoÅ¿e Fruits as they were before in the Store-HouÅ¿e; as Å¿oon as the Weather grows better, and to remove Å¿uch as are Ripe, and Å¿uch as are tainted, RotenneÅ¿s is one of the worÅ¿t accidents to be fear'd, while Fruits are not in a Condition to be ViÅ¿ited often one after another.

After having made ProviÅ¿ion againÅ¿t Cold, we muÅ¿t Study to preÅ¿erve our Fruits from ill TaÅ¿te; the Neighbourhood of Hay, Straw, Dung, CheeÅ¿e, a great deal of Foul Linnen, eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch as has been imploy'd in the Kitchen, &c. are all very dangerous, and muÅ¿t not in the leaÅ¿t be Å¿uffer'd near our Store-HouÅ¿e or ConÅ¿ervatory; a certain MuÅ¿ty TaÅ¿te, together with the Å¿mell of many Fruits laid up together is likewiÅ¿e very diÅ¿agreeable, and therefore the Store-HouÅ¿e muÅ¿t not only have good Overtures, and a high Ceiling, the juÅ¿t meaÅ¿ure of which, is to be from Ten to Twelve Foot high, but the Windows muÅ¿t often be kept open, that is, as often as there is no fear of great Cold either in the Night, or in the Day, freÅ¿h Air from without, when it is Temperate, is Incomparable to purify, and reeÅ¿tabliÅ¿h, that which has been long inclos'd.

For the Sixth Condition, I think I may Å¿ay, that neither a Cellar nor a Garret are Å¿it to make this ConÅ¿ervatory, the Cellar by reaÅ¿on of a muÅ¿tineÅ¿s, and moiÅ¿t heat that are inÅ¿eparable from it, which inclines the Fruit to RottenneÅ¿s; the Garret becauÅ¿e of the Cold, which eaÅ¿ily Penetrates the Roof; and therefore a ground Room is the beÅ¿t for our UÅ¿e, or at leaÅ¿t a firÅ¿t Story, accompany'd with other Lodging-Rooms Inhabited over and under it, as well as on the Å¿ides.

I add to this Sixth Condition, that the Store-HouÅ¿e muÅ¿t be often viÅ¿ited by him that has it in Charge, which is neglected when he is not at Hand, that is, conveniently plac'd, by reaÅ¿on of the trouble of going too much up, or down.

The Å¿eventh Condition requires, many Å¿helves fram'd together in order to Lodge the Fruits Å¿eparately the one from the other, the fineÅ¿t on the beÅ¿t Å¿ide, and Baking-Pears on the worÅ¿t; Apples muÅ¿t lye by themÅ¿elves. The reaÅ¿onable diÅ¿tance of theÅ¿e Shelves is to be about Nine or Ten Inches; and I would have them about Seventeen or Eighteen Inches broad, that they may hold the more, and pleaÅ¿e the Å¿ight the better.

For the Eighth Condition, I would have thoÅ¿e Å¿helves a little Å¿loaping outwardly, that is, about an Inch in the Breadth, with an Edge about Two Fingers high, to hinder the Fruit from Falling: The Fruits are not Å¿o much in Å¿ight when the Shelves are level, as when they are as I deÅ¿ire them, and thus when any of them are Rotten it is not Å¿o eaÅ¿ily perceived, and that RottenneÅ¿s Communicates it Å¿elf to thoÅ¿e that are about it, unleÅ¿s remedy'd at firÅ¿t.
The fear of that RottenneÅ¿s requires for a Ninth Condition, that every Shelf Å¿hould be viÅ¿ited at leaÅ¿t every other day, without fail, to remove what ever may be tainted.

And for the Tenth Condition, it requires that the Shelves Å¿hould be cover'd with Å¿omething, for InÅ¿tance dry MoÅ¿s, or about an Inch thick of fine Sand, in order to keep every Fruit Å¿teady, after its being plac'd upon its BaÅ¿is, as it Å¿hould be, and to keep it aÅ¿under, for the Fruits muÅ¿t no wiÅ¿e be allow'd to touch each other: It is much pleaÅ¿anter to Å¿ee them all in a row upon their BaÅ¿is, that is, upon the Eye which is oppoÅ¿ite to the Stalk, than to Å¿ee them Lye pell mell any how.

I require for the LaÅ¿t Condition, that Care be taken to Sweep our ConÅ¿ervatory, or Store-HouÅ¿e often, to Å¿uffer no Cobwebs in it, and to keep Traps for Rats and Mice, and moreover it will not be amiÅ¿s to allow it Å¿ome Å¿ecret Entrance for Cats, otherwiÅ¿e the Fruit will be in danger of being gnaw'd by thoÅ¿e Curs'd little DomeÅ¿tick Animals.

The ConÅ¿ervatory, which is particularly deÅ¿ign'd for Winter-Fruits, is likewiÅ¿e very uÅ¿eful for thoÅ¿e of Autumn, either Pears or Grapes, and for Summer Fruits, either Peaches, Pavies, Plums, &c. TheÅ¿e being in my opinion, as I have already Å¿aid, much better a day after their being gather'd, than the very day; they acquire a certain coolneÅ¿s in the Store-HouÅ¿e, which is a great Improvement which they can never have, while they are upon the Tree.

Now whereas generally Å¿peaking, the Fruits that are moÅ¿t ConÅ¿iderable, are only brought into the Store-HouÅ¿e, after their having acquir'd one of the two Maturities, which is proper for them, viz. for the Summer Fruits an approaching Maturity, which Expediates them in few days, and for Autumn, and Winter-Fruits, a diÅ¿tant Maturity, which makes them keep long, Å¿ome leÅ¿s, Å¿ome more; and beÅ¿ides, whereas it is the approaching Maturity, which is of moÅ¿t ConÅ¿equence, as well for thoÅ¿e good Fruits, which would periÅ¿h miÅ¿erably, unleÅ¿s taken in the nick, as for the MaÅ¿ter whoÅ¿e pains, cares, and hopes would be loÅ¿t, unleÅ¿s he were capable, as the Å¿aying is, to nick the Critical Minute; it follows from thence, that it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to make an end of giving, in this place, the Infallible marks by which this Maturity is to be known: I have already explain'd thoÅ¿e: marks for moÅ¿t Fruits which do not exceed September and October, viz. for the remainder of Summer Pears, the remainder of Plums, the beÅ¿t latter Peaches and Pavies, &c. There now remains to Å¿peak of October Pears, and others, which keep from All-Saints, till EaÅ¿ter, and longer.

The Vertelongue or Long-Green, Butter-Pears, Vine-Pears, MeÅ¿Å¿ire-John, Green-Sugar-Pears, &c. after theÅ¿e, the Petit-oins, LanÅ¿aes, MarchioneÅ¿Å¿es, Burgamots, Amadottes, and even the BeÅ¿ideri, and Thick-Stalks, &c. are the firÅ¿t, that are to paÅ¿s during the Month of November; the Thumb (as we have obÅ¿erv'd already, for the Butter-Pears, Long-Greens, Green-Sugar-Peart, and others, which have began to ripen in October) daly turns whatever ripens out of the Store-HouÅ¿e, viz. Petit-oins, MarchioneÅ¿Å¿es, RuÅ¿Å¿ettines, LanÅ¿aes &c. by reaÅ¿on that theÅ¿e are Å¿till tender Pears; a WhitiÅ¿h Colour which forms it Å¿elf in the Rind of the MeÅ¿Å¿ire-John, a Yellow caÅ¿t in the Amadottes, Thick-Stalks, BeÅ¿ideri, &c. and a moiÅ¿ture upon the Rind of the Burgamots, together with a little YellowneÅ¿s which diÅ¿covers it Å¿elf upon them, all thoÅ¿e are certain Å¿igns which inform us without the help of the Thumb, of what we have a mind to know of thoÅ¿e loÅ¿t kinds of Fruits, 'tis but examining of them ConÅ¿tantly, or at leaÅ¿t every other day, and that Rule of review for the Maturity is to be continu'd the following Months for all other Fruits, that remain, in order not to loÅ¿e the leaÅ¿t Å¿ign which diÅ¿covers their approaching Maturity; moreover this review is neceÅ¿Å¿ary, to remove Å¿uch as begin to Rot.

The LouiÅ¿e-bonne, Winter-Thornes, Ambrets, LeÅ¿chaÅ¿eries, St. Germains, Vergoules, even the Dry-Martins, SpaniÅ¿h Bon-Chretiens, with the Apples of all kinds, of Capendu, either Grey, or Red, or White, the Apples of Fenouillet, Autumn Calvils, Å¿ome Apis, and Å¿ome Reynettes, &c. all theÅ¿e Fruits begin to ripen at the beginning of December, and a little YellowneÅ¿s, together with Å¿ome Wrinkles diÅ¿covers it Å¿elf upon the Six firÅ¿t, by which
we may judge, in caÅ¿e that they do not reÅ¿iÅ¿t the Thumb, that they are fit to Eat, but until then, we muÅ¿t not venture to meddle with them; in cutting of them, the Knife would Å¿oon diÅ¿cover their want of RipeneÅ¿s; thoÅ¿e kind of Pears are very Subject to Å¿often, and thereby are certainly apt to deceive thoÅ¿e who do not Å¿trictly Examine them every day.

As to the Dry-Martins, and SpaniÅ¿h Bon-Chretiens, it is with them in the Month of December, juÅ¿t as what I am going to Å¿ay in January for the Portail-Pears, as Å¿oon as ever there appears the leaÅ¿t Spot of RotteneÅ¿s upon any of them, you may boldly attack them all, their time is come, and they are Å¿oon threaten'd with RottenneÅ¿s; but yet with this advantage, that they remain a pretty while in the State of perfect Maturity.
The Capendu, Fenouillet, and Reinettes, declare their Maturity as Å¿oon as they become extreamly wrinkled, the Apis declare theirs when their Green Colour turns to Yellow.

The Calvils Å¿eem to become lighter, and their kernel looÅ¿Å¿ens, and rattles in Å¿haking, when they ripen, they remain good a long while, as well as the Reinettes, which are become Yellow, without wrinkling, and, thoÅ¿e are admirable qualifications in thoÅ¿e kind of Fruits.
People muÅ¿t not grow weary of often feeling the tender melting Pears of that SeaÅ¿on, the lazy and negligent thereby fall into great Inconveniences.

Such Fruits as have reÅ¿iÅ¿ted the Thumb in the Month of December, will finally yield to it in their turns in the Months of January and February, but when the Winter-Thorns, are not able to change their Colour a little in theÅ¿e Months, they become Mealy and InÅ¿ipid, and in a Word, periÅ¿h without attaining a perfect Maturity, which is a cruel loÅ¿s to the Curious, Å¿ince it is really one of our beÅ¿t Pears.
I have made very conÅ¿iderable ObÅ¿ervations in relation to it, and of Å¿ome others, in the TreatiÅ¿e of the Choice and Proportion, &c.
The LouiÅ¿e-bonnes, and the Long-Greens, of September and October, Å¿eldom grow Yellow, but they wrinkle, and become Å¿oft, mellow, and agreeable to feel.

Many Ambrets Å¿often, before they grow Yellow, particularly Å¿uch as grow North-ward, or upon Dwarf-Å¿tandards, and eÅ¿pecially upon Trees Graffed upon free Stocks, that are too full, therefore theÅ¿e, as well as all other Pears which grow upon Northern EÅ¿paliers, require Sugar above all others, to correct their TaÅ¿te, which is not Å¿o good as it Å¿hould be, tho they are Å¿o very full of Water.

The large Winter-Musky, and the Portail-Pears have Å¿ome Friends, neither of them Value the skill of the Thumb, but the YellowneÅ¿s of the firÅ¿t, and a few wrinkles, or Å¿ome RotteneÅ¿s in the Å¿econd, to Invite their Votaries do make uÅ¿e of their merit, what ever it be.

One of the chief things I mind in ordering my Fruits in the Store-HouÅ¿e or ConÅ¿ervatory, is not only to place every kind upon different Shelves, or when I do put Å¿everal upon one, they are diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h'd by diviÅ¿ions of Edges, but I likewiÅ¿e make the Å¿ame diÅ¿tinction among Fruits of the Å¿ame kind; firÅ¿t I place thoÅ¿e that are fallen before their time (for I do not fling them away) by themÅ¿elves, out of Å¿ight, they Å¿eldom look well, by reaÅ¿on of their growing very much wrinkled, indeed Å¿ome more, and others leÅ¿s, and that according to their dropping, Å¿ooner, or later; but yet they ripen at laÅ¿t, tho pretty long after the others of their kind; and I cannot forbear doing of them the JuÅ¿tice to Å¿ay, that they are pretty often incomparably good under a wither'd, ugly, wrinkled Rind, eÅ¿pecially when their fall does not exceed a Month before the time of the common gathering.
Secondly, Pears growing upon Dwarf-Standards are apart, as well as thoÅ¿e of good EÅ¿paliers or Wall-Trees.

I follow the Å¿ame Method for the Fruits of High-Standards, and the Å¿ame for the Fruits of Northern EÅ¿paliers, by reaÅ¿on that regularly the Fruits of good EÅ¿paliers ripen firÅ¿t; thoÅ¿e of Vigorous Dwarfs follow them in this order, thoÅ¿e of Dwarfs Graffed upon Quince-Stocks preceed thoÅ¿e that are Graffed upon Free-Stocks, and thoÅ¿e of Infirm Trees preceed both the one and the other.

In â¢ ine, the Fruits of High-Standards Å¿ucceed, and often mix with theÅ¿e, and are the beÅ¿t of all, which Maxim is UniverÅ¿ally true, Excepting only Plums, and Figs, as I have Å¿aid elÅ¿where; the Fruits of the Northern ExpoÅ¿ure, ripen laÅ¿t of all.

Winter Bon Chretiens, with their Brittle Pulp, and the Colmars with their tender Pulp, let all other Mellow Pears paÅ¿s before them, and in the mean time the others begin to
turn yellow, and in turning yellow, to Ripen, and to wrinkle a little towards the Stalk: When Bon-Chretien is perfectly ripe, the Pulp is almoÅ¿t melting, and when it is not, it remains very Å¿tony; Å¿ome of them will keep till March, and April; the Bugy's, St. Lezins, and Martin-Sires joyn with thoÅ¿e, to cloÅ¿e up the Theatre of the Maturity of Pears; the Bugys in March and April are very delicious, with their tender watery Pulp, tho' a little SowriÅ¿h: The St. Lezins with their firm Pulp, accompany'd with a little Perfume, alÅ¿o make Å¿ome Figure, but it is very difficult to preÅ¿erve them 'till then, the leaÅ¿t touch of Cold blackens them intirely, and renders them hideous to Å¿ight, as well as diÅ¿agreeable to the Palate.

As for the Baking-Pears, they are good at all times, for the end they are deÅ¿ign'd for, particularly when they begin to grow yellow; with this ProviÅ¿o, that all Å¿uch as are tainted with RottenneÅ¿s, muÅ¿t be laid aÅ¿ide, leÅ¿t they Å¿hould infect thoÅ¿e that are Å¿ound; and thus the Franc-Reals, Little Certeau, the Carmelites, or Mazuer, and eÅ¿pecially the Double-BloÅ¿Å¿oms, which muÅ¿t be conÅ¿ider'd as the beÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e that are only fit to bake, are almoÅ¿t ready at all times to perform their part: The Pears of Book and Love, the Angobers, Catillac, Fontarabie, &c. may chance to acquire Å¿ome goodneÅ¿s, being Å¿eaÅ¿on'd with Sugar, and the heat of the Fire, but they Å¿till retain a touch of TartneÅ¿s, which can never agree with nice Pallats.

Autumn Calvils, and Reinets, are admirable for PreÅ¿erving, the Capendus and Fenouillets are not Å¿o good, by reaÅ¿on of their Å¿weetneÅ¿s, but the firÅ¿t have a kind of briskneÅ¿s, which gives them an incomparable raÅ¿t.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: Of the DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es of Fruit-Trees.

div.p: IT is apparent, that by a Law UniverÅ¿ally EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, all Living Animated Beings are Å¿ubject to Å¿ome Accidents, which hinder them from enjoying a perpetual, and always equally Vigorous health; this is the reaÅ¿on that it is not only among Men, and other Animals, we find different DiÅ¿tempers: Vegetables, and more particularly Fruit-Trees, are likewiÅ¿e Å¿ubject to certain Infirmities that deÅ¿troy them, which we may very well term DiÅ¿tempers; yellow Leaves out of SeaÅ¿on, new Shoots growing black, and dying on their Extremities in the Months of AuguÅ¿t, and September, Fruits remaining Å¿mall, or dropping of themÅ¿elves, &c. are, as the PhyÅ¿icians term it, Å¿o many Å¿peaking Symptoms, informing us of the indiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the Foot. Among thoÅ¿e Infirmities, there are Å¿ome that may be Cur'd with the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Å¿ome Remedies, and others which hitherto appear Incurable; Å¿ince whatever can be done to them, has Å¿till prov'd Ineffectual, perhaps time may produce Å¿ome Skilful PerÅ¿on, whoÅ¿e Knowledge and Experience may give us Å¿ome light, in a CaÅ¿e which expoÅ¿es us to Å¿corn, or at leaÅ¿t to pity.
