In the mean time, Å¿ince it is but too true that our Trees are liable to different DiÅ¿tempers, Gardners would certainly be blame-worthy, if they did not make it their Study to find out effectual Remedies for Å¿ome, and to Å¿atisfie themÅ¿elves as to the others; and if knowing thoÅ¿e Remedies, they were not careful to apply them upon occaÅ¿ion: For it were vain for them to breed Trees in their Gardens, to be liable to Å¿ee them periÅ¿h in their prime, for want of knowing how to Cure them, and reÅ¿tore them to their priÅ¿tine Vigour.

In Order not to omit any thing relating to thoÅ¿e Accidents which our Trees are liable to, without including Å¿uch as proceed from too long wounds, of great Heat, of great Cold, of Storms, of Whirlwinds, Hails, &c.

I think my Å¿elf oblig'd to Å¿ay, in the firÅ¿t place, that there are DiÅ¿tempers common to all Trees in general; Secondly, that there are Å¿ome that are peculiar to every particular kind: The common DiÅ¿tempers conÅ¿iÅ¿t either in a defect of Vigour, which makes the Trees appear in a languiÅ¿hing Condition, or elÅ¿e in a Å¿torm of large white Worms, which are Å¿ometimes form'd in the Earth, and there gnaw the Roots, or the Bark of the Neighbouring Stem; thoÅ¿e miÅ¿chievous little InÅ¿ects which we call Tons, by degrees cauÅ¿e Å¿o great a diÅ¿order, that the Tree which is attack'd by them, and had always appear'd Vigorous before, all on a Å¿uddain dies without any Remedy.

The Peculiar DiÅ¿tempers are, for Example, in Pear-Treees againÅ¿t a Wall, when their Leaves are attack'd with what we call Tigers: Cankers, and Scabs in other Pear-Trees, Viz. Robins, Å¿mall MuÅ¿cadins, &c. Gum on Stone-Fruit-Trees, eÅ¿pecially Peach-Trees, which commonly deÅ¿troys that part on which it fixes, either Branch, or Stem; and when, unfortunately it attacks the part where the Tree is graffed, which is often hid under ground, it inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly Å¿preads round about that Graff, without any bodies obÅ¿erving of it, for the Tree Å¿till continues in a good Condition, while there remains any paÅ¿Å¿age for the Sap; but, finally, this Gum hindering this Sap from riÅ¿ing to the upper parts of the Tree, makes that Tree die Å¿uddenly, as if it had been Å¿uffocated by a kind of Apoplectick Fit.

Moreover, Å¿ome Peach-Trees are alÅ¿o attack'd with Aemets, and a Å¿mall kind of green Fleas, which Å¿ometimes faÅ¿ten on the young Shoots, and hinder them from thriving; Å¿ometimes on the new Leaves, and cauÅ¿e them firÅ¿t to Å¿hrink, next to dry, and fall: We have likewiÅ¿e North-EaÅ¿t Winds which blaÅ¿t, in Å¿ome Springs wither, and as it were burn all the new Shoots; inÅ¿omuch, that the Trees on which this unlucky Influence lights, appears dead, while others about them are green, full of fine Leaves, and continue to produce fine Shoots: BeÅ¿ides this, are not the moÅ¿t Vigorous Trees Å¿ubject to have the end of their new Shoots intirely cut off by a little black round InÅ¿ect, call'd Bud-Cutter.
Fig-Trees dread the great Colds of the Winter, which are capable of Freezing their whole head, unleÅ¿s they be extreamly well Cover'd, but it is not Å¿ufficient to have Å¿ecur'd them againÅ¿t FroÅ¿t.
They are likewiÅ¿e Å¿ubject in that Winter SeaÅ¿on, to have the lower part of their Stems gnaw'd by Rats, and LiÅ¿ete. Mulots which makes them pine, and die.

ThoÅ¿e very Animals, together with Garden-Mice. Laires, Ear-wigs, and Snails, likewiÅ¿e Å¿poil the very Fruit on the Trees when they approach to maturity, eÅ¿pecially Peaches, and Plums; have not GooÅ¿berry-Å¿hrubs their peculiar Enemies alÅ¿o, which are a kind of Å¿mall green Caterpillars, which form themÅ¿elves towards the Months of May, and June, on the back part of their Leaves, and eat them to that degree, that thoÅ¿e little Shrubs remain altogether bare; and their Fruit no longer having any thing to cover and defend them from the great heats of the Sun, is deÅ¿troy'd, without being able to Ripen.

I might run over all the Accidents which all the reÅ¿t of Gard'ning is liable to, and cauÅ¿e abundance of DiÅ¿orders in it: For Example, Strawberry-Plants in the prime of their Youth and Vigour, are as it were treacherouÅ¿ly attack'd in their very Roots by thoÅ¿e wicked WeeÅ¿els. Tons which deÅ¿troy them.

Kitchen-Plants, eÅ¿pecially Lettuce, and Succory, &c. conÅ¿tantly have Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e ThoÅ¿e uÅ¿ually called by the Name of Cock-Chafers. Tons, or other little reddiÅ¿h Worms which gnaw them about the neck, and kill them juÅ¿t as they come to perfection.
How much do Artichokes Å¿uffer by little black Flies which infeÅ¿t them towards the end of Summer, and Mulots, or Garden-Mice, which gnaw their Roots in the Winter.
Lettuce, and Succory are abÅ¿olutely devour'd by Snails, Å¿ome of which are long, and yellow, Å¿ome blackiÅ¿h, and gray, and others little and white, eÅ¿pecially in Rainy Weather.
Sorell is tormented in very hot weather with little Black Fleas, which gnaw all the Leaves, inÅ¿omuch that it becomes of no uÅ¿e.

Even Cabbages are Å¿poil'd by green Snails, which gnaw and Å¿poil all their Leaves; but I am only to Å¿peak in this place, of thoÅ¿e DiÅ¿tempers that may be Cur'd in Fruit-Trees, and not of Å¿uch as are Incurable, nor of thoÅ¿e that are incident to Kitchen-Plants; thoÅ¿e commonly proceed, either from the defect of the Ground, which does not furniÅ¿h nouriÅ¿hment enough, or from an ill Culture, or a defect in Pruning, or finally, from a defect in the Tree, which was not well-condition'd, either before it was Planted, or in Planting of it.

It therefore follows, in the firÅ¿t place, that the Soil may contribute to DiÅ¿temper our Trees, which commonly happens when the Earth is not Fruitful in it Å¿elf, or is perhaps become Å¿o by being exhauÅ¿ted, or when it is too dry, or too moiÅ¿t; or elÅ¿e when, tho' never Å¿o good, there is not a Å¿ufficient quantity of it.

In order to remedy all thoÅ¿e kind of Inconvenients, I Å¿ay, that when the Soil is infertile, as it happens in many places, where there is nothing but clear Sand, the MaÅ¿ter is to blame to have Planted any thing in it, the defect of it can never be Corrected, whatever quantity of Dung he puts into it; the only Expedient is to remove that Earth, and put better Mould in the room of it: Happy are thoÅ¿e who can meet with it in their Neighbourhood, and thereby avoid the Trouble and Charge of fetching it at a diÅ¿tance. As to that which is worn out, it is likely that there may be Å¿ome better about
it which may be us'd, unleÅ¿s People would allow it two or three years time to lie Fallow, in order to amend it by reÅ¿t, but there is no pleaÅ¿ure in loÅ¿ing Å¿o much time: When we reÅ¿olve to make this Exchange of Mould, and yet are unwilling to remove the Tree which is not Old, one half of the Roots muÅ¿t be Prun'd short again, which will Å¿uffice for the firÅ¿t Year, doing the Å¿ame again at the end of two years, to the other half of the Tree: Nothing ExhauÅ¿ts the Ground more than the Roots of Trees lying long in the Å¿ame place, eÅ¿pecially the Roots of Neighbouring Trees, particularly PalliÅ¿ado's of Elms; Fruit-Trees muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity Pine, or PeriÅ¿h, if that Neighbourhood Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿ts.

When the Ground is too dry, and light, the beÅ¿t Remedy is to Å¿oak it often with frequent Waterings, or by Artificial falls of Water, or elÅ¿e by ordering Spouts, or, Dreins in Å¿uch a manner, that they may Conduct the Water of Rains into the Squares and Bordures, as I have explain'd it in the TreatiÅ¿e about Soils.

When the Ground is too moiÅ¿t, that part muÅ¿t be rais'd where the Trees Å¿tand, making lower Ridges to receive the Waters, and Conduct them out of the Gardens by Gutters, or Aqueducts, as I have done in the Kitchen-Garden of VerÅ¿ailles.

When there is not Mold enough, it muÅ¿t be augmented, either about the Roots, removing all the ill Mould, to put better in the room of it; or elÅ¿e laying new Mould over the Surface of it; the Mould being thus amended, without doubt the Trees will thrive better in it, and grow more Vigorous.

When the diÅ¿temper is only viÅ¿ible by a certain yellowneÅ¿s, as for Example; Pear-Trees Graffed upon Quince-Stocks, in certain Grounds, always grow yellow, tho' the Ground Å¿eems to be pretty good; it is a good and certain AdvertiÅ¿ement to remove them, and to place others in their room upon Free-Stocks, which are much more Vigorous, and agree better in an indifferent Soil, than others.

When Peaches Graffed upon Almond-Stocks, caÅ¿t too much Gum in moiÅ¿t Grounds, others muÅ¿t be Planted upon Plum-Stocks, and when they do not thrive upon Plum-Stocks in Sandy Grounds, only Å¿uch muÅ¿t be Planted there, as are Graffed upon Almonds.

If, on the other hand, the Tree appears over-burthen'd with Branches, Å¿o as only to Å¿hoot very Å¿mall ones, it muÅ¿t be eas'd, until it begins again to produce fine Shoots, always performing that Pruning, by lowering the uppermoÅ¿t Branches, or by removing part of thoÅ¿e that cauÅ¿e a ConfuÅ¿ion in the middle, obÅ¿erving the Maxims I have eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd for good Pruning.

When the DiÅ¿temper proceeds from the Trees being ill-Condition'd before its being Planted; as for inÅ¿tance, from its having a Scabby poor Foot, half dead for want, or from its being too weak, the beÅ¿t way is to pull it out, and place a better in the room of it.

If the Tree, being good in it Å¿elf, has been Planted too deep, or too Å¿hallow, or with too many Roots, the beÅ¿t expedient is to take it up again, Prune the Roots a-new, and Re-plant it according to the Rules of Art.
And to all theÅ¿e Ends, it is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to keep always Å¿ome Dozens of good Trees in Baskets, to place new ones ready grown in the room of Å¿uch as muÅ¿t be remov'd.

When the Trees are attack'd with Å¿ome Cankers, you muÅ¿t with the point of a Knife remove the part Å¿o tainted to the quick, and then apply a little Cow-Dung to it, covering it with a piece of Linen, a kind of Rind will grow over it, which will cover the Wound, and Å¿o that Accident will be Cur'd.
When Catterpillars annoy a Tree, Care muÅ¿t be taken to remove them.
When Rats gnaw the Barks, Snares and Traps muÅ¿t be laid for them.

When the DiÅ¿temper is Å¿uppos'd to proceed from Tons, the Foot of the Tree muÅ¿t be uncover'd to Extirpate them abÅ¿olutely, putting new Mould in the room of the old, after having Å¿hortned the Roots that are gnaw'd.

Among the Incurable DiÅ¿tempers of our Trees, I reckon firÅ¿t Old Age; when for InÅ¿tance, a Pear-Tree, or Plum-Tree has Å¿erv'd for Thirty, Forty, or Fifty years, we may conclude that it has attain'd a decrepit Age, and conÅ¿equently, that it has perform'd its part, and is out of date, there is no hopes of a return, it muÅ¿t be taken out, not leaving any of its Roots into the Ground, putting new Mould into the room of it, in order to Plant new Trees there, when People are deÅ¿irous of Å¿eeing Trees in the Å¿ame Place.

In the Å¿econd place, I reckon the Tigers which Å¿tick to the back of the Leaves of Wall-Pear-Trees, and dry them up by Å¿ucking all the green Matter that was in them, among the Incurable DiÅ¿tempers; I have imploy'd all manner of Å¿trong, Å¿ower, corroÅ¿ive, Å¿tinking Lees, Viz. of Rue, Tabacco, Salt, Vinegar, &c. to waÅ¿h the Leaves, and Branches: I have, by the Advice of Å¿ome of the Curious, imploy'd Oyl; I have Å¿moak'd them with
BrimÅ¿tone by the Advice of others; I have burnt the Old Leaves, I have Å¿crap'd the back of the Branches, and Stem, to which the Seed Å¿ticks: I daily endeavour to find out Å¿ome new Expedient; and after all, I confeÅ¿s freely, and to my Å¿hame, that I have never Å¿ucceeded in any of them; there Å¿till remains Å¿ome of the Seed of that CurÅ¿ed InÅ¿ect, in Å¿ome part or other: And in the Months of May, and June, this Seed is hatch'd by the heat of the Sun, and then multiplies ad Infinitum, and therefore one of theÅ¿e two things muÅ¿t be done; either no Pear-Trees muÅ¿t be Å¿uffer'd againÅ¿t a Wall, or in EÅ¿palier, which is a violent Remedy, eÅ¿pecially for Å¿mall MuÅ¿cat-Pears, Burgamots, and Winter Bon-Chretiens, which Å¿eldom thrive from a Wall; or elÅ¿e we muÅ¿t reÅ¿olve to Å¿ee thoÅ¿e Tigers upon them, contenting our Å¿elves with burning all the Leaves yearly, and with cleanÅ¿ing the Trees as much as is poÅ¿Å¿ible.

Thirdly, I reckon among the Incurable DiÅ¿tempers the Gum, which faÅ¿tens to Peach-Trees, and other Stone-Fruits; when it only appears on one Branch, it is no great matter, 'tis but cutting the Å¿aid Branch two or three inches below the part Å¿o DiÅ¿temper'd; whereby this kind of Gangreen is hinder'd from extending farther, as it would Infallibly do, if it Å¿tuck about the Graff, or all over the Stem, or on moÅ¿t of the Roots, and then the Å¿ole Expedient is to loÅ¿e no more time about it, and conÅ¿equently to remove Å¿uch a Tree out of the Ground, in the manner aforeÅ¿aid:

The Gum Å¿ometimes proceeds from an external Accident, for inÅ¿tance, from a Wound which has been made by way of InciÅ¿ion, by a Scratch, and Å¿ometimes from an Evil inward diÅ¿poÅ¿ition: In the firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e, that Gum is nothing but a Å¿purted Sap, which is Å¿ubject to Corruption, and RottenneÅ¿s, from the time it ceaÅ¿es to be inclos'd in its Ordinary Channels, which lye between the Wood, and the Bark; in that CaÅ¿e the Remedy is eaÅ¿ie, eÅ¿pecially when it happens only on a Branch, as I have declar'd in the preceeding Article, when the DiÅ¿temper affects the Stem, it often Cures it Å¿elf by a knob, or a Continuation of new Bark, which extends over the part Å¿o Wounded; Å¿ometimes it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to apply a PlaiÅ¿ter of Cow-dung over it, cover'd with a piece of Linen, until the Wound be clos'd: When the Gum proceeds from the inÅ¿ide, I judge it Incurable on the Stem, or Roots.

div.head: A TREATISE OF THE Graffs of Trees, AND OF NURSERIES.
CHAP. XI.

argument.p: Of Graffs.

div.p: I Never Reflect on what we call Graffing of Trees, and the Advantage which accrues from thence, for the ImbelliÅ¿hment of our Gardens; but at the Å¿ame time, in my Cultus, & in primis Å¿uccos emendat acerbos, &c. Ovid lib. remedio amoris. Sponte SuÃ¢ quae Å¿e tollunt inluminis auros, infaecunda quidem, Å¿ed laeta & fortia Å¿urgunt. Quippe Å¿olo natura Å¿ubeÅ¿t. Tamen haec quoque Å¿i quis inferat, &c. The HiÅ¿tory of Great Men, who have delighted in this Art, has Å¿ufficiently mention'd it, without my inÅ¿erting any Particulars about it; therefore I Å¿hall only Å¿ay, that as the great delight of the Famous Gard'ner of the Georgicks (which the Poet makes no Å¿cruple of Comparing to the PleaÅ¿ure of Kings) conÅ¿iÅ¿ted in finding at his coming home at night, wherewith to maintain, and treat his Family, without buying any thing, (no body can queÅ¿tion but it was with the Fruit and Legumes of his Garden, Å¿econded by Å¿ome Profits of his Poultry, Dairy, &c.) argument.p: Of the kind of Graffs that are in uÅ¿e.

div.p: THE Graffs that are moÅ¿t commonly us'd are Inarching, Budding or Inoculating, the Cleft, the Crown, or Graff's between the Wood and the Bark, and Whip-Graffing.
Inarching is for CheÅ¿nuts, Marons, Fig-Trees, &c.
Budding or Inoculateing is for all manner of Fruits, both Kernel and Stone, and Å¿ometimes for other Trees that bear no Fruit.

The Cleft is alÅ¿o proper for all manner of good Fruit Trees, and even for other great Trees, provided both the one, and the other have, at leaÅ¿t three or four Inches Circumference at the place where the Graff is to be Å¿o perform'd; Clefts are not generally Å¿o proper
for Stone Fruit, eÅ¿pecially Peaches, as for Kernel Fruit; the CurioÅ¿os of Å¿ome Provinces in Guyenne affirm the Contrary.

The Crown or Graffs between the Wood and the Bark, as well as Whip-Graffing, are particularly for thick Branches, or for thick Å¿horten'd Stems of Kernel Fruit, and are nought for Stone Fruit, as well as for all Branches and Stems of a moderate Size, which are too weak to preÅ¿s their Graffs Å¿ufficiently.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

argument.p: Of Proper Times to Graff.

div.p: THE Proper Times to Graff, are FirÅ¿t, the beginning of May, in which the Sap, being riÅ¿en into the Trees, eÅ¿pecially in the Branches of the preceeding years Growth, without the Eyes or Buds having Å¿hot yet, the Bark looÅ¿ens eaÅ¿ily, inÅ¿omuch, that they may be Å¿tript with eaÅ¿e, which is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for thoÅ¿e kind of Graffs in queÅ¿tion. This Month of May is only proper for Inarching, which as we have already Å¿aid, is only fit for CheÅ¿nut, Maron, and Fig-Trees, &c.

Secondly, The middle of June is proper for Inoculating,
A la PouÅ¿Å¿e, as the Author Terms it. which is only to be us'd for certain Stone Fruits; for InÅ¿tance, for Cherries, Morellos and Bigarreaux, upon a Å¿mall bitter Wild-Cherry, and Peaches upon old Almond-Trees, &c.

Thirdly, The Months of July and AuguÅ¿t, for Budding or Inoculating Trees, which by the Å¿mall Vigour of their Foot, or elÅ¿e by reaÅ¿on of the exceÅ¿Å¿ive Heat and Draughts which happen Å¿ometimes at that Time, Å¿eem to have a viÅ¿ible, if not total dimunition of Sap; for you muÅ¿t know, that this way of Inoculating, with a cloÅ¿e Eye or Å¿hut Bud, requires but little Sap, particularly from the Stock, upon which, after having made the neceÅ¿Å¿ary InciÅ¿ion, the Scutcheon muÅ¿t be apply'd: Too great an abundance of Sap in the Stock is pernicious to that apply'd Scutcheon, by reaÅ¿on that it is commonly Drown'd there with Gum, whereas it Å¿hould only Å¿tick, without meeting any thing there for the remainder of the year capable of making it Shoot; it Å¿tands in need but of a very Å¿mall help to preÅ¿erve it from Death, in expectation of a kind of vigorous ReÅ¿urrection, which the Spring PromiÅ¿es, when it recovers out of its Lethargy; as to the Twig from whence the Bud is taken, it can never have too much Sap, provided the Bark be Å¿ufficiently well nouriÅ¿h'd to Å¿trip with eaÅ¿e from the Wood it covers, and take along with it the Internal Sprout which forms the principal part of that Scutcheon; the Common Stocks which are Budded upon, during thoÅ¿e two Months, are Plum-Stocks, for Plums, or Peaches, young Almond-Stocks Planted in an ill Ground for Peaches, Quince-Stocks for Pears, White-Thorns for Apricocks; Paradice-Stocks and Apple-Wildlings, for good Apples, &c.

The Month of September is proper for Inoculating Peach-Trees, upon Vigorous Peach-Stocks, or young Almond-Stocks, of that years Groweth; Planted in good Ground, both the one and the other have the gift of preÅ¿erving abundance of Sap very Å¿afe; and they are only fit to Bud upon, at the Time of the Declining of that Sap.

We might Graff in the Cleft, during the Months of November, December, and January, but one is never the more forward, on the Contrary, it is much to be fear'd that the Graffs would Wither and abÅ¿olutely PerriÅ¿h, by reaÅ¿on that during theÅ¿e Three Months, they receive no aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance from the Root, which at that time, by reaÅ¿on of the Cold, is, as it were, benum'd of all its Vegetative Functions.

All the Month of February, and a conÅ¿iderable part of March, are admirable for the Cleft, and for Whip-Graffing, but that is to be underÅ¿tood, when by reaÅ¿on of the length of the Colds of the Winter, the SeaÅ¿on is not forward, and ConÅ¿equently the Trees not yet enter'd into Sap, that is before the Bark quits the Wood; for as Å¿oon as ever it looÅ¿ens, Å¿uch Trees can no longer be Graffed in the Cleft that year. Therefore it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary, to provide betimes, particularly againÅ¿t that time, Graffs of Pears, Apples, Plums, &c. eÅ¿pecially when they are to come from diÅ¿tant Countries.

The end of March in mild Springs, I mean Å¿uch, which inÅ¿tead of being accompani'd with Snows, and Å¿mall FroÅ¿ts, as it is uÅ¿ual, are Hot and MoiÅ¿t; the firÅ¿t half of April, particularly is very favourable for the Crown; by reaÅ¿on that the Sap muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be Å¿ufficiently riÅ¿en into thoÅ¿e Å¿horten'd Trunks, to be able to divide the Bark from the Wood, with Å¿mall wedges made of Box, or Ebony, in order to faclitate the Lodging of the Graff, that has been prepar'd on purpoÅ¿e for it.

The Month of April is only proper to Graff all manner of Apple-Trees in the Cleft, by reaÅ¿on that thoÅ¿e kind of Trees are not Å¿o eaÅ¿ily mov'd to produce Sap as other Fruit-Trees are, and as I have declar'd already, the only time to Graff in the Cleft is a little before the Trees begin to BloÅ¿Å¿om and Shoot; the Å¿aid Month of April is likewiÅ¿e Convenient to Graff Vines, which can only be Graffed in the Cleft upon Trunks cover'd with Earth.

The Figure of the Graffing-Knives is DeÅ¿cribed in the Plate of the Pruining-Knives, P. 15. Vol. II. Months of the Year, that are proper for each of them, there Å¿till remains to explain the proper manner of performing them; and therefore, I Å¿hall begin with the DeÅ¿cription of the Graffing-Knife.

The Blade of this Graffing-Knife muÅ¿t be about two Inches long, with a Å¿mall Handle, a full Inch longer than the Blade, or ordinary Knives, the overplus of the Handle muÅ¿t be flatten'd on the Extremity, and made round, about the Edges of that Extremity, in order to Å¿erve to looÅ¿en the Rind of the Wildlings with eaÅ¿e, upon which the Scutcheon is to be apply'd; the moÅ¿t Convenient Graffing-Knives, are thoÅ¿e which cloÅ¿e within the Handle, like Pruning-Knives, or like the Common Pocket-Knives that are made to fold.

Now Å¿ince in the order I have obÅ¿erv'd for Graffs, I have begun with that which is perform'd firÅ¿t in the fineÅ¿t SeaÅ¿on of the Year, viz. Inarching, I think it will be proper to begin this Chapter with the manner of doing it as it Å¿hould be; and therefore, I Å¿ay, that in order to Å¿ucceed in it, in the firÅ¿t place the Twig that is deÅ¿igned to Graff with, which you muÅ¿t hold in your hand before you begin, in order to make the neceÅ¿Å¿ary CompariÅ¿ons the better, between the Twig and the Branch that it is to be Graffed upon, either with Thred, RuÅ¿h, Ribbon, &c. by reaÅ¿on that this Twig muÅ¿t be exactly of the Å¿ame thickneÅ¿s with the Branch you are to Graff upon; for it being thicker or Å¿maller, the Graff will not Å¿ucceed. Next, you muÅ¿t chuÅ¿e a fine Place upon the Å¿aid Twig, having two good Eyes or Buds, looking regularly the one on one Å¿ide, the other on the other, and with your Graffing-Knife, or other Å¿harp InÅ¿trument you muÅ¿t cut the Bark of the Piece you are to take off for the Graff, Circularly to the very Wood, both at the top and bottom; you muÅ¿t take off all the Bark which covers the Å¿malleÅ¿t part of the Å¿aid Twig, in order to make that Piece come out there, which is to be taken off after having looÅ¿en'd it from its Wood, by twiÅ¿ting it gently with the Thumb: But before you take it quite out of its Place, you muÅ¿t Å¿horten the Branch that is to be Graffed upon, four or five Inches, and without wounding the Wood, you muÅ¿t Å¿trip it intirely in a very Å¿ound, and very Å¿mooth place, unto the lower part where the Graff is to come, that it may fit it Å¿o exactly, that it may rather be thought it grew there Naturally, than by Art, and immediately, in order not to permit a Å¿mall MoiÅ¿ture which lyes round about the part Å¿o Å¿tript, which is the Sap newly riÅ¿en, to Evaporate, you muÅ¿t make an end of taking the piece that is deÅ¿ign'd for the Graff, out of its Place, and Lodge it with all the Diligence, and dexterity imaginable within the Branch Å¿o Å¿tript, to the place where 'tis to remain, and Huc aliena ex Arbore germen includunt, udoque docent inoleÅ¿cere libro. Georg. 2. finally to hinder the moiÅ¿ture of the Air from penetrating into the Å¿pace between the Wood of the Branch that is Graffed, and the Bark that is newly applied, you muÅ¿t raiÅ¿e Å¿mall Shavings out of the Wood of the Branch round about the Superiour Extremity of that Graff, without putting them off, and make them hang like a kind of Ruff on the Extremity of that Bark, to cover, and Å¿helter it from the Injuries of the Air.

Inocculating or Budding, A la Pouce, (which I take to be with an open Bud) and with the cloÅ¿e Eye, or Å¿hut Bud, only differ as to the Time of performing them, as we have already
obÅ¿erv'd; they are both perform'd in the Å¿ame manner, the firÅ¿t thing to be done in order to it, is, to take from the Tree you deÅ¿ign to Graff with, Cyons of that years Growth perfectly at a Å¿tand, upon which you find good Eyes or Buds, likewiÅ¿e at a Å¿tand, and they are thoÅ¿e which have been firÅ¿t form'd Å¿ince the Spring, thoÅ¿e that are form'd laÅ¿t being too tender to Succeed: As Å¿oon as thoÅ¿e Twigs are cut, you muÅ¿t take off the Leaves cloÅ¿e to the Place where they Å¿tick to their Stalk, by which means the Eyes or Buds will not Wither Å¿o Å¿oon; the Cyons may be preÅ¿erv'd three or four days, provided the Butt end be plac'd in Water, or any thing that is MoiÅ¿t, and the Twig not above half a Foot long; inÅ¿omuch that one may very well cut a Twig that is two Foot long into Å¿everal Pieces: With theÅ¿e two Precautions you may very well Å¿end thoÅ¿e Twigs newly cut from the Tree, thirty or forty Leagues off (Note, that if they be Twigs taken from Peach-Trees, you muÅ¿t Å¿eldom take any Scutcheons from them, unleÅ¿s the Eyes be double or treble, that is, unleÅ¿s you find the beginning of a growing Branch accompani'd with Leaves, and two beginnings of Fruit Buds to the Right and Left, or other Branches to come) as for other Fruits, Pears, Apples, Plums, &c. a Å¿ingle Eye is as good as a double, or treble one, &c.

When you are ready to Bud, you muÅ¿t ChuÅ¿e upon the Branch, or Stem you deÅ¿ign to Inoculate upon, a fine Å¿mooth place, which is generally met with, in the Å¿pace which divides the inferior Eye from another which is immediately above it, where you muÅ¿t make two InciÅ¿ions repreÅ¿enting a great Roman T, that is the upper InciÅ¿ion Horizontal, and the Å¿econd beginning near the middle of the firÅ¿t Slit deÅ¿cending downwards, about an Inch or an Inch and a half in length; theÅ¿e two InciÅ¿ions may be made before you take off the Scutcheon you are to apply, provided the Rind of the Wildling be not Å¿eparated until the Scutcheon be ready; by reaÅ¿on that it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary that the Scutcheon Å¿hould meet with Å¿ome MoiÅ¿ture in that part of the Wildling it is to be apply'd to, and that this MoiÅ¿ture Å¿hould proceed from the Sap, which muÅ¿t Glue it to the Å¿aid Wildling; otherwiÅ¿e the place being Dry, the Graff would PeriÅ¿h, therefore the Å¿afeÅ¿t way is to begin by taking off the Scutcheon before you make your InciÅ¿ion on the Wildling; now in order to take off the Scutcheon, particularly for Peaches, you muÅ¿t make an InciÅ¿ion like to the
Figure A upon the Twig or Shoot, in that part where you obÅ¿erve a good Eye or Bud, which is partly the Figure of the Scutcheon of a Coat of Arms, from whence Gard'ning has borrowed that Term of Scutcheon, after which preÅ¿Å¿ing the Thumb cloÅ¿e upon the Å¿ides of that InciÅ¿ion towards that part which is near the Eye that is contain'd within the Å¿pace of the InciÅ¿ion, it is eaÅ¿ily looÅ¿en'd from the Twig, provided the Sap be plentiful there, otherwiÅ¿e, tho even in the CaÅ¿e of Peach-Trees, the Scutcheon muÅ¿t be raiÅ¿ed with a Wedge of Wood, which muÅ¿t be perform'd by Slipping the Graffing-Knife under the Bark from the Head of the Scutcheon to the Point, biting a little into the Wood, eÅ¿pecially about the Eye, &c.

As to the Scutcheons of Kernel Fruits, they can hardly be taken off otherwiÅ¿e than with a Piece of Wood: When the Scutcheon is taken off, you muÅ¿t look whether the inward Sprout, which is the Channel through which the Sap is Communicated for the Production of a new Branch, hold to the Å¿aid Scutcheon, as it muÅ¿t abÅ¿olutely do, which being Å¿o you Å¿hall hold this Scutcheon in your Mouth, only between your Lips by the end of the Stalk of the remaining Leaves, by reaÅ¿on that Spittle might prejudice it; in the mean time take care to Å¿eparate the Rind dexterouÅ¿ly, by degrees, with the flaten'd end of your Knife, without leaving any thing along the two long Å¿ides of the InciÅ¿ion, being careful that the InciÅ¿ion may be Å¿omewhat longer towards the Point than the Scutcheon, then take the Scutcheon out of your Mouth, and preÅ¿enting the pointed part thereof to the Horizontal InciÅ¿ion, make it Å¿lide down all along the InciÅ¿ion; inÅ¿omuch that it may be Lodg'd there intirely, and eÅ¿pecially that it may fill up all that part which is Å¿tript at the Head of the InciÅ¿ion, and finally that the Å¿ides of the Bark that are looÅ¿en'd, may afterwards come to cover all the Scutcheon, excepting the Eye, this being done, you muÅ¿t take courÅ¿e flat Flax, wherewith you muÅ¿t gently, and neatly, tye the Scutcheon, the looÅ¿en'd Bark, and the
Branch together, to the end that they may the better joyn together, and there ends the MyÅ¿tery of Inoculating, or Budding, with this difference only, that when it is perform'd in A la PouÅ¿Å¿e. June, the Branch, or Stem Å¿o Budded, muÅ¿t be immediately Å¿horten'd within two or three Inches of the Scutcheon; to the end that the Sap being hinder'd from aÅ¿cending higher (as it naturally would do) it may be forc'd to enter into that Scutcheon, in order to make it Å¿hoot Å¿oon after: Meriziers, a Å¿mall wild bitter Cherry, Å¿o Budded, commonly Å¿ucceed better than any Fruit-Trees, and eÅ¿pecially better than Peach-Trees Budded in June, either upon other Peach Trees, or Old Almond Trees; by reaÅ¿on that they are very Å¿ubject to periÅ¿h with Gum, and that by an over-abundance of Sap, which being in the Summer in the Trees that are Inoculated, and not finding a Å¿ufficient IÅ¿Å¿ue at the overture of the Eye of that Scutcheon, comes out at the InciÅ¿ion, there Congeals like Blood out of the Veins, and abÅ¿olutely deÅ¿troys the Å¿aid Scutcheon; but when this Inoculation is perform'd with a cloÅ¿e Eye, or Å¿hut Bud, neither the Branch, or Stem Å¿o Graffed, muÅ¿t be immediately Å¿horten'd, you muÅ¿t tarry until the Month of March following, which is the time that the Sap begins to mount up into the Trees again, which is the proper time to Å¿horten them in the Å¿ame manner we have expreÅ¿s'd for the Budding in June, the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on Å¿erving for both, provided always, that before that time, that is, during the Winter, the Flax which did tie the Scutcheon, has been cut neatly, without wounding the Bark that was cover'd by the Å¿aid Flax; for unleÅ¿s it were cut, all the part Å¿o tied, and what is above it, would be apt to periÅ¿h for want of a Å¿ufficient paÅ¿Å¿age for the Sap, which would aÅ¿cend to the Extremity of the Branch, and thereby all pains taken about the Inoculation, would prove vain, while the lower part below it, would Å¿hoot abundance of Wild Twigs, of no uÅ¿e.

The DeÅ¿cription of the Cleft we have in the Georgicks, tho' admirable in it Å¿elf, might Aut rurÅ¿um enodes trunci reÅ¿ceantur, & altÃ© finditur in Å¿olidum cuncis via: deinde Å¿eraces plantae immittuntur; nec longum tempus, & ingens exiit ad caelum ramis foelicibus arbos, Georg. 2 yet be much better, if it were more compleat, more particular, and more inÅ¿tructive; it only tells us, that in order to Perform this Graff, the head of the Trees muÅ¿t be cut off, in that part where the Stem appears moÅ¿t even, and leaÅ¿t knotty, that we muÅ¿t cleave the Å¿aid Stock pretty deep with Wedges, and finally, that we muÅ¿t lodge Cyons of better Fruits into thoÅ¿e Clefts, which in time produce fine large Trees.

The Reading of that DeÅ¿cription does not appear Å¿ufficient to me, to InÅ¿truct a new Learner in the Art of Graffing, to perform it as it Å¿hould be, it is deficient in Å¿everal Articles, FirÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e it does not inform us that we may not only Graff upon thick Å¿horten'd Stocks, but alÅ¿o that it may be done upon Å¿everal Branches of Trees, either Dwarfs, or tall Standards, even upon Stocks of two or three Inches Circumference, provided they be capable of Å¿uffering the Cleft, and of cloÅ¿ing the Graff Å¿ufficiently.
It is defective in the Second place, in not Å¿pecifying the proper time for thoÅ¿e kind of Graffs. We have explain'd it already.

Thirdly, It is defective, in not fixing the length of the Twigs that are employ'd about it: We commonly regulate it to two or three Inches in length, or rather upon the number of three good Buds at leaÅ¿t, which the Graff muÅ¿t have.

Fourthly, it is deficient, in neither teaching us how to Prune the Graffs well, nor how to place them Å¿o exactly in the only places that are proper for them, that the Sap of the Foot may enter Å¿ecurely into them: As for the Pruning of thoÅ¿e Graffs, in order to perform it well, the Butt-end of them muÅ¿t be Cut with a very Å¿harp Pruning-Knife, on both Å¿ides in the form of a Wedge, about half a large Inch in length, preÅ¿erving on the two Å¿ides which Edge that Figure of a Wedge, Å¿ome Bark Å¿ticking very cloÅ¿e to the Wood; the Å¿ide which is to be moÅ¿t outward muÅ¿t be Å¿omewhat broader, and thicker, than the other which is inward, and preciÅ¿ely on the top of that Bark preÅ¿erv'd for the outÅ¿ide, you muÅ¿t have a good Eye, or Bud, as high as the edge of the Å¿horten'd Stock, and the upper part of the Cleft; and as to the well-placing of the Graffs, the inÅ¿ide of the Barks, both of the Wildling, and of the Graffs, muÅ¿t be Å¿o exactly Å¿itted, that the Sap riÅ¿ing from the Foot, may as eaÅ¿ily enter into the Å¿pace between the Wood, and the Bark of the Graff, as between the Wood and the Bark of the Stock, or Branches Graffed upon.

The DeÅ¿cription is likewiÅ¿e deficient, in the Fifth place, in not obÅ¿erving, that in caÅ¿e the Cleft be not made very curiouÅ¿ly, as it happens often, you muÅ¿t pare it with your Pruning-Knife, removing whatever might obÅ¿truct or hinder the Graff from entring freely, nay more, in caÅ¿e there be cauÅ¿e to judge that the Graff, by being a little too Å¿mall, in proportion to the Stock, may be a little too much preÅ¿s'd, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to pare the wood on both Å¿ides of the Cleft very neatly, and very Å¿moothly, which is to be done with the point of a very Å¿harp Pruning-Knife, beginning from the lower part upwards, and all this Å¿o exactly, and Å¿o conformably to the Figure of the Branch that has been cut for the Cleft Graff, that after having lodg'd the Graff, there may appear no vacuity between it, and the Å¿ides of the Cleft; and yet, that the Graff may Å¿tick Å¿o cloÅ¿e, that it may not be eaÅ¿ie to move it.

Sixthly, The DeÅ¿cription is defective, in not mentioning how many Graffs may be apply'd upon one Stock, and how the upper part of the Stem being Cut muÅ¿t be prepar'd; large Stocks, or Branches that are to be Graff'd in the Cleft, muÅ¿t be very Å¿mooth at top, and equal on all Å¿ides, inÅ¿omuch that the head may be Horizontal, to place Å¿everal Graffs upon it, if there be room, and the Stock requires it; Å¿mall Stocks, or Branches that cannot receive above one Graff, muÅ¿t only be Å¿mooth'd in one part of the Head; and if that part where the Graff is to be apply'd, the remainder muÅ¿t be Cut like the Foot of a Hind.

Finally, the Å¿aid DeÅ¿cription is defective in not informing us how to Å¿ecure our Graff'd Trees, and hinder them from being prejudic'd by the Injuries of the Air, Rains, Heats, and Droughts, through the overtures of the Cleffs, whereupon it is to be noted, that all Cleft Graffs muÅ¿t be Å¿wadled with fine Earth, and Hay newly prepar'd, or elÅ¿e with Gum prepar'd to that end, compos'd either of black fat Pitch, melted in an Iron Pot, or Earth mix'd with a little yellow Wax, the Å¿aid Gum muÅ¿t be kept hot, and liquid, over a Chaffing-DiÅ¿h, to be apply'd with a kind of Wooden Trule; but before you apply either the Earth, and Hay, or the Gum, you muÅ¿t cover all the Crannies with Å¿ome Barks, immediately looÅ¿en'd from Å¿ome Branch of the Tree that is Graffed; they are commonly put croÅ¿swiÅ¿e on large Stocks, or Graff'd Branches, in order to cover the Clefts Å¿o well, that nothing may get into them; and whereas we generally cover the Earth, and Hay, with a piece of Linnen to keep it fix'd about the Head that is Graff'd, which has Å¿ome reÅ¿emblance to a Child's Baby, we often call the Cleft Graff a Baby-Graff: Nota, that when the Stock does not Å¿eem to preÅ¿s the Graff Å¿ufficiently, it muÅ¿t be bound about with Å¿ome tender Twigs of an Ozier, in order to Å¿ecure the Graff.

I conclude what relates to Cleft Graffs, after having declar'd what I can Å¿ay about Wedges; which is, that before you make uÅ¿e of them to open the Cleft, you muÅ¿t, in caÅ¿e it be a large Stock, begin the Cleft with the edge of a pretty large Knife, apply'd upon the whole breadth of the Trunk, or Branch, Å¿triking with a Hammer upon it, in order to make the Å¿aid edge enter pretty deep into the Wood, and thereby mark the Cleft in queÅ¿tion: Stocks of a moderate Å¿ize are eaÅ¿ily enough Cleft with the bare edge of the Knife, without the help of a Hammer.

The Wedges to be Convenient muÅ¿t be made according to the Model of this Figure, one of the Hooks being thicker, longer, and Å¿tronger than the other, which is to Å¿erve for large Stocks, and the other being both Å¿horter, Å¿maller, and weaker, for Å¿mall ones: In order to uÅ¿e thoÅ¿e Wedges, that which Å¿eems beÅ¿t proportion'd for the Stock that is to be Graffed upon, muÅ¿t be plac'd in the middle of the Cleft that is begun, and when it cannot enter Å¿ufficiently, to make the Overture that is neceÅ¿Å¿ary, it muÅ¿t be driven in with a Hammer: In fine, the Cleft being partly large enough, to lodge the Graff into it, you muÅ¿t raiÅ¿e or pull down the end of the Tool that Å¿erves for a Wedge, with the left hand, in the mean time, with the right, placing the Graff, Cut as aforeÅ¿aid, to the place where it is to remain; and thus you may make an end of Å¿tretching, or cloÅ¿ing the Cleft, according as you may judge it proper, when the Graff, or Graffs are plac'd as they Å¿hould be. I need not tell you, that one Cleft may Å¿erve to place two Graffs oppoÅ¿ite to one another, and when two more can be plac'd, a Å¿econd Cleft may be made CroÅ¿wiÅ¿e upon the Stock, altogether like the firÅ¿t, uÅ¿ing the Å¿ame Method preÅ¿crib'd about the two firÅ¿t Graffs.

We Å¿ometimes call it Graffing in the Crown, when we place four Graffs CleftwiÅ¿e upon a Stock, that is large enough to receive them Conveniently; but it is more particularly call'd Å¿o, when upon very large Å¿horten'd Stocks we place a greater number of Graffs between the Wood, and the Bark, for inÅ¿tance, 6, 7, 8. and therefore this kind of Graff, as well as that we call Whip-Graffing can only be perform'd upon Å¿uch Stocks as exceed three or four Inches Diameter, which cannot be Cleft; but we Å¿eldom uÅ¿e either of them, by reaÅ¿on that the Å¿ucceÅ¿s is very uncertain, and the trouble of making them very ConÅ¿iderable;
to that end Twigs are us'd about half an Inch Circumference, with four or five good Eyes, or Buds in their length; they muÅ¿t be Cut Å¿lantingly at the Butt-end, inÅ¿omuch that the Å¿lope may be about an Inch long, and that the upper part of it may be Cut cloÅ¿e to the Pitch of the Å¿aid Twig, in order to be as Å¿mall as poÅ¿Å¿ible can be at the end, and whereas the Sap, which begins to riÅ¿e from the Foot, paÅ¿Å¿es betwixt the Wood, and the Bark of the Graff, thoÅ¿e Å¿loping Å¿ides muÅ¿t be plac'd on the Å¿ide of the Bark of the Å¿horten'd Stock, by which means the Graff will receive its nouriÅ¿hment. But before you place thoÅ¿e Graffs, you muÅ¿t take out a little of the Wood of the Stock with a Å¿mall Joyner's Chizzel, from thoÅ¿e parts where it is to be plac'd, looÅ¿ening the Bark with a tough Wooden Wedge, Å¿triking dextrouÅ¿ly with a Hammer upon the Å¿aid Wedge, without prejudicing the Bark; the Graff being lodg'd, the Å¿ame thing muÅ¿t be done, we have already declar'd to Å¿ecure the Cleft Graffs from the injuries of the Air.

As for Whipp-Graffing, Slopes or Notches muÅ¿t be made into the Bark, and into the Wood of the Å¿horten'd Stocks, chuÅ¿ing Twigs about an Inch in Circumference, Cutting the Graffs in the Å¿ame manner as thoÅ¿e that are for the Cleft, proportioning the Twig Å¿o Cut, Å¿o exactly to the Notch of the Stock, that it may enter with Å¿ome Å¿mall difficulty, to the end, that the inÅ¿ide of the Barks may meet exactly, and that no Å¿pace may remain between the Å¿ides of the Graff, and the Å¿lop'd, or notch'd Å¿ides of the Stock; this being done, you muÅ¿t take one or two large Oziers to bind the Head Å¿o Graffed, as firm as can be, that the Graffs may not eaÅ¿ily be moved; doing moreover to Å¿ecure the Head from the Injuries of the Air, what we have already preÅ¿crib'd for the Graffs in the Cleft, and in the Crown.

The Authors, and particularly the Ancients, who have written about Graffs, have all Nam quae Å¿e medio trudunt decortice gemmae & tenues rumpunt tunicas anguÅ¿tus in ipÅ¿o Å¿ic nodo Å¿inus: hÃ»c aliend ex arbore germen includunt, udoque docent inoleÅ¿cere libro. Georg. 2. made mention of a certain Inoculating, as of a particular manner of Graffing; Å¿aying that this Inoculation is to be perform'd by placing the Scutcheon in Å¿uch a manner, that the Eye or Bud thereof may be exactly plac'd upon that part where there was another Eye before the InciÅ¿ion was made, and they pretend that it is the beÅ¿t Method of applying the Scutcheon. Nay, moreover I do believe that they were of Opinion that the Sap of the Stock Graffed upon, could not enter into the Eye or Bud of the Å¿aid Scutcheon, unleÅ¿s it were inclin'd to it by the Interiour Figure which remains upon the Wood that is Å¿trip'd, after the Eye is taken away: To which I anÅ¿wer, in the firÅ¿t place, That the daily Experience of all Gard'ners Å¿ufficiently confutes that Opinion, without my inÅ¿iÅ¿ting upon it: Secondly, I anÅ¿wer, not only that there is no advantage by that Inoculating; but moreover, that it is almoÅ¿t impracticable, by reaÅ¿on that the Scutcheon cannot thrive, unleÅ¿s it be abÅ¿olutely glued to the part to which it is apply'd; and conÅ¿equently that part muÅ¿t be as Å¿mooth as the Scutcheon, which cannot be when a Scutcheon is apply'd upon an Eye, or Bud, which is an Elevated part, that forms a kind of Stub, contrary to what muÅ¿t be plain, and Å¿mooth: I have often try'd thoÅ¿e Inoculatings, but have always loÅ¿t my time, and Labour.

div.head: CHAP. XV.

argument.p: Which are the Stocks that have a natural DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition to rereceive Å¿ome kinds of Fruits, each in particular, and to receive no others.

div.p:
THE Fruits in queÅ¿tion in the CaÅ¿e of Graffing, are reduc'd to thoÅ¿e we know by the Names of Pears, Apples, Plums, Peaches, Cherries, Figs, Azerolles, Quince-Apples, Grapes, Sweet-Almonds: To theÅ¿e we might add Medlars, tho' few Gentlemen care for them: As to Oranges, Lemons, and Pomegranats, I have given a Å¿ufficient account about them, in the TreatiÅ¿e of Orange-Trees. Goosberries, RaÅ¿pberries, Melons, Strawberries, and Avelins are not in the rank of Fruits that may be improv'd by Graffing. Pears Å¿ucceed very well, Graffed upon Pear-Wildlings grown from Trunks in Woods, and ForreÅ¿ts, and they are the beÅ¿t Fruits to Graff, eÅ¿pecially in the Cleft for Dwarfs, they are not fit to be Graffed Scutcheon-wiÅ¿e, their Bark being too thick for it; thoÅ¿e Wildlings are likewiÅ¿e very proper for High-Å¿tandards Graffed in the Cleft. Wildlings grown from Kernels in NurÅ¿eries, and the Suckers that Å¿hoot from the Roots of the Foot of Old Pear-Trees in Orchards, are likewiÅ¿e good to Graff Pears upon; either to be Budded while they are very young, or Graff'd in the Clef when they are grown large; but they are much
better for Tall-Standards, than for Dwarfs; they are too Vigorous to remain Low, and to Å¿ubmit to the hardÅ¿hips of Pruning.

Quince-Å¿tocks, eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch as are very Å¿ound, and produce large Leaves, and fine Å¿hoots, and have a Å¿mooth Å¿hining blackiÅ¿h Bark (they are call'd Females, and thoÅ¿e that are wrinkled, and Å¿hrunk, Males; tho' for my part, I do not admit that difference of Names; it is an Act of Vegetation, in which I only diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the degrees of Vigour in every Foot) thoÅ¿e kind of good Quince-Å¿tocks, I Å¿ay, are admirable to Graff all manner of Pears upon, againÅ¿t a Wall, or for Dwarf-Å¿tandards, with a Scutcheon: Nay, Å¿ometimes they will grow to be High-Å¿tandards, being Planted againÅ¿t a Wall, otherwiÅ¿e they are apt to unglue, that is, to Å¿eparate cleverly from the part where they are Graffed, in great Storins of Wind: The Cleft is Å¿eldom, or never proper for thoÅ¿e kind of Å¿tocks, unleÅ¿s the Quince-Å¿tock be large enough to preÅ¿s the Graff cloÅ¿e, and even then they muÅ¿t be us'd but Å¿eldom.

Nota, That there are Å¿ome kind of Pears which are difficult to take upon Quince-Å¿tocks; for inÅ¿tance, Summer Musky Bon-Chretiens; and Portails; to which I add, laÅ¿tly, that Pear-Trees Graffed, have as it were that ComplaiÅ¿ance for one another, to Å¿erve each other Reciprocally for Å¿tocks for a change of Graffs: Yet, notwithÅ¿tanding, Å¿ome are peeviÅ¿h, and untoward in that CaÅ¿e; for Example, Thick-Å¿talk'd-Pears; Pears are Å¿ometimes Graffed upon Apple-Å¿tocks, either Wildlings, or Paradice, and upon White-Thorns, and Medlars, but commonly they are not laÅ¿ting, or elÅ¿e they pine: There is certainly a kind of Antipathy in their Saps, inÅ¿omuch that they cannot mix together, and can Å¿uffer no Commerce of Graffing.

The Å¿ame thing I have been Å¿aying of Pear-Wildlings, and Quince-Trees, in relation to the Graffs of Pear-Trees, which Å¿ucceed very well upon them, muÅ¿t be Å¿aid of Apple-Wildings, either grown from Trunks, or Kernels, or Suckers of the Roots of Old Apple-Trees, in Relation to the Apples that are Graffed upon them, with this difference only, which Å¿eems Å¿urprizing between the Quince, and Paradice-Å¿tocks, that the Paradice-Å¿tocks, being any thing large, are extraordinary good Graffed in the Cleft, and Å¿eldom Å¿ucceed Graffed with a Scutcheon; whereas it is the clean contrary with Quince-Å¿tocks.

Moreover, Apple-Wildings, whatever they be, and however Graffed, are fit to make High-Å¿tandards, but not in the leaÅ¿t fit for Dwarfs; and the quite contrary with Paradice-Å¿tocks; inÅ¿omuch, that Apple-Trees muÅ¿t never be Planted to remain Dwarfs, and take up little room, unleÅ¿s they be Graffed upon Paradice-Å¿tocks, theÅ¿e quickly bear Fruit, and Å¿hoot but little Wood; the others are a long while producing nothing but a vaÅ¿t quantity of Wood, which makes exceÅ¿Å¿ive large Trees, and are long before they bear Fruit: Apples Graffed upon Pear-Trees, or Quince, Å¿ucceed no better than the Pears that are ventur'd to be Graff'd upon Apple-Å¿tocks, or Paradice; altho' the Poet Å¿eems of a different Opinion, but I rather believe, that he uÅ¿es indifferently, for all that relates to Kernel-Fruits, the Terms of Pyrus, Pyrum, Pomus, Pomum.

Plum-Trees are neither Graffed in the Cleft, nor Budded, unleÅ¿s upon other Plum-Trees, InÅ¿ere daphne pyros, carpent tua poma nepotes. Virg. Georg. and that only upon a Å¿mall number of kinds, for InÅ¿tance, upon St. Julians, Black Damask, and little Cherry-Plum, &c. and Å¿eldom Å¿ucceed upon good kinds; for Example, upon Perdrigons, Apricock-Plums, St. Catherin's, &c. I have Å¿ometimes Graffed Å¿ome Plums in the Cleft upon large Almond Å¿tocks, which have done indifferent well; but where I Å¿ucceeded in one, I loÅ¿t a great many others, and therefore there is but little to be got in making thoÅ¿e kind of Trials.

Peaches, to Å¿ucceed well, muÅ¿t be Budded, and Å¿eldom Graffed in the Cleft, at leaÅ¿t in our Climes. Secondly, they muÅ¿t be Inoculated with the cloÅ¿e Eye, or Å¿hut Bud, and that in a proper SeaÅ¿on, as we have heretofore declar'd, either upon St. Julian Plums, or black Damask, or upon Apricock Trees already Graffed, or upon young Almond-Trees of that years growth; they Å¿eldom Å¿ucceed upon Stones of other Peach, or Apricock Trees; neither do Peaches Å¿ucceed better being Graffed upon the Principal kinds of Plums, than the Plum-Trees themÅ¿elves, as we have Å¿aid already; Peaches Budded in the Month of June, are more apt to deceive the Gard'ners hope, than to confirm it; for the Scutcheon either periÅ¿hes with Gum, without having Å¿hot, or often periÅ¿hes after having Å¿hot; or laÅ¿tly, as it commonly Shoots but weakly during that firÅ¿t Summer, it periÅ¿hes the following Winter by Cold and by Ice, therefore, they muÅ¿t Å¿eldom be Graffed, and that but caÅ¿ually, and upon Stocks, that otherwiÅ¿e would be of no uÅ¿e.

Among what is vulgarly call'd Cherries, we reckon MeriÅ¿es, or a Å¿mall Wild Cherry, both White and Black, White and Black Hearts, Early and Late Cherries, Griotes, Bigareaux CeriÅ¿iers de Pied, White Cherries.

All theÅ¿e kind of Cherries are Graffed except the Meriziers, or Å¿mall White bitter Cherry, which are not worth it, but then thoÅ¿e Meriziers, eÅ¿pecially the White ones, which grow
in the Fields, and in Vineyards from each others Suckers, are very good Stocks to Graff other Principal kinds upon; viz. HaÅ¿ty and Late Cherries, Hearts, Griotes, Bigarreaux, &c. Suckers which Spring from the Root of other Cherries, Produce pretty good Cherries, and Å¿erve to be Graffed upon, particularly with Early Cherries, which are a kind of Cherry of a Moderate Size, that are Å¿eldom Planted but in EÅ¿paliers, to produce Fruit betimes; they are moÅ¿t Valued for their EarlineÅ¿s, and are no longer minded when the fine Cherries which come Å¿oon after begin to appear; Early Cherries require no very Vigorous Stocks, as the MeriÅ¿iers do, which have a far greater DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition to Shoot abundance of VVood that to bear Fruit Speedily.
You may Graff Fig-Trees if you pleaÅ¿e, but as I have already Å¿aid in the TreatiÅ¿e of the Choice of Figs, there accrues but little Advantage by Graffing of them.

Azerolles are Budded, or Graffed in the Cleft, Particularly upon the VVhite-Thorn; they are likewiÅ¿e Graffed Å¿ome times upon Å¿mall Pear-VVildlings which Succeed pretty well, and Å¿ometimes upon Quince, and Graffed Pear-Trees, but the SucceÅ¿s is not very certain.

As for the Quince-Apple it is Å¿eldom Graffed, by reaÅ¿on that Quince-Trees Produce Fruit Å¿o eaÅ¿ily of themÅ¿elves, yet they may be Graffed upon one another; thus you may Graff Portugal-Quince-Trees upon French ones, you may likewiÅ¿e Graff them upon Pear-Trees, whether Graffed, or Wildlings.

Vines are only Graffed upon old Plants of other Vines, and only in the Cleft; they are Å¿horten'd on purpoÅ¿e for it, and when the Graff is made, the Place Å¿o Å¿horten'd muÅ¿t be cover'd with Earth, yet without covering the Twigs or Cyons that are Graffed, the Heat of the Sun, and Drought, would kill the Graff, if it were left expos'd to the Air like the Cleft-Graffs of other Fruit-Trees; there is this difference between the Cleft Graff of Vines, and that of other Fruit-Trees, that the Graff is plac'd indifferently in the middle, or on the Å¿ides of the Å¿horten'd Trunk, which cannot be done to other Fruit Trees Graffed in the Cleft, as we have obÅ¿erv'd heretofore.
Meddlar Trees are Graffed either upon other Meddlars, or upon VVhite-Thorn, or Pear-VVildlings, or Pears Trees already Graffed, or elÅ¿e upon Quince-Stocks.
Almond-Trees whether with hard or tender Nuts, grow moÅ¿t Commonly from Almonds put into the Ground, or Graffed upon one another.

argument.p: Of NurÅ¿eries and Seminaries.

div.p: IT is proper to begin this Chapter, by Å¿aying that our NurÅ¿eries require a good EaÅ¿ie Soil, or ground, well Till'd, having at leaÅ¿t two Foot and a half Depth; the Trees muÅ¿t be placed in rows at three Foot diÅ¿tance, according to the largeneÅ¿s of the Trees, and at a Foot and a half, two or three Foot diÅ¿tance from one another in the Å¿aid rows, Å¿till according to the proportion of the Sizes: Of all VVildlings Almonds are plac'd cloÅ¿eÅ¿t in the Rows. Tis eaÅ¿y to conclude, from what I have been Å¿aying in the foregoing Chapter, about all kinds of Fruits to be Graffed, what kind of Stocks are moÅ¿t proper to make NurÅ¿eries of all kind of Fruits.

FirÅ¿t, for Pears you muÅ¿t Plant VVildlings out of VVoods and ForeÅ¿ts, or VVildlings grown from Kernels, or Suckers Sprouted from the Roots of old Pear-Trees, or elÅ¿e Plant Quince-Trees, all which muÅ¿t be well Condition'd both as to the Roots and Stem.

Secondly, For the Apple-Tree Seminary; when you deÅ¿ign to have them High-Standards, you muÅ¿t Plant pretty large VVildlings, taken out of VVoods and ForreÅ¿ts, to Graff them in the Cleft, or Kernel VVildlings to Inoculate them, when they are about two Inches Circumference, and are to Å¿hoot up, in order to become High-Standards; and when you deÅ¿ign to make a Seminary of Dwarfs, you muÅ¿t Plant Paradice-Apple-Trees, at a Foot diÅ¿tance in the rows: And that, by reaÅ¿on that thoÅ¿e kind of little Apple-Trees Å¿hoot but few Roots, and ConÅ¿equently require but little Room.

Thirdly, To make a Seminary of Plum-Trees, you muÅ¿t only Plant the Suckers of certain Plum-Trees, viz, St. Julian, Black-Damask, the little Cherry-Plum, thoÅ¿e that are large enough to bear it, are Graffed in the Cleft, and the leÅ¿Å¿er with the Scutcheon.

Fourthly, Good Seminaries for Peaches, muÅ¿t conÅ¿iÅ¿t of St. Julian, and Black Damask Plum-Trees, which muÅ¿t be Inoculated or Budded in the Months of July or AuguÅ¿t, or young Almond-Trees, that is, Almond-Trees grown from an Almond Planted
in good Grounds in the VVinter time, grown about September following half an Inch thick, to be Budded at that time: Old Almond-Trees of two or three Years Å¿tanding are hot proper to be Graffed.

Fifthly, to make NurÅ¿eries of red Stone-fruit, viz. Cherries, Griottes, Bigarreaux; no Stocks are Å¿o proper as MeriÅ¿iers, which is a Å¿mall wild bitter Cherry, eÅ¿pecially Å¿uch as beat whitiÅ¿h ones; the Sap of the black ones is commonly Å¿o bitter, that the Graffs of good Cherries do not take upon them, or always pine away.
Suckers which Å¿pring from the Roots of other Cherries may Å¿erve to Graff good Cherries upon, but they are moÅ¿t proper to be Graffed with early Cherries.

Sixthly, Fig-Tree Seminaries are Planted with Suckers Å¿prouted from the Foot of Old Fig-Trees, or with Branches of two years Å¿tanding laid into the Ground, and notch'd in that part which is moÅ¿t bent, and laid into that Ground.
Seventhly, for the NurÅ¿ery of Azeroles, you muÅ¿t only Plant White-Thorn, and Å¿ome few Quince-Å¿tocks.
Eighthly, no NurÅ¿eries are made for Vines, they are Å¿eldom Graffed otherwiÅ¿e than upon Old Plants, ready Planted.

Finally, for Medlars, People Å¿eldom make any particular NurÅ¿eries, the leaÅ¿t quantity of them is Å¿ufficient, a dozen Wildlings of that kind, or White-Thorn, or Quince-Å¿tocks; are Å¿ufficient to provide for the LargeÅ¿t Gardens.

Before I proceed to the Sixth Part, I think it will not be altogether improper to give my Opinion about the different kinds of Lattices, to the end that People may determine at firÅ¿t to pitch upon that which I value moÅ¿t, and indeed, which is the moÅ¿t Noble, and moÅ¿t Convenient.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.

argument.p: Of the different manners of Lattices us'd to PalliÅ¿ade.

div.p: FRom the very Moment we reÅ¿olve to EncloÅ¿e our Garden with Walls, we certainly deÅ¿ign to have Fruit againÅ¿t them, and conÅ¿equently muÅ¿t prepare whatever is neceÅ¿Å¿ary Pole Lattices Å¿et up againÅ¿t Walls, much us'd in France. to PalliÅ¿ade the Trees that are to be Planted there, neatly, and Conveniently.

The FirÅ¿t ObÅ¿ervation I have made in Relation thereto, is, that one cannot be too careful in having the Walls well Pargetted, or PlaiÅ¿tred over when it can be done Conveniently; in order to Å¿top all the holes from Rats, Snails, Earwigs, and other Vermin which deÅ¿troy the Fruits, and commonly attack the FaireÅ¿t, and beÅ¿t, and thereby continually Plague the Curious.

When the Walls are Pargetted with PlaiÅ¿ter, we have the Convenience to Ply, or PalliÅ¿ade the Branches with Nails, and Shreads of Sheep's-Skin, or Shamoy, or LiÅ¿ts of Cloath, both about half a finger broad, and a finger long againÅ¿t the Å¿aid Walls, putting the Stays about the Branch, and fixing it upwards with a Nail, we thus form the Figure of our Trees. This manner of PalliÅ¿ading is very agreeable, but tedious; thoÅ¿e Shreads may laÅ¿t a year or two, the only thing that can be Å¿aid againÅ¿t it is, that Å¿ometimes Earwigs Å¿helter in them in the day time, and come out at Night, to indammage the Trees.

ThoÅ¿e who are not willing to uÅ¿e thoÅ¿e Shreads, have try'd three or four ways of PalliÅ¿ading, Å¿ome for all manner of Walls, but eÅ¿pecially for Å¿uch as are made of Earth, and Hey, as they do in BeauÅ¿Å¿e, and Normandy; Å¿ome fix Spikes from Å¿pace to Å¿pace into the Wall, Å¿ticking out about two Inches, to faÅ¿ten Laths, Poles, Perches, or Switches upon them: Others make a Lattice of Poles, Å¿upported by the Bones of HorÅ¿es, or Oxen, fix'd into the Wall, to which they faÅ¿ten the Branches of their Trees: Others have abundance of Sheeps feet Bones fix'd into their Walls at a Å¿mall diÅ¿tance, in a Å¿traight Line, and Å¿o bind every Branch of their Tree to one of the Å¿aid Feet; Å¿ome make a Lattice of narrow Laths nail'd a croÅ¿s one another checker-wiÅ¿e, every Å¿quare conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of about twelve Inches; and this Lattice being made by whole, or half Fathoms, Å¿eparate, they fix them to the Walls with Nails, or Hooks, that are driven into the joynts of the Stones; it is a pretty good Expedient, but neither Gentile, nor HandÅ¿om.

Some who yet covet cheapneÅ¿s beyond theÅ¿e, make a Lattice of BraÅ¿s or Iron Wire, of a moderate Å¿ize, Å¿upported by flat-headed Nails fix'd into the Walls. Others have been Å¿atisfy'd with barely fixing Å¿treight Lines of this Wire, either longwiÅ¿e, or croÅ¿swiÅ¿e: TheÅ¿e two laÅ¿t Methods are pretty neat, but not very good; both by reaÅ¿on that they are too weak, inÅ¿omuch that the thick Branches, that Å¿ometimes require to be forc'd, either break, ofâª Å¿tretch them; and that this Wire is apt to wound and Å¿cratch the young, and conÅ¿equently tender Branches, which occaÅ¿ions Gum to grow upon them, which deÅ¿troys them; beÅ¿ides, thoÅ¿e young Shoots Å¿lip too eaÅ¿ily behind thoÅ¿e Wires, from whence it is not eaÅ¿ie to remove them, without Å¿poiling of them.

The beÅ¿t manner of all, the moÅ¿t Convenient, and moÅ¿t Noble, is a Lattice of quarter Wood, or Heart of Oak; every Pole or Lath about an Inch Å¿quare, and as much as can be without knobs, they muÅ¿t be very well plain'd, and notch'd in Å¿uch places as require it; thoÅ¿e that are not plain'd, are courÅ¿e, and ugly. I confeÅ¿s that this Lattice is chargeable at firÅ¿t, but then it is more laÅ¿ting, and requires leÅ¿s mending: The Å¿quare fathom of that Lattice amounts conÅ¿tantly to 25, 26, 27, and 28 Pence, for the Wood, Making, Wire and all.

In order to make this Lattice as it Å¿hould be, you muÅ¿t have Iron Hooks made on purpoÅ¿e, they muÅ¿t be Å¿quare, about a quarter of an Inch thick, and half a Foot long; beÅ¿ides, the end which turns upwards in a Å¿treight Angle, which muÅ¿t be above an Inch and a half long, the end which enters into the Wall, muÅ¿t be forked, to hold the faÅ¿ter into the Wall, into which it muÅ¿t enter about four Inches deep, two Inches on the outÅ¿ide will Å¿uffice.

ThoÅ¿e Hooks coÅ¿t commonly about a Penny a piece, they muÅ¿t be plac'd at three foot diÅ¿tance, and always Checker-wiÅ¿e, beginning the firÅ¿t Row within a foot of the Å¿urface of the Ground, continuing it to the top of the Wall; the rows of thoÅ¿e Hooks muÅ¿t lie in a Å¿treight Line, and parallel to one another; that is all I have to Å¿ay about the Hooks.

As to the Poles, or Laths, you may buye them in Shops, of different lengths, Viz. Of Four Foot and a half, of Six, Seven, Eight, or Nine; Å¿ome are made of twelve Foot, but Å¿eldom, becauÅ¿e it is too difficult to Å¿lit Å¿uch long pieces of Wood; you may take them of what length you pleaÅ¿e, according to the heighth of your Walls; they are Sold in Bundles, thoÅ¿e of Four Foot and a half, contain Forty, and CoÅ¿t Eleven Pence, thoÅ¿e of Six, coÅ¿t Twelve Pence, and contain Five and Twenty; thoÅ¿e of Seven, Eight, and Nine; likewiÅ¿e contain Twenty Five, and coÅ¿t Å¿omewhat more.

The beÅ¿t and moÅ¿t uÅ¿eful way is to make thoÅ¿e that Å¿tand upwards all of a piece, when you can, but yet you may joyn two or three, Å¿uch as you can get, and they are much cheaper; they muÅ¿t be joyn'd together neatly, plaining and proportioning the Extremities that are to be Marry'd together exactly, tying them afterwards very cloÅ¿e with Wire; to which end, you muÅ¿t uÅ¿e Å¿mall Pinchers made on purpoÅ¿e, with which you may pull the Wire towards you, and turn and wind it until the Ligature be Å¿trong enough, then break the end cloÅ¿e to the knot, and faÅ¿ten the Å¿aid knot againÅ¿t the Laths, leÅ¿t it Å¿hould prejudice the Gard'ner, or Branch.

In chuÅ¿ing the Poles, or Laths, take the Å¿treighteÅ¿t, and weakeÅ¿t, to Å¿erve in a Å¿treight Line, by reaÅ¿on that they always appear on the outÅ¿ide, placing the Butt-end downwards; the Å¿trongeÅ¿t muÅ¿t be imploy'd croÅ¿swiÅ¿e to Å¿upport the Work; the Squares of the Lattice muÅ¿t be regularly about 7 or 8 Inches, they do not look well of ten or twelve Inches, and in my Opinion, they are too little of 5 or 6 Inches for EÅ¿paliers; but they may be imploy'd for thoÅ¿e kind of Arbors, that are of late in faÅ¿hion. A good Maker of Lattice Å¿hould never work without a regulated meaÅ¿ure in hand for his Checkers, meaÅ¿uring every one of them carefully; he muÅ¿t leave an Inch between the Laths, and the Wall, and when the Hooks are too Å¿hort, he muÅ¿t make uÅ¿e of a Wooden Wedge, and hold it between the Laths, and the Wall, in order to have more room to paÅ¿s his Wire.
The Lattice muÅ¿t not only appear neatly made to the Eye, it muÅ¿t alÅ¿o be Å¿olid, which is eaÅ¿ily known by Å¿haking one of the Laths; for it is not as it Å¿hould be unleÅ¿s it reÅ¿iÅ¿ts the hand.

I muÅ¿t not forget to tell you, that you muÅ¿t uÅ¿e but one Å¿traight Lath in Corners, to faÅ¿ten the two Lattices of two Walls that joyn, two would look clumÅ¿ily, the one on one Å¿ide of a Wall, the other, on the other.
The laÅ¿t Perfection of our Lattice conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in being painted firÅ¿t with White, and when that is dry, with a fine Mountain Green.

We do not only make Lattice frames for Walls, we likewiÅ¿e make them Å¿ometimes for a kind of Counter-EÅ¿palier, or Pole-Hedges, which Lattice frames may be made four, five, or Å¿ix foot high, according as you pleaÅ¿e: In Order to its being Å¿olid, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Å¿tick
Oaken Spikes into the Ground, at five or Å¿ix foot diÅ¿tance from one another, about four Inches Å¿quare, driving them about a foot deep into the ground, the outward Extremity being pointed, to laÅ¿t the longer, for if it were Å¿quare, the Rain would Rot it the Å¿ooner; as for the Å¿ize, and the place to faÅ¿ten the Wire, the Checkers muÅ¿t be like thoÅ¿e of the EÅ¿paliers, with this only difference; that in Pole-Hedges, the Poles or Laths muÅ¿t be fix'd with Nails into the Body of the Spikes, which muÅ¿t be notch'd in order thereunto.

div.head: OF FRUIT-GARDENING AND Kitchen-Gardens. VOL. II. PART VI.
Of the Culture of Kitchen-Gardens.
div.p: THere's nothing Å¿eems leÅ¿s unknown than the Art of Cultivating Kitchen-Gardens. The Art of Cultivating Kitchen-Gardens and Pot-Herbs, &c. Ancient and UniverÅ¿al. It has been univerÅ¿ally practiÅ¿ed in all Ages, and almoÅ¿t in all Climates of the World, and the care to bring up and multiply in Å¿elect places, Å¿ome Herbs and Legumes, or Edible Plants, which Nature had produced promiÅ¿cuouÅ¿ly in the midÅ¿t of the wild Fields, and which the firÅ¿t Men uÅ¿ed for their only Food, has been, and Å¿till continues to be the Occupation of a great number of all Å¿orts of People. And indeed, how many do we Å¿ee, that being weary and tired, either with the fatigues of War, or the drudgery of publick Employments, or with the idleneÅ¿s of a City or Court Life, have choÅ¿en to retreat into the Country, to go (as our Proverb Beatus ille qui precul negotits, ãâã priÅ¿ca Gens Mortaliam, paterna rura bebus exercet Å¿uis, &c. Hor. Fp d. 2. Happy the Man from toilÅ¿om cares Å¿et free, Who does regain Man's ancient Liberty; Plowing his Ground with Oxen of his own. By Parents l â¢ fe, fr â¢ e from uÅ¿urious Loan. Å¿ays) and plant Cabbages, and how many others are there, that take an extream pleaÅ¿ure in entertaining their Friends with Herbs and Sallets out of their own Gardens, Å¿tiffly maintaining, that they taÅ¿te much better than thoÅ¿e bought in the Markets, and of common Gard'ners? And therefore Å¿ince Kitchen-Gardens have been planted in all times, have I not Å¿ome reaÅ¿on to fear, it may appear at firÅ¿t, either ridiculous or impertinent for me to Å¿ubjoyn here a particular TreatiÅ¿e of that Å¿ort of Gardens.

I anÅ¿wer, that I will not deny but that almoÅ¿t as Å¿oon as there were Men upon the Earth, they had Å¿ome kind of Kitchen-Gardens, and that in proceÅ¿s of time, the curioÅ¿ity of their Cultivation has been extreamly augmented, and has made mighty advances, and I am far from pretending, that the firÅ¿t Å¿owing of Sallets, and Roots, and planting of Cabbages, and Artichokes, and rearing of Cucumbers, Melons, &c. begun in our days. No, I know well enough, that our AnceÅ¿tours underÅ¿tood what belonged to the Culture of all thoÅ¿e plants, and that the moÅ¿t part of the very Country-people, and of the meaner Å¿ort of the inhabitants
of Cities, have Å¿ome Tincture of it; nay, and I will ingenuouÅ¿ly confeÅ¿s, that the knowledge I have my Å¿elf in the management of Kitchen-Gardens, was chiefly attained by my often converÅ¿ing with what we vulgarly call, able Market-Gard'ners. But I muÅ¿t add withall that as the Kitchen-Garden taken in a general Å¿ence, comprehends the Culture of a great number of different Å¿orts of Plants, Å¿o there is hardly any Gard'ner that has made it his BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s, to be skilful in cultivating generally all the Å¿orts of them; it having ordinarily hapned, that one has applyed himÅ¿elf to the care and improvement of one particular part of this culture, which he has performed exactly well, neglecting the reÅ¿t, whilÅ¿t another has employed his induÅ¿try, no leÅ¿s particularly in that which his Neighbour had neglected, and Å¿ucceeded in it, as much Å¿ighting on his Å¿ide, that other part in which the Å¿ame Neighbour had Å¿o proÅ¿perouÅ¿ly laboured; the different appetites of Men, but more eÅ¿pecially, the different goodneÅ¿s of Soils and Climates, having been the true cauÅ¿es of thoÅ¿e different affectations in the Cultivation of Pot or Kitchen-Plants.

Now it being undoubtedly neceÅ¿Å¿ary for a Gentleman's Gard'ner to be able to perform with equal skill and happineÅ¿s, all the parts of Culture belonging to a Kitchen-Garden, that Å¿o he alone may be in a condition to furniÅ¿h his MaÅ¿ter with all the variety that a good Kitchen-Garden can produce, without wanting at leaÅ¿t any of thoÅ¿e productions that are of moÅ¿t importance, and it being no leÅ¿s expedient too for the Gentleman himÅ¿elf to know exactly what he may expect from his Gard'ner every Month in the Year, and what is the particular work that is to be done in every SeaÅ¿on; I have therefore taken care to omit nothing that is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for either of them to be informed in, that the one may be able to give content by knowing how perfectly well to diÅ¿charge his Duty, and the other be contented, when he knows he has Å¿ufficient ReaÅ¿on to be Å¿o. In order to which, by way of anÅ¿wer to thoÅ¿e, that may ask me what I pretend to Å¿ay that is new, upon a Subject which I my Å¿elf confeÅ¿s to be Å¿o very well known,

I Å¿hall firÅ¿t repeat the Å¿ame thing which I have already laid down, and inculcated, as my intention in all the parts of this Work, viz. That I write not here for thoÅ¿e which are actually Gard'ners by ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion, and that are skillful in it, but for the inÅ¿truction, as well of thoÅ¿e that have a mind to become Å¿o, as for Gentlemen that are curious in Gard'ning, being well aÅ¿Å¿ured there are a great many of theÅ¿e Latter, though ignorant in the particulars of this Science, that eÅ¿teem it not unworthy of their CurioÅ¿ity, and are fully perÅ¿waded it is capable of giving them PleaÅ¿ure as well as Profit, and being no leÅ¿s certain, that I my Å¿elf found a great deal in purÅ¿uing the acquiÅ¿ition of thoÅ¿e lights I have attained in it, therefore I cannot but think, it will be Å¿weet and gratefull to them to enjoy without Pains, the Fruits of the Å¿tudy I have made therein, and to find out an exact and faithful Collection of all that concerns this matter.

In the Å¿econd Place, I Å¿hall anÅ¿wer, that 'tis my deÅ¿ign to cut out a Å¿horter way than the common Roads, for thoÅ¿e young PerÅ¿ons who though very deÅ¿irous of learning the Art of Gard'ning, yet would willingly be inÅ¿tructed by Å¿ome other means than by bare Å¿eeing others Practice, it being a tedious and uncertain way, and had rather be taught by Å¿tated Rules and Principles, which, I think may be done in a little time, and by very Å¿hort and eaÅ¿ie methods.

Thirdly, I reply, that I Å¿hall Å¿et down here Å¿ome particular experiments which I my Å¿elf have made with SucceÅ¿s, and which Å¿eem to me never to have been made before, and I think I may add, that they have been too well approved, not to merit to be divulged.

LaÅ¿tly, I anÅ¿wer, that my intention is to give Å¿uch Directions, that the place deÅ¿igned for a Kitchen-Garden may be Å¿o well ordered in all its parts, that not only each part may perform its duty in reÅ¿pect of its Productions but by the accurate Symmetry and Proportion obÅ¿erv'd in modelling of the whole, it may be in a Condition to allure the Spectators, and at all times to delight the Eyes of the Curious.

And accordingly for theÅ¿e ReaÅ¿ons, I purpoÅ¿e here to follow exactly the Model and Platform I have already delineated and explained at the beginning of theÅ¿e TreatiÅ¿es of Gard'ning, conformably to which, I Å¿hall Å¿et down,

FirÅ¿t, every thing that generally Å¿peaking, Å¿hould be in all Å¿orts of good and wellfurniÅ¿ht Kitchen-Gardens, to which I Å¿hall add a DeÅ¿cription of the Seeds and other things which Å¿erve for the Production and Multiplication of every particular Plant.

In the Å¿econd place, I Å¿hall Å¿pecifie not only all the things that may be gathered out of a Kitchen-Garden every Month of the Year, but alÅ¿o what work Gard'ners are to do in every one of thoÅ¿e Months, and to thoÅ¿e two heads I will joyn another, viz. a particular account of what Å¿hould at all times be found in any Kitchen-Garden whatÅ¿oever, that
Å¿o we may be able to judge when there is any thing wanting in it, and when not.

Thirdly, I will explain what Å¿ort of Earth or Soil, and what Å¿ort of Culture are moÅ¿t proper for each Å¿ort of plants, to make them excellent; and becauÅ¿e Å¿ome of them are Å¿own to remain always in the Å¿ame place, and Å¿ome, only to be tranÅ¿planted elÅ¿ewhere, and Å¿ome again are propagated without Seed; I will give Directions at the Å¿ame time how to order all of them, as well in reÅ¿pect to the SeaÅ¿ons in which they are to be Å¿own or planted, as the manner of their Propagation.

Fourthly, I will Å¿hew how long each Å¿ort may profitably occupy its place, and which of them muÅ¿t be laid up in Å¿tore for our Winter ProviÅ¿ion, and which may by the help of InduÅ¿try be produced in Å¿pite of the FroÅ¿ts.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Shews what a good Kitchen-Garden may yield us every Month in the Year, and how a Gard'ner may and ought to employ himÅ¿elf there in every one of thoÅ¿e Months.

div.p: THe Experience of hot Countries Å¿ufficiently convinces us, that the Earth taken in general, is capable at all SeaÅ¿ons, to produce all manner of things, without any extraordinary aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Art, becauÅ¿e in thoÅ¿e parts, there is no SeaÅ¿on in the Year, in which Å¿he is not teeming, but by a contrary experience we find, that our Climate is too cold to afford us any Å¿uch fertility; and yet becauÅ¿e there are few days, in which a Man has not occaÅ¿ion to make up a part of his nouriÅ¿hment and Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿tance with Å¿omething of the growth of his Garden; It concerns the induÅ¿trious Gard'ners Å¿o to manage it, that it may not only produce enough amply to Å¿uffice for our daily uÅ¿e, during the five or Å¿ix Months in which the Earth acts at her EaÅ¿e, by the favour of the Sun's Neighbourhood, but alÅ¿o furniÅ¿h us at the Å¿ame time, a Å¿ufficient ProviÅ¿ion for thoÅ¿e five or Å¿ix Months in which Å¿he is Å¿uÅ¿pended from her ordinary functions.

Now among the Barren and leÅ¿s happy Months that commonly make the greateÅ¿t oppoÅ¿ition to our Culture, are reckoned the laÅ¿t fifteen days of November, all December, and January, and the firÅ¿t fifteen days of February; the violence of the FroÅ¿ts which in that SeaÅ¿on uÅ¿e to harden and cool the Earth, and the abundance of Snow with which it is then wont to be covered, putting Å¿uch a perfect Å¿top to all Vegetative Operations, that the moÅ¿t fertile Soil becomes at that time altogether like that which never was bleÅ¿Å¿ed with that accompliÅ¿hment.
But notwithÅ¿tanding all thoÅ¿e hindrances, there is Å¿till work enough to be done in Winter, to keep us from being quite idle, and a great deal of AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance too to be drawn from our Gardens, even in that SeaÅ¿on, that we may not labour under too great a Å¿carcity of their Productions; and therefore I have determined to give you a particular account of every one of thoÅ¿e works, and of every one of thoÅ¿e Commodities which our Gardens will afford us, during every one of the twelve Months of the Year, and Å¿hall begin with that which, becauÅ¿e it paÅ¿Å¿es for the firÅ¿t, and opens and begins the Year, Å¿eems to me beÅ¿t to deÅ¿erve the preference.

div.head: Works which may be done in a Kitchen-Garden, in the Month of January.
div.p: TO Prune all Å¿orts of Trees, whether Dwarfs or Wall-Trees, to prepare Å¿ome of them to plant as Å¿oon as ever the Ground Å¿hall be open after the hard FroÅ¿ts, and the melting of the Snow that covered it.

To make Trenches, to plant Trees, to dig Molds to amend them; to dig round the Feet, either of Trees over Luxuriant, to cut off their thick Roots, and by that means to make them fructifie, or of Å¿uch as are infirm, to trim and redreÅ¿s them.

To make Hot Beds, to Å¿ow forward Cowcumbers, and Sallets in, whether in Rows or little Furrows, or under Bells. To make Screens to cover thoÅ¿e Seeds in caÅ¿e of need: The firÅ¿t hot Beds for Cowcumbers, as alÅ¿o for Musk-melons, are uÅ¿ually made at the very beginning of the Month, and at the Å¿ame time we may make hot Beds for MuÅ¿hrooms.
To heat or force AÅ¿paragus.
To heat Beds of Sorrel, Patience, Borage, &c.
To raiÅ¿e on hot Beds, Jacinths, NarciÅ¿Å¿us's of ConÅ¿tantinople, and Å¿ome Tulips, &c.
To make Trails, TrelliÅ¿ces, or Frames for Wall-trees.
To pull down the hot Beds of the laÅ¿t Year, and to take the rotten Dung that compoÅ¿ed them, and lay it upon thoÅ¿e Grounds we would amend, or Meliorate.
To lay apart Å¿ome Molds to have them at Hand, to prepare for the hot Beds, and we may alÅ¿o clear and cleanÅ¿e the places of the Hot beds, in order to the making of new ones.
To tie up with Bands of Straw, the tops of the Leaves of Long Lettuce, which have not Cabbaged, to make them Cabbage, or at leaÅ¿t to whiten them, when they are grown big enough for it.
To raiÅ¿e Å¿ome Strawberries upon hot Beds, to have Å¿ome ripe in the Months of April and May.
To dung Figg-trees, in order to have early Figs.
And in fine, to advance the doing by little and little, all that the Spring SeaÅ¿on is wont to do with an extraordinary Expedition.

To plant Trees in Baskets, to Pot, and CaÅ¿e Figg-trees, to lay Vine and Fig-tree Branches, to clear your Trees of MoÅ¿s, if troubled with it, which is done beÅ¿t in rainy weather, with the back of a Knife, or Å¿ome Å¿uch inÅ¿trument.

But it would be to little PurpoÅ¿e to know what to do, without being informed how to do it, and therefore for your inÅ¿truction in pruning, I referr you to my fourth Book, which treating throughly of that Subject, may excuÅ¿e me from Å¿peaking any more of it here.

And as to the way of making hot Beds, you muÅ¿t firÅ¿t know, they are to be made only with Long HorÅ¿e-Dung, or Mule-Dung, which is to be either all New, or mixed with a third part at moÅ¿t of Old, provided it be dry, and not rotten, for that which is rotten, is not at all proper for making hot Beds, no more than the Dung of Oxen, Cows, Hogs, &c. as well, becauÅ¿e it has little or no heat, as becauÅ¿e ordinarily thoÅ¿e kinds of rotten Dung are accompanied with an unpleaÅ¿ing Å¿mell that infects the Plants raiÅ¿ed upon Å¿uch Beds, and gives them an ugly TaÅ¿te.
By New Long Dung, is to be underÅ¿tood, that which is taken from under the HorÅ¿es, and has Å¿erved them for Litter but one Night or two at moÅ¿t.

By Long old Dung, is meant that which has been piled up ever Å¿ince it was new, in a dry place where it has lain all Summer, to be ready to be uÅ¿ed, either to make Coverings for Fig-trees, Artichoaks, Endive, &c. againÅ¿t the Winter Cold, or to make hot Beds after the ordinary manner, which is thus performed.

After we have mark'd and proportioned out the place where the Bed is to be, and mark'd out likewiÅ¿e with a Cord, or with Stakes, of what breadth it muÅ¿t be, there muÅ¿t be brought a Rank of Baskets full of Long Dung, one at the tail of the other, beginning the Rank or Row where the Bed is to end; which done, the Gard'ner begins to work where the Rank of Baskets ends, that Å¿o the Dung not being intangled with any thing lying upon it, may more eaÅ¿ily and handÅ¿omly be wrought into the Bed. Then the Gard'ner takes up this Dung with a Fork, and if he be any thing handy, places it Å¿o neatly and tightly in laying every layer of his Bed, that all the Å¿traw ends of the Dung, are turned inwards, and what remains, Å¿erves to make a kind of back or fence on the out-Å¿ide. The firÅ¿t layer being thus compleated exactly to the breadth that is marked out, which is commonly of about four foot, and to Å¿uch a length as is thought fit, the Gard'ner proceeds to lay the Å¿econd, third, &c. beating them with the back of his Fork, or elÅ¿e treading them with his Feet, to Å¿ee if there be any defect, becauÅ¿e the Bed muÅ¿t be equally Å¿tuft every where, Å¿o that no one part may be leÅ¿s Å¿trong of Dung than another, which being done, he continues it to the deÅ¿igned length, proportioning it Å¿till by Layers, till the Bed reach the length, breadth, and heighth it Å¿hould have, which heighth is of between two and three foot when 'tis firÅ¿t made, and Å¿inks a full foot lower when it is Å¿etled.

Now as to the intention of theÅ¿e Hot Beds, Å¿ome of them are deÅ¿igned for the raiÅ¿ing, or forwarding of Å¿ome plants which our Climate is not capable naturally of producing in the naked Ground, as for example, for the raiÅ¿ing of RadiÅ¿hes, little Sallets, Straw-berries, Cucumbers, Musk-Melons, &c. and the better to compaÅ¿s thoÅ¿e ends, we make Hot Beds during the Months of November, December, January, February, March and April. TheÅ¿e Beds muÅ¿t be covered over with a certain quantity of Å¿mall fine mold, as we Å¿hall afterward Direct, and muÅ¿t have heat enough to communicate to that mold, and to the plants that are nouriÅ¿hed by it; And therefore thoÅ¿e Hot Beds that are an Invention of Gard'ners againÅ¿t the Cold, which is the cruel Enemy of Vegetation, muÅ¿t be well made.
