In the Å¿econd place, there are other Beds which are to Å¿erve for MuÅ¿hrooms, in all the Å¿eaÅ¿ons of the Year, and Å¿uch may be made every Month, though they act not till about three Months after they are made; and that is, when all their great heat being quite Å¿pent, they are grown mouldy within; this Å¿ort of Beds are made in a new and Å¿andy Ground, in which is firÅ¿t made a Trench of about Å¿ix Inches deep, then we cover them with a layer of about two or three Inches thick of the Å¿ame Earth; they are raiÅ¿ed in the form of an AÅ¿Å¿es back, and over the covering of Earth, we lay another of five or Å¿ix Inches thick of Long Dry Dung, which Å¿erves in Winter, to Å¿helter the MuÅ¿hrooms from the FroÅ¿t, which deÅ¿troys them: and in Summer, from the great heat that broils them, and likewiÅ¿e to prevent the miÅ¿chievous effects of the Å¿ame exceÅ¿Å¿ive heat, we further take care gently to water theÅ¿e MuÅ¿hroom Beds twice or thrice a week.

As for the breadth of Hot Beds, it Å¿hould be in all Å¿orts of them, of about four foot, and their heighth muÅ¿t be of between two and three when they are firÅ¿t made, becauÅ¿e they Å¿ink afterwards a full foot, when once the great heat of the Bed is paÅ¿t; As for the length that is to be regulated by the quantity of Dung we have to make them with, Å¿o that according to that, we make them of Å¿everal lengths; But in heighth and breadth, all Beds Å¿hould be as near as may be, alike proportioned.

The difference which there is in other reÅ¿pects, between Hot Beds that are to produce plants by their heat, and thoÅ¿e which are deÅ¿igned for MuÅ¿hrooms, conÅ¿iÅ¿ts firÅ¿t in that thoÅ¿e of the firÅ¿t Å¿ort need not be Å¿unk down within the Earth like the others, which are uÅ¿ually Å¿unk about half a foot, unleÅ¿s they be deÅ¿igned for Å¿uch Beds as we call Deaf Beds, that is to Å¿ay, Beds Å¿unk Å¿o over Head and Ears into the Earth, that when filled up, they exceed not the Å¿uperficies of the reÅ¿t of the Ground about them, in height. In the Å¿econd place, this difference conÅ¿iÅ¿ts, in that thoÅ¿e of the firÅ¿t Å¿ort muÅ¿t be flat and even above, whereas theÅ¿e others muÅ¿t be raiÅ¿ed in form of an AÅ¿Å¿es Back.

LaÅ¿tly, it conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in that thoÅ¿e of the firÅ¿t Å¿ort muÅ¿t be Loaden with a pretty good quantity of very Å¿mall mold, as Å¿oon as they are made, whereas there muÅ¿t be but a very little mold laid upon the others; That mold by its weight, makes the Beds heat, and Å¿ettle the Å¿ooner. We lay upon them Å¿ometimes more, and Å¿ometimes leÅ¿s mold; as for Example, we throw on to the quantity of Å¿ix or Å¿even Inches thick, if it be to Å¿ow ordinary plants in, as Sallets, or Musk Melons, or Cucumbers, or to plant Cabbage Lettuce, and AÅ¿paragus to be advanced by heat; and to the depth of a foot, if we be to Å¿ow RadiÅ¿hes, and to replant Sorrel, and Musk Melons, and pots of Straw-berries, &c.

But before we Å¿ow or replant any thing whatÅ¿oever upon any new made Hot Beds, the firÅ¿t precaution we muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve, is, to Å¿tay Å¿ix or Å¿even days, and Å¿ometimes ten or twelve, to give the Bed time firÅ¿t to heat, and afterwards to give time to that heat which is very violent, to abate conÅ¿iderably; This abatement appears when the whole Bed is Å¿unk, and when thruÅ¿ting down our hand into the mold, we perceive in it but a moderate heat. Then it is we are to begin handÅ¿omly to Å¿hape out and adjuÅ¿t the mold, for which purpoÅ¿e the Gard'ner, makes uÅ¿e of a board of a foot broad, which he places upon the Å¿ides of the Bed about two Inches from the Edge, and joining cloÅ¿e to the mold, and having thus placed it, he endeavours to keep it firm and tight, as well with his left hand and Knee, as with the Å¿trength of his whole Body, and then with his right hand, he begins at one end, to preÅ¿s down the mold againÅ¿t the board, Å¿o hard, till he bring it to Å¿o firm a conÅ¿iÅ¿tence, that how light and looÅ¿e Å¿oever it were before of its own Nature, yet it may be able to keep up it Å¿elf alone, when the board is taken away, as well as if it were a Å¿olid body. When the mold is thus adjuÅ¿ted to the whole length of the board, then he removes the board to another place, and Å¿o continues till he has performed the Å¿ame operation on all Å¿ides of the Bed. And if the board be a little longer, and conÅ¿equently a little more unwieldy than ordinary, then there muÅ¿t two or three perÅ¿ons join together to work in the Å¿ame manner, and at the Å¿ame time, to adjuÅ¿t this mold; or if the Gard'ner be all alone, he muÅ¿t keep the board tight with Å¿ome Pins, faÅ¿tned in the Å¿ides of the Dung Bed already adjuÅ¿ted; And when the thing is done, the mold Å¿hould have at leaÅ¿t a full half foot extent leÅ¿s on every Å¿ide, than the lower part of the Bed, and in its oblong Å¿quare figure, appear as even as if it were a Bed formed on the plain Ground; After which, the Beds are to be employed for thoÅ¿e occaÅ¿ions that firÅ¿t obliged us to make them. All things in them would either periÅ¿h, or be much endamaged, if we Å¿owed or planted in them Å¿ooner, or if we Å¿hould delay our doing it any longer. The heat of the Bed, may laÅ¿t in a condition to be able to perform well its effects for about ten or twelve days after it is Å¿own or planted; but when that time is paÅ¿t, if we perceive the Bed to be too much cooled, we muÅ¿t renew the heat with Å¿ome good new long dung, or freÅ¿h warm litter applied round about it, both to recruit the heat, and to maintain it afterwards in that good temper in which it Å¿hould be, and in which it was before, when we begun to Å¿ow and plant there; Å¿o that the plants inÅ¿tead of waÅ¿ting away or periÅ¿hing there, may increaÅ¿e and thrive viÅ¿ibly as they Å¿hould do. It is not Å¿o very needful to tell you, that when a man has two Beds next one another, one recruiting of heat will Å¿erve for them both, becauÅ¿e there's no body but knows it, but it is good to know, that this recruiting of heat between two Beds, Å¿hould not be by a great deal Å¿o Å¿trong as when there is but one; for the ordinary Interval or Å¿pace left between two Beds for the path, being about the breadth of one full foot, a little Dung will Å¿uffice to fill it up, and that new heat is reciprocally maintained in its vigour by the Neighbour-hood of the two Beds, that border on each Å¿ide upon it; But when there is but one Bed, our addition of Dung for a new heat, muÅ¿t be at leaÅ¿t two foot broad, all along the whole length of the Bed, and to its full height, and many times it muÅ¿t be higher than that.

When we are to renew the heat, it is not always neceÅ¿Å¿ary to make an application of new Dung, it being many times Å¿ufficient to Å¿tir that the bottom upwards, which we laÅ¿t applied, and which needs it, provided it be not too much rotted, which Å¿tirring of it is enough to renew the heat for eight or ten days longer; and there is no need of applying new Dung but when by the rotting of all the laÅ¿t, or of at leaÅ¿t a good part of it, we find it to be no longer fit to yield that heat which is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for thoÅ¿e plants that are raiÅ¿ed on Hot Beds.

If they be AÅ¿paragus, or Straw-berries which we have taken out of their Cold Beds, and replanted in Hot ones, and there be any apprehenÅ¿ion of the Cold, we muÅ¿t carefully cover them with GlaÅ¿s Bells, or ChaÅ¿Å¿es or GlaÅ¿ed Frames; and to hinder the FroÅ¿t from penetrating even them, and Å¿poiling what is underneath them, we uÅ¿e beÅ¿ides to cover them with Screens of dry Long Dung, or Litter, or Straw, which we put over the GlaÅ¿s Bells or GlaÅ¿ed Frames, and plants never fail to produce upon Beds thus accommodated and maintained in a due heat, by Å¿uch recruitings Renewed from time to time.

This manner of proceeding is good and commodious enough for Sorrel; becauÅ¿e being animated by the moderate heat of the Hot Bed, it Å¿prings up there for Å¿ome fifteen days time, juÅ¿t as that do's that grows in the naked Ground in the Month of May, and afterwards dies; But it is not Å¿o good for AÅ¿paragus, becauÅ¿e they when they are pull'd
up and Replanted, never produce Å¿uch fine Shoots, as when they are Dunged and heat on the naked Earth.

It follows then, that the beÅ¿t method for AÅ¿paragus, and even for Sorrel too, is to take up for about two foot deep, all the Earth in the paths between two cold Beds, (which paths Å¿hould be a full foot broad) and fill them up afterwards with Long Warm Dung, to heat the neighbouring Earth, and if it be for AÅ¿paragus, to cover the whole Cold Bed with the Å¿ame Dung, to help to warm the Earth; And when the AÅ¿paragus begin to Å¿prout, we put Bells upon each plant, or elÅ¿e cover the whole Bed with GlaÅ¿ed Frames; after which, the heat of theÅ¿e paths muÅ¿t be renewed by Å¿tirring them the bottom upwards, or by renewing from time to time an application of freÅ¿h Dung, covering beÅ¿ides the Bells or GlaÅ¿s Frames with dry long Dung, or Screens of Straw, or Å¿uch like matter, for the reaÅ¿ons above expreÅ¿Å¿ed, when we were treating of AÅ¿paragus and Sorrel in Hot Beds. The AÅ¿paragus plants being thus warmed, and feeling under thoÅ¿e Bells or GlaÅ¿s Frames an Air as comfortable as in the Months of April or May, they produce Å¿hoots that are Red at firÅ¿t comming up, but which afterward turn green and long, like thoÅ¿e that Nature it Å¿elf produces in warm and temperate Å¿eaÅ¿ons. The only inconvenience of theÅ¿e Artificial heatings is, that becauÅ¿e they muÅ¿t be very violent to penetrate a Cold Earth, they dry up and Å¿poil thoÅ¿e plants, Å¿o that Å¿uch AÅ¿paragus, inÅ¿tead of continuing for fifteen years together, to bear well as otherwiÅ¿e they do, never Å¿pring kindly afterward, and though they be let alone two or three years after a firÅ¿t heating, yet at moÅ¿t, are able to endure but one more.

The Straw-berries which are forced on Hot Beds begin to put out their Å¿hoots in January, and Flower in February and March, and yield their Fruit in April and May. The beÅ¿t method of raiÅ¿ing them, is to pot them in September, in a tolerable good and light Earth, and afterwards to plant them in Hot Beds in December; they may alÅ¿o be planted in Hot Beds without potting at all, in the Month of March; their runners and Å¿ome of their leaves muÅ¿t be taken off, if they have too many; the Earth in their Pots muÅ¿t be kept always looÅ¿e and a little moiÅ¿t, and if there happen any exceÅ¿Å¿ive heats in Å¿ome days of March and April, they muÅ¿t have a little Air given them towards the North, and they muÅ¿t be covered a Nights.

To have little Sallets of Lettuce to cut, mixed with Chervil, CreÅ¿Å¿es, &c. with the furnitures of Mint, Taragon, &c. and to have RadiÅ¿hes, &c. we make Å¿uch Hot Beds as I have directed, and we Å¿teep in water about twenty four hours, a little bagg of Lettuce Seed, after which time, we take it out, and hang it in a chimny corner, or in Å¿ome other place where the FroÅ¿t can't reach it, and the Seed Å¿o wetted, drains it Å¿elf from the water, and heats to Å¿uch a meaÅ¿ure, that it Å¿prouts, and then after we have made upon our Hot Beds Å¿ome little furrows of about two Inches deep, and about as broad, with a little Å¿tick that we draw hard over the mold, we Å¿ow that Å¿prouted Seed in thoÅ¿e furrows, Å¿o thick that it covers all the bottom of the furrows; There muÅ¿t be a A French BuÅ¿hel is 20 Pound weight, or near a peck and half EngliÅ¿h. French BuÅ¿hel to Å¿ow a Bed of fourteen ToiÅ¿es or Fathoms long, and of four foot broad, and when 'tis Å¿own, we cover it with a little mold caÅ¿t upon it lightly with the hand; and each caÅ¿t of the hand dextrouÅ¿ly performed, Å¿hould cover a furrow as much as it needs, which done, we put Å¿ome Bells or long Rice Straw over them to hinder the Birds from Eating them, and the heat from evapourating, or the FroÅ¿t by chilling it, from deÅ¿troying the Seed, we take away the Straw when at the end of five or Å¿ix days, the Seed begins to Å¿pring well, and at length, ten or twelve days after it is commonly high enough to be cut with a Knife, and eaten in Sallets, that is to be underÅ¿tood, if the Ice and Snow, and even the heat of the Bed be not too exceÅ¿Å¿ive. We take the Å¿ame courÅ¿e with Chervil, and CreÅ¿Å¿es, Å¿ave only that they muÅ¿t be Å¿own without Å¿teeping their Seeds.
As for Mint, Taragon, Cives, and other Furnitures of Sallets, they are planted on the Hot Bed in the Å¿ame manner as on the Cold one.
As for RadiÅ¿hes, we Å¿eldom Å¿teep them to make them Å¿prout, the skins of their Seeds being Å¿o tender, that in leÅ¿s than a days time, they would be melted all to a Pap.
I have directed how to Å¿ow RoaiÅ¿hes, in the Works of November, where we treat of preparing the proviÅ¿ions we would have from our Gardens in January, February, and March.

It is convenient to Å¿ow in the beginning of this Month, or even in November, and December, a Hot Bed of ParÅ¿ley to Å¿upply us with freÅ¿h, in the Spring time to Å¿erve us till that we Å¿hould Å¿ow in the naked Earth, at the end of February, be grown to its perfection.

To lay the branches or Å¿lips of Vines, Fig-Trees, GooÅ¿e-berry and Curran BuÅ¿hes, to take Root, we need only Couch, or lay down their branches into the Earth and cover them in the middle with Earth, to the height of five or Å¿ix Inches, which are to remain in that condition, till the month of November following, when having taken Root, we take them up, that is, Å¿eparate them from the Tree, and plant them where we have occaÅ¿ion for them.

To CircumpoÅ¿e Trees by planting them in Baskets, Pots, and Boxes, or CaÅ¿es, we firÅ¿t fill half way with Earth thoÅ¿e Baskets, Pots, or Boxes, and then having pruned and trim'd the Trees as I have directed in the TreatiÅ¿e of Plantations, we Plant them, plunging the Baskets and Pots quite into the Earth, but leaving the Boxes or CaÅ¿es above Ground:

The way of potting the Bulbous Roots of TubereuÅ¿es, Juncquills, NarciÅ¿Å¿us's of ConÅ¿tantinople, Jacynths, &c. is firÅ¿t to put them into Pots, and then to plunge thoÅ¿e Pots into Hot Beds, covering the Beds carefully with GlaÅ¿s Frames, Bells, Straw Screens, &c.

To warm or force Fig-Trees, we muÅ¿t have Å¿ome in Boxes or CaÅ¿es, and make for them in January, a Deaf Hot Bed (being a Hot Bed made in a hollow dug into the Earth, and raiÅ¿ed only even with its Å¿urface) and place the Boxes upon it. Then we muÅ¿t have Å¿ome Å¿quare GlaÅ¿s Frames about Å¿ix or Å¿even foot high, which muÅ¿t be fitted purpoÅ¿ely to be applied againÅ¿t a Wall expoÅ¿ed to a Southern AÅ¿pect: And Å¿o the Dung in the Hot Bed fermenting into a heat, warms the Earth in the Box, and by conÅ¿equence, makes the Fig-Tree Å¿prout; That Bed is to be put into a new ferment when there is occaÅ¿ion, and great care muÅ¿t be taken to cover thoÅ¿e GlaÅ¿s Frames cloÅ¿e, that no Cold may get within them.

During the whole Month of January we continue to Å¿ow upon Hot Beds, under Bells, Lettuces to be Replanted again as I have directed in the Works of December; as alÅ¿o to Replant them under Bells, as well to Å¿erve for the NurÅ¿ery, as in the places they are deÅ¿igned for, and as to the Seeds when Å¿own, we may let alone covering them with mold, if we pleaÅ¿e, it being enough to pat with the flat of our hands upon the Bed, to preÅ¿s the mold cloÅ¿e about them; we uÅ¿e the Å¿ame method with PurÅ¿lain Å¿own under Bells, for we can hardly throw Å¿o little mold upon thoÅ¿e Seeds to cover them, but we Å¿hall through too much.

To have Å¿ome fine little Lettuces for Salleting, we muÅ¿t Å¿ow under Bells Å¿ome of the Bright curled Å¿ort, and Å¿ow it thin, and Å¿tay till it has Å¿hot forth two leaves before we gather it. The Seeds of theÅ¿e Lettuces muÅ¿t be Å¿own thin, that the Plants may grow tall, and if we Å¿ee them come up too thick, we muÅ¿t thin them; the choiÅ¿eÅ¿t Å¿orts of Lettuce for the Spring Å¿eaÅ¿on, are the Curled Fair or Bright Lettuce, and after that, the Royal Lettuce, the Short Lnttuce, and above all, the Shell Lettuce, &c. We alÅ¿o Å¿ow under Bells, to Replant again, Borage, BugloÅ¿s, and Arach, or Orage.

The right method of making Trenches, and diging of molds, is not as was heretofore practiÅ¿ed, firÅ¿t, to throw out of thoÅ¿e Trenches all the Earth, and then to throw it in again; for that was unprofitably to handle the Å¿ame Earth twice, and Å¿o to loÅ¿e time, and Å¿pend money to no purpoÅ¿e.

The beÅ¿t way to do it then, is to make at firÅ¿t a Gage full as broad as the Trench and of the length of a ToiÅ¿e or Fathom, and to throw up upon the bordering Alley, all the Earth that is taken out of that Gage, which will be all the Earth we Å¿hall need handle twice, becauÅ¿e at the end of the Trench there will remain one Gage, empty, which muÅ¿t be filled up with the Earth that came out of the firÅ¿t, when the firÅ¿t Gage is made, we muÅ¿t fill it up with the Earth that is to be dug up to make the next, throwing that part of it into the bottom which was at the Superficies, and making a new Superficies of that which was at the bottom; This kind of moving the Ground, makes a natural Slope before the Workman, and in caÅ¿e the Soil muÅ¿t be Dunged, we muÅ¿t have Dung ready placed all along the Å¿ide of the Trench, and whilÅ¿t two or three men are at Work in turning up the Earth, and throwing it before them, there muÅ¿t be one at the Å¿ide of the Trench, to Å¿catter Dung upon that Slope by which means the mold is well mixed, and not at all trampled on, as it is by common Gard'ners, that firÅ¿t lay a layer of Dung, and then a layer of Earth, and afterwards dig the whole over again, continuing this way of laying of layers of Dung and mold, and to turn up one over another, till their Trench be quite filled up as 'tis to remain.

div.head: Works to be done in February.
div.p: IN this Month, we continue the Å¿ame works we were doing in the laÅ¿t, if we have had the foreÅ¿ight and convenience to begin them then, or elÅ¿e at leaÅ¿t we Å¿et upon beginning them now in earneÅ¿t.

Therefore we Å¿et to manuring the Ground if the FroÅ¿t permits us, and about the end of the Month, or rather to wards Mid-March, or later, that is towards Mid-April, we Å¿ow in the naked Ground thoÅ¿e things that are long a rearing; as for Example, all Å¿orts of Roots, viz. Carrots, ParÅ¿nips, Chervils or Skirrets, Beet-Raves, or Red-Beet-Roots, Scorzoneres, and above all, ParÅ¿ly-Roots.
We Å¿ow now alÅ¿o Onions, Leeks, Ciboules, Sorrel, HaÅ¿ting Peas, Garden or MarÅ¿h-Beans, Wild Endive, or Succory, and Burnet.

If we have any Shell-Lettuces that were Å¿own in Autumn laÅ¿t, in Å¿ome well Å¿heltered place, we now replant them on Hot Beds under Bells, to make them Cabbage betimes. And particularly we take care to replant on them Å¿ome of the Curld Bright Lettuces, which we Å¿owed laÅ¿t Month, becauÅ¿e they turn to better account than the others.
We begin at the latter end of the Month, to Å¿ow a little green PurÅ¿lain under Bells, the Red, or Golden Å¿ort being too delicate and tender to be Å¿own before March.

We replant Cowcumbers and Musk-melons, if we have any big enough, and that upon a Hot Bed, in Å¿ome place well Å¿heltered, either by Walls, Straw or Reed Hedges, or Å¿ome other Invention to keep off the Wind.
We alÅ¿o Å¿ow towards the end of the Month, our Annual Flowers, in order to replant them again at the latter end of April, and the beginning of May.

We alÅ¿o Å¿ow our firÅ¿t Cabbages, if as we Å¿hould, we have not a proviÅ¿ion of Å¿ome in a NurÅ¿ery under Å¿ome good Å¿helter, which we Å¿hould have Å¿own at the beginning of AuguÅ¿t, and replanted in October in the NurÅ¿ery; we replant theÅ¿e latter in the places they are deÅ¿igned for, taking care not to replant any that begins to run to Seed.

We begin to Graft all Å¿orts of Trees in the Cleft, and we prune and plant them; we plant alÅ¿o Vines, and about Mid-February, if the weather be any thing fair, is the proper time to begin all Å¿orts of Works.
We only make now the Hot Beds which we have occaÅ¿ion to make uÅ¿e of for RadiÅ¿hes, little Sallets, and to raiÅ¿e thoÅ¿e things which we are to replant again in the Cold Beds.
We take care to maintain the neceÅ¿Å¿ary heat about our AÅ¿paragus, and to gather thoÅ¿e that are good.
As alÅ¿o to maintain the Heat in the hot Strawberry Beds.
We unnail our Wall-trees in order to prune them the more commodiouÅ¿ly, and then nail them up anew.
At what time Å¿oever RadiÅ¿hes are gathered, they muÅ¿t be tied up in Bunches, and put to Å¿teep in Water, or elÅ¿e they will wither, and retain too biting a taÅ¿te.
We alÅ¿o continue to plant Trees when the Weather and the Soil will permit us.

div.head: Works to be done in March.
div.p: AT the beginning of this Month, it appears who are the Gard'ners that have been idle, by their not furniÅ¿hing us with any thing which the diligent and skilful ones Å¿upply us with, and by their having neglected to Å¿ow their Grounds which lie for the moÅ¿t part as yet unÅ¿own, though the weather has been favourable for it. There is now no more time to be loÅ¿t in delaying the Å¿owing of the firÅ¿t Seeds that are to be Å¿own in the naked Earth, and of which we have Å¿poken in the Works to be done about the end of February. Good Gard'ners ought to cover with Mold, the Cold Beds which they have Å¿own with their deÅ¿igned Seeds, for fear the waterings and great Rains Å¿hould beat down the Earth too much, and render its Superficies too hard for the Seeds to pierce and Å¿hoot through; they Å¿hould alÅ¿o bank up their cold Beds tightly with a rake, that Å¿o the Rain water, or that of their waterings may keep in them, and not run out of them into the Paths; and in fine, if they have never Å¿o little of the Spirit of NeatneÅ¿s in them, they will not fail to take away all the Stones the Rake meets with in its way.
The way to cover well all theÅ¿e Seeds with Earth, is to harrow or rake, that is, to move it extreamly to and fro, which is commonly done with an Iron Rake.
About Mid-March at furtheÅ¿t, we make the hot Beds in which we are to replant the earlieÅ¿t Musk melons.

We Å¿ow in the naked Earth, in Å¿ome well Å¿heltered place, all thoÅ¿e things which we are to plant again in the like; as for Example, both our Spring Lettuce, and that which we are to replant again at the latter end of April, and at the beginning of May, viz. the Curl'd Bright Lettuce, and the Royal, and Bellegarde Lettuce, the Perpignan Lettuce which is greeniÅ¿h, the Alfange, the Chicons, and the Green, Red and Bright Genua Lettuces are near two Months on the Ground, before they grow big enough to be replanted. And we alÅ¿o Å¿ow Cabbages for the latter SeaÅ¿on, and Collyflowers to plant them in their proper places, about the end of April and beginning of May; and if they come up too thick, we take out Å¿ome, and replant them in a NurÅ¿ery, to make them grow bigger, &c.

We Å¿ow RadiÅ¿hes in the naked Earth, among all the other Seeds we are Å¿owing, becauÅ¿e they do no harm there, but are fit to be gathered at the beginning of May, before either the Sorrel, Chervil, ParÅ¿ly, Ciboule, &c. be grown big enough to Å¿uffer any incommodity by them.
We Å¿ow Arrach, or Orage, in the naked Earth.
About Mid-March, we Å¿ow Citruls or Pompions upon hot Beds, to replant in the beginning of May.

Commonly there is nothing fit to be replanted in Cold Beds at their coming out of the hot ones, till the end of April, or the beginning of May, unleÅ¿s it be Lettuce, and the Earth muÅ¿t be a little warmed before we remove any thing into it out of a Hot Bed, in which the Plants were Å¿till cheriÅ¿hed with Å¿ome remaining heat, or elÅ¿e they will all come to nothing there.

We make an end of pruning and planting during the courÅ¿e of this Month, of all Garden-Trees, and alÅ¿o of GooÅ¿eberry, Curran, and RaÅ¿pberry Å¿hrubs, &c. It is very convenient to delay the pruning of vigorous Trees till they begin to Å¿prout, as well to let them Å¿pend their firÅ¿t Strength, as to prevent the loÅ¿ing any of their Fruit Buds which we cannot till then diÅ¿cern, and which come to their perfection in the Spring-SeaÅ¿on.

We take up at the beginning of the Month, with Mold and all, the plantation of Strawberrys, which we had in the NurÅ¿ery, to form Cold Beds and Squares of them to remain and to refurniÅ¿h thoÅ¿e where there want any.

We Å¿ow Å¿ome Å¿eed of piercepier or Garden Sampire in Å¿ome tub of Earth, or in the naked Ground Å¿ome Å¿heltered place; it requires commonly two Months to come up, and when it is big enough, we replant it in the Month of May, and Å¿ometimes we let it grow till the next year, in order to replant it at the foot of Å¿ome Wall.
We Å¿ow a third time a few more Peas, for we Å¿hould be Å¿ure to Å¿ow Å¿ome of them every Month of the Year, and theÅ¿e now Å¿own muÅ¿t be of the great Å¿quare Å¿ort.
We now have Å¿ome MuÅ¿hrooms either upon Å¿ome Hot Beds made purpoÅ¿ely for them, or in Å¿ome other places well dunged.
At the very beginning of the Month, we Å¿ow Å¿ome little quantity of Endive very thin, to have Å¿ome of it whited about Mid-Å¿ummer.

When we know that the Paths between hot Beds, or AÅ¿paragus Banks, have been Å¿tuffed with very long Dung, Å¿o that there Å¿eems not to be heat enough in them, and if it be very hot weather, it is convenient to water them reaÅ¿onably well, that Å¿o the Straw in them being wetted, may the more eaÅ¿ily ferment into a heat.

Towards the end of the Month, or at the beginning of April, we Å¿ow a little Cellery in the naked Earth, to have Å¿ome late in the Months of AuguÅ¿t and September. Cellery is commonly almoÅ¿t a Month a coming up; and we Å¿ow a little of it at the Å¿ame time on a Hot Bed, in order to have Å¿ome of it early.
We digg about the Roots of Fruit-Trees, that we may have finiÅ¿ht that work before they bloÅ¿Å¿om; the FroÅ¿t being more dangerous in Soils newly moved and turned up than in others.

We begin now to uncover a little our Artichokes, but Å¿eldom begin to manure them till the full Moon of March be paÅ¿t, which is generally very dangerous both to them and to the Figg-trees, which laÅ¿t muÅ¿t not yet be quite uncover'd, it being enough to do it half way, at the Å¿ame time we take off all their dead Wood and Branches, whether killed by the FroÅ¿t, or by any other means.
About the middle of March or before, if the weather be mild, we begin to Å¿ow Å¿ome Red or Golden PurÅ¿lain upon hot beds under Bells, and continue Å¿till to Å¿ow of the Green Å¿ort.

We replant in their Å¿ixt places common Cabbages and Milan Cabbages, which we Å¿hould take care to have ready in our NurÅ¿ery, from the beginning of November laÅ¿t paÅ¿t, in Å¿ome well Å¿heltered place, but we replant none of thoÅ¿e that begin to mount, that is, to run up their Å¿talks, as if they were going to Seed.
We Å¿ow upon Å¿ome end of a cold bed in plain Earth, Å¿ome AÅ¿paragus Seed for a NurÅ¿ery, to furniÅ¿h us with a ProviÅ¿ion of it, which is Å¿own like other Seed.
We plant the AÅ¿paragus Squares we have occaÅ¿ion for, to which purpoÅ¿e we make choice of a fine Plantation of one years growth, or elÅ¿e of one of two.

The way to plant AÅ¿paragus is, to place two or three Plants of them together, and neatly to Å¿pread out their Roots without cutting them but very little, unleÅ¿s we pleaÅ¿e, and then to cover them with a layer of Earth of two or three Inches thick, to plant theÅ¿e Tufts Checquer-wiÅ¿e, at a foot and a half's diÅ¿tance one from the other.

This Cold Bed Å¿hould generally be full four Foot broad, that there may be room enough for three ranks of them. But if we deÅ¿ign to force any of them by heat in Winter, we muÅ¿t make the Cold Beds but three Foot broad, and we muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve, if the Ground be dry, to lay the Bed hollow within the Earth, with a good Spade, and by that means raiÅ¿e the Paths Arch-wiÅ¿e, making uÅ¿e of the Soil that comes out of it to cover again by little and little, and year by year, the Plantation as it grows Å¿tronger, and riÅ¿es out of the Ground. But if it be in a moiÅ¿t Ground, and very cool, it is better not to make the Bed Å¿o low nor hollow, but on the contrary to keep it a little higher than the paths, that the Winter waters may deÅ¿cend out of it into them, and may not rot the Plants, to which nothing is more dangerous than too much wet.

AÅ¿paragus both old and young muÅ¿t be carefully howed, or cleared of Weeds, and in this Month of March, before they begin to appear above Ground, we muÅ¿t afford them a little manuring, by turning up the Earth to the depth of half a foot about them, to give the young AÅ¿paragus the more Liberty to Å¿hoot up.
The RadiÅ¿hes that are Å¿own on hot Beds with a caÅ¿t of the Hand, are generally not Å¿o fair nor Å¿o good as thoÅ¿e Å¿owed in holes, and are more apt to grow hollow and Å¿tringy than they.

We Å¿till continue to make Å¿ome Hot Beds for RadiÅ¿hes, that we may be Å¿till Å¿upplied with them, till the beginning of May, when thoÅ¿e Å¿own in plain Ground come in. All the other Months in the Year will produce us enough of them, if we will take the pains to Å¿ow Å¿ome from time to time, and be careful liberally to water them.

At the beginning of the Month it will be time to replant what we have a mind Å¿hould run to Seed, viz. Leeks and Onions, and eÅ¿pecially the white Å¿ort, Cloves of Garlick Cloves and Seeds of Shalots, white Cabbage, Pancaliers Cabbage, &c. Now likewiÅ¿e we are to tie up Å¿uch Lettuces as Å¿hould Cabbage, and yet do not, which tying makes them in a manner Cabbage by force.

We Å¿ow the Seed of Pannacht or Å¿triped Gilliflowers upon Hot Beds, before the full Moon, to replant them in May; we alÅ¿o Å¿ow the Annual Flowers upon hot Beds, to replant at the latter end of May, viz. PaÅ¿Å¿e velours, or Velvet Flowers, called alÅ¿o Flower gentles, and Amaranthus, Indian Ocellus or French Marygolds, Indian RoÅ¿es, the Belles de Nuit.
We make an end of Planting Trees both in their fixed places, and in Baskets.
We beÅ¿tow the firÅ¿t manuring upon all Å¿orts of Gardens, as well to render them agreeable to the Å¿ight, during the EaÅ¿ter Holy-Days, as to diÅ¿poÅ¿e the Ground for all Å¿orts of Plants and Seeds.
We Å¿et in the Ground, Almonds that have Å¿prouted breaking off the Å¿prout before we plant them.
We Å¿ow in the Flower Plots, or Parterres, Å¿ome Seeds of Poppy, and of Larks Heels, which will flower after them that were Å¿own in September.
We plant Oculus ChriÅ¿ti.
Towards the twentieth day of this Month, we Å¿ow Å¿ome Capucin Capers, or NaÅ¿turces, to Replant them again a Month after in Å¿ome good ExpoÅ¿ition, or at the foot of Å¿ome Tree.

div.head: Works to be done in April.
div.p:
THere is no Month in the year wherein there is more work to be done in Gardens than in this, for now the Earth begins to be very fit, not only to be manured, but to receive whatÅ¿oever we have a mind to plant or Å¿ow in it, as Lettuce, Leeks, Cabbage,
Borage, BugloÅ¿s. Artichokes, Tarragon, Mint, Violets, &c. Before the Month of April, it is as yet too cold, and after April, it begins to be too dry.

We furniÅ¿h thoÅ¿e places where any new planted Trees give but little marks of their proÅ¿pering, whether it be by Gum, in Å¿tone Fruit, or by pitiful Å¿mall Å¿hoots in all manner of Fruit-Trees. But for this important Reparation, we muÅ¿t have brought up ready to our hands, Å¿ome Trees in Baskets, which an underÅ¿tanding curious PerÅ¿on will never fail to have made proviÅ¿ion of, who will have the pleaÅ¿ure to plant Å¿ome of them near thoÅ¿e that thrive not Å¿o well as they Å¿hould do, when he is not well aÅ¿Å¿ured they will abÅ¿olutely die; for when we are Å¿ure of that, we pluck them up quite, to make room for them we Å¿hould Å¿ubÅ¿titute in their place, for which purpoÅ¿e, we make choice of cloÅ¿e and rainy weather.

We perform now our Å¿econd pruning of the Branches of Peach-Trees, I mean only the Fruit Branches, in order to cut them off Å¿hort to that part juÅ¿t above where there is Fruit Knit; and if any of thoÅ¿e Peach-Trees, have produced any very thick Å¿hoots upon high Branches, as Å¿ometimes it happens after the full Moon of March, we pinch them to make them multiply into Fruit Branches, and to keep them low, when there is occaÅ¿ion, that they may not run up too high before their time.

Peas Å¿own in a good ExpoÅ¿ition, at the very middle of October, Å¿hould begin towards the middle of April, to put forth at leaÅ¿t their firÅ¿t BloÅ¿Å¿oms, and conÅ¿equently muÅ¿t be pinch'd; the BloÅ¿Å¿om Å¿prings out commonly in Peas, from the middle of the fifth or Å¿ixth Leaf, from which Å¿ame place, there Å¿prings an Arm or Branch that grows exceeding long, and produces at each Leaf, a couple of BloÅ¿Å¿oms like the firÅ¿t, and therefore the more to fortify the firÅ¿t, we cut off that new Arm or Å¿hoot, juÅ¿t above the Å¿econd flower.

We continue to trim Musk Melons and Cucumbers, to new heat our Hot Beds, and make new ones, and to Å¿ow Cucumbers, that we may have Å¿ome to replant that may ripen about the end of Summer, and beginning of Autumn.
We make Å¿ome hot MuÅ¿hroom Beds in new Ground, the manner of doing which, I have already deÅ¿cribed elÅ¿ewhere.

'Tis the Moon of this Month, that we vulgarly call the Ruddy Moon, it being very Å¿ubject to be windy, cold and dry, and to be fatal thereby to many new planted Trees, unleÅ¿s great care be taken to water them about the Foot, once a Week; For which purpoÅ¿e we make a round hollow circle or Å¿mall Trench, round about their foot juÅ¿t over the part where the Extremities of their roots are, and then pour into the Å¿aid Trench or Circle, a pitcher full of water if the Tree be little, or two or three, if it be bigger, and when the water is Å¿oak'd in, we fill up the Circle again, if we think good, with Earth, or elÅ¿e we cover it with Å¿ome dry Dung, or Weeds newly pluck'd up, that we may the better repeat our watering once a Week during the extream dry Weather.

We weed up all the ill weeds that grow among good Seed, we take the Å¿ame courÅ¿e with Straw-berries, Peas, and replanted Lettuce, and we howe all about them, the better to looÅ¿en the Earth, and open a paÅ¿Å¿age for the firÅ¿t rain that Å¿hall fall.

About the middle of April, we begin to Å¿ow a little White Endive, in plain Ground, to whiten it in the Å¿ame place; and provided it be thin Å¿own, no Seed comes Å¿o eaÅ¿ily up as this Å¿ort of Endive.
At the middle of April we alÅ¿o Å¿ow in their places, the firÅ¿t SpaniÅ¿h Cardons, and the Å¿econd at the beginning of May; the firÅ¿t are commonly a Month in coming up, and the others about 15 days.

We alÅ¿o Å¿till Å¿ow in this Month, Å¿ome Sorrel, if we be not Å¿ufficiently provided with it before; and we Å¿ow it either in Cold Beds, in little furrows, which is handÅ¿omeÅ¿t, or elÅ¿e Å¿catteringly on the plain Ground, which is moÅ¿t common; or elÅ¿e upon the Å¿ides of Squares, to Å¿erve for an edging: we likewiÅ¿e replant in rows or furrows, that which we remove from other places, and is but about a year old, and eÅ¿pecially of that of the large Å¿ort, whether our neceÅ¿Å¿ities have obliged us to break up Å¿ome Bed of it, and that we be not minded to loÅ¿e it, or whether we do it deÅ¿ignedly.

We uÅ¿e the Å¿ame method with Fennel and Anis, and if the high winds, and Cold hinder us not, we begin to give a little Air to our Musk Melons under Bells, and continue to give them a little more and more of it by degrees, till the end of May, when if we be in a good Climate, we take off the Bells quite. And we lift up each Bell with three little forks, otherwiÅ¿e the plant hurt by its Å¿ides, would dwindle and grow lank. And if after we have given it a little Air, the Cold continues Å¿till Å¿harp enough to Å¿poil the branches and Leaves of it that are Å¿prouting, we take care to cover them with a little dry Litter.

At the end of the Month, we replant the RadiÅ¿hes we have removed from the Hot Beds where we firÅ¿t raiÅ¿ed them, to make a good proviÅ¿ion of Seed, chooÅ¿ing for that purpoÅ¿e, thoÅ¿e that have the Reddest roots and the feweÅ¿t leaves, and we need only make holes at a foot diÅ¿tance one from the other, in one or more Cold Beds, with a planting Å¿tick, and thruÅ¿t in the RadiÅ¿hes into thoÅ¿e holes, and then preÅ¿s down the Earth about them, and afterwards water them, if the rain do's not Å¿pare us that labour.

We chooÅ¿e apart of the faireÅ¿t of the Cabbage-Lettuces, as well the Winter ones, which are the Shell, and JeruÅ¿alem Lettuces, as the Curles Bright Lettuce raiÅ¿ed upon Hot Beds and under Bells, to plant them all together in Å¿ome Cold Beds at a foot diÅ¿tance one from another, to let them run to Seed; which we alÅ¿o perform with a planting Å¿tick.
We plant edgings of Time, Sage, Marjoram, HyÅ¿Å¿op, Lavender, Rue, Worm-wood, &c.

We replant Spring Lettuce, to Cabbage, which Å¿ucceed one another in this order; the Curled Bright Lettuce is the firÅ¿t and beÅ¿t, as being the moÅ¿t tender and delicate, but it requires a mild and light Soil, or above all, a Hot Bed to plant it on, under Bells, from the Month of February, and during all the Month of March, and the beginning of April. A groÅ¿s Soil agrees not with it, for inÅ¿tead of growing bigger there, it dwindles to nothing.

The Green Curled Lettuce, the George Lettuce, the Little Red Lettuce, and thoÅ¿e called the Royal, the Bellegarde, and the Perpignan, follow next after. The Royal Lettuce is a very fair and thick Lettuce, which differs only from the Bellegarde in that it is a little leÅ¿s Curled. The Capucin, Short, Aubervilliers, and AuÅ¿trian Lettuces Å¿ucceed them, and run not Å¿o eaÅ¿ily to Seed, as the preceeding ones. The Alfanges, Chicons, and Imperials which are all Lettuces to tie up, bring up the Rear; and the Genua Lettuces, both the Red, Bright, and Green, are the laÅ¿t Summer Lettuces; we muÅ¿t replant a good number of them at the very beginning of May, to have them good about Mid-Å¿ummer, and all the reÅ¿t of the Summer; of all Lettuces, this Å¿ort beÅ¿t endures the great heats, and is leaÅ¿t diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to run to Seed; for which reaÅ¿on to obtain Seed of it, we muÅ¿t have Å¿own it upon Hot Beds from the very Month of February, that we may have Å¿ome good plants of it to Å¿et again at the latter end of April.

The Royal Lettuce begins again to be fit to be replanted about the middle of September, to Å¿upply us, together with that of Genua, all the reÅ¿t of Autumn. From the end of August, we begin to Å¿ow the Shell, or Winter Lettuce, that we may have Å¿ome fit to re-plant in the Months of October, and November, for our Winter proviÅ¿ion.

It is hard to make any DeÅ¿criptions of theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Lettuces, exact enough to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h them by, the difference between them conÅ¿iÅ¿ting chiefly in having Leaves a little more or leÅ¿s green, or Curled; It is enough for the curious to know their names, to be enabled to ask for them of their Friends, or buy them of the Herb Merchants, we learning effectually to know them in the uÅ¿ing. The two CriÅ¿ped or Curled Sorts are Å¿o called, from the Curling of their Leaves, and the Red ones from their Colour. The Shell Lettuce has a very round Leaf which is very apt to Å¿hut up like a Shell.

There is an infinite DiverÅ¿ity of kinds of Lettuces, the worÅ¿t is that which we call Cats Tongue, which is very Å¿harp pointed, and never Cabbages. The Aubervilliers Lettuce grows Å¿o very hard that it is Å¿carce fit for Sallets, but is better for pottage; but yet it is very Å¿ubject to be bitter.

We muÅ¿t not fail every fifteen days, to Å¿ow a little Genua Lettuce, that we may always be provided with Å¿ome fit to replant during all the whole Summer, till the middle of September; we muÅ¿t be careful and eÅ¿pecially in rainy weather, to deÅ¿troy both the Black and Shell Snails that come out of the Walls where they breed Young ones, becauÅ¿e they do a great deal of miÅ¿chief by gnawing the young Shoots of Trees, and new planted Lettuces and Cabbages. If the Ruddy or Dry Winds Reign, as they generally do this Month, we muÅ¿t carefully and plentifully water every thing in our Kitchen-Garden, except it be the AÅ¿paragus.

We continue to Trim Musk Melons, and Cucumbers, and plant new ones upon new Hot Beds, at the beginning of this Month, and we alÅ¿o Å¿ow Å¿ome in the naked Ground, in little Dikes filled with mold, or compoÅ¿t, like to thoÅ¿e I have already mentioned for Cardons.

We now likewiÅ¿e Å¿earch the Woods for Young Straw-berry Plants, to make NurÅ¿eries of, in Å¿ome part of our Garden, we plant tufts of two or three plants of them together at four or five Inches diÅ¿tance one from another, and if the Soil be dry, in a hollow Bed of two or three Inches deep, the better to retain and preÅ¿erve the rain water, and that of our waterings, or elÅ¿e upon Å¿ome Bed near Å¿ome Northern Walls.

We alÅ¿o now diÅ¿-eye or Å¿eparate the Off-Sets or Slips of our Artichokes, as Å¿oon as they are big enough, and we plant as many of them as we need, two or three of them in each hole, or Trench of about three or four Inches deep, and two full Foot and a half diÅ¿tance one from the other, each Bed Å¿hould be four foot wide, and contain two rows of Artichoke Plants along its Å¿ides, and there muÅ¿t be a void Å¿pace left in the middle, of three foot wide for the planting of Leek Chaids, or great whited Leeks, or elÅ¿e of Collyflowers, in imitation of the Market-Gard'ners, who are good Husbands of their Ground. The two Artichoke Plants which we Å¿et in each hole, muÅ¿t be placed a full foot and half diÅ¿tance one from the other.
We Å¿till continue planting AÅ¿paragus, and filling the places where there are any wanting, if we can timely diÅ¿cover them, and we take care to water the new Plants.
We likewiÅ¿e Å¿till bind up thoÅ¿e Lettuces that Cabbage not as they Å¿hould.

We keep open the Windows of the green HouÅ¿es, where our Orange Trees are in fair weather, to reaccuÅ¿tom them by little and little, to the wide Air; towards the end of the Month, we bring out our JaÅ¿min and trim it; we alÅ¿o begin to prune our Vines at the firÅ¿t coming in of the Month, if we have neglected to do it about the middle of March laÅ¿t; and we prune the Wall Vines Å¿ooner than thoÅ¿e in the open Fields.

We have already in the month of March, Å¿et into the Earth, thoÅ¿e Almonds which Å¿prouted early, and in this Month we Å¿et thoÅ¿e which having not Å¿prouted at the Å¿ame time with the others, had been put up back again into Mold, Earth, or Sand.

In the beginning of this Month, Gardens Å¿hould be almoÅ¿t in their Perfection, as well for their general neatneÅ¿s, and pleaÅ¿ing ProÅ¿pect, as being all over covered either with the green Seedlings of all Å¿orts which have been Å¿own, or with Plants which have been Å¿et, excepting Endive, Succory, Celery, Collyflowers, &c. which are not replanted till about the middle of May. In fine, if we have neglected any thing that Å¿hould have been done in March, we muÅ¿t be Å¿ure to do it at the very beginning of this Month, and particularly, we muÅ¿t Å¿ow ParÅ¿ly, wild Endive, or Succory, and the firÅ¿t Harico's or French-Beans, the Å¿econd being to be Å¿own about the middle, and the third at the latter end of May, that Å¿o we may have a crop of them about two Months after Å¿owing.

About this time, the Strawberries growing in the naked Earth, Å¿hoot forth their Å¿tems, when we muÅ¿t take exact care to pluck all the Cuckows among them, that is, thoÅ¿e Straw-berry plants that bloÅ¿Å¿om much without knitting; nay, I would have the Caprons pluckt up too, unleÅ¿s any PerÅ¿on have a particular fancy for them, they are eaÅ¿ie to be known by their thick Å¿hort and Velvet Å¿tems, their large Flowers, and their very long Velvet, and Å¿harp pointed Leaves; but the Cuckows are Å¿omewhat hard to be diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿ht, particularly till their Å¿tems be formed. The moÅ¿t part of them are Strawberry Plants that have degenerated, and yet Å¿o, that the Leaves of the good ones and the bad ones are pretty like one another; but thoÅ¿e degenerate Plants in proceÅ¿s of time by their runners, produce an infinite number of others, which to appearance are very fair, and conÅ¿equently very apt to deceive us, yet thoÅ¿e that are acquainted with them, obÅ¿erve that they are a little more Velveted, and Å¿omewhat greener than the good ones. And in ConcluÅ¿ion, I muÅ¿t tell you, that if extraordinary care be not taken to extirpate thoÅ¿e unlucky Plants that impoÅ¿e upon us thus by their Beauty, we Å¿hall in little time find ourâª Å¿elves Å¿tockt with none but Å¿uch, to which the Proverb particularly agrees, which Å¿aith, a fair Å¿how, but little Fruit.

We Å¿ow our laÅ¿t Cucumbers about the tenth or twelfth of this Month, to have Å¿ome lateward ones, and Å¿uch as may be fit to pickle in October, which laÅ¿t are commonly called Cornichons, or horned Cucumbers, and in EngliÅ¿h, Crumplings, and Guerkins.

The Strawberry Å¿tems muÅ¿t be much pinched, and Å¿ome of them muÅ¿t be quite plucked up too when they Å¿hoot up in too great Numbers from feeble Plants; by pinching, here is meant the taking off the laÅ¿t Flowers and laÅ¿t Buds of every Å¿tem, leaving but three or four of thoÅ¿e that firÅ¿t appeared upon thoÅ¿e Å¿tems, and which are neareÅ¿t to the Ground.

It is particularly about the end of this Month, that May Moon begins, that is Å¿o fertile, and Å¿o vigorous in its Productions, when we muÅ¿t with all poÅ¿Å¿ible care run over our Wall-trees, and draw from behind the Trails, thoÅ¿e Branches that grow between them and the Wall, as well the Å¿maller ones, as more particularly thoÅ¿e that are thick: at the Å¿ame time Peach-Trees and other Stone-Fruit-Trees are to be pruned the third time, it having been done the Å¿econd time whilÅ¿t they were in BloÅ¿Å¿om, to take away all thoÅ¿e Branches that had not bloÅ¿Å¿om'd. And at this time we reckon, that all thoÅ¿e BloÅ¿Å¿oms that will knit at all, are already knit, and accordingly we are not to count any of them for true Peaches, but thoÅ¿e only that are well knit, and of a pretty bigneÅ¿s too, becauÅ¿e
till then, many of them continue to fall, though they Å¿eemed well knit. And therefore it is convenient to Å¿horten all thoÅ¿e Branches which having been left long purpoÅ¿ely for Fruit, have not anÅ¿wered that end, but have either retained no Fruit at all, or a very Å¿mall quantity, and which perhaps Å¿prout but weakly, that is, produce but very little Å¿hoots, or perhaps nothing but Leaves, the feebleÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e Branches muÅ¿t be diÅ¿charged of all their Å¿hoots, to one or two at moÅ¿t, and in general, all thoÅ¿e Branches muÅ¿t be Å¿hortned, that appear not vigorouÅ¿ly, or that are blaÅ¿ted by the Ruddy Winds. And LaÅ¿tly, we muÅ¿t leave only Å¿uch a burden of Branches and Fruit on the Tree as Å¿hall be proportionable to its greater or leÅ¿Å¿er Vigour, and accordingly we muÅ¿t leave a great deal upon vigorous Trees, eÅ¿pecially if they be Å¿prung from Stones, and but a little on them that are weak, and always aim as near as may be, to form that which we call a goodly Tree, taking all poÅ¿Å¿ible care that each Fruit-Branch may have its Fruit at its Extremity. This third pruning Å¿hould be done either before we new nail up our Wall-Trees, or at leaÅ¿t whilÅ¿t we are nailing them.

At this time likewiÅ¿e, we are to pinch, that is to Å¿ay, break off, to four or five Eyes or Buds, thoÅ¿e thick Å¿hoots in Peach-Trees that are Å¿prung out Å¿ince the main Pruning of that year, in order to make them Å¿hoot out three or four midling Å¿hoots, one whereof may be for a Wood Branch, and the reÅ¿t for Fruit; this Operation is to be performed particularly upon thoÅ¿e very thick Å¿hoots that Å¿pring out of the Extremity of a Tree that is grown high, when it has already attained its due height. It is likewiÅ¿e Å¿ometimes, though rarely performed upon the lower Å¿hoots, when we have occaÅ¿ion to fill up any void places that are made near any very thick Branches, whether young or old, which we have cut Å¿hort the laÅ¿t Winters Pruning; thoÅ¿e thick Branches are but too Å¿ubject either not to Å¿prout at all, or to grow full of Gum, both they and the young Shoots they produce in the Spring time.

It is not convenient to pinch any of all the other Fruit-Trees, excepting Graffs, when having been graffed upon thick Å¿tocks, they have begun to Å¿hoot out with too much rigour, becauÅ¿e the Å¿hoots of Å¿uch graffs would grow too high, and too bare, if they were not checkt by this Operation, and made to produce many Branches that prove good, inÅ¿tead of one that otherwiÅ¿e might have remained uÅ¿eleÅ¿s, unleÅ¿s it be in Å¿uch occaÅ¿ions we may pinch as long as we pleaÅ¿e, we Å¿hall never gain any advantage by it. Sometimes pinching extends likewiÅ¿e to Fig-Trees, but that is not to be done till the end of May, as I Å¿hall further Å¿hew afterwards.

div.head: Works to be done in May.
div.p: THe Effects of Vegetation during the Month of March, Å¿eemed to be but little proofs of Trial which Nature then made in order to Å¿ome greater performances. For alaÅ¿s, Trees bloÅ¿Å¿oming or Å¿hooting forth Leaves, or beginning to put forth Å¿welling Buds. &c. are all marks of leÅ¿Å¿er vigour than weakneÅ¿s, after which, in the productions of April, we have Å¿een the Å¿ame Nature augment in Å¿trength, and Å¿hew its effects by the knitting of Fruit, lengthning out Branches, and the coming up of Å¿own Seeds, &c. But at length when we once come to the Month of May, 'tis then that Mother of Vegetation Å¿eems in earneÅ¿t to diÅ¿play and exert all the force Å¿he is MiÅ¿treÅ¿s of, in order to the maintaining her Å¿elf in that flouriÅ¿hing EÅ¿tate during the whole Months of June and July following, at this time covering the Walls with new Branches, plumping the Fruit, and covering the Earth with a lovely and charming verdure, &c. And now our Gard'ners have great need to be upon their Guards, to prevent their Gardens falling into diÅ¿order, becauÅ¿e 'tis moÅ¿t Å¿ure, that if they be not now extreamly careful and laborious, there is no DiÅ¿aÅ¿ter, but they may expect; pernicious Weeds will in little time choke up all their good Seeds, their Walks and Alleys will be overgrown, and their Trees will fall into the greateÅ¿t ConfuÅ¿ion, for which reaÅ¿ons it will highly concern them to be extreamly watchful and diligent to weed, manure, cleanÅ¿e, to take off all Å¿uperfluous Leaves and Sprigs, and to nail up Wall-trees, by which means it will be in their Power to acquire the deÅ¿irable Commendation of having adorned and Å¿et out their Gardens with all the luÅ¿tre and excellency which they ought to have.

Green Peas, that were Å¿own in Banks or Borders in October, now begin to recompenÅ¿e our Pains, and to bloÅ¿Å¿om at the coming in of this Month, (the BloÅ¿Å¿oms laÅ¿t commonly about eight or ten days before they begin to pod, and in three weeks after, they are fit to gather, and Å¿hell. In the mean while, about the Å¿eventh or eighth day of the Month, we Å¿hould plant our Collyflowers, Milan Cabbages, Capucin Capers, or NaÅ¿turces, Beet-Chards, &c.
If we plant them Å¿ooner, they commonly run to Seed, which is to be avoided; and in fine for thoÅ¿e things, we ought not to paÅ¿s the fifteenth day, nor likewiÅ¿e for the Å¿owing of Winter Cabbages. We now make all the haÅ¿t we can, to make an end of diÅ¿-eying or Å¿lipping our Artichokes, which are vigorous, and Å¿eem to have need of being diÅ¿charged and thinned, and we make an end of planting new ones. The Eyes or Sucker-Å¿lips are good enough, provided they be pretty thick and white, though they have no root at their heel or foot, and we may be Å¿ure to have very fine Fruit from them in Autumn, and in truth it were to be wiÅ¿hed, they would yield none Å¿ooner, becauÅ¿e thoÅ¿e produced before that time are commonly pitiful, Å¿tarveling, and as 'twere abortive Fruits. Yet 'tis not enough to plant only Å¿ome good thick young Å¿lip-Å¿uckers, but we muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e plant Å¿ome midling ones, eÅ¿pecially in Å¿ome well Å¿heltred place, only to fortifie themÅ¿elves there during the reÅ¿t of the year, that they may be able to yield us their firÅ¿t Artichokes next Spring; thoÅ¿e which have born in Autumn, not making Å¿uch Å¿wift advances as theÅ¿e other. Next we are to plant our Beet Chards almoÅ¿t at the Å¿ame time, which are well placed, if planted in the middle of the Artichokes, that is, one Beet plant between two Artichokes, Å¿o that there may be Å¿ome in one Rank, and none in the other, for there muÅ¿t be room enough left free, to go upon to water, weed, manure, gather, and to cover them too, when need Å¿hall require.

The EarlieÅ¿t Musk Melons begin to knit in the firÅ¿t quarter, or at the full of this Months Moon, but chiefly at the wane of it, if their Beds were very hot at the full, and are grown cooler at the wane.

We alÅ¿o at the Å¿ame time Rank our Fig-Trees in the place alloted for the Fig Plantation, that we may have them in the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition we deÅ¿ire. They begin then to put forth their Leaves and Å¿hoots, and at length their Fruit begins to plump at the full Moon.

Towards the end of the Month, we begin with diligence and expedition, to nail up the new Å¿hoots of Wall-Trees, if they be Å¿trong enough to Å¿uffer it: And it is convenient to have finiÅ¿h'd this Work at the beginning of June, becauÅ¿e at the end of that Month, we muÅ¿t begin the Å¿econd nailing of the firÅ¿t Å¿hoots, and the firÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e which were never yet nail'd. We muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e pinch, or break off the thick Å¿hoots we find, whether becauÅ¿e after the firÅ¿t pinching of April, they have not multiplied into Branches as far as they extend, and on the contrary, have produced yet but one thick Å¿hoot, or becauÅ¿e, though they have multiplied into Branches, they have produced one Å¿hoot thick enough to be pinched; for otherwiÅ¿e that thick Å¿hoot would be unuÅ¿eful and pernicious; unuÅ¿eful, becauÅ¿e it muÅ¿t be taken away, or at leaÅ¿t be cut very Å¿hort, and pernicious, becauÅ¿e it will, as one may Å¿ay, have robb'd other neceÅ¿Å¿ary Å¿hoots of that nouriÅ¿hment they Å¿hould have had: Always taking it for a Rule, that we muÅ¿t in nailing, take care to couch all thoÅ¿e Branches which may and ought to be couched, without tying Å¿everal of them together, or taking away, or plucking off any that is Å¿ightly, unleÅ¿s it be that we can by no means couch it, in which caÅ¿e, we muÅ¿t cut it off within the breadth of a Crown piece of the place from whence it Å¿prouts, in hopes that out of the two Å¿ides of the remaining Å¿tump of that thickneÅ¿s, there may Å¿prout Å¿ome good Fruit-Branches, we muÅ¿t alÅ¿o have a care not to lay one croÅ¿s another, unleÅ¿s we be neceÅ¿Å¿arily obliged Å¿o to do, to fill up a void place, or to preÅ¿erve a uniform equality.
If there be any Trees deÅ¿igned to mount upright, we muÅ¿t accordingly order for that purpoÅ¿e, the Branch that Å¿eems moÅ¿t proper for it.
We tie the graffs either to their Trunk, or to Å¿ticks Å¿et up on purpoÅ¿e by them, to make them grow in that figure we would have them, and hinder them from being broken by the Winds.
We Å¿ow a great deal of Genua Lettuce, and we replant Å¿ome of them, and of the other Lettuces alÅ¿o.

We likewiÅ¿e trim Pear-Trees, either to take off the falÅ¿e Å¿hoots if any appear, which is done by plucking them quite away when they make a confuÅ¿ion, or even Å¿uch others which though they be good, yet becauÅ¿e they might produce that confuÅ¿ion which is Å¿o much to be avoided in a Tree, muÅ¿t therefore be taken off, for the better fortifying of thoÅ¿e that are to make the figure of that Tree; for a Å¿econd Å¿hoot will grow much more vigorous, if we take away that which being at the extremity of the pruned Branch was counted for the firÅ¿t.

We Å¿ow Endive, that we may have Å¿ome good, at the end of July, which may be whitened in the Å¿ame place where it firÅ¿t grew, without removing, if it being Å¿own thin, and well watered during the whole Month. We now alÅ¿o take the advantage of Å¿ome rainy
weather, to replant in their deÅ¿igned places, our annual Flowers, Å¿ome of them Å¿eldom failing to come to good there; we likewiÅ¿e take the advantage of the Å¿ame time, to fill up with Basketed, or CircumpoÅ¿ed Trees, the places of thoÅ¿e that are dead, or that thwart our expectations, or that give us no very good hopes of their thriving. The manner of doing it, is, to make a hole big enough to hold the Basket and Tree, then to put it in, and carefully to fill up with Earth all the hollow Å¿pace round about the Basket, and to preÅ¿s it down hard either with the foot or hand, and then to pour down all round upon it, two or three pitchers full of water, in order to the better incorporating the Earth without, with that within, Å¿o that there may not be left the leaÅ¿t hollow in the world. It is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to renew theÅ¿e waterings two or three times during the reÅ¿t of the Summer.
We alÅ¿o Å¿till plant Beet Chards, chooÅ¿ing for that purpoÅ¿e the brighteÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e that are of the growth of the laÅ¿t Å¿own Seeds, as being both fairer and better than thoÅ¿e which are green.
We continue our NurÅ¿eries of Straw-berry Plants till the end of this Month, at which time, we may perfectly diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the good ones by their Stems, or upright Å¿hoots.
We alÅ¿o Å¿till continue to tie up thoÅ¿e Lettuces that Cabbage not as they Å¿hould.
We Å¿ow no more Lettuces, except Genuz Lettuces, after the middle of May, becauÅ¿e all the reÅ¿t but only this laÅ¿t Å¿ort, are too apt to run to Seed.

We replant Musk Melons and Cucumbers in the naked Earth in little Holes or Trenches filled with mold; we alÅ¿o plant Pumpionsâª or Citruls in the like holes, at the diÅ¿tance of three ToiÅ¿es or Fathoms, they are Å¿uch as have been raiÅ¿ed on Hot Beds, and therefore to make them take root again, the Å¿ooner, we cover them with Å¿omething for five or Å¿ix days, unleÅ¿s it rain, the great heat of the Sun, otherwiÅ¿e being apt to make them wither, and Å¿ometimes to kill them quite.

We continue to Å¿ow a few Peas, which muÅ¿t be of the biggeÅ¿t Å¿ort; and if we think good, we pull off Å¿ome of the Branches of the others that are over vigorous, after they are well cleared of Weeds; Peas that are disbranched, bearing a more plentiful crop than others.

We bring out our Orange-Trees at the firÅ¿t quarter of this Months Moon, if the weather begin to be Å¿ecure from the aÅ¿Å¿aults of the FroÅ¿t, and we put them into boxes that have need of it; I referr you for their culture to the TreatiÅ¿e I have compoÅ¿ed expreÅ¿ly about that Å¿ubject: It was our care during all the fair days in April, to leave open the windows of their ConÅ¿ervatories, to accuÅ¿tom them by degrees, to the open Air.
We trim our JaÅ¿mins when we bring them out, cutting off all their Branches to the length of half an Inch.
At the end of this Month, we begin to clip for the firÅ¿t time, our paliÅ¿ades, or pole hedges of Box, Filaria's, Yew and EÅ¿picia's.

Above all things, care muÅ¿t be taken to water all our plants largely, or elÅ¿e they will all roaÅ¿t and Å¿corch, whereas by the help of Å¿eaÅ¿onable waterings, we may viÅ¿ibly perceive them thrive. We alÅ¿o now water new planted Trees, and for that purpoÅ¿e, we make a hollow Circle of four or five Inches deep, round about the extreamities of the roots, and pour into it Å¿ome pitchers of water, and when 'tis Å¿oak'd in, we either throw back the Earth into the Circle, or elÅ¿e we cover it with dry Dung, or little, in order to renew our waterings Å¿everal other times, till the Trees have taken faÅ¿t root again, after which, we fill it up with Earth again.
We may begin to replant our PurÅ¿lain for Seeding towards the end of the Month.
We continue to trim Musk Melons, but we replant no more of them after the middle of May.
But we Å¿till continue to plant Cucumbers.

About the end of the Month; we begin to plant Cellery, and we uÅ¿e two ways of planting it, viz. either in Cold Beds hollowed into the Ground, as we do AÅ¿paragus, planting three ranks of them in every Bed, and placing both the ranks, and the Cellery plants at about a foot diÅ¿tance one from another, and that is the beÅ¿t way for them when they are a little bigger than ordinary, that Å¿o we may be able to raiÅ¿e the earth about them afterwards, with that which was taken out of the furrows, and which was thrown upon the next Cold Beds, or elÅ¿e we replant them on plain Ground at the Å¿ame diÅ¿tance as before, and at the end of Autumn, binding them firÅ¿t with two or three bands; theÅ¿e are raiÅ¿ed in tufts, that we may replant them as nigh as we can, to one another, that Å¿o they
may be the more eaÅ¿ily covered with long dry Dung, and be the better whitened, and defended from the FroÅ¿t.

Towards the end of the Month, we begin to tie our Vines to their props, and to nail up Å¿uch Å¿tocks of them as are planted by Walls, after we have firÅ¿t clear'd them of all their feeble, unprofitable, and unfruitful Shoots and Sprigs.

We likewiÅ¿e plant Å¿ingle Anemonies, which flower a Month after, and we may have planted Å¿ome every Month Å¿ince the laÅ¿t preceeding AuguÅ¿t, they blowing and flowering in the Å¿ame manner, if not hindered by an extream cold SeaÅ¿on.

At the very beginning of the Month, or at leaÅ¿t as Å¿oon as ever we can, we pick off, and thin our Apricocks when there are too many of them, never leaving two cloÅ¿e together, that Å¿o thoÅ¿e we leave on, may grow the bigger, and at the end of the Å¿ame Month, we may pick off, and thin our Teaches and Pears, if they be big enough, and there be two many of them. About that time alÅ¿o, or at the beginning of the enÅ¿uing Month, the firÅ¿t bright Cabbages are to be Å¿own for Autumn and Winter, the biggeÅ¿t of them which are replanted in July, being to be eaten in Autumn, and the leÅ¿s vigorous which are replanted in September and October, being to Å¿erve for our Winter ProviÅ¿ion.

During all the Month of May, the Å¿hoots of Wall-Trees are apt enough to Å¿lide themÅ¿elves behind their trails or props as I have Å¿aid in the Month of April, and we Å¿hall hardly be able to draw them out again without breaking them, unleÅ¿s we do it in time, and be careful once every Week, to take an exact view all along our Walls, to remedy Å¿o miÅ¿chievous an inconvenience, againÅ¿t which too much caution cannot be uÅ¿ed. Many Branches grow crooked, rugged, parched, and hooked at the ends, and their Leaves alÅ¿o; and therefore about the full Moon, we muÅ¿t pull off thoÅ¿e Leaves Å¿o crumpled and hooked, and break off as low as we can, the parched Å¿hoots, that there may Å¿pring others inÅ¿tead of them that may be better and Å¿treighter. Fig-Trees too muÅ¿t now be pruned, and eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e in Boxes, of the method of doing which, I have compoÅ¿ed a particular TreatiÅ¿e.
We continue to Å¿ow a few RadiÅ¿hes among other Seeds, as we Å¿hould have alÅ¿o done in the two laÅ¿t preceeding Months.

We alÅ¿o now take the advantage of Å¿ome gentle Showers, or of very cloudy weather, to uncover what we have Å¿heltred under GlaÅ¿s Bells or Frames, as well for the watering of our Beds, as for the inuring and hardening them to indure the open Air.

If our Garden be Å¿ituated in a Sandy and dry Ground, we endeavour by the help of Å¿ome little Dykes or Gutters, to carry off all the water that falls Å¿ometimes in haÅ¿tly Storms, to thoÅ¿e places that are manured, that none of it may be unprofitably waÅ¿ted in the Walks or Allies, and if they be Å¿ituated in Ground that is too Å¿trong, fat and moiÅ¿t, Å¿uch as that of our new Kitchen-Garden at VerÅ¿ailles, we drain it away from thoÅ¿e Grounds that are incommoded by it, by conveying it into the Walls or Allies, to Å¿pend it Å¿elf there, or Å¿hooting it off into Stone gutters that carry it out of the Garden; for which purpoÅ¿e we muÅ¿t raiÅ¿e our Ground into arch'd ridges.
During all this Month, it is good to lay yellow Å¿tock Gilliflowers, by planting cuttings of them, where ever we have a mind, or by laying their Branches that Å¿till grow to their Plants.

ThoÅ¿e that are curious in Carnations and Clove-Gilliflowers, in order to have double ones, Å¿ow Å¿ome good Seeds of them about the 5, 6, 7, or 8th. of May Moon, in earthen Pans, or wooden Tubs, that at leaÅ¿t they may begin to Å¿prout at the full Moon, which Å¿ometimes happens in June, but moÅ¿t commonly in May, thoÅ¿e plants ought to grow big enough to be removed in September, into the naked Earth, that Å¿o they may have taken Ground before the Equinox; others again content themÅ¿elves with Å¿owing their Seeds before the Equinox.
We Å¿hould likewiÅ¿e replant before the end of May, Å¿ome green curled, and Aubervilliers Lettuce, that we may have Å¿ome all the Month of June, together with the Chicons, and Imperial Long-Lettuce.

We muÅ¿t alÅ¿o at this time endeavour to deÅ¿troy the thick white Worms, which now Å¿poil the Strawberries, and Cabbage Lettuce, and take away the green Caterpillars, which quite cat up the Leaves of the Curran and GooÅ¿eberry buÅ¿hes, and Å¿o Å¿poil their Fruit.
At the end of May, we Å¿hould alÅ¿o thin thoÅ¿e Roots that grow too thick, and replant thoÅ¿e we have plucked up in another place, as Beet-raves, or Red Beet-Roots, ParÅ¿nips, &c.
We may replant DaiÅ¿ies, Bears-Ears, and white double NarciÅ¿Å¿us's, though in Flower, that not at all hindering them from taking Root again.

div.head: Works to be done in June.
div.p: IHere repeat the Å¿ame Caution I have already given at the beginning of the Works of each Month, which is, that we muÅ¿t be careful to do that at the beginning of this Month, which we could not do in the laÅ¿t, and we muÅ¿t moreover continue all the Å¿ame Works, excepting hot Beds for Musk-melons, which now have no longer need of them, but we may Å¿till make Å¿ome for the latter Cucumbers, and for MuÅ¿hrooms.

We may alÅ¿o plant Å¿ome Artichokes, till the twelfth or fifteenth of the Month, which being well watered, will Å¿erve for the next Spring. Waterings are to no purpoÅ¿e, if they Å¿oak not to the Root, and therefore the deeper the Plant is rooted, the more plentifully muÅ¿t it be watered, and eÅ¿pecially in dry Ground, for in wet Grounds, they muÅ¿t be watered both leÅ¿s often, and leÅ¿s plentifully. For example, Artichokes growing in light Grounds, have need of a Pitcher full or two of Water, for each Plant, whereas in Å¿tronger Grounds, one pitcher full will Å¿erve three.

Towards the middle of June, we plant Leeks in Holes or Trenches Å¿ix full Inches deep, at half a foot's diÅ¿tance one from the other, which is done with a planting Å¿tick, placing but one of them in each hole, without heeding to preÅ¿s down the Earth cloÅ¿e about the Leek, when we have done, as is practiÅ¿ed to all other Plants that are Å¿et with a planting Å¿tick.

We continue to Å¿ow Endive, and Genua Lettuce, that we may be furniÅ¿ht with Å¿ome to replant upon occaÅ¿ion, all the reÅ¿t of the Summer, and we gather the Chervil that is the firÅ¿t that runs up to Seed from the Chervil, that was Å¿own the Autumn before, cutting off all the Seed Å¿tems, and when they are dried, threÅ¿hing out the Seed, and fanning it like Wheat.

The Å¿ame method is practiÅ¿ed with all Seeds that are gathered each in their proper SeaÅ¿ons, and eÅ¿pecially in the Months of July and AuguÅ¿t, taking great care to prevent the Birds, who are very greedy of them, from devouring them.

We replant Beet Chards in order to have them good to eat in Autumn, and they are beÅ¿t placed in the void Å¿pace remaining between the Artichoke Ranks, they muÅ¿t be Å¿et at the diÅ¿tance of a Foot and a half one from the other.

We muÅ¿t take great care to extirpate all the Weeds which now grow up in abundance, and that particularly before they run to Seed, to prevent their multiplying which they are apt to do but too much of themÅ¿elves without Å¿owing.

We muÅ¿t now alÅ¿o without further delay, clip all our PaliÅ¿ade's, and edgings of Box, Å¿o that they may be all furniÅ¿ht at furtheÅ¿t at Mid-Summer, and have time to Å¿hoot out again before Autumn; and we muÅ¿t liberally water all Seeds Å¿own in our Kitchen Gardens.
We muÅ¿t water plentifully, and every day the Cucumbers upon Hot Beds, and Musk-melons moderately two or three times a Week, allowing half a pitcher full of Water to each Plant.

From the very middle of June we begin to graff by Inoculation, our Stone-Fruit-Trees, and eÅ¿pecially Cherries upon great Trees, upon Wood of two years growth, which are cut off three or four inches from the place where the Scutcheon is to be placed. The beÅ¿t time for this, is always before the SolÅ¿tice.

GroÅ¿s Soils muÅ¿t be often Å¿tirred and manured, that they may not have time to grow hard, and chap, commonly we beÅ¿tow an univerÅ¿al manuring or Å¿tirring up the Ground upon all our Gardens in this SeaÅ¿on, and the beÅ¿t time to Å¿tir dry Grounds in, is either a little before or after Rain, or even whilÅ¿t it rains, that the water may the more Å¿wiftly penetrate to the bottom, before the great heat comes to turn it into Vapors, and for Å¿trong and moiÅ¿t Soils, we muÅ¿t wait for hot and dry weather, to dry and heat them, before we move them, carefull Gard'ners make Dykes to convey the gluts of Water that fall about this time in haÅ¿ty Storms, a croÅ¿s their Squares, eÅ¿pecially if their Ground be light; but on the contrary, if it be too Å¿trong, they drain the water out of the Squares, as I have Å¿aid already, when I was Å¿peaking of the works of May.

PerÅ¿ons curious in Carnations, and Clove-gilliflowers, Å¿hould have begun before this time to put Rings about each plant of them, to keep up their mounting Å¿tems, and hinder the Winds from breaking off their Buds or Buttons, the like they do to their Sedums, &c. and if they have not yet done it, they do it in this Month, and not only take off
from them the Å¿mall Buds that grow upon them in over great Numbers, to fortifie the principal ones, but likewiÅ¿e the greateÅ¿t part of the mounting Å¿tems, in order to preÅ¿erve only one of the faireÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t likely, to produce the moÅ¿t beautiful Flowers.
We alÅ¿o Å¿till continue to deÅ¿troy the thick white Worms that Å¿poil the Strawberries and Cabbage Lettuce.
We carefully cultivate our Orange-Trees, according to the method preÅ¿cribed in the TreatiÅ¿e I have compoÅ¿ed purpoÅ¿ely on that Subject.
The Wild PurÅ¿lain begins to appear at the beginning of June, and laÅ¿ts till the end of July, which muÅ¿t be carefully Å¿craped.
We take up our Tulip Roots out of the Ground at the end of this Month, their Leaves being then withered.
We disbranch Harico's or French-Beans, and towards the end of this Month, we Å¿ow Peas to have them fit to eat in September.

div.head: Works to be done in July.
div.p: THis Month likewiÅ¿e requires a great deal of application and activity in a Gard'ner, to do all that he could not do the laÅ¿t Month, and to continue Å¿till all the Å¿ame Works, but only the hot Beds. Now the great heats without waterings, do very great damage, but being allayed with frequent waterings, give Birth to very fine Productions.
In this Month, many Å¿orts of Seeds are gathered, and Endive is Å¿own for the proviÅ¿ion of Autumn and Winter. We alÅ¿o Å¿ow Royal Lettuce to have it good for uÅ¿e at the end of Autumn.

We alÅ¿o Å¿till continue to Å¿ow Å¿ome Ciboules, and white Beets for Autumn, and Å¿ome few RadiÅ¿hes in cool Places, or Å¿uch as are extreamly well watered, to have them fit to eat at the beginning of AuguÅ¿t.
If the SeaÅ¿on be very dry, we begin at the latter end of the Month, to graff by inoculation of a Dormant Bud, upon Quince-trees, and Plum-Trees
We begin to replant White or Bright Cabbages for the end of Autumn, and the beginning of Winter.
We Å¿ow more Lettuce Royal.
We Å¿ow for the laÅ¿t time, our Square Peas in the middle of July, that we may have Å¿ome to Å¿pend in October.

In this Month particularly, Peach-Trees produce Å¿everal Å¿hoots. About the middle of July, we begin to lay our Clove-gilliflowers and Carnations, if their Branches be Å¿trong enough to bear it, otherwiÅ¿e we muÅ¿t Å¿tay till August, or the middle of September.

From the very middle of AuguÅ¿t, we begin to Å¿ow Spinage to be ready about the middle of September, and MÃ¢ches for Winter Sallets, and Shell-Lettuces, to have ProviÅ¿ion of Cabbage-Lettuces at the end of Autumn, and during the Winter SeaÅ¿on.
We replant Strawberry Plants in their deÅ¿igned Places, which we had raiÅ¿ed in Tufts.
We gather Lettuce and RadiÅ¿h Seeds, as Å¿oon as ever a part of their Pods appears dry, and then we pull up their Plants, and lay the whole a drying.
We alÅ¿o gather the Seeds of Chervil, Leeks, Ciboules, Onions, Shalots, and Rocamboles, or SpaniÅ¿h Garlick.
We Å¿ow RadiÅ¿hes in the naked Earth, for Autumn.

At the latter end of the Month, we Å¿ow Å¿ome Cabbage in Å¿ome good ExpoÅ¿ition, to remove into a NurÅ¿ery, in Å¿ome other well Å¿heltered place, where they are to paÅ¿s the Winter, in order to be replanted in their deÅ¿igned places in the following Spring.

We alÅ¿o Å¿ow all the Month long, Å¿ome Shell-Lettuces in Å¿ome good ExpoÅ¿ition, as well to replant at the end of September, or beginning of October, in the places where they are to remain under Å¿ome good Å¿helter, as to have Å¿ome ready hardned to the cold, to replant again after Winter, either in the naked Earth in the Month of March, or upon hot Beds; at the very beginning of February, and if the Winter be very cold, they muÅ¿t be covered with long Litter.
We may Å¿ow Onions to have good ones the next year, at the very beginning of July, which it is beÅ¿t to replant in the Month of March next following.
We now water liberally.
We replant a great deal of Endive at a large foot diÅ¿tance between Plant and Plant, as alÅ¿o Royal and Perpignan Lettuces, which are very good in Autumn and Winter.
We Å¿ow MÃ¢ches for Lent.
We Å¿till continue to replant Winter Cabbages.
We Å¿hear our PaliÅ¿ade's the Å¿econd time.
We continue to nail up our Wall-Trees, and by little and little, to uncover thoÅ¿e Fruits, which we would have tinged with much Red, as Peaches, Api Apples, &c.

We tye up our Endive with one, two, or with three bands, if it be very high, but the uppermoÅ¿t Band muÅ¿t be always looÅ¿er than the reÅ¿t, otherwiÅ¿e the Lettuce will burÅ¿t in the Å¿ides whilÅ¿t it is whitening.

At the middle of AuguÅ¿t we begin to cover with compoÅ¿t, the Sorrel that was cut very cloÅ¿e to recruit its vigour, a good Inch's thickneÅ¿s of CompoÅ¿t is enough to Å¿trew all over it, becauÅ¿e they would be apt to rot, if we Å¿hould uÅ¿e more to them.
We Å¿till continue Å¿owing of Sorrel, Chervil, and Ciboules.

We pluck off the runners of Strawberry Plants, to preÅ¿erve their old Stocks in the greater vigour, and when their Fruit is paÅ¿t, which is about the end of July, or the beginning of AuguÅ¿t, we cut away all the old Å¿tems, and old Leaves, that they may produce new ones.
We alÅ¿o cut away all the old Stems of Artichokes, when the Artichokes are taken off.
We Å¿till continue Å¿owing of Spinage, for the beginning of Winter.

We take our Onions out of the Ground as Å¿oon as their Stems begin to dry, and we let them lie ten or twelve days a drying in the Air, before we lay them up in our Granary, or Å¿ome other dry place, or elÅ¿e we bind them up in Ropes, becauÅ¿e otherwiÅ¿e they would ferment and rot, if they were laid up before they were dry.
We gather our Shalots at the very beginning of the Month, and draw our Garlick out of the Ground.
At the end of AuguÅ¿t the FloriÅ¿ts Å¿et into the Earth their Jacinths, fair Anemonies and Ranunculus's or Crow-foots, Junquills, Totus Albus's and Imperials.

We deÅ¿troy both ordinary Flies and WaÅ¿ps which eat the Figs, the MuÅ¿cat Grapes, and other Fruits, and for that effect, we tye Å¿ome Bottles or Cucurbit-glaÅ¿Å¿es full of water mixed with a little Honey, to Å¿ome of their Branches, by which means, thoÅ¿e inÅ¿ects being allured by the Å¿weetneÅ¿s of the Honey, enter into the necks of thoÅ¿e GlaÅ¿Å¿es, and Å¿o periÅ¿h in that mixture, but they muÅ¿t be emptied and Å¿hifted with new Water, as often as they begin to fill with thoÅ¿e little unlucky inÅ¿ects.
Though the firÅ¿t Bud of a Clove-gilliflower or Carnation is beautiful and PromiÅ¿ing, it do's not follow thence, that all the reÅ¿t will be Å¿o too.

The Beauties of a Carnation are, to be high and tall, well burniÅ¿ht and garniÅ¿ht, well ranged, of a lovely colour, well plumed and diÅ¿played, and of a perfectly Velvet-like Å¿oftneÅ¿s to the Touch.

At the beginning of this Month, we tread down the Å¿tems of Onions, and the Leaves of Beet-raves, or Red Beet Roots, Carots, ParÅ¿nips, &c. or elÅ¿e we take off their Leaves quite, to make their Roots grow the bigger in the Ground, by hindering their Sap from Å¿pending it Å¿elf above Ground.
It is Å¿till a good SeaÅ¿on enough to lay Clove-gilliflowers and Carnations.

div.head: Works to be done in September.
div.p: THE Ground in Gardens in this Month Å¿hould be univerÅ¿ally covered all over, Å¿o that there Å¿hould be not Å¿o much as the leaÅ¿t Å¿pot in it without Å¿ome Kitchen and EÅ¿culent Plants, whether Å¿own or replanted, which is not altogether Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary in the preceeding Months, both becauÅ¿e we then reÅ¿erve a good part of our Ground for Winter Plants, Å¿uch as are Lettuces, Endive, Peas, &c. and becauÅ¿e Å¿ome plants require a very conÅ¿iderable time to arrive to perfection in, and would not have enough if they were allowed leÅ¿s than to the end of Autumn.
We Å¿till continue the works of the preceeding Month.
We make hot Beds for MuÅ¿hrooms.

We replant a great deal of Endive, and that cloÅ¿er together now than in the foregoing Months, that is, we place them at half a foots diÅ¿tance one from the other, becauÅ¿e now their Tufts grow not Å¿o large as before.

They muÅ¿t be replanted in almoÅ¿t all the Å¿pare places from the very beginning of the Month, till the fifteenth or twentieth day. At the latter end of the Month, we Å¿ow Spinage the third time, which will be good in Lent, and even in the Rogation Å¿eaÅ¿on following.
We Å¿till continue planting Winter Cabbages, and eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e of the Greener Å¿ort.

We may likewiÅ¿e Å¿till about Mid-September, Å¿ow Å¿ome Cold Beds of Sorrel, and replant Å¿ome old, there being yet time enough for it to attain to a Å¿ufficient vigour before the firÅ¿t FroÅ¿ts come.

During this whole Month we continue to remove Straw-berry Plants out of our NurÅ¿eries, to reimplace thoÅ¿e tufts which are dead in our Beds, and we immediately water them, as we muÅ¿t do all Plants which we Å¿et a new.
We Å¿et Å¿ome in Pots towards the twentieth day, if we intend to force any in the Winter.

About the fifteenth of the Month, we graff Peach-Trees upon Almond-Trees, and upon other Peach-Trees as they Å¿tand in the places where they are to remain; the Å¿ap being then too much diminiÅ¿hed to be in any capacity to overflow the Scutcheons.

We tie up firÅ¿t with OÅ¿ier withs, and afterwards towards the fifteenth of the Month, we carefully wrap up with long Litter, or new Å¿traw, Å¿ome SpaniÅ¿h Cardons, and Artichoke Plants, to have them whitened or Blanched about fifteen or twenty days after; But great care muÅ¿t be taken in wraping them up, to keep them perfectly upright, otherwiÅ¿e they will overÅ¿et, and Å¿nap in Å¿under on one Å¿ide; and to hinder the winds from laying them on one Å¿ide too, they muÅ¿t be fenced with a Bank of Earth of about a full foot high.
Towards the end of the Month, we plant Cabbages in NurÅ¿eries, in Å¿ome well Å¿heltred place, in order to replant them in their deÅ¿igned places aÅ¿Å¿oon as the Winter is over.

From the fifteenth of the Month to the end, and till the middle of October, we replant Shell Lettuces in Å¿ome well Å¿heltered place and eÅ¿pecially near the foot of Å¿ome Southern and EaÅ¿tern Wall, that we may have Å¿ome of them Cabbage for our Å¿pending in Lent, and during the whole Months of April and May.

We bind up our Cellery with one or two bands below, and then we raiÅ¿e a Butt or Bank about it, either with very dry long Dung, or with very dry Earth, to whiten it; but we muÅ¿t have a care not to tie it up but in very dry weather.
