The Å¿ame caution muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erved in all Plants that are to be tied, after which, we cut off the extreamity of the Leaves, to prevent the Å¿ap from aÅ¿cending and Å¿pending it Å¿elf to no purpoÅ¿e, by which means it is kept down in the Buried Plant, and makes it grow thick.
We alÅ¿o now tie up the Leaves of Å¿ome Collyflowers whoÅ¿e Fruit Å¿eems to begin to be formed.
We cover with compoÅ¿t, the Sorrel which has been cut.

We Å¿ow Maches for Lent, and for Reponces, it is not worth the while to Å¿ow them in a Garden becauÅ¿e there are enough of them in the Spring time, to be found in the Corn Fields, and by hedge Å¿ides.
It is particularly in the Month, and during all Autumn, that Gard'ners moÅ¿t deÅ¿ire rain.
We continue to deÅ¿troy Flies and WaÅ¿ps that eat the Figs, MuÅ¿cat Grapes, and Pears, and other Fruits, &c. with Bottles, or Cucurbit GlaÅ¿Å¿es of Honied Water.
We Å¿ow Poppies and Larks Heels in Flower Gardens, to have them Flower in June, and July, before them that are Å¿own in March.

In this Month, and the precedent one, we replant Endive among Cabbage Lettuces, theÅ¿e latter having commonly performed their duty, before the Endive is come to its full growth. Waterings muÅ¿t be continued as long as the weather is Hot and dry.

Good Winter Endive, if our Garden be in a Å¿andy Soil, muÅ¿t be Å¿own from the middle of AuguÅ¿t, to St. Lambert's Day, which is the Å¿eventeenth of this Month; and if it be in a Å¿tronger and heavier Soil, it muÅ¿t be Å¿own a little Å¿ooner, and that always very thin, that in a Month's time, it may grow big enough to remove, that is to Å¿ay, about as thick as ones Finger. It Å¿hould be planted till the middle of September, at Å¿ix or Å¿even Inches diÅ¿tance between Plant and Plant, that it may be replanted a Å¿econd time, and that nearer together, afterwards, at the beginning of September two or three Inches deep in the Earth, if it be dry and Å¿andy, or at leaÅ¿t in a Å¿loping Ground, without cutting off any thing from the Root, which has produced a little tuft, and it muÅ¿t
be covered in froÅ¿ty weather, to prevent the cold from rotting it to the very Heart, which caution being obÅ¿erved, it will keep till Lent, whereas Endive that is come to its full growth before the bitter cold weather, will not keep at all in Winter.

div.head: Works to be done in October.
div.p: WE continue the Å¿ame Works as in the preceeding Month, except Graffing, the SeaÅ¿on for which is now paÅ¿t, but we are particularly buÅ¿ie in preparing Cellery and Cardons; we plant a great many Winter Lettuces, and Å¿ome too upon old Hot Beds, to force them Å¿o as to have them good for our eating about Martlemas.
At the beginning of the Month, till the tenth or twelfth day, we Å¿ow Å¿ome Spinage to be ready for the Rogation SeaÅ¿on.
We alÅ¿o Å¿ow our laÅ¿t Chervil upon the Ground, that it may be come up before the great FroÅ¿ts, and may yield Seed betimes the next Year.

At the very beginning of this Month, if we did not do it at the beginning of the laÅ¿t, we take down our Hot Beds, and apply our Å¿elves to making of Stacks or large Cocks of the mouldieÅ¿t Dung, to raiÅ¿e MuÅ¿hrooms on.

We plant Winter Cabbages on thoÅ¿e Stacks, we lay aÅ¿ide all the Mold or made Earth, to uÅ¿e again when we make new Hot Beds, and we carry away the rotteneÅ¿t Dung to thoÅ¿e Grounds that are to be dunged.

About the middle of October, we carry back into their HouÅ¿es our Orange-Trees, TuberoÅ¿es, and JaÅ¿mins, placing them there with Å¿ome agreeable Symmetry, leaving the Windows open in the day, Å¿o long as it freezes not, but keeping them always carefully Å¿hut at Night, till at laÅ¿t we Å¿hut them up quite, and carefully dam up both them and the Doors.
We lay the TuberoÅ¿e Pots upon their Sides to drain them from the Water, that the Roots of thoÅ¿e plants may not rot in them.
We begin to plant all Å¿orts of Trees as Å¿oon as their Leaves are fallen.

We Å¿till continue to plant a great many Winter Lettuces in Å¿ome well Å¿heltered Place, and on Å¿ome good Borders, at Å¿ix or Å¿even Inches diÅ¿tance one from the other, there uÅ¿ually periÅ¿hing enough of them to prevent our Complaints of their growing too thick together.
Towards the middle of October, the FloriÅ¿ts plant their Tulips, and all other Bulbous Roots not yet Å¿et into the Ground.

In this Month we muÅ¿t perform our laÅ¿t manuring and turning up of Å¿trong, heavy, and moiÅ¿t Grounds, as well to deÅ¿troy the Weeds, and give an Air of neatneÅ¿s and agreeableneÅ¿s to our Gardens in this SeaÅ¿on, when the Country is more viÅ¿ited by all the World than at any other time, as to make that Å¿ort of Ground timely contract a kind of CruÅ¿t, that may hinder the Winter waters from Å¿o eaÅ¿ily penetrating them, and on the contrary, may Å¿hoot them off down to places of a lower Situation.
We continue our HoÅ¿tilities againÅ¿t the WaÅ¿ps that deÅ¿troy the Figs and Grapes, and the good Plums and Pears, &c.
We cut old Chervil, that it may Å¿pring afreÅ¿h.

It is convenient to begin to Å¿ow now in Å¿ome well Å¿heltered place towards the South or EaÅ¿t, or elÅ¿e upon Hot Beds, thoÅ¿e Sallets, &c. that are to be made uÅ¿e of in Winter, or early in the Spring, upon Condition they be well covered when Å¿own, againÅ¿t the cold, when it Å¿hall be time.

div.head: Works to be done in November.
div.p: IN this Month we begin to force an Artificial Spring by the means of our Hot Beds, upon which we Å¿ow little Sallets, viz. Small Lettuce to cut, Chervil, CreÅ¿Å¿es, &c.

We plant Lettuce to Cabbage, under Bells or GlaÅ¿s Frames, and we replant upon them, Mint, Tarragon and Balm Plants, and Å¿ome Sorrel, wild Endive or Succory, and Macedonian ParÅ¿ly. We alÅ¿o Å¿ow in them Peas, Beans, ParÅ¿ly, and Burnet, and if the weather Å¿till continue pretty fair, we make an end of planting Lettuces in places of good Å¿helter.

This is peculiarly the Month of the greateÅ¿t Work and Labour of all, in order to the avoiding the inconvenience of wanting Garden neceÅ¿Å¿aries, which is an ordinary Companion in this dead SeaÅ¿on, to thoÅ¿e that have been wanting in timely foreÅ¿ight; for in
earneÅ¿t the Cold fails not to make great Havock in the Gardens of the lazy; and therefore at the very beginning of the Month, how flatteringly fair Å¿oever the weather appear, there muÅ¿t be Å¿ome dry long Dung brought and laid near the Endive, Artichokes, Chard Beets, Cellery, Leeks, Roots, &c. that being ready at hand, it may with the more facility in few hours be thrown upon every thing that needs it, to prevent their deÅ¿truction; and aÅ¿Å¿oon as ever the Cold begins to declare it Å¿elf, we muÅ¿t begin to cover our Fig-Trees.

Now is the proper time to make Plantations of all Å¿orts of Trees, and of GooÅ¿e-berry, Curran, and RaÅ¿p-berry Shrubs, and 'tis good to continue on till the end of March, unleÅ¿s it be when it Freezes hard, or when the Earth is covered with a great deal of Snow.

During all the Å¿ame time, we Å¿et Trees and Shrubs in Baskets, which we diÅ¿poÅ¿e of in Å¿ome particular place, and eÅ¿pecially towards the Northern quarter. We Å¿et in them Standards as well as Dwarfs, keeping an exact account in writing of the order of the Å¿everal kinds. TheÅ¿e Baskets are to be placed at half a foot diÅ¿tance one from the other, and muÅ¿t be Å¿o well interred, that but juÅ¿t their Brims at moÅ¿t may be diÅ¿cerned above Ground: And we couch in thoÅ¿e Baskets, Å¿uch Trees as are deÅ¿igned for Wall-Trees, juÅ¿t in the Å¿ame manner as if we were actually planting them by Walls, and thoÅ¿e which are deÅ¿igned to be planted in the open Air, we place upright in the middle of the Baskets.

AÅ¿Å¿oon as the FroÅ¿ts begin to appear, we begin to uÅ¿e the long Dung which we have been carefull to order to be brought and laid ready in needfull places; for example, if it be for Artichokes, we may keep them a little elevated towards the North, to Å¿erve them inÅ¿tead of a Å¿mall Å¿helter, till we cover them quite, or elÅ¿e if we be preÅ¿Å¿ed with work to be done elÅ¿ewhere, we cover them preÅ¿ently, always taking care however before we cover them, to cut off all that is withered from them. A little of this Dung Å¿erves againÅ¿t the firÅ¿t attacks, but we redouble our coverings as the Cold augments. They which are not provided with that Å¿ort of dry Dung, may uÅ¿e inÅ¿tead of it, Å¿uch dry Leaves as are gathered up in the neighbouring Woods.

If we have a mind to whiten for Chards any of the biggeÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e Artichoke Plants, we tie them below with two or three Bands, and then we wrap them about with long dry Dung, or Å¿traw, which we bind over them again, as we have already directed when we were Å¿peaking of Cardons.
In dry Soils, we earth up a little our Artichokes, which would be pernicious in wet Grounds, becauÅ¿e it would rot the Artichoke Plants.

It is convenient to let the Artichokes alone Å¿o covered till the full Moon of March be paÅ¿t, that being commonly very dangerous; and many Gard'ners are the cauÅ¿e of the loÅ¿s of their Artichokes, when they let themÅ¿elves be tempted by Å¿ome fair days in March, to take off their coverings quite, and to proceed to manuring them; for if we uncover them, it Å¿hould at moÅ¿t, be but a little, and we Å¿hould always have that caution, to leave the Dung cloÅ¿e by them, to be ready at hand to cover them again, in caÅ¿e the FroÅ¿t returns.

At the very beginning of the Month, before the FroÅ¿ts be come, we make an end of tying up our Endive that is big enough to Å¿uffer it, and we cover it with what we can get: we alÅ¿o cover our other Endive in the Å¿ame manner, which we could not tie up. It likewiÅ¿e whitens equally well; and it is very convenient, if we have a conÅ¿ervatory, to plant as many as we can of the biggeÅ¿t of them there, in tufts, as we Å¿hall further Å¿hew afterwards.

We cut down AÅ¿paragus Å¿talks when the Seed is Ripe, which we carefully lay up, if we be minded to Å¿ow any of them in the following Spring. It would be dangerous to cut thoÅ¿e Å¿talks Å¿ooner, as well becauÅ¿e of Å¿poiling the Seed, as the plants or Å¿tocks themÅ¿elves, which might by that means be irritated to an abortion, and producing before their time, Å¿ome pitiful Å¿orry little new Å¿hoots.

We take the advantage of Å¿ome fair dry weather, to lay up all we have a mind to keep for our Winters proviÅ¿ion; and for that effect, we take up the plants in tufts, with Earth hanging to them, before they be FroÅ¿t bitten, and plant them very cloÅ¿e to one another in the ConÅ¿ervatory, which are for Example, all Roots, as Carrots, ParÅ¿nips, and Beet-raves, or Red Beet Roots, and Artichokes, which have Fruit. The Green ones are more proper for this purpoÅ¿e than the Violet ones, which are more tender and leÅ¿s able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the FroÅ¿t, and more apt to putrefie in that part next their Å¿tem, than the others which are more ruÅ¿tical and hardy. And alÅ¿o SpaniÅ¿h Cardons, Collyflowers and Endive or Succory, as well the White, as the Wild Å¿ort, and even Leeks and Cellery, though both
theÅ¿e laÅ¿t will keep well enough in the naked Earth, when they are well covered: But here it is to be noted, that Cellery when once whitened muÅ¿t be eaten preÅ¿ently, otherwiÅ¿e it would rot; And we muÅ¿t be carefull to raiÅ¿e Å¿ome of it late, that may remain Å¿mall in the Earth, without being very much covered, which Å¿erves for the latter end of February and the Month of March.

ThoÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons who live near Woods, will do well to gather up the leaves there, not only to make uÅ¿e of for coverings, as I have Å¿aid, but likewiÅ¿e to lay them to rot in Å¿ome hole, the powder of them being very good, and eÅ¿pecially to make uÅ¿e of for mold.

We now open and lay bare the Roots of Trees that Å¿eem to languiÅ¿h, in order to take from about them the old Soil, cut off as much of their Roots as is found in an ill condition, and Earth them up again afterwards with good new Earth.

We make Å¿ome Hot Beds for MuÅ¿hrooms. The method to make them well, is to chooÅ¿e Å¿ome Å¿pot of new, and as near as can be, light and Å¿andy Ground, and dig there a hollow Bed of five or Å¿ix Inches deep, of three or four wide throughout, and of what length we pleaÅ¿e. The Dung muÅ¿t be either of HorÅ¿e, or Mule, and muÅ¿t be already pretty dry, and Å¿uch as has been piled up Å¿ome time: Then we make the Bed about two foot high, ranking and preÅ¿Å¿ing the Dung as cloÅ¿e and tight as we can, yet Å¿o diÅ¿poÅ¿ing it that the upper part of it may be raiÅ¿ed into a ridge like the Back of an AÅ¿Å¿e, that it may the better Å¿hoot off the waters to the right and left, which if they Å¿hould pierce through it, would rot the Dung; after that, we cover the Bed to the thickneÅ¿s of two foot more, with the Neighbouring Earth, over which again, we throw another covering of three or four Inches thick of Litter, which in the Winter may guard from the great Cold, and in the Summer, Å¿hade from the violent heat the MuÅ¿hrooms which may be expected to Å¿hoot up about three or four Months after.
We cleanÅ¿e Trees of MoÅ¿s that are troubled with it.
They which have great Plantations of Trees to prune, Å¿hould now begin that operation upon thoÅ¿e which are leaÅ¿t vigorous.

We employ the long dry Dung of which we ought to have made proviÅ¿ion in the Summer, to cover our Fig-Trees, as well thoÅ¿e of the Wall, as Dwarfs; and for theÅ¿e laÅ¿t, we tie all their Branches as cloÅ¿e as we can conveniently, together with OÅ¿ier Withs, that we may the more eaÅ¿ily wrap them about with this covering; and for the Wall-Trees, we endeavour to leave Å¿o many of the higher Branches as we can, on the Å¿ides, and to tie Å¿everal of them together to poles or forked Å¿ticks that are to Å¿erve them for Props, and by that means too, we cover them with more eaÅ¿e, and leÅ¿s charge. We leave on them that covering till the full Moon of March be paÅ¿t, at which time, we only take off part of it, till the full Moon of April be likewiÅ¿e paÅ¿t, the FroÅ¿ts of theÅ¿e two laÅ¿t Months being dangerous to the young Fruit which then begins to put forth it Å¿elf, as the Winter FroÅ¿ts are to the Wood which they make to turn all into Pith.

They whoÅ¿e Pear-Trees are peÅ¿tered with Tiger Babbs, will do well now, not only to gather up the Leaves that are attack'd by them, to burn them immediately, but alÅ¿o to Å¿crape their Branches with the back of a Knife to clear them of the Eggs or Seed of that CurÅ¿ed InÅ¿ect, which remains Å¿ticking to them all Winter, for though we cannot Å¿o far prevail that way, as totally to exterminate them, yet however there will be Å¿o many Enemies deÅ¿troyed, as we deÅ¿troy of thoÅ¿e Eggs.

The days being now very Å¿hort, skilful Gard'ners will therefore work by Candlelight till Supper time, either in making of Straw-Screens and Coverings, or preparing Trees for planting, as Å¿oon as the FroÅ¿t permits them, or in deÅ¿igning, &c.

We put thoÅ¿e Trees into the Earth in furrows which we could not plant, covering up their Roots as carefully as if we were planting them in their deÅ¿igned places, without leaving any hollow Chinks about their Roots, becauÅ¿e otherwiÅ¿e the great FroÅ¿t would Å¿poil them.

We may begin at the latter end of the Month to force Å¿uch AÅ¿paragus, as are at leaÅ¿t three or four years old, and this forcing is performed, either on the cold Bed in the place where they grow, which is the beÅ¿t way, or elÅ¿e upon a Hot Bed, if we be minded to remove them. But ordinarily we Å¿tay till towards the beginning of the next Month, before we make any EÅ¿Å¿ays of that kind, it being in my Opinion, long enough to have of them for four Months together by Artifice, till Nature be ready to furniÅ¿h us with more of them for two Months longer by her own Å¿ole Virtue and Power, not but that we might begin to force them at the very beginning of September or October.

The way of forcing them is, to dig the Earth out of a Path, to the depth of two Foot, and the breadth of one full foot and a half, if originally the Path were but three Foot over, becauÅ¿e there muÅ¿t be at leaÅ¿t Å¿ix or Å¿even good inches of Earth be left next the AÅ¿paragus Tufts. The Path being thus voided, we fill it up with long hot Dung, very well ramm'd and trodden down, till it be a full foot higher than the Superficies of the Cold Bed, at the firÅ¿t making, and after fifteen days, we Å¿tir this Dung over again, mixing Å¿ome new Dung with it, the better to enable it to communicate Å¿ufficient heat to the two adjoyning Cold Beds, but if it appear too much mortified, Å¿o that the AÅ¿paragus does not Å¿hoot up briskly enough, then this recruiting of the path-way with freÅ¿h Dung and Å¿tirring, muÅ¿t be repeated afterwards as often as it Å¿hall be neceÅ¿Å¿ary, which commonly happens to be once every ten or twelve days. If there fall any great Rains or Snow, that may have too much rotted that Dung, Å¿o that it appears not to retain a Å¿ufficient heat, then muÅ¿t it be quite taken away, and all new put in its place; for in fine, this Bed muÅ¿t always be kept extreamly hot; as to the Cold Bed, in which the Plants are, the Ground muÅ¿t be digged up, and Å¿tirred a little in it, to the depth of about four or five Inches, as Å¿oon as the path-way is filled up, for it cannot be done before, becauÅ¿e of bringing the Dung to that, (which cannot be done without much trampling on the Soil) which digging being finiÅ¿hed, we cover the Å¿aid Cold Bed with Å¿ome of the Å¿ame long Dung, to the thickneÅ¿s of three or four Inches, and at the end of fifteen days, Å¿o much time at leaÅ¿t being neceÅ¿Å¿ary to give activity to thoÅ¿e AÅ¿paragus Tufts, that in this SeaÅ¿on, are as 'twere dead, or at leaÅ¿t benumbed with the cold, we lift up the Dung to Å¿ee whether the AÅ¿paragus begin to Å¿hoot or no, and if they do, at every place where they appear, we clap a GlaÅ¿s Bell, which we alÅ¿o take great care to cover cloÅ¿e with long Dung, and eÅ¿pecially a-nights, to prevent the FroÅ¿t from penetrating in the leaÅ¿t manner in the World, to the AÅ¿paragus, which being Å¿o extreamly tender and delicate as 'tis, would be abÅ¿olutely Å¿poiled by the leaÅ¿t breath of Cold. If in the day time, the Sun Å¿hine out a little bright, we muÅ¿t not fail to take off the Dung from the Bells, that the AÅ¿paragus may be viÅ¿ited by thoÅ¿e kindly beams that animate all things, and if beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e Bells, we had likewiÅ¿e GlaÅ¿s Frames to clap over them, and Å¿o doubly to cover whole Beds of Plants, that would Å¿till be more commodious and more advantageous for bringing to effect this little MaÅ¿ter-piece of our Art. By theÅ¿e helps, the AÅ¿paragus Å¿pringing out of that warm Earth, and meeting with a warm Air under thoÅ¿e Bells, grow red and green, and of the Å¿ame thickneÅ¿s and length as thoÅ¿e of the Mont â¢ s of April and May; nay, and prove a great deal better too, becauÅ¿e they have not only been unattack'd by the injuries of the Air, but have attained their perfection in much leÅ¿s time than the others, and I can without vanity affirm, that I was the firÅ¿t that by the inducement of Å¿ome very plauÅ¿ible ReaÅ¿ons, deviÅ¿ed this expedient, to oblige the greateÅ¿t King in the World, with a PleaÅ¿ure before to him unknown.

I add here, that a Bed of AÅ¿paragus dextrouÅ¿ly forced, and well maintained, produces abundantly enough for a Fortnight or three Weeks, and that becauÅ¿e the King Å¿hould not want during the whole Winter, this new DiÅ¿h which he beholds with Å¿o gracious an Eye, as Å¿oon as the firÅ¿t Beds begin to furniÅ¿h him, I begin to force as many new ones, and Å¿o continue the Å¿ame courÅ¿e every three Weeks, till the end of April, when Nature advertiÅ¿es me, that 'tis time to put an end to thoÅ¿e Violences I have done Her, and that Å¿he is then willing in her Turn, to Å¿erve us Å¿ome DiÅ¿hes prepared by her own skill.

I can likewiÅ¿e tell you, that though my Beds are but â¢ i â¢ teen ToiÅ¿es or Fathoms long, and that I force but Å¿ix at a time, yet there is Å¿pent on them each time, at leaÅ¿t fifty Cart loads of Dung, and that the only Vexation I meet with in this Work, is to Å¿ee an infinite number of GlaÅ¿s Bells broke with covering and uncovering them every day, in Å¿pite of all the care I can take to prevent it.

We may likewiÅ¿e remove old AÅ¿paragus Plants out of Cold Beds into Hot ones, it being true that they Å¿pring there, but they never prove Å¿o fair as the others, and are attended beÅ¿ides with this inconvenience, that they die there in a very Å¿hort time.

We force Sorrel and Wild Endive, or Succory, Macedonian ParÅ¿ly or AliÅ¿anders, &c. in the Å¿ame manner as we do AÅ¿paragus, but moÅ¿t commonly it is done rather upon Hot Beds, than on the naked Earth, and the SucceÅ¿s is very Å¿peedy and infallible, and particularly in procuring in one fifteen days time, Sorrel that is as fair as that of the Month of May.

We Å¿hould have finiÅ¿hed our laÅ¿t manuring of dry Grounds the fifteenth day of this Month, as well to render them impenetrable to the Rain and Snow waters, as to deÅ¿troy the Weeds, and to make our Gardens appear Å¿omething neat and handÅ¿ome.

We preÅ¿erve in their places, or rather we tranÅ¿plant in Turfs, Å¿uch Cabbages as we deÅ¿ign for Seed; and if in the Month of April, we perceive they meet with any difficulty in making their way, we muÅ¿t help them by giving the Cabbage a cut croÅ¿s-wiÅ¿e on the Head pretty deep, by which means the Seed Å¿tem will the more eaÅ¿ily paÅ¿s. We do the Å¿ame thing in May to Å¿ome Å¿orts of Cabbage Lettuce, which have much ado otherwiÅ¿e to run up to Seed.

To have RadiÅ¿hes betimes, that is, towards ChriÅ¿tmas, or Candlemas, we Å¿ow them in Hot Beds about the middle of November. I have already laid down directions for the making of Hot Beds, in the works of February: That which is particularly to be obÅ¿erved for RadiÅ¿hes, is that we muÅ¿t beat down with a board, the Superficies of the mold, to render it a little Å¿olid, and to prevent it from rowling into the holes that are to be made to Sow the RadiÅ¿hes in, after which, that the Bed may be handÅ¿omly Sown, we take a cord rubbed with PlaÅ¿ter, or Chalk, or other white matter, and holding it well Å¿tretched out between two of us, we mark out with it as many white lines, at three or four Inches diÅ¿tance one from another, both throughout the whole length and breadth of the Bed, as its extent will permit, and then with a round wooden planting Å¿tick of a full Inch thick, we make holes all along every line at the like diÅ¿tance of three or four Inches one from another, and we put only three RadiÅ¿h Seeds into every hole, and if we chance to let fall any more we pull up all the RadiÅ¿hes that come up above the number of three. They which obÅ¿erve not to mark out Å¿uch lines, but make their holes by random-Å¿ight only, have their Beds not Å¿o handÅ¿ome, and they which make their holes nearer, and which leave more than three RadiÅ¿hes in a hole, run the hazard of having RadiÅ¿hes with a great many leaves and but little Root, there are many Market Gard'ners whoÅ¿e practiÅ¿e it is, to Sow lines or rows of Lett â¢ ces in February and March, a croÅ¿s their Beds of RadiÅ¿hes, but then the holes muÅ¿t be made at the diÅ¿tance of Å¿even or eight Inches; and the Lett â¢ ces thus Å¿own in lines, will be gathered and Å¿pent, before the RadiÅ¿hes are fit to gather.

If it freezes very hard we cover the Hot Bed, with long Å¿teeped Straw, for five or Å¿ix days, beÅ¿ides which, for its further defence againÅ¿t the rigours of the Winter, wecover them with Straw-Screens or coverings, Å¿upported upon TraverÅ¿e Frame â¢
or Cradles compoÅ¿ed of Stakes, or other Poles of Wood, placed very near the Superficies of the mold, and we Å¿top the Å¿ides cloÅ¿e up, and if the FroÅ¿t increaÅ¿e notably, we put a new load of long dung over thoÅ¿e Straw-Screens, but if it be but moderate, there will need no other covering, the heat of the Bed being Å¿ufficient to defend the Plants; RadiÅ¿hes thus Å¿own come up in five or Å¿ix days, and if the holes had not Å¿ome Air, they would be Å¿moothed and grow dwinling in piercing through the Å¿mall Straw.

We muÅ¿t not fail at the beginning of this Month, to take up in Turf, the Cellery which we had planted at a reaÅ¿onable diÅ¿tance, in the Months of June and July, in particular Cold Beds; and when we have taken it up, to carry it into the ConÅ¿ervatory, or elÅ¿e to replant it in Å¿ome other Cold Bed, placing its Plants very cloÅ¿e together, that they may the more eaÅ¿ily be covered.

AÅ¿Å¿oon as the White FroÅ¿ts Å¿eem to be Å¿etled, we muÅ¿t cover our Winter-Lettuces which are planted in well Å¿heltred places, but not with dry Dung as other Plants, for fear Å¿ome of the filth Å¿hould get into the heart of thoÅ¿e that Cabbage, but with very clean Straw, upon which we lay Å¿ome long pole of Wood, to keep it in its place, and hinder the wind from blowing it off.

div.head: Works to be done in December.
div.p:
IF it be a pertinent caution I have given at the beginning of every Month, That we ought then to be careful to finiÅ¿h what we could not do in the preceeding Month, it is particularly neceÅ¿Å¿ary to repeat it at the beginning of this Month, with reÅ¿pect to that which laÅ¿t expired. AÅ¿Å¿oon as December is come it is no longer time to dally. For now the Earth in Gardens is quite Å¿trip'd of all its uÅ¿ual ornaments, and the FroÅ¿t that Å¿eldom fails to Å¿ignalize it Å¿elf this Month, without reÅ¿pecting the quality of their MaÅ¿ters, Å¿pares no bodies Gardens, but unmercifully deÅ¿troys all it meets with of a nature too delicate to endure its rigour; and therefore it concerns us now to make an end of houÅ¿ing and of covering what we could not houÅ¿e or cover in the Month of November, viz. Endive, Cardons, Cellery, Artichokes, Roots, Collyflowers, Chard-Beets, Leeks, Fig-Trees, &c. And above all things, we muÅ¿t be careful to preÅ¿erve thoÅ¿e Novelties which we may have begun to advance by Art, as Peas, Beans, Cabbage, Lettuce, and little Sallets,
to avoid the diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure of Å¿eeing periÅ¿h in one bitter Night, what we have been labouring two or three Months to advance.

We may likewiÅ¿e Å¿till at the beginning of the Month, continue to Å¿ow Å¿ome early Peas, upon Å¿ome banks made of Earth raiÅ¿ed in double Å¿lopes along by Å¿ome Wall placed in a good ExpoÅ¿ition, and eÅ¿pecially that towards the South.

We tranÅ¿port our rotten Dung to thoÅ¿e places we deÅ¿ign to muck, and Å¿pread them abroad there, that the rain and Snow waters may the better penetrate them, and carry their Salt a little below the Superficies of the Earth where our Seeds are to be Å¿own.

We interr our Almonds in Å¿ome Basket, to Sprout. They Å¿hould have Å¿prouted by the Month of March, to be ready then to be planted in their allotted places. It is convenient to prevent the great FroÅ¿t from coming at them; for which end the Baskets muÅ¿t be houÅ¿ed up in the ConÅ¿ervatory, or elÅ¿e well covered with long Dung if left in the naked Earth. The way to lay theÅ¿e Almonds to Å¿prout, is firÅ¿t to lay at the bottom of the Basket, a layer of Sand, Earth or mold, or made Earth between two and three Inches thick, and to lay a Layer of flat Almonds, upon it with their Å¿harp ends inwards, till its firÅ¿t layer of Earth be quite covered with the layer of Almonds, upon which we lay a Å¿econd layer of Mold or Sand of two Inches thick, and then upon that again a Å¿econd layer of Almonds placed in the Å¿ame manner as the firÅ¿t, and Å¿o a third and fourth, &c. till the Basket will hold no more.

It is likewiÅ¿e not amiÅ¿s to put one Å¿ingle layer of Almonds into the naked-Earth, and to cover them with Earth, to the thickneÅ¿s of about three Inches: When they begin to come up at the latter end of April, we take them in up Turfs, that is, with Å¿ome Earth hanging to them, and breaking off their Å¿prouts, we replant them in their deÅ¿igned places, in rows diÅ¿tant one from another, a foot and a half, and in thoÅ¿e rows, the Almonds muÅ¿t be placed at the diÅ¿tance of half a foot from each other.
We are buÅ¿ie in making trails for Wall-Trees.

We may prune Trees as long as there is no Icicles, or hoar upon the Branches, and as the hard FroÅ¿ts do not raign, for they harden the Wood Å¿o that the pruning knife cannot eaÅ¿ily paÅ¿s: Always obÅ¿erving that we muÅ¿t never prune Wall-Trees without unnailing them, becauÅ¿e it would be too troubleÅ¿om to do it otherwiÅ¿e, neither can we Å¿o well diÅ¿cern what Work we are to do.

One of the moÅ¿t principal Works of this Month, is, at the beginning of it, to make a Hot Bed of long new Dung of the ordinary breadth of four foot, and height of three, and aÅ¿Å¿oon as its great heat is Å¿pent, we muÅ¿t Å¿ow upon it, under GlaÅ¿s Bells, Å¿ome good bright Curled Lettuce, and aÅ¿Å¿oon as 'tis grown a little big, which uÅ¿ually happens in a Month's time, we muÅ¿t take up the faireÅ¿t, and plant it in a NurÅ¿ery upon another Hot Bed, and under other Bells, to the number of twenty, or twenty five under every Bell, and when they are grown reaÅ¿onably big there too, we muÅ¿t take up the biggeÅ¿t with a little Earth about them, to replant them to the number of five or Å¿ix under each Bell, to remain there till they be quite Cabbaged, which uÅ¿ually happens towards the latter end of March, and we take care to fence them well from the Cold, as well with coverings of Litter, as by new heating their Beds.

We practiÅ¿e the Å¿ame method in Å¿owing theÅ¿e Lettuces in the Month of January, and in replanting in February, that we may have Å¿ome ready betimes, that is, towards the end of March, and to continue Å¿o doing till the Earth produces us Å¿ome of her Å¿elf, without the help of Hot Dung. At this time they that employ themÅ¿elves in rearing Novelties, Å¿pend the moÅ¿t part of each day in covering them at night, and uncovering them in the morning, or elÅ¿e all comes to nothing.

When in the Winter time, we are raiÅ¿ing and forcing of Lettuce upon Hot Beds, and under Bells, we muÅ¿t be careful often to lift up the Bells, to take away the dead Leaves, there being a great many that rot and periÅ¿h, and one rotten Leaf rots others. The inÅ¿ide of the Bells muÅ¿t alÅ¿o be cleanÅ¿ed from the filth and moiÅ¿ture that gathers there in abundance, and when there comes a fair Sun Å¿hiny day, we muÅ¿t not fail to lift up the Bells, that the moiÅ¿ture may be dryed up that Å¿ticks about the Leaves. But the chiefeÅ¿t thing to be obÅ¿erved above all, is to keep the Beds moderately hot, by recruiting and new heating, and fermenting them from time to time.

div.head: ProviÅ¿ions and Products we may have from our Gardens in the Month of January.
div.p: BEÅ¿ides the good Pears following, viz. LeÅ¿chaÅ¿Å¿eries, Ambrets, Thorn Pears, St. Germains, Dry Martins, Virgoulees, and Winter Boncretiens, &c. and theÅ¿e good Apples, viz. Calvils, Pippins, Ap â¢ 's, Courpendu's, or Å¿hort Å¿talkt Apples, Fennellets, or Fennel-Apples, &c. All Å¿orts of Roots, as Beet-raves, or Red Beet-Roots, Scorzonera's, Carrots, ParÅ¿nips, common SalÅ¿ifies, or Goat's Beard, Turneps, &c.

We may likewiÅ¿e have little RadiÅ¿hes upon Hot Beds, provided the abundance of Snow, and the rigour of the FroÅ¿ts be not Å¿o terrible great, that we cannot for Å¿o much as a few hours in a day, uncover the Beds on which they are, nor give them any new Recruits of heat, without which, all that is planted of this Å¿ort, on Hot Beds, is Å¿ubject to grow yellow, and come to nothing.

We have now naturally but few Flowers, except thoÅ¿e of Laurel-Time, or Laurus Thymus, and Snow drops, but by the help of Hot Beds, we may have Å¿ome Å¿ingle Anemonies, Winter NarciÅ¿Å¿us's, and NarciÅ¿Å¿us's of ConÅ¿tantinople, Crocus's, &c. div.head: ProviÅ¿ions and Products of February.
div.p: THE Weather uÅ¿ually begins to grow a little milder this Month, Å¿o that as to Flowers, we may now naturally by the favour of a good Shelter and a good ExpoÅ¿ition, have of all thoÅ¿e Å¿orts which I told you in my DiÅ¿courÅ¿e of the Products of the laÅ¿t Month, might be raiÅ¿ed by forcing on Hot Beds. BeÅ¿ides which, we may have Å¿ome PrimroÅ¿es, and the heat of the Hot Beds may even produce us Å¿ome Tulips, and Totus Albus's.

But in reÅ¿pect of Kitchen-plants, we have as yet only thoÅ¿e things which we have before mentioned; that is to Å¿ay, we continue to Å¿pend the Stock we have in the ConÅ¿ervatory or Store-houÅ¿e, and what we raiÅ¿e by the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of our Hot Beds, and artificial heatings, as little Sallets, Sorrel, RadiÅ¿hes, AÅ¿paragus, &c.

div.head: ProviÅ¿ions and Products of March.
div.p: VVE have now upon our Hot Beds, abundance of RadiÅ¿hes, and little Sallets, and of Sorrel, and Cabbage Lettuces under Bells, which are the bright curled Lettuces Å¿own in November and December, and afterwards tranÅ¿planted into other Hot Beds. div.head: ProviÅ¿ions and Products of April.
div.p: VVE have now abundance of RadiÅ¿hes, Spinage, and Sallets with their Furnitures, and other edible Herbs.

We have likewiÅ¿e at the very beginning of the Month, bright curled Cabbage Lettuces, if we have taken care to raiÅ¿e any upon Hot Beds, otherwiÅ¿e we have none, for the Winter Lettuces are not as yet Cabbaged.

div.head: ProviÅ¿ions and Products of May.
div.p: IT is now the time of the flouriÅ¿hing Reign of all Å¿orts of Verdures and Green things, and of Sallets, RadiÅ¿hes, AÅ¿paragus, and Cucumbers as to their plenty and abundance. Peas and Strawberries now begin to come in, and we may and ought to have of thoÅ¿e Å¿orts of Long Lettuces call'd Alfanges, and white Chicons, provided we have had timely care to raiÅ¿e Å¿ome upon Hot Beds, and early to tranÅ¿plant them, either in other Hot Beds, or elÅ¿e in the naked Earth in Å¿ome well expoÅ¿ed place.

ThlaÅ¿pi or Treacle MuÅ¿tard of two Å¿orts, the great and little MuÅ¿cipula's, Valerians, Toute-Bonnes, or Algoods, or Good Harries, Poets Gillyflowers, both the white and Carnations, yellow Willow Herbs, or LooÅ¿e-Å¿trifes, Lady-Gloves; and towards the middle of June, Roman Chervil, Orange Flowers, TuberoÅ¿es, Å¿ingle Anemonies, MignardiÅ¿es, and Marine, or Sea violets.

div.head: ProviÅ¿ions and Products of July.

argument.p: How to judge certainly by viewing and viÅ¿iting a Kitchen-Garden, whether there be any thing wanting in it, which it Å¿hould be Å¿tockt with.

div.p:
IT is no inconÅ¿iderable thing to underÅ¿tand certainly, not only what ProviÅ¿ions a Kitchen-Garden well maintained and ordered may furniÅ¿h us with every Month in the Year, but likewiÅ¿e what works are to be done there in every SeaÅ¿on, by an able Gard'ner, but yet that is not enough to make a Gentleman Å¿o knowing, as to be able to give himÅ¿elf the PleaÅ¿ure to judge certainly by viewing of his Kitchen-Garden, whether it be indeed Å¿o well Å¿tockt or no, as to want nothing that it Å¿hould have. For in fine, we muÅ¿t not expect always actually to find init, all the advantages we are beholding to Gardens for. We know indeed, that it Å¿hould bring forth a proviÅ¿ion for the whole Year, but we know very well too, that it does not bring forth all days in the Year, for example, in the Winter Months we hardly Å¿ee in it any of its Productions, the moÅ¿t part of them being then carried out of it, and laid up in Store-houÅ¿es and ConÅ¿ervatories. And beÅ¿ides, among the Plants that are to be Å¿een in it at other times, how many is there which have not then attain'd to their perfection, which yet ought to make a Figure in this Garden, though they require perhaps two or three, and Å¿ometimes five or Å¿ix Months time to arrive to it? Thus it is in the beginning of the Spring, with all Legumes or Edible Plants, and green things, and thus it is too in the Summer, with the principal Fruits of the other SeaÅ¿ons, upon which ConÅ¿ideration, I thought it not impertinent nor unuÅ¿eful, to Å¿hew yet
a little more particularly wherein conÅ¿iÅ¿ts the excellency and accompliÅ¿hment of a Kitchen-Garden, judging of it acccording to the proportion of what we ought to find in it every time we go into it, and to give you the more exact and perfect an Idea of it, I will as near as I can, draw you the picture of our Kings, which is in its kind, the greateÅ¿t that ever was beheld, as its MaÅ¿ter is the greateÅ¿t Prince that ever yet appeared; not, that I exhibit this Picture to engage any PerÅ¿on to copy it, but only to direct them how by the Rules of a juÅ¿t CompariÅ¿on, and proportion of great things to little, they may take Å¿uch MeaÅ¿ures, as they Å¿hall think moÅ¿t accommodated to their own particular conveniences.

I will begin this Chapter with the Month of January, as I have done the two next preceeding ones, and Å¿hall tell you firÅ¿t, That in the Month of January, we ought to January. be very well Å¿atisfied with the Garden in QueÅ¿tion, if we find in it a reaÅ¿onable quantity of Winter Lettuces planted in Borders by Walls, and covered with long Straw, or Straw Screens. And Secondly, if we find in it Å¿ome Squares of Artichokes, and Beet-Chards well covered with long Dung, with the like proviÅ¿ion of Cellery, Endive, Common ParÅ¿ly, and Macedonian ParÅ¿ly, or AliÅ¿anders, &c. and ordered after the Å¿ame manner. And in the third place, Å¿ome Winter Cabbages, Ciboules, Sorrel, and Sallet Furnitures, and if theÅ¿e two laÅ¿t be Å¿heltred with Å¿ome Å¿ort of Covering. And if in the fourth place there be Å¿ome Å¿quares of AÅ¿paragus without any other Artifice, than what is uÅ¿ed to warm and force them in their Cold Beds, as I do, and have begun to do in November and December. All other Kitchen-plants muÅ¿t be houÅ¿ed and laid up, as Roots, Onions, Cardons, Artichokes, Collyflowers, &c. In the fifth place, we may be content if we find the Fig-Trees well covered, all places where Trees Å¿hould be, well filled up with Trees, or at leaÅ¿t, with holes digged, and Trenches prepared, ready for planting them, or the Roots of thoÅ¿e bared and laid open, that begin to languiÅ¿h, in order to their Cure. Sixthly, if we Å¿ee Men buÅ¿ie in clearing the Fruit-Trees of MoÅ¿s, and other filth that Spoils them, and if over and above that, we find there any Hot Beds for the Novelties of the Spring time, Å¿uch as are Strawberries, RadiÅ¿hes, Little Sallets, Peas, Beans, Cabbage Lettuces, ParÅ¿ly, Cucumbers, and Musk-melon Plantations, &c. If we likewiÅ¿e Å¿ee Å¿ome Fig-Trees and Å¿ome other Trees forced and advanced by artificial Warmth, what then ought we not to Å¿ay in praiÅ¿e of the Gard'ner, eÅ¿pecially if we find the Walks and Alleys kept neat and clean, and no Garden Tools or UtenÅ¿ils any where neglected?

Having told you what Å¿hould compoÅ¿e the Beauty of a Kitchen-Garden in the Month of January, I think it needleÅ¿s to add any DeÅ¿cription of what makes it imperfect and diÅ¿agreeable as well in that Month, as in all the reÅ¿t of which I Å¿hall afterwards treat, becauÅ¿e any Body may eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cern of himÅ¿elf, that 'tis juÅ¿t the contrary and reverÅ¿e of what I have juÅ¿t now Å¿pecified, that is to Å¿ay, a want of any thing that Å¿hould be in it, Negligence, SlovinglyneÅ¿s, &c. which we are to look upon as the MonÅ¿ters of Kitchen Gardens.

In the Month of February, we muÅ¿t certainly expect to Å¿ee the beginning of a great BuÅ¿tling and Activity in Garden works, we Å¿hould now find the moÅ¿t part of thoÅ¿e things February. flouriÅ¿hing, and grown pretty forward, that we told you were to be raiÅ¿ed on Hot Beds, in the preceeding Month, and if about the latter end of the Month, the Weather appear pretty temperate, and there happen Å¿o conÅ¿iderable a Thaw as to promiÅ¿e an end of the great cold, our Gard'ners Å¿hould then begin to dig and manure the Squares and the Counter Borders prepare the Cold Beds, Å¿ow thoÅ¿e Å¿orts of Seeds that are long coming up, as ParÅ¿ly, Onions, Ciboules, Leeks, &c. They muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e now earneÅ¿tly mind the pruning of Trees, as well Dwarfs, as Wall-Trees, and paliÅ¿ade or nail up theÅ¿e laÅ¿t for the firÅ¿t time, and particularly they muÅ¿t take care to make Hot Beds for the replanting of Musk-melons and Cucumbers, and for little Sallets, RadiÅ¿hes, Cabbage-Lettuces, &c.

In March, when the Sun begins to pleaÅ¿ure us with both indifferent fair, and pretty long days, and nature begins viÅ¿ibly to grow warm and active, our Gard'ners alÅ¿o Å¿hould March. with new and freÅ¿h vigour, and Application, beÅ¿tir themÅ¿elves in all parts of their Garden, and be Å¿een indefatigably to purÅ¿ue all the works I have mentioned in the particular TreatiÅ¿e I made on that Å¿ubject, and which therefore 'tis not neceÅ¿Å¿ary to repeat here again; Å¿o that if the extent of our Ground be great, and the number of Labourers proportionable, we Å¿hould have the pleaÅ¿ure with one caÅ¿t of an Eye to Å¿ee them diging, making up, Å¿owing, planting, howing, weeding, graffing, pruning, &c. for in fine, before the Month be out, the moÅ¿t part of the Ground Å¿hould be taken up either with Seeds or plants, which are to Å¿erve for proviÅ¿ion for the whole year. All that was before covered with Dung, ought to be diÅ¿charged of its coverings, which are now grown hidious, aÅ¿Å¿oon as they ceaÅ¿e to be neceÅ¿Å¿ary, and every thing ought to breath the free Air, which begins now to cheer both Animals and Plants; we Å¿hould at this time have at leaÅ¿t Å¿omething to begin to
gather, either of Sallets or RadiÅ¿hes, of the new SeaÅ¿on, if the Hot Beds of the foregoing Months have not as yet obliged us with that pleaÅ¿ure; But neatneÅ¿s and politeneÅ¿s ought particularly to glitter every where, and Å¿erve for a varniÅ¿h to all the Alleys, and the dreÅ¿Å¿ed Grounds, that together with the firÅ¿t dawning of the riÅ¿ing Green that is now Å¿pringing out of the Womb of the teeming Earth, and the perfumed breath of thoÅ¿e Plants which Heavens richer influences have made odoriferous, and the abundance of Flowers which begin to diÅ¿play their beauties on every Å¿ide, and the harmony of the pretty Birds, which a Å¿ort of extraordinary gayety and briskneÅ¿s at this time inÅ¿pires with amorous prattle, and with melodious Airs to Å¿trive to out-vie each other. This neatneÅ¿s may concurr to make a Theater of pleaÅ¿ure univerÅ¿ally perfect, which may with irreÅ¿iÅ¿tible allurements intice the curious to the divertiÅ¿ement of walking in Å¿o delicious a place.

In the Month of April, we are not to find any thing new to be done in our Kitchen-Gardens, April. unleÅ¿s it be an augmentation of Hot Beds for Musk-Melons and Cucumbers. The Earth in them Å¿hould now be covered almoÅ¿t all over with a new decoration of Infant Plants; Here we Å¿hould Å¿ee Artichokes riÅ¿ing as 'twere from the dead, and there AÅ¿paragus piercing the Ground in a thouÅ¿and places; here we Å¿hould with pleaÅ¿ure obÅ¿erve the Cabbage Lettuce wind up it Å¿elf into round Balls, and here that multitude of Green Herbs, and Legumes, Å¿o different in colour, and Å¿o various in their Å¿hapes; TheÅ¿e, theÅ¿e are the Innocent and natural Dainties which there preÅ¿ent themÅ¿elves for the nouriÅ¿hment, and Delicious entertainment of Humane kind. The Jacinth, the Tulip, the Anemone, the Ranimculus, and Å¿o many other Flowers, with what Glories do they not adorn the Gardens where they are? That which is here to be remarked, is only the ordinary maintaining of what is already done and perfected; but that which Å¿hould moÅ¿t take up our thoughts is the hopes of a future crop of Fruits, every one now being eager to run and view the Trees that Å¿hed their BloÅ¿Å¿oms, to Å¿ee whether much Fruit knit upon them or no, or elÅ¿e to viÅ¿it the Hot Beds of Musk-Melons and Cucumbers that Å¿eem to have taken well, to Å¿ee how liberally they are like to recompence them for all the pains beÅ¿towed upon them.

When the Month of May comes in, what contentment have we not in uÅ¿eful May. Gardens; and how great are the Å¿weets of enjoyment which we begin then to taÅ¿te? MuÅ¿hrooms Å¿hoot up in Crowds; and in fine, of all the things contained in the Alphabet I have premiÅ¿ed before this TreatiÅ¿e, there is hardly any but Spinage, and MÃ¢ches, that Å¿tave off the performance of their duty till AuguÅ¿t and September, for we may now Å¿ee Å¿ome little beginnings even of Endive, and if HaÅ¿ting or Early Cherries were the firÅ¿t Fruit that appeared in this Month of May, the HaÅ¿ting Apricocks, the Little MuÅ¿cat Pears, and the Avant Peaches, or Forward Peaches will not leave them long alone to enjoy the glory of being the Å¿ole Riches and Ornaments of our Gardens, all theÅ¿e Fruits being now preparing themÅ¿elves to appear in a very few days; the Musk-Melons likewiÅ¿e will not Å¿tay long behind them, &c. while the Cucumbers with an infinite number both of Lettuces and of other Plants, Å¿atisfie both our Palates and NeceÅ¿Å¿ities, as the Flowers together with the Orange-Trees, which in Mid-May we carry abroad out of their houÅ¿es, perform likewiÅ¿e their functions in delighting both our Sight and Smell.

The parching heat of the Month of June, hinders us indeed from going into our June. Garden in the heat of the day, but what charms are there not in going to viÅ¿it it Morning and Evening, when the cool breathings of a gentle Zephir reign there with Sovereign Å¿way? In theÅ¿e two Months of July and AuguÅ¿t, Kitchen-Gardens Å¿hould be Å¿o richly and happily endowed with whatÅ¿oever their condition is capable of, that we may find plenty July and AuguÅ¿t. of all things there both to Å¿atisfie the pleaÅ¿ures of the preÅ¿ent, and provide for the neceÅ¿Å¿ities of the future time, Å¿o that let us require of them what we pleaÅ¿e, they may be as ready to anÅ¿wer as we to make our Demands.

Pears, &c. we Å¿hall Å¿ee that in the Months of September and October which Å¿ucceed them, they will Å¿hew themÅ¿elves exceedingly Glorious in the matter of Fruits which will be by the abundance of Peaches, MuÅ¿cat, and ChaÅ¿Å¿ela's Grapes, of Å¿econd Figs, and of RuÅ¿Å¿elet, Butter, Verte Longue, or Long Green, and Bergamot Pears, &c. That moderate temper of the Air which now keeps an agreeable Medium between the great Heat of the Dog-days newly paÅ¿t, and the bitter Cold that is to bring on Winter; this charming moderate temper I Å¿ay, of the weather, Invites out the inhabitants of the Cities, to make a Å¿ally out to go and breath the free Air of the Countrey, and to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t at the diverting employment of the Vintage, and gathering of Fruits: And the Gardens ought now to Å¿urpaÅ¿s in an infinite quantity of all they were accuÅ¿tomed to produce in other Months, nor is it fit now to Å¿uffer one Å¿peck of Ground to lie idle. The Month of December, is Å¿till not without Å¿tanding in need of a great deal of December. activity, for it often happens that the preceeding Month proves too Å¿hort to let us finiÅ¿h all that Å¿hould be done in it, which muÅ¿t therefore be made an end of in this, and that particularly if the Cold have not yet made all the havock it is capable of: We muÅ¿t then mind exactly to do all I have directed to be done under the head of the Works of this Month; Å¿o that we Å¿hould expect to Å¿ee now a great diligence uÅ¿ed to prepare the Novelties of the following Spring; to clear the places of old Hot Beds, and to make preparation for the making of new ones with all imaginable expedition, and care taken not only to have a good proviÅ¿ion of long Dung, and a great many GlaÅ¿s-Bells, but likewiÅ¿e to keep all the GlaÅ¿s-Frames in good repair, &c. And here I Å¿hall not forget to recommend to thoÅ¿e curious perÅ¿ons who are bleÅ¿Å¿ed with the means to do it, the care to force AÅ¿paragus, and to recruit their Beds with new warmth as often as their great heat Å¿hall begin to flag. It is a work indeed of no inconÅ¿iderable pains and expence, but the pleaÅ¿ure to Å¿ee growing in the midÅ¿t of the Å¿evereÅ¿t FroÅ¿t and Snow, abundance of AÅ¿paragus, both thick, green, and every way moÅ¿t excellent, is great enough to take us off from grudging at our coÅ¿t or trouble, and it may be truly Å¿aid, that 'tis a priviledge hardly belonging to any but our King, to taÅ¿te of Å¿uch a pleaÅ¿ure as that, which is perhaps none of the leaÅ¿t which his VerÅ¿ailles has afforded him by the care I have had the honour to take of it for that effect; and I may add, that 'tis certainly the only place in the world, where a Ground naturally Cold, backward and unfruitful, was ever Å¿een to be forced to bear in the midÅ¿t of the hardeÅ¿t Winter, what the beÅ¿t Grounds produce not but in temperate SeaÅ¿ons.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: What Å¿ort of Ground is Proper to each Legume and Kitchen-Plant.

div.p:
IT is certain, there are certain Å¿orts of Grounds which want none of the good Qualities required to make them produce in every SeaÅ¿on, and for a long time together, all Å¿orts of fair and good Legumes, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing always, that they be reaÅ¿onably well cultivated: And there are Å¿ome that beÅ¿ides that, have the faculty to produce them more early Å¿ome than others, and they are Å¿uch Grounds as they commonly call Black Sands, in which is found an equal temper between dry and moiÅ¿t, accompanied with a good expoÅ¿ition, and with an inexhauÅ¿tible Salt of fertility, rendring them eaÅ¿ie to be entred by the Å¿pade, and to be penetrated by the rain waters: But on the other hand, it is no leÅ¿s certain that it is rare enough to find any of theÅ¿e perfect Å¿orts of Earth, and that on the
contrary, it is very uÅ¿ual to meet with thoÅ¿e that offend either in being too dry, light, and parching, or over moiÅ¿t, heavy and cold, or elÅ¿e by being unfortunately Å¿ituated, as being Å¿ome of them too high, Å¿ome too Å¿loping, and Å¿ome again too low, and too much in a bottom. Happy are thoÅ¿e Gard'ners that meet with thoÅ¿e firÅ¿t Å¿orts of Ground that are Å¿o admirably well diÅ¿poÅ¿ed for Cultivation, in which they have hardly ever any bad Å¿ucceÅ¿s to fear, but commonly all manner of good Fortune to expect: on the other Å¿ide unhappy, or at leaÅ¿t much to be pitied are thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e Lot it is to have always Å¿ome of the great Enemies of Vegetation to combat with, I mean, either great drought, or more eÅ¿pecially exceÅ¿Å¿ive moiÅ¿ture, becauÅ¿e this laÅ¿t, beÅ¿ides that it is always attended with a chilling cold that retards its productions, is likewiÅ¿e apt to rot the greateÅ¿t part of the Plants, and conÅ¿equently, it is very difficult to correct, and almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible entirely to Å¿urmount Å¿o great a defect, but it is not altogether Å¿o difficult to qualifie a dry temper, for provided it be not extream great, and that we have the convenience of Water to water it, and of Dung to amend and inrich it, we are MaÅ¿ters of two Soveraign and Infallible Remedies, which we muÅ¿t apply for its cure. And Å¿o by care and pains we may get the ConqueÅ¿t over thoÅ¿e dry and Å¿tubborn Lands, and force them to bring forth in abundance all things we Å¿hall regularly demand of them.

It follows thence, that when we are Å¿o happy as to meet with thoÅ¿e choice good Å¿orts of Ground, we may indifferently both Å¿ow and plant every where in them, any Å¿orts of Legumes or Plants whatÅ¿oever, with an aÅ¿Å¿ured Confidence, that they will proÅ¿per there. The only Subjection we are obliged to in Å¿uch Grounds is, firÅ¿t, to weed much, becauÅ¿e they produce abundance of Weeds among the good Herbs, and Å¿econdly to be often removing our Legumes, and changing their places, which is an eÅ¿Å¿ential point of Practice in all Å¿orts of Gardens, it being not at all convenient to place for two or three times together, the Å¿ame Vegetables in the Å¿ame piece of Ground, becauÅ¿e the Nature of the Earth requires theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Changes, as being as 'twere aÅ¿Å¿ured in this DiverÅ¿ity, to find wherewithall to recruit and perpetuate its firÅ¿t vigour. And though in thoÅ¿e good Grounds all things proÅ¿per admirably well, yet is it a moÅ¿t undoubted truth, that Southern and EaÅ¿tern ExpoÅ¿itions are here as well as every where elÅ¿e, more proper than thoÅ¿e of the WeÅ¿t and North, to forward, and improve its productions, witneÅ¿s Strawberries, HaÅ¿ting Peas, Cherries and MuÅ¿cat-Grapes, &c. To balance which, theÅ¿e laÅ¿t ExpoÅ¿itions have likewiÅ¿e Å¿ome peculiar advantages, that make them to be eÅ¿teemed in their turn; for Example, during the exceÅ¿Å¿ive heats of Summer, that often Å¿corch up every thing, and make our Legumes and other plants run up too haÅ¿tily to Seed, they are exempt from thoÅ¿e violent impreÅ¿Å¿ions, which the Sun makes upon thoÅ¿e places that are fully expoÅ¿ed to his burning Rays, and conÅ¿equently our Plants will, maintain themÅ¿elves longer in good plight in thoÅ¿e Å¿ituations than in the others.

It alÅ¿o follows from hence, that if any PerÅ¿on have Ground, though tolerably good, yet not of an equal goodneÅ¿s all over, either cauÅ¿ed by the difference of its natural temper, or Å¿ituation, and Å¿loping inclination upwards or downwards, that then I Å¿ay, the skill and induÅ¿try of the Gard'ner Å¿hews it Å¿elf, by knowing how to allot every plant the place in which it may beÅ¿t come to maturity in every SeaÅ¿on, as well in regard of forwardneÅ¿s, and Å¿ometimes of BackwardneÅ¿s, as of its outward Beauty, and inward perfection.

Generally Å¿peaking, thoÅ¿e Grounds that are moderately dry, light, and Å¿andy, and Å¿uch as though they be a little Å¿trong and heavy, are Å¿ituated on a gentle riÅ¿ing towards the South or WeÅ¿t, and are backed by great Mountains, or fenced by high Walls againÅ¿t the Cold Winds, are more diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to produce the Novelties of the Spring, than the Å¿trong, heavy, fat and moiÅ¿t Sands, but likewiÅ¿e on the other Hand, in Summers when there falls but little Rain, theÅ¿e laÅ¿t produce thicker and better nouriÅ¿ht Legumes, and require not Å¿uch large and frequent Waterings, Å¿o that we may find Å¿ome Å¿ort of ConÅ¿olation and Satisfaction in all Å¿orts of Grounds.

However though abÅ¿olutely Å¿peaking, all things that may enter into a Kitchen-Garden, may grow in all Å¿orts of Grounds that are not altogether Barren, yet it has been obÅ¿erved in all times, that all Å¿orts of Earth agree not equally with all Å¿orts of Plants, our able Market Gard'ners in the Neighbourhood of Paris, juÅ¿tifie the truth of this by a moÅ¿t convincing Experience, for we Å¿ee that Å¿uch of them whoÅ¿e Gardens are in Sandy Grounds, Å¿eldom mind to plant in them any Artichokes, Collyflowers, Beet-Chards, Onions, Cardons, Cellery, Beet-raves or Red Beet-Roots, and other Roots, &c. as thoÅ¿e do that have theirs in Å¿tronger and more hearty Lands, and on the contrary, theÅ¿e laÅ¿t employ not their Ground in Sorrel, PurÅ¿lain, Lettuce, Endive, and other Å¿mall plants that are delicate and Å¿ubject to periÅ¿h with Mildew, and the wet rot as do thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e Gardens are in lighter Lands.

From all that I have aÅ¿Å¿erted, there reÅ¿ult two things, the firÅ¿t is, that an able Gard'ner which has a pretty dry or hilly Ground to cultivate with an Obligation to have of all Å¿orts of things in his Garden, Å¿hould place in the moiÅ¿teÅ¿t parts thoÅ¿e plants that require a little moiÅ¿ture to bring them to perfection, as Artichokes, Red Beet-Roots, Scorzonera's, SalÅ¿iÅ¿ies, Carrots, ParÅ¿nips, Skirrets, Beet-Chards, Collyflowers and Cabbages, Spinage, Common Peas, Beans, Currans, GooÅ¿eberries, RaÅ¿pberries, Onions, Ciboules, Leeks, ParÅ¿ly, Sorrel, RadiÅ¿hes, Patience or Dock-Sorrel, Sweet Herbs, Borage BugloÅ¿s, &c. And (Å¿uppoÅ¿ing the ProviÅ¿ions above Å¿pecified, without which nothing will be Å¿ightly, be already planted in its other parts) he Å¿hould fill up the drier parts of the Å¿ame Garden with Lettuces of all SeaÅ¿ons, Endive, Succory, Chervil, Tarragon, BaÅ¿il, Burnet, Mint, and other Sallet-Furnitures, and PurÅ¿lain, Garlick, Shalots, Winter-Cabbages, Hot Beds of all Å¿orts of Plants, and of little Sallets; he may likewiÅ¿e plant in the Å¿ame places what Grapes he has a mind to, and he muÅ¿t place his Legumes there at moderate diÅ¿tances, becauÅ¿e they grow not of Å¿o large a Size and Stature there, as in fatter places. And laÅ¿tly, he muÅ¿t keep his Walks and Path-ways higher than his dreÅ¿Å¿ed Grounds, as well to draw into theÅ¿e latter the Rain waters that would be but unuÅ¿eful and incommodious in the Walks, as to render the artificial waterings he Å¿hall be obliged to uÅ¿e, of the greater advantage to them, by preventing them from running out any where aÅ¿ide, which muÅ¿t be one of his principal Applications.

He muÅ¿t alÅ¿o chuÅ¿e out in the Å¿ame Grounds thoÅ¿e Parts which come the neareÅ¿t to the good temper between dry and moiÅ¿t, for the raiÅ¿ing of AÅ¿paragus, Strawberries, Cardons, Cellery, &c. becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e Å¿orts of Plants languiÅ¿h with drowth in places too dry, and periÅ¿h with rottenneÅ¿s in parts over-moiÅ¿t. He muÅ¿t place in the Borders under his Northern Walls his Alleluia's, Latter Strawberries, and Bourdelais, or Verjuice Grapes, and in the Counter-Borders of the Å¿ame Northern Quarter, he may make his NurÅ¿ery Beds for Strawberries, and Å¿ow Chervil all the Summer long, the North Å¿ide in all Å¿orts of Grounds, being moÅ¿t proper for thoÅ¿e purpoÅ¿es. And as this Gard'ner Å¿hould be curious of Novelties, he ought to look upon the Banks under the Walls towards the South and EaÅ¿t to be a marvellous and favourable Å¿helter for the raiÅ¿ing them; as for Example, for the procuring of Strawberries and early Peas at the beginning of May, Violets at the entrance of March, and Cabbage-Lettuces at the beginning of April. He Å¿hould likewiÅ¿e plant in the dreÅ¿Å¿ed Banks next to the Å¿ame EaÅ¿tern and WeÅ¿tern Walls, his NurÅ¿ery of Cabbages, and Å¿ow there his Winter Lettuces, that is, Shell-Lettuces, to remain there all Autumn and Winter, till in the Spring it be time to tranÅ¿plant them into the places where they are to come to perfection; He Å¿hould likewiÅ¿e plant in the Borders of the Å¿ame Walls, his PaÅ¿Å¿e-pierre, or Sampire, which he can hardly have by any other means, which courÅ¿e is to be followed in all Å¿orts of Gardens; and in the Winter time he Å¿hould likewiÅ¿e obÅ¿erve this particular caution to throw all the Snow off from the neighbouring places upon the dreÅ¿Å¿ed Borders of thoÅ¿e Wall-trees, and eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e of the EaÅ¿tern Quarter, both for the erecting of a Magazine, as 'twere of moiÅ¿ture in Å¿uch places upon which the Rain but Å¿eldom falls, as upon thoÅ¿e in which the violent heat of Summer is like to be of pernicious influence.

The Å¿econd thing that ReÅ¿ults from what I before laid down, is, That the Gard'ner whoÅ¿e Garden is in a very fat and moiÅ¿t Ground, muÅ¿t take a quite contrary method with all his Plants to that juÅ¿t now above mentioned; always aÅ¿Å¿uring himÅ¿elf that thoÅ¿e parts of it which are very moiÅ¿t, unleÅ¿s he can find means to drain and render them lighter, will be of no other uÅ¿e to him than to produce noxious Weeds, and conÅ¿equently, that thoÅ¿e which partake the leaÅ¿t of that intemperature, whether by their own Nature and Situation, or by the care and induÅ¿try of the ingenious Gard'ner, are always to be lookt upon as the beÅ¿t for all Å¿orts of things. He muÅ¿t place in the drieÅ¿t parts moÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e Plants that keep in their places for Å¿everal years together, excepting Currans, GooÅ¿e-berries, and RaÅ¿pberry BuÅ¿hes; as for Example, AÅ¿paragus, Artichokes, Strawberries, Wild Endive or Succory, &c. In other places, let him put thoÅ¿e things which in Summer require the leaÅ¿t time to come to perfection, viz. Sallets, Peas, Beans, RadiÅ¿hes, nay and Cardons, Cellery, &c. and becauÅ¿e all things grow thick and tall in thoÅ¿e fat and moiÅ¿t places, therefore he muÅ¿t plant his Kitchen-plants there, at greater diÅ¿tances one from the other, than in drier places; he muÅ¿t alÅ¿o keep his Beds and dreÅ¿Å¿ed Grounds, raiÅ¿ed higher than his Walks and Path-ways, to help to drain out of his Grounds the Water that is Å¿o hurtful to his Plants, and for that ReaÅ¿on, his Beds of AÅ¿paragus, eÅ¿pecially, as likewiÅ¿e his Strawberry and Cellery Beds, &c. no more than thoÅ¿e of his Sallets muÅ¿t not be made Hollow, as thoÅ¿e muÅ¿t be that are made in drier Grounds.

I have had good SucceÅ¿s in the new Kitchen-Garden at VerÅ¿ailles, where the Ground is fat, viÅ¿cous, and as 'twere Clayie, by raiÅ¿ing in the midÅ¿t of it, certain large Å¿quares where the frequent Rain Waters in the Summer, of the Year 1682. remained without penetrating above Å¿even or eight Inches deep, and by having given to the Å¿aid Å¿quares by the means of that elevation, a Å¿loping deÅ¿cent on each Å¿ide, all along the bottom of which I made at the Å¿ame time Å¿ome little dikes or water-courÅ¿es about a foot deep, as well to Å¿eparate the Å¿quares from the Counterborders as particularly to receive the miÅ¿chievous waters which by Å¿taying on the Å¿quares, otherwiÅ¿e would ruine all the Plants in them; which waters afterwards diÅ¿charged themÅ¿elves into Å¿tone gutters which I had purpoÅ¿ely ordered to be made to carry them off. I afterwards raiÅ¿ed moÅ¿t of the Counterborders in the Å¿ame manner, Arch-wiÅ¿e, that what water might remain in them might Å¿hoot off into the Å¿ides of the walks, all along which there were other little dikes almoÅ¿t unperceivable, to receive thoÅ¿e waters and convey them into the Å¿ame Å¿tone gutters-newly above mentioned; and I can truly affirm, that before I uÅ¿ed this precaution, all that I had in thoÅ¿e Å¿quares, not only of Kitchen-Plants, even to the moÅ¿t ruÅ¿tical and hardy Å¿ort of them, as Artichokes, Beet-Chards, &c. but to the very Fruit-Trees were viÅ¿ibly perceived to periÅ¿h, the Plants with the rot, and the Trees with the Jaundice, beÅ¿ides which miÅ¿chiefs, the winds eaÅ¿ily threw up my Trees by the Roots, becauÅ¿e they could hardly take any faÅ¿t hold in that kind of Ground that were grown liquid and Å¿oft like new made mortar, or Pap. My forecaÅ¿t and diligence were a great help to me in that caÅ¿, eand I Å¿incerely adviÅ¿e all thoÅ¿e that Å¿hall have to do with places of the like difficulty, to uÅ¿e the Å¿ame method, if they can find out no better expedient.

The reaÅ¿oning by which I was induced to this way of proceeding, was this: That though the exceÅ¿Å¿ive quantity of water did reduce that unhappy Å¿ort of Ground to a kind of MarÅ¿h, and thereby diÅ¿poÅ¿ed it afterwards by the operation of the great heat to grow as hard as a Å¿tone, and conÅ¿equently rendred it uncapable of culture in either of thoÅ¿e two Å¿tates wet, or dry, yet I Å¿ay, my reaÅ¿on Å¿uggeÅ¿ted to me, that if I could hinder the firÅ¿t inconvenience which was the rendring of this Ground too Liquid and MarÅ¿hy, it would be an infallible means to Å¿ecure me againÅ¿t the Å¿econd, which was to Å¿ee them grow hard and Å¿tony, becauÅ¿e I concluded, that if my Grounds having been once made light and looÅ¿e, could be kept reaÅ¿onably dry after that, as they would be if the waters were hindred from lodging in them, they would not be any more Å¿o cloÅ¿ely glued together as to grow into any Å¿uch kind of Å¿tony conÅ¿iÅ¿tence, but would become tractable like other Lands; and accordingly I found my reaÅ¿oning anÅ¿wered by the Å¿ucceÅ¿s which I expected.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: What Å¿ort of Culture is moÅ¿t proper for every particular Plant.

div.p: IT is a very conÅ¿iderable Advance to have Å¿ettled a Garden upon a good foot at firÅ¿t and to have wiÅ¿ely employed, or at leaÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿igned out all its parts according to the different Qualifications of its Ground, the goodneÅ¿s of its ExpoÅ¿itions, the order of the Months, and the nature of each Plant; But that is not all, we muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e carefully cultivate them, in Å¿uch a manner as they peculiarly require.

For there is a general Culture of Kitchen-Gardens, and there is a particular Culture peculiar to each Plant. As to the general Culture, it is well enough known, that the moÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿ary and important points of it conÅ¿iÅ¿t firÅ¿t, in well amending and mucking the Earth, whether it be naturally good or not, becauÅ¿e Kitchen-Plants exhauÅ¿t it much; Å¿econdly, in keeping it always looÅ¿e and Å¿tirred, either by digging up whole Beds, to Sow or tranÅ¿plant in them, &c. or Å¿uch other places where the Å¿pade may be employed, as for Example, among Artichokes, Cardons, &c. or by pecking and grubbing up where the cloÅ¿eneÅ¿s of the Plants to one another, will permit us to uÅ¿e only grubbing inÅ¿truments, as for Example, among Straw-berries, Lettuces, Endive, Peas, Beans, Cellery, &c. Thirdly, in watering plentifully all Å¿orts of Plants in very Hot weather, and eÅ¿pecially in Å¿andy Grounds, for thoÅ¿e that are Å¿trong and rank require not Å¿o much, always obÅ¿erving that in both Å¿orts of Ground, watering is not Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary for AÅ¿paragus, nor for borders or edgings of Time, Sage, Lavender, HiÅ¿Å¿op, Rue, Worm-wood, &c. which need but little moiÅ¿ture to keep them in good plight; Fourthly, it conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in keeping the
Superficies of our Ground clear of all Å¿orts of Weeds, either by Weeding, or digging, or by only raking them over, when they have not been long dreÅ¿Å¿ed, Å¿o that as far as 'tis poÅ¿Å¿ible, the Earth may always appear as if it had been newly Å¿tirred up.

I Å¿hall not inÅ¿iÅ¿t any longer here upon the head of the General Culture, becauÅ¿e it is Å¿o well known to all people, but Å¿hall only declare my Opinion and the practice of able Gard'ners in that which is peculiarly to be uÅ¿ed to each particular plant.

And I Å¿hall begin with obÅ¿erving to you, that among Kitchen-Plants, there are Å¿ome that are Sown to remain Å¿till in the place where they were firÅ¿t, and others again, only to be tranÅ¿planted elÅ¿ewhere; that there are Å¿ome that prove well both ways; Å¿ome that are multiplied without Seed, Å¿ome that are tranÅ¿planted whole, and Å¿ome that are cut to be tranÅ¿planted; that there are Å¿ome which for the Å¿upply of Man-kind, bear Å¿everal times in a year, and that laÅ¿t longer than a year; others that produce but once in a year, but yet laÅ¿t to bear for Å¿everal years after; and LaÅ¿tly Å¿ome again, that periÅ¿h after their firÅ¿t production.

The Plants of the firÅ¿t ClaÅ¿s, are RadiÅ¿hes, almoÅ¿t all Red Beet-Roots, Carrots, ParÅ¿nips, Skirrets, Turneps, Maches, Reponces, Scorzonera's, SalÅ¿ifies, and beÅ¿ides them, Garlick, Chervil, Wild Endive, or Succory, Harts-Horn Sallet, Garden-CreÅ¿Å¿es, Shallots, Spinage, Beans, Å¿mall Lettuce to cut, ParÅ¿ly, Burnet, Cutting Beets, Peas, PurÅ¿lain, &c. and the greateÅ¿t part of our Sorrel, Patience or Sharp-Leav'd Dock, Onions, and Ciboulees.

The Plants of the Å¿econd ClaÅ¿s which Å¿ucceed not without being tranÅ¿planted, are Chard-Beets, Cellery, and the greateÅ¿t part of our White Endive, both long and tied, and Cabbages, unleÅ¿s they be Å¿own very thin, or be very much thinn'd after they are Å¿own; of this ClaÅ¿s are alÅ¿o Cabbages, moÅ¿t Musk-Melons, and Cucumbers, Citrulls or Pumpions, Potirons or flat Pumpions, Leeks, &c.

ThoÅ¿e of the third ClaÅ¿s, that is, Å¿uch as may be indifferently either continued in the places where they are firÅ¿t Å¿own, or tranÅ¿planted elÅ¿ewhere, are AÅ¿paragus, though moÅ¿t commonly they are Å¿own at firÅ¿t in NurÅ¿eries, to be tranÅ¿planted a year or two after; as alÅ¿o BaÅ¿il, Fennel, Anis, Borage, BugloÅ¿s, Cardons, Capucin Capers or NaÅ¿turies, Ciboulees, Savory, Time, Musked Chervil, &c.

The Plants of the fourth ClaÅ¿s that are multiplied without being Å¿own, are Alleluia, or Wood-Sorrel, EngliÅ¿h Cives, Violets, &c. BecauÅ¿e they grow into thick Tufts which are Å¿eparated into many; Artichokes are propagated by their Eyes, Off-Å¿ets, or Slips; Mint, and Round Sorrel, Tripe Madame, Tarragon, Balm, &c. by their Layers or Branches that take Root where they touch the Earth, the two laÅ¿t of which have alÅ¿o the advantage of multiplying by Seed, as likewiÅ¿e have the Artichokes Å¿ometimes. Straw-berries propagate by their Runners, RaÅ¿p-berries, GooÅ¿e-berries, and Currans, by their Slips, or Suckers, and by their Cuttings which alÅ¿o take Root. Lavender, Worm-wood, Sage, Time, and Marjoram, by their Branches which take Root at their joints, and are alÅ¿o multiplied by their Seed; the common Bays, both by Layers and Seed too; Vines, and Fig-Trees, by their Suckers, Hooked Slips, and Cuttings whether Rooted or not Rooted.

In the fifth place, thoÅ¿e Plants of which we cut off Å¿ome part either of the Leaves or Roots or both at the Å¿ame time, in order to tranÅ¿plant them, are Artichokes, Chard-Beets, Leeks, Cellery, &c. And thoÅ¿e others whoÅ¿e Leaves we do not cut at all, though it be good always to trim their Roots a little to refreÅ¿h them, are Endive, and Succory, moÅ¿t commonly, and Savory, Sorrel, &c. and all Lettuces, Alleluia or Wood-Sorrel, Violets, BaÅ¿il, Arrach or Orage, Borage, BugloÅ¿s, Capucin Capers or NaÅ¿turces, Cabbages, Tarragon, Samphire, Straw-berries, Marjoram, Musk-Melons, Cucumbers, Citrulls or Pumpions, PurÅ¿lain; and RadiÅ¿hes for Seed, &c.

The Plants that bring forth Å¿everal times in a year, and yet laÅ¿t for Å¿ome years following, are Sorrel, Patience or Sharp Dock, Alleluia or Wood-Sorrel, Burnet, Chervil, ParÅ¿ley, Fennel, all Edging, or Sweet Herbs, Wild Endive or Succory, Macedonian ParÅ¿ley or AliÅ¿anders, Mint, Tarragon, Samphire, &c.
ThoÅ¿e that produce but once in the year, but yet laÅ¿t bearing for Å¿everal years together afterwards, are AÅ¿paragus, and Artichokes.

And LaÅ¿tly, thoÅ¿e that ceaÅ¿e to be uÅ¿eful after their firÅ¿t production, are all Lettuces, Common Endive, Peas, Beans, Cardons, Melons, Cucumbers, Citrulls or Pumpions, Onions, Leeks, Cellery, Arrach or Orage, and all Plants whoÅ¿e Roots are only in uÅ¿e, as Red Beets, Carrots, &c.

Now to give you a particular account of the Culture that belongs to every Å¿everal Å¿ort of Plant, I muÅ¿t tell you, that this Culture conÅ¿iÅ¿ts, firÅ¿t, in obÅ¿erving the diÅ¿tances they are to be placed at one from the other; Å¿econd, in the Triming of Å¿uch as need it;
third, in planting them in that Å¿ituation, and diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, which they require; fourth, in giving them thoÅ¿e aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tances which Å¿ome of them have need of to bring them to perfection, or which are convenient for them, whether it be by typing up, or wrapping about, or Earthing up, or otherwiÅ¿e covering them, &c.

div.opener: I begin in the ALPHABETICAL Order

div.head: A.
div.p: ALIS ANDERS: See Macedonian ParÅ¿ley.

Alleluia, or Wood-Sorrel, when it grows old, grows into Tufts, and being a Plant that grows in the Woods, and conÅ¿equently that loves the Å¿hade, we therefore plant it along by the Å¿ides of our Northern Walls, at the diÅ¿tance of about one foot between one plant and another; the more we Å¿trip it of its Leaves, which is one good quality it has, the more freÅ¿h ones it Å¿hoots forth: It is enough to Å¿et it two Inches into the Ground; it laÅ¿ts three or four years without being renewed, and to renew it, we need do no more than to Å¿eparate or Å¿lip out the great Tufts of it into Å¿everal little ones, and replant them again immediately, which is to be done in the Months of March and April; a little watering in very Hot weather, and eÅ¿pecially in Å¿andy Grounds, is a very great and welcome help to them.

Anis and Fennel are commonly Å¿own pretty thin, either in Å¿urrows, or borders; their Leaves are uÅ¿ed in Sallets among other Furnitures. They run to Seed towards the Month of AuguÅ¿t, and when their Å¿talks are cut down, they Å¿hoot out new Leaves the next year that are as good as the firÅ¿t, but however it is beÅ¿t to renew them every two years.

Arrach, Orrach, or Orage, is propagated only by Seed, and is both one of the quickeÅ¿t both in coming up, and in running to Seed, which latter it does at the very beginning of June. It is Å¿own pretty thin, and to have good Seed of it, we muÅ¿t tranÅ¿plant Å¿ome plants of it in Å¿ome Å¿eparate place. The Leaf of this plant is very good both in pottage, and in Å¿tuffings or farces; we uÅ¿e it almoÅ¿t as Å¿oon as it peeps out of the Earth, for it paÅ¿Å¿es away very quickly; and to have Å¿ome the more early, we Å¿ow a little quantity of it upon a Hot Bed: It thrives well enough in all Å¿orts of Grounds, but yet it grows always fairer in good Grounds than in but indifferent ones.

Aromatick or Å¿weet, or Å¿picy Herbs Å¿uch as are planted in Edgings of Borders, as Marjoram, Time, Sage, RoÅ¿emary, &c. See their Culture under the Å¿everal Titles of each of thoÅ¿e particular Herbs.

Artichokes, as we have already elÅ¿ewhere told you, are multiplied by their Eyes, Suckers, Slips, or Off-Sets, which every plant of them uÅ¿ually Å¿hoots out every year in the Spring, round about its old Root, and which muÅ¿t be taken off as Å¿oon as they are grown big enough, leaving only at each place three of the beÅ¿t and furtheÅ¿t diÅ¿tant one from the other. For the planting them, we commonly make little Trenches, or Pits about half a foot deep, and three foot diÅ¿tant one from another, and filled with Mold, and we place two rows of them regulated by a line, in each Bed, which is to be full four foot broad, and parted from the next Bed by a path-way of one full foot; theÅ¿e Trenches of Pits are to be made at about half a foots diÅ¿tance from the edge of the Bed, and ChecquerwiÅ¿e one towards the other; we place two Slips in a right Line in each Å¿pace containing between Nine and Ten Inches in Length. We muÅ¿t renew them once every three years at leaÅ¿t, cut off their Leaves at the beginning of Winter, and cover them with long dry dung during all the very cold weather till the end of March, when we muÅ¿t uncover them, and Å¿lip them, if their Slips be yet big enough, or elÅ¿e Å¿tay three Weeks or a Month longer till they be, then we muÅ¿t labour and move the Earth well about them, and dung them with the rotteneÅ¿t part of that Dung that Å¿erved them for a covering; we water them moderately once or twice a Week, till about the end of May, their Fruit begins to appear, and from that time we muÅ¿t water them plentifully, that is two or three times a Week, during the whole Summer, allowing half a Pitcher full of Water to each plant, and eÅ¿pecially in Grounds naturally dry; thoÅ¿e planted in the Spring, Å¿hould bring their Fruit to perfection in Autumn following, if well watered, and they which do not, ought to yield their firÅ¿t Fruit in the next Spring after, in caÅ¿e they be Å¿trong enough to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the Å¿harpneÅ¿s of the Winter. Artichokes have not only the hard weather, and exceÅ¿s of wet to fear, but they have the Field Mice likewiÅ¿e for their Enemies, thoÅ¿e miÅ¿chievous little Animals gnawing their Roots in the Winter-time, when they find nothing better in the Gardens, and for that
reaÅ¿on, it's good to plant one Rank of Beet-Chards between two Ranks of Artichokes, that the Field-Mice finding the Roots of theÅ¿e laÅ¿t the tendrer of the two, may fall upon them inÅ¿tead of the others, as they never fail to do. There are three Å¿orts of Artichokes, viz. the green, or otherwiÅ¿e white ones, which are the moÅ¿t early, the violet ones, whoÅ¿e Fruit is almoÅ¿t of a pyramidal Figure, and the red ones which are round, and flat like the white ones. The two laÅ¿t Å¿orts are the moÅ¿t delicious.
Artichoke Chards. See Chards.

AÅ¿paragus are Å¿own at the beginning of the Spring like other Seeds, that is, they are Å¿own in Å¿ome Bed well prepared; they muÅ¿t be Å¿own indifferent thin, and raked with an Iron Rake, to cover them with Earth. About a year after, if they be big enough, as they will be, if the Ground be good, and well prepared; or if not, at leaÅ¿t at two years end, we muÅ¿t tranplant them, which is to be done about the end of March, and all the Month of April; and for that effect we muÅ¿t have Beds between three and four foot broad, and Å¿eparated one from the other; if it be in ordinary Ground, we dig theÅ¿e Beds hollow with a good Spade, throwing up the Earth we take out of them upon the Path-ways; and as to Å¿trong, heavy and moiÅ¿t Grounds, I would have them ordered as I have done the Kitchen-Garden at VerÅ¿ailles, that is to Å¿ay, I would not have the Beds in them at all laid hollow, but on the contrary, raiÅ¿ed and kept higher than the Path-ways, too much wet being mortal to theÅ¿e Plants. AÅ¿paragus thus Å¿own Å¿hoot out Tufts of Roots round about their Eye, or Mother Root; that is to Å¿ay, round the place from whence all their Å¿hoots are to Spring, which Roots Å¿pread between two Earths, and in order to tranÅ¿plant them either into a hollow Bed, or a high raiÅ¿ed Bed, we beÅ¿tow a good thorough Tillage on the bottom of the Trench, and if the Ground be not very good, we dung it a little, and afterward we plant two or three Å¿tocks of theÅ¿e young Plants, orderly in ranks upon the Super â¢ icies of the Bed prepared for them, without needing to trim the extremity of their Roots, or at leaÅ¿t, but a very little, and if our intention be, to force theÅ¿e AÅ¿paragus by an artificial heat, when they are grown big enough, we place them at a foot diÅ¿tance one from the other, and if they be to remain to grow after the uÅ¿ual manner, we allow them at a foot and a half's diÅ¿tance, but in both CaÅ¿es, we place them ChecquerwiÅ¿e, and when they are Å¿o placed, we cover them up again with two or three Inches depth of Earth: if any of them fail to Spring up, we may reimplace them with new ones two or three Months after, which is to be done in the Å¿ame manner as we planted the others, only taking care to water the new planted ones Å¿ometimes during the great heat, and to keep them always well weeded, and well dug about, or elÅ¿e we mark out with little Å¿ticks the empty places, and Å¿tay till the Spring before we fill them up again. Every year we cover the Bed with a little Earth taken off from the Path-way, becauÅ¿e inÅ¿tead of Å¿inking, they always are riÅ¿ing by little and little: we dung them moderately every two years, and let them Å¿hoot up the firÅ¿t three or four years without gathering any, till we Å¿ee them begin to grow pretty thick, and then we may force as many as we pleaÅ¿e of them, or if not, we continue to gather of them every year a crop for fifteen years, before we need to renew them. Every year about Martlemas, we cut down all their Å¿tems, every Å¿tock producing Å¿everal Å¿tems, and take the Å¿eed of the faireÅ¿t of them for Seed, if we would have them come to bear at the time above-mentioned. To draw them out of their NurÅ¿ery-Beds, we uÅ¿e an Iron Fork, the Spade being too dangerous for that work, becauÅ¿e it would cut, and hurt thoÅ¿e little Plants.

We muÅ¿t not fail every Year at the latter end of March, or beginning of April, that is, before the AÅ¿paragus begin to Å¿prout naturally, to beÅ¿tow a Å¿mall dreÅ¿Å¿ing or Å¿tirring of the Ground about three or four Inches deep, on every Bed, taking care not to let the Spade go Å¿o deep, as to hurt the Plants; which Å¿mall dreÅ¿Å¿ing Å¿erves, both to kill the Weeds and to render the Superficies of the Earth looÅ¿e, and thereby not only the better to diÅ¿poÅ¿e it to drink up the Rain, and the May-dew that nouriÅ¿hes the Stocks, but likewiÅ¿e to facilitate the paÅ¿Å¿age of the AÅ¿paragus in Å¿prouting. The particular and moÅ¿t dreadful Enemies of AÅ¿paragus are a Å¿ort of little Fleas, that faÅ¿ten upon their Å¿hoots, make them miÅ¿carry, and hinder them from thriving; they are moÅ¿t troubleÅ¿ome in very hot and dry years, not appearing at all in other years; there has been no Remedy found yet againÅ¿t this miÅ¿chief.

div.head: B.
div.p: BAlm, called in French MeliÅ¿Å¿e, is an Odoriferous Herb, whoÅ¿e Leaf when tender, makes a part of Sallet-Furnitures. It is multiplyed both by Seed, and by rooted Branches, like Lavender, Time, HyÅ¿Å¿op, &c.

BaÅ¿il is an annual Plant, that is very delicate. We Å¿eldom Å¿ow it but upon Hot Beds, and not in open Ground, as we do PurÅ¿lain, Lettuce, &c. We begin to Å¿ow Å¿ome in that manner at the very beginning of February, and we may continue Å¿o to do the whole year.
