Its tender Leaves are mixed in a Å¿mall quantity, with the Furnitures of Sallets, among which, they make an agreeable perfume; It is likewiÅ¿e uÅ¿ed in Ragou's, eÅ¿pecially dry ones, for which reaÅ¿on, we take care to keep Å¿ome for Winter. We gather its Seed in the Month of AuguÅ¿t; and uÅ¿ually to make it run to Seed, we tranÅ¿plant it in the Month of May, either in Pots, or Beds. There are Å¿everal Å¿orts of it, but that which bears the biggeÅ¿t Leaves, and eÅ¿pecially if they incline to a Violet Colour, and that which bears the leaÅ¿t Leaves, are the two moÅ¿t curious; that which produces midling ones, being the ordinary or Common Å¿ort.

The Common Bays, or Bay-Tree, is a Å¿hurb of no very great uÅ¿e in our Gardens, and therefore it is enough to have Å¿ome few Plants of it in Å¿ome well Å¿heltered place, to gather Å¿ome Leaves of them when occaÅ¿ion requires.

Beans, as well thoÅ¿e of the Common, and Garden Å¿ort, as thoÅ¿e called Kidney-Beans, and French-Beans, and in French, AricÃ´s, are Å¿own in open Ground, and grow not otherwiÅ¿e; The AricÃ´ French, or Kidney-Beans, are Å¿own about the latter end of April, and all the Month of May, and are very Å¿enÅ¿ible of the FroÅ¿t; The Common Garden Beans are Å¿own at the Å¿ame time with HaÅ¿ting-Peas, both in November, and in February.
Hot Beds. See the Works in November.

Bete-raves, or Red Beet-Roots, are annual Plants propagated only by Seed, and are Å¿eldom tranÅ¿planted. They are Å¿own in the Month of March, either in Beds or Borders. They muÅ¿t be Å¿own very thin, or at leaÅ¿t if they come up too thick they muÅ¿t be very much thinned, or elÅ¿e they will not grow Å¿o fair and large as they Å¿hould be. They require a very good, and well prepared Ground: They are the beÅ¿t that have the ReddeÅ¿t Å¿ubÅ¿tance and the ReddeÅ¿t Tops: They are not good to Å¿pend till towards the end of Autumn, and all the Winter SeaÅ¿on. To have Seed of them, we tranÅ¿plant in March Å¿ome of the laÅ¿t years Roots that we have preÅ¿erved from the FroÅ¿t, their Seed is gathered in the Months of August and September.
White, or Chard-Beets: See Chards.

Borage and BugloÅ¿s, grow and are to be ordered in the Å¿ame manner as Arrach, only they come not up Å¿o vigorouÅ¿ly. We Å¿ow of them Å¿everal times in the Å¿ame Summer, becauÅ¿e their Leaves, in which conÅ¿iÅ¿ts all their excellence, are good only whilÅ¿t they are tender, that is, while they are young. Their little Violet Colour'd Flowers Å¿erve to adorn Sallets. Their Seed falls aÅ¿Å¿oon as 'tis ripe, and therefore muÅ¿t be carefully watch'd: The Å¿ureÅ¿t way is to cut down the Å¿talks, and lay them a drying in the Sun, aÅ¿Å¿oon as ever the Seeds begin to ripen, and by that means we Å¿hall loÅ¿e but very few.

Bourdelai's, otherwiÅ¿e called Verjuice, as well the White, as Red Å¿ort, is a kind of Vine which is pruned, and Å¿lipt, or layed, and graffed and planted as other Vines are in the Months of January, February, and March. Care muÅ¿t be taken to tie up its Branches, either to props, or Å¿ome Å¿ort of trail, about the middle of June at lateÅ¿t, or elÅ¿e the wind deÅ¿troys it quite: We muÅ¿t alÅ¿o pick and pluck off the weak and unprofitable Branches of theÅ¿e Vines; and when we prune them, 'tis enough to leave two, three, or four fair Branches at moÅ¿t upon each Å¿tock, and to keep them not above three or four buds long, every one of which uÅ¿ually Å¿hoots forth one bearing Branch, with three or four fair Bunches of Grapes upon each Branch. My practice is in all Å¿orts of Vines, but particularly in the MuÅ¿cat or Musked Å¿orts, to keep the lower Branches Å¿horter by two buds, than the higheÅ¿t, to keep the Plant always low, when I would not have them mount up upon a Trail.
Buckshorn-Sallet: See Hartshorn-Sallet.
Burnet, called in French Pimprenelle, or Pimpernelle, is a very Common and ordinary Sallet furniture, which is Å¿eldom Å¿own but in the Spring, and is Å¿own thick either in Beds or Borders.

It often Springs afreÅ¿h after cutting, of which the youngeÅ¿t Å¿hoots muÅ¿t be choÅ¿en for Sallets, the Leaves that are any thing old being too tough. It does it a great deal of good to water it in Summer. There is but one Å¿ort of it whoÅ¿e Seed is gathered at the end of Summer.

div.head: C.
div.p: CAbbages of all Å¿orts of Kitchen-Plants take Root again the eaÅ¿ilieÅ¿t when tranÅ¿planted, as they are likewiÅ¿e the moÅ¿t known, and moÅ¿t uÅ¿ed of any in our whole Gardens. They are multiplied by Seed, and are of Å¿everal Å¿orts and SeaÅ¿ons. There are Å¿ome called White, or headed Cabbages, which are for the Å¿ervice of the latter end of Summer, and for Autumn. There are Å¿ome Curled, called Pancaliers, and Milan Cabbages, which produce Å¿mall headed Cabbages, for Winter; there are Å¿ome of a Red or Violet Colour; and Å¿ome called long Å¿ided Cabbages, whereof Å¿ome are Bright or White, and very delicate, ripe in Vintage time, and others Green, and are not very good till they be FroÅ¿t-bitten. LaÅ¿tly, there are Å¿ome called Choux Fleurs, i. e. Cabbage Flowers, and by the EngliÅ¿h Collyflowers, which are the moÅ¿t noble and valuable of them all, and are not uÅ¿ed in pottage, but in choice intermeÅ¿Å¿es; they cannot endure the FroÅ¿t, and therefore aÅ¿Å¿oon as they begin to form their heads, they muÅ¿t be covered with their Leaves tied up for that end over them, with Straw bands, to guard them from the inÅ¿ults of the Cold that Å¿poil and rot them. They are for our Winter Å¿pending, and muÅ¿t be Å¿heltred in the Green houÅ¿e or ConÅ¿ervatory, whither they muÅ¿t be carried and there planted with a turf of their old Earth, about them, where they commonly are uÅ¿ed to perfect the full growth of their heads. All other Cabbage-Plants yield Seed in France, but only theÅ¿e, whoÅ¿e Seed we are fain to have brought up from the EaÅ¿tern Countries, which makes them ordinarily very dear. To make Cabbages run to Seed, we uÅ¿e every year either in Autumn or Spring to tranÅ¿plant Å¿ome of the beÅ¿t and faireÅ¿t of them, which run to Seed in the Months of May and June, that is gathered in July and AuguÅ¿t.

You are by the way to remark two things; The firÅ¿t is, that all thick Plants that run to Seed, and grow pretty high, as Cabbage, Leeks, Ciboules, Onions, Red Beet-Roots, Carrots, ParÅ¿nips, Cellery, &c. muÅ¿t be Å¿upported either with upright props, or cro â¢ s Å¿ticks, to hinder the wind from breaking down their Å¿tems before the Seed be Ripe.

The Å¿econd is, that we Å¿eldom Å¿tay to let any Seeds dry upon their Plants as they Å¿tand, it being enough to let them only Ripen, when we cut down their Å¿tems, and lay them to dry upon Å¿ome Cloth, after which, we beat them out, and fan and cleanÅ¿e them and lay them up when they are fully dry: And thus we do with the Seeds of CreÅ¿Å¿es, Chervil, ParÅ¿ley, RadiÅ¿hes, Borage, BugloÅ¿s, &c.

Ordinary Capers grow upon a Å¿ort of Å¿mall Shrub that is raiÅ¿ed in niches made purpoÅ¿ely in well expoÅ¿ed Walls, for that end, which are filled with Earth to nouriÅ¿h the Plants; and every year in the Spring we prune their Branches, which afterwards Å¿hoot out buttons or Å¿welling buds, which are pickled up in Vinegar to be uÅ¿ed in Winter, either in Sallets, or in pottage.

Capucine-Capers, or NaÅ¿turces, are annual Plants which are uÅ¿ually Å¿own in Hot Beds, in the Month of March, and tranÅ¿planted again in the naked Earth along by Å¿ome Walls, or at the foot of Å¿ome Trees, where their mounting Å¿talks which are but weak, and grow pretty high may take Å¿ome hold, to Å¿upport themÅ¿elves. They are alÅ¿o planted in Pots, and Boxes, in which Å¿ome Å¿ticks are Å¿et up to Å¿upport their Å¿talks. Their Buttons or round Buds before they open, are good to pickle in Vinegar. Their Flower is pretty large of an Orange Colour, and very agreeable. They muÅ¿t be carefully watered in the Summer, to make them Å¿hoot vigorouÅ¿ly, and Å¿o long time as they Å¿hould. Their Seed falls to the Earth aÅ¿Å¿oon as ever 'tis ripe, as well as that of Borage and BugloÅ¿s, and therefore muÅ¿t be carefully gathered up.

Caprons, are a Å¿ort of large Straw-berries, not over delicate, which ripen at the Å¿ame time as thoÅ¿e of the better kind. Their Leaves are extraordinary large, velveted and of a darkiÅ¿h Green Colour. They are little to be prized, and are found in the Woods as other Straw-berries are.
SpaniÅ¿h Cardons or Cardoons, grow only from Seed. They are Å¿own at two Å¿everal times.
The firÅ¿t is commonly about the middle, or latter end of April, and the Å¿econd, at the beginning of May.

They muÅ¿t be Å¿own in good and well prepared Ground, and in little Trenches or pits a full foot wide, and about Å¿ix Inches deep, filled with Mold. We make Beds of four or five foot wide, in order to place in them two ranks of thoÅ¿e little Trenches or pits checker-wiÅ¿e. We put five or Å¿ix Seeds in every hole, with intention to let but two or three of them grow, if they all come up, taking away thoÅ¿e that are over and above that
number, either to throw away, or to new Å¿tock thoÅ¿e places where there perhaps are none come up, or where we may have Å¿own Å¿ome few upon a Hot Bed for that intention. And if in fifteen or twenty days we do not Å¿ee the Seed come up, we Å¿hould uncover them, to Å¿ee whether they be rotten, or begin to Å¿prour, that Å¿o we may fill up their places with new ones in caÅ¿e of need. The Seeds of the firÅ¿t Å¿owing are generally three weeks coming up, and thoÅ¿e of the Å¿econd fifteen days. Cardons muÅ¿t not be Å¿own before the middle of April, for fear they Å¿hould grow too big, and run to Seed in AuguÅ¿t and September, and then they are not good. Great care muÅ¿t be taken to water them well; and when towards the end of October, we have a mind to whiten them, we take the advantage of Å¿ome dry day, firÅ¿t to tie up all their Leaves with two or three bands, and Å¿ome days after, we cover them quite up with Straw or dry Litter well twiÅ¿ted about them, Å¿o that the Air may not penetrate to come at them, except it be at the very top, which we leave open.

TheÅ¿e Cardoon Plants thus wrapt up, whiten in about fifteen days or three weeks, and grow fit to Eat. We make an end of tying up, and wrapping, or covering all that we have in our Gardens, when we perceive the Winter approach, and then we take them up with the Earth about them, to tranÅ¿plant them in our Green HouÅ¿e, or ConÅ¿ervatory: Some of thoÅ¿e Plants are good to tranÅ¿plant in the naked Earth in the following Spring, to run to Seed in June, or July, or elÅ¿e Å¿ome Plants of them tied up in their firÅ¿t places, will Å¿erve for that three or four times together.

Carrots are a Å¿ort of Root, whereof Å¿ome are White, and others Yellow, that grow only from Seed, and require the Å¿ame care and ordering which we have already deÅ¿cribed under the head of Red Beet-Roots.

Cellery, is a Å¿ort of Sallet produced by Seed, and is not good but at the end of Autumn, and during the Winter SeaÅ¿on. We Å¿ow of it two Å¿everal times, to be Å¿upplied with it Å¿o much the longer, becauÅ¿e that which has been long Å¿own, eaÅ¿ily runs to Seed, and grows hard. We Å¿ow it then the firÅ¿t time upon Hot Beds in the beginning of April, and becauÅ¿e its Seed is Å¿o extream Å¿mall, we cannot help Å¿owing it too thick, Å¿o that if we be not careful to thin it, and crop it in time, to make it grow to Å¿ome Å¿trength and bigneÅ¿s before we tranÅ¿plant it, it warps and flags its head too much, and grows weak, and Å¿hoots its Leaves Å¿traglingly outward, inÅ¿tead of producing Å¿tore of them from the middle of its Å¿tock. The Å¿ureÅ¿t way is to tranÅ¿plant it in a NurÅ¿ery Bed, placing the Plants two or three Inches one from another, for which we make holes with our fingers only; we tranÅ¿plant that which comes of the firÅ¿t Å¿owing at the beginning of June, and Å¿ow our Å¿econd Å¿owing, at the latter end of May, or beginning of June, but 'tis in open Beds, and we take the Å¿ame care to thin, crop, and tranÅ¿plant this, as we did that of the firÅ¿t Å¿owing, but we muÅ¿t plant more of it the Å¿econd time, than at the firÅ¿t. There are two ways of tranÅ¿planting it; the one is in a Pit or Trench one full Å¿pit deep, and between three and four foot broad, in order to place in it three or four ranks of theÅ¿e Plants at the diÅ¿tance of one foot from one another: This way of making hollow Beds Earth up our Cellery in, is good only in dry Grounds, wet ones being too apt to rot, it. The Å¿econd way of tranÅ¿planting it, is in plain Beds that are not made hollow, and at the Å¿ame diÅ¿tances as in the other, taking care in both Å¿orts of Beds to water them extreamly in Summer time, its chief goodneÅ¿s conÅ¿iÅ¿ting in being tender, as well as in being very White. Watering contributes to the firÅ¿t kind of goodneÅ¿s, and for the Å¿econd, you are to obÅ¿erve, that to Whiten Cellery, we begin at firÅ¿t to tie it with two bands when it is big enough, chuÅ¿ing dry weather for that effect, and afterward we Earth our Cellery Plants quite up, with Earth taken off the high raiÅ¿ed path-ways, or elÅ¿e cover it all over with a good quantity of long dry Dung, or dry Leaves, as we do Cardoons. Cellery Å¿o Earthed up with dry Earth, or Clothed with long dry Dung, or dry Leaves, to the very top of its Leaves, Whitens in three weeks or a Month, and becauÅ¿e when 'tis Whited, it rots as it Å¿tands, if it be not preÅ¿ently eaten, by conÅ¿equence, we are not to Earth it up, or cover it with Dung, but in Å¿uch proportion as we are able to Å¿pend out of hand; there needs no other precaution to be uÅ¿ed to it Å¿o long as it does not freeze; but as Å¿oon as ever it begins to Å¿et to freeze, we muÅ¿t then cover up our Cellery quite over head and ears, for a hard FroÅ¿t Å¿poils it preÅ¿ently. And that we may the more eaÅ¿ily cover it, after we have firÅ¿t tied it up with two or three bands, we take it up with the Earth about it, at the beginning of Winter, and plant it in another Bed, Å¿etting the Plants as cloÅ¿e as we can one to another, and then there needs much leÅ¿s Å¿tuff to cover them, than when they are left Å¿tanding in their old places at Å¿uch great diÅ¿tances aÅ¿under. The way to raiÅ¿e Seed from them, is, to tranÅ¿plant Å¿ome Plants of them in Å¿ome by-place, after Winter is paÅ¿t, which will not fail to run to Seed in the Month of AuguÅ¿t, we know but one Å¿ort of it.

Chards of Artichokes, otherwiÅ¿e called CoÅ¿tons, are the Leaves of fair Artichoke Plants tied, and wrapt up with Straw in Autumn and Winter, which being covered up all over but at their very top, with Straw, grow white, and by that means, loÅ¿e a little of their bitterneÅ¿s, Å¿o that when they are boiled, they are Å¿erved up like true SpaniÅ¿h Cardons, but after all, are not Å¿o good, and beÅ¿ides the Plants often rot and periÅ¿h whilÅ¿t we are whiting them.

Chard-Beets are Plants of white Beets tranÅ¿planted in a well prepared Bed, at the diÅ¿tance of a full foot one from the other, which produce great Tops, that in the middle have a large white, and thick downy Cotton-like Main Å¿hoot, and that downy Cotton-like Å¿hoot is the true Chard uÅ¿ed in Pottages and IntermeÅ¿Å¿es. After we have Å¿own white Beets upon Hot Beds, or in the naked Earth, in the Month of March, we tranÅ¿plant that which is yelloweÅ¿t in Beds purpoÅ¿ely prepared, and by taking care to water them well during the Summer, they grow big and Å¿trong enough to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the hard winter cold, provided care be taken to cover them with long dry Dung, juÅ¿t as we do Artichokes. They are likewiÅ¿e well placed, when two Ranks of them are tranÅ¿planted between two Ranks of Artichokes. We uncover them in April, and dreÅ¿s the Earth about them, and give them careful attendance, and by the means of this diligent Culture, they produce thoÅ¿e fine Chards we have in the Rogation SeaÅ¿on, and in the Months of May and June; in fine, they run to Seed, which we gather in the Months of July and AuguÅ¿t, to Å¿ow in the following Spring.

The ChaÅ¿Å¿ela's is a very good and Å¿weet Å¿ort of Grape, of which there are two kinds, white and Red, and this latter is very Å¿carce and rare, but the other very common. It requires the good ExpoÅ¿itions of the South, EaÅ¿t and WeÅ¿t, to be Å¿o much the yellower, the more firm and crackling, the better; It is of all Grapes that which keeps longeÅ¿t, if it be not Å¿uffered to grow too ripe upon the Vine before it be gathered. Its Culture which conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in pruning it, is the Å¿ame with that of the Bourdelais or Verjuice Grape.

Musked Chervil is one of our Sallet-Furnitures, and at the beginning of the Spring, whilÅ¿t its Leaves are young and tender, it is agreeable, and proper to contribute towards the giving a perfuming ReliÅ¿h, but they are to be uÅ¿ed no longer when they are old and tough. It remains Å¿everal Years in its place without being Å¿poiled by the FroÅ¿t, Å¿o that its Stock grows pretty big and high: it runs to Seed towards the Month of June, and by that is multiplyed.

Ordinary Chervil is an annual Plant, or rather a plant of few Months, which Å¿erves for many UÅ¿es, and eÅ¿pecially in Sallets, when it is young and tender, and therefore we ought to Å¿ee a little of it every Month proportionably to the occaÅ¿ions we have for it, and to the quantity of Ground we have. It runs very eaÅ¿ily to Seed, and if we have Å¿ome of it betimes, we muÅ¿t Å¿ow it about the end of Autumn, and doubtleÅ¿s we Å¿hall have the Seed quite ripe towards the middle of June following; we cut down the Å¿talks as Å¿oon as it begins to grow yellow, and beat it out as we do that of other Plants.

Chicons are a Å¿ort of Lettuces to tie up; Å¿ee their Culture under Lettuces. Cibouls or Chibouls, properly Å¿peaking, are but Onions that are degenerated, and of which Nature has as 'twere miÅ¿carried, that is to Å¿ay, Onions that inÅ¿tead of producing a thick Root in the Earth, and one Å¿ingle Å¿tem, produces but a Å¿mall Root, and Å¿everal Stems, or upright Shoots, and thoÅ¿e which produce moÅ¿t of them, are moÅ¿t eÅ¿teemed, which are the Å¿ort of which we Å¿hould be moÅ¿t careful to preÅ¿erve Seed, and which if planted in March will yield us Seed fit to gather in AuguÅ¿t. We Å¿ow Cibouls almoÅ¿t every Month in the Year, except in very hard Weather, when the Earth cannot be cultivated; their Seed is Å¿o perfectly like that of Onions, that they cannot be diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿ht one from the other, but the former never recover Å¿o as to produce Onions, and particularly thoÅ¿e we pluck up out of the Onion Beds, which are Å¿own too thick, and muÅ¿t be thin'd, that thoÅ¿e which are left, may grow the bigger. We thin our Cibouls alÅ¿o for the Å¿ame, and we tranÅ¿plant Å¿ome which proÅ¿per very well, and grow big when they are Å¿o tranÅ¿planted. It is convenient Å¿ometimes to water our Ciboul Beds in Summers that prove extraordinary dry, and unleÅ¿s in Å¿uch caÅ¿es, they will not need watering, but however they muÅ¿t be always planted in good Earth.

EngliÅ¿h Cives, otherwiÅ¿e called Appetites, are multiplied by producing thick Tufts, which are Å¿lipt out and Å¿eparated into many little ones, and are tranÅ¿planted nine or ten Inches aÅ¿under, either in Borders or Beds; they require pretty good Ground, with which if they be accommodated, they will laÅ¿t three or four years without removing, without needing any great culture; it being enough to keep them well weeded, and to water them Å¿ometimes
during the great heat. It is their Leaves only, that are uÅ¿ed for one of the Sallet Furnitures.

Citrulls or ordinary Pompions, Pumpions, or Pumkins, and Potirons, or flat Pumpions, as every body knows, are the biggeÅ¿t productions the Earth brings forth in our Climates, for whoÅ¿e culture there is little to be done; uÅ¿ually we Å¿ow them in Hot Beds towards the middle of March, that being the only way to preÅ¿erve and multiply them, and at the end of April, we take them up with the Earth about them, to tranÅ¿plant them in holes made for that purpoÅ¿e, of about two foot diameter, and one foot deep, and two ToiÅ¿es or Fathoms aÅ¿under one from the other, which are filled with mold; when their Vines begin to grow five or Å¿ix foot long, which happens about the beginning of June, we throw upon them in the middle of that length Å¿ome Å¿hovels full of Earth, both to prevent their being broken by the winds driving them to and fro, and to make them take root at the place Å¿o covered, by which means the Fruit that grows beyond that part, will be the better nouriÅ¿hed and conÅ¿equently grow the bigger: There are two Å¿orts of Citruls or Pumpions, the Green, and the WhitiÅ¿h ones, but neither of them are Å¿it to be gathered till they be AuguÅ¿ted, that is till they be grown Yellow, and their skin grown tough enough to reÅ¿iÅ¿t ones nail. We keep of them in our Å¿tore-houÅ¿es, till about the middle of Lent, when they have been Å¿eaÅ¿onably gather'd, and well defended from the Cold: All Å¿orts of Å¿ituation in the open Air agree with them well enough, but yet they which are well expoÅ¿ed ripen Å¿ooner than the others; we trim nothing off from them, but only content our Å¿elves with watering them Å¿ometimes when the Summers are exceÅ¿Å¿ive dry. Their Seed is found in their Bellies.
Coleworts and CollyÅ¿towers are included under Cabbage.
CoÅ¿tons of Artichokes: See Chards.

Garden CreÅ¿Å¿es, is one of the little Sallet Furnitures, and is a Plant that laÅ¿ts but a little while. We Å¿ow of it every Month as we do Chervil, that we may have always Å¿ome of it that is tender; and we Å¿ow it very thick. It is propagated only by Seed, which it is very apt to run to, and which we begin to gather at the end of June, cutting down the Å¿talks in order to dry them, and beat out the Seeds and winnow them as we do thoÅ¿e of other Plants, aÅ¿Å¿oon as we perceive any of them to ripen.

Cucumber: See their culture under the head of Melons, and Musk-Melons. It is to be obÅ¿erved, that a Cucumber Plant yields a great quantity of Fruit, and for a long time, when 'tis well cultivated, and eÅ¿pecially when 'tis well watered.

Currans and GooÅ¿e berries, both being comprehended under the French name GroÅ¿eilles, both the Red and White, or Pearled Å¿ort, termed in EngliÅ¿h, Currans, and the prickly Å¿ort, called in EngliÅ¿h, Dutch GooÅ¿e-berries, are kinds of little Fruit Å¿hrubs, which yield a great deal of Fruit. They produce round about their old Å¿tock, a great number of rooted Å¿uckers or Å¿lips, which Å¿erve to propagate them, beÅ¿ides which their Branches and eÅ¿pecially the young ones that are cut off from them, take root eaÅ¿ily. They are planted in the Month of March, at the diÅ¿tance of at leaÅ¿t Å¿ix good foot one from the other, either in whole Beds, or Å¿quares, or in the void Å¿paces between the Dwarf-Trees which are uÅ¿ually planted about the Å¿quares of Kitchen or Fruit-Gardens. Both of them delight in a Ground that is a little moiÅ¿t, the better to enable them to produce thick Å¿hoots, and conÅ¿equently good Fruit.

The Red and Pearled, or White Å¿ort, called in EngliÅ¿h Currans produce Bunches, which are Ripe in July, but the prickly ones, named in EngliÅ¿h, GooÅ¿e berries, produce none, but bear their Fruit upon Å¿ingle Å¿talks all along the young Branches of the preceeding years growth, and that at the place of every one of the Eyes or Buds of that Branch. The Fruit of this latter is uÅ¿ed particularly in March and April, in CompÃ´tes or wet Å¿weet-meats, and Å¿auces, for which uÅ¿es it muÅ¿t be very Green, for when it is Ripe, it grows too Å¿oft and flat. The culture that is moÅ¿t proper to be uÅ¿ed to both Currans and GooÅ¿e-berries, and eÅ¿pecially to the Currans, conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in cutting away all their old wood, and preÅ¿erving only that of one and two years growth: for a confuÅ¿ed mixture of one with the other, is not only very indiÅ¿agreeable and pernicious, but the old Branches will bear nothing but very Å¿mall Fruit, till at laÅ¿t they quite degenerate, Å¿o that they will bear none but Å¿mall, common, and very crabbed Å¿owre Currans or GooÅ¿e-berries, and aÅ¿Å¿oon as the old Å¿tocks have done bearing any longer either fair Branches or good Fruit, we Å¿hould take a ReÅ¿olution utterly to grub them up, after we have firÅ¿t raiÅ¿ed a plantation of new ones in Å¿ome other choice freÅ¿h piece of Ground, to Å¿upply their places; for a Garden ought by no means to be without fair Currans and GooÅ¿e-berries, and aÅ¿Å¿oon as ever the new ones begin to bear, we are to deÅ¿troy the old ones, which make but a very unÅ¿ightly figure in a Garden.

div.head: D.
div.p: SHarp Dock, or Dock-Sorrel, or Patience, properly Å¿peaking, is but a Å¿ort of very great or large Sorrel, which is very Å¿ower. We content our Å¿elves only with Å¿ome borders, or perhaps, Å¿ome one Å¿ingle Bed of it, to have Å¿ome of its Leaves to mix now and then among our Sorrel. The manner of raiÅ¿ing it is the Å¿ame we practiÅ¿e with Sorrel.

div.head: E.
div.p: ENdive is a Å¿ort of very good annual Plant uÅ¿ed in Sallets, and in our pottage in the Autumn and Winter SeaÅ¿ons, provided it be well whitened, and conÅ¿equently tender and delicate; it is multiplied only by Seed. There is the Common or Garden Endive, and wild Endive, called alÅ¿o Succory, the common name in French to them both. The Common Endive is of Å¿everal kinds, viz. The White, which is the moÅ¿t delicate, and the Green Å¿ort which is the moÅ¿t ruÅ¿tical, and beÅ¿t able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the Cold, as likewiÅ¿e the Curled Å¿ort, and that which is not Curled.

All Å¿orts of them agree tolerably well with all kinds of Ground. We Å¿eldom begin to Å¿ow any of them till towards the middle of May, and then they muÅ¿t be Å¿own very thin, or be very much thinned, aftewards in order to be whitened in the places where they firÅ¿t grow, without tranÅ¿planting, and we alÅ¿o Å¿ow but a little quantity of them at once, becauÅ¿e they are too apt to run to Seed: The Å¿eaÅ¿on for Å¿owing a greater quantity of them is at the latter end of June, and during the whole Month of July, in order to have Å¿ome good for Å¿pending in September, and we afterwards Å¿ow a great deal of it again in AuguÅ¿t, that we may have a Å¿ufficient proviÅ¿ion of it to Å¿upply us all the reÅ¿t of Autumn, and the firÅ¿t part of the Winter. When our Endive comes up too thick, we cut it, or elÅ¿e pull up Å¿ome of it, to thin it, that the reÅ¿t may grow big enough to be tranÅ¿planted; and when we tranÅ¿plant any of it in Summer time, it muÅ¿t be placed at the diÅ¿tance of a large foot between Plant and Plant; we uÅ¿ually make great Beds of five or Å¿ix foot broad, in order to tranÅ¿plant them afterwards in rows markt out Å¿trait with a cord. This Plant requires great and frequent waterings; and when 'tis big enough we muÅ¿t go to work to whiten it, for which effect, we tie it up with two or three bands according as its height requires; and being Å¿o tied, it whitens in fifteen, or twenty days: But becauÅ¿e it is very apprehenÅ¿ive of the FroÅ¿t, therefore aÅ¿Å¿oon as ever the Cold begins to come on, we cover it with long dry Dung, whether it be tied up or no: At the end of September, we plant the Å¿tocks of it pretty near together becauÅ¿e then it grows neither Å¿o high, nor Å¿preads Å¿o much as in Summer: And if we can Å¿ave any Plants of it in Winter, we muÅ¿t tranÅ¿plant them again in the Spring in order to produce Seed that may have Å¿ufficient time to ripen. ThoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons that have a good ConÅ¿ervatory or Green houÅ¿e, will do well to houÅ¿e it up there, but they which have none muÅ¿t be content to cover it up well with a good quantity of long dry Dung, Å¿o that the FroÅ¿t may not come at it.

Wild Endive, or Succory is Å¿own at the very beginning of the Month of March, and that pretty thick, and in Ground well prepared. We endeavour to fortifie it, and make it grow big all Summer, by watering, and cropping it that it may be fit to whiten in Winter.

There are Å¿ome People that will eat it Green in Sallets though it be never Å¿o bitter, but commonly they rather deÅ¿ire it whitened: And to whiten it, we cover it up with a great deal of long Dung, after we have firÅ¿t cut it cloÅ¿e to the Earth, by which means, it been forced to Å¿pring up in obÅ¿curity, and Å¿haded from all light, its young Å¿hoots grow White and tender. The neateÅ¿t way is by the interpoÅ¿ition of Å¿ome props croÅ¿Å¿ing from Å¿ide to Å¿ide, to keep the Dung from touching it, Å¿ince it Å¿hoots up in the Å¿ame manner under Å¿uch a hollow covering as under a cloÅ¿e one, Å¿o that care be taken, Å¿o well to Å¿top up paÅ¿Å¿ages on all Å¿ides, that no light or Air at all get in. Being thus ordered, its Å¿hoots are much cleanlier, and reliÅ¿h not Å¿o much of the Dung. They which have ConÅ¿ervatories may tranÅ¿plant Å¿ome of it thither in Winter, it Å¿prouting well enough there, when it is but a little obÅ¿curely placed. When it is Green it endures the FroÅ¿t well enough, and at the very latter end of May, it runs to Seed. Many People eat its young Å¿hoots in Sallets when they are young and tender.

div.head: F.
div.p: FEnnel is one of our Sallets Furnitures which grows only from Seeds, and is Å¿eldom tranÅ¿planted. It reÅ¿iÅ¿ts the Cold of Winter. We Å¿ow it either in Beds or Borders. It Å¿prings again, when cut. Its youngeÅ¿t and tendreÅ¿t Å¿hoots are the beÅ¿t. Its Seed is gathered in AuguÅ¿t; and in fine it agrees well enough with all Å¿orts of Grounds. See more of it under Anis.
Furnitures, which are Mint, Tarragon, Samphire, &c. See their culture under the Å¿everal titles of thoÅ¿e Plants that compoÅ¿e them.

div.head: G.
div.p: GArlick is propagated by heads, or kernels called Cloves, about the end of February which are Å¿et three or four Inches deep in the Ground, and at three or four Inches diÅ¿tance one from the other. They are taken out of the Earth at the end of July, and laid to dry in a place free from moiÅ¿ture, in order to preÅ¿erve them from one year to another.
GooÅ¿e-berries: See Currans.

div.head: H.
div.p: HArtshorn or Buckshorn Sallet, is a little annual Plant whoÅ¿e Leaves when tender, are uÅ¿ed in Sallet Furnitures they are Å¿own in March very thick, it being impoÅ¿Å¿ible to Å¿ow them thin, becauÅ¿e their Seeds are Å¿o very Å¿mall which are gatherad in the Month of AuguÅ¿t. The little Birds are very greedy of them, as they are of all other Å¿mall Kitchen Plant Seeds. When the Leaves of this Plant are cut, there Å¿pring up freÅ¿h ones, as do alÅ¿o from Sorrel, Cives, ParÅ¿ley, &c.
Fine, or Sweet Herbs: See Aromaticks.

div.head: L.
div.p: LAvender Å¿erves to garniÅ¿h borders in Kitchen-Gardens, and yields a Flower which without being Å¿eparated from its Å¿talks, is uÅ¿ed to put among clean Linen to perfume it. It is multiplied both by Seed, and by its Branches or Slips which have taken Root at their joints.

Leeks are Å¿own at the end of Winter, and that pretty thick, and in Beds well prepared, after which during the whole Month of June, we take them up neatly and tranÅ¿plant them into other Beds which are no leÅ¿s carefully prepared; in order to which, we make with a planting Å¿tick, holes about four Inches deep, and half a foot aÅ¿under, and after we have a little trimmed both their Roots and Leaves, we only Å¿lide down a Å¿ingle Plant into every hole, without minding to preÅ¿s down the Earth about it, as we do to all other Plants; however we take care to grub up the Weeds about them from time to time, and to water them a little in very dry weather, that their Å¿tems may grow to a due thickneÅ¿s, and may whiten before Winter; when the FroÅ¿t is very brisk, it is beÅ¿t to cover them, or elÅ¿e, to Å¿et them into Earth in the ConÅ¿ervatory; it is likewiÅ¿e very convenient, to take them up out of their Bed where they are planted a little at large, and to place them nearer together afterwards in another NurÅ¿ery Bed, and cover them up with long Litter, becauÅ¿e otherwiÅ¿e when it freezes hard, we Å¿hould not be able to get them out of the Ground without breaking them. We may leave Å¿ome of them Å¿tanding after Winter, to run to Seed, or elÅ¿e we may Plant Å¿ome in a Å¿eparate place for that purpoÅ¿e. Their Seed is gathered in AuguÅ¿t, and there is one Å¿ort that is bigger than the ordinary one, which is the beÅ¿t.

Lettuces are Plants that are the moÅ¿t ordinarily and commonly Å¿een in our Kitchen-Gardens, and are indeed the moÅ¿t uÅ¿eful Manna of them, and eÅ¿pecially for Sallets, of which almoÅ¿t all the World is moÅ¿t conÅ¿tantly amorous. We have many things; for in the firÅ¿t place, there are Lettuces of different SeaÅ¿ons, thoÅ¿e which are good in certain Months in the year being not good in others; and thoÅ¿e which grow well in the Spring, thriving not well in Summer; and they which proÅ¿per in Autumn and Winter, coming tonothing, neither in Spring nor Summer, as will be Å¿een afterwards: In the Å¿econd place, there are Å¿ome that with the ordinary help of the general culture attain their due perfection, and contribute both to the nouriÅ¿hment and pleaÅ¿ure of Man-kind, and they are the Cabbage Lettuces.
Thirdly, there are Å¿ome that neceÅ¿Å¿arily require the Art of InduÅ¿try and the Gard'ner to advance them to that degree of perfection which they Å¿hould have; and they are Å¿uch as muÅ¿t be tied up to make them grow white, without which they would be neither tender, nor Å¿weet, nor good; Å¿uch as are the Roman Lettuces, &c. Nay, and I have thought fit Å¿ometimes to tie up thoÅ¿e that were to cabbage, when I Å¿aw they did not cabbage Å¿oon enough, by which means they may be forced to cabbage whether they will or no. I uÅ¿e this Method particularly with Å¿ome Å¿orts of Winter Lettuces, that is, when there are any of them which though furniÅ¿hed with leaves big enough to cabbage, yet for want of Å¿ufficient heat, are hindred from turning, that is from growing hard; and this expedient is a very Å¿overaign Remedy againÅ¿t that Defect, in a Å¿urly SeaÅ¿on; and beÅ¿ides theÅ¿e general diÅ¿tinctions, the number of the particular Kinds of Lettuces is greater than of any other Å¿ort of Kitchen-plants whatÅ¿oever, as will appear more eÅ¿pecially by the order they obÅ¿erve in reÅ¿pect of the SeaÅ¿ons; and the order of the Cabbage-Lettuces, as near as I can deÅ¿cribe it, is this.

The firÅ¿t that cabbage at the going out of Winter, are the Shell Lettuces Å¿o call'd, becauÅ¿e their Leaf is round almoÅ¿t like a Shell. They are otherwiÅ¿e called Winter-Lettuces, becauÅ¿e they pretty well indure ordinary FroÅ¿ts, which none of all the other Lettuces can do. TheÅ¿e are Å¿own in September, and afterward tranÅ¿planted in Å¿ome Wall-Border towards the South and EaÅ¿t, in the Months of October and November, or elÅ¿e they are Å¿own upon Hot Beds under Bells, in the Months of February and March, and are good to eat in April and May. We have at the Å¿ame time another Å¿ort of ReddiÅ¿h Lettuces called PaÅ¿Å¿ion Lettuces, which proÅ¿per very well in light Grounds, but not over well in others that being colder and Å¿tronger or heavier, eaÅ¿ily infect them with Å¿limy Snivel. Both theÅ¿e kinds Å¿hould when they thrive, produce very thick and good Heads. To theÅ¿e Å¿ucceed the Bright curled Lettuces, which uÅ¿ually cabbage in the Spring, that is before the heat grows any thing exceÅ¿Å¿ive, but they muÅ¿t not be planted in Å¿trong and heavy Lands. They likewiÅ¿e do well enough upon a Hot Bed, and eÅ¿pecially under GlaÅ¿s Bells or Frames; for when they are Å¿own in January, and tranÅ¿planted as Å¿oon as they are grown any thing thick, or elÅ¿e left thin upon their NurÅ¿ery-Beds, they cabbage as Å¿oon as the Winter-Lettuces, and are very excellent.

There is about the Å¿ame SeaÅ¿on, two other Å¿orts of Curled Bright Lettuces; viz. one called George Lettuces, which are thicker and leÅ¿s curled than the ordinary Curled Bright Lettuces; and another called the Minion Lettuce, which is the leaÅ¿t Å¿ort. Both theÅ¿e laÅ¿t require Å¿uch Ground as we term good black Sand, but yet their Heads Å¿eldom cabbage cloÅ¿e enough, that is to Å¿ay, are not ordinarily Å¿o hard and firm as thoÅ¿e of the right Curled Bright Lettuces.
The Curled Green Lettuces come in near about the Å¿ame SeaÅ¿on with the preceeding ones, but are not Å¿o tender nor delicate.

There is alÅ¿o a Å¿ort of Å¿mall red ones, and another named Short Lettuces, both which have all the neceÅ¿Å¿ary qualifications of good Lettuces, excepting only that their Heads are Å¿mall, and that they likewiÅ¿e require Black Sandy Ground.

The firÅ¿t Lettuces Å¿upply us amply as I have Å¿aid, during the Months of April and May, and the beginning of June, but after that time they are too apt to be influenced to run to Seed by the great heat that then comes on. They are followed during the reÅ¿t of June, and all the Month of July, by thoÅ¿e called the Royal Bellegardes, or Fair Looks, Bright Genua's, Capucins, Aubervilliers, and Perpignans; of which laÅ¿t, there are both green and bright, both of which produce very fair and very good heads, and thrive well enough in Å¿trong Grounds too, when the Summer proves not too Rainy; but cold, or too frequent Rains infect them with Slime and Snivel, and conÅ¿equently deÅ¿troy them. The Capucin Lettuces are reddiÅ¿h, cabbage eaÅ¿ily, even without tranÅ¿planting, and are pretty delicate. The Aubervilliers bring forth Heads that are too hard, and Å¿ometimes bitter withall, and are more uÅ¿ed for boiling than for Sallets. The difference that appears between the Royal and the Bellegardes or Fair look'd Lettuces, is only, that the former are a little more GreeniÅ¿h, and theÅ¿e laÅ¿t a little Brighter.

However in the Summer time, the tied Lettuces are mixed among the cabbaged ones, viz. the Roman Lettuces which are open, and are called Chicons, or Bright, and are termed Alphanges, which laÅ¿t are more delicate than the Chicons, both to raiÅ¿e, and when they are eaten in Sallets. There are alÅ¿o a Å¿ort which are Å¿tiled Imperial Lettuces, which are of an extraordinary great Size, and are likewiÅ¿e very delicate to the taÅ¿te, but very apt to rot as Å¿oon as ever they grow white; there are beÅ¿ides, a certain kind of large ReddiÅ¿h Chi
â¢â¢â¢ s, which whiten in a manner of themÅ¿elves without tying, and are good in courÅ¿e Grounds, and Å¿ucceed uÅ¿ually pretty well in Summer, for as for the green Chicons, we
cannot well have them but in the Spring, becauÅ¿e they run too haÅ¿tily to Seed. The Lettuces that defend themÅ¿elves beÅ¿t from the great heat that predominates about the end of July, and all the Month of AuguÅ¿t, are thoÅ¿e we call Genua Lettuces, and eÅ¿pecially the green Å¿ort, for the Bright Genua, and Red Genua run more eaÅ¿ily to Seed, and will hardly come to good but in light Grounds. We Å¿hould therefore prepare a great many of theÅ¿e green Genua's againÅ¿t the Dog-days, and the firÅ¿t FroÅ¿ts; we may alÅ¿o intermix with them Å¿ome few Bright, and Å¿ome Red Genua's; but more eÅ¿pecially we Å¿hould be Å¿ure to mix with them Å¿ome Alfanges, and a great quantity of bright or white Endive, as likewiÅ¿e, a great many Perpignan Lettuces, both of the bright and green kind. The great Inconveniencies that happen to Cabbage Lettuces, are firÅ¿t, that they often degenerate Å¿o far as to cabbage no more, which is diÅ¿covered by their Leaves growing out in length like a Cat's Tongue, as Gard'ners term it, or by their changing their natural colour into another more or leÅ¿s green; and therefore we muÅ¿t be very careful to gather no Seed from any but Å¿uch as cabbage very well, for which effect, we Å¿hould be Å¿ure to mark out at firÅ¿t, Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e that turn beÅ¿t, in order to reÅ¿erve them to run to Seed where they Å¿tand, or to remove them with a turf of the Earth about them into Å¿ome Å¿eparate place aÅ¿Å¿igned for that purpoÅ¿e.

The Å¿econd is, that as Å¿oon as the moÅ¿t part of them are cabbaged, they muÅ¿t be Å¿pent, unleÅ¿s we would have the diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure to Å¿ee them run to Seed without doing us any Service; in which ReÅ¿pect the Market Gard'ners have a great advantage beyond other PerÅ¿ons, becauÅ¿e they can Å¿ell off in one day, whole Beds of theÅ¿e Cabbage Lettuces, for commonly the Beds which were new planted at the Å¿ame time, Cabbage likewiÅ¿e all at once, whereas in other Gardens, we cannot Å¿pend them any faÅ¿ter than we need them, for which ReaÅ¿on we are obliged to plant often of them, and that in greater quantity than we are able to conÅ¿ume, that we may have a continual Å¿upply of them Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively, without any DiÅ¿continuation, it being much more commodious to have an over-plus quantity of them, than to want. The Å¿ureÅ¿t way is to keep particularly to thoÅ¿e Å¿orts that are the moÅ¿t RuÅ¿tical, and that laÅ¿t a great while cabbaged before they run to Seed, Å¿uch as are the Shell Lettuces, the Perpignans, the Green Genua's, the Aubervilliers, and the AuÅ¿trichettes, or AuÅ¿trian Lettuces, which I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s too, are a long time cabbaging.

The third inconvenience is, that the Morie, that is, the Rot which begins at the ends of their Leaves, Å¿eizes them Å¿ometimes, and that when the Ground or the SeaÅ¿on are not favourable to them, they remain thin and lean, and run up to Seed inÅ¿tead of Å¿preading and cabbaging. There is hardly any Remedy to prevent this Rot becauÅ¿e there is hardly any to be found effectual againÅ¿t the cold and rainy SeaÅ¿ons that cauÅ¿e it; but againÅ¿t the defects that may be in the Ground, there are infallible ones, that is to Å¿ay, it muÅ¿t be amended and improved with Å¿mall Dung, if it be barren, whether it be a Å¿andy, or a Cold and groÅ¿s Earth; and to this laÅ¿t, we Å¿hould give a little Å¿lope, if when the Ground is good, the waters Å¿poil it by Å¿ettling too much in it, and by that means, make all the Plants growing there to rot. Good Dung throughly rotten, being the Soul and Primum Mobile of Kitchen-Gardens, without which, no more than without frequent waterings, and dreÅ¿Å¿ing of the Ground no man can ever be rich in fine and goodly Legumes.

There yet remains to be known for the perfect underÅ¿tanding the ordering of Lettuces, that they which grow biggeÅ¿t muÅ¿t be placed ten or twelve inches one from the other, which is to be underÅ¿tood of the Shell Lettuces, Perpignans, AuÅ¿trians, Bellegardes, or Fair-looks, Aubervilliers, Alfanges, and Imperials; and for thoÅ¿e that bear heads but of a midling Å¿ize, the diÅ¿tance of Å¿even or eight inches is enough, which are the Bright Curled, the Å¿hort, the little Red, and the Green Chicon Lettuces, &c. ThoÅ¿e that will be good husbands may Å¿ow RadiÅ¿hes in their Lettuce Beds, becauÅ¿e the RadiÅ¿hes will be all drawn out and Å¿pent before the Lettuces cabbage; and for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on, becauÅ¿e the Endives are much longer before they come to perfection than the Lettuces, we may Plant Å¿ome of theÅ¿e laÅ¿t among the Endives; they agree well enough one with the other: and Å¿o we may have a double crop to gather upon one and the Å¿ame Bed and in the Å¿ame SeaÅ¿on; for the Lettuces are gathered firÅ¿t, and afterwards the Endives arrive to their full goodneÅ¿s.

div.head: M.
div.p: MAches, are a Å¿ort of little Sallet which we may call a wild and ruÅ¿tical Sallet, becauÅ¿e indeed it Å¿eldom is brought before any noble Company. They are multiplied by Seed which is gathered in July, and are only uÅ¿ed towards the end of Winter. We make Beds for them which we Å¿ow about the end of AuguÅ¿t; they are hardy enough to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the rigours of the FroÅ¿t, and becauÅ¿e they produce a great many little Seeds that eaÅ¿ily fall, though we have but a little quantity of them, they will propagate themÅ¿elves Å¿ufficiently, without any other culture but weeding them.

Mallows and MarÅ¿h-mallows ought to be allowed a place in our Kitchen-Gardens, though civility will not permit us to explain in this TreatiÅ¿e what uÅ¿es they Å¿erve for, and though they be rather Plants of the wild fields than of a Garden. They grow of their own accord, and have no more need of cultivating than any of the Weeds that infeÅ¿t the good Herbs. When we have a mind to have any of them in our Gardens, it will be beÅ¿t to Å¿ow them in Å¿ome by-place.

Marjoram, or Marjerom, is an Odoriferous Plant of which we compoÅ¿e agreeable Borders and Edgings. There is the Winter Marjoram, which is the beÅ¿t, and the Summer Marjoram which laÅ¿ts not beyond that SeaÅ¿on. Both of them are multiplied by Seed, and likewiÅ¿e by Rooted Å¿lips or Å¿uckers. They are principally uÅ¿ed in making Perfumes.

Mint, called in French, Balm, when once planted, needs no other particular culture than being cut down cloÅ¿e to the Ground every year, at the end of Autumn, to make it Å¿hoot out Å¿tore of tender Sprouts in the Spring, which are mingled with the Furnitures of Sallets for them that love them a little Å¿picy and perfumed. It muÅ¿t be renewed every three years at leaÅ¿t, and placed always in good Earth. The Branches when cut off, take Root at the place where they are covered, and by that means, of one great Tuft, we may eaÅ¿ily make a great many, which are to be planted at the diÅ¿tance of a foot one from the other. In the Winter likewiÅ¿e, we plant Å¿ome thick Tufts of it upon Hot Beds and by taking care to cover them with Bells, they Å¿pring very well for about fifteen days, and then periÅ¿h.

MuÅ¿cats are a kind of Grapes, which when they attain to their natural goodneÅ¿s, are one of the moÅ¿t conÅ¿iderable commodities of a Kitchen-Garden. There are three Å¿orts of them, viz. White, Red, and Black, the White is commonly the beÅ¿t of the three, it requires temperate Countries like that of the IÅ¿le of France, and the ExpoÅ¿itions of the South and EaÅ¿t, and always a light Ground, we Å¿eldom Å¿ee any good ones in pure Earth, and if it be in hot Climates, or Gravelly, and Sandy Ground; they proÅ¿per very well upon Counter-EÅ¿paliers, or Pole Hedge-Trees, and even in the open Air. Their GoodneÅ¿s conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in having large, yellow, and crackling Berries, and growing thin in their CluÅ¿ters, and in a pretty rich musked taÅ¿te, but yet not too Å¿trong like the SpaniÅ¿h ones. The Province of Tourain produces admirable ones. Their Culture is exactly the Å¿ame with that of the ChaÅ¿Å¿ela's Grapes, both as to their Pruning, and manner of Propagation.

The Long MuÅ¿cat, called otherwiÅ¿e the PaÅ¿Å¿e-MuÅ¿quee, is another Å¿ort of Grape whoÅ¿e Berry is bigger and more longiÅ¿h than that of the ordinary MuÅ¿cat, and its cluÅ¿ters are alÅ¿o longer, but yet its taÅ¿te is nothing near Å¿o rich as that of the others.

div.head: N.
div.p: NAÅ¿turces: See Capucin Capers.

div.head: O.
div.p:
ONions are red or white, which laÅ¿t are Å¿weeter and more prized than the red ones. There's no Body but knows how many uÅ¿es they Å¿erve for. They are propagated only by Seed, which is commonly Å¿own at the latter end of February and beginning of March, in Beds of good Earth, and well prepared, and afterwards raked with an Iron Rake, to cover them, as is done to other Å¿mall Seeds. They muÅ¿t be Å¿own thin, that they may have room to grow to their full bigneÅ¿s, and therefore if they come up too thick, they muÅ¿t be thinned by pulling Å¿ome of them up as Å¿oon as they are big enough for that, which is towards the Month of May, which we tranÅ¿plant in order to uÅ¿e inÅ¿tead of Cibouls. Though the ordinary SeaÅ¿on for Å¿owing Onions, be at the end of Winter, yet we
mayÅ¿ow Å¿ome in September, and tranÅ¿plant them afterwards in the Month of May, by which means we may have Å¿ome full grown at the very beginning of July, which we may gather, plucking them firÅ¿t out of the Ground as Å¿oon as that time comes, and then after we have dried them two or three days in the hot Sun, lay them up in Å¿ome dry place, to keep all the year in caÅ¿e of need. We muÅ¿t not forget when our Onions begin to appear with pretty thick Stems above the Superficies of the Earth, that is, when they begin to advance towards their Maturity, to break them down, either by treading them under our Feet, or with a board pretty hard preÅ¿Å¿ed down upon them, becauÅ¿e by that means the nouriÅ¿hment that was before Å¿pent in their Å¿tems, being hindered from mounting upwards, will remain and Å¿ettle all in that which I think, is but improperly called their head, and make it grow Å¿o much the bigger. I have already told you elÅ¿ewhere, how their Seed is to be raiÅ¿ed.

div.head: P.
div.p: PArÅ¿ley, as well of the Curled as ordinary Å¿ort, is of great uÅ¿e in Kitchens all the year long, as well for its Leaves as Roots. It is comprehended under the Title of Verdures or green Pot-herbs. We ought not to fail in the Spring, to Å¿ow a reaÅ¿onable quantity of it in every Garden, and that pretty thick, and in good, and well prepared Ground. When its Leaves are cut, it Å¿hoots out new ones like Sorrel. It well enough reÅ¿iÅ¿ts a moderate, but not a violent cold, and therefore 'tis beÅ¿t to beÅ¿tow Å¿ome covering on it in Winter, to defend it. When we would have any of it produce large Roots, we muÅ¿t thin it in the Beds or Borders where 'tis Å¿own. It requires pretty much watering in very hot weather. There are Å¿ome that pretend to have a kind of ParÅ¿ly bigger than ordinary, but for my part I know no Å¿uch kind. The Curled ParÅ¿ly appears more agreeable to the Sight, than the Common Å¿ort, but is never a whit better than it for that. We gather our ParÅ¿ly Seeds in the Months of AuguÅ¿t and September.

Macedonian ParÅ¿ley, or AliÅ¿anders, is one of the Furnitures of our Winter-Sallets, which muÅ¿t be whitened like Wild Endive, or Succory; that is to Å¿ay, at the end of Autumn, we muÅ¿t cut down all its Leaves, and then cover the Bed where it grows, all over with long dry Dung, or Straw Screens, Å¿o cloÅ¿e, that the FroÅ¿t may not come at it, by which means, the new Leaves that Å¿pring from it, grow white, yellowiÅ¿h and tender. We Å¿ow it in the Spring, pretty thin, becauÅ¿e it produces a great many large Leaves, and we gather its Seed at the latter end of Summer. It is a good hardy Plant, and that defends its Å¿elf very well from the Drought, without requiring much watering.

ParÅ¿nips are a Å¿ort of Roots well known in our Kitchens. We Å¿ow them towards the end of Winter, either in open Ground, or Borders, and that always pretty thin, and in good and well prepared Ground; and if they come up too thick, they muÅ¿t be thinned as Å¿oon as May comes in, that they which are left, may be the better nouriÅ¿ht, and grow the fairer. They are propagated only by Seed, for the raiÅ¿ing which, the Å¿ame care is to be taken as we have directed for that of Red Beet-roots, Carrots, &c.
PaÅ¿Å¿e MuÅ¿quee: See MuÅ¿cats.
Patience, or Sharp Dock: See Dock.

Peas, or PeaÅ¿e may be placed in rank of Kitchen-plants. It is a good ruÅ¿tical or hardy Plant, which commonly is Å¿own in the open Field, without needing any other Culture than being weeded whilÅ¿t 'tis young, that is, before it begins to codd. But when they are propt, they yield more than when they are not. They require pretty good Ground, and a little Rain to make them tender and delicate, and muÅ¿t be Å¿own pretty thin. There are Å¿everal Å¿orts of them, viz. HaÅ¿tings, Green, White and Square ones, otherwiÅ¿e called large codded Peas, &c. We may have of them in the Months of May, June, July, AuguÅ¿t, September and October. For to have Å¿ome all that while after the firÅ¿t, we have no more to do, but to Å¿ow them in different Months, to have them fit for eating three Months after. ThoÅ¿e Å¿orts we are moÅ¿t choice of in Kitchen-Gardens are the HaÅ¿tings both White and Green, which are of a midling Size. We Å¿ow them at the end of October, under the Å¿helter of Å¿ome EaÅ¿tern or Southern Walls, and we raiÅ¿e Ridges or Å¿loped Banks too, Å¿ometimes for that purpoÅ¿e; and to diÅ¿poÅ¿e them to come up Å¿o much the Å¿ooner when they are Sown, we make them Sprout five or Å¿ix days before, by laying them to Å¿teep two days in Water, and afterwards laying them in a place where the cold cannot reach them, till their firÅ¿t Root begins to appear. Hard weather Å¿poils them quite, which is the reaÅ¿on why all we can do, will not procure us any good ones till the latter end of May. We likewiÅ¿e Å¿ow Å¿ome upon hot Beds, at the end of February, in order to tranÅ¿plant them by the Å¿ides of Å¿ome well expoÅ¿ed Walls, in
caÅ¿e thoÅ¿e Å¿own at the latter end of October preceeding, happen to have been Å¿poiled by the FroÅ¿t. Our laÅ¿t time of Sowing them is at MidÅ¿ummer, to have them fit to eat about All-hallow-tide.
Pompions and Potirons, or Flat Pompions: See Citrulls.

PurÅ¿lain is one of the prettieÅ¿t Plants in a Kitchen-gardens, which is principally uÅ¿ed in Sallets, and Å¿ometimes in Pottages. There are two Å¿orts of it, viz. The Green, and the Red, or Golden; this latter is the more agreeable of the two to the Eye, and more delicate and difficult to rear, Å¿o that in hard weather we have much ado to make it grow even upon hot Beds, and under Bells, for it Å¿eldom proÅ¿pers in open Beds till about the middle of May, and then too, the Earth muÅ¿t be very good, Å¿weet, and very looÅ¿e, and the weather very fair. And therefore for our firÅ¿t PurÅ¿lain which we are not to begin to Å¿ow upon hot Beds till towards the Middle of March, we muÅ¿t uÅ¿e only the Green Å¿ort, becauÅ¿e the Yellow or Golden Å¿ort dwindles away as Å¿oon as 'tis come up, unleÅ¿s the SeaÅ¿on be a little advanced, and the Sun a little hot, which is, towards the end of April. It is commonly Å¿own very thick, becauÅ¿e its Seed is Å¿o very Å¿mall, that it cannot be Å¿own thin. When we Å¿ow it upon hot Beds, either when 'tis cold, and that by conÅ¿equence GlaÅ¿s-bells or Frames are needfull, or in milder Weather, we only preÅ¿s down the Mold about it with our hands, or with the back of a Spade; but when we Å¿ow it in open Beds which muÅ¿t be well prepared for that purpoÅ¿e, we rake it over five or Å¿ix times with an Iron Rake, to make the Seed enter into the Ground.

They way to raiÅ¿e Seed from it, is to tranÅ¿plant Å¿ome Plants of it that are big enough, into Beds well prepared, at the diÅ¿tance of eight or ten inches ones from the other: The Months of June and July are proper for that effect. And then in a little time after, they are run up, and have done flowring, aÅ¿Å¿oon as ever we perceive any of their Husks to open, and diÅ¿cover Å¿ome black Seed, we muÅ¿t cut down all their Stems and lay them Å¿ome days in the Sun till all the Seed be quite ripened, and then we beat them out and winnow them, &c. We muÅ¿t be carefull to tranÅ¿plant each Å¿ort apart by it Å¿elf, that we may not be miÅ¿taken in the Seed when we are to Å¿ow it. The Stick Stalks of PurÅ¿lain that is run to Seed, are good to pickle in Salt and Vinegar, for Winter Sallets.

div.head: R
div.p: RAdiÅ¿hes, when they are qualified with all the goodneÅ¿s they Å¿hould have, that is, when they are tender, and Å¿nap eaÅ¿ily, and are Å¿weet, are in my Opinion, one of the Plants that give the moÅ¿t pleaÅ¿ure of any in our Kitchin-gardens, and that give it as often, and for as long a time as any of them all; and I look upon them as a kind of Manna in our Gardens. There Å¿eems to be no great pains required to make them grow, it being indeed only neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Å¿ow them pretty thin, in well prepared looÅ¿e and mellow Earth, and to water them Å¿oundly in drie Weather, and with this culture they will attain to all the perfection they are capable of. But the main points here in QueÅ¿tion, are firÅ¿t, to be always provided with Seed of a good kind; and Å¿econdly, to take order to have RadiÅ¿hes without diÅ¿continuation, from the Month of February, till the coming in of the FroÅ¿ts in the middle of November. As for Seed of a good kind, know, that is it that produces few Leaves, and a long red Root, for there are Å¿ome that produce a great many leaves and little Root; and when we are once provided with Seed of a good kind, we muÅ¿t be extreme carefull to propagate it, that we never be without a Å¿tock of it; for which effect, in the Month of April, we muÅ¿t chooÅ¿e out among thoÅ¿e RadiÅ¿hes that are come of the laÅ¿t years Seed, Å¿uch, as I have Å¿aid, which have the feweÅ¿t Leaves and the moÅ¿t Root, and reddeÅ¿t Necks, and tranÅ¿plant them quite whole in Å¿ome well prepared Å¿pot of Ground, a foot and a half a Å¿under: Being Å¿o tranÅ¿planted, they will run up, flower and yield Seed ripe enough to gather towards the end of July; and then we cut down their Å¿tems; and after they have been dried Å¿ome days in the Sun, we beat out the Seed, and winnow it, &c.

ThoÅ¿e Å¿tocks of them that run up to Seed, Å¿hoot up their Branches to Å¿uch a height, and perpetuate their flowers Å¿o far as if they knew not where to Å¿top; and therefore it is good to pinch off theÅ¿e Branches to a reaÅ¿onable length, that the firÅ¿t Podds may be the better nouriÅ¿hed.

But 'tis not enough to raiÅ¿e good Seed, we muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e take order to be Å¿upplied with good RadiÅ¿hes for eight or nine Months in the year. The firÅ¿t that are eaten grow on Hot-beds, the manner of raiÅ¿ing which, I have explained in the Works of November; and by the means of thoÅ¿e Hot Beds, we may have Å¿ome during the Months of February
March and April; otherwiÅ¿e we have none; and in order to have Å¿ome all the other Months, we muÅ¿t Å¿ow Å¿ome among all manner of Seeds, they coming up Å¿o very quickly, that we have time to gather off our RadiÅ¿hes before they can do any harm to the other Plants. RadiÅ¿hes are extreamly apprehenÅ¿ive of the exceÅ¿Å¿ive heat in Summer, which makes them grow Å¿trong as they term it, that is, too biting, Å¿tringy, and Å¿ometimes very hard; and therefore in that SeaÅ¿on we would affect to Å¿ow them in very looÅ¿e Mellow Ground, where the Sun Å¿hines but little; and the beÅ¿t way Å¿hould be, to make up along by the Å¿ides of Å¿ome Northern Walls, a Bed or two for that purpoÅ¿e, filled with mold to the depth of a large foot and an half, and to Å¿ow our RadiÅ¿hes there, and water them well. In Spring and Autumn, when the Sun is not Å¿o Hot, RadiÅ¿hes take well enough in open Ground, and in the wide unÅ¿heltered Air.

RaÅ¿s-berries, or RaÅ¿p-berries, as well as the White as Red, begin to Ripen at the beginning of July. They are planted in March, either in Beds or borders obÅ¿erving the diÅ¿tance of two foot between Plant and Plant. They Å¿hoot out during the Summer many well Rooted Suckers, Å¿ome of which we take away to make new plantations with, by which means the old ones are likewiÅ¿e renewed for they drie aÅ¿Å¿oon as their Fruit is gathered. The only culture uÅ¿ed to them is, firÅ¿t, in the Month of March to Å¿horten all their new Å¿hoots which we preÅ¿erve round about the old Å¿tock, and which ought to be only the thickeÅ¿t and handÅ¿omeÅ¿t, and in the Å¿econd place, to pluck away all the Å¿mall ones, as likewiÅ¿e the old ones that are dead.
Reponces are a Å¿ort of Å¿mall Å¿weet RadiÅ¿hes which grow wild in the Country, and eÅ¿pecially in the Corn, and are eatch in Sallets in the Å¿pring time. They are multiplied only by Seed.
Rocamboles: See Shallots.

Rocket is one of our Sallet Furnitures, which is Å¿own in the Spring as moÅ¿t of the others are. Its Leaf is pretty like that of RadiÅ¿hes, and its Seed is very Å¿mall, and almoÅ¿t like PurÅ¿lain Seed, but it is of a ReddiÅ¿h, or rather darkiÅ¿h Cinnamon Colour.

RoÅ¿emary is another Å¿ort of Odoriferous Plant which is principally uÅ¿ed for the perfuming of Chambers, and in decoctions for waÅ¿hing the Feet. It is multiplied in the Å¿ame manner as Rue, and other border Plants, and laÅ¿ts five or Å¿ix years in its place.

Rue is a Plant of very Å¿trong Å¿mell, of which we plant Å¿ome borders in our Gardens; it is propagated both by Seed, and Rooted Å¿lips, and is hardly of any uÅ¿e but againÅ¿t the vapours of the Mother.

div.head: S.
div.p: SAge is a border Plant, whoÅ¿e culture has nothing of particular, but is like that of the other border Herbs, as RoÅ¿emary, Lavender, Worm-wood, &c. There is a Å¿ort that is parti-Coloured, which to Å¿ome people appears more agreeable than the common Sage, which is of paliÅ¿h Green Colour.

SpaniÅ¿h SalÅ¿ifie, or SaÅ¿Å¿ifie, otherwiÅ¿e Scorzonere, is one of our chiefeÅ¿t Roots, which is multiplied by Seed as well as the others, and is admirable good boiled both for the pleaÅ¿ure of the taÅ¿te, and the health of the Body. It is propagated only by Seed which is Å¿own in March. We muÅ¿t be careful to Å¿ow it pretty thin, whether it be in Beds or borders, or elÅ¿e at leaÅ¿t to thin it afterward, that its Roots may grow the bigger. Scorzonere runs up to Seed in the Months of June and July, and is gathered aÅ¿Å¿oon as 'tis Ripe.

Common SalÅ¿ifie is another Å¿ort of Root cultivated after the Å¿ame manner as the preceeding one, but is not altogether Å¿o very excellent. They eaÅ¿ily paÅ¿s the Winter in the Ground. It is good to water both Å¿orts of them in very dry weather, and to keep them well weeded, and eÅ¿pecially, to put them into good Earth well prepared, of at leaÅ¿t two full foot deep.

Samphire called in French, Pierce Pierre, or PaÅ¿Å¿e-Pierre, is one of our Sallet Furnitures that is multiplied only by Seed, and which being by nature very delicate requires to be planted by the Å¿ides of Walls expoÅ¿ed to the South or East, the open Air, and great Cold being pernicious to it. We uÅ¿ually Å¿ow it in Å¿ome Pot or Tub filled with mold, or elÅ¿e on Å¿ome Å¿ide-Bank towards the South or EaÅ¿t, and that in the Months of March or April, and afterwards tranÅ¿plant it in thoÅ¿e places above-mentioned.

Savory is an annual Plant a little Odoriferous, which grows only from Seed, and whoÅ¿e Leaves are uÅ¿ed to Å¿ome Ragou's, and particularly among Peas, Beans; it is Å¿own in the Spring either in Beds or borders.
Scorzonere, or Scorzonera: See SpaniÅ¿h SalÅ¿ifie.

Shallots, otherwiÅ¿e Rocamboles, or SpaniÅ¿h Garlick, require no other culture than common Garlick, and are particularly remarkable for that their Seeds are as good to eat as their Cloves taken out of the Earth. Their Seed is large and Å¿erves to propagate them as well as the Cloves or Kernels that compoÅ¿e their Root.
Skirrets are a Å¿ort of Roots propagated by Seed, and cultivated like other Roots, as is directed in the Month of March.

Spinage is one of thoÅ¿e Kitchen Plants that requires the beÅ¿t Ground, or at leaÅ¿t that which is moÅ¿t amended and improved. They are multiplied only by Seed. We Å¿ow them either in open Ground, or elÅ¿e in furrows or Å¿trait rows upon well prepared Beds and this we do Å¿everal times in the year, beginning about the Å¿ixteenth of AuguÅ¿t, and finiÅ¿hing a Month after; the firÅ¿t are fit to cut towards the middle of October, the Å¿econd in Lent, and the laÅ¿t in Rogation time; ThoÅ¿e which remain after Winter, run up to Seed towards the end of May, which we gather about the middle of June. When they are once cut they Å¿pring up no more, as Sorrel do's. All their culture conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in keeping them very clear from Weeds; and if the Autumn prove extraordinary dry, it is not amiÅ¿s to water them Å¿ometimes. They are never tranÅ¿planted no more than Chervil, CreÅ¿Å¿es, &c.

Sorrel in Kitchen-Garden terms, is placed under the title of Verdures, or Green Pot Herbs, and accordingly is much uÅ¿ed in the Pot. There are Å¿ome Å¿orts of it that produce a larger Leaf than others, which are called Sorrel of the greater Å¿ort. All the Å¿orts may be Å¿own in the Months of March, April, May, June, July and AuguÅ¿t, and in the beginning of September too, provided they be allowed Å¿ufficient time to grow big enough to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the rigour of the Winter, we Å¿ow Sorrel either in open Ground, or elÅ¿e in Å¿trait rows, or furrows, in Beds or borders, in all which caÅ¿es, it muÅ¿t be Å¿own very thick, becauÅ¿e many of its Plants periÅ¿h. It requires a ground that is naturally good, or elÅ¿e well improved with Muck. Its culture conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in being kept very clear of Weeds, in being well watered, and being covered with a little mold once or twice a year, after 'tis firÅ¿t cut down very cloÅ¿e to the Ground. That mold Å¿erves to give it new vigour, and the SeaÅ¿on moÅ¿t proper for applying it, is in the hot Months of the year. Sorrel is moÅ¿t commonly multiplied by Seed, though Å¿ometimes we tranÅ¿plant Å¿ome of it that thrives very well. We gather its Seed in the Months of July and AuguÅ¿t. There is a particular Å¿ort of Sorrel, which is called Round Sorrel, its Leaves being indeed Round, whereas thoÅ¿e of the other Å¿orts are very Å¿harp and pointed. The tender Leaves of this Å¿ort are Å¿ometimes mixed with Sallet Furnitures. But it is ordinarily uÅ¿ed moÅ¿t in Bouillons, or thin Broths. It is multiplied by running Branches, that take Root in the Earth, as they run over it, which being taken off, and tranÅ¿planted, produce thick Tufts which alÅ¿o produce other runners, and Å¿o in infinitum.
Sharp Dock, or Dock-Sorrel: See Dock.
Wood Sorrel, or Alleluia: See Alleluia.

Straw-berries, as well the White as the Red, multiply and perpetuate themÅ¿elves by running Suckers that Å¿pringing out of their old Å¿tocks, take Root. It is obÅ¿erved, that a new plantation of them taken out of the Woods, turns to better account when tranÅ¿planted, than one Å¿lipt of from the Garden Straw-berries. We plant them either in Beds or borders, both which muÅ¿t be well prepared, amended and laboured or Å¿tirred up in one manner or other. If it be in dry and Å¿andy Ground, both the Beds and borders muÅ¿t be Å¿unk a little lower than the Allies or path-ways, the better to retain both the rain that falls, and the water we beÅ¿tow on them; a quite contrary courÅ¿e muÅ¿t be taken, if we plant them in Å¿trong, heavy, and fat Earth, and that is almoÅ¿t all pure Clay, becauÅ¿e exceÅ¿Å¿ive moiÅ¿ture rots the Plants. We place them uÅ¿ually nine or ten Inches aÅ¿under, putting two or three little Plants into each hole which we make with a planting Å¿tick. The beÅ¿t time to plant them in is during the whole Month of May, and in the beginning of June, that is to Å¿ay, before the great heat comes in. And we may plant them all Summer long in rainy SeaÅ¿ons. It is particularly requiÅ¿ite to plant NurÅ¿eries of them in the Month of May, and that in Å¿ome place near the North Quarter, the better to Å¿helter them from the violent heat of the Summer Sun, and then we plant them but three or four Inches one from the other, and when they are grown big enough there, we tranÅ¿plant them afterwards in the Month of September in order to make Beds or Å¿quares of them, according as we find occaÅ¿ion to have a greater or leÅ¿s abundance of them. Their culture conÅ¿iÅ¿ts chiefly, firÅ¿t, in watering them well in dry SeaÅ¿ons; Å¿econdly in leaving, but a moderate number of Å¿tems or upright Å¿hoots to every Å¿tock, three or four of the moÅ¿t vigourous being enough; in the third place, in leaving but three or four Straw-berries of
them that appeared firÅ¿t, and neareÅ¿t the Å¿tock, on every Å¿tem, and therefore we muÅ¿t pinch of all their other BloÅ¿Å¿oms that almoÅ¿t endleÅ¿sly grow out at the ends of thoÅ¿e that have already BloÅ¿Å¿omed, or are Å¿till in BloÅ¿Å¿om, becauÅ¿e none but the firÅ¿t produce any fair Straw-berries, hardly any of the laÅ¿t being ever known to knit or come to any perfection, but when we are careful to pinch them off judicially we may be aÅ¿Å¿ured always to have good Straw-berries. I have already given directions in the works of the Month of February, how to raiÅ¿e HaÅ¿ting Straw-berries. Curious PerÅ¿ons have uÅ¿ually two Straw-barries of two Å¿everal Colours, viz. Red and White, but they place them in Å¿eparate Beds. The great Enemies of Straw-berry Plantations are the Ton's which are great White Worms, that in the Months of May and June, gnaw the necks of their Roots between two Earths, and Å¿o kill them; to prevent which, in thoÅ¿e Months we Å¿hould carefully Å¿earch every day, under the Roots of all our Straw-berries that begin to wither, where we Å¿hall commonly find one of theÅ¿e great Worms which after they have done a miÅ¿chief to one, paÅ¿s on to do the Å¿ame to other Straw-berry Plants, and kill them in the Å¿ame manner. Straw-berry Plants bear very well the year after their planting, if planted in May; but yield very indifferently, if not planted till September, after they are taken out of the Woods; yet in the Å¿econd year they bear wonderfully, but that being paÅ¿t, they produce but very pitifully, and therefore 'tis good to renew them every two years; it is likewiÅ¿e convenient to cut off every year their old tops, when the Straw-berries are gone, which is commonly at the latter end of July. The earlieÅ¿t Straw-berries that ripen towards the end of May, are thoÅ¿e that were planted by the Å¿ides of Southern or EaÅ¿tern Walls, and they that ripen laÅ¿t, are Å¿uch as are planted in a Northern ExpoÅ¿ition.
Succory: See Endive.

p.hi: Sweet Herbs: See Aromaticks.

div.head: T.
div.p: TArragon is one of the perfuming or Spicy Furnitures of our Sallets, it is propagated both by rooted Å¿lips and Seed. It Å¿prings again Å¿everal times after 'tis cut; it endures the Winter, and needs little watering in the drieÅ¿t weather in Summer, when we plant it, we muÅ¿t allow eight or nine inches diÅ¿tance between Plant and Plant in the Beds we Å¿et with it. The beÅ¿t time to plant in, is in March and April, which hinders not, but that we may tranÅ¿plant it again in the Summer SeaÅ¿on.
Time is another odoriferous Border-plant, which is multiplied as well by Seed as rooted Branches or Slips. A Border of Time is a conÅ¿iderable and neceÅ¿Å¿ary Ornament in our Kitchen-Gardens.

Tripe-Madam is one of our Sallet-Furnitures; it is uÅ¿ed chiefly in the Spring when it is tender, but a little of it ought to Å¿erve in the Summer, becauÅ¿e then it is too tough. It is multiplyed both by Seeds and Cuttings.

Turneps or Turnips are not properly Kitchen-Garden Plants, but yet where they are Å¿pacious, they may be admitted into them. They are propagated only by Seed, and are Å¿own very thick in Beds, Å¿ome in March, and others in AuguÅ¿t. We gather their Seed in July and AuguÅ¿t, every Body Å¿o well knows their uÅ¿e, that I need Å¿peak no more of them here.

div.head: V.
div.p: Verjuice Grapes: See Bourdelais.
Vines: See the Å¿everal heads of Bourdelais, MuÅ¿cats, &c.

Violets, and eÅ¿pecially the double ones Å¿erve to make pretty Borders in our Kitchen-Gardens. Their flowers make a very agreeable Figure when they are artfully placed on the Superficies of Spring-Sallets. Every Body knows, that they are propagated by Tufts, that is, by dividing one great Tuft into Å¿everal little ones, which likewiÅ¿e in time grows thick, and fit to be divided into other little ones.

div.head: W.
div.p: WOrmwood. The plants of this and all other Plants placed in Borders of Edgings, and therefore called Border-plants, as of Time, Lavender, HyÅ¿Å¿op, &c. are planted by a Line, and at the diÅ¿tance of two or three Inches one from the other, and five or Å¿ix inches deep in the Ground. It is good to clip them every Spring, and to renew them every two years, and to take away their oldeÅ¿t and decayed Å¿tocks. Their Seed is gathered about the Month of AuguÅ¿t.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Shewing how long every Kitchen Plant may profitably Å¿tand in its place in a Kitchen-Garden; which of them muÅ¿t be houÅ¿ed in the ConÅ¿ervatory to Å¿upply us in the Winter, and which are they which we may force to grow by Art, in Å¿pite of the FroÅ¿t. And laÅ¿tly, how long each Å¿ort of Seed will laÅ¿t without loÅ¿ing its Virtue.

div.p: IT is a very important point in Gard'ning, to know how long every plant may uÅ¿efully poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s the place where it grows in our Gardens, that Å¿o the forecaÅ¿t of an able Gard'ner, may prepare others immediately to Å¿ubÅ¿titute in the places of Å¿uch as being as 'twere, but PaÅ¿Å¿engers, take up their places but a few Months; for by this means, not only there remains no unprofitable Å¿pot of Ground in our Gardens, but we Å¿eem beÅ¿ides to reap a Å¿enÅ¿ible pleaÅ¿ure by enjoying in Å¿ome SenÅ¿e beforehand Å¿ome things that are not yet in Nature.

To treat of this matter well, I think it very pertinent to Å¿peak firÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e Plants that are of long duration, whether in reÅ¿pect of the time they take up in attaining to their Perfection, or of that in which they continue bearing. All Å¿orts of Grapes, Capers, and AÅ¿paragus, doubtleÅ¿s, hold the firÅ¿t Rank in this number, for Vine and Caper plants laÅ¿t five and twenty or thirty years, and as to AÅ¿paragus, reckoning from the time we firÅ¿t Å¿ow or tranÅ¿plant them, we ought hardly ever to begin to gather them till their Å¿hoots be of a competent thickneÅ¿s, which happens not till the third or fourth year after, but after that time, provided they be placed in good Ground and carefully cultivated, they may very well be Å¿uffred to Å¿tand ten or twelve years, it being certain that they will not fail to Å¿hoot up and bear vigorouÅ¿ly and plentifully during all that time; but yet if we perceive any decay in them Å¿ooner, we may deÅ¿troy and break them up Å¿ooner, and if on the contrary, we find them continue to produce well longer than we have limited, we may continue them longer in their places.
Rasberry, Curran, and GooÅ¿eberry Å¿hrubs, eaÅ¿ily laÅ¿t eight or ten years.
Artichokes muÅ¿t be renewed, that is new planted in a freÅ¿h place after the third year.

The Borders of Wormwood, HyÅ¿Å¿op, Lavender, Marjoram, Rue, RoÅ¿emary, Sage, Time, Violets, &c. provided they be not endamaged by an extraordinary hard Winter, may Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t in their places three or four years, if care be taken to clip them pretty cloÅ¿e every Summer.

Alleluia, or Wood-Å¿orrel, Mint, Musked Chervil, EngliÅ¿h Cives, Tarragon, Sorrel, Patience, or Å¿harp Dock, Samphire, Macedonian ParÅ¿ly or AliÅ¿anders, Tripe-Madame, &c. may likewiÅ¿e laÅ¿t well enough in their places three or four Years.
Strawberry Plants may laÅ¿t three years, Wild Endive or Succory, Anis, Ordinary ParÅ¿ly, Burnet, Fennel, Scorzonere, and Common SalÅ¿ifie, &c. laÅ¿t two years.
Leeks both to cut, and for Chards, and Cibouls, &c. laÅ¿t a year, that is, from one Spring to another.

Borage, BugloÅ¿s, Red Beet Roots, SpaniÅ¿h Cardons, Carrots, Skirrets, Cabbages, Milan Cabbages, Collyflowers, Citruls or Pumpions, Harts-horn Sallet, Potirons or Flat Pumpions, ParÅ¿nips, Leeks, &c. keep their places nine Months, that is, reckoning from the Spring, when they were Å¿own, to the end of Autumn.

Garlick, BaÅ¿il, NaÅ¿turces or Capucin Capers, Cucumbers, and Melons or Muskmelons, Shalots, Onions, and the firÅ¿t or Summer Turneps, &c. take them up only during the Spring and Summer SeaÅ¿ons, Å¿o that their places may receive a new Decoration of Plants in Autumn.
Arrach, or Orage, Ordinary Chervil, White Endive, and Succory Garden CreÅ¿Å¿es, and all Å¿orts of Lettuces, whether to cabbage, or to tie up, &c. take up their Ground about two Months.
RadiÅ¿hes, PurÅ¿lain, and Ordinary Chervil, &c. take up their places but five or Å¿ix Weeks, and therefore they muÅ¿t be new Å¿own every fifteen days in Summer time.

Hasting PeaÅ¿e and Beans, continue on the Ground Å¿ix or Å¿even Months, reckoning from the Month of November when they are Å¿own, but common Peas and Beans, and AricÃ´s, or French-Beans, take it up but four or five Months.
Spinage and MÃ ches keep theirs all Autumn and Winter, and therefore are planted in places, where we have already raiÅ¿ed Å¿uch Plants as laÅ¿t not beyond the Summer.
Mallows and MarÅ¿h-mallows are multiplied only by Seed, and paÅ¿s not beyond the Winter.

The Plants that require houÅ¿ing in the ConÅ¿ervatory during Winter, are Cardoons, Cellery, Artichoke heads, both the Endives, as well the White, as the Wild Å¿ort, all that are known by the name of Roots, as Red Beet Roots, Carrots, &c. as likewiÅ¿e Leeks, Citruls or Pumpions, Potirons or Common Pumpions, Garlick, and Shalots. All the reÅ¿t reÅ¿iÅ¿t the injuries of the Winter well enough, viz. Cabbages, ParÅ¿ly, Fennel, Cibouls, and even Tarragon, Mint, Samphire, Tripe-Madame, Balm, AÅ¿paragus, Sorrel, &c. But they Å¿prout not till the Spring, unleÅ¿s forced on Hot Beds. Other Plants are not acquainted with that Å¿ort of help, or rather Violence, Å¿uch as are all Roots, and Garlick, Onions, Leeks, Cabbages, &c. Add to this, that by the Å¿ame expedient of Hot Beds, we may alÅ¿o raiÅ¿e in the height of cold Weather, little Sallets of Lettuces, with their Furnitures of CreÅ¿Å¿es, Chervil, Mint, &c.

There remains now nothing but to know how long each Å¿ort of Seed will keep good, upon which I muÅ¿t tell you, that generally Å¿peaking, moÅ¿t Seeds grow naught after one of two years at moÅ¿t, and therefore it concerns us always to be provided with new ones, if we would not run the hazard of Å¿owing to no purpoÅ¿e in the Spring. There are hardly any but Peas, Beans, and the Seeds of Muskmelons, Cucumbers, Citruls or Pumpions, and Potirons or Flat Cucumbers, that laÅ¿t eight or ten years. The Seeds of Collyflowers laÅ¿t three or four, and thoÅ¿e of all Å¿orts of Endive and Succory, five or Å¿ix years. Of all Å¿orts of Seeds there are none that keep Å¿o Å¿mall a time as Lettuce Seed, which yet are better the Å¿econd, than the firÅ¿t year, but yet are good for nothing the third.
