div.head: DIRECTIONS Concerning MELONS.
div.p: IT is now more than Twenty Years Å¿ince MonÅ¿ieur De la Quintinye, being in England, that receiving the Honor of a ViÅ¿it from him at my HouÅ¿e, and falling into DiÅ¿courÅ¿e of Gardens, he afterwards (on my RequeÅ¿t) Å¿ent me Å¿ome Directions from Paris, concerning the Ordering of Melons; it being in Effect the Å¿ame (though Å¿omewhat more ample) which was about that time PubliÅ¿hed by Mr. Oldenburg. It may not perhaps be Unwelcome to our Gard'ner, or improperly Annex'd to this UÅ¿eful Part of Horticulture; eÅ¿pecially coming from the moÅ¿t Tran. R. S. Experienc'd, in relation to this delicious Fruit: However (and for what ReaÅ¿on I enquire not) omitted as to any particular, and full InÅ¿tructions in this long expected Work of his.

p.hi: I give it therefore in the Method I long Å¿ince caÅ¿t it for Å¿ome Friends of mine.

div.p: THE moÅ¿t Undegenerating Å¿ort of Melons are not large, but of a middling Size, the Rind thin, faintly Embroider'd, and without being Ribb'd or divided along the Sides, or at leaÅ¿t very obÅ¿curely: Others there are which be whitiÅ¿h, Å¿ome of a Slate-colour, Red-fleÅ¿h, dry, yet melting in the Mouth, and not at all Mealy, but of an high and generous GuÅ¿t. In a word, the only Å¿ort (after Trials of many hundred Kinds) I have Cultivated with SucceÅ¿s, and that retain their good Qualities more than Twenty Years, without any conÅ¿iderable Alteration.

Every Gard'ner now-a-days, knows how to raiÅ¿e Melons, but very few to Govern them; the greateÅ¿t difficulty whereof is in the Guelding of Superfluities, to cauÅ¿e them to knit, and bear as they Å¿hould do. In order to which, obÅ¿erve theÅ¿e few Directions:

The firÅ¿t thing appearing (after the Seed is Sown, and the Plants prick'd out from the Hot-Bed into a more temperate) are a pair of Å¿mall Å¿mooth Leaves, which (in France) we call the Ears, marked 1. 1. in the Figure above. A few days after, 'twixt theÅ¿e, comes up a Å¿ingle Leaf, which we call the FirÅ¿t Leaf, as being on the firÅ¿t Knot, noted 2. Next to this, in the Å¿ame place, and Å¿oon after, there appears another, which we term the Second Knot, marked 3. About the middle of whoÅ¿e Stalk there Å¿hoots out another Leaf, call'd the Third Knot, Figur'd 4. Which Third Knot is always to be Pruned off at Fig. 6. but with Care, and without Wounding the Stalk or Branch of the Second Knot, marked 3, upon which that Third did grow; it being from this place you will find that Branch to Sprout, which we call the FirÅ¿t Leader; and is that which will Å¿end out a FirÅ¿t, Second, and Third Knot; which Third (and all other Å¿uch Thirds) you muÅ¿t Cut, or pinch off, as you did the other, without Å¿taying 'till a Fourth, or Fifth, or more, Å¿hoot out. It is, I Å¿ay, from theÅ¿e Knots and Joints, that other Branches in like manner will proceed, knit, and form into Excellent Fruit, provided the Foot and Original Stem have been well nouriÅ¿h'd in rich, warm, and proper Mould, and well expos'd.

I muÅ¿t not forget, that from the middle, likewiÅ¿e 'twixt the Ears and two firÅ¿t Leaves, there frequently riÅ¿es another Branch, which you may abate, or leave on, as you find it likely to prove, eÅ¿pecially if a vigorous one; but the Leaf Figur'd 5, iÅ¿Å¿uing from the middle of the Fourth Joint, and Å¿everal more beÅ¿ides, Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively Springing out of one another, as you Å¿ee the Fourth from the Third (and as all the reÅ¿t I have marked do) I purpoÅ¿ely omit, and have only Figur'd, as Å¿uperfluous to the Ingenious Gard'ner.

When I TranÅ¿plant from this NurÅ¿ery-Bed (into the prepared Holes or Ridges, and open Meloniere) I commonly place two Roots together, unleÅ¿s I meet with an extraordinary good Plant, and then Å¿pare both the Branches which Spring from each Å¿ide, 'twixt the Ear and Leaf 7, 7, as before is Å¿hew'd: But when I Plant two Roots near each other (as I do when they are not very fair ones) I totally reject both Branches which Å¿hoot from the two oppoÅ¿ite Ears, to avoid that ConfuÅ¿ion of thoÅ¿e Supernumeraries which injure the principal Stem and Foot it Å¿elf.

Never Å¿uffer the Root, or Stalks of your Melon Plants, to touch the Dung; nor Å¿hould you Water them immoderately, but when the Earth is very dry, and the SeaÅ¿on exceÅ¿Å¿ively hot, refreÅ¿h, and give the Roots Drink, without deferring it 'till the Shoots complain, when it may come too late: I Water them in theÅ¿e parching SeaÅ¿ons, two or three times every Week, and in the Evenings when the Sun is Setting, and then cover them with MatraÅ¿Å¿es, from Eleven 'till Two a Clock; and in the Afternoon during the Suns exceÅ¿Å¿ive violence, which ExhauÅ¿ts, and ConÅ¿umes the Humidity neceÅ¿Å¿ary to both Roots and Branches.

I cover my Meloniere alÅ¿o when it Rains, leÅ¿t too much MoiÅ¿ture prejudice the Fruit; all which requires a great deal of Care, and no Å¿mall Pains, though this Regular proceeding is to me a real PleaÅ¿ure.

When the Foot of your Melon Plant grows over Luxurious in Branches, cut away the feebleÅ¿t of them, leaving not above three or four of the moÅ¿t vigorous, and whoÅ¿e Knots grow neareÅ¿t to one another: And when the Melons are Knit, Å¿uffer not above two upon each Foot, chooÅ¿ing Å¿uch as are beÅ¿t plac'd, and neareÅ¿t to the main and principal Stem, which Å¿hould be thick, Å¿nug, and not too far above the Ground. Of theÅ¿e that are knit, and beginning to form, make choice of the handÅ¿omeÅ¿t, that are well TruÅ¿s'd with a thick Å¿hort Tail; Melons with long Å¿tarts, Å¿lender, and narrow Leaves, never prove worth any thing.

When you begin to Cover with Bells, raiÅ¿e them Å¿o upon little Forks, as they neither reÅ¿t upon the Fruit or Branches, or quite exclude the Air; but Å¿o as to keep the edges from bruiÅ¿ing, and preÅ¿Å¿ing the tender Stalk, and Intercepting the Current Sap.

It now and then happens, that there riÅ¿es a Å¿econd Branch from between the Ears, and two firÅ¿t Leaves (though I mention'd indeed but one) but this is very Å¿eldom; and you are Å¿till to count them but for one Joint or-Knot, though there will thence proceed a Second, Third, Fourth, and perhaps Twenty or Thirty more, and further remote, if you let them alone, and be not vigilant to reÅ¿train, and Å¿top this ex â¢ berance in due time. 'Tis true, they will preÅ¿ent you with Fruit at the Extremities of their Branches, but 'tis little worth, as being Å¿o far diÅ¿tant from the Root, that the Sap Å¿pends it Å¿elf in the tedious paÅ¿Å¿age before it arrives, as
you'll find by the wither'd Branch, and dryneÅ¿s of the Leaves which Å¿hould skreen both Branches and Fruit, 'till they are Ripe, as we Å¿ee they do, where a Melon has a Å¿hort and Å¿ubÅ¿tantial Foot. A Curious Gard'ner therefore Å¿hould viÅ¿it his Meloniere from time to time, and be Cutting off all Mutilated, Starv'd and Vicious Branches which annoy the Plants, for theÅ¿e Impertinents will grow even to the view of ones Eye, and quite ImpoveriÅ¿h the Fruit, if not timely prevented.

Thus you Å¿ee I am careful to Purge the Stems of all the Å¿mall, Å¿traggling, and unprofitable Branches, from which there is no expectation of good Fruit, whilÅ¿t obÅ¿erving thoÅ¿e that have well knit Melons on them at the ends of the Branches, I conÅ¿tantly take away the reÅ¿t of that Branch on this Å¿ide the Fruit, which-divaricating into other uÅ¿eleÅ¿s Wanderers, would Rob, and deprive the Fruit of the Nutriment derived from the Root; nevertheleÅ¿s with this Caution, that in Pruning, I Å¿pare Å¿ome other leÅ¿s Noxious Branches to Å¿hade the Fruit, that it be not left quite Naked, and expos'd to Å¿uch a Å¿corching Heat as would hinder its Growth and Maturity, which within Forty days from its Nativity and knitting into Fruit, arrives to full Perfection.

Great and Pumpion-like Melons are very Å¿eldom tollerably good, as arriving to their bulk either from the Nature of the Seed and Kind, or from Å¿uperfluous Watering the Å¿maller ones; wherefore (though as I Å¿aid they cannot Å¿upport the too exceÅ¿Å¿ive Heats) the leÅ¿s Water you give your Plants (provided you find them not to want it) the better; and that rather a little at a time than much: Once a Week is for moÅ¿t part Å¿ufficient. As to this therefore you muÅ¿t determine, and regulate your RefreÅ¿hments with great CircumÅ¿pection, and Judge by the NouriÅ¿hment which you concieve NeceÅ¿Å¿ary to Produce and Maintain the Foot, with its Branches, and Leaves deriving from it; without which no Kind and Genuine Fruit is to be expected.

When you would Gather a Ripe Melon, you will have notice by its turning a little Yellow; for from that time, within a day (as the Weather proves) it does ordinarily Ripen, and begin to caÅ¿t a grateful Scent: This YellowneÅ¿s appearing in Å¿ome part of it or other, and not Å¿eldom with Å¿ome Rift, or little CaÅ¿m's about the Stalk, &c. are moÅ¿t Infallible Indications of its being left rather too long, than too haÅ¿tily Gather'd: The Gard'ner muÅ¿t therefore not fail of ViÅ¿iting the Meloniere at the leaÅ¿t three times a day, Morning, Noon, and Evening, for this Critical time of Ripening. He will Å¿ometimes find Melons Ripen too faÅ¿t, but they are Å¿eldom or never Good, as proceeding rather from a Å¿ickly, or vicions Root, than from the Nature of the Plant, or Species of thoÅ¿e I Cultivate.

After Twenty four Hours keeping, or the next day after it has been Gather'd (for Å¿o long, contrary to Vulgar Opinion, it Å¿hould be preÅ¿erv'd in Å¿ome Å¿weet dry place) and not Eaten immediately as it comes from the Garden: A perfect and tranÅ¿cendent Melon will be Full, Juicy, and without any Vacuity (which you'll eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cern by Rapping a little with your Knuckles upon the outÅ¿ide of the Fruit) the Meat Å¿hould alÅ¿o be dry, or but a little Rorid meazing out of the Pulp; but by no means WatriÅ¿h and FlaÅ¿hy. To this add a Vermillion Colour, a grateful Flavor, and an high and Racy TaÅ¿te.

LaÅ¿tly, ReÅ¿erve for Seed of that only which lies towards the Sunny Å¿ide of the Melon, which being immediately cleans'd from its MuÅ¿ilage, with a dry Linnen Cloth, ReÅ¿erve in Boxes, or Papers, in Å¿ome Temperate and Sweeter place.

div.head: AN AdvertiÅ¿ement to the CURIOUS.
div.p: IT were to be wiÅ¿h'd that the Author (whom I had the Honour to know) had liv'd to put his laÅ¿t Hand to this whole Work, and added to his Potagere, the Culture of Melons in which he was the moÅ¿t ExquiÅ¿ite MaÅ¿ter, but has in a manner quite omitted it: Not, that what he has oblig'd the World withal, is not the moÅ¿t Perfect, and ConÅ¿ummate Piece that was ever, I believe, PubliÅ¿h'd on this agreeable Subject, but becauÅ¿e 'tis Å¿aid, He did himÅ¿elf intend it, and perhaps, to have abbreviated Å¿ome Periods and Repetitions which now and then occur to the TranÅ¿lator, but which he cannot honeÅ¿tly pretermit to juÅ¿tifie the VerÅ¿ion. As to what the Author has mention'd in Chap. ix. I acknowledge to have Å¿een by Experience, that the Naked Fire, made t â¢ o near the Pipes, is intolerable, melting even CaÅ¿t Iron it Å¿elf: But, as I no where recommend that Metal, but that the Pipes be made of Crucible Earth, and propoÅ¿e the whole but as a laudable Experiment; Å¿o I do not QueÅ¿tion, but if Å¿uch Pipes were contriv'd to be plac'd at farther diÅ¿tance from the Fire, or that there were a reaÅ¿onable thick Fire-Stone laid flat, or rather Arch-wiÅ¿e (on which there might be Å¿trew'd a Bath or Bed of Sand) between the Naked Fire and the Pipes, to Intercept, and moderate the IntenÅ¿er Heat (with due regard to RegiÅ¿ter and Govern the BlaÅ¿t) but that a gentle and benign warmth would enÅ¿ue, and Å¿uch as Å¿hould only Recreate, without the leaÅ¿t Inconvenience to our niceÅ¿t Exotics: Add to this, and for the more equal distribution of this Genuine Temper, that the NoÅ¿es of the Pipes might eaÅ¿ily be InÅ¿erted into a larger Pipe of Laton, which Å¿hould be applied either to the blind Wall the whole length of the HouÅ¿e within, or in the middle, which being pierced with frequent Å¿mall holes, would breathe it more equally through the ConÅ¿ervatory: There might alÅ¿o be placed a VeÅ¿Å¿el, or Kettle, upon the FireÅ¿tone-Diaphragma, to be at any time fill'd, and Å¿upplied by a Tunnel from without with Water, the Vapor of which would exceedingly temper the Pipes, and Contribute to the Perfection of this Experiment.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: AMong the FloriÅ¿t Gard'ners, of whom there are a great many very able Men, one frequently meets with Å¿ome, pretending as if to them alone pertain'd the Government of Orange-Trees; and would make the World believe, that the Culture of thoÅ¿e Å¿ort of Trees is the only MaÅ¿ter-Piece of Gard'ning; and upon this, make a great deal of Å¿hew, and talk mightily about the Preparation of Earths, and of finding out all the Ingredients which, they'll tell you, ought to go to their CompoÅ¿ition: Nor boaÅ¿t they leÅ¿s of their In-CaÅ¿ement, Potting, Waterings; the Å¿etting them in, bringing out, and ExpoÅ¿ure, &c.

There are likewiÅ¿e Å¿ome among 'em, who carry the Secret a great deal farther, and that pretend the Kinds and Species of Orange-Trees are almoÅ¿t infinite, and Å¿uch as (how true Å¿oever) were enough to affright the moÅ¿t Curious, if, as they would make one believe, every one of thoÅ¿e Kinds did abÅ¿olutely require a certain Specific Salt peculiar to them, and would imbark us upon Å¿uch an Ocean of Difficulties, as hardly any Body would adventure upon a Voyage Å¿o dangerous, and where the Ship-wreck Å¿eems almoÅ¿t inevitable.

But, as in our Ort-yards and Olitorie Gardens, where the Number of the Species, and Å¿everal Kinds, do greatly exceed thoÅ¿e of Orange Trees, Experience
teaches us, that the very Å¿ame Culture does very near Å¿erve for all Å¿orts of Kernel-Fruit, all kind of Stone-Fruit, and all Verdures whatÅ¿oever: Upon this Experience therefore we preÅ¿ume, that there needs no other Culture for all the Å¿orts of Orange Trees, and this upon very good AÅ¿Å¿urance, daily Trials, and convincing Proofs.

I Å¿hall not therefore Å¿tand upon Å¿o many and great Difficulties, by which both the one and the other have deterr'd many Curious PerÅ¿ons, PaÅ¿Å¿ionate Lovers of the Orange Tree: A PaÅ¿Å¿ion, in my Opinion, the moÅ¿t reaÅ¿onable, and beÅ¿t plac'd, of any; Å¿ince, in effect, through the whole extent of Gard'ning, we find neither Plant nor Trees that afford us Å¿o much Delight, and that are Å¿o laÅ¿ting: For there is not a day throughout the whole Year, wherein Orange Trees may not (and as they Å¿hould do,) gratifie and court their Lovers, either by the Verdure of their Leaves, the AgreeableneÅ¿s of their Shape, Plenty, and Perfume of their Flowers; and, in a word, the Beauty, GoodneÅ¿s, and DurableneÅ¿s of their Fruit; Å¿o as I muÅ¿t acknowledge there is no Man more charm'd with them than my Å¿elf.

In Favour therefore of Å¿uch whoÅ¿e Inclinations I find Å¿o general for theÅ¿e Trees, I take a third Party totally oppoÅ¿ite to the Doctrine of theÅ¿e MyÅ¿tery-Men, and do declare, that, after a long and ample Examination, there Å¿eems nothing in the whole Art of Gardning Å¿o eaÅ¿ie, and little difficult, as the Culture of Orange Trees, be it either the raiÅ¿ing them from their firÅ¿t Principles, the governing them afterwards, and maintaining them in good Condition, when once they have been Å¿et; there being only the Recovery of thoÅ¿e that are Å¿ick, of any Difficulty; notwithÅ¿tanding all which, I think, one may (according to every Man's Ability,) reÅ¿olve to Å¿tore ones Å¿elf with Orange-Trees, provided one have an able Gard'ner, and a good Green-HouÅ¿e, without which, indeed, I would adviÅ¿e none to enter upon this CurioÅ¿ity; for, certain I am, the OrangiÅ¿t Gard'ner is abÅ¿olutely guilty, and to blame, either through groÅ¿s Ignorance, LazineÅ¿s, want of Diligence, Application, or over-fondneÅ¿s to his myÅ¿terious Fancies, if his Orange-Trees do not thrive; provided, I Å¿ay, that his Green-HouÅ¿e be not faulty, nor the Earth and Mould in which they are planted; or that the Head of the Tree be not diÅ¿proportionate to the Root, or there be Å¿ome defect in the CaÅ¿ing, which may perhaps be ill made, or not in fit SeaÅ¿on, or, eÅ¿pecially, by over-watering, and the too much uÅ¿e of Fire during Winter, which is not at all needful, or of Water during Summer, which Å¿hould be given with great Moderation.

I Å¿hall, in the next place (after I have declared what my Opinion in general is, as to the eaÅ¿ie Culture of Orange-Trees,) explain, what Conditions are required in a good Green-HouÅ¿e: This eaÅ¿ie Culture, which I Å¿peak of, I know does not pleaÅ¿e many of our Doctor OrangiÅ¿ts: They'll tell ye, that both thoÅ¿e who believe it, and thoÅ¿e who publiÅ¿h it, do not themÅ¿elves underÅ¿tand it: However, without being in the leaÅ¿t diÅ¿courag'd with what they Å¿ay, I Å¿hall adventure to declare my Opinion upon this Matter.

div.head: A TREATISE Of the CULTURE of ORANGE-TREES.
CHAP. I.

argument.p: Of the eaÅ¿ie Culture of Orange-Trees.

div.p: IN Confirmation of what I undertake to prove in this Chapter, I advance Five PropoÅ¿itions, which I hold for indubitable: The FirÅ¿t is, That we have hardly any Plants or Trees which take Root Å¿o eaÅ¿ily: Secondly, That there's none which Å¿o naturally agree with all Å¿orts of NouriÅ¿hment: Thirdly, That theÅ¿e are the moÅ¿t laÅ¿ting and longaevous Trees of all others: And in the Fourth Place, That there are none leÅ¿s obnoxious, and Å¿ubject to Infirmities: And LaÅ¿tly, None that have Å¿o few particular Enemies as Orange-Trees.

The Tons, which kill our Strawberry-Plants at the Root, and the Caterpillar, which Å¿poil their Leaves; the Canker-worm that cuts them off to the very Ground; the Field Mice, little Flies, and Gnats, which deÅ¿troy our Artichoaks: The Gumm, PiÅ¿mires, Å¿mall Fleas, that ruine Peach-Trees; and the Tyger-bob which ravage the Pear-Trees; all theÅ¿e afflicting Accidents attacquing our Melons, and invading all our Olitory and Kitchin-Garden Furniture, are what we may truly reckon to be the greateÅ¿t Enemies to Gard'ning in general; Enemies, I Å¿ay redoubtable Enemies, invincible, and by conÅ¿equence, a ThouÅ¿and Times more dangerous than any others whatÅ¿oever that menace our Orange-Trees: Some Foes I confeÅ¿s they have, nor are they altogether exempt, as there's no Plant which is; I Å¿hall here therefore examine them one by one, and in the mean time, preÅ¿cribe Å¿uch Remedies as are proper for their Cure and PreÅ¿ervation.

The particular Enemies of Orange-Trees are the PiÅ¿mires, the PunaiÅ¿e or Bug, Ear-wigs, &c. but all the MiÅ¿chief they are able to do, is far from being Mortal: There's nothing more eaÅ¿ie than a DefenÅ¿ive War againÅ¿t their rudeÅ¿t InÅ¿ults; for firÅ¿t of all, as to Ants and PiÅ¿mires, which Å¿ometimes come upon Trees in whole Troops, and gnaw the Leaves; they rarely invade the Orange-Tree, Å¿ave when baited and intic'd by Bug-Eggs: This filthy Spawn, (as all OrangiÅ¿ts well know without need of much DeÅ¿cription) can prejudice them no further, than to make the Tree look all over Å¿oul, Å¿qualid, and not Å¿o agreeable to the Eye as a Tree Å¿hould be, whoÅ¿e principle Beauty conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in the NeatneÅ¿s and CleanneÅ¿s as well of its Boughs as Leaves; this Å¿ort of Filth is bred by certain winged Mother-InÅ¿ects, but too well known by their green Colour, and naÅ¿ty Smell, proceeding from their Bodies being bruiÅ¿ed: They lay their Spawn in Autumn, almoÅ¿t as do the Silk-worms, and wind their Bags eÅ¿pecially about the dry and withered Twigs, and under the foul and rumpled Leaves; one would take them at firÅ¿t but for little reddiÅ¿h Frecles and Spots, whilÅ¿t they no Å¿ooner appear on a Tree (how few Å¿oever they are) but the heat of Summer following, makes them grow, extend, and Å¿well, 'till they become as big as a Lentil, and then they hatch and multiply, and in Autumn again produce infinite Numbers of others: But as theÅ¿e NeÅ¿ts are neither errant, fugitive, or volatile, one eaÅ¿ily Å¿pies where they faÅ¿ten, and may as eaÅ¿ily take them away, Å¿o one begin the Work betimes, and eÅ¿pecially when firÅ¿t you bring the Trees forth of the Green-HouÅ¿e: TheÅ¿e
pull'd off with your Fingers, or cleanÅ¿ed with a little BruÅ¿h, you'll immediately be Å¿ecured from the PiÅ¿mires, which give over their HoÅ¿tility againÅ¿t Orange-Trees Å¿o Å¿oon as ever the Bugs are gone.

Earwigs, thoÅ¿e little, long, reddiÅ¿h, nimble InÅ¿ects, that now and then invade the Orange-Trees (Å¿haring both Flowers and Leaves, and marring their prime Beauty.) are not Å¿o eaÅ¿ily deÅ¿troy'd as thoÅ¿e we newly mentioned: But as the MiÅ¿chief is not Mortal, reaches not to the Roots, and happens but Å¿eldom, there are ways enough to prevent it; as by Å¿ticking up Caps of Paper, and Neat-hoofs in Å¿everal Places of each Tree: TheÅ¿e pernicious Å¿mall InÅ¿ects, that go out to forage during Night only, you'll be Å¿ure to meet with in their Retreat and hiding-Places as Å¿oon as 'tis Day, when viÅ¿iting the Hoods and Hoofes, you may cruÅ¿h them under Foot, and with eaÅ¿e diÅ¿patch them.

Another Expedient is by VeÅ¿Å¿els of Earth, Wood, Lead, or Copper made Å¿quare, or round, and hollow; there are alÅ¿o of them of two FaÅ¿hions; one whereof is to be Å¿et about the Stem of every Tree; the others under all the four Feet of each CaÅ¿e: ThoÅ¿e that are for the Stem or Body of the Tree, are compoÅ¿ed of two Pieces, which may eaÅ¿ily be glew'd or cemented together, when they are plac'd about the Stem, and Å¿o accurately cloÅ¿e to it, as to hold the Water you pour into it: The others conÅ¿iÅ¿t but of one Piece, which are to be put under the Feet of the CaÅ¿es, and Å¿o being fill'd with Water like the firÅ¿t, are an invincible ObÅ¿tacle againÅ¿t Earwigs, which being no good Swimmers, will hardly attempt the Liquid PaÅ¿Å¿age. Thus are Orange-Trees intirely Å¿afe from DeÅ¿olation by Earwigs. The Å¿ame VeÅ¿Å¿els are likewiÅ¿e Protection againÅ¿t PiÅ¿mires; Å¿hould there any be Å¿o bold to adventure the Traject, and get over to theÅ¿e beautiful Trees, as Å¿ome perhaps will try to do, though there be no more of that Bug-Spawn which Å¿o powerfully attracts them.

There are beÅ¿ides theÅ¿e miÅ¿chievous Minute Creatures (againÅ¿t which Orange-Trees require Defence) Å¿everal other great and Å¿ore Inconveniencies, to which they (in common with all other Fruit-Trees) are obnoxious, whilÅ¿t they Å¿tand abroad and are expoÅ¿ed: As namely, impetuous Winds, white and pretty hard FroÅ¿ts, and above all, great Hails; but Å¿ince Å¿uch Calamities happen rarely, a Gard'ner Å¿o Å¿urpriz'd is rather to be extreamly pitied, than at all to be blam'd, eÅ¿pecially in caÅ¿e of Hail: 'Tis a MiÅ¿chief which comes like a Ruine on the Å¿udden, and which no Fore-Å¿ight can well prevent, be one's Carenever Å¿o great, and therefore no Remedy but Patience.

As for Danger of Winds, Å¿uch as for moÅ¿t part are thoÅ¿e between the WeÅ¿t and South, Å¿eldom blowing before the beginning of Autumn; they give fair Warning to Remove Orange-Trees to Å¿ome place of Shelter from their Fury; be it in Å¿ome HouÅ¿e, or under Protection of a Wall, or Grove of Trees, Å¿o plac'd and oppos'd to the Weather, as the Orange-Trees may, at leaÅ¿t Å¿ome part of the Day, enjoy the Comfort of the Sun.

Concerning FroÅ¿ts, in as much as we Å¿eldom bring Orange-Trees out of the Green-HouÅ¿e 'till it be towards Mid-May, and commonly Å¿hut them up again about the Middle of October: They are Times when theÅ¿e Trees are Å¿afe, and Å¿ufficiently out of their reach: TheÅ¿e kind of Spring FroÅ¿ts, which came in the tail of Winter, uÅ¿ually end about Mid-May; and the SeaÅ¿on praedicting their fierce Return, is not come at Mid-October: As for the Å¿mall White FroÅ¿ts, which Å¿ome times continue till half May is Å¿pent, and appear again at the beginning of October, they do no conÅ¿iderable Damage to Orange-Trees, that are Sound and in Health: Indeed, the Sick and Crazy may Å¿uffer and receive Prejudice by them, by reaÅ¿on of their general TenderneÅ¿s, which they would not have done if Å¿trong and vigorous; that is, well govern'd, and treated as they ought to have been.

Now therefore, being Å¿ufficiently aÅ¿Å¿ur'd, that the Beauty and PreÅ¿ervation of the Trees we diÅ¿courÅ¿e of, does in the firÅ¿t place, Å¿o entirely depend upon the being provided with a good and well-qualified Green-HouÅ¿e, as that whoever pretends to Orange-Trees, is never to expect any tolerable SucceÅ¿s and Contentment, without beginning with this neceÅ¿Å¿ary Precaution: It follows, that before we proceed any farther in explaining what more belongs to their Culture and Government, the Green-HouÅ¿e be the firÅ¿t Thing we ought next to Å¿peak of, as of the greateÅ¿t Importance.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of the Conditions of a good Green-HouÅ¿e.

div.p: TO the having a good and well condition'd Green-HouÅ¿e, there are in my Opinion, Five principal Qualities requiÅ¿ite: The FirÅ¿t is, That it be well plac'd and expos'd: Secondly, That it have Å¿ufficient Openings, and they well provided, and guarded with all that is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the Å¿hutting them up cloÅ¿e when the SeaÅ¿on requires it: Thirdly, That the Walls be made of a good ThickneÅ¿s, and Å¿ubÅ¿tantially built: Fourthly, That it be well cover'd: And laÅ¿tly, That the Floor be laid even and firm. Let us now examine each of theÅ¿e Conditions in particular.

As touching the FirÅ¿t, 'tis univerÅ¿ally agreed upon, That the Meridian ExpoÅ¿ure and Situation is abÅ¿olutely the beÅ¿t, Å¿o that it may enjoy the Sun from the Hour of Ten in the Morning, 'till it Å¿ets, or is almoÅ¿t ready to go down. The EaÅ¿tern Situation, which receives the Sun from its RiÅ¿ing till Noon, or a little after, is alÅ¿o very good. That of the WeÅ¿t, which enjoys the Sun but from Noon to the Evening, may Å¿erve for want of the other two; whil'Å¿t the North is very pernicious and good for nothing, as hardly Å¿eeing the Sun at all either Morning or Afternoon.

The Second Property of a good Green-HouÅ¿e, namely, That it have fair Openings; requires that the Doors and Shutters be Å¿o made, as that the Orange-Trees may eaÅ¿ily paÅ¿s thro' them; and the Windows large, and Å¿o high, as almoÅ¿t to touch the Timbers which Å¿upport the Cieling, which is commonly about three Foot, and five or Å¿ix Foot in breadth; Å¿o as having occaÅ¿ion to open them at any time in the Winter (as 'tis requiÅ¿ite) when the Sun Å¿hines invitingly, all the Trees may receive the Warmth and Comfort of his Beams: And in caÅ¿e any MoiÅ¿ture remain among them, it may be dried up by the Virtue of this bright Planet: TheÅ¿e Windows Å¿hould alÅ¿o be fitted within Å¿ide of the HouÅ¿e, with ChaÅ¿Å¿is of doubled Paper, that is, by glewing the Sheets on both Å¿ides of the Frame; and without this, another ChaÅ¿Å¿is of GlaÅ¿s: As for other Shutters of Wood, they Å¿ignifie little, and are nothing comparable to the other, which Å¿hould be accurately Å¿topp'd, and cauk'd during the Winter, to Å¿eclude and keep out all acceÅ¿s of the cold Air from penetrating, which would infallibly chill and abate the warm and comfortable Temper, which the Air in the HouÅ¿e received from the Sun, when the Windows were lately open'd upon thoÅ¿e fair Days we mentioned, and without which, the Orange-Trees would not preÅ¿erve their good Looks.

In the Third Place, all the Walls of the Green-HouÅ¿e (thoÅ¿e eÅ¿pecially that are to the North) Å¿hould be built of good Free-Å¿tone and Mortar, Chalk and Sand (which doubtleÅ¿s is beÅ¿t) or of PlaÅ¿ter, (which is not the worÅ¿t) provided the Walls be Å¿o carefully wrought, and well joynted, that there be no Crevices or void Places left between the Stones: Where Stones are not eaÅ¿ily to be had, they may be built of Loame, tempered, and mingled with Straw or Hay; or with a double CloiÅ¿on made of Boards well Rabetted, filling the void between with Earth or They in Holland uÅ¿e Chaff, or, (which is certainly better, becauÅ¿e of Vermin,) SawduÅ¿t, exceeding well dried in the Sun; giving the whole HouÅ¿e a Coat of Pitch. Sand, Å¿o as the Walls and Partitions, as well of the one as the other, be at the leaÅ¿t two Foot, or two and an half, in thickneÅ¿s: Happy in the mean time are they, who with all this, have Å¿ome other Building, dry Bank, or Grove of tall Trees to bask it on the North!

Fourthly, Since both the Cold and Wet is apt to inÅ¿inuate and get in through the Roof and Covering, as well as through the Sides of the HouÅ¿e: The Cieling and Floor above ought to be of a good thickneÅ¿s; and beÅ¿ides that, be clad in Winter with a Thatch of Hay or Straw, unleÅ¿s there happen to be a Room or Lodging over Head, or Å¿ome Gallery, whoÅ¿e Windows alÅ¿o muÅ¿t be kept very cloÅ¿e Å¿hut, whilÅ¿t the cold Weather continues: Or, except at leaÅ¿t it be Å¿ubÅ¿tantially vaulted and cover'd with Å¿tore of Earth, or Å¿ome Å¿uch Material as we have deÅ¿crib'd. LaÅ¿tly,

The Lower Floor of the Green-HouÅ¿e (which cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly be too dry) Å¿hould methinks, be laid a little higher than the Area or Walk without, or at leaÅ¿t even with it; but by no means much lower, for fear of DampneÅ¿s, which is more pernicious than the Cold it Å¿elf; in as much as there's hardly any Remedy for this, as there is againÅ¿t the other.

ThoÅ¿e who have not heard what I formerly objected againÅ¿t the UÅ¿e of Fire, (which is Å¿ometimes made in the Green-HouÅ¿e) will preÅ¿ently conclude, that whilÅ¿t I diÅ¿courÅ¿e of Remedies againÅ¿t the Cold, I would have it underÅ¿tood to be Fire of Charcoal, which they commonly make in Å¿everal places of the HouÅ¿e; but in truth, I mean nothing leÅ¿s, Å¿eeing on the contrary, I am of Opinion and abundantly Convinc'd, that Å¿ort of Fuel to be no leÅ¿s than Exitial, and hurtful to Orange-Trees, than either cold or wet, as I pretend to prove.

Having then Å¿poken of the height of the Green-HouÅ¿e Floor, it remains to Å¿hew, that it may be made of well beaten, hard and compacted Salpeter'd-Earth, or of PlaÅ¿ter; or which is to be preferr'd before all, a Floor of well lay'd Planks, &c. Ou de Salpetre batu.

By what was Å¿aid of the height of the Floor, it needs muÅ¿t follow, that Cellars, and Vaults are very dangerous, and often Mortal, as well to Orange-Trees, Lemons, JeÅ¿Å¿imines, Myrtles, &c. as generally to all Cas'd, and Impotted Shrubs whatÅ¿oever, for that Å¿uch low Subterraneous places are commonly damp and moiÅ¿t, out of reach, and far from receiving any comfort from the Sun, without whoÅ¿e influence, no Green-HouÅ¿e can be fitly qualified.

As to the breadth and length of the Green-HouÅ¿e within Å¿ide, it were not deÅ¿irable it Å¿hould exceed Twenty-four Feet, although it might well be made from Thirty to Thirty-Å¿ix, or a little more, nor would the HouÅ¿e be much the worÅ¿e, provided the height be withal proportionable, and Å¿o dry, as neither Cold, nor Wet get entrance. They are not the Sun beams immediately darting on the Orange-Tree Leaves, that are Å¿o eÅ¿Å¿entially Å¿alutary and propitious to them, Å¿eeing they Å¿eldom viÅ¿it the foliage in the middle, and interior parts of the branches, and head of the Tree, how ever advantagiouÅ¿ly expos'd; but they are thoÅ¿e Rays of the Sun, which Å¿hine into the whole Capacity of the HouÅ¿es, that diÅ¿pel, and hinder this humidity from Å¿ettling and doing the miÅ¿chief.

And thus having EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd for a general Maxim, that Å¿uppoÅ¿ing one is well provided of a good Green-HouÅ¿e, it is eaÅ¿ie to be MaÅ¿ter of fair, and excellent Orange-Trees. I next come to explain more particularly, what my Opinion is of their Culture.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the Å¿everal parts belonging to the Culture of Orange-Trees.

div.p: TO Å¿peak of this as Intelligibly as is poÅ¿Å¿ible, I conceive there are five Articles to be conÅ¿ider'd; the knowledge of which, will be of great InÅ¿truction to the newly Curious: ThoÅ¿e I mean, who are altogether Strangers to theÅ¿e Matters, and are deÅ¿irous to Learn.

The FirÅ¿t, and which is very Important for the removing of many Scruples is about the CompoÅ¿ition of the Earth and Mould, moÅ¿t proper for the NouriÅ¿hment of Å¿uch Orange-Trees as we Plant in Pots or CaÅ¿es.

The Second, treats of the way of RaiÅ¿ing them from Seed, and afterwards how to Graft them; and more eÅ¿pecially, what there's to be done to Trees of great, or leÅ¿Å¿er Growth, newly brought from other Countries, whether naked, Å¿trip'd, and without any Clod, or Earth adhering to the Roots (like other Fruit-Trees) or whether with their Leaves on, together with the Clod, &c. When I Å¿ay, receiving them in this manner, we would Impot or CaÅ¿e them.

The Third Article, directs the Å¿hape, and bigneÅ¿s of the CaÅ¿es to be us'd, and what is to be done about the Clod, and Roots of Å¿uch as are to be new CaÅ¿ed, with the manner of doing it, which are two EÅ¿Å¿ential points in this Culture, and alÅ¿o Rules concerning Watering.

The Fourth Article, Å¿hews how to dreÅ¿s and faÅ¿hion the heads of Orange-Trees, whether it be to Recover Å¿uch as have been long neglected, or ill treated, or Å¿uch as have Å¿uffer'd by the FroÅ¿t, or humidity of Winter; or, that one would have handÅ¿om Trees, that Å¿hould always maintain their beautiful Figure in health and vigour, without loÅ¿ing their Leaves.

The Fifth concerns the NeceÅ¿Å¿ary Situation of the Places in which Orange-Trees are to be Å¿et, when they are brought out of the Green-HouÅ¿e, and (as every body knows) what time they Å¿hould be carried in, Å¿hut up, and expos'd again
abroad. It alÅ¿o Å¿hews what is to be done, during Å¿ix or Å¿even Months, that the Trees are thus Confin'd; upon which, I Å¿hall in particular Å¿ay what I think concerning Fire, which divers People kindle in their Green-HouÅ¿es.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: Of the CompoÅ¿ition and Mixture of Earths, proper for the In-CaÅ¿ing Orange, and Lemon-Trees, &c.

div.p: SINCE Orange, and Lemon-Trees, are Strangers among us, and as one may Å¿ay, come Artificially into Climates Å¿ubject to rigorous Winters; as here in the IÅ¿le of France, and other Northern Countries, whereas they grow SpontaneouÅ¿ly and Naturally in warmer places. It makes Å¿ome to fancy, that this may partly proceed from Å¿ome defect in the Earth that's us'd, as well as from the Air we breathe in, which cauÅ¿es theÅ¿e Trees to undergo Å¿ome inconvenience here: And upon this, every Gard'ner makes a wondrous MyÅ¿tery, forÅ¿ooth, of certain peculiar CompoÅ¿itions of Earths, &c. And of this, there are various ConteÅ¿ts, and very different Opinions. For,

Some will have the main Importance of the Mixture, to conÅ¿iÅ¿t as well in the Plurality of Ingredients (eÅ¿pecially if they be hard to come by) as in the Å¿everal DoÅ¿es: Others, in the frequent removing and Å¿tirring the Mould, Å¿o blended together; without which, they conceive all the reÅ¿t unprofitable, and of no effect. There be others, who Å¿tand much upon the Antiquity, and Age of the CompoÅ¿ition; and that what has been longeÅ¿t made and prepared, is beÅ¿t: Some again, for that which has moÅ¿t been Å¿tirr'd. In fine, moÅ¿t of them make chiefeÅ¿t Account of the lighter Ingredients for their Mixture, namely, Å¿uch as is Sifted, and reduc'd to Powder, The Marc of Wine, Earth of an old Hot-bed, &c.

I Å¿hould never have done, Å¿hould I Å¿peak particularly to every OrangiÅ¿t's Conceit upon this Subject: 'Tis certain, there's hardly one of them but pretends to Å¿ome rare, and peculiar Secret, that no body has Å¿ave himÅ¿elf, and which he would not impart to another for any thing in the World. I'll Å¿uppoÅ¿e they all have reaÅ¿on to be Å¿atisfied with their manner of proceeding, nor is it for me to contradict them, none ever heard me CenÅ¿ure them for it: In the mean time, for my own part, as I think I have made choice of a Method EaÅ¿ie and Simple, and that appears to me very conformable to the general CourÅ¿e and Order of Vegetation, and particular Nature of the Trees, under conÅ¿ideration, I Å¿hall endeavour to explain it to the Curious, and let them Å¿ee with what SucceÅ¿s I have long made uÅ¿e of it effectually. There are alÅ¿o, divers other Worthy PerÅ¿ons, who have thought good to purÅ¿ue my Method for their Orange-Trees, who Å¿hall be my Vouchers.

But before I enter far on this Explication, I declare again (once for all) that whatever the Earth produces, be they Plants, or Trees, there is none of them, (as to their Culture, their Complexion and ConÅ¿titution) more EaÅ¿ie, Tractable, and (as I may Å¿ay) Accommodant, than are Orange and Lemon-Trees; the different manners they are Govern'd by, in Å¿everal places, viÅ¿ibly juÅ¿tifie it. One may, in my Opinion, fitly reÅ¿emble them to thoÅ¿e Healthy, and Vigorous Youths, who Abandoning themÅ¿elves to Debauchery, and diÅ¿orderly CourÅ¿es, their Juvenile Å¿trength does, for all that, often Repair the breaches of their irregular Lives; but it laÅ¿ts but for a certain time, the Young PerÅ¿on, accuÅ¿toming his Body to that, which in fine, muÅ¿t abÅ¿olutely deÅ¿troy him, or at leaÅ¿t extreamly alter, and impair its RobuÅ¿t CompoÅ¿ure. 'Tis juÅ¿t Å¿o with our Orange-Trees, which are Naturally wonderful, Å¿trong and lively; Å¿o as by that, they eaÅ¿ily Repair whatever NouriÅ¿hment (though little agreeable to their kind) it be, that may corrupt and Å¿poil them. It is not with theÅ¿e Trees as with certain other Vegetables, Å¿ome of which will thrive and live no where, but in a dry and light Soil; others, Å¿ave in the Fat and MoiÅ¿t, whereas Orange-Trees live in either, but by no means thrive Å¿o well in one, as in the other.

That which I would eÅ¿pecially recommend to ObÅ¿ervation, concerning the Culture of Orange-Trees, which (as we Å¿aid) are but Å¿trangers to our Climate, is to take good Notice out of what Å¿ort of Earth they were brought, and did Naturally grow in, and accordingly endeavour to Replant them in the like, as near as one can gueÅ¿s: By this Inquiry, I have found that they moÅ¿t Naturally thrive, and
grow to Perfection, in Strong, Fat, and Heavy Earth, and from thence conclude, that it were convenient, by Art, (which Å¿hould ever imitate Nature) to prepare Mould that were accordingly Rich and Weighty: But foraÅ¿much as theÅ¿e Trees, being Å¿et in CaÅ¿es, this heavy Fat Earth, which is to NouriÅ¿h them (without receiving any AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance from the Neighbouring Mould) would be apt to grow dry, and hard almoÅ¿t as a Stone, Å¿o as becoming unfit for Vegetation, the Roots cannot Å¿pread and extend themÅ¿elves, without AdminiÅ¿tring Å¿ome Succour to them. It follows, that of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity we not only afford them due Watering and RefreÅ¿hment, but Å¿uch as may eaÅ¿ily, and univerÅ¿ally penetrate throughout, and therefore Å¿ome means muÅ¿t be found, that this Earth be well, and induÅ¿triouÅ¿ly Å¿tirr'd, and made looÅ¿e, to correct its Natural SluggiÅ¿hneÅ¿s.

But you'll preÅ¿ently Object, as to this dull and heavy Material I Å¿o commend, That the Sun, which looks but obliquely upon us, cannot have the Å¿ame effects as it has in thoÅ¿e Climates where it Darts its Beams more directly. This is the Common Objection of our OrangiÅ¿ts. To which I reply in the firÅ¿t place, That as every body Å¿ees (and is confirm'd by daily Experience) the Heat which we have here during the four or five Months in which our Orange-Trees are expos'd, is Å¿ufficiently great to make them Live, and that with a great deal of vigour for a long time. In the Å¿econd place, That the Cas'd-Mould being open to the Air, and conÅ¿equently viÅ¿ited on every Å¿ide by the Sun, receives the ImpreÅ¿Å¿ions of its Heat almoÅ¿t as freely, as what being in the wide and open Field, enjoys its Beams on the Superficies only. And laÅ¿tly, That the Earth being thus made looÅ¿e, as well as ponderous, is by this Expedient render'd eaÅ¿ie and compliant for the Roots to Å¿pread in, and for the Water to penetrate and refreÅ¿h it, and by Å¿o much the more diÅ¿pos'd to entertain the impreÅ¿Å¿ions of the warmth which it requires: And thus we render it capable of receiving that by our Art, which would be Å¿uperfluous, and too much in the hotter Countries.

Upon this Foundation and ReaÅ¿on (be it in what Country Å¿oever) I endeavour to find out the beÅ¿t, natural Common-Earth, and leaÅ¿t Stony that I can light upon in all the Neighbourhood: That is to Å¿ay, Mould which has Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and is pretty Å¿olid; by no means Clay, which I look on as Dead, but Å¿uch as all Å¿orts of Plants Å¿eem naturally to delight in by their growth and thriving. Nor am I much concern'd what colour it is of, though for the moÅ¿t part, and to Å¿ight, the blacker be moÅ¿t agreeable and approv'd of. For Example, That which is proper for Hemp, good Wheat, or PaÅ¿ture-Ground, or of an High-way, or that lying low, it receives the Water, and Drainings of Å¿ome higher rich Ground. Of this Earth I take as much as I have need, and without farther trouble of preferring that which lies uppermoÅ¿t, (and which indeed, is the beÅ¿t in moÅ¿t Mens Opinions) I rather chooÅ¿e that which lies undermoÅ¿t, provided it appears to be of the Å¿ame quality of that which is above it, ever Å¿eeking that which is freÅ¿heÅ¿t; I mean, that which haply never Å¿aw the Sun, and conÅ¿equently, has never yet Å¿erved to the NouriÅ¿hment of any Plant; Å¿o as 'tis not only to be preÅ¿um'd, that it retains in it all its Original Salts, but a good part likewiÅ¿e of that which the upper, and Incumbent Ground, through which it has been the drain, contributes to it.

After this, viÅ¿iting the Folds, I procure dry Sheeps-Dung, reduc'd almoÅ¿t to Powder; (and which is to be had in almoÅ¿t every Country) or for want of that, I Å¿eek for Soil where Sheep have formerly been pent; than which, there is nothing better and more Soveraign for the Trees we Å¿peak of. But in defect of this, I uÅ¿e either the Mould of well-rotted Leaves of Trees, or of an old Hot-Bed, that has not been over Sob'd and Water'd, without ever medling with the Marc, and Husks of Grapes for ReaÅ¿ons I Å¿hall alledge hereafter.

Now (as I Å¿aid above) I would have the Mould which I prepare, weighty, and yet Å¿o looÅ¿e withal, as w â¢ ilÅ¿t it being Å¿olid and material, it â¢ ail not of producing good and Å¿ubÅ¿tantial Roots, Å¿uch as it could not do in lighter Earth. On the other Å¿ide, it being thus looÅ¿en'd, the Water and RefreÅ¿hments, together with the warmth of the Sun may the more eaÅ¿ily penetrate it, than poÅ¿Å¿ibly it could, were it altother ConÅ¿tipat and over-heavy. ConÅ¿idering then, how many Trees I have to In-CaÅ¿e, I accordingly order my CompoÅ¿ition, by taking, at leaÅ¿t, one half of that Natural Earth which I find near at hand, (and which is that which gives it that weight, â¢ nd Å¿olidneÅ¿s which I judge convenient) proportionable to the other half, which I compoÅ¿e of Powder'd Sheeps-Dung, if I can p â¢ ocure enough of it; and if not, of thoÅ¿e other Ingredients I before have mention'd, viz. Mould of the Old Melon
ãâ¦ã d, or of Rott â¢ d Leaves, and all theÅ¿e in almoÅ¿t equal Portions, which makes the
half of my Mixture, and imparts to it that lightneÅ¿s which I deÅ¿ire. All this do I mingle together the very Å¿ame day I have occaÅ¿ion for it (if I could not diÅ¿patch it Å¿ome days before) not thinking it at all neceÅ¿Å¿ary to have prepar'd it much Å¿ooner; and that which induces me is, FirÅ¿t, That every Particle of Earth contains evidently in it Å¿elf, its peculiar Vegetative Salt. Secondly, 'Tis certain That no Grain, or Particle of Earth does enter into the Body of another Grain, much leÅ¿s into the Bodies of the Roots, which only common Water does, which drenching (as I may Å¿ay) the borrow'd Earth with the Salt of every part, receives more or leÅ¿s, according as the Earth is more or leÅ¿s charged with it: And this Water Å¿o Impregnated, and SeaÅ¿on'd with the Salts of thoÅ¿e good Earths, is that which (as we have often noted) adminiÅ¿ters to the Roots that Food and NouriÅ¿hment which forms their Sap, which we affirm will be found Å¿o much better, according as the Earths (through which the Water has drain'd) renders them more Fruitful, and above all leÅ¿s Diluted.

This being Å¿o, it follows, That the Å¿taleneÅ¿s and oldneÅ¿s of the CompoÅ¿ition, Å¿ignifies no more to its Melioration and Improvement, than the frequent Å¿tirring of it. On the contrary, methinks it were to be wiÅ¿h'd, that this Mixture, once made, and the Earths caÅ¿t into Heaps, were cover'd from the Rain, leÅ¿t the Waters falling upon them, waÅ¿h, and carry away the beÅ¿t part of it, and Å¿catter it unprofitably about the Å¿ides or bottom of the whole MaÅ¿s.

Now to make our CompoÅ¿ition the more Å¿peedily and eaÅ¿ily, and indeed with more exactneÅ¿s; having firÅ¿t caÅ¿t all the Materials into Å¿everal Heaps, pretty near to one another, I cauÅ¿e as many Men as there are different Ingredients, with their Shovels and Spades, Å¿tanding by their reÅ¿pective Heaps, to caÅ¿t it equally, and in equal Portions Pell-mell in Å¿ome void place near them. For inÅ¿tance, If I have but one Å¿ingle Heap of good Earth, and another of Sheeps-Dung, there will need but two Men to fling them equally from their Heaps, to make another Heap: And if with the Heap of good Earth, I have two or three of thoÅ¿e other Ingredients mention'd, I place as many Labourers near that Å¿ingle Heap of good Earth, as I do at all the other Heaps. And thus at one, and the Å¿ame inÅ¿tant, as a Shovel-full of Stuff is thrown from each of the two or three Å¿eparated Heaps, there may (at the Å¿ame time) be caÅ¿t as many Shovel-fulls of the Å¿ingle Heap of good Earth: And Å¿o my CompoÅ¿ition is Å¿oon finiÅ¿h'd, and made exactly, without loÅ¿ing any time, or of making a greater quantity, or removing more Ingredients than one needs.

From that which has been Å¿aid, it appears, That I neither much look after the Earth of Drains, Dry and Old Rotted Dirt, MarÅ¿hy, or CaÅ¿tings of Ditches, Pidgeons-Dung and the like, as well becauÅ¿e I can be very well without them when I have the others which put me to no trouble in finding (the facility and eaÅ¿ineÅ¿s in Agriculture being that which infinitely Charms me) as eÅ¿pecially, becauÅ¿e I eÅ¿teem them preferable, and much better, Å¿o as I never make uÅ¿e of the other when I can have theÅ¿e at hand, but upon the utmoÅ¿t Exigence and NeceÅ¿Å¿ity.

By this you alÅ¿o Å¿ee, I do not Plant in pure and Å¿imple Earth only, and leÅ¿s yet in that which is finely Sifted, as do divers Gard'ners. Indeed, Orange-Trees will I confeÅ¿s, make pretty Shoots in this Powder'd-Mould for a year or two, but 'tis as true, that they make no Clod, or Union, Å¿o as 'tis very difficult to CaÅ¿e, or change them upon occaÅ¿ion, without danger of leaving no Mould cleaving about the Roots; without which, you muÅ¿t look for nothing during that whole year, nor the next, but the dropping of their Leaves, whereas Å¿uch as are Planted in my CompoÅ¿ition, retain a fair luÅ¿ty Clod about them, from which one may (and as indeed one Å¿hould) pare off a good part when you Re-caÅ¿e them, Å¿o that as well the old Roots, as old and exhauÅ¿ted Earth, may be Å¿ufficiently abated, without any Peril of loÅ¿ing the Leaves, or RiÅ¿quing the Tree, but, on the contrary, make it Å¿tronger, and more beautiful, and begin to put forth conÅ¿iderable Shoots that very year.

This alÅ¿o Å¿hews, how little I attribute to the Marc of Wine: And firÅ¿t, for that the Water which muÅ¿t retain the TaÅ¿t and Quality of Wine (as in effect it would, if the Marc contain'd in it any, the leaÅ¿t Å¿ort of moiÅ¿ture, the Water, I Å¿ay, in which it were infus'd, participating of it) is really, not only improper, and not at all good for any kind of Plants, but extreamly pernicious to them. In the Å¿econd place, For that this Mare, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting, as it does, of three things, which contain in them no Å¿ort of Juice (namely, the Stone or Kirnel, the Skin, and the Stalk) furniÅ¿h nothing of advantage to Vegetation, for the Kirnels are commonly as hard as little Stones, which Å¿carce ever rot or turn to Earth; the Skin, and Stalks for having been extreamly preÅ¿s'd, can yield nothing at all of NouriÅ¿hment. And all this we
find, in as much as the Water, wherein the Mares have been macerated, and infus'd a conÅ¿iderable while has no manner of TaÅ¿t or ReliÅ¿h in it; whereas the Water which has percolated; and paÅ¿s'd through Sheeps-Dung, or an old Melon-Bed, &c. Å¿enÅ¿ibly retains in it Å¿omething of extraordinary, as appears by the Acrimony or the TaÅ¿t it leaves,

To conclude, After all the Pains that I have taken, I never yet obÅ¿erv'd that the Mare of Wine did Impinguate, and Inrich the Ground; it renders it indeed Å¿omewhat lighter (but without imparting to it any other Quality) and that's what I Å¿trive chiefly to avoid in Earths for Orange-Trees, not only becauÅ¿e I would not have a Mold too light, but above all, that what does give it the lightneÅ¿s requiÅ¿ite, Å¿hould carry with it alÅ¿o Å¿omething of more UÅ¿eful and Soveraign towards the NouriÅ¿hment of Plants. BeÅ¿ides, if the Mare of Wine were of that AbÅ¿olute Importance for Orange-Trees, what Å¿hould they do, or rather what had they done, who having Orange-Trees, live in colder Countries, where Vine-yards to not Å¿ucceed or proÅ¿per?

Add to this, That as to the MoiÅ¿t and Colder Climates, and indeed other places alÅ¿o where the Soil is ChurliÅ¿h and over Binding (approaching the Nature of Clay) the Earth for Orange-Trees, ought to have good and Å¿ufficient quantity of Sheeps-Dung, or of thoÅ¿e other light, and tractable Ingredients, apt and diÅ¿pos'd to warm and heat; but which is not needful in hot, and more temporate Countries, or in the good Earth of other places, Å¿o as on Å¿uch occaÅ¿ions, one may go as far as two Thirds of Sheeps-Dung: And this laÅ¿t CompoÅ¿ition is I aÅ¿Å¿ure you, very proper and good to raiÅ¿e any Å¿ort of Plant in whatÅ¿oever, whether in Pot or CaÅ¿e.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: Of the manner how to raiÅ¿e Orange-Trees from the Seeds, and afterwards to Graft them: How firÅ¿t to Cultivate thoÅ¿e which are newly brought to us from the Countries where they grow and live without Art, whether they come Stripp'd and Naked, without Clod, or with it, having Å¿ome Leaves upon them.

div.p: TOUCHING the firÅ¿t Article, we have this to Å¿ay, That though it be true, that the Branches of Orange-Trees in certain Climates (thoÅ¿e eÅ¿pecially which come in Bundles, will take Root of Suckers, as eaÅ¿ily as with us GooÅ¿e-berry, Fig, and Quince-Trees do, &c. yet in theÅ¿e Countries here, where there is not that facility, we Å¿eldom raiÅ¿e them but from the Seeds, and Å¿uch as we get from very Ripe, or Rotten Fruit: The Month of March is the proper time to Sow them, either in Earthen-VaÅ¿es, or CaÅ¿es fill'd with Sheeps-Dung-Mold, or that of the old Melon-Bed, Burying what Seeds you intend to Sow, two or three Fingers deep, in Rills and Lines, or in Holes at two Inches diÅ¿tance, and at this nearneÅ¿s, that at the leaÅ¿t Å¿ome of them may take, if not all, and with purpoÅ¿e to thin, and pull up Supernumeraries where they Å¿tand too thick, that thoÅ¿e which are left may thrive the better, as in a Å¿hort time they will do.

Preparatory to this Semination, chooÅ¿e of the beÅ¿t Species and Kinds of Oranges, eÅ¿pecially of the Bigarades, which will produce, and furniÅ¿h you with Wild Stocks, that in two years time may be fit to Re-plant at greater diÅ¿tance, and by this means Å¿o increaÅ¿e in Growth and SubÅ¿tance,, as that at the end of five or Å¿ix Years (if care be taken to DreÅ¿s them, either by frequent, but gentler Å¿tirrings of the Earth, ordinary Watering, and diÅ¿creetly Trimming and Pruning them) they will become fair and luÅ¿ty Stocks fit to Graft on.

And this is done two manner of ways: The firÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t frequent is by In â¢ culation, and Grafting in the EÅ¿cutcheon in the Months of July, AuguÅ¿t, and September as they do other Fruit-Trees, and that as near the Earth as conveniently you can, that it may Å¿end forth a Å¿trait, and fair Shoot from the Shild: The Å¿econd way is Grafting by Approach, which is done in the Month of May, but for this Operation the Wild Stock had need be of Å¿ome conÅ¿iderable SubÅ¿tance and Growth, becauÅ¿e the Head is to be cut off to make the InciÅ¿ion or GaÅ¿h, and Å¿ometimes a Cleft, in which to Apply or Approach a Branch of the Orange-Tree of whoÅ¿e Kind you deÅ¿ire a Graft. In AdjuÅ¿ting theÅ¿e, you muÅ¿t cut away a little of the Rind, and of the Wood of both Å¿ides of the Branch, and Å¿o inÅ¿ert and apply it neatly to the middle of the GaÅ¿h, and then with a PlaiÅ¿ter of Å¿oft Wax, or Clay, and wrapping
that about with a Linnen Rag, bind all cloÅ¿e together, Å¿o as it may reÅ¿iÅ¿t the Wind until towards AuguÅ¿t; when, if you perceive the Graff has taken (which you'll find by the vigorous Shoot it makes) you may then Å¿eparate the Stock-Graff from the Mother-Tree, by Sawing, or Cutting the Approached Branch juÅ¿t before the place where it was bent down.

After the Å¿ame manner are Grafted Lemon-Trees, and that indifferently; Orange on the Lemon and Orange-Stock, as well as the Lemon upon either, though indeed the Orange does better upon its own Kind, than on either Lemon or Balotins.

'Tis eaÅ¿ie to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h an Orange-Stock from the Lemon, for the latter has a YellowiÅ¿h Bark, the Orange GreeniÅ¿h; beÅ¿ides, that the Leaves of Orange-Trees have near the Stalk a little foot at the bottom of the Leaf, Å¿haped like an Heart, which Lemon-Trees have not. Moreover, Orange-Trees Graffed on the Wild Stock of their own Species, commonly make a more vigorous Shoot, and are leÅ¿s obnoxious to Å¿hed their Leaves, than what are Grafted on the Lemon-Stock or Balotins.

Here about Paris, we Å¿eldom raiÅ¿e either by Seeds or Graffs; none Å¿ave the Curious for Tryal Å¿ake, will put themÅ¿elves to the pains of it, Å¿ince the Genoa Merchants Å¿o eaÅ¿ily relieve us of that trouble, where they raiÅ¿e them with Å¿uch Å¿ucceÅ¿s, as well for the Profit they make of them, as for our Satisfaction. There come Yearly to us in the Months of March, April and May in great abundance, both Orange and Lemon-Trees, Å¿trong and luÅ¿ty Plants, and that at very reaÅ¿onable Price, as well Å¿uch as have no Clod or Earth about them, as thoÅ¿e that have.

The main thing is, how to preÅ¿erve Å¿uch of either Kind as are well-condition'd: That the Stem be Å¿trait, even and Å¿ound, not gall'd any where, and of competent height, as about a Foot and a half, or from two Foot to a Yard, or four Foot; That the Roots be alÅ¿o Å¿ound, and look as if but newly drawn out of the NurÅ¿ery: That the Cold, Wet, or too much Heat have not dried, chill'd, or any way injur'd them by the way; either of all which defects, may have utterly Å¿poil'd them, and made them good for nothing. TheÅ¿e, and other Infirmities, you may eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cover by Cutting or Peeling a little of the Rind of the Stem, Branches and Roots, which Å¿hould be pretty firm and cloÅ¿e, and of a yellowiÅ¿h Green; the Bark alÅ¿o looÅ¿en'd a little from the Wood, Å¿hould be found of an Oily MoiÅ¿ture, which is the Effect of the Sap's being plentifully in it. On the other Å¿ide, if the Bark be too Å¿oft, or rather rotten, or very rough, hard and dry, they are Mortal Symptoms, and you'll commonly find the Wood underneath the Bark, to appear blackiÅ¿h and Å¿potted, and Å¿uch are only fit for the Chimney.

ThoÅ¿e Trees which are brought us without the Earth, or any Clod about the Roots, and have yet perhaps other good Marks, are to be Trimm'd from Head to Foot: The Head, that is to Å¿ay the Branches, being commonly Naked and Bare of Leaves, Å¿hould be Å¿ufficiently Prun'd and Abated, and Å¿o order'd, that new Shoots may Spring from their Tops, fit to be form'd into beautiful, and handÅ¿om Heads, round and full, as we Å¿hall Å¿hew in due place. As to the Roots, be Å¿ure to â¢ eanÅ¿e them well from their Hairy Fibers, which for the moÅ¿t part you'll find quite dry'd and Å¿hrunk up; and take Å¿o much off the other Roots, that you leave not the very largeÅ¿t, and beÅ¿t grown above four or five Inches in length, and in proportion the leaÅ¿t alÅ¿o, Cutting thoÅ¿e that are Å¿poil'd by any Galling, or BruiÅ¿e quite off to the very Quick: And this done, plunge the Roots for five or Å¿ix hours into common Water, and then Plant them in Baskets, Tubs, CaÅ¿es, or Pots fill'd with good Mould, a little lighter than that which is compos'd for Grown Orange-Trees, Å¿uch as you have had a good while, and that have their Clod about them: For theÅ¿e new Plants therefore, there needs not be in the CompoÅ¿ition of the Mould above a quarter part of the groÅ¿Å¿er Earth at moÅ¿t, the reÅ¿t being of the above-mention'd Ingredients.

When this is done, place the Baskets, or VaÅ¿as in a moderate Hot-Bed, made in Å¿ome Å¿hady Place where the Sun does but a little Peep through; or if more expos'd to its Heat, which may dry and injure the tender Plants during the firÅ¿t hot Months, in this caÅ¿e you muÅ¿t cover, them with MatreÅ¿Å¿es, or Canvas, Å¿o as preventing theÅ¿e Inconveniences, you may yet give them Air in Rainy, CloÅ¿e, and Cloudy SeaÅ¿ons, being alÅ¿o careful to Water them from time to time moderately, and with diÅ¿cretion, Å¿o as the Mould may remain always a little MoiÅ¿t; yet Å¿o, as that the Earth in the CaÅ¿e, may enjoy Å¿ome, be it never Å¿o little (Å¿ince a very little is Å¿ufficient) of the warmth, and comfort of the Hot-Bed: But by no means too much, for that were worÅ¿e than none at all.

Arm'd with theÅ¿e Cautions, you will be able to Å¿ave moÅ¿t Orange-Trees Å¿o In-Cas'd, Potted, or in Baskets, leaving them in the Å¿ame Bed all the reÅ¿t of the Year, until towards the middle of October, when you are to remove them to Å¿uch a Green-HouÅ¿e as we have recommended, or elÅ¿e made them a warm Cover as they Å¿tand, with dry Dung and Litter well Matted, &c. Å¿ufficient to preÅ¿erve them from the Cold of Winter to the end of April, or the beginning of May, when you Å¿hall take them out of this firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e or Pot, together with Earth and all; or if in Baskets (which commonly you'll find Rotten at the Years end) put them as they are, into new, and proportionable CaÅ¿es, without troubling your Å¿elf about taking any of the Rotten Basket-Twigs away, leÅ¿t by letting in the Air, you prejudice the tender R â¢ o â¢ s: This done, give them the ordinary DreÅ¿Å¿ing and Culture as hereafter we Å¿hall direct, from henceforth beginning to form the Head till it arrive to the utmoÅ¿t Beauty it is capable of.

Thus much touching Orange, and Lemon-Trees brought to us with the Clod, Branches and Leaves about them. As for Å¿uch as come with all this Furniture, you are FirÅ¿t, To Examine whether the adhering Clod be Natural, becauÅ¿e they are Å¿ometimes Artificially Clump'd, and Daub'd about the Root with Clay after the Root is Cut; but this is eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cover'd by the manner of the Å¿mall Roots clinging to it, for if it be Natural, it will Å¿tick very firmly to them, but if looÅ¿e, 'tis a certain Å¿ign of Knavery: And if it be only Å¿uch as has apparently been thus applied, take it all clear off, if otherwiÅ¿e, â¢ abating very little, let moÅ¿t of it remain, Å¿ince 'tis likely to be no great quantity, and then you need only refreÅ¿h the Roots, by pairing and Å¿hortning them diÅ¿creetly. But for the others, they are to be Treated as has already been Å¿hew'd, where we Å¿peak of Å¿uch Young Orange-Trees as arrive without their Clod.

Having thus perform'd what is neceÅ¿Å¿ary about the Clod, you are in the next place to Work about the Head, and conÅ¿ider how to give beginning to the moÅ¿t agreeable Figure; which you Å¿hall do by taking away a great part of the little Å¿mall, Å¿traggling Branches, you find to grow Confus'dly, Cutting alÅ¿o the groÅ¿Å¿er ones off, which you Å¿ee hinder the Symmetry and Beauty of the Head, which Å¿hould be reduc'd to a perfect Round, and Full.

This done, Bathe the Root a good quarter of an Hour, namely, Å¿o long as (that being quite under Water) you perceive any Air-Bubble to riÅ¿e, and then Å¿et it as long to Drain. LaÅ¿tly, Place it in your CaÅ¿e, after the Å¿ame manner we commonly do Orange-Trees out of an Old CaÅ¿e.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Of the Size and BigneÅ¿s of good CaÅ¿es, and other CircumÅ¿tances relating to them.

div.p: THERE needs no great Directions about the BigneÅ¿s and Shape of CaÅ¿es, which ought to be of Capacity made proportionable to the Growth and SubÅ¿tance of the Trees which you would Plant in them. A Å¿mall Tree would appear as ridiculouÅ¿ly in a large CaÅ¿e, as a great Tree in a Å¿mall one; but with this difference in the mean time, That the latter would LanguiÅ¿h, and be in danger of PeriÅ¿hing for w â¢ nt of competent NouriÅ¿hment, it being impoÅ¿Å¿ible a great Tree, together with all its Roots, Å¿hould find Å¿ufficient to maintain Life in a VeÅ¿Å¿el that contain'd but little Matter, whereas a little Orange-Tree, in a great and large CaÅ¿e, would run no Å¿uch danger, but be in effect the Å¿ame as if it had been Planted in the wide and open Field.

I am not of Å¿ome Curious Mens Opinion, who hold that large and ample CaÅ¿es hinder the Growth, and Thriving of young Orange-Trees, unleÅ¿s they alÅ¿o imagine they would grow and be worÅ¿e in the plain Earth, and open Field. 'Tis a great miÅ¿take to think that a Å¿ingle Root produces nothing of it Å¿elf; let it be never Å¿o throughly heated, it will never exert any thing, if it be not Animated with a certain Vital-Principle, as I have fully demonÅ¿trated in one of the Chapters of my TreatiÅ¿e of Reflections. Now the ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion which muÅ¿t promote this Activity, Å¿eems to proceed more Naturally from the Superficies than from the Å¿ides.

What remains to be Å¿poken concerning CaÅ¿es, is the Figure, which every body knows to be Square, for though they Å¿ometimes make little Round ones, and other
OblongiÅ¿h, they are not Å¿o agreeable, unleÅ¿s the height (without reckoning the Feet) correÅ¿pond, and anÅ¿wer the length; for to be large and low, or high, and but narrow, is very unÅ¿ightly: The Foot ought therefore ordinarily, to be from five, to Å¿ix Inches high, for CaÅ¿es, that are in height from one Foot and half, to two or three Feet. They may be Å¿ome Inches Å¿horter, if they be not above eight, ten, or twelve large; or be allow'd Å¿ome Inches more, if of three and half, or four Feet, which are the largeÅ¿t Size we Å¿ee any where us'd.

The beÅ¿t Timber to make CaÅ¿es of is Oak, as the moÅ¿t durable: Firr, Beech, CheÅ¿nut, &c. are by no means proper. CaÅ¿es may alÅ¿o be made of Barrel-board, or Pipe-Å¿taves, when they exceed not Twenty, or Two and Twenty Inches; but if more, of good Clap-board, and WainÅ¿cot full Inch thick, they will elÅ¿e be apt to break, and be diÅ¿-joynted when they come to be remov'd and carried by the Lever, eÅ¿pecially being large, full of Earth and heavy.

'Tis of great Importance to have their Feet of Å¿ound Oak, and made Square, and Proportionable to the bigneÅ¿s of the CaÅ¿es: AlÅ¿o, that the Bottoms be very Å¿ubÅ¿tantial, Å¿upported with Bars well Nail'd and faÅ¿ten'd, that they may be able durably to Å¿uÅ¿tain their Burden, and Å¿ecur'd from becoming Rotten, to which the frequent Waterings make them obnoxious: For it were deÅ¿irable that the Trees might continue in the Å¿ame CaÅ¿es many Years without any neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Change, every Removing and Alteration being prejudicial to them. One Å¿hould likewiÅ¿e take Care, that the Bottoms of the CaÅ¿es hold Å¿tanch, and without Å¿tarting; and that they may laÅ¿t the longer, it were in my Opinion requiÅ¿ite to give the InÅ¿ide a good Priming or two, with Å¿ome Oil-Colour'd, no matter what it be. This may perhaps Å¿eem needleÅ¿s, but I aÅ¿Å¿ure you upon Experience, you'll find it worth the Expence in the durableneÅ¿s of your CaÅ¿es, and the benefit of the Orange-Trees; which being thus accommodated will not need to be Å¿o often chang'd, provided you Govern them as I have Å¿hew'd, and that you In-CaÅ¿e them pretty high, and tread the Earth well at the bottom before you Re-plant them.

Every body knows that the bottom of the CaÅ¿e Å¿hould be bor'd through in Å¿everal places with an Auger, if the Board be joyn'd cloÅ¿e, or elÅ¿e be laid at Å¿ome reaÅ¿onable diÅ¿tance one from another, Bar-wiÅ¿e, for the more commodious draining, and paÅ¿Å¿age of the Å¿uperfluous Water, and often RefreÅ¿hments.

If the CaÅ¿e or Box be of two Foot and halfSize, it were convenient to give it an Iron plate at each Corner, and under the Bars below, that the Levers (which you muÅ¿t of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity make uÅ¿e of, to Lift and TranÅ¿port Å¿o great a Burden by) do not break any of the Bars. I would alÅ¿o AdviÅ¿e, that two of the Å¿ides of the Boxes were contriv'd with Wickets, to open and Å¿hut at pleaÅ¿ure, by the help of Å¿ome Iron-Bars and Hooks, to hold them faÅ¿t in: Not that hereby one may give them an half In-CaÅ¿ing upon occaÅ¿ion, a thing I neither approve of or uÅ¿e (for ReaÅ¿ons hereafter) but that when ever there really is need of Re-IncaÅ¿ing large and great Orange-Trees, one does the more eaÅ¿ily take them forth their Old CaÅ¿e, with the greater part of the Earth and Clod adhering, which one cannot Å¿o commodiouÅ¿ly and Å¿afely do otherwiÅ¿e, without danger of breaking and diÅ¿order. Let us next Å¿hew how they are to be Re-Cas'd.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Of Re-CaÅ¿ings, and the beÅ¿t manner of doing it.

div.p: RE-CASING an Orange-Tree is Å¿ometimes NeceÅ¿Å¿ary, either for Å¿ome defect in the Box, or in regard of the Tree: As FirÅ¿t, When a Box, or CaÅ¿e is Å¿o broken through Age or other Accidents, that it cannot be removed without Detriment to the Tree it contains; or when it is too little and has not Å¿ufficient room to nouriÅ¿h, and entertain it in any longer.

Secondly, When one Å¿uÅ¿pects, or foreÅ¿ees the Ruine of a Tree by the WeakneÅ¿s and Languor of the Shoots, the YellowneÅ¿s of its Leaves, the Å¿mallneÅ¿s of the crumpled Flowers, &c. Or that in fine, one of the moÅ¿t principal Perfections, and Beauty of an Orange-Tree being (in my Opinion) its yearly putting forth LuÅ¿ty, and handÅ¿om new Shoots, if it have fail'd in Å¿o doing the laÅ¿t Spring, 'tis to be preÅ¿um'd there is Å¿omething in Fault, and that though it may haply bear a Florid, and Green Leaf of the laÅ¿t two Years, 'tis evident yet that it does no
more receive that due NouriÅ¿hment in the CaÅ¿e which it requires: And therefore be it that the Mould is too Old, and much exhauÅ¿ted, or the Box too narrow in regard to the quantity of the Roots, on either of theÅ¿e defects, a new Re-CaÅ¿ing is to be reÅ¿olv'd on.

Happy thoÅ¿e Orange-Trees, or rather Happy the MaÅ¿ter of them, that has an able and Skillful Gard'ner to Govern 'em, and the Sagacity to prevent theÅ¿e Accidents, by a timely Re-CaÅ¿ing before his Trees complain or Å¿uffer; being careful to do it before theÅ¿e Infirmities Å¿eize too far upon them, and perform it dextrouÅ¿ly with all the neceÅ¿Å¿ary circumÅ¿tances: He may then in the firÅ¿t place, be Å¿ure his Trees will regularly maintain their Leaves and Verdure, which is no Å¿mall MaÅ¿ter-piece; and in the Å¿econd place, find them to Å¿hoot (that very year) almoÅ¿t as freely as if they had not at all been New-Cas'd, which is another extraordinary advantage. Thirdly, SuppoÅ¿ing it to have already attain'd as beautiful an Head as we have fancied in our Idea, there will be no farther need of Working upon that, or uÅ¿ing the Knife, though haply it may be convenient to pare away, and abate about two third parts of the Clod and Earth which is about the Root; and thus have you an Orange-Tree perfectly well Re-Cas'd.

'Tis therefore very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Re-CaÅ¿e (though the Tree may have been never Å¿o well Treated) whenever we obÅ¿erve it to have paÅ¿s'd a Summer without continuing to make as vigorous a Å¿hoot as 'twas wont to do; Å¿ince being neglected, until we find our Trees actually Å¿ick, and in an ill condition, one may aÅ¿Å¿uredly conclude, that either the Å¿ame year, or the next after, they'll in all probability loÅ¿e their Leaves, and that the very year of Re-CaÅ¿ing they will make no Å¿hoot at all, or if they do put any out, none but Å¿uch as are very feeble, wretched and miÅ¿erable ones, with Å¿mall round Flowers, moÅ¿t of which will drop before they be Å¿pent or wither'd; Å¿o as of neceÅ¿Å¿ity, you will be oblig'd to cut off a very great part of the old Branches, and Å¿ometimes the entire Head, to ones infinite vexation, to behold the poor Trees in this Å¿ad and naked condition, and that for Å¿o long a time before they will recover, or afford you any Å¿atisfaction.

It is fit you Å¿hould have notice, that Å¿ometimes a CaÅ¿ed Orange-Tree (be it one brought from hot Countries, or that has only been newly chang'd into another Box) may now and then remain two, or three years without puÅ¿hing either Roots or Branches, whatever pains one takes about it, which is very irkÅ¿ome: But even in this caÅ¿e, one is not preÅ¿ently to deÅ¿pair of the Tree, or caÅ¿t it away, Å¿eeing Å¿o long as the Stem and Branches continue freÅ¿h, you may be Å¿ure it is alive, and may for all this Emerge. Nor will I adviÅ¿e you to change its CaÅ¿e, but to continue your wonted care of him as he Å¿tands, and you'll after a while find him to Recover, and anÅ¿wer all your Pains and Patience, it familiarly happening, that this Lethargie and Benumb'neÅ¿s (from I know not what unknown and Å¿ecret CauÅ¿e) is at laÅ¿t vanquiÅ¿h'd and overcome: But where an Orange-Tree that (for inÅ¿tance) has been In-Cas'd, and diligently DreÅ¿s'd for three or four years, ceafes for a whole Twelvemonth to Spring at all, you may (as already we have noted) conclude that he is beginning to be Sick, and Å¿peedily Re-CaÅ¿e him the next year following. To perform this well, you Å¿hall firÅ¿t of all pare off two Thirds of the Old Mould or Clod, which indeed looks very frightful at firÅ¿t to thoÅ¿e who are yet unacquainted with the Government of CaÅ¿ed Trees: Though it be indiÅ¿penÅ¿ably neceÅ¿Å¿ary at every Re-CaÅ¿ing, eÅ¿pecially if the Tree have been in the Å¿ame Box four or five years, or perhaps a a longer time; for 'tis Å¿ometimes expedient to diminiÅ¿h, and take away a full half of its Clod; as when through the negligence, or imprudence of former Gard'ners, you find a Tree become exceÅ¿Å¿ively GroÅ¿s and Over-grown, for want of being duly Prun'd and Trimm'd on its precedent Re-CaÅ¿ings. The Å¿econd thing to be done in Re-CaÅ¿ing well, is before you begin this Important Work: In the firÅ¿t place to conÅ¿ider the Mould and Earth of the Clod: In the next, to Å¿ee what condition the CaÅ¿e and Box is in. As for the Mould, if you find it over light, and that you conceive the Root has but a Å¿mall Clod about it, you muÅ¿t then Water it plentifully the day before you Å¿tir any thing, that Å¿o the MoiÅ¿ture may cauÅ¿e it to adhere to the Roots, leaÅ¿t otherwiÅ¿e the Earth fall wholly away from them, leaving them quite Naked when you come to take the Tree out of its CaÅ¿e; but if you perceive the Earth to be Å¿olid and material, Å¿o as in likelihood the Root has a Å¿ufficient Clod about it, you may altogether omit the previous Watering, and proceed to Un-CaÅ¿e: The Earth will hold well enough to the Roots, and you may Work without any danger.

As for the Box, you were before to conÅ¿ider, whether it be fit to Å¿erve any more; and if Å¿o, to ReÅ¿erve it: If not, to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of it accordingly. Now for the Å¿aving
of the CaÅ¿e, be it with a Wicket, or (as ordinarily) without any, you Å¿hould with Å¿ome fitting InÅ¿trument, Howe, or Trowel Å¿crape, and take away from about the Roots Clod and all the four Å¿ides of the CaÅ¿e, as much old Earth as until you can conveniently arrive at the Clod; and then alÅ¿o, pare off as much of the ancient Roots as you can without diÅ¿ordering of the Clod, of which you Å¿hould leave three parts. This is a neceÅ¿Å¿ary Operation for the cleanÅ¿ing of it quite round, which otherwiÅ¿e you would not be able to reach and come at. This done, lift the Tree out of the CaÅ¿e with either Å¿trength of Arm, if it be not too heavy, or by the help of a Crane, Pully, and Ropes if it be of too great a bulk; and Å¿o without demoliÅ¿hing any part of the Old CaÅ¿e, you may keep or make uÅ¿e of it again, either to Re-CaÅ¿e the Å¿ame Tree in, or Å¿ome other, whilÅ¿t the former, with Å¿ome Å¿mall Reparations, may laÅ¿t perhaps four or five years longer: But if you find it not worth the mending, let it be broken up for the Fire, and Å¿o you Å¿hall come to the intire Clod, and as before, abating about two Thirds, or more of the Mould as you Å¿ee cauÅ¿e, Å¿ince in either reÅ¿pect, Retrenchments are to be made as well on every of the four Å¿ides, as underneath, Å¿craping away Å¿o much of the old ExhauÅ¿ted Earth, as till you diÅ¿cover, and lay bare about two Inches of the ends of the Roots that had been Cut, to be ReveÅ¿ted and turniÅ¿h'd in Re-CaÅ¿ing with new and freÅ¿h Mould (as Å¿hall hereafter be Å¿hown) that Å¿o they may at their Extremities, put forth new and luÅ¿ty Roots, Å¿ufficiently to Re-eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the Tree.

By the way, I AdvertiÅ¿e, that in Pruning the Roots, which you will find twiÅ¿ted and intangled one within the other, you be careful to take clean away all that you Cut off, without leaving Å¿o much as a Fragment, or Chip remaining, thereby preventing the Rotting, and Infecting of their Neighbours, which were very dangerous. In a word, after theÅ¿e Retrenchments made of Earth and Roots, if the Weight and Bulk of Earth permit, I CounÅ¿el you to dip it in Å¿ome Tub, or VeÅ¿Å¿el full of Water or Fountain BaÅ¿in, deep enough to cover the intire Clod, and there to let it remain as long as the Water Works and Boils about it; for Å¿o it will, Å¿oaking in by degrees, where the ordinary Waterings could not penetrate, and conÅ¿equently, the Earth exceÅ¿Å¿ively dry'd, and Water taking place, will force out and expel the latent, and prejudicial Air which cauÅ¿es the Ebullition and DiÅ¿order.

So Å¿oon as the Boiling ceaÅ¿es, take the drenched Tree out of the Water, and placing it on Å¿ome Block or CaÅ¿e laid Å¿ide-long (or any thing that Å¿tands a little higher than the Ground) there let it reÅ¿t until all the Water be drain'd from it, and it have almoÅ¿t quite done dropping: For this ReaÅ¿on, That whilÅ¿t the Clod is thus Å¿treaming, Å¿hould one put it into a new Earth'd CaÅ¿e, it would make it all into a Mortar, which were very pernicious to the Tree; for being neceÅ¿Å¿arily oblig'd to preÅ¿s, and cloÅ¿e the Mould to the Å¿ides of the Clod, and crowd as much into the CaÅ¿e as is poÅ¿Å¿ible, as well about the Naked Roots, as where ever one finds a void, it could not be, but the Earth thus moiÅ¿ten'd, beaten and preÅ¿s'd would turn all to pap and Mortar, which would at laÅ¿t grow hard, and petrifie like Stone, by all means to be prevented.

Now in caÅ¿e the Clod be too big to be thus plung'd in Water: When the Re-CaÅ¿ing is finiÅ¿h'd, with a good big pointed Stake (made of Å¿ome hard Wood) or an Iron Crow or Pin made for the purpoÅ¿e; endeavour to pierce the Clod in Å¿everal places of it, and pour Water in the holes gently from time to time, as long almoÅ¿t as it will imbibe any, and that you judge the whole MaÅ¿s of Earth may Å¿ufficiently be Å¿oak'd with it.

Let us next proceed to fit our new CaÅ¿e, be it of the Å¿maller, middle, or largeÅ¿t Å¿ize: The CuÅ¿tom is, and 'tis a very good one, both for the benefit of the Roots, as for the preÅ¿ervation of the CaÅ¿es bottom, to cover them with a Bed of RubbiÅ¿h, old Brick-Bats, &c. that the frequent Waterings draining through thoÅ¿e looÅ¿e Materials, may not Stagnate and Corrupt, which would both Rot the Roots, and bottoms of the CaÅ¿es alÅ¿o. I would have this RubbiÅ¿h handÅ¿omly rang'd, pretty groÅ¿s and thick, Å¿uitable to the bigneÅ¿s and capacity of the CaÅ¿e, yet not to lye above three or four Inches thick, the leaÅ¿t Å¿iz'd Boxes two.

This done, 'tis Å¿ufficient to fill in as much prepar'd Earth as is requiÅ¿ite to Å¿et the Clod in, Å¿o as the Superficies be plac'd level with the brim of the CaÅ¿e, and then finiÅ¿h all, gently filling the void places at the Å¿ides, and give it all a plentiful Watering: So have you the true ordinary way of In-CaÅ¿ing all Å¿orts of Trees.

But, for as much as I perceive that by this manner of putting in the Mould, 'tis apt to Å¿ink, and Å¿ettle too much after a little while, and conÅ¿equently cauÅ¿e the Roots quickly to touch the bottoms of the CaÅ¿es, which may extreamly prejudice the
Beauty of Orange-Trees; make them look Yellow, put forth Å¿mall Shoots and Flowers, and Å¿oon deÅ¿poil them of their Leaves, and Å¿o oblige one to change the CaÅ¿es every four, or five Years. I have conÅ¿ider'd the doing Å¿omething more, which has very well Å¿ucceeded with them, though I confeÅ¿s upon this account I have Å¿tirr'd up againÅ¿t me a great many among the OrangiÅ¿t-Gard'ners, who upon this, as well as my CompoÅ¿ition and Mixture of Earth, have looked on me as an Innovator, and as one may Å¿ay, a DiÅ¿turber of the Publick Peace, and as if I had at the Å¿ame time DiÅ¿honour'd both them and their AnceÅ¿tors: But let the SucceÅ¿s of my Method decide the ProceÅ¿s, to the ConfuÅ¿ion of the Envious.

See then how I Re-CaÅ¿e my Trees: So Å¿oon as I have laid upon the Bed of RubbiÅ¿h a Foot of the prepar'd Earth, which I would have to be dry, or very little moiÅ¿t, I cauÅ¿e it to be exceedingly beaten with the FiÅ¿t, or with Å¿ome Rammer, or piece of Wood when it is for the leÅ¿Å¿er CaÅ¿es; or elÅ¿e make one to go into the bigger CaÅ¿es, and tread the Mould Å¿ufficiently, Å¿o as it may Å¿ubÅ¿ide, and Å¿ettle almoÅ¿t once for all, whilÅ¿t the weight of the Earth, and agitation of its TranÅ¿porting, would in time by the common Method, Å¿hake the Clod down to the very RubbiÅ¿h, and bottom of the CaÅ¿e, to the great Damage of the Tree, which I would by all means prevent, as I have already Å¿hew'd.

And Å¿ince my purpoÅ¿e is, FirÅ¿t, That in Re-CaÅ¿ing, the Superficies or upper part of the Clod Å¿hould exceed the Brim of the Box three or four Inches, as certainly knowing that notwithÅ¿tanding all the Treading and Ramming, the Clod will in leÅ¿s than three or four Years, be Å¿o Å¿unk down, as to be no higher than the Edge of the CaÅ¿e (as it happens at the firÅ¿t in the ordinary way above deÅ¿cribed) though the bottom of the Clod be well enough plac'd: And, Å¿ince alÅ¿o I would that the Clod Å¿hould meet, and touch three or four Inches of the well-looÅ¿en'd Mould, into which the naked Roots may commodiouÅ¿ly enter and inÅ¿inuate themÅ¿elves. Upon theÅ¿e two ConÅ¿iderations I govern my Å¿elf, as well for the due RepleniÅ¿hing the CaÅ¿e with Earth, to the place where it touches the bottom of the Clod, as for the well Ramming and Treading of it, as by degrees (and Bed upon Bed) I caÅ¿t it in, 'til the whole CaÅ¿e be full within three or four Inches of the top, which Å¿hould remain looÅ¿e, and not be Trodden at all.

After all theÅ¿e Precautions, I Å¿o Plant my Clod, as that its Stem be juÅ¿t in the Center of the CaÅ¿e, and Å¿tand exactly upright. To do which, you Å¿hall draw Diagonal Lines from Corner to Corner; by the DecuÅ¿Å¿ation of which, you cannot fail of placing it Accurately in the middle. Then for RepleniÅ¿hing the void places about the Clod to the height of its Superficies, I uÅ¿e to cram and preÅ¿s in of the prepar'd Mould (as much as is needful) with the end of a little piece of Wood or Barrel Board, which forces and crowds the Earth in Å¿o very hard, as from that very day forward, Å¿ettles the Tree, without looÅ¿ing its Perpendicular, and EÅ¿tabliÅ¿hes it againÅ¿t all ordinary Winds, Motions, or TranÅ¿portings of the CaÅ¿es whatÅ¿oever.
