Now to keep the Earth (which I AdviÅ¿e Å¿hould conÅ¿iderably exceed the Margins of the CaÅ¿e) from Å¿liding down, eÅ¿pecially, that when you refreÅ¿h it, the Water run not down unprofitably by the Å¿ides, I order pieces of Boards of four or five Inches breadth, be applied to all the four Å¿ides of the CaÅ¿es, Å¿inking and preÅ¿Å¿ing in one of the Edges of the Boards between the Earth and the Å¿ide of the CaÅ¿e, to Mettre des hauÅ¿Å¿es. keep up the Mould Å¿o heaped above the Level of the CaÅ¿es brims: Nor is this any great Eye-Å¿ore, provided the Boards be handÅ¿omly plac'd, which otherwiÅ¿e I confeÅ¿s it would be; but however, 'tis neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be done, the benefit and uÅ¿e eaÅ¿ily reconciles one to the CuÅ¿tom, as well as its being to continue but a few Years, for Å¿o Å¿oon as the Clod is once deÅ¿cended as low as it Å¿hould go, they Å¿ignifie nothing, and you may take them away.

LaÅ¿tly, The Tree and Å¿ide Boards plac'd in this Order, I make a Å¿mall Circle of three or four Fingers deep in the upper Earth, 'twixt the Extremities of the Clod and this new looÅ¿e Mould, and then by degrees, pouring Water into the Channel, and RefreÅ¿hing it plentifully, the Mould by this time cloÅ¿ed to the ends of the new cut Roots, will Å¿oon diÅ¿poÅ¿e them to exerciÅ¿e their Function, which is to produce new ones, &c. I Å¿hall in the next Chapter Å¿peak concerning what other Waterings, and RefreÅ¿hments are to be given after this firÅ¿t.

One thing I muÅ¿t not forget, That inÅ¿tead of CaÅ¿es, they often make uÅ¿e of VaÅ¿as, and Earthen-Pots; and many now a-days would perÅ¿wade us, that certain VaÅ¿as of a peculiar Fabrick, are incomparably better than CaÅ¿es and Boxes: In the mean time, I am not of that Opinion, Å¿ince by long Experience, we all find the
many Conveniences of CaÅ¿es, and the great Inconvenience of Pots. I confeÅ¿s Pots and VaÅ¿as may be proper enough for ordinary Trees, and eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e of the new Make, Å¿eeing beÅ¿ides that they are very Beautiful, both for their Shape and fine Paintings; they are alÅ¿o capable of Earth enough (for Å¿ome time at leaÅ¿t) for thoÅ¿e leÅ¿s Curious Å¿orts of Trees, without needing Å¿o great, and Å¿o frequent Waterings, which I do not Approve of, nor of Å¿uch often Changes, which I like as little. But for great and well-grown Trees, abounding in Roots, and diÅ¿pos'd to IncreaÅ¿e them with new ones, when they are well Planted, I do not think VaÅ¿as (which cannot be made of Capacity to furniÅ¿h Å¿ufficient Matter, and maintain them well any conÅ¿iderable time) can be Å¿o proper, and convenient, as are our ordinary CaÅ¿es. Concerning the Inconvenience of the UÅ¿e of Pots and VaÅ¿as: Trees that have ample and goodly Heads, ought to be Å¿o Å¿teadily plac'd, and at large, as to be able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the ImpetuoÅ¿ity of the Winds, which VaÅ¿as do not afford them, whoÅ¿e Å¿light, and narrow Feet, commonly make them Å¿ubject to be over-thrown, and conÅ¿equently Å¿poil'd, beÅ¿ides their fragility and brittleneÅ¿s; Å¿uch Trees are therefore in continual danger of unexpected Re-CaÅ¿ing upon all Å¿uch Accidents.

To conclude, without entring farther into this ControverÅ¿ie, upon any PhiloÅ¿ophical Account, in favour of Pots and VaÅ¿as; and eÅ¿pecially, upon the ConÅ¿ideration of a certain. AntiperiÅ¿taÅ¿is (which I do not at all Comprehend) I am Å¿ufficiently convinc'd, that generally Å¿peaking, this Novel Mode, is none of the beÅ¿t, and that CaÅ¿es are much to be preferr'd, and a thouÅ¿and times better for Service, and more Commodious, though there go about of late, certain ManuÅ¿cripts, which endeavour to turn our UÅ¿e of CaÅ¿es to Ridicule.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: Of Watering: Its UÅ¿e and Way of Applying it.

div.p: I Come now to the UÅ¿e and Manner of ordinary Watering and RefreÅ¿hing of Orange-Trees, either during Winter in the Green-HouÅ¿e, or particularly in Summer-time whilÅ¿t they Å¿tand Abroad: And the Difficulty is in my Opinion greater than it appears at firÅ¿t, for as if it were of little Importance, moÅ¿t of our Gard'ners, perÅ¿waded of the great NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of it, but unwilling to take the pains of fetching the Water, leave it for the moÅ¿t part to the moÅ¿t Ignorant of their Boys and Drudges, and think it well, Å¿o their Trees be often and Å¿oundly Drench'd; that is to Å¿ay, Three or four times a Week, and Å¿ometimes more frequently, and that Å¿o profuÅ¿ely, as that it Streams out at the bottom of the CaÅ¿es in that abundance, that the Neighbour places where they Å¿tand, are commonly all in a Puddle, and unacceÅ¿Å¿ible.

I acknowledge that theÅ¿e Gard'ners have good ReaÅ¿on to Water well, becauÅ¿e of the lightneÅ¿s of the Mould they uÅ¿e for In-CaÅ¿ings: That is, having (as I reckon) committed an Error at firÅ¿t, through Ignorance, they think of mending it by a Å¿econd; which, whatever be the Fault, (conÅ¿ider'd in it Å¿elf) hinders for a time, the firÅ¿t from being as pernicious as it would have been without a Å¿econd.

For my own particular, I am extreamly Å¿crupulous, and Å¿paring as to point of Waterings; not that I totally forbid it, it being of Å¿o AbÅ¿olute NeceÅ¿Å¿ity, eÅ¿pecially during the great and extraordinary Drouths and Heats of May, June and July, whilÅ¿t the Roots are (as one may Å¿ay) more Animated than in the former Months: BeÅ¿ides, that they be then moÅ¿t Stirring and Active, it being the SeaÅ¿on of their Flowering, and putting out new Shoots, &c. But I Å¿hould not CounÅ¿el you to exceÅ¿Å¿ive reiterated, or over frequent Waterings, excepting it be during thoÅ¿e Months above-mention'd, as being the moÅ¿t Important, and ConÅ¿iderable for Vegetation; when yet it will be Å¿ufficient to beÅ¿tow on them two good Weekly Waterings, and no more. I Å¿tint it to that number, becauÅ¿e I certainly know, that in the fat and Å¿luggiÅ¿h Earth I make uÅ¿e of, there is no Å¿uch great occaÅ¿ion for great and frequent RefreÅ¿hings, and that it would be extreamly prejudicial to the Trees that receive them; and expect withal, that we Å¿hall Å¿ee conÅ¿iderable Change, in the Common UÅ¿e of great, and often Waterings, if one would apply them in the Ancient CompoÅ¿ition of Moulds.

Certain it is, that Earths which are light, and which (as they Å¿peak) have little or no Body and ConÅ¿iÅ¿tence, coming to be Watred in any Å¿ort, will hardly retain Å¿ufficient MoiÅ¿ture for any time, as indeed they Å¿hould: On the contrary, they quickly become dry, by reaÅ¿on of the eaÅ¿ie paÅ¿Å¿age which the Water finds, as well through the looÅ¿e Mould, as through the very CaÅ¿es, and Å¿o the Trees not finding their Roots Å¿ufficiently RefreÅ¿h'd (of which they have now moÅ¿t need, to Å¿et them in motion) are Å¿ubject to pine away and wither, unleÅ¿s they be plied with Water. In Å¿uch kind of Earth therefore, 'tis indiÅ¿penÅ¿ably neceÅ¿Å¿ary to repeat it; but, as 'tis only want of MoiÅ¿ture, which makes them dwindle thus, Å¿o thoÅ¿e Earths which we have deÅ¿crib'd above, being of ConÅ¿iÅ¿tence naturally to retain their MoiÅ¿ture, and continue FreÅ¿h, how little Å¿oever you Water them, will preÅ¿erve the Trees from that Infirmity, and enable them to exert their Genuine Activity, in Å¿ending forth good Roots, and conÅ¿equently fair Shoots, large and ample Leaves, and beautiful Flowers, &c. In a word, maintain themÅ¿elves in perfect Health, without needing Å¿uch abundant, and continual Waterings.

The Rules which I follow as to Waterings, concern firÅ¿t of all, that which is given immediately either after their being put into the Green-HouÅ¿e, or at their bringing out. And Å¿econdly, thoÅ¿e RefreÅ¿hings which are given during all the time that Orange-Trees Å¿tand abroad, Å¿ome of theÅ¿e Waterings I make to be great, others moderate: ThoÅ¿e I call great, when pouring Water on the Earth, it drop out at the bottom of the CaÅ¿e, but Å¿o as it be very little or nothing; and Å¿uch Waterings are profitable, provided one uÅ¿e them not too often. ThoÅ¿e I call Moderate, which I caÅ¿t on to RefreÅ¿h the Surface-Clod only, and maintain the MoiÅ¿ture that has been conÅ¿um'd, as well by the Heat, and DryneÅ¿s of the Air, as by the Attraction of the Roots.

As for thoÅ¿e RefreÅ¿hings which are given immediately after they are Å¿et into the Green-HouÅ¿e, I would beÅ¿tow a plentiful one, Å¿o Å¿oon as the Orange-Trees are placed where they muÅ¿t Å¿tand during all the time of their Confinement; and that which JuÅ¿tifies it, is, The neceÅ¿Å¿ary CloÅ¿ing of the Mould about the Roots, which in TranÅ¿porting, the Å¿haking, and agitation of the Stem, may have Å¿eparated both from it and the Roots, letting the Air into the void places, which would prove an invincible obÅ¿tacle to their Action, which (as we have often noted) never move or thrive in any Plant, Å¿ave when the Roots, and the moiÅ¿t Earth, immediately unite, which is effected by a good Watering, and prevents the diÅ¿order one is to apprehend, when a Tree is DiÅ¿abl'd from Acting according to its Nature.

Having finiÅ¿h'd this great RefreÅ¿hment of our CloiÅ¿ter'd Orange-Trees, I hardly give them any more, unleÅ¿s it be very Å¿paringly at the entrance and expiration of April, when the SeaÅ¿on growing mild, the Inclos'd Trees themÅ¿elves become Å¿enÅ¿ible of it; and then one Å¿hould not fail of Å¿etting open the Doors and Windows of the Green-HouÅ¿e often, Å¿o as the Heat of the Sun augmenting by degrees, its Beams, or the newly warmed Air at leaÅ¿t, qualifying the Room, the Earth about the Trees becomes a little more thirÅ¿ty, and being heated, urges the Roots to begin to Shoot and Quicken apace. I Å¿ay, Quicken and Augment their Motion; for 'tis certain, (as I have elÅ¿ewhere Å¿hew'd) Orange-Trees, as well as all other Verdures, are in perpetual Action, and that in the very HouÅ¿e, elÅ¿e would both their Fruits, and Leaves infallibly drop off, as being only preÅ¿erv'd, and faÅ¿tned to them by Vertue of the Sap, which continually maintains, and gives them NouriÅ¿hment, &c. 'Tis true indeed, theÅ¿e Plants do Act and Move leÅ¿s Å¿ome time than in another; that is, more Å¿lowly in Winter than in Summer, when the Sun (which is the Parent of all things Living) favours them with his benign Influence: But excepting only this Month of April, I totally ceaÅ¿e from Watering all the Winter long; and in this I Å¿ay nothing New, all diÅ¿creet Gardners obÅ¿erve it, and very rarely give I any Water at the beginning even of May, becauÅ¿e its approaching Å¿o near the time of freeing the Trees from their long Confinement, I Å¿ee no NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of making the CaÅ¿es heavier by Watering, which one Å¿hall find weighty enough already, and Å¿ufficiently difficult to T â¢ anÅ¿port.

By the way, I make no reckoning at all of certain CaÅ¿ts and Sproutings, which Å¿ome Orange-Trees now and then puÅ¿h out during Winter; nor in truth are they good, as appears by the withering of their Tops, and falling of the Leaves; Å¿o as inÅ¿tead of its perÅ¿wading me thoÅ¿e Trees Å¿hould be Water'd, that they may make better Shoots, I rather pull them quite off, as Å¿uperfluous, and good for nothing, but unprofitably to avert the Sap from the other more Å¿ubÅ¿tantial Parts, Branches and Foliage, which it Å¿hould Augment and Fortifie.

The Work I would have beÅ¿tow'd about Orange-Trees whilÅ¿t they are inclos'd, in order to their neceÅ¿Å¿ary PoliteneÅ¿s, is to finiÅ¿h the making them clean from the Filth and Ordure, which the PunaiÅ¿es and Buggs have left behind, and that has not yet been well taken away; and that if any may here or there Å¿eem to wither, a little Water be given to it, but in very little quantity, Å¿ince it proceeds only from Å¿ome of the Superficial Roots that Å¿uffer, for the Water which was given upon their firÅ¿t ConÅ¿inement, has doubtleÅ¿s ConÅ¿erv'd the Body of the Tree, and bottom of the Clod Å¿ufficiently MoiÅ¿t: Since having not yet undergon any Å¿uch Å¿corching heats of the Sun as was able to dry them up, they can Å¿uffer no Å¿uch exceÅ¿Å¿ive ThirÅ¿t, and therefore a very Å¿mall RefreÅ¿hing will Å¿oon revive the drooping Leaves. As for thoÅ¿e which Å¿tand Å¿ound and vigorous in the Green-HouÅ¿e, maintaining their Leaves freÅ¿h, large, upright and open, they are only to be look'd on and admir'd.

What I have Å¿aid concerning Watering Confined Orange-Trees, is to be underÅ¿tood (and that with greater rigour and exactneÅ¿s) of the Watering of all Trees and Shrubs that are their Fellow-PriÅ¿oners; Å¿uch as JeÅ¿Å¿imines, Granads, &c. the over-frequent Waterings Å¿poiling their Roots, and injuring the Trees; and beÅ¿ides they Naturally are not Å¿o Active as Orange, Lemon, and Myrtle-Trees, theÅ¿e latter Å¿ort giving Indications for moÅ¿t part, by the Å¿aint and pallid Complexion of the Leaves, when they Å¿tand in need of a little RefreÅ¿hment.

I would moreover for all Å¿orts of Cas'd-Trees, whether in the HouÅ¿e or Abroad, that the upmoÅ¿t Earth Å¿hould be always kept looÅ¿e, and appear as if newly Å¿tirr'd; Å¿ince beÅ¿ides, this Å¿light motion yields a marvellous Relief and Succour, by facilitating the penetration of the RefreÅ¿hments you give them, and Å¿hews very handÅ¿omly to the Eye, whilÅ¿t the Chap'd, Cloven, and CruÅ¿ty Surface is as unÅ¿ightly, I would therefore have it alÅ¿o a little Å¿prinkled.
We come now laÅ¿tly to Waterings abroad out of the Green-HouÅ¿e, as being in truth that which requires a great deal of DiÅ¿cretion, and in which methinks they commonly moÅ¿t fail.

As Å¿oon therefore as you bring forth your Trees, and have Rang'd them in the Stations where they are to continue, beÅ¿tow upon them as plentiful a Watering as you were Advis'd to do when firÅ¿t you Hous'd them: I Å¿ay, let this be a thorough and bountiful RefreÅ¿hment; which to do effectually, make Å¿everal holes in the Earth with Å¿ome Iron-Pin, or Stake of hard Wood, but withal Å¿o cautiouÅ¿ly, as not to gall any of the Roots: By this expedient the Water will viÅ¿it every part of the Clod as 'tis neceÅ¿Å¿ary it Å¿hould.

BeÅ¿ides this firÅ¿t plentiful Watering, I allow them alÅ¿o two conÅ¿iderable ones more every Week, Å¿o long as I Å¿ee the Trees to Flower and Spring; namely in the Months of May, June, July, and conÅ¿equently (if the SeaÅ¿on prove very hot and dry) to Mid-October, when they are to be Hous'd, and which Å¿ome, Trees will themÅ¿elves AdvertiÅ¿e you of, by the crumpling, half cloÅ¿ing, and hanging down of their flaccid Leaves, giving notice that they want RefreÅ¿hment, as you'll alÅ¿o find if you thruÅ¿t your Hand a little down into the Earth by its being dry. I would likewiÅ¿e every Ten days, o â¢ thereabouts, order them a conÅ¿iderable RefreÅ¿hing, and Å¿ometimes a Å¿econd moderate one, eÅ¿pecially in AuguÅ¿t when commonly Orange-Trees make new Shoots, Å¿o as you do not repeat it in caÅ¿e the Mould be moiÅ¿t enough already, for 'tis not always the dryneÅ¿s of the Earth which cauÅ¿es the Leaves to wither, they faint oftentimes before a following TempeÅ¿t, or that the Tree be not well EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h'd, is looÅ¿e in the Roots, or too much expos'd to the Sun. In Å¿uch caÅ¿es you are ever to Examine of what Temper the Earth is, dry or moiÅ¿t, and accordingly to Govern the Waterings. NotwithÅ¿tanding all this, every body finds that Å¿ome Å¿ort of Trees will always look faint and Å¿ickly, whatever bountiful Waterings you beÅ¿tow upon them.

'Tis very certain as to this particular, I have often obÅ¿erv'd two things: FirÅ¿t, That when Å¿ome Gard'ners have Command of Water, they are commonly apt to over Water their Orange-Trees, either themÅ¿elves or by their Servants. And in the Å¿econd place, Some extreamly neglect to do it, and give them not Å¿ufficient, eÅ¿pecially where it requires pains to fetch the Water, LazineÅ¿s or ill CuÅ¿tom carrying them to theÅ¿e Extreams. 'Tis I Å¿ay moÅ¿t certain, that as to the firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e two CaÅ¿es, I would not they Å¿hould exceed very moderate RefreÅ¿hments, finding that they commonly give them too much: And to the Å¿econd quite the contrary, namely, To allow them a thorough Watering, leÅ¿t being to take pains to fetch the Water, they afford them not enough. I very well know that diÅ¿creet Gard'ners need none of theÅ¿e SteppoÅ¿ite Documents; however, that I may Reconcile them both together,
I adhere to my former Opinion, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing the Earth to be mingled according to my Method; That regularly Watering twice a Week, at certain times (namely during the hot SeaÅ¿ons, the time of Flowring, and pride of Shooting, and ever obÅ¿erving a Mediocrity between two great ones, and RefreÅ¿hing them every eight or ten days only at other times) you will find your Trees in excellent condition as to their Waterings: To which add, That Orange-Trees have this of Agreeable as to what concerns their Drink, and in which they almoÅ¿t reÅ¿emble Men that are WiÅ¿e, That as they Å¿eldom call for it but when they have Need and are ThirÅ¿ty; to urge them when they do not require it, inÅ¿tead of doing them a kindneÅ¿s one does but incommode them. In like manner Orange-Trees Å¿ometimes of themÅ¿elves give notice when they have need of being RefreÅ¿h'd; Å¿o as we certainly do them injury when we Water them out of SeaÅ¿on, whereas we do them good in RefreÅ¿hing them when their Leaves becoming lank, and wrap'd together call for help, and give Symptoms that the Root is LanguiÅ¿hing for want of MoiÅ¿ture. But that which juÅ¿tifies the CompariÅ¿on farther is, That a Prudent and Skilful Gard'ner is never to wait for the Signal from his Orange-Tree when he Å¿hould do his Duty, but that when ever he perceives or Å¿uÅ¿pects it (if he be not miÅ¿taken) he be Å¿ure to apply the proper Remedy according to our PreÅ¿cription; but as there are both good and wholÅ¿om RefreÅ¿hments, there are likewiÅ¿e very evil and pernicious ones too. Concerning which I Å¿hall declare what I think, with that Moderation I judge moÅ¿t convenient.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.p: Of the Inconveniences which happen to Orange-Trees, as well from Over-Waterings as from the Fire which is made in Green-HouÅ¿es.

div.p: 'TIS eaÅ¿ily perceiv'd, that when too much Water is given Cas'd Orange-Trees, there uÅ¿ually enÅ¿ue two great DiÅ¿orders; and as remarkable it is, that one is not Å¿enÅ¿ible of the Evil when it firÅ¿t begins, but the conÅ¿equence makes us feel it at laÅ¿t, when 'tis too late for Remedy.

The firÅ¿t DiÅ¿order conÅ¿iÅ¿tsin this, That thoÅ¿e unreaÅ¿onable and frequent Summer-Watering AccuÅ¿toming (as one may Å¿ay) the Trees to a CourÅ¿e of Life which though Inconvenient, would nevertheleÅ¿s enable them to Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t, were it to be continued all the Winter long: Their being Å¿o eaÅ¿ily inur'd to all Å¿orts of NouriÅ¿hment, would produce them this Å¿ingular Advantage. But Å¿ince we find that Å¿uch Waterings will become Mortal to them when the cold Weather comes, we ought to be very Å¿paring, though to avoid one danger (which in effect is of all other the greateÅ¿t) we are apt to fall into another which is not without its great Inconvenience, namely, That of an every Years loÅ¿s of Leaves. Now one cannot Reflect on an Accident Å¿o ungrateful, without concluding it to proceed from the Roots not receiving that due NouriÅ¿hment during the Å¿even previous Months of their Confinement, which they us'd to have the five former Months abroad, which needs muÅ¿t check and put a Å¿top to their Natural Activity. This doubtleÅ¿s is the CauÅ¿e that the Leaves finding themÅ¿elves deÅ¿titute of that perpetual Å¿upply of Sap which then they need, are forc'd to forÅ¿ake the Branches, which Naturally and from their Birth produc'd them: And Å¿o not well underÅ¿tanding from what Å¿ource this Evil proceeds we make divers Erroneous Conjectures, and have recourÅ¿e to other things which peradventure have not at all Contributed to it, always Å¿uppoÅ¿ing that the Green-HouÅ¿e be not in fault.

In the next place (and which indeed is the moÅ¿t Important) Å¿ince the Nature and Quality of the Shoots intirely depend upon the Quality of the Roots, and theÅ¿e particularly upon that of NouriÅ¿hment. 'Tis certain, That when this is peccant and feeble, the New-born Roots muÅ¿t needs be weak and feeble alÅ¿o, and conÅ¿equently, that the Sap which they prepare being of an ill ConÅ¿titution, the Shoots themÅ¿elves which they produce muÅ¿t needs be Å¿hort and weak, alÅ¿o the Leaves Å¿inall, limber, and often Yellow. Hence it comes to paÅ¿s, that theÅ¿e Orange-Trees, which for want of Å¿ufficient NouriÅ¿hment during Summer are already fall'n Sick, finiÅ¿h (as I may Å¿ay) their LanguiÅ¿hing and MiÅ¿ery, Å¿o Å¿oon as the Cold (which above all things they dread) aÅ¿Å¿aults them: The main Principle of their Natural Strength and Vigour, may poÅ¿Å¿ibly have enabled them to reÅ¿iÅ¿t and Å¿truggle for
Å¿ome time againÅ¿t the MiÅ¿chief to which their ill Culture has reduc'd them, but when once this little Stock comes to be Å¿pent and exhauÅ¿ted (as at length it will be) they pine Å¿o miÅ¿erably, that for Å¿ome years after one Å¿hall be hardly able to Recover them, and perhaps at laÅ¿t without SucceÅ¿s.

We have already Å¿aid (and may not improperly repeat here) that it is not from the Material SubÅ¿tance of the Earth the Roots Elaborate and CompoÅ¿e the Sap, adminiÅ¿tring NouriÅ¿hment to all the parts of the Tree; it is the Water only, which percolating through the Ground, is Impregnat with part of its Salt, or Å¿ome other qualities wherewith the Earth was endowed: So as if this Earth, whoÅ¿e Salt doubtleÅ¿s is not InexhauÅ¿tible and without end, comes once to be over-diluted by great and frequent WaÅ¿hings, it muÅ¿t needs at laÅ¿t be quite robb'd and depriv'd of all its Salure, and within a Å¿hort time after, the Roots finding no more of it in the Water which moiÅ¿tens the Earth, or but very little, they can produce no more new Shoots worth any thing; and conÅ¿equently, neither any good and laudable Sap, Branch, Leaves, or Flowers, &c. as doubtleÅ¿s they would do in better Mould moderately moiÅ¿ten'd and refreÅ¿h'd. Whence I conclude (and I think with ReaÅ¿on) That to Water Trees to the purpoÅ¿e, requires more Skill and Prudence than uÅ¿ually appears in the ordinary Conduct of moÅ¿t Gard'ners.

On the other Å¿ide, by the uÅ¿e of Fire which moÅ¿t of them affect to make in the Green-HouÅ¿e, Orange and Lemon-Trees fall into other very pernicious Inconveniences as by long Experience I have Learn'd. The ReaÅ¿on is evident, The Fire is either too great or too Å¿mall. If the latter, the Heat can only affect thoÅ¿e Plants which are very near it, without any Influence on the farther diÅ¿tant. For Example, If you make it below, and (as commonly they practice it) in Å¿everal places of the Room, neither the Heads (of any height) nor oppoÅ¿ite Å¿ides of Å¿uch as Å¿tand not near, are Å¿enÅ¿ible of it; and in caÅ¿e you make it higher, the under Branches receive no comfort by it. Thus granting it may do Å¿ome good, which I don't believe, 'tis yet certain, that the Fire being little it does but little good, and in few places, and conÅ¿equently its Benefit is inconÅ¿iderable, or rather none at all.

On the contrary, If you make a great Fire, as the Nature of Å¿uch a Fire is to dry up that which is MoiÅ¿t, as far as its Heat extends, 'twill doubtleÅ¿s parch and dry both the Bark and Branches of the Trees, eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e parts on which the Leaves depend, and conÅ¿equently make them Å¿hrink; Å¿top and obÅ¿truct the Channels and PaÅ¿Å¿ages of the Sap, which Å¿hould always continue moiÅ¿t and open for its free and perpetual IntercourÅ¿e, whilÅ¿t (as above we Å¿aid) 'tis indiÅ¿penÅ¿ably requiÅ¿ite that the Sap do convey continual Supplies both to the Trunk, Branches, Fruit and Leaves, this diÅ¿order elÅ¿e will be Å¿ure to happen, upon the leaÅ¿t Interception of this Supply: Sap, without queÅ¿tion, being to theÅ¿e Å¿ort of Trees what Water is to FiÅ¿hes, and the Air to all TerreÅ¿trial Animals, and even what Foundations are to Buildings, and the Hand is to the Ballance which holds it up, and Å¿uÅ¿pends it in the Air.

In all Events this Fire (as PhiloÅ¿ophers Å¿peak) Changes, and Dries the Air, and cauÅ¿es a notable Alteration, and has the Å¿ame effect upon it as it commonly has on Water, which Experience tells us being Boil'd, and coming after to be expos'd to the freÅ¿h Air, grows more Å¿uÅ¿ceptible of Cold than 'twas before, and conÅ¿equently Å¿hall Å¿ooner Freeze than that which has never been near any Fire at all: So as to the ImpreÅ¿Å¿ions of Cold in relation to the Air, this Fire (kindled in the Green-HouÅ¿e)
â¢ enders the Air more obnoxious and diÅ¿pos'd to receive the Cold which environs it on every part, than that which never was thus alter'd with any Artificial Heat. The Heat of Char-coal, and the like, whether in Å¿ome hidden Stove, or Earthen Pan, though it may perhaps encounter, and hinder Å¿ome Effects of Cold offenÅ¿ive to living Creatures, who will receive no more than they need and have a mind to; yet Orange-Trees have not that Gift to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h and know the juÅ¿t degree of a Foreign Heat, neceÅ¿Å¿ary to protect them againÅ¿t the rigour of Winter. The truth is, to derive any advantage from Artificial Fire in favour of the Green-HouÅ¿e, one Å¿hould firÅ¿t underÅ¿tand the juÅ¿t MeaÅ¿ure of the Need which theÅ¿e Trees have of it, whether only to defend them from the Cold, or Å¿o to recover the Heat which they have loÅ¿t, as that afterwards no Infirmity may be the conÅ¿equent of it; but we have not this Sagacity, an Orange-Tree which has once been attack'd by the FroÅ¿t Infallibly loÅ¿es its Leaves, remaining Sick and IndiÅ¿pos'd a long time after. In the Å¿econd place, it were neceÅ¿Å¿ary that through the whole extent of the Green-HouÅ¿e, the Heat were always Uniform and of the Å¿ame Temper, which it neither is nor can be, for it can neither be equal as to its continuance, nor (as PhiloÅ¿ophers Å¿peak) perfectly Regular as to its Intention: That is (as all the World has Å¿ufficiently Experienc'd)
maintain a conÅ¿tant Heat, and of the Å¿elf Å¿ame Tenor, eÅ¿pecially during the Night, which is the Time that the Cold is moÅ¿t IntenÅ¿e and Penetrating, and when the Gard'ner is commonly faÅ¿t aÅ¿leep; Å¿o as the Fire, which at the Beginning, or when newly kindled was but moderate, does afterwards IncreaÅ¿e, the Fuel at laÅ¿t being all Å¿pent and conÅ¿um'd, it does either extreamly diminiÅ¿h and abate of its Heat, or is altogether extinguiÅ¿h'd: Such Fire, I affirm therefore creates great DiÅ¿orders in the Green-HouÅ¿e, Spoiling the Boughs that are neareÅ¿t to it, Parching the Leaves, and above all, Altering the Air, which produces all the Good, and all the MiÅ¿chief, accordingly as 'tis well or ill qualified.

My Opinion therefore is, that the very beÅ¿t Expedient for the PreÅ¿ervation of Orange-Trees thus Inclos'd againÅ¿t the Cold, which is Å¿o funeÅ¿t and deadly to them, were (as we have Å¿hew'd) a good Situation and ExpoÅ¿ure: That the Doors be made of Å¿ufficient ThickneÅ¿s, and exactly Shutting; The Windows very CloÅ¿e, with good ChaÅ¿Å¿is double, and well Cauk'd; EÅ¿pecially, that the Walls of the HouÅ¿e be SubÅ¿tantial. But in CaÅ¿e the ConÅ¿ervatory Å¿hould not have purpoÅ¿ely been built for this PurpoÅ¿e, as now and then it may happen; and that perhaps one is oblig'd to make uÅ¿e of a Room that has been formerly Å¿ome Hall, Cellar, or Stable, &c. as occaÅ¿ion prompts till a Better be made. In Å¿uch exigence; the beÅ¿t way is to build either within, or on the out-Å¿ide (as Å¿hall be found moÅ¿t Convenient) Å¿ome Counter-Wall, of a full foot in thickneÅ¿s, as high, and long as is the old Wall, if you Å¿uÅ¿pect it not thick enough; and this Å¿hould be built of good MaÅ¿onry: Or in caÅ¿e of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity, one may Cloath an Old Wall with Litter of a dry Dunghill, beating it very cloÅ¿e together as you heap it up; and to the end it may Å¿tand and not Å¿lide down, to drive in Å¿ome Å¿tout quarters of Wood at Competent diÅ¿tances from the Wall about four foot of each other, joyning to the Counter-mure of the Litter.

Indeed Å¿uch Litter-Counter-Walls are not Å¿o Å¿ightly and Å¿weet within Doors: BeÅ¿ides they will be a Retreat for Rats and Mice, which may be apt to gnaw and diÅ¿bark the Trees, not Å¿paring the Roots themÅ¿elves: But beÅ¿ides that there are many remedies and ways to deÅ¿troy moÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e Vermin; They are not Å¿uch deadly and pernicious Enemies to Trees which are Inclos'd, as the FroÅ¿ts againÅ¿t which Å¿uch Counter-Walls of Dung are made uÅ¿e of, 'till a more commodious HouÅ¿e can be built: This therefore may Å¿erve to anÅ¿wer the Objection of UnÅ¿ightlineÅ¿s, and ill Odor. I wiÅ¿h no body (who is a Lover of Orange-Trees) may be reduc'd to this Extremity; but may have timely prevented it by erecting a good ConÅ¿ervatory for this purpoÅ¿e only.

But, if notwithÅ¿tanding all theÅ¿e Precautions, we diÅ¿cover the Ice in our IncloÅ¿ure, as 'tis eaÅ¿ily done by hanging a Linnen Rag moiÅ¿tned, or Å¿etting Å¿ome Å¿mall DiÅ¿hes of Water in Å¿everal Places of the HouÅ¿e in the Winter-time, and eÅ¿pecially near the Doors and Windows, on the edges of the CaÅ¿es and Boxes, to obÅ¿erve whether the FroÅ¿t (againÅ¿t which one cannot be too Watchful and Jealous) have gotten any entrance: In this Exigence, the moÅ¿t Infallible Remedy to maintain a Sweet and uniform Warmth, and which may laÅ¿t as long as one pleaÅ¿es; is to Hang up lighted Flambeaux, or Lamps (which will be Å¿ure to laÅ¿t) either between the ChaÅ¿Å¿is againÅ¿t the Windows, if it be there the Cold enters, or near the Doors, or all along the whole HouÅ¿e; taking care the Flame touch none of the Trees, and that the Warmth continue of the Å¿ame Temper, as is eaÅ¿ily done: The Experience of Å¿etting a Å¿mall Wax-Candle lighted in a Coach cloÅ¿e Å¿hut up, or of more than one, in a very cloÅ¿e Chamber, may Å¿erve to Confirm this Expedient, as they have me to JuÅ¿tifie this Imagination.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: What there is to be done to the Heads of Orange-Trees, as well in order to the Recovery of Å¿uch as have been long Neglected, Ill Govern'd or Spoil'd, either by Cold, Wet, Hail; as alÅ¿o how to Attain the having Å¿uch Trees as Å¿hall be always Beautiful, and Agreeable both in Shape, and Figure, Health, and Vigour.

div.p:
TO Å¿atisfie the Importance and Extent of this ComprehenÅ¿ive Chapter, I think firÅ¿t to propoÅ¿e the Idea which I have conceiv'd of the Beauty of the Orange-Tree; whether it be a Well-grown Tree, a Small, or Moderate one; for there are very fine ones both of the one and other Å¿ort, as well as among all the Species of
Animals, there are fair ones of all Ages and Growths: But the Truth is, there is nothing more Rare, than to find Orange-Trees, Å¿uch as are Great and Perfect at the Å¿ame time; whilÅ¿t it is eaÅ¿ie enough among the ordinary and moderate Å¿ort, to meet with Å¿uch as are both Fair, and extreamly handÅ¿om: There are alÅ¿o I confeÅ¿s, very beautiful Orange-Trees in BuÅ¿h (that is, Å¿uch as produce Branches from the very bottom) but indeed thoÅ¿e which maintain an upright, Å¿trait and fair Stem of about two feet and an half, to Three or Four, or at moÅ¿t, to Five Feet in Height, are much Å¿tatelier, and carry a certain MajeÅ¿ty, much Superior to the Shrub and BuÅ¿h: I am not much for thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e Beam Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿es this Height; tho' they have otherwiÅ¿e their Beauties alÅ¿o, and really Å¿omething in them of Noble and Royal; Å¿uch as would Infinitely become a Plantation without Doors, and in plain Ground: But for the CaÅ¿e and Box, they would bring with them great Inconveniences, and be nothing Å¿o Commodious, in regard of the difficulty of Carrying and Removing them, the Height and Capacity of the Doors, and Cieling of the ConÅ¿ervatory, &c. A Green-HouÅ¿e from Fifteen to Sixteen Feet, is an handÅ¿om proportion for the well entertaining any ReaÅ¿onable and Curious PerÅ¿on's Trees: But for Å¿uch as have HouÅ¿es of Twenty, Twenty two, and Twenty four feet high (as indeed there ought to be) for Trees of Eight, Nine, and Ten feet Stem or above, they ought to have Heads correÅ¿pondent to their Å¿tature, and will require CaÅ¿es of four and five feet Depth: But I confeÅ¿s theÅ¿e Gyants affright me; there being I fear few PerÅ¿ons that would be at the Expence of Å¿uch Buildings: And indeed hardly find we the Gates of Cities of that Altitude: However, they deÅ¿erve due PraiÅ¿e and Encouragement, who in our Days attempt the RaiÅ¿ing Trees of that goodly Stature, Å¿ince we may hope, that as they appear Worthy the CurioÅ¿ity of the greateÅ¿t Monarch of the World, Å¿o we Å¿hall Å¿hortly Å¿ee them an Extraordinary Ornament to his Gardens.
Now therefore to be able to pronounce that the Head of an Orange-Tree (whatever it be) is Endow'd with all the Beauty and AccompliÅ¿hments 'tis capable of, theÅ¿e Å¿ix Conditions are requiÅ¿ite:

FirÅ¿t, That the Head be of a Round Figure, yet Å¿o as it be alÅ¿o large, wellÅ¿pread, and almoÅ¿t flat, approaching in Shape to that of a MuÅ¿hroom newly riÅ¿en, or of a Calott, yet not Affected or nicely Circular, as they uÅ¿e to cut Myrtles, Tews, Philyria's, and Standard-Honey-Suckles, Box, &c. which appear forc'd and conÅ¿train'd, but of a Natural RoundneÅ¿s, Free and Airy, and without Art, as we commonly Å¿ee grow the ConÅ¿tantinople-CheÅ¿s-Nut, Lime-Trees, &c.

Secondly, That it be Full, without ConfuÅ¿ion within, and not void and hollow as we Affect to have our Fruit-Trees: But the Orange-Trees Heads Å¿hould be furniÅ¿h'd with a pretty number of fair well-fed Branches, almoÅ¿t of an equal Å¿ize, and eaÅ¿ie to be Å¿een and numbred if one be diÅ¿pos'd. This is one of the moÅ¿t principal Conditions of the Beauty of Orange-Trees, as it is alÅ¿o the moÅ¿t Rare, whilÅ¿t many do not EÅ¿teem this ConfuÅ¿ion for any great Defect, though I confeÅ¿s it appears to me a great one.

Thirdly, That the Branches which form and compoÅ¿e the Head of the Tree, be Å¿ufficiently and well NouriÅ¿h'd, and Å¿o Å¿trong that their Tops inÅ¿tead of Inclining towards the Earth (as many we find do) erect and hold up their Heads to the Air, with plenty of large and green Leaves; yet Å¿o, as that the longeÅ¿t Branches exceed not half a Foot, Å¿ince if the Boughs Å¿ink down, 'tis a mark they are Å¿o weak that they are not able to RedreÅ¿s themÅ¿elves; and Å¿eeing the new Shoots Å¿pring only from the Extremities and Tops of the old ones (whoÅ¿e Situation they naturally follow) it comes to paÅ¿s that all Å¿uch Shoots as proceed from thoÅ¿e feeble ones, are yet more feeble, and leÅ¿s able to erect themÅ¿elves, and conÅ¿equently yield a very Ill-favour'd ProÅ¿pect. BeÅ¿ides, If the Leaves be Å¿mall and yellow, 'tis yet a Å¿ign of greater Imbecillity in the Roots (for as much as Naturally this Tree does produce Leaves that are large, green, thick and in plenty) and therefore that they will quickly fall off, and denude the Tree of its genuine Ornament. In Å¿hort, the ReaÅ¿ons of this third Qualification propos'd, are, That if the utmoÅ¿t length be exceÅ¿Å¿ive (as a Foot or more would be) the Leaves not being of above three or four Years abiding on the Branch which bears them (and even for thoÅ¿e a Tree ought to be a very luÅ¿ty one, Å¿ince moÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e which we Å¿ee Å¿eldom hang on above a Year or two, and live not beyond three or four) it happens, that coming to drop off in their turns, thoÅ¿e over-long Branches will appear all naked and bare, which is extreamly unÅ¿ightly; therefore, whatever Branch in the Spring of the Year advances above half a Foot, it Å¿hould be nipp'd off and confin'd to that dimenÅ¿ion.

Fourthly, The fourth condition requires that the Tree Å¿hould be ready to put forth plenty of fair Shoots every Spring Yearly; which if it do not, or that it only produce but Å¿mall and trifling ones, the defect is from the Foot, and the next Year after it will be in danger of loÅ¿ing its Leaf, which Å¿hould be prevented by all means poÅ¿Å¿ible. Now no Shoots ought to be accounted fair, but Å¿uch as are of competent length and bigneÅ¿s, and conÅ¿equently (as we Å¿hew'd) able to Å¿uÅ¿tain themÅ¿elves without bending their Tops; Å¿uch never fail of large and green Leaves, which they keep on from falling, Å¿ince thoÅ¿e which have now perhaps been on for three Years paÅ¿t, coming to drop according to the courÅ¿e of Nature, there is Å¿till a Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of thoÅ¿e of the two former Years, beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e of the current and preÅ¿ent Year, to maintain the Ornament and Decoration of the Tree.

Fifthly, 'Tis required that our Orange-Tree produce (not an Infinite, but) a ReaÅ¿onable quantity of Flowers, fair, great, long, large and weighty, Å¿uch as give preÅ¿age of goodly Fruit: On which I am to AdvertiÅ¿e, That Orange-Trees do every Spring produce two Å¿orts of Flowers, one whereof proceeding from the old Wood or Shoot of the precedent Year, uÅ¿ually are but Å¿mall and round, and confus'dly plac'd, Å¿o as moÅ¿t of them drop off without knitting; and theÅ¿e firÅ¿t appear in the early Spring. But Woe to that Tree which is over-charg'd with them however the Owner eÅ¿teem of it; their Beauty will Å¿oon paÅ¿s, and the end of it be unproÅ¿perous and diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ing.

I foreÅ¿ee that my Sentiments herein will not be very Acceptable to every body, divers Curious PerÅ¿ons fancying that an Orange-Tree can never bring forth too many Flowers; but for all that, I adventure to declare it a great MiÅ¿take, which Time and Experience will Cure them of. I Å¿hould willingly be of their Opinion, were it poÅ¿Å¿ible to Reconcile that large quantity of thoÅ¿e Å¿ort of Flowers with thoÅ¿e other Conditions, which indeed I eÅ¿teem a great deal more, the Beauty of the Abundance of thoÅ¿e being but for one Fortnight, whereas the other are the Beauty of the whole Year about, and therefore to be preferr'd.

The other Flowers of the Orange-Tree Å¿pring out at the tops of the Shoots of that Year, and commonly with thoÅ¿e tranÅ¿cendent Qualities we have enumerated; nor come they in CluÅ¿ters and confus'dly, but are of Å¿ubÅ¿tance long, and well fed, and do not appear 'til the end of June, or beginning of July, and of which we cannot have too many.

The Sixth RequiÅ¿ite to the Beauty of the Orange-Tree, is its being free of all Ordure, DuÅ¿t and Sullage, and eÅ¿pecially of Bugs and PiÅ¿mires. We have Å¿hew'd already how this may eaÅ¿ily be compaÅ¿s'd at the beginning of this TreatiÅ¿e.

Having thus propos'd the Idea which I have form'd of a Beautiful-headed Orange-Tree, and eÅ¿pecially Å¿uppoÅ¿ing they have not fail'd in performing all the Directions I have given concerning the Root, in order to its Shooting well (upon which all the reÅ¿t depends) there remains to inquire what there is more to be done to arrive at this Idea, whether in Relation to Å¿uch Trees as have not yet begun their Heads, and are but newly In-Cas'd, or in ReÅ¿pect to others, which have never received any AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance or (as one may Å¿ay) Education at all.

And FirÅ¿t, As to the roundneÅ¿s and fullneÅ¿s of the Head, I conceive that having well conÅ¿ider'd and approv'd of it, one Å¿hall eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cover the defects which are repugnant to it, Å¿o as one Å¿hall not endure Å¿o much as the Å¿ight of an Orange-Tree unfurniÅ¿h'd in the middle, flat at one of the Å¿ides, over long on another, or riÅ¿ing in Pyramid like a CypreÅ¿s, or with Branches groveling on the Earth like the tardy and late-bearing Cherry-Tree: You will not (I Å¿ay) be able to Å¿uffer the leaÅ¿t Bough to Å¿tart out beyond its Fellows, disfiguring the roundneÅ¿s which is now a forming.

And Å¿o for the Å¿upply of Vacuities (which Å¿eldom is the Fault of Orange-Trees, that on the contrary grow Naturally full, confus'd and irregular, as do moÅ¿t Å¿orts of other Fruit-Trees) one is to conÅ¿ider, that this defect either proceeds from no other CauÅ¿e than from the Ignorance, and ill handling of the Gard'ner, or that Å¿ome interior and middle Branches may unhappily, or unwarily have been broken. In either of theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es, there's nothing to be done but to endeavour the preÅ¿erving of thoÅ¿e other Branches which Nature will not fail of putting forth if the Tree be vigorous; or if it be not in condition (whilÅ¿t perhaps it is become Sick and LanguiÅ¿hing) you muÅ¿t Å¿peedily reÅ¿olve to Lop off, and Abate one or two of the biggeÅ¿t Branches near to the middle, being certain of its Å¿oon producing others, Å¿ufficient to furniÅ¿h and repair this blemiÅ¿h in a little time.

As to a Tree defective in roundneÅ¿s, or that you find one of its Å¿ides too flat, it may proceed from a double CauÅ¿e; as either from Å¿ome Accident of a Boughs
being broken, which Å¿hould naturally have Contributed to that comely Figure, and then the remaining Å¿ound part of the Branch muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be Cut off, as far as to that very place which the DiÅ¿cretion of an Able Gard'ner judges may beÅ¿t Å¿upply the Defect: Or elÅ¿e it Å¿prings from where an Ignorant Gardner may have Å¿uffer'd Å¿ome one or more Libertine great Branches to Å¿hoot uncontroll'd, and to have Robb'd and receiv'd all the NouriÅ¿hment from the ReÅ¿t; whilÅ¿t the moÅ¿t Å¿eeble parts remain as it were Abandon'd: whereas, he Å¿hould have Nipp'd off thoÅ¿e Exorbitants, at their very firÅ¿t appearing, and Reduc'd them to Order, or elÅ¿e have Cut them Å¿hort the enÅ¿uing Spring.

Branches thus Nipp'd off, or diÅ¿creetly Cut, would not have fail'd to Å¿prout from all about the Tops Å¿everal New Branches, and become a Round and handÅ¿ome Tree: Nay for the RedreÅ¿s of Å¿uch a Fault (a great one in my Opinion) one is Å¿ometimes forc'd to proceed to an Operation which at firÅ¿t appears a little Cruel; Namely, to the Amputation of all thoÅ¿e Wanderers, and conÅ¿train the Whole-Tree to begin a new the forming of that agreeable RoundneÅ¿s, as Å¿hall be thought moÅ¿t Convenient, and which commonly reaches to that feeble part of the Tree: Or elÅ¿e one muÅ¿t begin upon the very Tops and Summity of thoÅ¿e eÅ¿caped Branches, provided there be any likelihood of bringing it to a Beautiful Shape, in which CaÅ¿e, one is to abandon all thoÅ¿e Å¿mall and Infirm ones that Å¿tand in the way:

If the Figure of an Orange-Tree be diÅ¿agreeable by being too long Å¿ided; you have no more to do, than to Cut away, and abate all that part which grows out of due Rank, and Å¿trangles beyond its bound: The Å¿ame is to be done to the Pointed, and over Tapering Trees, till you have reduc'd them to that Globular and deÅ¿irable Figure a little Flatted at the Crown.

But in CaÅ¿e that moÅ¿t of the Branches bend down their Tops, it proceeds from want of Å¿trength; elÅ¿e they all of them naturally Å¿uÅ¿tain themÅ¿elves upright, if of Å¿ufficient SubÅ¿tance to Å¿upport the burden of the Leaves: Now this defect of vigour Å¿ometimes Å¿prings for want of wholeÅ¿ome NouriÅ¿hment, and now and then from the Superfluous number of Branches, which require to be fed according to the vigour of the Root, be it Great, or Small; Å¿ince its Strength can reach but a determin'd point: The Gard'ner therefore ought to be an Able, and Experienc'd Workman; FirÅ¿t, in knowing how to apply good and proper Mould (of which the Chapter above has amply treated) and then (having done his Endeavour as to that particular) to ConÅ¿ider what Weight and Charge his Tree is able to Å¿uÅ¿tain, and accordingly leave no more Branches on than can well be fed, and the Stem Å¿upport.

When therefore one perceives a Tree to Å¿uffer under this Infirmity, the Branches Growling or over-bending (which happly may not yet proceed from want of NouriÅ¿hment) one Å¿hould begin to take a great part of thoÅ¿e Branches quite away; Namely, all the Feeble ones, and thoÅ¿e eÅ¿pecially which grow out of Order, and diÅ¿compoÅ¿e the Figure; preÅ¿erving only thoÅ¿e SubÅ¿tantial ones which are found well plac'd.

This Operation Å¿hould be perform'd with great diligence, juÅ¿t when the Trees begin to Sprout; and therefore one is to ObÅ¿erve, that commonly, as to Orange-Trees (for it does not fall out the Å¿ame in moÅ¿t other Trees) from whatever part a Branch does IÅ¿Å¿ue, be it from the Body of the Tree, or from Å¿ome other Bough, 'tis ever accompanied with a Second, and not Å¿eldom with a Third; upon which this Reflection is to be made; That in caÅ¿e the Sap, which is divided into Two or Three Channels, were all reduc'd to One alone, namely to a Å¿ingle Branch; that one Branch partaking of the greater Portion, would doubtleÅ¿s be the moÅ¿t Å¿trong and vigorous, and capable of Erecting its Head, and Supporting all its Weight.

Now the AÅ¿Å¿embling and Uniting this divaricated Juice to one Channel, is Å¿oon learn'd and done, by pulling off the Å¿mall Shoots, and notably diminiÅ¿hing of their number, not leaving above one in a place, Namely, the handÅ¿omeÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t Commodious, in order to the deÅ¿ired Figure propoÅ¿ed. This pulling off the Shoots Å¿hould be done as Å¿oon as poÅ¿Å¿ibly, that the Sap Å¿pend not it Å¿elf unprofitably amongÅ¿t the Faulty Branches to be taken away; but finding its accuÅ¿tomed paÅ¿Å¿age not only Å¿topp'd and intercepted, but another (which is near it) open, may flow in plentifully there, and render it a conÅ¿iderable increaÅ¿e of NouriÅ¿hment, and as Certain of SucceÅ¿s, as the Execution of it is EaÅ¿ie.

'Tis Å¿ufficiently Evident, that it were much better not to have above one Å¿ingle good and Å¿ubÅ¿tantial Shoot, than two or three moderate ones; One Å¿trong, vigorous, and conÅ¿equently moÅ¿t Beautiful Shoot, Å¿hall furniÅ¿h infinitely beyond all thoÅ¿e trifling ones which can produce but poor and deÅ¿picable Foliage.

It often fortunes, that Å¿uch a Branch, Å¿o NouriÅ¿h'd with the portion of three or four, will in a Å¿hort time become of great length, and much exceed its Neighbours, to the ruine of our Propos'd Symmetrie: Wherefore, in this CaÅ¿e, 'tis adviÅ¿able to Nip it off, and not permit it to exceed a Foot in length. To which Standard and Size, I would willingly Reduce the Shoots of all our Orange-Trees, that by this means, their Heads growing at leaÅ¿t a Foot large in Diameter every Year (never above) that is half a Foot on each part or Å¿ide round the Stem (I do not mean to ReÅ¿train its growing more in height, half a Foot Å¿hall Å¿uffice me) One may be Contented with this Annual Augmentation for the Diameter; Å¿ince it fairly promiÅ¿es an IncreaÅ¿e of Six Feet, in Six or Seven Years, which is very ConÅ¿iderable if one be able to attain it, as I doubt not but the OrangiÅ¿t will AccompliÅ¿h doing his Duty as he Å¿hould, or the Fault is in the Gard'ner.

Now in CaÅ¿e that all you thus Nip off, Å¿oon after produce new Shoots, and that in reaÅ¿onable number, well plac'd, for the equally furniÅ¿hing the whole Circumference of your Orange-Tree; 'Tis happy for you, and Å¿hould be CheriÅ¿h'd, Å¿ince it does not often happen: And therefore if there be but few Branches, that having been Å¿o Nip'd put â¢ orth new Shoots at their Tops, you Å¿hould Å¿pare none of them but Å¿uch as may Contribute to the Beauty of the Figure; continually plucking off all the Springs of the reÅ¿t: Which if the Lazy or Unskilful Gard'ner have omitted to do, and what elÅ¿e has lately been directed him, and was to have been done in Summer (when thoÅ¿e Shoots being extremly Tender and Brittle, knap off eaÅ¿ier than GlaÅ¿s) You muÅ¿t have recourÅ¿e to the Knife again, and fall to Cutting when they are now grown Hard, either at the end of Summer, before you Å¿hut them up in the Green-HouÅ¿e (which is beÅ¿t) or at the Spring of the Year, when you bring them forth: For abÅ¿olutely, you muÅ¿t not Indulge any one Branch that grows Extravagantly, diÅ¿gracing the Shape and comely Figure which one Å¿hould always bear in Mind and aim at.

The Pruning and Cutting of Orange-Trees has an advantage, which other Trees have not, Particularly Peach-Trees; It often happening that a Branch of the Peach being cut off, does not Å¿prout at all again, hindred by a certain Gum that kills it: But of the Orange-Tree, whatever Branch you cut, or pinch off, if it be a Vigorous Tree, Å¿mall or great, it will not fail of re-producing new ones, according to the Å¿trength and ability of the Tree.

As to Nipping of the Orange-Tree; you Å¿hould never permit any new, long and Å¿traggling Branch upon them, excepting on Å¿uch as have been newly Planted, and that yet have nothing to Å¿hew but the Stem only, without any old Branches: 'Tis neceÅ¿Å¿ary that thoÅ¿e Å¿ort of Trees Å¿hould Å¿peedily put forth good and luÅ¿ty Shoots, and Å¿uch as being free and without intanglement, may form an Head proportionable to the bigneÅ¿s and Å¿tature of the Stem; which they would not do, but on the Contrary, produce Å¿ome confuÅ¿ed Å¿light ones, if according to the Rules formerly EÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed, the vigorous Shoots were not pinch'd off Å¿hort.

The Summer SolÅ¿tice is the proper SeaÅ¿on when Orange-Trees make their Å¿trongeÅ¿t and moÅ¿t vigorous Shoot, Namely the Month of June; and 'tis then one Å¿hould be moÅ¿t InduÅ¿trious in Nipping, and taking off the falÅ¿e Shoots, and Watering them more than at other times; That is, once or twice a Week, thereby to AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t them in this firÅ¿t and greateÅ¿t Action, and to promote the continuance of it, which Å¿ometimes they Redouble conÅ¿iderably towards the end of July, and beginning of AuguÅ¿t: And therefore the Å¿ame care is to be taken in June. But if this exuberance of Second puÅ¿hing, do not appear till towards the expiration of AuguÅ¿t, or commencement of September, they are worth little: The Shoots of that SeaÅ¿on will periÅ¿h in the Green-HouÅ¿e for want of time to perfect them; and therefore it were beÅ¿t to take them off as Å¿oon as they peep; That the Sap which gave them beginning, may continue in the bodies of the Branches that bare them, and make them the Å¿tronger.

So Å¿oon as you perceive any luÅ¿ty Branch left upon a Tree Re-Cas'd, that has made no Shoot in any part of it, excepting perhaps, a Å¿ome few Å¿mall yellowiÅ¿h and trifling ones, inÅ¿tead of Å¿trong and luÅ¿ty ones; Å¿uch as was expected to break out from the extremities of thoÅ¿e Branches, and Å¿hould have Å¿erv'd to Shape the Tree: Cut them away without any Å¿cruple, even during the Pride of their Sap.
ThoÅ¿e which you leave will proÅ¿per much the better.

I am alÅ¿o bold to affirm, That 'tis impoÅ¿Å¿ible to have an Orange-Tree anÅ¿werable to the Idea which I have conceiv'd; unleÅ¿s you take off thoÅ¿e early Shoots Å¿o Å¿oon as ever they firÅ¿t begin to puÅ¿h; and eÅ¿pecially from thoÅ¿e Trees which have not as yet attain'd that goodly Head which becomes them: ThoÅ¿e Trees which are left with theÅ¿e Å¿maller Shoots on them without this diÅ¿charge, or that it be not finiÅ¿hhd, before the Flowers are paÅ¿t, may indeed produce more Flowers, but never come to be Beautiful Trees.

The firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e are moÅ¿t to be Condemn'd; foraÅ¿much as all the Branches of thoÅ¿e Trees abound with Knots and Bunches, and conÅ¿equently are full of Buggs, producing none Å¿ave a few pittiful Flowers: The others diÅ¿cover themÅ¿elves Å¿oon enough (as well as the FirÅ¿t) to Å¿ee themÅ¿elves Å¿tripp'd of theirs, whilÅ¿t they Å¿uffer'd a part of the NouriÅ¿hment to go into, and feed thoÅ¿e Branches which are to be taken away, inÅ¿tead of managing it for thoÅ¿e which are to be preÅ¿erv'd, and would become much fairer, Å¿trong, and well furniÅ¿h'd with goodly Flowers, and Å¿preading Leaves.

This pinching off the idle Shoots, does not only Contribute to the Rounding, Filling, and extending of the Head of an Orange-Tree, but likewiÅ¿e gives it all thoÅ¿e other graces and perfections 'tis capable of; It produces fairer and Å¿touter Shoots, Å¿trong and able to Å¿uÅ¿tain themÅ¿elves; adorns it with plentiful Leaves, ample and lovely Green; and enables the Tree to put forth abundance of new Shoots every Spring, and afterward to produce a Å¿ufficient quantity of goodly Fruit; and laÅ¿tly, hinders the increaÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e numerous Swarms of Buggs and Ants you Å¿ee crawling on the Heads of thoÅ¿e Trees, Å¿o extreamly Bunch'd, and full of Tufted Leaves, and conÅ¿equently preÅ¿erves them in that NeatneÅ¿s and Beauty which is Å¿o Charming.

If therefore (always Å¿uppoÅ¿ing a Commodious Green-HouÅ¿e) a little Care and InduÅ¿try inable one to maintain our Trees in this excellent plight, of Shape, Beauty, Strength and SoundneÅ¿s: Is't not evident, that it is no Å¿uch hard and difficult matter, to know what is firÅ¿t to be done to Recover, and Å¿tabliÅ¿h thoÅ¿e which happly are deficient in nothing but their Shape and Figure; being otherwiÅ¿e Vigorous and LuÅ¿ty Trees; as alÅ¿o Å¿uch as are of Shape and Figure beautiful enough; but wanting Å¿trength and health: and laÅ¿tly, to Recover thoÅ¿e, which labouring under both theÅ¿e Defects together, LanguiÅ¿h and are ready to PeriÅ¿h?

Generally, The great diÅ¿order of Orange-Trees happen to them from theÅ¿e four different CauÅ¿es: FirÅ¿t, from the In-CaÅ¿ing, which peradventure was not carefully done, or with improper Mould; or for want of Renewing in due time. Secondly, from Å¿ome defect in the Green-HouÅ¿e, its being over-Heated with Fire; or from the Cold or too much MoiÅ¿ture. Thirdly, it may proceed from Without, as by Hail, Impetuous Winds, or Å¿ome other unforeÅ¿een Accident. And LaÅ¿tly, from their being ill and unskilfully Prun'd and Cut, or perhaps too unmercifully: AlÅ¿o from over-Watering without neceÅ¿Å¿ity, or neglect of due RefreÅ¿hment during the Months of May, June, and July. TheÅ¿e are in my Opinion the principle CauÅ¿es of Orange-Trees being reduc'd many times to a miÅ¿erable Condition.

That which many Gard'ners are Å¿o afraid of, and does not a little trouble them, is, That to Remedy theÅ¿e Defects, they are often neceÅ¿Å¿itated to have recourÅ¿e to the Severity of Abating and Cutting off both the Head and Foot of their Trees: Which Operation, very few Å¿ave the skilful in theÅ¿e matters, are capable of, and all the World are ready to Condemn at firÅ¿t Å¿ight, how well Å¿oever it be perform'd: But however, we hope, the Curious, truly knowing and Experienc'd will Approve of it, and are certain that the SucceÅ¿s will JuÅ¿tifie it, though it indeed require Å¿ome time.

To Commence firÅ¿t with the Roots of a Sick Orange, or Lemon-Tree if it has long been Cas'd, Å¿o as one may reaÅ¿onably Å¿uÅ¿pect that the Roots are come to Touch the bottom of the Box, and Å¿o to receive no NouriÅ¿hment there: One is then to ReÅ¿olve without more ado to take it quite out of the CaÅ¿e, and Abate two third parts of the Clod, and withall to examine whether the Mould of the Clod be not too Light; and if Å¿o, to Water it Å¿ufficiently for three or four Hours before you lift it out; Thus the Earth being well drench'd, the Roots may adhere the faÅ¿ter to it, and you with more eaÅ¿e and aÅ¿Å¿urance take away what you judge Convenient.

This is not to be done where you find the Earth Å¿o light, exceÅ¿Å¿ive dry, and exhauÅ¿ted as to fall, and crumble away at every touch more than it Å¿hould: But in caÅ¿e it be Å¿ufficiently tenacious and conÅ¿iÅ¿tent to hold, Å¿pare the Pains of the Watering we Å¿peak of in New CaÅ¿ing. If the Trees have not been Cas'd above a Year
or Two, and have perhaps been planted too deep and low: You Å¿hould then examine in what Temper the Earth is; as whether too Å¿trong or over light: If the Latter; you muÅ¿t give them an half Re-CaÅ¿ing; That is, Å¿upply them with as much well prepared, and better condition'd Mould as you can, and be careful in the mean time that you neither Å¿hake the Tree, or lay bare its Roots, which would be very prejudicial. But if you find the Earth to be over GroÅ¿s and Stiff, or not Å¿ufficient, I hold your beÅ¿t courÅ¿e is to UncaÅ¿e it quite, and to abate part of the Clod after 'tis well Sob'd and MoiÅ¿tned, and to replace and Å¿et it in again, as already we have taught; Å¿ince in truth, all that can be done about the Head, will be of Å¿mall Advantage, unleÅ¿s you begin firÅ¿t to fecure the Foot, which is the BaÅ¿is and Foundation of all, and the Å¿ole Architect able to PreÅ¿erve both Head and all the reÅ¿t.

Having thus perform'd what is due to the Foot, your next work muÅ¿t be about the Head again, and make account that what you'l moÅ¿t Regret, are the Extremities and Tops of the Branches, to which hardly any NouriÅ¿hment for a long time has been able to arrive, and accordingly, you'l find them Chang'd and Dry'd exceedingly, either by reaÅ¿on of the diminution of the Sap it Å¿elf in the Roots, or that the Head and Branches are charg'd beyond what the Foot is able to Support: Not unlike thoÅ¿e Fountains, which cannot RiÅ¿e to their accuÅ¿tomed height, either from the failure of the Spring or SourÅ¿e, or that the Waters are too much divided and have taken Å¿ome other CourÅ¿e. In this Exigent, you muÅ¿t not only pluck away, and cut off the Tops of thoÅ¿e Branches, but do it to the purpoÅ¿e, Å¿ince your own ReaÅ¿on will tell you, that having Treated the Foot as a Sick and Crazy Member, you Å¿hould not charge it with a greater Burden than it can bear. Now Å¿uppoÅ¿ing the Tree to be in a languiÅ¿hing Condition (as by its Root appears) and that you have been oblig'd to retrench a conÅ¿iderable part of it: That is, That a great many of thoÅ¿e Agents, which wrought and endeavoured to Maintain the whole Tree, be extreamly diminiÅ¿h'd by theÅ¿e great Abatements and Amputations of the Roots, (although for the good and benefit of all) You muÅ¿t reÅ¿olve to do as much proportionably, by diminiÅ¿hing of the Head.

Moreover, as you expect your Tree Å¿hould likely put forth new Branches at the Tops of the old ones which you have Å¿hortn'd: You Å¿hould carry Å¿uch an Idea in your Mind of the Shape and Beauty you would bring it to, that no more new Branches Å¿ucceed in any place, than what may Å¿erve and contribute to that conceiv'd Idea.

Now according to this Idea one ought to be as DiÅ¿creet as Bold: DiÅ¿creet, to Cut and Prune off no more than is neceÅ¿Å¿ary; Bold, to Å¿pare no unprofitable Branches. In a word, one Å¿hould be Compleat MaÅ¿ter of the Operation, and proceed CouragiouÅ¿ly and without heÅ¿itation: He Å¿hall elÅ¿e work with a Trembling Hand, in fear of being blam'd for having been too free with his Knife, and cut too much; and by this means falling into the common and contrary Error of not Cutting enough at firÅ¿t, be at laÅ¿t reduc'd to a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of Å¿till Cutting more for two or three Years Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively, by which a great deal of Time's loÅ¿t that one Å¿hall afterwards repent of.

Not but that however Skilful and dextrous one be in Pruning, one Å¿hall now and then find Å¿ome Tops of cut Branches to die without putting forth any Shoots at all, eÅ¿pecially among the Sick and long diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed Trees; Å¿o as one Å¿hall be forc'd to cut them again lower, and that immediately as Å¿oon as ever one finds that there's nothing to be hop'd for or expected, as you'l know by a DryneÅ¿s, accompanied with a certain BlackneÅ¿s, or Å¿ome Cleft, and then you'l never be in danger of Reproach for having abated too much.

For in â¢ ine, altho' in Å¿uch like Re-CaÅ¿ing of Trees one ought to Cut a great deal, yet Å¿hould one alÅ¿o be exceedingly Cautious in Å¿paring what ought to be preferr'd; EÅ¿pecially among the greater Branches: The Å¿mall ones are not of the Å¿ame ConÅ¿equence; though by reaÅ¿on of a Å¿hew they make of Å¿ome remaining Leaves, they appear indeed as if they were of Å¿ome ConÅ¿ideration: On the Contrary, one Å¿hould not at all pity or Å¿pare 'em upon that account; for you'l find them quickly drop off after the N â¢ w CaÅ¿ing, without advancing a jot the more for your Indulgence.

But if you have been afraid to Cut theÅ¿e Å¿mall trifling Branches when you new Cas'd your Tree, be Å¿ure to do it to the purpoÅ¿e, Å¿o Å¿oon as the Leaves forÅ¿ake them; Nay, though you Å¿hould find Å¿ome pretty likely Shoots upon them, Å¿ince you are to reckon none for fair Shoots, but thoÅ¿e which are great and Å¿trong ones, and that Å¿prouting from Å¿ome good part of the Tree, Branch, or Stem, may contribute to the Beauty of its Shape: As for thoÅ¿e which you find upon the weak and feeble.
Branches of the Years before, they are to be looked on but as falÅ¿e Money, which makes a fair Å¿hew indeed, and nothing elÅ¿e.

I muÅ¿t here acquaint you, that it is not with Orange-Trees, as with other Fruits which come from the Kernel or Stone, as to what concerns all Å¿orts of Branches: For InÅ¿tance, ThoÅ¿e great Boughs which we call FalÅ¿e Wood, are commonly pernicious and hurtful to Fruit-Trees. Indeed, on whatever part we find them to grow, we ought inÅ¿tantly to make War againÅ¿t them, and Cut them off, as very Å¿eldom producing Fruit, which is the thing we principally Å¿eek from thoÅ¿e Trees, and therefore Spare and CheriÅ¿h with great Care the Å¿mall and feeble Branches: But as to the Orange-Trees, the chief thing we affect, is to have them of a beautiful and elegant Shape, that they appear full of Vigour, as well by their Leaves as the Shoots they make, without being much concerned about the Flowers, which commonly they are furniÅ¿h'd with in too great quantity: Hence it is, that we Å¿ave and Å¿pare all the great and Å¿ubÅ¿tantial Branches we can, even thoÅ¿e which in our Fruit-Trees they call Water-Bows, or FalÅ¿e-Wood; provided that both the one and the other be well plac'd: In effect, they are thoÅ¿e only which are able to put out others as fair, and as many as we have need of, and conÅ¿equently to produce large and ample Leaves, and as fair and goodly Flowers as one would deÅ¿ire.

It will not be amiÅ¿s here, that for the ConÅ¿olation of the Curious, I give them notice that the firÅ¿t Shoots which puÅ¿h out at the Tops of the old Branches of thoÅ¿e Trees that have been Re-CaÅ¿ed whilÅ¿t they were Sick: I Å¿ay, That theÅ¿e new Shoots, far from being Å¿ound and Å¿trong, are themÅ¿elves very Sick and near their end. But let not this trouble you, they commonly reÅ¿emble Water that firÅ¿t runs through the Pipe of a Fountain newly made, which comes foul and duty, as bringing along with it the filth and Å¿ullage of the Ground and Place it paÅ¿Å¿es through; neither is the Pipe clean at firÅ¿t 'til it cleanÅ¿e it Å¿elf, the pure new Water of the SourÅ¿e, aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted by the Wind, chaÅ¿es the filth before it; after which it continues to run perfectly clear. In like manner the Shoots of an Orange-Tree that are Sick, are YellowiÅ¿h and Languid, becauÅ¿e its Branches retain nothing in them Å¿ave the Dregs, and Å¿mall remainder of a Morbific and Tainted Sap, riÅ¿ing from the long DiÅ¿eas'd and Infected Roots; and therefore you cannot reaÅ¿onably expect that Å¿uch a Tree Å¿hould make any new, Å¿trong and vigorous Shoots, large and Verdant Leaves, 'til it produce new and Å¿ound Roots, by having the old ones cut away, and an application of new and Å¿ound Earth at its Re-CaÅ¿ing, with good Government and Culture. 'Tis obÅ¿ervable, that what proceeds even from the faireÅ¿t new Roots, come ordinarily at the foot, and underneath the firÅ¿t yellow Å¿ick ones; and which from the Å¿ole Effort of the Rarefaction of the Spring, have been immediately produc'd independently from the new Roots. But theÅ¿e laÅ¿t Shoots which come out below theÅ¿e, near the Body of the Tree, proceed from the Operation of the new Roots, which acting their part in their freÅ¿h and new good Earth (given them at their Re-CaÅ¿ing) prepare good and wholÅ¿om Sap, and conÅ¿equently produce fair and goodly Shoots.

Now Å¿uch newly Re-Cas'd Trees, are Å¿ometimes a great many years e'r they produce any thing, Å¿o as one may fitly compare them to Å¿ome Animals, that having lived a long time upon unwholÅ¿om Food, find it very difficult to Recover when they come to that which is better; and it Å¿eems as the Stomach, MuÅ¿cles, Bowels &c. of theÅ¿e Creatures are Å¿hrunk up by Famine and Want: So the Skin which Clothes and InveÅ¿ts the Stems and Roots (the Seat of the Principle of the Life of Orange-Trees) grows hard, and by this means, the Heat which Å¿hould Revive, Excite and Animate this Vital Spring, which puts all into Action (and Animates and Awakens the old Roots to begin to Act a new) is not able to reach them, and to Rarifie the old torpent and Å¿luggiÅ¿h Sap, and Mollifie the dry Bark, for the paÅ¿Å¿age of the new Roots to which it Å¿hould give Birth.

But albeit Å¿uch newly Cas'd Trees remain a long time without Action, as being in a manner quite Stupified, one is not yet quite to deÅ¿pair of them, Å¿o long as there's any appearance of Green in them, for I have known Å¿ome of them three or four years without putting forth Å¿o much as one Shoot, and yet afterwards do Miracles.

MoÅ¿t Å¿ort of Trees regularly do Å¿ooner put forth new Shoots than new Root (as we have Å¿hewed in our TreatiÅ¿e of Plants) but Orange and Fig-Trees Spring Å¿ooner at the Root than in the Branches, and in more abundance. One may know as to both theÅ¿e effects, that when they grow in the Roots, they produce new Shoots, of which if any dye after they have begun to Shoot, 'tis a Å¿ign that the new Root does alÅ¿o periÅ¿h, tho' it Å¿eldom happens.

'Tis likewiÅ¿e to be remembred, that if upon the old Branches of the Trees we Å¿peak of, new ones Å¿pring out in Å¿everal places, and the faireÅ¿t of them puÅ¿h in thoÅ¿e parts that are neareÅ¿t the Body of the Tree, one Å¿hould bring them as near one another as is poÅ¿Å¿ible, and abandoning all the reÅ¿t, follow and promote this Natural Vigour whereÅ¿oever it Å¿hews it Å¿elf.

I Å¿uppoÅ¿e it is not at all neceÅ¿Å¿ary to AdvertiÅ¿e you to cover over the Wounds and Scars of the Amputations you have made in thoÅ¿e Å¿trong bigger Branches or Stems, with Wax which is prepar'd; this one never fails of, and Careful Gard'ners are diligent to obÅ¿erve it: I wiÅ¿h they were as InduÅ¿trious in the reÅ¿t of what belongs to the Culture of Orange-Trees. This prepar'd Wax protects the Wound againÅ¿t the Heat and Ardour of the Sun, and is Compos'd of a very Å¿mall quantity of Oil mingled with new Yellow Bees-Wax, melted and brought to Å¿uch a temper as makes it eaÅ¿ie to be handled and Å¿pread. The Apothecaries (at Paris) commonly Å¿ell it ready made, and for the better Å¿how, Colour it with Å¿ome cheap Red, Green or Blue, &c. which is more than needs.

Having thus Å¿aid all that I think needful concerning the Re-CaÅ¿ing of Sick Orange-Trees; it remains to give Å¿ome Directions about thoÅ¿e, that being Å¿ound and Å¿trong, may have been batter'd and Å¿poil'd by Hail and Winds, or other unexpected Accident: But this operation is nothing Å¿o terrible and Å¿evere as what we have DeÅ¿crib'd a little while ago, the greateÅ¿t miÅ¿chief happening commonly among the Leaves, which the Hail may have jagg'd and mangled, whilÅ¿t the Roots (which are the moÅ¿t Important) Å¿uffer nothing which obliges one to New CaÅ¿e them. On this Accident one needs only to Strip the Leaves off, and if any Shoot be broken or bruis'd, to Cut it off beneath the place; and in caÅ¿e one finds that one Å¿ide is more broken than the other (which may Disfigure the Tree) Å¿pare not to Cut, and Trim the other unhurt Å¿ide as much, for it being a vigorous Tree (as it to be Å¿uppos'd) you will quickly Å¿ee it Recover: But if it be a Sick and LanguiÅ¿hing Tree, the MiÅ¿chance will prompt one the Å¿ooner to Re-CaÅ¿e it. So as if it have Å¿uffer'd by the Hail towards the end of May, or beginning of June (which is ordinarily the moÅ¿t dangerous SeaÅ¿on) one Å¿hould go about it immediately with a conÅ¿iderable Retrenchment of Branches, but if the Hail have Å¿par'd it 'til the end of July, 'twill be Å¿ufficient to Prune, and Cut off thoÅ¿e Leaves and Branches that have been Å¿o Å¿poil'd.

div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.p: Directions for the Carrying and TranÅ¿porting of Orange-Trees, and how to place them when they are brought out of the Green-HouÅ¿e, and at what SeaÅ¿on beÅ¿t: What is to be done both at their carrying in and bringing out, and whilÅ¿t they are Å¿hut up. LaÅ¿tly, Of the Ornament they will afford whilÅ¿t they Å¿tand in the Green-HouÅ¿e.

div.p: THE Title of this Chapter is not Å¿o long, as the Matter and Subject of it will be Å¿uccinct and Å¿hort: Not but that one might perplex it with Å¿ome Impertinent difficulties; As whether I Å¿hould firÅ¿t begin to Å¿peak of what were to be done at the Bringing out the Orange-Tree, or at their Carrying into the Green-HouÅ¿e-Since the Bringing of them out, Å¿uppoÅ¿es they firÅ¿t were Carried in; and their being Carried in, that whether one had them by SucceÅ¿Å¿ion, or New PurchaÅ¿e and AcquiÅ¿ition, they already had been Å¿et Abroad, and afterwards brought In: Somewhat like that Probleme, whether were FirÅ¿t, the Egg or the Chick? But as I conceive the Point is of no very great Importance, I Å¿hall leave it to the DeciÅ¿ion of thoÅ¿e who are at LeiÅ¿ure, and would make themÅ¿elves Merry.

Returning then to my Subject and Å¿uppoÅ¿ing, that as to the Removing and TranÅ¿porting CaÅ¿es and Boxes of the Middle and Å¿maller Size, every body knows 'tis done by Wheel-Barrows, or Å¿trong Coul-Staves, which with good Hocks take hold on the Bottom of the CaÅ¿es at both Å¿ides, or elÅ¿e with Ropes put about the four Feet, to carry the Great Trees, to place them on low Truckles by the help of Lovers, and Å¿o draw them along, either by the labour of Men or HorÅ¿es to the Stations appointed for them. This Å¿uppos'd, I Å¿ay to the other part of my Contents; That as theÅ¿e Trees affect Warmth, and as from Mid-May (when we bring them forth) to Mid-October (when we Å¿hut them up) which is the whole time of their ExpoÅ¿ure, they do well enough in what place Å¿oever you Å¿et them, provided they enjoy the Sun,
at leaÅ¿t a good part of the day: So they are moÅ¿t happily plac'd if near a Wall, Wood, or Grove to protect them from the North. BeÅ¿ides, this Situation being from the end of AuguÅ¿t to the time of carrying into the Green-HouÅ¿e, is of all the reÅ¿t moÅ¿t convenient for them, as defending them from the South and WeÅ¿tern Winds, which about that SeaÅ¿on blow, and commonly diÅ¿order and exceedingly ruffle our In-Cas'd Trees: So as if one had the Convenience, it were to be wiÅ¿h'd, that after they had been expos'd to the EaÅ¿t or South, during the Months of May, June, July and AuguÅ¿t (which in effect, are the moÅ¿t favourable Situations for them at firÅ¿t bringing out of the Green-HouÅ¿e) You might afterwards expoÅ¿e them to the North till Mid-October, when it is time to carry them in. The expoÅ¿ing them to the EaÅ¿t and South, Screens the Orange-Trees from the North Winds, which are Cold, and eÅ¿pecially from the North-WeÅ¿t that blow moÅ¿t in May, and are not Å¿eldom without White FroÅ¿ts enough to Å¿poil them.

As to the Time of Carrying in, and Bringing out theÅ¿e Trees, every body knows that as they dread nothing Å¿o much as Cold, they are to be protected from that, where-ever it Invades and threatens them. Now the Nights Å¿eldom fail of being Cold and dangerous till about the Full Moon of April, or towards the Eighth, Tenth, or Twelfth of May, when you may boldly bring them forth: EÅ¿pecially if there be any appearance of Rain during that Full-Moon: But if on the Contrary, the Sharp and Cold Winds continue, have patience a while, till the Weather come to be more favourable.

Again, the Nights begin to be Cold near the fifteenth of October, which is your juÅ¿t time of Retiring them into the Green-HouÅ¿e, or at leaÅ¿t to bring them Å¿o near it, that in caÅ¿e the SeaÅ¿on prove very fair, you may Å¿uÅ¿pend the carrying them in for a few days; for as long as you find the Weather at all Inviting, it does the Orange-Trees good to enjoy the freÅ¿h Air; EÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e, whoÅ¿e Shoots grow Å¿till in Length: But as Å¿oon as ever the Wind Changing menaces Cold, haÅ¿ten them to Covert as Å¿peedily as conveniently you can.

I have been particularly Cautious at the beginning of May, not to bring them forth (as I noted) till the Full Moon of April be paÅ¿t; becauÅ¿e commonly we are till then in danger of FroÅ¿ts: And I take care that the Air begins to be very Agreeable and Temperate, eÅ¿pecially if there be Å¿hew of a warm and gentle Shower, which if it happen, I often reÅ¿olve to bring them forth before Mid-May.

This is certain, that however Å¿ome Orange-Trees give Signs, and Å¿eem (as one may Å¿ay) Impatient to be at Liberty, by the Shoots they begin to put out in the Green-HouÅ¿e, and would undoubtedly be much better abroad in the Sweet and more benigne Air, than in that which has been pent up, and is Colder by reaÅ¿on of Å¿o long abÅ¿ence of the Sun. Yet Å¿ince the FroÅ¿t but of one Å¿ingle Night, may extreamly prejudice them, parch many of their Leaves, and ruin the Tops of the tender new Shoots; I perÅ¿wade you to have a very Å¿pecial Regard to the Temper and Inclination of the SeaÅ¿on, and that rather than Hazard them, to defer their ExpoÅ¿ure, though it be a little late, than at all too Å¿oon. In a favourable Year, Warm, and Showry one may do well to bring them Å¿ooner out: But in a Dry, Cold, and Windy Year be not over-haÅ¿tly of ExpoÅ¿ing them, and even in Places that are low, you had need yet to be more Å¿crupulous, than in the higher and more Elevated: BecauÅ¿e commonly, the free Air, and the Å¿mall Breezes Å¿pring there, the FroÅ¿ts are leÅ¿s to be apprehended.

Now as a kind and gentle Shower were to be deÅ¿ired at the time of their bringing forth; above all, that their Leaves might be WaÅ¿h'd and Cleans'd from the duÅ¿t contracted in the HouÅ¿e: For the Å¿ame ReaÅ¿on, one Å¿hould be glad of Å¿uch another Shower a little before we carry them in to cleanÅ¿e them of the DuÅ¿t gotten on them Abroad. But not that I CounÅ¿el you to Retire them whilÅ¿t it actually Rains, leÅ¿t the Sob'd Leaves, Å¿hut up wet, Å¿hould Å¿oon become Å¿oul and Å¿qualid again, by the DuÅ¿t Å¿ettling on them there: However you muÅ¿t Remember to give them one plentiful Watering, Å¿o Å¿oon as you have Rang'd and Plac'd them in the HouÅ¿e, as was directed you in the Eighth Chapter, wherein we have copiouÅ¿ly Å¿poken of RefreÅ¿hments to be applied whilÅ¿t Abroad.

'Tis not very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Repeat here, That as great Care is to be taken to prevent the Cold from piercing into the Green-HouÅ¿e: So nor Å¿hould there be leÅ¿s, for the duly opening the Windows when the Sun Å¿hines; and the preÅ¿erving them likewiÅ¿e from Rats and Mice: But of this alÅ¿o, we have Å¿poken in the Chapter of the Qualifications of a good Green-HouÅ¿e.

There only now Remains to Caution, That there be Å¿ome Å¿pace left between the Green-HouÅ¿e Walk and the CaÅ¿es; as well to keep their Branches from touching the Walls and being Å¿poil'd, as for commodiouÅ¿ly paÅ¿Å¿ing to ViÅ¿it and Water the Trees from time to time if occaÅ¿ion be: Moreover, that if your Green-HouÅ¿e be a very ample one, Å¿o as to contain a double Rank of Trees, Ornamentally and with Symmetry all your other Plants (Å¿o as to leave an Alley in the middle, and enjoy a graceful Walk between them) it will be worth your ConÅ¿ideration how to do it, Å¿o as to EmbelliÅ¿h the Place with Å¿everal other VaÅ¿as, and Pots of Flowers of the SeaÅ¿on, by placing them about them, or plunging them in the Ground, which would grace and become the Front of the Door, by Å¿etting the leÅ¿Å¿er Trees and Shrubs above the Greater, and by RaiÅ¿ing alÅ¿o the Greater on Blocks as on Å¿o many PiedeÅ¿tales, Å¿o as to hide the Naked Walles (and the Blocks themÅ¿elves too) with Pots and little Boxes: Thus will the Room appear full and aboundantly FurniÅ¿hed: The Lemons, Limes, JeÅ¿Å¿amines, Myrtles, Laurel Trees, LentiÅ¿es and Å¿ome Cherry-Laurels, and a World of other Simples properly enter into the Ornament, and the variety of Foliage Rejoyces and Recreates one marvellouÅ¿ly. But for the Pome-Granate and RoÅ¿e-Laurel-Trees (looÅ¿ing their Leaves Å¿o Å¿oon) they are not at all agreeable, as neither are the Å¿mall Sharp-pointed gray Leaves of that other Shrub, which diÅ¿parage our Orange-Trees, and diÅ¿grace the reÅ¿t of the verdant Theatre.

I would likewiÅ¿e if PoÅ¿Å¿ible, that in bringing them Abroad, which were Å¿o well ranged within, they Å¿hould be Å¿et and diÅ¿pos'd in as graceful a Figure without, for the Decoration of the Place they are to Summer in; and above all, if it might be Å¿o Martial'd as agreeably to Å¿urprize the Eye, by making them appear in greater number than they really are: And now I think there has enough been Å¿aid, concerning Orange-Trees, their Flowers, Leaves, and Shoots; Let us now Å¿peak a Word or two of the Fruits, Å¿uch as are deÅ¿irable; and how long they Å¿hould hang upon the Trees and when to Gather them off?

div.head: CHAP. XII.

argument.p: Of the Fruits of Orange and Lemon Trees.

div.p:
ALL Oranges are either Sweet, Eger, or Sharp-Å¿weet; that is participating of both: The Sharp are for Sauces; the other to be eaten Raw like other Fruits. Of the firÅ¿t Form are the SweetiÅ¿h or Flats (as Å¿ome call them) not at all pleaÅ¿ant, and therefore one Å¿hould avoid having any of them, if one may chuÅ¿e: The beÅ¿t of the Sweet Oranges are thoÅ¿e of Portugal, and another of a great kind, with a fine thin Rind, which are brought from the Indies. The Å¿mall China-Oranges are alÅ¿o very agreeable. Of the ClaÅ¿s of Sharp Oranges, the Bigarad â¢
are the BeÅ¿t, the FaireÅ¿t and moÅ¿t ConÅ¿iderable. ThoÅ¿e which they call Rich-depouille, and the Common Orange-Tree, whether Grafted or Wild are all likewiÅ¿e Good.

There are Orange-Trees that bear Fruit with extraordinary groÅ¿s and thick Rinds, which have but very little Juice, and others, whoÅ¿e Skin is horny and knobb'd, as are the Bigarades: And laÅ¿tly, Å¿ome which are endued with a Sweet, thin and delicate Rind.

ThoÅ¿e goodly Oranges which one Å¿hould leave to knit, are Å¿uch as you find to grow on the Tops of the Shoots of that Year, and that are in Flower at the end of June, or Mid-July: The reÅ¿t that Å¿pring from the Shoots of the Year before, as being Subject to drop, and fall off without coming to maturity, one would reÅ¿erve but few of.
One ought Å¿eldom to leave Two together on the Top of the Å¿ame Twig, leÅ¿t they hinder one anothers growth, being alÅ¿o apt to break the Shoots on which they depend.
Such Oranges as knit in June and July, are Å¿eldom fit to be Gathered till fourteen or fifteen Months after, when they begin to turn Yellow.
The very Leaves of that they call Cedrat Orange-Tree, have the Å¿ame TaÅ¿t with the Fruit it Å¿elf, and are proper to make Limonades.
Among the Lemon-Trees and Limes, there are of different SweetneÅ¿Å¿es and TartneÅ¿s, as well as among the Orange-Trees: So is there likewiÅ¿e among the Pomcytrons.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

argument.p: Of Orange and Lemon Trees Planted Abroad in the open Ground.

div.p: SINCE it is certain that Orange, and Lemon-Trees do Naturally grow Abroad in the open Field and plain Earth in Warm and Temperate Countries; and that it is by Art alone we RaiÅ¿e and bring them up in Pots and CaÅ¿es in Climates obnoxious to Å¿evere Winters: It needs muÅ¿t follow, That theÅ¿e kind of Trees are more diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to Thrive in the FirÅ¿t way of Culture, and where their Roots have free Å¿cope and Liberty to receive abundance of NouriÅ¿hment on every Å¿ide, than by the Second and Artificial Way; where the Å¿ame Roots being Reduc'd to a Narrow CompaÅ¿s, ImpriÅ¿on'd as it were, and Surrounded with Air capable of Å¿poiling them, attain it but in very Å¿mall proportion.

In the Planting therefore and Cultivation of theÅ¿e Trees, there's no more MyÅ¿tery, than in Planting of other Fruit-Trees: All the Trouble and Difficulty is, how to protect and Å¿ecure them with Covering's during Winter; which, beÅ¿ides their being well and Å¿ubÅ¿tantially made, and Å¿o thick as the Cold cannot penetrate them, are capable of being very Ornamental on the out Å¿ide if well underÅ¿tood, and that Å¿uch as are Able, Curious and DiÅ¿cerning, take care and have the diÅ¿poÅ¿ing of them: That which we every Year Å¿ee, and Å¿o much admire at VerÅ¿ailles in the Gardens of Trianon, may Å¿erve for InÅ¿tance, and InÅ¿truction to thoÅ¿e who are able to Imitate it.

The INTRODUCTION.
