div.p: THE Å¿ame CurioÅ¿ity which made me take Notice of thoÅ¿e uÅ¿ual Faults in Gard'ning I have already DiÅ¿courÅ¿ed of, and Endeavoured to Correct, has frequently put me upon making ObÅ¿ervations upon Plants, and Engaged me in Å¿ome Natural DiÅ¿quiÅ¿itions. And now having Reduced thoÅ¿e Particular Remarks, and General ConÅ¿iderations, which were both the FirÅ¿t Ground, and the main Proof of what I here Advance into the Form of a TreatiÅ¿e, under the Title of Reflections, I think it my Duty to Communicate them to the World.

'Tis like they may not ReliÅ¿h well with Å¿ome of our New PhiloÅ¿ophers: And indeed it were an Extravagant Pretence to PleaÅ¿e every Body. However it is poÅ¿Å¿ible that among Å¿o many great Wits in this our Enlightened Age, there may be Å¿ome that may obÅ¿erve Å¿omething in them worth their Notice, and thence take occaÅ¿ion to puÅ¿h on their own Enquiries to greater Attainments, then a PerÅ¿on of my weak Abilities can Pretend to; for having carefully Employ'd Å¿o many Years in making Å¿uch ObÅ¿ervations upon the ordinary Productions of Nature, as might be Å¿ome ways Serviceable to Perfect the Art of Gard'ning, I can hardly think Å¿o very ill of my own Endeavours, as that they Å¿hould be deÅ¿piÅ¿ed by every Body as UÅ¿eleÅ¿s and InÅ¿ignificant, and that at leaÅ¿t my good Intentions Å¿hould be Å¿o Unhappy, as not to meet with Å¿ome few that may Approve of them. They will however, I preÅ¿ume, Accept of this Franc and Ingenuous Account of my ObÅ¿ervations, and Pardon the weakneÅ¿s of my Judgment and ReaÅ¿onings thereupon. And with this I Å¿hall be very well Å¿atisfied.
I will therefore begin with an Account of what Å¿tirr'd up my CurioÅ¿ity, and firÅ¿t put me upon making theÅ¿e Re â¢ lection â¢ .

div.head: CHAP. 1.

argument.p: Reflections upon the Different Condition wherein Fruit-Trees appear in thoÅ¿e two different SeaÅ¿ons of the Tear, Autumn and Spring.

div.p: IF you look upon Fruit-Trees in the latter end of Autumn, when they are diÅ¿poiled of the Ornaments of there Fruits and Leaves, and when there appears no Å¿ign of Life in them, as alÅ¿o upon Å¿uch as are newly Planted, you wou'd take them for dead Trunks, or Poles, rather than Live Trees; both of them Å¿eem to have Å¿o perfectly loÅ¿t the Principle of Vegetation, that there appears not the leaÅ¿t hopes they Å¿hould ever Recover themÅ¿elves.

But then if you look upon them again in the beginning of the Spring, when both the Old and the Young ones begin on all Å¿ides, either to BloÅ¿Å¿om or Bud, or put forth Cions, you wou'd think they were either performing a kind of ReÅ¿urrection, or that they were not really the Å¿ame we lately Å¿aw in Å¿o deplorable a Condition; and wherein we Å¿hall firÅ¿t conÅ¿ider them.

TheÅ¿e as well as many other things, wou'd doubtleÅ¿s be very Surprizing to us, if they were not common in the ordinary CourÅ¿e of Nature, and if thoÅ¿e continual Miracles were not become Å¿o familiar to us; though when a Man Å¿eriouÅ¿ly conÅ¿iders them, he cannot but be much AbaÅ¿h'd at his own Ignorance, and very deÅ¿irous by all means poÅ¿Å¿ible to find out the CauÅ¿es, and the Manner of Å¿uch Alterations.

And this Particular affords us Matter for two Nice and Weighty Enquiries: The one is, Whence this CeÅ¿Å¿ation of Action proceeds, which makes the Trees all on a Å¿udden appear Dead when really they are not? And the other is, How that Wonderful Change is Effected, which, a few Months after, puts them into the Å¿ame CourÅ¿e of Acting as before; Å¿o that the Old Trees becoming, in a very little Å¿pace, as Gay as ever, and the Young ones, as it were after their Example, Shooting out Roots at the one end, and Branches at the other, plainly Å¿hew, that, quite contrary to what they appeared, they Å¿till continued Live Trees? As alÅ¿o how they Å¿hould be always liable to the Å¿ame viciÅ¿Å¿itudes of Nature: That as Autumn and Spring make their Annual Returns, Å¿o they make our Gardens their Theatre, and as often preÅ¿ent us with new Scenes? For theÅ¿e Trees upon the firÅ¿t Nipping FroÅ¿t, Return to the very Å¿ame DeÅ¿olate Condition from which we lately Å¿aw them Recover themÅ¿elves, but as Å¿oon as ever the Severity of the Weather is over, they, as it were, Conquer and Triumph over their Enemy which had brought them Å¿o very low, and preÅ¿ent us with the Å¿ame Beauty and Agreeable Verdure wherewith they had formerly Charmed our SenÅ¿es.
Now the better to RepreÅ¿ent to others the Conceptions I have of theÅ¿e Different Appearances of Trees, I Å¿hall IlluÅ¿trate them by Plain, Vulgar and SenÅ¿ible CompariÅ¿ons.

FirÅ¿t then, I imagine an Artificial Tree, of as Å¿olid a Matter as you pleaÅ¿e, of Iron, Å¿uppoÅ¿e, or Copper, and that it Å¿tands upright, exactly reÅ¿embling a real Tree, and having Tubes or PaÅ¿Å¿ages in all parts of it, the greater for the UÅ¿e of the Trunk, and the leÅ¿Å¿er for the Branches and Roots.
I imagine further, thoÅ¿e Tubs or PaÅ¿Å¿ages filled either up to the top, or a good way, with Milk.

Things thus prepared, I Å¿uppoÅ¿e this Liquor at ReÅ¿t, and in its Natural ConÅ¿iÅ¿tencies, taking up no more Å¿pace than its ordinary Quantity requires, nor any more at one time than another; but this only Å¿o long as no External Heat comes near the Tubes. For as Å¿oon as ever the Heat of the Fire comes near either the ends, or the middle of the Tree, I perceive the Liquor begin to move, to Rarifie, as the PhiloÅ¿ophers Å¿peak, or, as we commonly Å¿ay, to Boil up, and to fill a larger Å¿pace than it did before; Å¿o that if any part of the Tubes was empty, the Liquor Å¿welling as the Heat encreaÅ¿es, fills them up; or if they were full at firÅ¿t, the Liquor diÅ¿charges it Å¿elf at the ends of the Tree. And this it does with Å¿uch force, that if it could find none, it would burÅ¿t the Tubes, and make it Å¿elf a PaÅ¿Å¿age out of a place that was not large enough to contain it.
Green Wood put in the Fire, and Å¿ending out a kind of Froth at the end as Å¿oon as ever it begins to Burn, Å¿eems to me an Ocular DemonÅ¿tration of all this.

Now 'tis certain, that if the Ejected Milky SubÅ¿tance thus Rarified be capable of becoming Å¿olid, it will produce, or rather turn into a kind of New Body, which will not give over growing Å¿o long as more of the Å¿ame Liquor Å¿hall Å¿ucceed in the room of that, which after it has been thus Heated, becomes Å¿olid; but a Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of Å¿uch Operations will produce a Continuation of Å¿uch Effects.

Now by theÅ¿e Tubes I would RepreÅ¿ent the Bark of the Trees, and by the Unmoved Liquor in them, the Condition of the Sap in Winter, when the Extremity of Cold, which fixes the Motion of the Liquids, and hinders the Natural Effects of Heat, Thickens the Sap, and renders it Å¿o Unactive, that for want of the Ordinary Influence of the Suns Heat upon it, it remains Immoveable; that is, without any Appearance of Action.

The Fire warming the Tubes, and, through them, the Liquor incloÅ¿ed in them, RepreÅ¿ents the Air and the Earth, which, being in themÅ¿elves warmed, do alÅ¿o in the very Å¿ame manner warm the real Trees.

And this I look upon as the Manner and Order of this Wonderful Operation which we Å¿ee performed every Spring. The Air is firÅ¿t Heated by the Rays of the Sun, and from it, both the Bark, and the Earth that lyes about the Roots of the Trees receive their Heat, which they immediately Communicate to every part of the Plant which they reÅ¿pectively IncloÅ¿e.

Upon this, the Sap which is DiffuÅ¿ed throghout the whole Tree but is eÅ¿pecially Lodged between the Bark and the Wood, where it chiefly operates, and where it Remained, as it were Dead all the Winter, having then no motion at all. This Sap, I Å¿ay, as Å¿oon as ever it comes to feel the Heat of the Sun in the Spring, begins firÅ¿t to move in its Place, and then to Swell and RariÅ¿y, and to require more room than it took up before; and the Hotter the Air and the Earth grows, by the EncreaÅ¿ing Heat of the Sun, the more it Rarifies and Exerts it Å¿elf towards all the Branches and Roots of the Tree, that it may get out of that Place where it finds it Å¿elf too cloÅ¿ely confin'd. And thus it begins to enter upon a Å¿tate of Action.

But this firÅ¿t Motion or Action, begins to appear at the upper End of the Tree firÅ¿t, thoÅ¿e Parts Heating firÅ¿t, as being moÅ¿t Expos'd to the Heated Air, which does nor till Å¿ome conÅ¿iderable time after, reach thoÅ¿e Parts that are fixed in the Earth and conÅ¿equently thoÅ¿e Parts being at GreateÅ¿t DiÅ¿tance from the Air, are the LaÅ¿t that are Å¿enÅ¿ible of its Heat.
But how far Å¿oever this Agitated Sap Reaches, it immediately Å¿hews what it can do, having this wonderful Quality, that it hardens, and grows Å¿olid whereÅ¿oever it makes its PaÅ¿Å¿age out.

And indeed this is that which of all others is the moÅ¿t Difficult both to UnderÅ¿tand, and to Explain, whether we take notice of the New Growths, Å¿imply ConÅ¿idered in themÅ¿elves, or their Conjunction with and AdheÅ¿ion to thoÅ¿e of the Former Year; or eÅ¿pecially the ExactneÅ¿s of the Order, and Proportion of thoÅ¿e new Productions we Å¿ee in the Extreme Parts of each Branch, where we find Leaves breaking out at the Å¿ame diÅ¿tance one from another. ThoÅ¿e of Å¿ome Plants are diametrically oppoÅ¿ite to each other, and of others, at certain diÅ¿tances one above another; And again, Å¿ome Branches are at certain diÅ¿tances Å¿o perfectly divided by Knots, that they Å¿eem to be Contiguous Bodies, rather than Continued Parts of the Å¿ame Body, as we Å¿ee in the Vine, the Fig-Tree, the Elder, &c. And in general, the Origine of Flowers and Fruits, the Difference of their Colour, TaÅ¿t, Shape, and Smell, and the variety of Leaves and Barks afford us matter of the greateÅ¿t Wonder and Admiration.

Now to give the beÅ¿t account we can of all this, let us purÅ¿ue the working of this Heated Sap as far as we are able. We have already Å¿aid, that its firÅ¿t Effects in the Spring, do uÅ¿ually diÅ¿cover themÅ¿elves in the upper Parts of the Tree, as being moÅ¿t ExpoÅ¿ed to the Air. Now thoÅ¿e Upper Parts are the Bole and the Branches, whereof the Former is more MaÅ¿Å¿ive, and the Latter Small and Tender; Upon each of which I conceive the Sap Operates after this manner.

The latter being Smaller and more Limber, and having a Finer and more Delicate Bark, are more eaÅ¿ily pierced by the Air, than thoÅ¿e that are Harder and Larger. And this is the ReaÅ¿on why thoÅ¿e Å¿maller Parts, and eÅ¿pecially the Fruit-Buds they Å¿end forth, are as it were the Fore-runners of the approaching Spring. And this appears eÅ¿pecially in Å¿uch Trees as bear Stone-Fruit, the Buds whereof are then Perfected, having begun to be Formed at the Latter end of the Fall of the Sap the foregoing Year.

And thus the firÅ¿t Action of the Sap concludes in RaiÅ¿ing the Buds, which it opens Å¿oon after, and at laÅ¿t, if the rigour of the SeaÅ¿on does not hinder, makes the Fruit to Knot in the Center of the Bud, which after it has been the Subject of the Gard'ner's Hopes and Care, is to recompenÅ¿e all his CoÅ¿t and Pains.

As for the ordinary Eyes which appear upon the Å¿maller Branches, particularly thoÅ¿e of Core-Fruit, the Sap enlarges Å¿ome of them, thoÅ¿e eÅ¿pecially that are nearer the End, where its Force is the greateÅ¿t; and entering with leÅ¿s ImpetuoÅ¿ity into thoÅ¿e that grow along the Branches, it at the Å¿ame time Å¿ends forth Leaves, and lays a Foundation for Fruit-Buds againÅ¿t the next Year; and thoÅ¿e of the laÅ¿t years Formation which it finds in any good forwardneÅ¿s, it goes on to Perfect the following Spring.

But as for the Bole and the largeÅ¿t Boughs, the firÅ¿t Action of the Sap, when the lenites is over, and it begins to grow Warm, goes no further than to enlarge Å¿uch Eyes as it finds already Formed, and to begin the Formation of New Branches, as Å¿ometimes alÅ¿o of New Fruit-Buds, tho' it has not yet received any new Å¿upply from the Roots. And this is the reaÅ¿on, that moÅ¿t of the Branches, and Trees that are newly Planted, Å¿prout out in the Spring, and Å¿hew Å¿ome Å¿igns of Life, tho' â¢ it cannot thence be certainly concluded that they are really Alive: For theÅ¿e Å¿mall Sprouts are no Å¿ure Proof that the Trees are Recovered, eÅ¿pecially at the Lower End, where the great Difficulty lies in producing a good Set of New Roots: There lies the great PreÅ¿s of the Work of Nature in Recovering the Tree, whereto are required much greater Efforts of the moving Sap, than in thoÅ¿e Parts of the Tree, that are ExpoÅ¿ed to the Air.
Let us now Å¿ee what paÅ¿Å¿es in the other Element, as Å¿oon as the Warmth of the Spring has Allay'd its Natural Cold, and the Heated Air has Imparted its Warmth to the Old Roots.

We are therefore to Imagine that, as the Sap being moved in the Bole and Branches, requires more Å¿pace than it took up before, Å¿o, being in the very Å¿ame manner moved in the Roots, neither can it be wholly Confined in them; and that as the Sap appeared firÅ¿t in the Smaller, and then in the Greater Branches: So it obÅ¿erves the very Å¿ame Method in the Roots alÅ¿o. The Å¿welling Sap breaks the Bark that contains it, and gets out at every PaÅ¿Å¿age it can poÅ¿Å¿ibly make; and then this, which as well as that above, was Liquid in the Tree, being got out, grows Hard, and aÅ¿Å¿umes the Nature and Form of Roots in the Earth, juÅ¿t as that in the Branches becomes Leaves, Fruit, New Branches, &c.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Reflections upon the Origine, and the Action of the Roots.

div.p: THus then this FirÅ¿t and Principal Part of Vegeration begins, Namely, the Producing of Roots; Concerning which we are to know that in their firÅ¿t Formation they appear White, much like Bubbles of Å¿ome Clammy Fluid, and that they continue of the Å¿ame Colour for Å¿ome days, while they are Å¿hooting out; and after that, this WhiteneÅ¿s which we may call their Native and Infant Colour) turns into a more Lively one, Å¿omething Red, which repreÅ¿ents their Riper Å¿tate: And while this laÅ¿ts, all thoÅ¿e Greater Operations of the Roots are performed. And at laÅ¿t, after a certain number of Years, Å¿ucceeds a Dusky and BlackiÅ¿h hue, which plainly Å¿hews them to be in their Declining Age; InÅ¿omuch that thoÅ¿e Roots being no longer able to perform any of their Offices, they become not only UÅ¿eleÅ¿s, but alÅ¿o Å¿o Prejudicial to the Tree, that we may fitly ReÅ¿emble them to Rotten Teeth in Animals. For as thoÅ¿e, if they be not pull'd out, Å¿erve only to Torment and DiÅ¿order the Body: Å¿o unleÅ¿s theÅ¿e Decrepit Roots be taken away, the Lower Part of the Tree will I anguiÅ¿h and Decay. And I have therefore Å¿hewn, that the taking away of theÅ¿e Old Roots is the beÅ¿t means of ReÅ¿toring a LanguiÅ¿hing Tree to its former vigour.

Now of theÅ¿e Roots that firÅ¿t Å¿pring out, Å¿ome are Weak, namely Å¿uch as are Small; and thoÅ¿e that are Thicker are alÅ¿o Stronger: And at the ends of the Former of theÅ¿e grow very Å¿mall Ones, which we commonly call Fibers. TheÅ¿e laÅ¿t Å¿eldom grow to any ConÅ¿iderable BigneÅ¿s; each Root acting in Proportion to thoÅ¿e Å¿everal Degrees of Å¿trength or weakneÅ¿s, they naturally have at their firÅ¿t Formation.
And of theÅ¿e it may be truly Å¿aid, that they Å¿erve but to very little PurpoÅ¿e, and that they are of no long Continuance, notwithÅ¿tanding all the Care and Pains that many Gard'ners take with them. But, for my part, tho' I may have Å¿ome regard to them, Å¿o long as they are in the Earth, yet when they are out, and the Trees are to be Planted anew, I cut them all quite away. And this way of Dealing with them, I endeavour to JuÅ¿tifie in another Place, where I treat more particularly of this matter.

As to thoÅ¿e Roots that Å¿prung out Large, and Strong, and Good, and took their beginning from a vigorous Principle, which they could not do, if they grew out of others, that were themÅ¿elves Small, theÅ¿e are the chief Sinews and Strength of the Tree. TheÅ¿e, as they encreaÅ¿e in Length and ThickneÅ¿s, do alÅ¿o continually prepare and Å¿upply more of Å¿uch new Matter as is proper to be Å¿ent up into the Body of the Tree, both to Produce new Growths, and alÅ¿o to Strengthen and Enlarge Å¿uch as are already Produced at the upper end of it. And to Å¿uch Roots eÅ¿pecially it is, that thoÅ¿e Trees that Thrive well are beholding for their Beauty, Bulk, and FruitfulneÅ¿s.

And here we are to ObÅ¿erve, that there are Å¿ome Trees and Plants, wherein that Sap which turns to Branches becauÅ¿e it goes out at the Upper Part of the Tree, which is ExpoÅ¿ed to the Air, would have become Roots, if that part of the Tree, where it made it's PaÅ¿Å¿age ont, had been cover'd with Earth & c'eÅ¿t ce qui s'appelle Marcoter, ou Provigner. And contrariwiÅ¿e, that Sap which in the parts under ground turns to Roots, would have been Branches, if it had come out above the Surface of the Earth. And I heartily wiÅ¿h it were as eaÅ¿ie to make Roots the Å¿ame way in other Trees, as it is in Å¿etting the Branches of Vines, Fig-Trees, Quince-Trees, Goosberry-Trees, Myrtle, and Å¿ome others, for that the Advantages that would thence accrue would be vaÅ¿t, and in a manner infinite, will eaÅ¿ily appear by a General ConÅ¿ideration, without deÅ¿cending to Particulars.

And here it may not be Improper to add, That though the Orifices which the Rarify'd Sap makes, be ordinarily either Horizontal, or on the Lower Å¿ide of the Root, yet Å¿ometimes they happen to be on the Upper Å¿ide, and inÅ¿tead of Roots, Å¿end forth Shoots, which grow up into New Trees. This ObÅ¿ervation is as certain as the former, and yet I am Å¿o far from DemonÅ¿trating to others how the different Situation of thoÅ¿e Orifices alone Å¿hould be the CauÅ¿e of Å¿uch different Effects, that I IngenuouÅ¿ly confeÅ¿s I could never find out a ReaÅ¿on Å¿ufficient to Å¿atisfie my Å¿elf therein.

But to return to the Production of the Roots, it is eaÅ¿ie to imagine how they EncreaÅ¿e in Length and ThickneÅ¿s, by comparing them to a Stream of Water, which grows longer and broader, and Å¿tronger, according as the Spring, from whence it ariÅ¿es, Å¿upplies it with a greater quantity of Water: For juÅ¿t after the Å¿ame manner, the Sap aÅ¿cending continually from the Roots to the upper parts of the Tree, is made uÅ¿e of in all thoÅ¿e New Productions we there behold.

But I could never yet think of any Material Agent, that might in the leaÅ¿t RepreÅ¿ent the manner how the Roots, thoÅ¿e eÅ¿pecially of Trees Newly Planted, do at the Å¿ame time Grow themÅ¿elves, and Convey Sap to their Trees. And if I were not afraid of DiÅ¿paraging the Glorious Nature of the Angels, I Å¿hould borrow a Parallel from them, to make my Conceptions in this Matter the better underÅ¿tood: For indeed, thoÅ¿e Spiritual Beings Act with all poÅ¿Å¿ible Perfection, from the very firÅ¿t Moment their Creation has given them an ExiÅ¿tence. And in like manner, theÅ¿e New Roots no Å¿ooner appear out of the Old ones, but they immediately enter upon Action in Å¿earching out their own NouriÅ¿hment, and by their Action, which begins as Å¿oon as ever they begin to be, they contribute towards their own EncreaÅ¿e in LargneÅ¿s and Number; and after the very Å¿ame manner they make the Tree which they Support, equally to EncreaÅ¿e in ThickneÅ¿s and Length, in number of Branches, and quantity of Fruit. And in Å¿hort, to the great AÅ¿toniÅ¿hment of him that ConÅ¿iders them, they all on a Å¿udden, and that too in the very Å¿ame Action, Effect their own, and the Good of the whole Tree.

The firÅ¿t Sett of New Roots that the Rarified Sap produces, are not only Employed in Feeding themÅ¿elves, and the Tree out of which they grow, but they alÅ¿o immediately Contribute to the Production of a Å¿econd CourÅ¿e of Roots which grow out at their ends, and are in all reÅ¿pects like themÅ¿elves, and whereby they alÅ¿o become both Larger and Stronger; and by the Joint-force of both, the whole Root of the Tree becomes Longer and better Fortify'd. And, which is yet more wonderful, this Å¿econd Range both contributes to the Feeding and Enlarging the firÅ¿t
from which they Sprang, and alÅ¿o by a continued CourÅ¿e of Acting grow bigger themÅ¿elves, and joining with the former, produce a third CourÅ¿e of little Roots, growing out of their Extremities, and Å¿o cloÅ¿ely Link'd, Interwoven, and as it were Incorporated into the two former, as that it is not poÅ¿Å¿ible to LooÅ¿e and DiÅ¿entangle them; all which three New Growths make up one Body of Roots, which is then more able to Act than it was at any time before.

And after that thoÅ¿e two former Growths have, as I may Å¿ay, given Being to this third, they both receive from it that Supply which before the firÅ¿t receiv'd from the Å¿econd; and theÅ¿e continually Enlarging themÅ¿elves by an endleÅ¿s SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of Å¿uch New Productions, and Mutually doing to, and receiving from each other thoÅ¿e good Offices that preÅ¿erve them, they alÅ¿o preÅ¿erve the Tree in all its parts Alive and Vigorous.

But after all, I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s I cannot fully Comprehend this continued Miracle of Nature in Vegetables. I Å¿ee plainly, that from the Rarefaction of the Sap the firÅ¿t Roots have their Being; but conÅ¿idering them as they Live and Mutually Act, I find it a very difficult Matter to Account for the Acting either of the firÅ¿t or Å¿econd, or any of the following Growths, Å¿o immediately after they are formed, for they cannot be Idle and Unactive one Moment after they begin to be formed Å¿ince that might make them Dye, and thereupon the whole Tree wou'd certainly Dye alÅ¿o.

And what is thus performed in the firÅ¿t Production of Roots, may be illuÅ¿trated by comparing it with the Lighting of a Torch, that will in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure help our Conception of this firÅ¿t Act of Vegitation.âThe Torch continues wholly UÅ¿eleÅ¿s and Unactive in the place that contains it, till a little Fire and Flame, apply'd to it from Å¿ome other Matter, put it into a Condition of Burning and Flaming it Self; the firÅ¿t Fire and Flame by their own Vertue and Action, encreaÅ¿ing in the Torch to which they are Communicated.

JuÅ¿t Å¿o the Tree remains Unactive, and without any Vegetative Motion in the Earth, 'til by the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Å¿omething elÅ¿e, that is, By the Efforts of Rarefactiion, its Principle of Life having made Å¿ome Å¿mall Beginnings of new Roots at the ends of thoÅ¿e old ones it had before, it at the Å¿ame time begins to perform all the Offices of a Live Tree, thoÅ¿e new Roots encreaÅ¿ing and enlarging themÅ¿elves by their own Operations.

And, as in the former CaÅ¿e, the EncreaÅ¿e of the firÅ¿t Fire and Flame proceeds from their Acting, which having melted down Å¿omething a greater quantity of the Neighbouring Matter that is proper for it to Work upon, it furniÅ¿hes both the Fire and the Flame with more Fuel, and conÅ¿equently puts both into a Condition of Acting more vigorouÅ¿ly.

After the very Å¿ame manner the firÅ¿t Root being Enliven'd by the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Rarefaction, which gave it its Being, it enlarges it Å¿elf to Å¿uch a Degree, that having got together a large quantity of new Sap, and becoming thereby Å¿tronger and better able to perform that kind of Action, it at laÅ¿t produces a great number of other Roots; by means whereof, the whole Tree becomes more Beautiful, Large and Vigorous.

We eaÅ¿ily perceive that in the Torch, the greater the Heat is the more Matter it melts down; and we obÅ¿erve alÅ¿o, that that melted Matter Å¿erves to encreaÅ¿e the Å¿ame Heat that melted it; and that the Heat thus encreaÅ¿ed has Å¿till a greater power to Subtilize the Matter upon which it Acts, and to turn it into a proportionably thinner Vapour and Exhalation, and conÅ¿equently to make a large Flame bigger; and that this Augmented Flame does again encreaÅ¿e the Heat that produc'd it: And thus we Å¿ee a Circulation of Actions and Re-actions perform'd by the Heat, the Flame, and the Fuel.

And moreover, as in the Torch the more Matter the Fire Acts upon, the clearer the Flame is; Å¿o the More and the Better Roots the Trees Å¿end forth, the larger the Branches alÅ¿o are, and the longer they are like to live.

And this is the ReaÅ¿on alÅ¿o, why Trees Å¿tanding alone have a much greater number of Roots than thoÅ¿e that are Å¿et againÅ¿t a Wall; becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e latter have Roots only on one, whereas the other have them on all Å¿ides. From whence alÅ¿o it comes to paÅ¿s, that the former do uÅ¿ually much exceed the latter, both in Height, ThickneÅ¿s and Duration.

And although the Principle of Life, which makes the Roots to Act, be at firÅ¿t the Å¿ame in both, juÅ¿t as the Fire that Lights a great Torch is the Å¿ame that Lights a little one, yet this Principle of Life Å¿eems to grow Å¿tronger in a Tree that Å¿ends forth many Roots, than in one that Å¿ends forth but a few; each Root according to
its firÅ¿t Natural Å¿trength and bigneÅ¿s, growing as it were a particular and diÅ¿tinct Agent: So that each PreÅ¿erving and Improving thoÅ¿e AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tances which it hath, and Å¿till does receive from the Principle of Life, and without which it would remain void of all manner of Action, it every day Acts more vigorouÅ¿ly, and does really encreaÅ¿e its power of Acting in proportion to its Length and ThickneÅ¿s, and according as it Multiplies it Å¿elf; which it does after the very Å¿ame manner that the firÅ¿t Fire, and the firÅ¿t Flame of a Torch grows Å¿tronger by the Å¿upply of new Fuel, which they prepare themÅ¿elves by continually encreaÅ¿ing their Heat and Light; and in both, the larger the Matter is, the greater is the Action; only with this difference, That whereas the firÅ¿t Fire, and the firÅ¿t Flame, do both periÅ¿h at the Å¿ame time that that firÅ¿t Matter which gave them Being is ConÅ¿umed, and as one may Å¿ay, Annihilated, the Tree's Principle of Life Å¿till Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿ts after it has loÅ¿t Å¿ome of its Roots. Nay, we Å¿ee that the taking Å¿ome of them away proves the moÅ¿t effectual Means of making it Grow and FlouriÅ¿h.

We muÅ¿t therefore lay down this as a certain Truth in the CourÅ¿e of Nature, That in every Plant there is a certain Principle of Life, which continuing the Rarefaction, does alÅ¿o continue both the Being and the Action of the Roots in their Formation: That 'tis this Inward Principle, which Co-operating with each of them in thoÅ¿e Offices which Nature has AÅ¿Å¿igned them, AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ts them in performing what otherwiÅ¿e it were impoÅ¿Å¿ible for them to Effect; and conÅ¿equently, that 'tis this Principle alone that gives theÅ¿e Roots a Power either to Attract, or Receive.

I Å¿hall hereafter give my Opinion in this Grand QueÅ¿tion concerning the Action of the Roots; at preÅ¿ent I Å¿hall only Å¿ay, That there are but very few Roots that are able to Act of themÅ¿elves, and when they are once Å¿ever'd from the Trees with which they were formed; I only Å¿ay Å¿ever'd; for of Roots firÅ¿t pluck'd up, and then Å¿et again, I know not whether any are able to Recover themÅ¿elves, and to Act again: And though the principal Roots of Elms, RoÅ¿e-Trees, Vines, Fig-Trees, RaspiÅ¿h-BuÅ¿hes, and Å¿ome other very Å¿prightly Shrubs, may Å¿ometimes Å¿end forth at that end which was next to the Tree from which they were Cut off, Å¿uch Sprouts as may become Elms, RoÅ¿e-Trees, Vines, &c. yet 'tis certain that this is a Privilege peculiar to themÅ¿elves, Å¿o that we cannot draw any General ConÅ¿equence from them, that the Roots of other Trees and Plants may do the Å¿ame; and upon the whole we may conclude, that there is in every Tree a certain Principle of Life which makes its Roots to Act, and that too to the utmoÅ¿t of their Power and Capacity.

We muÅ¿t alÅ¿o allow that in reÅ¿pect of this Principle of Life, as well as of the Soil, there is a vaÅ¿t difference between Trees: The Heat of the Sun being equal in it Å¿elf, does equally Heat a piece of Ground equally Good in it Å¿elf, and equally Expos'd to its Rays, as it does alÅ¿o all the Trees that are Planted in it, and yet, though they Å¿eemed all in good Condition when they were Set, Å¿ome of them produce Roots in abundance, and others none at all, but LanguiÅ¿h and Dye.

Which failure muÅ¿t ordinarily be AÅ¿cribed to the Trees themÅ¿elves, and not to the Ground, which we Å¿uppoÅ¿ed equally well Qualified, nor to the Sun which alÅ¿o Acts equally upon both It, and Them.

The Planted Trees therefore do chiefly Act by their Principle of Life, Å¿ince it is that which being Animated by the Heat, makes the old Roots Å¿end forth Young ones; to the Actings whereof the Trees are obliged for that conÅ¿tant Supply of NouriÅ¿hment which preÅ¿erves and makes them Grow. CuÅ¿tom has fix'd the Name of Sap upon this NouriÅ¿hment, and therefore we Å¿hall commonly call it Å¿o, as often as we Å¿hall have occaÅ¿ion to Å¿peak of it.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Reflections upon the Nature of Sap.

div.p:
BEfore I proceed to a cloÅ¿er DiÅ¿quiÅ¿ition about the Nature of Sap, which is the Å¿ame in Plants that Chile; or Blood are in Animals, the Water in the Bowels of the Earth being alÅ¿o the Å¿ame to Plants, that Food in the Stomach is to Animals, it may be requiÅ¿ite to obÅ¿erve, that as the Earth Å¿erves to produce, and nouriÅ¿h Vegetables, as having in it a Virtue or Principle of Fertility neceÅ¿Å¿ary for Å¿uch performances, Å¿o 'tis alÅ¿o certain that of it Å¿elf, and unleÅ¿s it be duly moiÅ¿tened it cannot
perform thoÅ¿e Offices. JuÅ¿t as SenÃ©, which being of a Purging Nature, does not operate of it Å¿elf, but by means of a proportionate quantity of Water, or Å¿ome other Liquid, wherein it is Infus'd, and to which, by that InfuÅ¿ion, it Communicates its Vertue. But as this Purging Quality becomes altogether Ineffectual, if the proportion of Water be too great for the Quantity of the SenÃ©, Å¿o alÅ¿o the Earth becomes Unfruitful, and Rots Fruit-Trees, as well as moÅ¿t other Plants, if it happens to be Drench'd or Cover'd with Water. It requires Å¿ome, but not too much MoiÅ¿ture; and too much Wet is altogether as Prejudicial, as too much Drought.

Now whereÅ¿oever the Earth is too Dry, it is neceÅ¿Å¿arily Barren: and therefore all the Ground we commonly call Good, is attended with all Å¿orts of MoiÅ¿ture, which indeed is nothing elÅ¿e but real Water diffus'd through every part of the Ground. And this Water comes for the moÅ¿t part, either from Rain, or Snow, or Rivers, or Springs, and Å¿ometimes by Artificial Conveyances; which Water having by its Weight Å¿unk into, and diffuÅ¿ed it Å¿elf through all parts of the Earth, it becomes, as PhiloÅ¿ophers Å¿peak, Impregnated with the Nitre, or Fertile Salt of that Earth: Or, to uÅ¿e the Gard'ners Term, it becomes Å¿o far SeaÅ¿oned with the Quality of that Earth, as to aÅ¿Å¿ume its TaÅ¿te, whatÅ¿oever it be, which it Communicates to thoÅ¿e Plants it NouriÅ¿hes. The Truth of which ObÅ¿ervation is Å¿ufficiently Evinced from Experience in Wines, and Å¿everal Å¿orts of Fruits, which receive different TaÅ¿tes from the different Soils they Grow in.

One part of this Impregnated MoiÅ¿ture, whether its Tincture be perceiveable by SenÅ¿e or not, Å¿erves to make Minerals and Fountains: And another part, as we have juÅ¿t now Å¿aid, goes to the Production and NouriÅ¿hment of a ThouÅ¿and Å¿everal Å¿orts of Trees, and Plants, and Vegetables; it being in every Earth of Å¿uch a SubÅ¿tance as may Å¿erve for the uÅ¿e of all Å¿orts of Trees and Plants, and is, in effect, nothing elÅ¿e but that Water we are going to Treat of, though it immediately appear very different both in Colour, TaÅ¿te, and ConÅ¿iÅ¿tency, as Å¿oon as ever it has, by the Action of the Roots, enter'd into the Å¿everal Plants, and that it ceaÅ¿es to be pure and Å¿imple Water.

For whereas it was at firÅ¿t Liquid, before it enter'd the Roots, it becomes in time, and by degrees, in a manner perfectly Hard, and as it were MetamorphoÅ¿ed into the Nature either of Fruits or Leaves, of Wood or Bark, or Pith; and there makes a Body more or leÅ¿s Hard, according as it happens to be diÅ¿pos'd of into the Å¿everal Fruits, Trees, or Plants.

And hence perhaps it comes that the Simple Dew, which is Å¿prinkled upon certain Flowers in Gardens and Meadows, becomes changed, part into Honey, part into Wax, and part into little thin Coats, as Å¿oon as the Bees have with their uÅ¿ual InduÅ¿try Collected, and by the InÅ¿tinct and Direction of Nature, Wrought and Separated it.

Now this Hardening of the Sap is not to be AÅ¿cribed to any Quality peculiar to it Å¿elf, Å¿ince 'tis no more than what the Skin in Fruits, and the Bark in Trees may be Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to effect, for both of them are in all likelihood made up of the groÅ¿Å¿er parts of the Sap; and it is eaÅ¿ie to imagine that they may have a Power of Communicating their own DenÅ¿ity to the Sap, when their inward parts come to be Bathed and Drench'd in it. As for inÅ¿tance, When the Sap paÅ¿Å¿ing between the Bark and the Tree, not only AÅ¿cends, by a kind of Filtration, up to the top of the Plant, but alÅ¿o, if it be in a Å¿ufficient Quantity, riÅ¿es even above the top, and adds Å¿omething to the length of it.

This therefore muÅ¿t be AÅ¿cribed to the Vertue of the Bark, which in Trees makes this Sap Å¿o Hard and Durable, that it cannot be DiÅ¿Å¿olv'd, but by a long Continuance in Å¿ome Corroding or Putrifying MoiÅ¿ture; and to the Skins, which in Fruits makes only a kind of Congelation, and Å¿uch a one as is eaÅ¿ily DiÅ¿Å¿olv'd, either by Chewing, or any Å¿ort of Heat, or by violent BruiÅ¿ing.

Common Salt apply'd to all the Å¿ides of a VeÅ¿Å¿el full of Liquor, and then encompaÅ¿Å¿ed with Ice, has altogether the Å¿ame Vertue of Congealing the Liquor in the VeÅ¿Å¿el. And thus the InduÅ¿try of PerÅ¿ons of Qualities Servants furniÅ¿h them in the Heat of Summer with Å¿everal Å¿orts of Artificial Snows, and delightful Coolers.

But after all, there remains one very great Difficulty, How both the Skin, and the Bark themÅ¿elves grow Hard, and how they afterwards encreaÅ¿e and enlarge themÅ¿elves. This, I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s, paÅ¿Å¿es my Skill, as indeed do moÅ¿t other things in the whole CourÅ¿e of Vegetation.

Neither is this all, namely, That the Water being made Sap by the Action of the Roots, turns by degrees into a Å¿olid Body, but it alÅ¿o undergoes Å¿everal other Changes
which are no leÅ¿s Wonderful than the former: For one part of it grows Stinking, as when it is to make an Onion, a Leek, Wormwood, &c. Another part becomes Odoriferous, viz. In the formation of Jonquille Balm JaÅ¿Å¿imen, &c. 'tis ranck PoyÅ¿on in Aconit and Hemlock, and an Antidote in the Antorat and Rhubarb; it becomes of a bitter TaÅ¿te, and a viÅ¿cous ConÅ¿iÅ¿tency in the Branches of Stone-Fruit-Trees, and thinner, but clammy withal, in Fig-Trees and Jitimales. It is of an Oily Nature in the Indian-C â¢ eÅ¿nut, Clear and Sweet in the Mulberry, in Core-Fruit, the Sallow, and eÅ¿pecially in the Vine wherein it becomes Wine, which may very well be look'd upon as the great MaÅ¿ter-Piece both of Nature and Art, begun by the one, and perfected by the other.

But above all, How can a Man chooÅ¿e but be wonderfully aÅ¿toniÅ¿h'd when he ConÅ¿iders how that which is nothing elÅ¿e but a Å¿weetiÅ¿h, Å¿imple, and harmleÅ¿s Juice, when it comes firÅ¿t to be Lodg'd in the Å¿everal Cells of the Grape, Å¿hou'd, when it is out, make Å¿o Rich, Å¿o Strong, and Å¿o Noble a Liquor.

'Tis Å¿trange indeed that this Å¿imple Juice, upon its paÅ¿Å¿age out of thoÅ¿e Natural Cells (where it firÅ¿t Contracted Å¿uch an extream Å¿harpneÅ¿s, and then by degrees became Mellow by the Heat of the Sun, which manag'd the whole proceÅ¿s of the Ripening) being in a great quantity Collected and Shut up in a VeÅ¿Å¿el, Å¿hou'd paÅ¿s Å¿uch a wonderful Change as makes it the Delight of Mankind; for no Å¿ooner is it in the VeÅ¿Å¿el than it begins to Ferment, and to Boil up, juÅ¿t as if its parts were forced up by the Heat of an External Fire; and by the violence of this Natural Agitation it Å¿o Purges it Å¿elf, and comes to Å¿uch a Perfection, as we Å¿hou'd certainly judge ImpoÅ¿Å¿ible, if we were not Convinc'd by Experience.

But beÅ¿ides all this we are to obÅ¿erve, That this Sap which in the Stocks of Å¿uch Trees, for InÅ¿tance, as bear Core-Fruit, is InÅ¿ipid, and the very Å¿ame in all Å¿orts of Å¿uch Trees, becomes of a quite different TaÅ¿te in the Å¿everal Fruits which each of thoÅ¿e Trees do reÅ¿pectively bear. It has a Flavour in Å¿ome which it has not in others; it has a Sweet and SugariÅ¿h TaÅ¿te in the Bergamot-Pear and Bon-Chretien, and an Eager and HarÅ¿h one in the Franc-real and Angober, &c. And that which in the Quince-Tree naturally produces a Hard, Sharp, and UnpleaÅ¿ant Fruit, if it go out at one Å¿ide of the Tree into a Graff of a Butter-Pear, or Ambrette, will produce a Sweet Mellow Fruit, and at the other into an Amadote, or Robin, and the great Musk, a WateriÅ¿h and well Scented Fruit, the different Graffs in Å¿ome Trees managing and altering the Sap that comes from the Roots, much after the Å¿ame manner as in Water-works the InÅ¿truments do the Water that comes from the elevated Source, the Water of each of thoÅ¿e Artificial Fountains being Naturally alike diÅ¿pos'd to RepreÅ¿ent any Figure whatÅ¿oever, of a Drinking-GlaÅ¿s, for inÅ¿tance, a Crown, Flower-de-Liz, &c. according to the Difference of the InÅ¿truments, upon the opening whereof, it being forced out by its own Weight, riÅ¿es up in various forms.
After the Å¿ame manner the Sap in the Stoek of a Quince-Tree, being equally diÅ¿pos'd to make any kind of Fruit, is by means of the Graffs determin'd to this or that Å¿ort in particular.
And the particular Alterations which the Sap undergoes by reaÅ¿on of the difference of the Trees it enters, are no leÅ¿s Wonderful than Infinite.

The Juggler, who of Simple Water which he Drinks Vomits up Å¿o many Å¿everal Å¿orts of Water, all differing in Colour, TaÅ¿te, and Smell, performs by Art what nearly reÅ¿embles the Working of Nature in thoÅ¿e Stocks whereon the Å¿lips of Å¿everal Trees are Graffed.

Now of this Sap, which may properly be Å¿aid to be nothing elÅ¿e but Water prepar'd by the Roots, Å¿ome part may indeed enter into the very Body of the Tree for its Support, as I have already Å¿aid; but the greateÅ¿t part of it goes up, chiefly between the Bark and the Wood, either to make Å¿ome new Addition in the Height or ThickneÅ¿s of the Tree it Å¿elf, or to produce Leaves, Flowers, Fruits, &c.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: Reflections upon the PaÅ¿Å¿age of the Sap.

div.p: THE Arguments we have to prove that the Sap aÅ¿cends principally between the Bark and the Tree, are grounded upon a vaÅ¿t number of undeniable Experiments; whereof the firÅ¿t is that of Graffs. Now it is certain that theÅ¿e Graffs are not rightly apply'd, but between the Wood and the Bark of the Tree; and that the Experiment wou'd not Å¿ucceed, unleÅ¿s the Slip, or little Branch, that is to be Engraffed, have its Bark likewiÅ¿e; and that they be Å¿o exactly plac'd one againÅ¿t the other, that the aÅ¿cending Sap may paÅ¿s under the Bark of the Graff.

There is only the Vine that is Graffed without Å¿uch an exact fitting of the Barks; and indeed, to Å¿peak properly, it has no Bark; for the Body of it being Å¿o Porous, that the Sap aÅ¿cends in great quantity both athwart, and into every part, as well of the Bole as the Branches, it Å¿eems to Suck in in the Spring, more NouriÅ¿hment than any other Plant we know of; and has alÅ¿o a power of DigeÅ¿ting it; inÅ¿omuch that upon its iÅ¿Å¿uing out of the Stock, which it eaÅ¿ily does by any the leaÅ¿t InciÅ¿ â¢ on you can make in it, it will keep a long time without Corrupting, being in that very different from the Sap of Stone-Fruit-Trees, which will not keep much longer out of its Tree than the Blood of Animals out of their Bodies, but turns to Slime and Putrefaction, as Å¿oon as it is out of its Natural VeÅ¿Å¿els.

There is, I Å¿ay, no Plant, but only the Vine, that can be Graffed by a Å¿imple InciÅ¿ion into the Body of another Plant, without an exact fitting of the Barks to each other, nor indeed is a Vine-Å¿lip capable of being Å¿o juÅ¿tly Adapted. 'Tis true indeed all other Trees might be Graffed the Å¿ame way as the Vine is, if in them as in the Vine, the Sap paÅ¿s'd up the Bole in Å¿uch a quantity as were Å¿ufficient to join and incorporate the Graff into the Tree, which it does not.

Hence alÅ¿o it comes that as the Sap never paÅ¿Å¿es out of Å¿uch new Branches in any part of the Å¿ides of the Tree as are without Bark, Å¿o neither will it ever paÅ¿s out of the middle of the Bole when the upper part of the Tree is cut of, or of the Branches that are crop'd, or of any Stock when the Tree is cut down; whereas ordinarily about the end of any Å¿uch cut Tree or Branch having Bark, that being the place whither all the Sap that was prepar'd in the Root chiefly directs its courÅ¿e, it there forms a great number of Branches which break through the Bark, and in their formation faÅ¿ten upon that part of the Tree which is neareÅ¿t the Breach they have made in the Bark; though theÅ¿e Branches are not near Å¿o firmly united to the Tree, as thoÅ¿e are to an old Branch which the Sap produces at the end of it.

The Å¿econd Argument to prove that a great part of the Sap paÅ¿Å¿es up between the Wood and the Bark, may be taken from the quantity of Water which goes out at the ends of a piece of Wood while it is in burning; and eÅ¿pecially if you burn it Å¿oon after it has been cut off from the Stock that nouriÅ¿hed it, for this Liquor iÅ¿Å¿uing out like a whitiÅ¿h Froth, and bubling out from between the Wood and Bark, falls down and turns to perfect Water.

From whence I conclude, that this is nothing elÅ¿e but the diÅ¿Å¿olving of the Å¿ame Sap, which having paÅ¿Å¿ed through the Roots, was formerly the Nutriment of the Tree, differing now from what it was then only in this, that whereas the MoiÅ¿ture upon its entrance into the Roots, was by the acting of the Roots render'd capable of aÅ¿Å¿uming the Nature and Quality of Å¿uch Sap as was proper for Å¿uch or Å¿uch Trees, becomes of Å¿omewhat a thicker conÅ¿iÅ¿tency, when the Branch which it was to have fed and enlarg'd, is Å¿ever'd from the Live Tree to which it belong'd, or when the whole Tree is pluck'd up by the Roots. In either of theÅ¿e caÅ¿es it is Å¿o, as it were laid to Sleep, that it may be preÅ¿erv'd whole Years without any Alteraration, provided the Tree or Branch be kept in a place that is moderately warm and moiÅ¿t; inÅ¿omuch that Å¿uch a Tree or Branch coming at the Years end to be Å¿et again in a good Earth, or Graffed upon a good Stock, and to have the benefit of a warm Sun, flouriÅ¿hes as well as thoÅ¿e that were never remov'd out of the places where they firÅ¿t grew. All which is Å¿ufficiently confirmed by Experience in Trees and Graffs, we receive Å¿afe and Å¿ound from Foreign Parts; and in others, which at certain SeaÅ¿ons of the Year we Å¿end thither.

But if inÅ¿tead of Replanting this Tree, or making uÅ¿e of this Branch for a Graff, you put them into the Fire, you will Å¿ee that part of the Sap which was not turn'd into the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Tree, but only a little thicken'd for want of Action, as Å¿oon as it comes to be heated by the Fire, firÅ¿t to grow thin, and then to Rarifie it Å¿elf to Å¿uch a degree as to paÅ¿s out at the ends of the Tree or Branch in a thouÅ¿and little Sources; and that Liquor, which before its entrance into the Tree was really nothing but Water, and which afterwards Å¿uffer'd Å¿o many Alterations both in Colour and TaÅ¿te, and ConÅ¿iÅ¿tency, and other Qualities, recovers the Natural Å¿implicity it had before it enter'd the Tree, without any Remains of the Effects of thoÅ¿e great Changes it had undergone, except only a little Å¿harpneÅ¿s in the Smoak, which doubtleÅ¿s is only Accidental, and to be aÅ¿crib'd to the Fire, by which thoÅ¿e pieces of Wood are conÅ¿umed.

I know very well that 'tis not only from between the Wood and the Bark that the Fire makes this Rarified Water to paÅ¿s out, but that it does the Å¿ame alÅ¿o at the ends of all the inward parts of the Wood Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively and circularly, as it were one Lair after another; which it does according as the Heat advancing reaches by degrees, and in a circular manner, the inner parts of the Wood.

But yet this is Å¿o far from deÅ¿troying my HypotheÅ¿is, that the Sap paÅ¿Å¿es up chiefly between the Wood and the Bark, that it mightily confirms it. For every one of the inward parts of the Tree having been in their turn, next to the Bark, and conÅ¿equently each Å¿oaked in the Sap which paÅ¿Å¿ed by it, and indeed being it Å¿elf nothing elÅ¿e but Sap condenÅ¿ed, it is no Å¿trange thing to Å¿ee it in its DiÅ¿Å¿olution return to the Å¿ame Matter of which it was at firÅ¿t made. And for the further proof of this Opinion, I have two Arguments to offer, both which Å¿eem to me very Å¿trong and cogent.

The firÅ¿t is, that as it is the Sap which being for a time grown thick, and as it were cold, Å¿o Å¿trongly glues and joins the Bark to the Wood, that they are not eaÅ¿ily pull'd aÅ¿under; Å¿o upon its being heated either by the Sun, in the Spring or Summer, or by our common Fire, they become eaÅ¿ily Å¿eparable. And this is eaÅ¿ily concieveable to every one that conÅ¿iders that almoÅ¿t the very Å¿ame thing is every day done in the uÅ¿e of common Glue.

As to the Å¿econd, you need only take a view of the inÅ¿ide of the Bark, and the outÅ¿ide of the Tree, and you will percieve in both an infinite number of little Gutters or Chanels which are Å¿eparated from each other by as many little Partitions, which Å¿erve to faÅ¿ten the Bark to the Tree, and to be PaÅ¿Å¿ages for the Sap to aÅ¿cend up to the very top, both to be a continual Supply to all the Å¿everal parts of the Tree, and to add new Growths to Å¿uch Parts as are capable of Enlargement.

ObÅ¿erving all thoÅ¿e little Chanels which in every part of the Wood appear croÅ¿s-wiÅ¿e from the Pith to the Bark, like Å¿o many Å¿traight Lines drawn from the Center of a Circle to its Circumference, or the Sun as Painters uÅ¿e to draw it, and which are plainly Å¿een in cutting a Turnip through the middle, I know not whether inÅ¿tead of aÅ¿Å¿igning the Saps paÅ¿Å¿age up into the Body of the Tree through the Fibres of it, I may not as reaÅ¿onably conclude, That theÅ¿e are the real PaÅ¿Å¿ages by which the Sap (which as I have already proved is Lodged, and performs moÅ¿t of its Actions between the Wood and the Bark) is conveyed into the Body of the Tree, to refreÅ¿h and feed all the inward Parts of it, Å¿ince I cannot poÅ¿itively determine for what other UÅ¿e Nature Å¿hou'd have intended thoÅ¿e little Chanels which are made with Å¿o much ExactneÅ¿s and CurioÅ¿ity.
I have already obÅ¿erved, in Å¿peaking of the Water which becomes Sap by the Operation of the Roots, that it undergoes a great variety of Alterations in the Å¿everal Plants into which it is received.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: Reflections upon the CauÅ¿e of the Difference in Saps, and upon the Effects produced by Engraffing.

div.p:
THE Opinion of our Modern PhiloÅ¿ophers, who aÅ¿cribe the great difference that is in Saps, as well as in other Sublunary Bodies, to the difference of Pores, is indeed very Ingenious and Pretty: But for my part, I muÅ¿t own, I cannot underÅ¿tand it. I cannot imagine how a PoiÅ¿onous Juice Å¿hou'd become wholeÅ¿om, an InÅ¿ipid Sweet, or a Å¿tinking one well Å¿cented, meerly by changing its Place;
and how its being in certain Pores of Å¿uch a Figure made it one thing, and then its paÅ¿Å¿ing thence into others of another Figure, Å¿hou'd make it the quite contrary.

Yet notwithÅ¿tanding this, I Å¿hou'd make no great difficulty of agreeing with Å¿o many Ingenious PerÅ¿ons as maintain this Doctrine of Pores, if they wou'd undertake to give as good an account how the great Changes we Å¿ee in Trees by the means of Graffs, might be perform'd the Å¿ame way. I confeÅ¿s the CompariÅ¿on between this performance of Nature, and that of a Water Engine, appears very fit for their purpoÅ¿e. It appears at firÅ¿t Å¿ight to have Å¿o much of DemonÅ¿tration in it, as may perhaps Puzzle a Man, but I dare Å¿ay, can never perÅ¿wade or convince him. The Workings of Nature in the Graffs are too dark and intricate to be thereby Å¿ufficiently illuÅ¿trated; and the particulars wherein they plainly diÅ¿agree, do vaÅ¿tly exceed thoÅ¿e wherein they Å¿eem to agree, and for which the Fancy was Å¿o much Applauded, as will appear by inÅ¿iÅ¿ting upon Å¿ome particulars, and conÅ¿idering what light this way of Explication can give us therein.

The force of the Water-InÅ¿trument, the more it is uÅ¿ed, the weaker it grows, and at laÅ¿t quite Å¿pends it Å¿elf; whereas on the contrary, that of the Graff, the more it is Employ'd, the Å¿tronger it grows.

Again, each of thoÅ¿e InÅ¿truments can repreÅ¿ent but one Å¿ort of Figure, while every Graffed Slip produces a vaÅ¿t number of diÅ¿tinct Effects, and all differing from one another. As for InÅ¿tance, The Bark produces Wood, Leaves, Flowers, Fruits, &c. which Fruits do alÅ¿o differ in their Colour, Shape, TaÅ¿te, Meat and Seed, &c. Add hereto, that the Slip in producing an infinite number of other Slips, does alÅ¿o produce a like number of new InÅ¿truments for the conveyance of its Sap; a thing which our Water-Engines cannot any ways be Å¿aid to do, Å¿eeing they are incapable of Multiplying themÅ¿elves. As alÅ¿o, laÅ¿tly, That any Water-Engine will Å¿erve for all Å¿orts of Water, whereas each Slip is ReÅ¿trained and Limited to one particular Å¿ort of Fruit: ThoÅ¿e, for inÅ¿tance, of a Core-Fruit-Tree, Å¿erving only for the Production of Å¿uch Fruit, and it being impoÅ¿Å¿ible to employ thoÅ¿e of any Å¿ort of Tree in producing the Fruit of another.

And now what Convincing Arguments does this CompariÅ¿on bring along with it? And how does it make it barely poÅ¿Å¿ible, that a Å¿maller number of Pores Å¿hou'd of themÅ¿elves be able to alter the DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of a much greater number of quite contrary Pores?

But that which Å¿till adds to the Difficulty is, That the Å¿maller number of Pores in the Slip being, as I may Å¿ay, become Strangers, Weak, and in Å¿ome Å¿ort already Alter'd by its Inoculation, whereas the greater number of Pores in the Tree are, as it were, at Home, and Å¿upported by a Å¿trong and vigorous Stock, one wou'd imagine that the former Å¿hou'd Å¿ubmit to the latter, and yield to the ImpreÅ¿Å¿ions which the Å¿tronger Å¿hou'd, according to the CourÅ¿e of Nature, make upon the weaker. But here we Å¿ee the quite contrary, the Å¿tronger Å¿hamefully Å¿ubmitting, and all the Glory and Advantage on the weaker's Å¿ide; that a poor Slip pull'd from the Tree whereon it grew, and deprived of all AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance from it, which one wou'd think abÅ¿olutely NeceÅ¿Å¿ary at leaÅ¿t to preÅ¿erve it in its Specific Being, and having nothing but a little of its Native Sap, Å¿hou'd not only Live, and PreÅ¿erve its own Species, but alÅ¿o be able as it were to MaÅ¿ter that Å¿o much greater quantity of Sap with which it Mixes, That this Å¿mall Stream Å¿hou'd Å¿top the Violence of Å¿o mighty a Torrent, and keep it Å¿elf within its own narrow Bounds, instead of being hurried away by the Violence of the Current to which it is joined.

The vigorous Stock was, by the particular manner of its Action upon the Sap, which its Roots had prepared about to produce a Fruit of Å¿uch a TaÅ¿te, Colour, Figure, &c. but the Sap finding one or more Graffs in its paÅ¿Å¿age up the Tree, accommodates it Å¿elf to them, and produces both Trees and Fruits of a quite different Nature.

Thus a Quince-Tree, for Example, about to produce Quinces, which every Body knows to be a Hard, HarÅ¿h, Gritty, and UnpleaÅ¿ant Fruit, produces a vaÅ¿t number of very good and Å¿weet Pears; and an Almond-Tree, which Naturally bears only Almonds, is thus made to bear Plumbs, Apricots, &c. And all this by means of certain Slips, which being, as I may Å¿o Å¿ay, endued with a Commanding Power, and preÅ¿enting themÅ¿elves to the aÅ¿cending Sap, oblige it to paÅ¿s according to their Directions, and Subject it to all thoÅ¿e Å¿everal Alterations which we daily Å¿ee in Graffed Trees.

Now the better to comprehend how this little Graff Works, and by what Power of Nature it Å¿erves it Å¿elf Å¿o advantagiouÅ¿ly of that MaÅ¿s of Matter which were Å¿ufficient to drown and deÅ¿troy it, or at leaÅ¿t make it Å¿ubmit to it, we may not unfitly reÅ¿emble it to a weak Child, and one that is not of the Royal Blood, placed at the Head of an Army at the Å¿ame time that it is Engaged. The Army continues reÅ¿olutely to purÅ¿ue the Orders it received from its General, till the Young SucceÅ¿Å¿or coming to give New Orders, Employs its Force and Courage in the Execution of a quite contrary DeÅ¿ign. Now that which enables this New Commander, who is yet a Child, thus all on a Å¿udden to put the whole Army upon a different Enterprize, can be nothing elÅ¿e but a certain Character of MajeÅ¿ty which he carries in his PerÅ¿on, which makes the Army, how Numerous and Brave, and how Hot Å¿oever it was upon another DeÅ¿ign, at the very firÅ¿t to Acknowledge his Sovereign Authority, blindly to follow, and without any manner of Reluctancy to Execute his Orders; though perhaps it may not do Å¿o very long, no longer than till another New Commander Å¿hall get the Å¿ame Advantage over him, which he had over the firÅ¿t. All which we Å¿ee in Å¿ome Å¿ort performed by the Sap of the Graff, which after it has prevailed over that of the Tree, comes it Å¿elf to be Å¿ubject to that of another Å¿et upon it Å¿elf.

But yet after all it muÅ¿t be owned, that though there be nothing either more common or more eaÅ¿ie than Engraffing, there is nothing in the whole Production of Vegetables that is more Wonderful, or harder to be UnderÅ¿tood than it.

It Å¿hou'd Å¿eem that Nature has here placed the bounds of our CurioÅ¿ity, Dazling our Sight when it wou'd pierce any farther, thinking it Å¿ufficient we Å¿hou'd know how to apply the Agent and the Patient together, without diÅ¿covering the particular manner of that Action whereby Å¿uch Wonderful Effects are produced; and perhaps if we knew it, we Å¿hou'd not be much better Graffers than we now are without that Knowledge: And a Å¿mall Experience is Å¿ufficient to teach us both the Manner and the SucceÅ¿s of every kind of Graffs in all Å¿orts of Fruits. Let us therefore be content to make the beÅ¿t UÅ¿e we can of what we know already in this Particular, without Å¿pending time in endeavouring to advance our Knowledge further therein. Let us fix our Thoughts upon Å¿ome other Things, which may be conÅ¿ider'd with leÅ¿s Difficulty and more Advantage, and endeavour to diÅ¿cover Å¿omething that may be of uÅ¿e to us in the Better and Quicker Improvement of them.

From all that has been thus far DiÅ¿courÅ¿ed upon this Subject of Graffs, I cannot but conclude, That there muÅ¿t of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity be Å¿omething more extraordinary in all this than what can be aÅ¿cribed to the bare meeting together of certain Pores, Å¿ome of one Figure, and Å¿ome of another.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Concerning the different Effects of the Sap in Plants, and of that Opinion which Maintains the Notion of Pores.

div.p: WHEN I further obÅ¿erve that in every Tree a certain Quantity of Sap, which of it Å¿elf is equally diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to make either Wood, Leaves, Fruit, or Bark, paÅ¿Å¿es up into a Branch of a Wallnut, a Marroneer, an Orange, or Cherry-Tree; and that at certain places of thoÅ¿e Branches this Sap, after it has Å¿ent forth BloÅ¿Å¿oms, which are the firÅ¿t beginnings of the Fruit, comes promiÅ¿cuouÅ¿ly, and without diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing it Å¿elf into parts, to enter the Stalks of each of thoÅ¿e BloÅ¿Å¿oms, how Å¿mall Å¿oever they be; and immediately upon this ProgreÅ¿s of the Sap thus far, and its paÅ¿Å¿age out of the Stalk, it Å¿o dextrouÅ¿ly Å¿eparates it Å¿elf, that in a Wallnut, for InÅ¿tance, one part goes to make a Green, Tough, and Bitter Bark, another part the Shell lin'd with Films, a third to make certain Partitions exactly proportioned where the Body of the Nut is to be formed and lodged, a fourth the Skin that is to cover it; and laÅ¿tly, another part makes the Nut it Å¿elf Å¿weet, and without any thing of that bitterneÅ¿s with which 'tis encompaÅ¿Å¿ed on every Å¿ide; and from which it Å¿eems to have been Extracted.

When I likewiÅ¿e carefully conÅ¿ider all the other Å¿everal Å¿orts of Fruit, and obÅ¿erve that in the very Å¿ame manner the Sap paÅ¿Å¿ing out at the end of the Stalk divides
it Å¿elf, in order to the forming and making up of thoÅ¿e Fruits, agreeably to the diÅ¿tinct Nature of each of them, and that Å¿o variouÅ¿ly, that in Å¿ome, that part which we value moÅ¿t is without, and that which we eÅ¿teem leÅ¿s, within; as in Peaches, Cherries, Plumbs, &c. And in others the better part is within, to which the leÅ¿s uÅ¿eful part which is without Å¿erves only for a Defence and Security; as in the CheÅ¿nut, NoiÅ¿itiers, Oranges, &c. And when I alÅ¿o obÅ¿erve Å¿ome valuable Fruits, Å¿uch as Figs, Perdrigons, Peaches, &c. expoÅ¿ed to all the Injuries both of Air and Animals, without any other Defence than that of a little, thin and delicate Skin, while the CheÅ¿nut, the Wallnut, the Acron, and Hazle-Nut, &c. are Guarded with Å¿uch Prickles, Shell, and Rind.

When, I Å¿ay, I conÅ¿ider this ConÅ¿tant and Regular CourÅ¿e of Nature in each of theÅ¿e Vegetables, and wou'd explain all this by an infinite number of Pores of different Figures, I muÅ¿t own my Å¿elf quite loÅ¿t in the Contemplation, being not able to Solve any of that vaÅ¿t Crowd of Difficulties, which at the very firÅ¿t preÅ¿enting themÅ¿elves to my CurioÅ¿ity, DiÅ¿order and Confound my Thoughts.âI cannot know, for InÅ¿tance,

How, by what, where, and when are all thoÅ¿e Pores made? For 'tis evident, they did not come all ready made out of the Earth, nor were they IncloÅ¿ed in the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of that Water which the Roots make uÅ¿e of in making the Sap.

Whether they are all made at once, and Å¿eparated afterwards, or whether the firÅ¿t have a Power of making others as occaÅ¿ion Å¿hall require? For if Å¿o, they muÅ¿t be Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to produce one another in infinite SucceÅ¿Å¿ions.

And admitting this, how Å¿hall I certainly know the Original, and the place of this firÅ¿t Pore, which upon its paÅ¿Å¿ing out of this Å¿mall Stalk, is either to produce, or to find in its paÅ¿Å¿age, Å¿uch a vaÅ¿t number of others as Å¿hall be exactly fit to qualify the Sap for thoÅ¿e Å¿everal UÅ¿es, of Bark, SubÅ¿tance, Seed, Smell, and all the other Parts and Qualities of the Fruit they are to make.

Whether this Å¿mall Stalk be really the Womb where all thoÅ¿e Pores are formed, or whether it is any more than a Chanel through which they only paÅ¿s, without leaving any of their number behind, when they go to make Å¿uch fair, uÅ¿eful, delicate, and wellÅ¿cented Fruits.

How this Number of Pores Å¿o range themÅ¿elves in the Stalks of Fruits, as to make them always exactly of Å¿uch a determinate length; In Leaves, Å¿o as to make that half Leaf en caur which we find before the great Leaf in Orange-Trees: In the Wallnut and Almond, to preÅ¿erve the reÅ¿pective bigneÅ¿s of their Shells: In Plants, to obÅ¿erve the Å¿ame diÅ¿tances between the knots whereby they are at certain lengths, diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed, as in the RoÅ¿e-Tree, the Vine, the Sureau, as alÅ¿o in Corn; and to perform all this with Å¿o much exactneÅ¿s and proportion.

Furthermore when in the Months of January or February, Thirty Melon-Seeds, for Example, being Å¿et in the Å¿ame Bed, are Å¿o far from Sprouting or Growing up all together, that there is Å¿ometimes Three or Four, or Five or Six Months Å¿pace, between the firÅ¿t and the laÅ¿t.
I wou'd gladly have thoÅ¿e that will needs have Vegetation performed by a forcible bringing in of certain little Particles of Earth into the Plant, ReÅ¿olve me in theÅ¿e Particulars.
FirÅ¿t, Whether Particles thus brought in, have Pores or not? If they have, then we Å¿hall have Pores brought one into another; And then pray conÅ¿ider, whither Å¿uch a Notion as this will lead us.

Secondly, Whether the Pores are all firÅ¿t Form'd before the Seed is Set, or whether they are afterwards made by the Heat of the Bed? They cannot Å¿ay it is done the latter way; and if the former, I Demand further,
Thirdly, Whether thoÅ¿e Pores are always open and ready to receive, or they are open'd by the Heat of the Bed?
Fourthly, SuppoÅ¿ing thoÅ¿e Pores always open, I wou'd know whether they have any thing within, or Nothing?
Fifthly, Upon this SuppoÅ¿al that they are all open, I ask further, Why thoÅ¿e in one Seed do not as well, and as Å¿oon draw in theÅ¿e Earthly Particles as thoÅ¿e of another?

Sixthly, Granting this Introduction of Å¿mall Particles of Earth, How comes it to paÅ¿s that thoÅ¿e Particles, which in all things elÅ¿e appear plainly to go upward, enter into the Seed for no other end, but only that they may immediately paÅ¿s out again downwards, that Å¿o they may be turn'd into Roots?

Seventhly, I Demand whether new Pores are Formed in the Root, and the Introduced Particles come in only through thoÅ¿e new Pores, or whether they Å¿till continue to come in only through thoÅ¿e of the Seed, through which they firÅ¿t enter'd in to make their Roots?

I would alÅ¿o further know, Whether one Å¿ort of Wood be more Porous than another? I own that Å¿ome have larger Pores than others, as the Liege, for Example, than the Ebene: But I cannot conceive how one Å¿hould have more than another, Å¿ince all are made up of little Parts which come together Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively one after another.
Now if all Roots be equally Porous, how comes it that Å¿ome Act more vigorouÅ¿ly than others? The Vine, for InÅ¿tance, and the Fig-Tree, make abundantly more Roots than any other Trees.

Is it not reaÅ¿onable to aÅ¿cribe theÅ¿e Effects to a certain Principle of Action which exerts it Å¿elf more vigorouÅ¿ly in thoÅ¿e than in any other Vegetables, juÅ¿t as we Å¿ee more of vigour and Å¿prightlineÅ¿s in one Man than in another; and in one fort of Brutes than in Å¿ome of another Kind?

I would alÅ¿o fain know, whence it happens, as we Å¿ee it often does, that certain Trees newly Planted remain a long time in the Earth, Å¿ome two or three Months; nay as many Years, without any the leaÅ¿t appearance of Action: As alÅ¿o how Å¿ome Seeds continue whole Years without Sprouting?

This queÅ¿tionleÅ¿s muÅ¿t be acknowledged a matter of great Difficulty, and very ObÅ¿cure. In Å¿hort therefore, I will take it for granted, that there is more in the effecting of all this, than a meer meeting together of certain great or little Pores of different Figures. That we muÅ¿t look higher for the Original of that Vegetative Faculty, and own that Principle of Life to be neither a Free nor a CaÅ¿ual, but a NeceÅ¿Å¿ary Agent; concerning which I Å¿hall Å¿peak more at large hereafter, which by means of an External Heat, and a due Proportion of MoiÅ¿ture, is determined to Form thoÅ¿e Å¿everal Particles of Matter, Å¿ome into Skin, others into Pulp, others into Juice, Å¿ome to give the Fruit its ReliÅ¿h, and others its Smell; Å¿ome to become Seeds, others Stalks of the Fruits, and others the Wood of the Tree, &c. And it is this alÅ¿o that, by means of the Sap, which it Prepares in the Roots, makes the Trees capable of receiving an infinite variety of Alterations, juÅ¿t as the MoiÅ¿ture of the Earth makes it capable of Producing, or rather indeed of being InÅ¿trumental to the Production of Å¿o many Å¿everal Å¿orts of Plants, all different one from another.

The Living Stock of each Tree is, in effect, the Å¿ame to Graffs that the Earth is to Seeds and Plants; and in Å¿ome Å¿ort the Å¿ame that the Air is to the Different InÅ¿truments of MuÅ¿ick, or Water to the InÅ¿truments of Water-works: That is, the Sap in each of thoÅ¿e Stocks is equally diÅ¿pos'd to produce this or that Effect; and conÅ¿equently is capable of great Alterations, according to the difference of the Graffs which are Å¿et upon the Stock; between which and them, there muÅ¿t however be Å¿ome Å¿ort of Natural Agreement.âThough after all, the farther I purÅ¿ue this Enquiry, the greater Difficulties I find my Å¿elf Entangled in, and the leÅ¿s able I am to Å¿atisfy my own CurioÅ¿ity.

I Å¿hould very willingly Embrace this New Opinion, if it could not Å¿hew me all the Å¿everal Figures of thoÅ¿e Wonderful Pores, but only Teach me, how, upon occaÅ¿ion, to direct Nature to make Å¿uch Pores as were for my PurpoÅ¿e, and to hinder the Making of Å¿uch as were not. But now that there is no great likelihood that this PhiloÅ¿ophy will ever procure us Å¿uch an Advantage, Å¿ince none has yet been able to attain to it, and that notwithÅ¿tanding all that is, or can be Å¿aid, we muÅ¿t have RecourÅ¿e to Divine Providence, and AÅ¿Å¿ert that if what thoÅ¿e Gentlemen Advance be true, that every particular Kind of Fruit is of Å¿uch, or Å¿uch a TaÅ¿t, BigneÅ¿s or Shape, meerly becauÅ¿e its Pores are of Å¿uch or Å¿uch a Figure: (I Å¿ay we muÅ¿t AÅ¿Å¿ert) that 'tis the Divine Providence alone that has Ordained, that Pores of Å¿uch or Å¿uch a Figure Å¿hall certainly make Å¿uch or Å¿uch a Å¿ort of Fruit. And then Pray, what New DiÅ¿coveries has this PhiloÅ¿ophy made towards finding out of the Nature of Individual Beings? And did not the Old HypotheÅ¿is go altogether as far in Å¿earching out the firÅ¿t Workings of Providence?

But if in favour of this Opinion it be urged, That one day Lunetts and MicroÅ¿copes may poÅ¿Å¿ibly be invented, whereby theÅ¿e Pores may plainly be Å¿een and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed, and that there wants only Time and InduÅ¿try to bring all this to paÅ¿s, may it not alÅ¿o, with as good ReaÅ¿on be hoped, That the Å¿ame InÅ¿truments may Å¿erve to DiÅ¿cover the Attractive Motion of the Roots, againÅ¿t which thoÅ¿e Gentlemen Å¿o
eagerly contend? Though to Å¿peak my Mind freely, I cannot underÅ¿tand what a Company of Pores is able to effect; how each Å¿hould be joyn'd to its Fellow, Å¿o at leaÅ¿t as to make up any thing that is not it Å¿elf a Pore; what their Å¿ides are made of, and what they are joyn'd together with. I am indeed of Opinion, that in every one of the Works of Nature there are a great many of theÅ¿e Pores; as alÅ¿o, tht they are much bigger in Å¿ome Bodies than in others. But Å¿ince Pores can be nothing elÅ¿e but little Bodies, that is, Figured Cells, having no Å¿olid Matter within, and compaÅ¿s'd about with their own Å¿ides, thoÅ¿e Å¿ides muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be Å¿olid; and alÅ¿o be joyn'd together by Å¿omething elÅ¿e of a Nature different from their own. And this will engage us in Å¿uch deep Speculations, as are not leÅ¿s difficult than the Ideas of Accidents and Occult Qualities; which I think is as much as needs be Å¿aid, for 'tis no more poÅ¿Å¿ible that a ConcourÅ¿e of many Pores Å¿hould make up a Å¿olid Body, without being determined by Å¿ome other thing that is Å¿olid, than that in Arithmetic a Line of Ciphers Å¿hould make up an Effective Number, without having at the Head of it Å¿ome one of thoÅ¿e Nine Principal Characters, which CuÅ¿tom and Common ConÅ¿ent has VeÅ¿ted with a Power of Determining what each of thoÅ¿e Ciphers Å¿hall Å¿tand for in Numeration.

Their Notion, who hold that all theÅ¿e Changes can be AÅ¿crib'd to nothing elÅ¿e but Å¿uch different Qualities as the Great Author of Nature has thought good to fix in the Å¿everal kinds of Bodies, is more eaÅ¿ily conceiv'd, and better underÅ¿tood, by my weak and Å¿hallow ReaÅ¿on.

Though after all, I do not pretend MagiÅ¿terially to Determine, whither of the two Opinions has the more of Certainty and ReaÅ¿on on its Å¿ide, my BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s being only to preÅ¿ent to the World thoÅ¿e Thoughts which my Study, and the Remarks I have made upon Vegetation, have Å¿uggeÅ¿ted to me. And in this Particular I Å¿hall uÅ¿e the Å¿ame Diligence I have done in the reÅ¿t of the Book.

'Tis true, I have upon OccaÅ¿ion conÅ¿ider'd Å¿everal other Parts of the Works of Nature, and obÅ¿erv'd how the Heads of Å¿ome Å¿orts of Birds are Adorned with Tufts and Combs, whilÅ¿t others are DiÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h'd either by the Feathers, or the Make of their Bodies.

And I have alÅ¿o often Admired the Melodious and Charming Notes of the Nightingale and Canary-Bird, while thoÅ¿e of the Magpy, the Jay, and the Crow, are Å¿o harÅ¿h and ungrateful. And how wonderfully Å¿atisfied am I in my Å¿elf, when conÅ¿idering theÅ¿e, and an infinite Number of other Particulars, I ReÅ¿olve all meerly into the Good PleaÅ¿ure of the Great Author of Nature, which Ordain'd all theÅ¿e pretty Marks of DiÅ¿tinction that make up that Wonderful Harmony and Agreement in this Great Machine, the World, without ever Troubling my Å¿elf to conÅ¿ider how poÅ¿Å¿ibly, by the help of this Doctrine of Pores, all this might be well, and convincingly Accounted for.

So that Referring all this Variety we Å¿ee in Flowers, and Fruits, and Seeds, immediately to the Providence of God, I Å¿hall only add, That Å¿o Wonderful has been the Contrivance of the Great Creator in every, the Å¿malleÅ¿t piece of his Work-manÅ¿hip, as well as in thoÅ¿e great ones, the Heavens and the Earth, as Å¿hews his WiÅ¿dom and his Power to be equally Infinite.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Some further ConÅ¿iderations upon the Action of the Roots.

div.p: BUT to Return to the Roots of Plants, and to Å¿ee what UÅ¿eful InÅ¿tructions may be drawn thence for the Advancement of Husbandry, let us Å¿omething more cloÅ¿ely conÅ¿ider, whether the Roots have really any Attractive Faculty, whereby they, as the MdÅ¿araic Veins in the Body of an Animal, do, at their Extremities, Draw to them, and Suck in the Impregnated MoiÅ¿ture of the Earth, or whether like the Cover of a Pot, they only by means of their Pores, receive the Vapours and Exhalations which are continually aÅ¿cending out of the Bowels of the Earth.

Each of theÅ¿e Opinions has its Patrons and Friends; and indeed, both Å¿eem to be Supported by good and plauÅ¿ible ReaÅ¿ons. But my preÅ¿ent BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s being only to offer my own ObÅ¿ervations upon Husbandry, I Å¿hall be as ReÅ¿erv'd in giving my Judgment in this, as I have been in that other CaÅ¿e of Pores, and declare IngenuouÅ¿ly, That I am not able poÅ¿itively, to Determine in Favor either of the one, or the other.

And yet how Difficult Å¿oever it may be to Explain, or even to Conceive a clear Idea of what we call Power, or Quality in Sublunary Bodies, I cannot but own my Inclination to Approve rather of Living and Attractive Powers, than an Inanimate and LifeleÅ¿s Row and Order of Parts of Matter. And indeed it Å¿eems to me very ReaÅ¿onable, to AÅ¿Å¿ign Action to that alone which has need of it, namely, to Plants, to the end they may Attract, and Suck in Å¿uch NouriÅ¿hment, as may be NeceÅ¿Å¿ary both to PreÅ¿erve and Enlarge themÅ¿elves, and to Multiply their Species. And thence I conclude, that 'tis they that Act.

Without doubt the Earth would not grow Lank, Meagre, and Hungry, as it does, if the Plants did not Suck it juÅ¿t as Animals do their Dams; and as they do not tarry till the Milk comes to find out them, Å¿o neither do the Plants expect till the Vapours and Exhalations come and preÅ¿ent themÅ¿elves to the Pores. This MoiÅ¿tureriÅ¿es up continually out of the Bowels of all Å¿orts of Earth, though thoÅ¿e Earths do not thereby ceaÅ¿e to be Å¿till FreÅ¿h; that is, in a Condition to produce all Å¿orts of Fruits. And Å¿ince it is utterly falÅ¿e that the GoodneÅ¿s of any Rich Soil Decays, or is in the leaÅ¿t DiminiÅ¿hed by being not made uÅ¿e of in Feeding Å¿ome Å¿et Plants, it neceÅ¿Å¿arily follows, That when Å¿uch an Earth fails of its uÅ¿ual FruitfulneÅ¿s, as it Å¿ometimes does, even to perfect BarrenneÅ¿s, this Decay muÅ¿t proceed from the Activity of the Roots, which by their Attractive Motion have ExhauÅ¿ted all that Fruitful Salt which Nature had furniÅ¿hed it with. And if we obÅ¿erve how the Roots of a Plant, Å¿et in a CheÅ¿t of Earth, get out in great Numbers, at Å¿uch Holes or Crevices of the CheÅ¿t as are neareÅ¿t the Ground, that they may there Grow and Multiply, I know not whether we may not, with very good ReaÅ¿on, allow them a kind of Local Motion.

And indeed, it is for ReaÅ¿ons that Incline me to Favour this Opinion of an Attractive Power in the Roots, that I do leave but a very few Roots upon the Trees I Plant; for if I imagined that the Sap, which the Tree requires in great Abundance, did without any Action in the Vegetable, barely enter into the Roots through Å¿uch Holes, or Pores, as it found open, I Å¿hou'd certainly believe that the more old Roots I left on, the more Pores or Holes to receive the Sap I Å¿hou'd alÅ¿o leave, and that it wou'd aÅ¿cend in greater quantities into the Bodies of Å¿uch Trees, than of thoÅ¿e that had fewer Roots.

But my own Experience Å¿hews me that all this is falÅ¿e, and that a good Tree, of what Å¿ort Å¿oever, being Planted in a good Earth, with a few Roots, and reaÅ¿onably Å¿hort, Grows much better and quicker than another equally Good, and Planted at the Å¿ame time in as Rich an Earth with many long Roots.
And in this CaÅ¿e I think I may Å¿afely rely upon my own Experience, Å¿ince I herein advance nothing but upon above Thirty Years Tryal and Careful ObÅ¿ervation.

And upon the whole, I lay down this as a Å¿tanding Rule, That the more old Roots you leave upon the Tree you Plant, the fewer and the worÅ¿e the New ones will be which it Å¿ends forth; whereas the fewer you leave, provided they be good ones, and indifferently Å¿hort, the more and the better the New ones will be. And to this I chiefly AÅ¿cribe the different SucceÅ¿s we uÅ¿ually obÅ¿erve in Planting.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: ConÅ¿iderations upon the Vital Principle in Plants.

div.p:
I Lay down this as another Maxim which I think never fails, and which, having already Å¿poken Å¿omething of it, I come now more fully to Enlarge upon; Namely, That there is in every Tree and Plant a certain Principle of Life, which being AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted with all the neceÅ¿Å¿ary CircumÅ¿tances of a good Earth, due MoiÅ¿ture, a favourable Sun, &c. makes every part of the Tree or Plant Å¿o to Act, and Perform all its Offices, that they all continue in their Natural Vigour, Å¿o long as this
Vital Principle is not injured; and that as Å¿oon as it is deÅ¿troyed, the Plant immediately Dies.

But this Vital Principle is not in all Plants lodged in one and the Å¿ame place; for in Å¿ome 'tis lodged in that outward Eye of the Plant, which is the firÅ¿t that appears above Ground, and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hes it from other Plants, as in Melons, Turnips, and all Å¿orts of Annual Flowers; and this being cut off, all the reÅ¿t of the Plant immediately dies, and that without recovery.

In others 'tis Å¿eated in the Ball of the Root, as in Tulips, Jacintes, Imperiales, Anemonies, &c. And theÅ¿e Plants do not die, but when their round Root is Å¿poiled by Heat, or Cold, or Wet, or by being cut or bruiÅ¿ed; nor will the taking away the fore-mentioned Eye do them any great hurt.

In others, beÅ¿ides its principal Seat, which I Å¿hall Å¿peak of by and by, when I come to Treat of Great Trees, 'tis diffuÅ¿ed like a kind of Seed through all the remoter Parts, as is evident in the Branches of Vines, Fig-Trees, Quince-Trees, Salows, Ivy, GiroÅ¿tees, Jaunes, and in general of all Å¿orts that eaÅ¿ily admit of either Engraffing or Inoculation.

LaÅ¿tly, In others, as in all Trees, both thoÅ¿e that do, and Å¿uch as do not bear Fruit, this Vital Principle Å¿eems to be between the Bole and the Roots; for the Upper Parts may be cut off, and the Roots taken away, provided nothing be done to the very place where it is lodged, and yet the Tree be Å¿o far from being prejudiced thereby, that on the contrary this will make it Å¿end forth both more Branches, and more Roots.

Now that which gave me the greateÅ¿t Light in judging of the Seat of this Vital Principle, was the ObÅ¿ervations I made upon the Sprouting either of Almonds, or Peach-Stones, or the Seeds of Melons, Lettuces, or any other Å¿ort of Pot-herbs; that when they come once to be throughly moiÅ¿ten'd, and heated in the Earth, the SubÅ¿tance of each Å¿welling Å¿o, as not to be any longer contained within their reÅ¿pective Shells or Skins, it makes it Å¿elf a paÅ¿Å¿age out at the Å¿harpeÅ¿t part of the Shell or Seed howÅ¿oever it happen'd to lie in the Ground; and thence iÅ¿Å¿ues out firÅ¿t the beginning of a Root, white, and proportionable to the Nut, or Seed out of which is Å¿prouts. This, directing its courÅ¿e downwards, grows longer and thicker, and Å¿ends forth other Å¿mall Roots all along on every Å¿ide of it. And all this it does before any thing appears to aÅ¿cend upwards to the Å¿urface of the Earth.

But at length when the Root has Å¿o fixed and Å¿trengthen'd it Å¿elf, as to be able to Å¿upport and nouriÅ¿h the Plant, whereof it is to be the Foundation, then at the very Å¿ame place where it Å¿prung out, the Nut or Seed perfectly opens it Å¿elf, to give a paÅ¿Å¿age to the Stem, which begins its Formation exactly in the Å¿ame place with the Root; and by degrees it works it Å¿elf through all the Earth that lies upon it, and at laÅ¿t appears above Ground in a few Å¿mall Leaves, which Å¿hew both the Top of the Plant, and of what kind it is, and Å¿o grows up to its natural bigneÅ¿s.

I hold then, that there is in Plants a certain Principle of Life, and that is the very Å¿ame that PhiloÅ¿ophers call The Vegetative Soul; and that 'tis a neceÅ¿Å¿ary Agent which at certain times cannot but act, and that too Å¿ometimes after Å¿uch a manner as Men Å¿hall direct.

But to make it do Å¿o, care muÅ¿t be taken, that That part of the Plant where this Vital Principle is chiefly lodged, be perfectly Å¿ound; that the Principle it Å¿elf be moved and actuated by a juÅ¿t degree of Heat; and laÅ¿tly, that if the Plant have Roots, they be found, and Å¿et in a good Earth, duly moiÅ¿ten'd. But for the better clearing of this Particular, it may be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to obÅ¿erve theÅ¿e four Things:

FirÅ¿t, That that part of the Plant where the Vital Principle is Å¿eated be Å¿ound, and in good condition: For if it be in the leaÅ¿t Putrified or Corroded, or have Å¿uffered any thing from Cold, Drought, or any other Accident, it will receive no benefit from that Heat which Plants require, but will at beÅ¿t Thrive but very ill, and perhaps quite die away.

Secondly, That it be CheriÅ¿hed with a due and a proportionable degree of Heat, both in the the Earth, and in the Air; For Å¿ome Plants are Å¿oon Heated, and put into Action, as all Spring-Flowers in General, the Indian CheÅ¿nut, the RaÅ¿pis, the Sparagus, and moÅ¿t Kitchin-Herbs, and particularly the Oignons de Coronne Imperiale, the Tulip, and Å¿ome others; Å¿ome of which Å¿hoot out their Roots, and others their Stem, without being Å¿et in the Ground; and that too when the Power of Vegetation Å¿eems to be as it were aÅ¿leep, namely in the month of AuguÅ¿t.

And others again are of a colder Complexion, and harder to be moved; Å¿uch as the Mulberry, Yew-Å¿eeds, Sweet Charvil, &c. And therefore 'tis no wonder if
all Plants do not enter upon Action at one and the Å¿ame time, tho' the Heat both of the Earth, and of the Air, be the Å¿ame to all, and upon that ConÅ¿ideration might be Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to Influence all alike. So that it is evident, that 'tis the different Nature of the Plants that makes them quicker or Å¿lower in entring upon a Å¿tate of Action.

Thirdly, That the Action of the Vital Principle is limited and confined to certain Å¿paces of Time, which in Å¿ome Plants are much longer than in others; as in all larger Trees, and eÅ¿pecially in thoÅ¿e we commonly call for diÅ¿tinction-Å¿ake Green-Trees, Å¿uch as the Yew, the EÅ¿picias, the Holly, &c. as alÅ¿o in the Orange-Trees, In moÅ¿t of which Trees, it Å¿carcely ever gives over Acting either in Summer or Winter, provided none of thoÅ¿e four Qualifications be wanting.
