In other Plants this SeaÅ¿on of Action is much Å¿horter, and can by no means be prolonged beyond that time Nature has aÅ¿Å¿igned it, as in Lettices, PeaÅ¿e, Tulips, Anemonies, Hyacinths, &c. all which have but a very Å¿hort time of Action, and appear in a manner quite dead within a very few months after they firÅ¿t began to give any certain Å¿igns of Life.

The laÅ¿t thing I am to obÅ¿erve is, That the Roots muÅ¿t not only be Å¿ound, but alÅ¿o Å¿et in a good Earth duly moiÅ¿ten'd: For if the Roots be Damaged, either by drought, or any other way; or if being Sound, they happen to be Å¿et in an Earth that is either bad, or exhauÅ¿ted; or laÅ¿tly, if being good, it want due moiÅ¿ture: In any of theÅ¿e caÅ¿es, you will not be Å¿enÅ¿ible of any manner of Action the Plant performs.

And this is a Truth which every body knows, Å¿o that I need not Enlarge upon it. We Å¿ee daily InÅ¿tances of it, eÅ¿pecially in the Spring, in Trees both kept in CheÅ¿ts, and newly Set. For if either of theÅ¿e want moiÅ¿ture, without which they cannot Act, and conÅ¿equently grow too Hot, and Dry, they immediately Å¿eem as it were Faint, and in a dying Condition; but no Å¿ooner are they wet either with a Shower, or by the Gardiner's Hand, then you immediately obÅ¿erve in them juÅ¿t Å¿uch another Change as is made the Å¿ame way in PerÅ¿ons recovered out of a Swoon.

For as in this latter CaÅ¿e, PerÅ¿ons in a Swoon recover themÅ¿elves by receiving a little Wine, or Spirits; which Recovery is perform'd by the Nutritive Faculty, which coming to Act upon this new Supply of NouriÅ¿hment, makes uÅ¿e of it as a Remedy, and diÅ¿penÅ¿es it out of the Stomach, where it received it, to all the Parts of the Body: JuÅ¿t Å¿o when the Tree, which either in a CheÅ¿t, or newly Set, had Å¿uffered for want of Water, comes to be RefreÅ¿hed by a new Supply of Water, its Roots, and eÅ¿pecially the extreme Parts of them, being throughly moiÅ¿ten'd therewith, immediately the Vital Principle begins to act again upon the moiÅ¿ten'd Earth, and Å¿ends up a great quantity of Sap, which diÅ¿tributing it Å¿elf into all the Å¿everal Parts of the Tree, its Boughs, Leaves, Flowers, and Fruits, puts them all into the very Å¿ame condition they were in before, when for want of moiÅ¿ture the Roots gave over Acting.

And this it does, provided this CeÅ¿Å¿ation of Action be not too long, which if it be, 'twill kill the Plant; the Vital Principle being not able to preÅ¿erve it Å¿elf, if it have not always Å¿omething of moiÅ¿ture to work upon, (which moiÅ¿ture it can have no way, but by the Action of the Roots;) juÅ¿t as continual Evacuation, and long AbÅ¿tinence, prove mortal to Animals, which cannot live any conÅ¿iderable time without freÅ¿h Supplies of Food.

And 'tis likewiÅ¿e to be obÅ¿erved, That Flowers, and Fruits, and Leaves, which are all tender, and Å¿hort-lived, have much more need of conÅ¿tant Supplies of Sap to keep them alive, and to preÅ¿erve their Beauty, then the Stocks, or other Parts of the Tree, which being more Å¿olid and maÅ¿Å¿ive, will live a long time, though the Roots Å¿hould perform no Action that might any way advantage them.

We are further to note, That though the greateÅ¿t part of the Sap, that is prepared in the Roots, goes up into the upper Parts of the Tree, yet it does not equally at all times make them grow longer; Å¿ometimes it does only, and that too Å¿o as we cannot perceive it, Å¿trengthen its Parts, and enable it to Å¿end forth fairer Sie â¢ s; whereas when the Sap goes up in a greater abundance, it makes it Å¿hoot out in Length, as we often Å¿ee it does in a double Quantity, at both the SolÅ¿tices, and at the Vernal Equinox.

And in the laÅ¿t place I hold, That the Vital Principle being duly moved, and quicken'd, Å¿erves as an InÅ¿trument to Enliven, to Strengthen, and to Envigorate the Roots: So that the Strength or WeakneÅ¿s of their Action, depends wholly upon the Strength or WeakneÅ¿s of the Motion or ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion they derive from this Principle;
as alÅ¿o, That the Vigour and Activity of this Principle being not Infinite, but proportion'd to the Nature of the Tree which it is to Enliven, it communicates it Å¿elf to all the Roots that depend upon it, and which it is to Actuate, according to their Å¿everal Capacities, as being InÅ¿truments it muÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿arily make uÅ¿e of in the Performance of its Office.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.p: ConÅ¿iderations upon the Number of Roots to be left in the Planting of Trees.

div.p: FRom what has been Å¿aid, it evidently follows, that the more Numerous thoÅ¿e Roots are which depend upon that Principle, Å¿o much a leÅ¿Å¿er Å¿hare of the aforeÅ¿aid Motion and ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion does accrue to each of them in particular.

For 'tis moÅ¿t certain, that when only three or four Roots receive the whole ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion of Å¿uch a certain proportion of Vigor as might have been diÅ¿tributed to a greater Number; each, I Å¿ay, of thoÅ¿e three or four being thereby more plentifully Å¿upplied, doth conÅ¿equently become capable of producing more, than if that ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion had been divided amongÅ¿t a dozen.

It is alÅ¿o as certain, that Å¿ince this ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion can never lie uÅ¿eleÅ¿s in that part where it is received; it muÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿arily act in proportion to what it is in it Å¿elf, that is either Å¿trongly or weakly, according to its own Strength or WeakneÅ¿s. Now Å¿ince the effect of this ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion upon the Root is nothing but the Production of other Roots; if the ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion it Å¿elf be weak and feeble, Å¿uch alÅ¿o by conÅ¿equence muÅ¿t the Roots be that are produced by it.

'Tis upon this ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion that the GoodneÅ¿s and Vigour of theÅ¿e Roots, and the continuance of the whole Tree in its Beauty, do entirely depend: So that when the Roots Å¿ucceed well, and exert themÅ¿elves Å¿trongly, the Tree cannot fail of thriving both in its Trunk and Branches; as, on the contrary, if the Roots do not take well, the Tree will of neceÅ¿Å¿ity grow but very poorly.

But to proceed: Since every one that Plants in a good Soil, propoÅ¿es to himÅ¿elf the RaiÅ¿ing a Tree as Å¿oon as may be, that Å¿hall be Vigorous, and capable of being long Liv'd. He muÅ¿t take Å¿pecial Care Å¿o to order it in the Setting, as to make it in a little time put forth Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e good new Roots, Å¿ince it is from them only that he can expect the AccompliÅ¿hment of his DeÅ¿ires.

Now for the better attaining of this, it is to be conÅ¿idered, FirÅ¿t, That although there are few Trees Planted, but what have Å¿ome of theÅ¿e Roots; yet they will receive no Advantage from them, whatever their Number be, if thoÅ¿e Roots Å¿oon after they are Planted do not produce new ones.

Secondly, You muÅ¿t take notice, that it is from theÅ¿e thick and Å¿trong new-grown Roots, that Trees become fair, great, thick Leav'd, and firmly Rooted in the Ground; whereas thoÅ¿e new Roots which are Å¿mall and feeble, act but very weakly, and always diÅ¿cover the Symptoms of their Infirmity, either in the Leaves or Branches of the Trees belonging to them.

Thirdly, TheÅ¿e thick and hard new Roots Å¿hoot forth only from two Places, viz. Either from the very Body of the Tree, which rarely happens; or elÅ¿e, as is moÅ¿t uÅ¿ual, from Å¿ome other thick and Å¿trong old Roots: For, as I have obÅ¿erved before, Å¿uch Roots as are Å¿mall and feeble, can only produce others as feeble as themÅ¿elves, and therefore not likely to turn to any account.

Fourthly, You muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve, that even of thoÅ¿e old, thick, and hard Roots, from which only you are to expect Å¿uch new ones to Å¿hoot out as you deÅ¿ire, Å¿ome are much better than others. The beÅ¿t, and principally to be choÅ¿en, are thoÅ¿e of the lateÅ¿t Growth out of the foot of the Tree, and they are eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed by their Å¿mooth and reddiÅ¿h Skin from thoÅ¿e that are older, which always look black, rugged, and full of wrinkles; whereby you will preÅ¿ently diÅ¿cover them to be unfit for uÅ¿e.

Fifthly, This Å¿ort of good Roots cannot be produced, but by virtue of that ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion proceeding from the Vital Principle of the Tree; and this ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion will be Å¿o much the more Å¿trong and active, the fewer you leave of thoÅ¿e old Roots amongÅ¿t which it is to be divided.

You muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve likewiÅ¿e, that this ImpreÅ¿Å¿ion will be the more effectual, the nearer it is made to the Principle from which it proceeds. But this NearneÅ¿s is not to be Å¿trictly and abÅ¿olutely underÅ¿tood, but with Å¿uch a ReÅ¿triction, as when we Å¿ay, A good Eye can better diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h Objects which are near, than thoÅ¿e which
are remote; Å¿ince it is well obÅ¿erved by the PhiloÅ¿ophers, That all Extremes are to be avoided.

Sixthly, 'Tis to be obÅ¿erved, that theÅ¿e good new Roots by which the Trees are Å¿trongly faÅ¿ten'd in the Ground, and plentifully nouriÅ¿hed, generally Å¿hoot forth at the ends of the old Roots; provided they are not left of too great a Length, or planted above a Foot deep.

For you will find, that of theÅ¿e new Roots of the later Shoot, thoÅ¿e which grow at a greater diÅ¿tance from the Body of the Tree are generally more lively, and conÅ¿equently of greater Virtue, than thoÅ¿e that grow nearer to it; which are always obÅ¿erved to be Å¿omewhat Å¿maller than the others.

Now Å¿ince the Extremities of the old Roots muÅ¿t not be too far diÅ¿tant from the Trunk, becauÅ¿e then the Tree will not be able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the force of the Wind: It will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary to cut all of them in general Å¿omewhat Å¿horter, as their Strength or WeakneÅ¿s will permit; that is, the weaker Roots may have more cut from them, but the Å¿tronger may admit of a greater length. Taking this as a General Rule: That the Roots of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t and largeÅ¿t Trees ought not to be left above 9 or 12 Inches long; but for the weaker, it will be enough to leave Å¿ome of them 2, and to others 5 or 6 Inches at moÅ¿t.

TheÅ¿e Things being premiÅ¿ed, our Gardiner muÅ¿t remember, FirÅ¿t, That to make a Tree which is planted in a good Soil thrive well, he muÅ¿t retain thoÅ¿e Roots only which appear PromiÅ¿ing, Young, and of a Å¿ufficient BigneÅ¿s; and conÅ¿equently cut off all the Rags, and Å¿uch as we call Hairy Roots; as likewiÅ¿e all that through Age are worn out, rotten, or abandon'd by the Sap, which abandoning you may eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cover by this Sign, namely, When Å¿ome younger, larger, and fairer Roots Å¿hoo â¢ out above the old ones.

Secondly, It muÅ¿t be allowed, (which yet, as I have already hinted, is not to be Å¿trictly and literally underÅ¿tood,) that how Å¿mall Å¿oever the Number of Roots is which you retain, it will be Å¿ufficient for receiving the whole Virtue of the Tree's Vital Principle, and Å¿o become capable of producing Å¿uch new Roots as may be good and Å¿erviceable, Å¿o that oftentimes he muÅ¿t be contented with one Å¿ingle Root, if all the reÅ¿t do not prove good; Å¿ometimes he may keep 2 or 3, or 4 or 5 at moÅ¿t, all of them Å¿eparated at a due diÅ¿tance from each other: TheÅ¿e altogether make up what we call a Bed or Lay of Roots, and when they happen to be Å¿o many, muÅ¿t, in the Planting your Tree about a Foot deep, be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed Å¿o far below the Surface of the Ground, as may Å¿ecure them from being killed either by Heat, Cold, or the Stroke of a Spade, (and for this, 8 or 9 Inches will be enough) but yet not Å¿o deep as to hinder them from enjoying of the comfortable warmth of the Sun, or Å¿o much of the Earth's moiÅ¿ture as is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for their NouriÅ¿hment.

LaÅ¿tly, Let him reÅ¿t fully aÅ¿Å¿ured, that if a young Tree thus planted, with a few, and thoÅ¿e but Å¿hort Roots left upon it, do not thrive in the two firÅ¿t Years; it would certainly have Å¿ucceeded no better, though he had left it more Roots, and of greater length. So that without loÅ¿ing any more time in a fruitleÅ¿s Expectation, to which all Gardiners are extremely Å¿ubject, let him reÅ¿olve with all convenient Å¿peed according to the Directions here preÅ¿cribed, to Plant another good Tree in the room of it.

Thus I have given you the Rules for Planting, which I had propoÅ¿ed to my Å¿elf, with relation both to the Tree and the Soil; by the ObÅ¿ervation of which, the Tree will put forth good new Roots, whereby that NouriÅ¿hment is conveyed to it which cauÅ¿es it to thrive as well in the Body as Branches, and makes it continue vigorous, and every Year to bring forth plentifully both Leaves and Fruit.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: ConÅ¿iderations upon the Motion of the Sap as Å¿oon as it is Prepared in the Roots.

div.p: FOR the better IlluÅ¿tration how that NouriÅ¿hment, which in the Spring begins to enter into each Root, is at the Å¿ame inÅ¿tant of time diÅ¿tributed into the Trunk, Branches, Leaves, and Fruit of the Tree. I cannot think of any fitter or more InÅ¿tructive CompariÅ¿on than that of a Torch, which, as Å¿oon as it is lighted in the midÅ¿t of a dark Room, does in a moment, and at once, diffuÅ¿e its Light in its whole Circumference, in every place of the Room wherever it can reach.

For Sap being a Liquid, Light, and Subtil Body, which, as well as all Vapours and Exhalations, Å¿eems to participate of the Nature of Air, and conÅ¿equently to
have its Centre in the upper, rather than in the lower Parts: The ReÅ¿emblance in the Å¿ubtility of their matter, which Å¿eems to be found between Sap and Light, will, I hope, make my CompariÅ¿on allowable.

But how far Å¿oever it may hold in Å¿ome ReÅ¿pects, yet I am very Å¿enÅ¿ible there is a conÅ¿iderable difference in others. For as Light diffuÅ¿es its Å¿trongeÅ¿t emiÅ¿Å¿ions upon thoÅ¿e parts of the Air that are neareÅ¿t to the Luminous Body, which is their Source and Original CauÅ¿e, Å¿o likewiÅ¿e it grows Å¿enÅ¿ibly Weaker in the Remoter Parts, in proportion to their greater or leÅ¿Å¿er diÅ¿tance from that Source. And this is grounded upon the Order of Nature, which hath determined every Agent to a certain limited Sphere of Activity, and to Act more powerfully upon thoÅ¿e Objects that are at a ReaÅ¿onable diÅ¿tance, than upon Å¿uch as being further off, are in Å¿ome manner out of its reach.

But now on the contrary, the Sap produces its moÅ¿t conÅ¿iderable Effects, in thoÅ¿e Parts which are fartheÅ¿t diÅ¿tant from the Roots, from which it is originally deriv'd. For having a Natural tendency to raiÅ¿e it Å¿elf, with impetuoÅ¿ity to the Extremities of the Tree, which are its proper Centre; it only makes a quick and brisk PaÅ¿Å¿age through all the other Parts, which are the Channels to convey it to that Centre.

We find then, That the Sap which is prepared by the Roots in the Ground, makes its firÅ¿t Entrance in great Plenty into theÅ¿e Extremities of the Branches; the other parts of thoÅ¿e Branches, tho' nearer to the Trunk, receive no benefit from that Sap, but proportionably as they lye nearer, or farther from the Spring which produced it. The only Advantage the Lower parts of thoÅ¿e Branches can get from it, proceeds merely from the abode which that Sap, in its continual AÅ¿cent towards thoÅ¿e Extremities, is Å¿ometimes forced to make in the Neighbourhood of thoÅ¿e Lower parts. This abode happens, when that which was already come up of the firÅ¿t Sap, being not able to break out Å¿oon enough to be employed in putting forth Branches, Leaves and Fruits is a hindrance to the Attempt of that which comes after it, and conÅ¿equently Å¿topping it by the way; for a while makes it tarry at Å¿ome diÅ¿tance from thoÅ¿e extremities, till the paÅ¿Å¿age be opened for it, to iÅ¿Å¿ue out as the foregoing Sap did.

And methinks, This Å¿eems to have a great ReÅ¿emblance with what often happens in a Stream, that is Å¿topt in its deÅ¿cent by Å¿ome Dam. This Stream haÅ¿tening to its Centre beyond that Dam, runs continually toward it, with all the Å¿wiftneÅ¿s that the preÅ¿Å¿ure of its own Weight can afford it. In the mean time, all the New Water which flows every moment from the Å¿ame Spring, from whence both of them are deriv'd, Å¿triving naturally to follow the CourÅ¿e of the foregoing, which iÅ¿Å¿ued out firÅ¿t; 'tis intercepted in its paÅ¿Å¿age by that firÅ¿t, Å¿o as it cannot reach even the Dam; by reaÅ¿on that the firÅ¿t having as it were Å¿eized upon that principal PoÅ¿t, hinders it from flowing any further, juÅ¿t in the Å¿ame manner as the Dam hindred the flowing of the firÅ¿t.

From hence it comes to paÅ¿s, FirÅ¿t, That both being Å¿o Å¿topt, there is a great Conflux of Water made in a certain Tract of Land. Secondly, That thoÅ¿e parts of that Water, which are moÅ¿t diÅ¿tant from the Dam, dilate themÅ¿elves on every Å¿ide, and conÅ¿equently Wet, NouriÅ¿h, and even Drown Å¿ometimes the Plants growing on its Banks, which would have been neither Watered nor NouriÅ¿hed, could that Water inÅ¿tead of meeting with the Å¿aid Dam, have freely arrived whither its own Declivity would have carried it.

In like manner the Sap whoÅ¿e Source is in the Roots, having a natural propenÅ¿ion to RiÅ¿e up to the Extremities of the Branches, to which it tends as its own Centre, is, as we have already Å¿aid, Å¿ometimes Å¿topt far enough from its deÅ¿igned mark, by that which aÅ¿cended firÅ¿t, and which had not time enough by iÅ¿Å¿uing forth to compleat its intended Work.

If the Sap which aÅ¿cended laÅ¿t, continues never Å¿o little in the place where it is Å¿topp'd, it never fails of producing Å¿ome New Effect, which Å¿hews it has been Å¿topp'd there: for its abode is never uÅ¿eleÅ¿s wherever it be; and the Effects produced by it are theÅ¿e.

Where it is in great Plenty, as it uÅ¿ually is in the Trunk and bigger Branches, the more Active parts of it which are got neareÅ¿t to that which AÅ¿cended firÅ¿t, are prepared there in Å¿ome MeaÅ¿ure, to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t that which came up firÅ¿t, in putting forth New Branches, differing in their bigneÅ¿s and number, according to its plenty: (in what Order theÅ¿e Branches are produced, I Å¿hall explain hereafter) but that which is leÅ¿s Vigorous, doth the Å¿ame every where about it, which a Å¿mall quantity of Sap appears to do in Branches of a leÅ¿Å¿er Size; Viz. Both of them Form
thoÅ¿e Protuberant and Round Eyes which meet near their PaÅ¿Å¿age, and Place of their abode, and by that means begin, and Å¿ometimes finiÅ¿h the Fruit-buds; Namely, when the Sap is happily Temper'd to Å¿uch a Degree, as is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to bring them to perfection. The ConÅ¿ideration of this, has induced me to lay down this Maxim, That the Fruit Buds grow Å¿ometimes upon the weak of the Strong, and Å¿ometimes upon the Strong of the Weak.

div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.p: Reflections upon the Production of the Fruit-buds.

div.p: FOR the better UnderÅ¿tanding this Maxim, it is to be obÅ¿erved, That the former part of it Relates to thoÅ¿e Fruit-buds, which tho' they grow Å¿ometimes upon the bigger Branches, yet it is only in the parts which are fartheÅ¿t diÅ¿tant from their Extremities, that is to Å¿ay in the loweÅ¿t part of the Branch: The Second part of it is concerning the Buds that grow upon the Weak Branches, in a place quite contrary to that of the big ones; Viz. In the very Extremities of them.

There are then, as you have already heard, two Å¿orts of Branches, Strong and Weak, upon each of which theÅ¿e Fruit-buds are formed; and I think I may preÅ¿ume to Å¿ay, That the Sap which is diffuÅ¿ed through the whole extent of thoÅ¿e Branches, makes there as it were a Body of Sap: I am forced to expreÅ¿s my Å¿elf in theÅ¿e Terms, to render my Maxim more intelligible.

There is no queÅ¿tion to be made, as I have before intimated, but that a far greater proportion of that Sap riÅ¿es up to the Extremity of all Å¿orts of Branches, than remains of it in any other parts.
Now I give the Name of Strong, as well to the whole Branch that is big and Å¿trong, as to that part of all Å¿orts of Branches whatÅ¿oever, where the Sap is gathered in a greater quantity.
And I call Weak, as well the whole Branch whether Å¿mall and weak, as that part of any Å¿ort of Branches whatÅ¿oever, which partakes of that Sap in a leÅ¿Å¿er quantity.

This being Å¿uppos'd, I poÅ¿itively affirm, that in the big and Å¿trong Branches, where there is a greater confluence of Sap, that Sap forcing it Å¿elf upward to their Extremities, is conÅ¿equently convey'd thither in great Plenty. But that abundance as great as it is, may be fit to cauÅ¿e the putting forth many Branches, but is not Adapted to the making of Fruit-buds. For experience tells us, that theÅ¿e are never brought forth, but in thoÅ¿e places where there is a juÅ¿t proportion of Sap, Viz. Neither too much nor too little.

And 'tis for this ReaÅ¿on probably, That we never Å¿ee any Fruit-buds growing at the Prun'd or Lopp'd Extremity of a big Branch, except when the Sap has been diverted by Å¿ome unknown ObÅ¿tacle, from RiÅ¿ing up to it altogether, according to its uÅ¿ual CourÅ¿e; but upon the lower parts of the Branch, where the Sap is neither Å¿o plentiful nor Å¿o Å¿tirring, they are frequently produced.

And this is the ReaÅ¿on, that induced me to lay down this as a Maxim, That the Fruit-buds grow Å¿ometimes upon the Weak of the Strong; That is to Å¿ay upon the Weak part of the Strong Branch, where by Weak, the lower part of the Branch is to be underÅ¿tood; foraÅ¿much, as there being really much leÅ¿s Sap in the lower, than in the upper part, or Extremity of the Branch, it has by conÅ¿equence a greater diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, to bring forth thoÅ¿e lovely Fruit-buds which Å¿o juÅ¿tly challenge our Admiration.

The former part of this Maxim being well underÅ¿tood, there will remain no great difficulty in the latter; Å¿o that when I Å¿ay, That the Fruit-buds grow Å¿ometimes upon the Strong of the Weak the meaning is plain, that they Å¿hoot out at the extremity of the weak Branches, wherein, tho' indeed there is but a Å¿mall quantity of Sap, in compariÅ¿on of what is to be found in the big ones, yet there is more of it in the extremities, than in any other parts of the Å¿ame Branches, and therefore enough to make up the juÅ¿t meaÅ¿ure, which is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to the Frame or Conformation of thoÅ¿e Fruit-buds. And this is the true ReaÅ¿on, why the middle Å¿iz'd Branches that are neither too big nor too little, are commonly firÅ¿t loaded with Fruit-buds; the firÅ¿t years they begin to put out Buds at their ends, then continue from year to year to bring them forth in their whole length, but afterwards they Å¿hift from one part to another,
Å¿till drawing back by degrees nearer to that big Branch out of which they Å¿prung, till at laÅ¿t they come to bear in that which is neareÅ¿t to the place from whence they had their firÅ¿t Production.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

argument.p: Reflexions upon the Å¿hort continuance of the Fruit-bearing Branches.

div.p: I Have obÅ¿erved elÅ¿ewhere, in DiÅ¿courÅ¿ing of the means to prevent the ill Accidents, to which the Fruit-bearing Branches are Subject, that thoÅ¿e Branches never laÅ¿t long in any Trees: But that in Stone-Fruits, and eÅ¿pecially in Peaches, they never bear twice Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively in the Å¿ame place. Commonly they die in the very year of their bearing, which is the following year after their Å¿hooting forth. But if any of them eÅ¿cape, the ReaÅ¿on is, that being grown a little bigger than they were, they put forth out at their Extremities, Å¿ome other Fruitful Branches againÅ¿t the next year; but after that time they become Dry and UÅ¿eleÅ¿s, and by conÅ¿equence muÅ¿t be cut off.

In Core-Fruits, the Branches laÅ¿t Å¿omewhat longer, a ãâ¦ã continue bearing throughout their whole Length 5 or 6 years Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively, till at laÅ¿t they fall by the Common Fate of Fruit-bearing Branches, that is to periÅ¿h by their own FruitfulneÅ¿s.

It is not improbable, but that the Å¿ame thing may be Å¿aid, in Relation to the dying of theÅ¿e Fruit-Branches, that is generally obÅ¿erv'd in the Fruits themÅ¿elves, which decay conÅ¿tantly in a certain time; and the ReÅ¿emblance between them, is, in my Opinion, well enough Grounded, to admit the CompariÅ¿on. For as the firÅ¿t degree or mark of Corruption in Fruits, is the perfection of their RipeneÅ¿s; that is to Å¿ay, they are then neareÅ¿t to Corruption, when they have attained their compleat Maturity; Å¿o likewiÅ¿e in the Branches their beginning to bear, is the firÅ¿t Sign of their approaching DeÅ¿truction; that is to Å¿ay, according to the Common ObÅ¿ervation of Gard'ners, they begin to die, juÅ¿t in the Å¿ame Moment, that they begin to bear Fruit.

Now to give Å¿ome probable ReaÅ¿on of this particular DeÅ¿truction; it cannot be Å¿aid, That the Fruit-bearing Branch deÅ¿troys it Å¿elf, Å¿eeing it hath no peculiar Action diÅ¿tinct from the general Action of the Plant, whoÅ¿e great End is Å¿elf-preÅ¿ervation. It is then more to the purpoÅ¿e, I conceive to Å¿ay, that thoÅ¿e Parts (Viz. The Weak Branches) through which that Å¿mall quantity of Sap paÅ¿Å¿eth, which makes the Fruit, being not Å¿tored with a Å¿ufficient quantity of Sap to Å¿trengthen themÅ¿elves, and to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the injuries of the Air, do firÅ¿t begin to dry up inÅ¿enÅ¿ibly, and Å¿oon after wholly Wither and Dye: Whereas the other parts which are furniÅ¿h'd with it in greater Plenty; Viz. The Strong, Thick, and Vigorous Branches, being daily Å¿upplied with New Sap, and thereby Fortified againÅ¿t the Injuries of the Air, have alÅ¿o the good luck of a longer continuance.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

argument.p: Reflections upon the inward Contexture of Fruit-buds.

div.p: IT is a QueÅ¿tion that has extreamly puzled the Curious, to explain the inward Frame of theÅ¿e Fruit-buds, and I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s, that the Contexture and Arranging of thoÅ¿e little Leaves enfolded in one another, which make up thoÅ¿e Buds and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h them from the other parts of the Tree, are an ample Subject for a very Curious but difficult diÅ¿quiÅ¿ition; and I Å¿hould be extreamly glad to Arrive at a perfect underÅ¿tanding of this wonderful MaÅ¿ter-piece of Nature.

But after having a great deal of pains to little purpoÅ¿e, I am forced to acquieÅ¿ce and Å¿atisfie my CurioÅ¿ity, by Å¿aying plainly and in the general, that thoÅ¿e Buds may probably be formed, almoÅ¿t after the Å¿ame manner, with Cabbages and Loaf'd Lettuces. Let us Å¿ee then, whether we can unfold the MyÅ¿tery of thoÅ¿e, and thereby attain to the knowledge of the other.

To find how far this CompariÅ¿on will hold, we muÅ¿t conÅ¿ider, that of the Å¿everal Species of Plants, there are Å¿ome which commonly do but Å¿hoot forth outwardly, that is,
they only lengthen and extend their Extremities. Of this Å¿ort are Å¿uch as either grow upright, for InÅ¿tance, Trees, AÅ¿paragus, Artichokes; or Å¿uch as creep upon the Ground, as Melons, Gourds, Ivy, and the like, &c. Others there are which for a while do only Å¿hoot inwardly, to get a firmer and more compacted SubÅ¿tance, till at laÅ¿t they take the Å¿ame way with the former; for InÅ¿tance, All Å¿uch as are of an Orbicular Figure, as Cabbages, Loaf'd Lettuces, and even thoÅ¿e Plants which are tied together to make them grow white, as Chicorees, &c. ThoÅ¿e of the former kind Å¿hoot only at the Extremities of what was grown before; the others rarely Å¿hoot but only juÅ¿t round about their Center, in the Å¿ame manner almoÅ¿t as we Å¿ee Water Å¿pringing up in the Å¿ource of a Fountain.

Having premiÅ¿ed this: I Å¿ay, That as Cabbage and Lettuces cannot grow round when their Root is too vigorous; that exceÅ¿s of Vigor cauÅ¿ing them to grow upright in their Stem as much as their Å¿trength will allow, and at laÅ¿t cauÅ¿ing them to run up to Seed, when their Å¿trength is much exhauÅ¿ted; Å¿o likewiÅ¿e Å¿carce any Fruit-buds can be produced on Trees or Branches too much invigorated by the Sap, that exceÅ¿s of it cauÅ¿ing them to exert themÅ¿elves in length inÅ¿tead of growing round, as it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary they Å¿hould do to become really Fruit-buds.

A certain Mediocrity then of Vigor is requiÅ¿ite in thoÅ¿e kinds of Plants, in order to their growing Round and Headed, as there muÅ¿t be a certain Mediocrity of Sap in Fruit-Trees to produce Fruit-buds.

Now to underÅ¿tand after what manner thoÅ¿e Heads are framed in Cabbages and Lettuces, it is to be obÅ¿erved, FirÅ¿t, That thoÅ¿e outward Coats and Leaves are commonly firÅ¿t produced in thoÅ¿e Plants, and have their Formation begun as Å¿oon as the Plants themÅ¿elves. Secondly, That of all thoÅ¿e Leaves firÅ¿t produced, there uÅ¿ually remain but few, which growing proportionably to the DimenÅ¿ions of the Cabbage or Lettuce, Å¿erve for Ramparts and BaÅ¿tions to defend the Nobler Parts lying innermoÅ¿t, and which are, as it were, the Cittadel or Magazine of the Place.

Hence it comes to paÅ¿s, that Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e old outward Leaves, either by InÅ¿tinct of Nature, or the Gardiner's InduÅ¿try, contracting their Extremities very cloÅ¿e to one another, do form a kind of Natural Girdle, or Cap as it were, which entirely covers and encloÅ¿es the Heart and InÅ¿ide of thoÅ¿e Plants; which being the Seat of their Vital Principle, and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted by the Action of the Roots which are produced by it, and reÅ¿embling, as we have Å¿aid already, the Spring of a Fountain, Å¿hoots continually from its whole Circumference an infinite number of Å¿mall Productions, which become Å¿o many Å¿mall Leaves.

Now theÅ¿e being confined, and hindred from Å¿preading abroad, enfold and entangle themÅ¿elves for a while one within another, till they grow Å¿trong enough to break open the Bars which reÅ¿train them in Å¿o narrow a compaÅ¿s, and violently to force their way out: And becauÅ¿e they are not expoÅ¿ed to the Injuries of the Air, they remain tender, delicate, and white; as alÅ¿o being very numerous, and having but little room, they draw Å¿o cloÅ¿e together, that at laÅ¿t they become a hard and Å¿olid Body. And this is what is called Cabbages, and Loaf'd-Lettuces.

Now it is not improbable, but that Fruit-buds are formed juÅ¿t in the Å¿ame manner as thoÅ¿e Headed Cabbages. Without queÅ¿tion 'tis partly the Frame and Figure which makes the difference of their Denominations. In Trees, that Å¿mall, blackiÅ¿h, Å¿harp-topped RoundneÅ¿s which both makes, and encloÅ¿es the bloÅ¿Å¿om, is more properly termed Bud, than Head; as in Cabbage and Lettuce, their bigneÅ¿s and roundneÅ¿s cauÅ¿es them to be more fitly Å¿tyled Heads, than Buds.
I am of opinion, That Onions are formed within the Ground almoÅ¿t after the Å¿ame manner as the Heads of Cabbages and Lettuce are upon the Å¿urface of it.

Now as thoÅ¿e Onions, Cabbages, and Lettuce, when they are Å¿upplied with an additional encreaÅ¿e of Sap, begin to diÅ¿cloÅ¿e themÅ¿elves, and to put forth that which they had a long time contained hidden within: JuÅ¿t Å¿o the Fruit-buds, having in the Spring received an inward EncreaÅ¿e, as well by Rarefaction of their former Sap, as their new NouriÅ¿hment, burÅ¿t out, and diÅ¿cloÅ¿e at laÅ¿t that BloÅ¿Å¿om which carries in it the Embrio, or firÅ¿t beginning of the Fruit.

That firÅ¿t beginning of the Fruit is a very Å¿mall Particle, encloÅ¿ed in the Heart of the BloÅ¿Å¿om, wherein is contained the Seed from which the Fruit is produced; nor does either of them receive their Formation till the decreaÅ¿ing of the Heat, and deÅ¿cent of the Sap of the foregoing Summer. The temperate Warmth of the Spring aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ts the Tree in bringing to perfection what was but juÅ¿t begun, at once gratifying the Gardiner with the agreeable Object of his Hopes and DeÅ¿ires, and giving Nature an opportunity of multiplying its Productions.

Thus far I have been led by my CurioÅ¿ity to make an EÅ¿Å¿ay of enquiring into the inward Frame and Texture of Fruit-Buds, but I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s ingenuouÅ¿ly, That I have not made any conÅ¿iderable ProgreÅ¿s, when I reflect upon that vaÅ¿t difference in their Å¿everal Species in this reÅ¿pect, viz. That the Buds of S â¢â¢ pe-Fruits have in them but one BloÅ¿Å¿om apiece, whereas the Core Fruit-Buds encloÅ¿e 10 or 12 together, not to mention the many other DiÅ¿tinctions in their Colour, BigneÅ¿s, &c.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.

argument.p: Reflections upon other Effects of the Sap relating to the Thickning and Lengthning of the Branches.

div.p: I Come now to Å¿peak again of thoÅ¿e Effects which owe their Being to the continuance of the Sap in Å¿ome particular Parts of the Trees, and theÅ¿e are in my Opinion evidently demonÅ¿trated by the InÅ¿tance of thoÅ¿e Willow-tops that grow to an extraordinary bigneÅ¿s in compariÅ¿on of their Trunk, which undoubtedly proceeds from hence, That their Top-branches being often Lopp'd off near the place of their Å¿hooting out, the Sap riÅ¿ing up to it in its uÅ¿ual courÅ¿e, cannot iÅ¿Å¿ue out Å¿o Å¿oon as it is arrived there, but is forced to tarry there for Å¿ome time, and Å¿o Å¿ticking and incorporating it Å¿elf in part to that place where it is Å¿topp'd, it cauÅ¿es that Head to grow much bigger than all the reÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e Parts through which it only makes a quick PaÅ¿Å¿age.

It may be Å¿aid, and perhaps reaÅ¿onably enough, that the Sap cauÅ¿es-the bigneÅ¿s of the Branches in Trees, and the Leaves in all other Plants, almoÅ¿t in the Å¿ame manner, as the melted Wax doth in Tapers, Flambeaux and Torches, with this difference only, (which yet doth not alter the CompariÅ¿on) That the Sap riÅ¿esup between the Wood and the Bark, aÅ¿piring to the Center of light Bodies; whereas on the contrary, the melted Wax runs downward along the Å¿uÅ¿pended Wyck, becauÅ¿e it tends to the Center of heavy Bodies: And if it happens that any of that melted Wax Å¿tays any longer in one part than in another, it will not fail of producing the Å¿ame Effect that the Sap doth in the Extremities of maimed Trees. I cannot find any thing in Mechanics fitter to give a lively RepreÅ¿entation, how Sap, though Liquid it Å¿elf, can contribute to the thickning a Solid Body by that Solidity which it Å¿elf acquires; for it really grows thick as it were, by Å¿o many Coats Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively enfolded one over another, as is obvious enough to the Eye of him that doth but conÅ¿ider the extremity of any Stump of a Tree, or that views the Structure of Onions, RadiÅ¿hes, and other Roots, when cut through the middle.

But now as to the ExtenÅ¿ion of the Branches of Trees, and Leaves of every Plant; (which is made in this manner, viz. By the new Parts drawing nearer to the old ones, there is Å¿o cloÅ¿e an Union made, and, to Å¿peak PhiloÅ¿ophically, Å¿uch an intimate and individual Incorporation, that it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible either to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h them by the Eye, or to unfold and Å¿eparate them from one another.) I Å¿ay then, as to this ExtenÅ¿ion of Branches, the new Sap muÅ¿t needs have in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure the Propriety of mollifying and melting the hard Extremity of each Branch, and Trunk, of the former Year's Growth, that Å¿o it may unite the new Liquid with the old Solid, and conÅ¿titute a Body altogether like, Å¿o as that the leaÅ¿t difference cannot be perceived between them.

I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s, this is a Point that Å¿eems to me worthy of the higheÅ¿t Admiration, nor has the utmoÅ¿t of Humane InduÅ¿try ever yet attained to any Performance comparable to that Imperceptible ExtenÅ¿ion of Branches: For though the Painters Colours laid on at Å¿everal times, and the Solder which GoldÅ¿miths and Founders make uÅ¿e of, afford us Å¿ome Å¿aint ReÅ¿emblance of it; yet we muÅ¿t have RecourÅ¿e to Å¿ome other Effect of Nature, to give us a clear Idea of this Å¿o perfect an Union. For InÅ¿tance; That of Ice, which by the Å¿harpneÅ¿s of the Cold is formed over all Å¿orts of Water, as we Å¿ee it in the BaÅ¿in of a Fountain. 'Tis true, the Superficies of that Water which was Congeled to day, cannot abÅ¿olutely be diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed from the inner Parts of that Water which will be Congeled to morrow, and Å¿o Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively from one Part to another, as the Cold continues to have a Å¿tronger Influence upon them: But the compariÅ¿on of Gutters in which the Icicles grow longer, proportionably as the Cold of the Air becomes more intenÅ¿e, repreÅ¿ents Å¿till more clearly, that lengthning of Branches which we can Å¿o difficultly Å¿olve in Trees, for to give an account how thoÅ¿e Knots and Eyes come to be Å¿o artificially
placed at certain DiÅ¿tances, and to be Å¿o beautifully adorned with Leaves and Fruits, is beyond the Limits of our UnderÅ¿tanding.

But however, neither of theÅ¿e CompariÅ¿ons will Å¿ignifie much to us, unleÅ¿s there happen in the interval, from one day to another to be Å¿ome abatement of Cold, Å¿o as it may certainly appear, that there has been Å¿ome relenting of the FroÅ¿t: For when that continues without any intermiÅ¿Å¿ion, it has a like effect in the Water during the extremity of Winter, that the Sap has in the extended Branches during the Heats of the Spring and Summer. The only difficulty lies in the firÅ¿t ExtenÅ¿ion, which happens at the end of the Winter; and this ariÅ¿es from the Å¿tirring activity in the Liquid Sap, which riÅ¿es up anew to the extremity of the hard and Å¿olid Branches of the preceding Year.

And here we may obÅ¿erve, That a Tree is eaÅ¿ily to be cleft lengthways, viz. From the Head to the Foot, or from Foot to Head, as if in that PoÅ¿ition the Fibres, of which its Trunk conÅ¿iÅ¿ts, were in Å¿ome manner like Threads wrapped cloÅ¿e one over another: But to take it breadthways or acroÅ¿s from one Å¿ide to the other, 'tis very difficult to cleave it. For the Å¿everal Parts are Å¿o compacted and linked together, that each of them Å¿eems to make a little All, perfect and entire in it Å¿elf, neither can any Separation be made of it, but by means of a Å¿harp-edg'd Tool.

What Effects are produced by the continuance of the Sap, are yet more fully demonÅ¿trated by its contrary, namely by the too quick PaÅ¿Å¿age of it, as it happens, (eÅ¿pecially in any Å¿ort of Fruit-Trees whether Core or Stone-Fruit) when the Sap following its uÅ¿ual CourÅ¿e, which is to aÅ¿cend by regular Steps to the extremities of the Branches, doth in its PaÅ¿Å¿age open to it Å¿elf an indirect and extraordinary way into Å¿ome other part of the Tree, and in few days puts forth what we call Suckers or FalÅ¿e Shoots. The Sap, I Å¿ay, being thus diÅ¿ordered, and making its EÅ¿cape with Å¿ome Å¿ort of Violence, burÅ¿ts out and riÅ¿es with an impetuous force, and during that firÅ¿t Effort, makes no Å¿tay in its PaÅ¿Å¿age.

From hence it comes to paÅ¿s, that thoÅ¿e Eyes which are neareÅ¿t that breaking out are very far diÅ¿tant from one another, are flat and ill nouriÅ¿hed, Å¿o as to be Å¿carcely diÅ¿cernible: But when the violence of that firÅ¿t Effort is Å¿omewhat abated, the Sap returns to its ordinary pace, and Å¿eems to have its regular PauÅ¿es; whereby it both forms thoÅ¿e Eyes nearer to each other, and affords them better NouriÅ¿hment. So that while the lower Parts are accounted uÅ¿eleÅ¿s and falÅ¿e Wood, the upper on the contrary prove fruitful and well condition'd.

The Reader perhaps may think, I have inÅ¿iÅ¿ted too long upon this CompariÅ¿on between Sap and Light, but as I could not explain my Notion more briefly concerning that extream quickneÅ¿s wherewith the Sap, after its being prepared by the Roots, Å¿eems as it were to fly to all the extremities of the Branches, Å¿o I wiÅ¿h that even thus I may have the good fortune to be underÅ¿tood.

div.head: CHAP. XV.

argument.p: Reflections upon Å¿ome other Effects proceeding from the greater or leÅ¿Å¿er Quantity of the Sap.

div.p: I Shall now proceed to give another InÅ¿tance, wherein a lighted Torch and the Roots of Trees have a mutual Analogy or ReÅ¿emblance, for a further Confirmation of my Opinion, concerning the different Operation of the Roots in relation to the Sap, which cauÅ¿es the Thickening, Lengthening, and indeed the UniverÅ¿al ExtenÅ¿ion of the Tree.

For as a Luminous Body, the bigger and brighter it is, the farther will it diffuÅ¿e its Light; juÅ¿t Å¿o thoÅ¿e Roots that are thickeÅ¿t, hardeÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t vigorous in their Operation, do force up higheÅ¿t that Sap or NouriÅ¿hment that is prepared by them.

And hence it is very eaÅ¿ie to give a ReaÅ¿on how the Extremities of Å¿ome Trees or Branches come to die, which certainly in my Opinion is nothing elÅ¿e but only the want of Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e Å¿ubÅ¿tantial and Å¿trong Roots growing out of the foot of the Tree; whence conÅ¿equently it happens, that there is not Sap enough prepared to riÅ¿e up Å¿o high as it uÅ¿ed to do, either in former Years, or even in that very SeaÅ¿on wherein this Defect was obÅ¿erved.

For InÅ¿tance: The Sap that in other Years uÅ¿ed to riÅ¿e 3 or 4 Fathoms, may now perhaps riÅ¿e but 10 or 12 Feet, and of this you have a certain Indication when the new Branches Å¿hoot out no where but at a conÅ¿iderable diÅ¿tance below the Extremities of the old ones.

On the other hand, when the Sap in the beginning of the Year had advanced the Boughs 3 or 4 Feet in height, and yet towards the latter end of the Summer they begin to grow blackiÅ¿h, and at laÅ¿t to wither and die within 5 or 6 Inches of the Top; and this even when the Root Å¿eemed in the Spring to have Å¿ufficiently done its part, and the Soil to have been duly qualified with Å¿uch a juÅ¿t proportion of Heat and MoiÅ¿ture as was requiÅ¿ite for their Vegetation: When this, I Å¿ay, happens, it muÅ¿t be aÅ¿cribed to no other CauÅ¿e than the drying up of their MoiÅ¿ture by the exceÅ¿Å¿ive Heat of the Summer, in regard that their Roots being but Å¿mall and weak, could not Å¿o well reÅ¿iÅ¿t the Violence of it, as thoÅ¿e which were more vigorous and Å¿ubÅ¿tantial. What means are proper to be uÅ¿ed for the preventing of Å¿uch Accidents, I have already mentioned elÅ¿ewhere.

Now Å¿ince the more vigorous the Root is, the more vigorouÅ¿ly alÅ¿o it will act, and conÅ¿equently Å¿uck in more NouriÅ¿hment, and cauÅ¿e that NouriÅ¿hment to riÅ¿e Å¿o much higher, it muÅ¿t undoubtedly follow, that the riÅ¿ing of the Sap to the Top of the Branches, whereby there is an AcceÅ¿Å¿ion made to their former length, proceeds only from this vigour and Å¿trength of the Root; as on the other Å¿ide, the weakneÅ¿s of the Root is the true cauÅ¿e that the Sap, not being in a Å¿ufficient quantity to riÅ¿e to a conÅ¿iderable height, is confined much lower than its uÅ¿ual pitch.

And indeed it Å¿eems probable, that as all Animals are limited to Å¿uch a determinate Size and Proportion, and, as a Fountain, containing Å¿uch a quantity of Water, and conveyed by a Pipe of Å¿uch a Capacity, cannot raiÅ¿e it up to a greater height than the Level of that Source from whence it flows.

In the very Å¿ame manner the DimenÅ¿ions of all Vegetables Å¿eem to be confined to a certain Å¿tint both of height and circumference, Å¿o as to have a fixed Point to which the Sap may aÅ¿cend in order to the putting forth new Branches, but cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly riÅ¿e higher to cauÅ¿e any further Production. Thus if we Lop a Tree 5 or 6 Feet, whoÅ¿e uÅ¿ual height does not exceed 10 or 12, it will always appear vigorous and lively, till it have recovered its uÅ¿ual height of 12 Feet; and the ReaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e it will be continually labouring to exert it Å¿elf to the utmoÅ¿t Sphere of its Activity, and conÅ¿equently there is no danger of its falling to Decay, or dying at the Extremities of its Branches.

It muÅ¿t therefore be the Gardiner's buÅ¿ineÅ¿s to render himÅ¿elf expert in his ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion, by a diligent ObÅ¿ervation of what is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be done, both in the Ordering of his Trees, and the Manuring of the Ground; and indeed, the difference that is between a Fertile and Barren Soil, will aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him very much in the making a true EÅ¿timate of the Force and Vigour of the Sap. For in a Soil that is really good, a Tree will grow 30 or 35 Feet high, with a Circumference proportionable; but if the Soil be lank or barren, a Tree, though of the Å¿ame Species, and as well Condition'd as the other, will not, perhaps, exceed 10 or 12 Feet. The former kind of Soil will prove fruitful in a manner without any Cultivation, but the latter will be good for nothing, if its Sterility be not Å¿upplied by the utmoÅ¿t Care and AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Gardiner.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.

argument.p: Reflections upon the Order of the Branches Å¿hooting out of the Tree.

div.p: HAving thus given my Opinion, how the Sap, after its entrance into the Roots, does afterwards riÅ¿e up, and communicate it Å¿elf to the upper Parts of the Tree, I Å¿hall now proceed to Explain in what manner the new Branches grow out of the Extremities of thoÅ¿e of the precedent Year, and how it comes to paÅ¿s that their Shooting out is generally Å¿o ordered by Nature, that the higher Branches have moÅ¿t commonly Å¿ome Advantage both in their length and thickneÅ¿s over the lower.

And here I Å¿hall reÅ¿ume my former CompariÅ¿on of a Brook, which having its CourÅ¿e retarded for Å¿ome time by a Digue or Dam, is hindred from continuing its ProgreÅ¿s to its deÅ¿igned Journey's end. This Water then, which we will Å¿uppoÅ¿e amaÅ¿s'd together in a conÅ¿iderable quantity, as we Å¿ee in larger Ponds, coming afterwards to find divers Vents of equal Capacity, as well in the Body of the Dam which principally Å¿uÅ¿tained its PreÅ¿Å¿ure, as in the Walls built on each Å¿ide of it, for the confining it within Å¿uch a compaÅ¿s: This Water, I Å¿ay, having either found or made theÅ¿e Breaches, will iÅ¿Å¿ue out at the Å¿ame inÅ¿tant through all of them; but for the moÅ¿t part will run out in a much greater Stream, and with a Å¿tronger Current, at
the breach of the Dam it Å¿elf, than at the Crannies of the Å¿ides, and Å¿till faÅ¿ter in proportion, through thoÅ¿e breaches which have an aperture neareÅ¿t reÅ¿embling that of the Dam, than through thoÅ¿e which are more unlike. This Å¿o remarkable a difference is caus'd by the PreÅ¿Å¿ure of the Water, haÅ¿tning continually towards its Centre, which preÅ¿Å¿ure Å¿till encreaÅ¿es the nearer it approaches to that Centre, as is obvious to the meaneÅ¿t UnderÅ¿tanding.

The Sap produces almoÅ¿t the Å¿ame effect in the Branches of Trees; for having found in them Å¿everal Apertures of an equal bigneÅ¿s, which we call Eyes, it makes its way at the Å¿ame time through thoÅ¿e in the upper parts, but principally, and in greater abundance, through the laÅ¿t Eye, (That I mean, which is in the very Extremity of the Branch) and where the Sap makes its Å¿trongeÅ¿t Effort, than it does through the others which are at Å¿ome diÅ¿tance. 'Tis true if there be Å¿uch an exuberance of Sap, that the parts of it which aÅ¿cended firÅ¿t are preÅ¿s'd forwards by the Å¿ucceeding ones, it will then diÅ¿charge it Å¿elf into the lower Eyes, but always more plentifully into thoÅ¿e which are neareÅ¿t to the top of the Branch, than into thoÅ¿e which are at a greater diÅ¿tance from it.

Now, that I may give the beÅ¿t ReaÅ¿on I can of this Effect, which is Å¿o contrary to the Natural CourÅ¿e of the Sap; I conceive that this Alteration may proceed from hence, viz. That little Portion of Sap which paÅ¿Å¿ed to the uppermoÅ¿t Eye or Eyes, having there produced Branches of but an indifferent bigneÅ¿s, communicates to them what it uÅ¿es to do to all the weak Branches; namely a great DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition to a quick Production of Fruit Buds. I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s it is a difficulty which neither my long Study, nor diligent ObÅ¿ervation have been able to Solve, how this Sap in proportion to its greater or leÅ¿Å¿er Quantity Å¿hould produce Å¿uch different Effects. After all theÅ¿e ObÅ¿ervations, I think I may Å¿afely aver, that in all that Infinite variety of Speculations that Å¿erve for the Entertainment of our Intellectual Faculties, there is not perhaps any Subject more Nice and Intricate to adjuÅ¿t rightly than that of Vegetation. div.head: CHAP. XVII.

argument.p: Reflections upon the different Effects of the Sap in the Outward Parts of the Plants.

div.p: THough it be very probable that the Formation of the Roots, and NouriÅ¿hment of all Plants, Å¿o far as it is tranÅ¿acted under Ground, is performed by Nature in the Å¿ame manner, as I have formerly explain'd it in the Ch. of Plants. Yet as to their outward Appearance, they may not unfitly be compared to Å¿o many little Republicks, each of them differing from the other in their Government, and having nothing in their manner of Acting common with their Neighbours, but the Polity of the one being pretty often quite contrary to that of the other. Thus we Å¿ee, for inÅ¿tance, that Birds, though they all agree in the way of Multiplying their Species, viz. by Eggs, do notwithÅ¿tanding differ in their bigneÅ¿s and colour, in their Note, their way of Living, Acting, &c.

Nature has ImpreÅ¿s'd Å¿o great a diverÅ¿ity in all Vegetables, as if Å¿he had deÅ¿ign'd as well to make us admire that InexhauÅ¿ted Stock of Variety in her Productions, as to confound and dazle the UnderÅ¿tanding of Mankind, when it preÅ¿umes to Dive into the MyÅ¿teries of her WorkmanÅ¿hip, and pretends to give ReaÅ¿ons for the abÅ¿truÅ¿eÅ¿t of her Operations.

There have been in all Ages Å¿ome very Ingenious PerÅ¿ons, who have made it their buÅ¿ineÅ¿s to become knowing in this Faculty; and even at this preÅ¿ent time we Å¿ee many that Study it with extraordinary Application. But the Misfortune is, that if we happen to make any, though but an inconÅ¿iderable DiÅ¿covery, into the Nature of Å¿ome one Vegetable, beyond the Medicinal Properties of it, we are preÅ¿ently too apt to flatter our Å¿elves with a belief, that we have attain'd to a perfect UnderÅ¿tanding of it both in the CauÅ¿e, and Manner, of its Being, and from thence make no Å¿cruple to infer ConcluÅ¿ions concerning others alÅ¿o; whereas if we look into the Matter but a little further, there will immediately occur to us Å¿o many Plants of a quite contrary Nature, as are more than enough to confound our Judgments, and deÅ¿troy our HypotheÅ¿is, or at leaÅ¿t to give a fatal blow to the greateÅ¿t part of what we pretend to lay down as UniverÅ¿al Maxims.

For inÅ¿tance, if we conÅ¿ider the proceÅ¿s of Maturation, or what part it is that grows Ripe Å¿ooneÅ¿t in Pears, Apples, Grapes, &c. As likewiÅ¿e if we do but obÅ¿erve the order of Production in the Flowers of the TubereuÅ¿e, Lilly, Hyacinth, Larksfeet, viz. which of their Buds come to be firÅ¿t blown, we Å¿hall certainly â¢ ind that both in thoÅ¿e Fruits and Flowers, that part which is next to the Stalk, and Å¿o to the Bole and Roots, and which conÅ¿equently doth firÅ¿t receive its Being and Formation, doth alÅ¿o get the advantage of Priority in Ripening and Blowing. Which RipeneÅ¿s as it is, with relation to Mans UÅ¿e, the higheÅ¿t degree of its Perfection, Å¿o in reÅ¿pect to the duration of the Fruit or Flower, it is the neareÅ¿t Å¿tep to its DeÅ¿truction. This ConÅ¿ideration, I Å¿ay, is enough to encline one, to lay down this as a General Rule, That in all Plants, the nearer any Part is to that Place from whence it receives its NouriÅ¿hment, Å¿o much Å¿ooner doth that Part arrive to its Maturity and Perfection.

But how ill grounded this AÅ¿Å¿ertion would be, is Å¿ufficiently DemonÅ¿trated by what we continually Å¿ee in Figs, Melons, Peaches, Plums, Abricots, &c. namely that the beÅ¿t part, and which Ripens Å¿ooneÅ¿t, is furtheÅ¿t from the Stalk, and conÅ¿equently that which is at the greateÅ¿t diÅ¿tance both from the Bole and Roots.

In Orange-Trees, JeÅ¿Å¿imines, Pinks, Musk RoÅ¿es, &c. the Buds that Flower firÅ¿t, are thoÅ¿e Growing at the Extremities of the Branches; and indeed, there needs no more to the putting our NaturaliÅ¿t to an AbÅ¿olute Non plus, than only to bid him conÅ¿ider the Nature of the Rasberry and RoÅ¿e-Laurel Trees, neither of which keep any conÅ¿tant order either in the Ripening of their Fruit or Blowing of their Bud; for Å¿ometimes that which is furtheÅ¿t off Ripens or Blows firÅ¿t, and Å¿ometimes that which is neareÅ¿t. This unequal, or rather diÅ¿orderly way of acting, cannot without extream difficulty be fix'd or Å¿tated by any General Maxims.

Thus then we Å¿ee, that inÅ¿tead of laying down one General AphoriÅ¿m concerning the order of Nature in the Ripening of Fruit, and Blowing of Flower Buds, we muÅ¿t deliver as many different Maxims as there are different Specie; of Fruits and Flowers upon the whole Face of the UniverÅ¿e.

Again, if in the Spring we Examine what Branch it is out of which moÅ¿t Fruit. Grows, as Pears, Apples, Peaches, Plums, Abricots, Cherries, Goosberries, &c. it will appear to be upon the Boughs of at leaÅ¿t one or two years former Growth, for here it was that the Fruit-Buds did upon the fall of the Sap in the preceding Summer receive their firÅ¿t Formation.

Now having gain'd this Point of Knowledge, we are tempted to infer from thence that all BloÅ¿Å¿oms have their Being a long time before the Fruit, but then on the other Å¿ide, let us but look upon the Vine, the Wallnut-Tree, the Great CheÅ¿nut, the Quince-Tree, the Rasberry-BuÅ¿h, &c. and we Å¿hall Å¿ee that in theÅ¿e Nature has Acted in a quite different manner than Å¿he uÅ¿ually doth in other Trees: For in thoÅ¿e I have now mentioned, the BloÅ¿Å¿oms precede the Fruit but a very few days, Å¿ince both the BloÅ¿Å¿oms and the Fruit Grow only upon Å¿uch Branches as were put forth themÅ¿elves but that very Spring, and are almoÅ¿t Contemporaries in their Birth with the Bough it Å¿elf that is to Å¿upport them. However there is this difference between them, That Å¿ome Fruits are form'd at the very extremity of the Bough, as Wallnuts, CheÅ¿nuts, Quinces, and theÅ¿e for the moÅ¿t part do entirely put a Å¿top to the Branches Growing any further, except only that on the Wallnut and CheÅ¿nut-Trees, we Å¿ee Å¿ometimes that after the Nuts have received their formation at the top of the Bough, there will yet riÅ¿e Sap enough to make it grow conÅ¿iderably longer. If we look, in the latter end of Autumn, upon that part of the Branch which is firÅ¿t Å¿tripp'd of its Leaves, it will preÅ¿ently appear that in moÅ¿t Trees it is the Top that firÅ¿t Å¿hews it Å¿elf bare, as if the Roots not being then Å¿o vigorous in their Action, or the Heat of the Air not Å¿trong enough to Å¿upply their NeceÅ¿Å¿ities, the Sap thereupon became incapable of riÅ¿ing to its uÅ¿ual heighth; but now on the contrary in PeaÅ¿e, Beans, Artichokes, Cabbage, and moÅ¿t Å¿orts of PulÅ¿e or Legumes; as alÅ¿o in Almond and Peach-Trees, that are very vigorous and thriving; we find the lower part is firÅ¿t dried and decayed, whilÅ¿t at the Å¿ame time the Top continues its Verdure, and Shooting forth. Can any thing be more irreconcileable than theÅ¿e two effects of Sap Å¿o contrary one to another?

In all Trees whether of Stone or Kernel Fruit, Ocular Experience tells us that the Fruit grows always juÅ¿t in the Å¿ame place where its BloÅ¿Å¿om grew, as if the BloÅ¿Å¿om in its Exit or falling off Å¿eem'd only to give way to the coming of the Fruit, for whoÅ¿e Å¿ake it was blown; but now in Wallnut-Trees, CheÅ¿nuts and HaÅ¿ â¢ enuts, as alÅ¿o in Turky Wheat, &c. we find no Fruit where the BloÅ¿Å¿oms were, Å¿o far rather to the contrary, that in thoÅ¿e Trees the Fruit is produced at the very end of the Branch where not one BloÅ¿Å¿om appear'd, and in Turky Wheat, the BloÅ¿Å¿om is form'd at the Top of the Stalk, and the Seed grows out from the very middle of each of the lower Leaves.

As to the order or proceÅ¿s of Nature in the Production of Fruits, the firÅ¿t beginning of it is made by the Fruit-buds, and as we have Å¿aid already concerning Kernel-Trees, every Bud contains in it Å¿everal BloÅ¿Å¿oms, and conÅ¿equently Å¿everal Fruits alÅ¿o; as in Stone Fruit-Trees every Bud contains but one BloÅ¿Å¿om, and therefore but one Å¿ingle Fruit. In the midÅ¿t of every one of theÅ¿e BloÅ¿Å¿oms, there is a little Sting or Active Particle, from which within three or four days after Blowing the Fruit is form'd if the Weather prove favourable; that is, if the Rigor of the Cold do not deÅ¿troy theÅ¿e precious Embryo's or Beginnings; Å¿o that ordinarily every Species of Fruit is UÅ¿her'd in by its BloÅ¿Å¿om. But here we muÅ¿t except the Fig, which is produced entirely, and all at once, without any BloÅ¿Å¿om; and in Melons, Cucumbers, Gourds, &c. the Fruit it Å¿elf appears before the BloÅ¿Å¿om, for it is not till Å¿ome days after the Production of the Melon, that the BloÅ¿Å¿om which grows out of the Top of it receives its compleat Formation, and afterwards proceeds to Blowing. 'Tis upon the thriving of this BloÅ¿Å¿om that the Perfection of the Fruit depends; Å¿o that if that prove unable to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the Cold, and all its other Enemies, the Fruit will dye almoÅ¿t as Å¿oon as it is Born.

It is further obÅ¿ervable, that though for the moÅ¿t part there remaineth nothing of the BloÅ¿Å¿om with the Fruit, Å¿o that this is not wont to appear before the BloÅ¿Å¿om is entirely gone, yet notwithÅ¿tanding we find that in the Pomegranate there is left Å¿ome part of the BloÅ¿Å¿om which goes to the ConÅ¿truction or CompoÅ¿ition of it; unleÅ¿s you will Å¿ay rather that part of the Fruit grows at the Å¿ame time with the BloÅ¿Å¿om
and is to it, if I may uÅ¿e the CompariÅ¿on, like a Cradle or Shell, and this as well for the preÅ¿ervation of it, as to Å¿erve for a cover both to that Å¿ort of congealed Liquor, and to the Grains or Kernels which are the very EÅ¿Å¿ence and SubÅ¿tance of this Fruit.

In an Acorn the firÅ¿t thing that appears is a kind of Shell or Husk, of a Figure between round and flat, that Å¿hews it Å¿elf about the latter end of July, and which we may Å¿ay Å¿erves in Å¿tead of a BloÅ¿Å¿om to it, Å¿ince indeed it has no other: and out of the middle of this Husk the Acorn it Å¿elf grows, which Tradition tells us was the principal Food of Mankind in the Primitive Ages of the World.

Now as every Tree is compoÅ¿ed of Å¿everal Branches, Å¿ome Å¿trong and others weak, if we examine the place whereon ordinarily the Fruit grows, we find that Nature has induÅ¿triouÅ¿ly choÅ¿en to fructifie upon the weaker, and not upon the Å¿tronger Branches.

But now in Vines and Fig-Trees it is juÅ¿t the contrary, for it is generally Å¿een that Grapes and Figs very rarely grow upon the weak Branches, but are in great plenty upon thoÅ¿e that be thicker, Å¿tronger and more vigorous. How then is it poÅ¿Å¿ible to reduce to one Maxim this inconÅ¿iÅ¿tency of Nature in chuÅ¿ing Å¿uch different Situations for the Production of Fruit?

If we conÅ¿ider after what manner Trees are extended in length both in their Trunk and Branches, we find this remarkable CircumÅ¿tance, namely, that in the Spring and Summer whilÅ¿t the Sap acts moÅ¿t briskly, that which was the Top or Extremity of a Bough this moment, ceaÅ¿es to be Å¿o the next; by reaÅ¿on that the Sap aÅ¿cending continually without intermiÅ¿Å¿ion, Å¿till puts out new Leaves above the precedent extremity; and the new Å¿hoot receives the Å¿ame Treatment from the Å¿ucceeding Sap, that it gave to that extremity of the Branch which immediately preceded it.

But on the contrary in Artichokes, AÅ¿paragus, Grapes, in all Leafs, and Fruits, in Tulips Pinks, and moÅ¿t Å¿orts of Flowers, we Å¿ee that what was once the extreme part, always continues Å¿o, Å¿o that their Augmentation or Growth is only inward, and not form'd outwardly, as Experience Å¿hews us it is in Trees. The AÅ¿paragus, Artichoke, Tulip and moÅ¿t Å¿orts of Flowers appear plainly to grow entirely, though but in Å¿mall Threads or Filaments, out of the very Å¿ubÅ¿tance or heart of the Plant, and afterwards encreaÅ¿e in thickneÅ¿s in the inÅ¿ide of it by the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance or Å¿upply of the Adventitious NouriÅ¿hment. Again, If we conÅ¿ider what it is that cauÅ¿es the whiteneÅ¿s and delicacy of tyed Lettuce, Celeri, the SpaniÅ¿h or White ThiÅ¿tle, the Leek, &c. it will appear to be either from their having been cover'd with dry Dung, dry Leaves, Earth or Mould, whereby they are hindred from receiving the uÅ¿ual freÅ¿hneÅ¿s and virtue of the open Air.

Now for the Leaves of Plants and Trees, we commonly find but one upon a Stalk, and they grow upon the Boughs ChequerwiÅ¿e, in little Stories or Steps at a Å¿mall diÅ¿tance from each other. The manner of the Indian Fig-Tree's bearing its Fruit without the Support of any Trunk or Branches, and making uÅ¿e of its Leaves only to multiply and grow upon, is, in my Opinion, as Å¿urpriÅ¿ing a Phaenomenon as any of thoÅ¿e Objects which daily attract our Admiration.
