That indented, or jagged Figure wherewith Nature has wantonly adorned moÅ¿t Å¿orts of Vigetables, and which by its different Cut or Edging, in every Species, gave Mankind the firÅ¿t Hint that hath Å¿ince furniÅ¿h'd him with Å¿o many Varieties: This Artificial, and Curious Edging, may very well deÅ¿erve Å¿ome Place in our PhiloÅ¿ophical Meditations.

If we conÅ¿ider the CircumÅ¿tances attending the Bulbs of Tulips, we cannot but acknowledge that PhiloÅ¿ophy has not yet been able to give us a Å¿atisfactory Account of them. They are put into the Ground in October, and there take Root, and in March following, each of them puts out a Stalk, in order to Budding, and BloÅ¿Å¿oming in due time. Hitherto you will Å¿ay, there is nothing extraordinary, Å¿ince the Å¿ame thing is always Å¿een in the Imperial Crown, the Hyacinth, TuberoÅ¿e, Jonquil, &c. but here then lyes the Wonder, that this Tulip-Stalh, which grew manifeÅ¿tly out of the very Middle, or Center of the Bulb, juÅ¿t as the Stalk uÅ¿ually grows out of the Middle in all other Bulbs, is at length remov'd from its firÅ¿t Seat, viz. the Center, to the OutÅ¿ide, or Superficies of its Bulb; a peculiar CaÅ¿e which happens not to any other Plant. Now who is it that can Å¿olve the Difficulty how this TranÅ¿poÅ¿ition is brought to paÅ¿s? Does the Bulb force it back again? Or does it by a Å¿ort of Leger de main in its AÅ¿cent, penetrate the Å¿ides of the Bulb? This indeed is a MyÅ¿tery in Vigetation that can never be look'd upon with Å¿ufficient AÅ¿toniÅ¿hment and Admiration.

It would be an endleÅ¿s Labour, Å¿hould I particularize all my ObÅ¿ervations of this kind in Vegetables: But theÅ¿e are Å¿ufficient to demonÅ¿trate, that every Plant has a peculiar, determinate, certain, and infallible Stint or Term, for the Beginning and Duration of its Action, for the Manner of its Appearance above Ground, for the Quality of its Soil, for the TaÅ¿te, Colour, and Å¿ize of its Fruit, for the Figure, BigneÅ¿s, and Colour of the Seed, the Difference of its Leaves and Stalk, or for the Parts of the Tree where the Fruit and the Seed grows. And though, as I have Å¿aid divers times, it be very difficult to explain all theÅ¿e peculiar Differences by the Doctrine of Pores, the different Configuration of Parts, or Atoms of a Figure, juÅ¿tly proportioned for the Penetration of them.

I Å¿hall here, notwithÅ¿tanding, conclude this Subject at preÅ¿ent, after I have given the Reader my Thoughts concerning that Circulation of the Sap, which Å¿ome pretend to have diÅ¿covered in Plants.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.

argument.p: Reflections upon their Opinion that maintains the Circulation of the Sap.

div.p: AS I am of Opinion, FirÅ¿t, That there is in the Spring, a certain Rarefaction in all Vegetables, which is the firÅ¿t Mover in Vegetation. And Secondly, That there is in every Plant a Vital Principle, which being a neceÅ¿Å¿ary Agent, receives the firÅ¿t Effects of that Rarefaction, as I have already diÅ¿courÅ¿ed elÅ¿ewhere. So I cannot think of any CompariÅ¿on fitter, to make my Notion intelligible, than that of a Clock, which needs no more to Å¿et it going, than only to pull up the Weight, and give a little Jog to the PendulumâThe Truth is, I always thought it abÅ¿olutely impoÅ¿Å¿ible to make this pretended Circulation conÅ¿iÅ¿tent with the Action of the Roots, which we daily Å¿ee to extend themÅ¿elves both in Length and ThickneÅ¿s at the very Å¿ame InÅ¿tant that they receive their NouriÅ¿hment. And the Objections that prevail'd with me, were theÅ¿e.

FirÅ¿t, I cannot apprehend either at what time, or in what Place this Circulation Å¿hould begin. Secondly, I cannot Å¿ee either any NeceÅ¿Å¿ity, or Advantage of it. Thirdly, SuppoÅ¿ing we Å¿hould admit it, I am in the dark, whether we muÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ert one general Circulation only in every Tree, or whether there muÅ¿t be as many Circulations, as there are particular Branches, &c.

As for the Time when it begins, if there be Å¿uch a Circulation, it muÅ¿t certainly have its Beginning the very Å¿ame InÅ¿tant that the Roots begin their Action, and alÅ¿o muÅ¿t owe that very Beginning to the Influence and Virtue of the Roots; Å¿o that conÅ¿equently there may be a Time when there will be no Circulation, for as much as the Roots are not continually in Action. Now, as the principal ReaÅ¿on of admitting this HypotheÅ¿is of Circulation in Animals is drawn from the NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of it, viz. for the Purifying the Blood, which, we are told, would be in great Danger of being corrupted, if not kept in continual Motion: So if that InÅ¿tance hold in Plants, it muÅ¿t then alÅ¿o follow, that the Sap would be in the like Danger of Corruption, that very firÅ¿t Moment of its Circulations being intermitted; and conÅ¿equently we Å¿hould Å¿ee a general Mortality of all thoÅ¿e Trees that Å¿hould happen not to be in Action; whatever the CauÅ¿e of it might be, whether their being hindred by the FroÅ¿t, or their lying out of the Ground; and much more, that all Branches, when once Å¿eparated from the Tree that bare them, muÅ¿t immediately periÅ¿h; juÅ¿t as the Members, as Å¿oon as they are cut off from the Body. But now there is nothing more contrary to the Experience of every one, than this will, as appears evidently by that infinite Number of Plants, and Grafts, which are Å¿o frequently, and with Å¿uch good SucceÅ¿s, Å¿ent into foreign Countries, without the leaÅ¿t ill Accident, provided they be not overmuch dry'd by exceÅ¿s of Heat.

But Å¿uppoÅ¿ing there be really Å¿uch a Circulation, and that it commences at the Å¿ame time with the Action of the Roots: Yet how will they be able to Å¿olve the Production of thoÅ¿e Branches which Å¿hoot forth in the Spring, without any Dependance upon the Roots. That it is Å¿o, there can be no doubt, Å¿ince we have InÅ¿tances of it every Spring in Trees newly planted, and which have not yet put forth any new Roots. As alÅ¿o in Trees digg'd up in the Winter, and left lying on the Ground: and even Branches lopp'd off in that SeaÅ¿on, and Å¿et up an end in the Ground, will put out little Shoots in the Spring.

In fine, How is it poÅ¿Å¿ible to give a clear Account of this Circulation, when we find that Almonds, Nuts, and even common Seeds, Å¿hoot out within the Earth, and in a few days put forth a Root, growing in length downward, but do not cauÅ¿e any Production to riÅ¿e up out of the Ground? When we Å¿ee that, the Bulb of the Imperial will Å¿end out Roots in AuguÅ¿t, but no Stalk; and on the contrary, other Bulbs put out Stalks in the Autumn and Spring, but no Roots; when Tulips, TuberoÅ¿e's, and eÅ¿pecially the AÅ¿paragus, grow upright in Å¿uch a manner, as that which was the extream Part at its firÅ¿t Appearance, Å¿till continues Å¿o, and that all of it riÅ¿es entirely and at once from the Bottom to the Top; when the Sprouts Å¿hooting out from the Extremity of a Branch, which has been cut or cropt, have Å¿uch an extream difference in Length and ThickneÅ¿s, as I have formerly deÅ¿cribed. It is, I think, Å¿ufficiently clear from hence, that there is a very unequal DiÅ¿tribution made of the Sap; Å¿eeing that the Fruit-buds are form'd only upon the Top of the weak Branches, and grow only at the Bottom of the Strong. I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s, it Å¿eems a
very difficult Task to me, to prove a Circulation in all theÅ¿e, and an infinite Number of other Examples, that I could produce upon this OccaÅ¿ion.
If we can prove therefore that there is no Circulation in Å¿ome Plants, I Å¿ee no reaÅ¿on why we may not poÅ¿itively conclude againÅ¿t the AdmiÅ¿Å¿ion of it in others.

But to give a further DemonÅ¿tration of the ImpoÅ¿Å¿ibility of this Circulation, let us but conÅ¿ider, that upon the AdmiÅ¿Å¿ion of it, we muÅ¿t Å¿uppoÅ¿e in every Branch, three diÅ¿tinct, and Å¿eparate PaÅ¿Å¿ages, viz. two for the going, and returning of the imperfect Sap, and a third for the return of it when it is arriv'd at its Perfection, namely, to convey it to that Place where it is to make its ReÅ¿idence. I do not Å¿ay there muÅ¿t be PaÅ¿Å¿ages for its RiÅ¿ing and DeÅ¿cending, becauÅ¿e it happens very frequently, that the Branches hang downward, and Fruit-Branches generally grow in that PoÅ¿ture; Å¿o that to Å¿peak properly, we cannot Å¿ay that the Sap AÅ¿cends, when really it DeÅ¿cends; and for this ReaÅ¿on I choÅ¿e rather to Å¿ay barely, that the Sap will need Å¿everal Ways or PaÅ¿Å¿ages for the Conveyance of it in its going and return.

For InÅ¿tance, I deÅ¿ire to know where they will find theÅ¿e three diÅ¿tinct PaÅ¿Å¿ages in a Cherry-Stalk, or how the Sap, which in its firÅ¿t Motion, Å¿hould have riÅ¿en to the Extremity, or Top, and then return'd back immediately down to the Roots: how I Å¿ay it Å¿hould be determin'd by Nature, to deÅ¿cend to the Cherry, which hangs down, and afterwards re-aÅ¿cend to that Place, where it turn'd out of the way that lead it upward, and from thence fall into that Path which was to convey it to the Root, and at laÅ¿t re-conduct it to the Place where it is finally lodg'd, to Å¿upply the Exigencies of the Fruit and Leaves.

I would ask further, Whether or no there be not a Circulation of Sap in the Fruit, as well as in the Tree; if Å¿o, then theÅ¿e two Saps, muÅ¿t, in their Return, have each of them their particular Way (which will cauÅ¿e a great Multiplication of Ways) or elÅ¿e they muÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿arily mix together, and then would enÅ¿ue an unlucky ConfuÅ¿ion of the two Saps, one of which is affirm'd, by them, to be much Purer and Nobler than the other.

According to this HypotheÅ¿is, the Sap muÅ¿t make a great many Journeys backward and forward, which is a thing very diÅ¿agreeable to Nature, who affects to be plain and Å¿imple in all her Operations. Why therefore may we not rather Å¿ay, that the Sap acquires its Perfection that very Moment in which it arrives at the Roots; juÅ¿t as the Air is illuminated in every part, immediately upon the Sun's beginning to appear above the Horizon? But further, admitting that this Circulation were neceÅ¿Å¿ary for perfecting the Sap, I would fain be Å¿atisfy'd where it is that the Sap receives this Perfection. It cannot be at its firÅ¿t entrance into the Roots, becauÅ¿e, according to the Principles of our AntagoniÅ¿ts, it is there but in an imperfect and indigeÅ¿ted State; neither can it be when it is arrived at the Extremities of the Boughs, or Fruit, Å¿eeing it doth not continue there, but has yet two Stages to travel further; for if it take up its ReÅ¿t in thoÅ¿e Extremities, it muÅ¿t then follow, that it was come to its compleat Perfection, and conÅ¿equently would have no need of returning to its firÅ¿t SourÅ¿e. Neither can it be Å¿aid to be thus perfect at its Å¿econd coming into the Roots, becauÅ¿e then certainly it would take up its final ReÅ¿idence with them; for Å¿ince it is indifferent to the Sap, when it is once perfectly digeÅ¿ted, whether it be employed in the Formation of the Roots, Trunk, or Branches, Leaves or Fruits; it would undoubtedly fix it Å¿elf in the very firÅ¿t Place, where it Å¿hould find it Å¿elf qualified with all the Degrees of Perfection requiÅ¿ite to its Nature.

Again, SuppoÅ¿ing that the Extremity, or Top of the Branch, to which the Sap was to have riÅ¿en, were cut off, I deÅ¿ire to know in what manner this Communication of Ways, and turning out of the one into the other, could be Å¿olved, and what would become of the Sap deÅ¿ign'd to have been made into Fruit, if it Å¿hould be Å¿topp'd in the midÅ¿t of the Way, before it could arrive at its Journey's End.

It cannot be deny'd that this Doctrine of Circulation, draws an infinite Number of Inconveniencies along with it, which, in my Judgment, can be prevented no other way, but by the following Account of the ProceÅ¿s of the Sap in Vegetation, viz. That the Vital Principle, which is the FirÅ¿t Mover in the Action of the Plant, being Invigorated by the Warmth of the Sun, immediately communicates to that MoiÅ¿ture, which was attracted by the Roots, Å¿uch a Quality as is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to the making of it perfect Sap, which nevertheleÅ¿s is not determined in its own Nature, to any particular. Production, but may indifferently become either Fruit, Leaves, or Trunk; and as that Sap has all the Degrees of Rarefaction that are requiÅ¿ite for
it, it muÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿arily be a light and Å¿ubtil Body, and conÅ¿equently extreamly adapted to riÅ¿e up to all the Extremities of the Branches. Where it is very plentiful, it exerts it Å¿elf, in producing a great Number of Boughs, and Leaves, all of them bearing a Size proportionable to the abundance of the aÅ¿cending Sap: If it aÅ¿cend but in a very Å¿mall Quantity, it is employ'd in bearing an infinite Number of BloÅ¿Å¿oms, and good Å¿tore of Fruit, though it will be but Å¿mall in its DimenÅ¿ions. And laÅ¿tly, where the Sap riÅ¿es in a moderate Proportion in Å¿ome certain Places, as either upon the Top of the weak Branches, or the lower part of the Strong, it there Å¿ignalizes it Å¿elf in the Productions of Buds, and of large and beautiful Fruit.

But now to give a clear and rational Account of this admirable DiÅ¿tribution of the Sap unto every part of the Tree, either for the Beginning, Continuing, or Compleating, and Determining it in its juÅ¿t BigneÅ¿s and Proportion, is a Work above Humane Performance. Nature Å¿eems expreÅ¿ly to have deny'd us that Priviledge, as if Å¿he had Å¿eem'd induÅ¿triouÅ¿ly to hide from us, under a thick Veil, the Manner, both of her Conception and Production; Å¿o that hitherto, our ordinary Faculties have not been able to fathom this myÅ¿terious Subject of Vegetation.

I will not deny but that there is a Circulation of the Blood in all Animals; forasmuch as the VeÅ¿Å¿els with their Extremities and InÅ¿ertions, and indeed the whole Structure of their Body is Å¿o exactly entire, and perfect in all its Extent, as that we cannot conceive an abrupt Beginning or End of them. Hence it is that they are Å¿o excellently fitted for the Reception of the Blood and Spirits, and reÅ¿training them from iÅ¿Å¿uing out at any Extremity. But in Trees, whoÅ¿e encreaÅ¿ing in length is continually form'd outwardly, we muÅ¿t Å¿uppoÅ¿e the VeÅ¿Å¿els to be open at their Extremities, and that they receive their Augmentation in length, on their OutÅ¿ide, as the whole MaÅ¿s of the Tree doth; Å¿o that there is no Analogy between the VeÅ¿Å¿els in the Body of an Animal, and thoÅ¿e in a Tree, and conÅ¿equently the Inference deduced from that CompariÅ¿on, muÅ¿t needs be erroneous.

The third QueÅ¿tion, wherein I deÅ¿ire to be Å¿atisfy'd, viz. Whether, upon Å¿uppoÅ¿ition that there be Å¿uch a Circulation, we muÅ¿t Å¿ay that there is but one general Circulation in each reÅ¿pective Tree, or elÅ¿e that there are as many particular Circulations as there are Branches, is perhaps as difficult to reÅ¿olve as any. For if we admit but one in general, we Å¿hall be hard put to it to give an Account how a Slip Å¿et in the Ground, comes to take, Å¿o as in a Å¿hort time to become a perfect Tree. We muÅ¿t be forc'd to Å¿ay, that in every one of theÅ¿e Branches there was a true Circulation, which ceas'd from Action as Å¿oon as they were cut off from the Tree upon which they grew; but that as Å¿oon as by their Re-plantation they were reÅ¿tor'd to a Condition of Acting of themÅ¿elves, their Circulation alÅ¿o began to reÅ¿ume its Action; and by theÅ¿e Steps they came to be perfect Trees.

If therefore, to give a ReaÅ¿on for this Growth of Slips, we muÅ¿t admit of a particular Circulation in every Branch, we muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be forc'd to admit of many Circulations in every Branch. For Å¿ince any Branch may be divided into Å¿everal Parts, if every one of theÅ¿e Parts be Å¿et in the Ground, with all the due CircumÅ¿tances belonging to them, they will as eaÅ¿ily take to grow, as if they had been entire Branches. But this Solution will draw us into a ProgreÅ¿Å¿us in infinitum, than which, in Ratiocination, nothing can be more abÅ¿urd.

Thus, when a Layer of a Vine being put into the Ground, takes a new Root, and thereupon that Part of the Layer next to the Earth, which before was the Å¿malleÅ¿t, becomes in a little time thicker than the Part next adjoyning to the Tree: MuÅ¿t we not of neceÅ¿Å¿ity have recourÅ¿e to a new Circulation, Å¿ince the former Å¿eems plainly to be at an end, or at leaÅ¿t to have become altogether uÅ¿eleÅ¿s I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s, I cannot find any Expedient of adjuÅ¿ting all theÅ¿e particular Circulations, with the general one, to make them act in Conformity with, and Subordination to it, when they are all together in the Å¿ame Tree at the Å¿ame time.

Such a Cloud of Difficulties and Inconveniencies have prevail'd with me not to give any Credit to this new Opinion of the Circulation of the Sap, though I have at the Å¿ame time an extreme Veneration for thoÅ¿e Worthy and Learned PerÅ¿ons, who are the Authors of it.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.

argument.p: Reflections upon the Opinion that maintains the Conveyance of the NouriÅ¿hment through the upper parts of the Plant.

div.p: THere have been Å¿ome of Opinion that the NouriÅ¿hment of the Tree is not only derived to it through the Pores, and by the Operation of the Roots in the Earth, but that there is likewiÅ¿e Å¿ome Contribution of maintenance afforded by the Air, and Å¿ubtilly conveyed to it through the upper parts of the Tree. This Opinion of theirs is grounded upon this ObÅ¿ervation, That if you make a very Å¿trait ligature round any Branch, or even if you Å¿trip the Bark off it, the Boughs that are below that part Å¿o tyed or Å¿tripp'd, will notwithÅ¿tanding encreaÅ¿e both in length and thickneÅ¿s.

But to this I AnÅ¿wer, FirÅ¿t, That in Å¿ome Vegetables, viz. In Almonds, and Stones of Fruit, as alÅ¿o in ordinary Seeds, there is no NeceÅ¿Å¿ity for this Aerial NouriÅ¿hment, Å¿ince the whole Series of their Vegetation is performed in the Bowels of the Earth without having the leaÅ¿t Communication with the Air.

Secondly, I AnÅ¿wer that it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to tye any Branch Å¿o Å¿traitly as that the Sap (a Liquor not only very Å¿ubtil and delicate, but alÅ¿o very Impetuous in its Operation) Å¿hall not inÅ¿inuate it Å¿elf, and find Å¿ome paÅ¿Å¿age through; for tho' the main Å¿tream of the Sap riÅ¿es up between the Bark and the Tree, yet it is certain that Å¿ome little quantity doth conÅ¿tantly penetrate through the Fibres of the Å¿olid Wood, neither is it any Wonder if Nature, who out of her great abhorrence of a Vacuum does frequently perform Å¿uch extraordinary and Å¿urprizing Wonders, may likewiÅ¿e in this caÅ¿e force up the Sap (which was Å¿top'd in its AÅ¿cent either by that ligature or Å¿tripping off the Bark) through the very Å¿ubÅ¿tance or Fibres of the Wood, in order to its NouriÅ¿hing the upper parts of the Tree, which muÅ¿t Infallibly have periÅ¿hed without a Å¿eaÅ¿onable Supply.

LaÅ¿tly, I Å¿ay it may be AnÅ¿wer'd with very good ReaÅ¿on, that this DiÅ¿tenÅ¿ion or Tumor of Å¿uch tyed Branches in their breadth, and accretion to their length, may be Stiled rather a kind of DropÅ¿ie, than a real and firm Augmentation of their Å¿ound Å¿ubÅ¿tance and continuity; for Experience tells us, That in Trees thus tyed or Å¿tripp'd, the upper parts of the Tree come to dye in a very little time, as they muÅ¿t needs do if the Channel be not open'd again to give a free paÅ¿Å¿age to the true NouriÅ¿hment of the Tree.

Now to give Å¿ome other InÅ¿tances, to confirm our Opinion, we may conÅ¿ider that thoÅ¿e Plants whoÅ¿e Roots lye very deep in the Ground, as Tulip-bulbs, &c. do always grow up to the greateÅ¿t heighth.
As alÅ¿o we may obÅ¿erve the Pointed and Pyramidal Extremity of all Branches; every one of which Å¿eem in the manner of their Growing, as with one conÅ¿ent, Naturally to tend upward.

To which we may add, as another Corroborating CircumÅ¿tance, the Å¿hooting out of new Sprouts, upon the Back or Elbow of Å¿uch Branches as are bent violently, or by force, to the Ground; the Suckers that grow out of the foot of the Tree when it has been injured at the top: the decay of the Branches at the Extremities notwithÅ¿tanding their being Å¿till vigorous at the Root, as alÅ¿o the Withering and Fading of Plants at the top of their Leaves in hot Weather when they are newly Set: All theÅ¿e InÅ¿tances Å¿eem to me evidently Contradictory of any deÅ¿cent of the Sap which they Å¿uppoÅ¿e to be caus'd by the Influence of the Air, either upon the Bark of the Tree, or the Extremity of the Branches.

The different TaÅ¿tes in Fruits which always have a Å¿mack of their Soil, are a Å¿ufficient proof that their NouriÅ¿hment is derived from a Soil of Å¿uch a Savour, and not from the Air, which has none at all; and certainly if any of the Sap could find a paÅ¿Å¿age acroÅ¿s, or through the Å¿olid Wood, it might as well enter in the Å¿ame manner through the Skin of the Fruit; and Å¿o the Stalk, which by a long PreÅ¿cription has hitherto been look'd upon as the true and only Channel for Conveyance of the Aliment to the Fruit, would have a great many Partners in that Office, and conÅ¿equently become in a manner wholly uÅ¿eleÅ¿s.

I will not deny but that it is highly neceÅ¿Å¿ary for Trees to enjoy the benefit of a temperate Air, whereby the Bark may be rendered the more pliable and eaÅ¿ie to
be dilated and loos'd from its incloÅ¿ed Trunk, to give the freer paÅ¿Å¿age for the Sap in its riÅ¿ing up from the Root. Indeed, I can never be perÅ¿uaded to think that any NouriÅ¿hment can be conveyed through that Rind, but am of Opinion rather, that a Tree depriv'd of all its Top Branches, in a very hot Region; as for inÅ¿tance, we may Å¿uppoÅ¿e a Row of Trees cut even at the Tops, and Planted in a Hedge to the South under the Torrid Zone, would be Å¿o far from drawing in any NouriÅ¿hment through the Bole, that even the Sap would be Å¿o much hindred by the heat of the Air from aÅ¿cending by its ordinary paÅ¿Å¿age, as that the upper part of the Tree would Infallibly periÅ¿h; whence it would follow, that the Sap being made unable to riÅ¿e up to the Å¿mall upper Boughs, would burÅ¿t out at the foot into an infinite number of new and Å¿mall Productions.

As for thoÅ¿e who from the Experiment of making an InciÅ¿ion into a Tree, pretend to prove this IntromiÅ¿Å¿ion of Sap into the upper part, or to defend the Circulation of the Sap from that Liquor which will run plentifully out of Å¿uch an InciÅ¿ion, in my Opinion they build their HypotheÅ¿is upon a very Sandy Foundation.

For, FirÅ¿t, If we either cut or break off the Top of any Plant, the Sap will be Å¿een plainly to guÅ¿h out in great abundance from each of the two Extremities bubling out of every Pore, as well in that part which retain'd its Situation, as in the other which was Å¿eparated from the former.

Secondly, If the InciÅ¿ion be made at the bottom, there will run out not only Å¿ome part of that Sap which is continually aÅ¿cending, but alÅ¿o a little of that which being already upon its riÅ¿e, and having till then been Å¿upported by the Å¿ucceeding Sap, muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity fall down when deÅ¿titute of that Support and Foundation of which it was depriv'd by that InciÅ¿ion.

To conclude, If this InciÅ¿ion were a Å¿ufficient proof of this AÅ¿Å¿ertion, it muÅ¿t follow that all the uppermoÅ¿t Sap muÅ¿t make its way out at one Å¿ingle hole, as we Å¿ee the Water in a VeÅ¿Å¿el runs all out at any hole it meets with: But Experience tells us, That how many InciÅ¿ions Å¿oever you make, either above or below the firÅ¿t, the Sap will iÅ¿Å¿ue through all of them, but moÅ¿t abundantly through the loweÅ¿t, and in leaÅ¿t quantity through the higheÅ¿t, which certainly muÅ¿t proceed from the ReaÅ¿on which I have given before.

div.head: CHAP. XX.

argument.p: Reflections upon the undiÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hable likeneÅ¿s of the Sap in the Wood, Leaves, and Fruit.

div.p: THere is hardly any Plant growing with us, during the whole Summer, puts out more Roots, and conÅ¿equently produces greater plenty of Sap, than the Fig-Tree does; Å¿o that we may venture to build our ObÅ¿ervations concerning Sap in general, upon Å¿uch Remarks as a particular Enquiry into the Nature of this Tree will afford us: The Sap whereof appears to me to have exactly the Å¿ame Colour, TaÅ¿te, and ConÅ¿iÅ¿tence both in the Wood of the Tree, and the Stalk both of the Leaves and Fruit, that it has in the Fruit it Å¿elf, whilÅ¿t it is yet Green; for when it comes to be Ripe and fit for Gathering, there is not the leaÅ¿t Å¿ign to be perceived of that white Sap with which it was Å¿o plentifully impregnated before it was come to Maturity.

From hence we may very well advance this general concluÅ¿ion, That there can be no material difference between that Sap which goes to the forming of the Fruit, and that which enters into the CompoÅ¿ition of all the other parts of the Tree, Å¿ince there is Å¿o great a Conformity between them at the time of its paÅ¿Å¿ing out of the Stalk into the Fruit. So that admitting the Sap for Fruit to be endued with Å¿ome particular degrees of Perfection beyond what are to be found in the Sap of the Tree, yet what do they think becomes of it, when the Fruit which it was deÅ¿ign'd to have form'd and nouriÅ¿h'd, chances to periÅ¿h, as oftentimes it doth, even in the Embryo, or at leaÅ¿t before it comes to Perfection? In this caÅ¿e it muÅ¿t certainly be mixed with the reÅ¿t of the Sap, and be equally employ'd with it in the Production of Å¿omething that is not Fruit.

And this will Å¿uggeÅ¿t the ReaÅ¿on to us why Trees without Fruit abound more in Wood than thoÅ¿e that bear Fruit plentifully; which according to the Opinion I ever had, is nothing elÅ¿e but the different proportions of the Sap; the Å¿maller quantity
whereof cauÅ¿es plenty of BloÅ¿Å¿oms and Fruits, as the greater quantity produces the like EncreaÅ¿e both in the Body and Leaves.

To this may be added, what I have already repeated Å¿o often, viz. That the Fruit grows at the Top of the weak Branches, but at the Bottom of the Å¿trong; whence it appears, that no part of the Branch is exempted from bearing, and that they are under a very great miÅ¿take, who, while they pretend to render an account why the weak Branches are generally moÅ¿t loaded with Fruit, and particularly towards the Extremities, put us off with this ReaÅ¿on, That it is for the better concoction and refining of the Sap, which (Å¿ay they) can be effected no other way than by Å¿o long a PaÅ¿Å¿age and Percolation through the narrow Conveyances.

But Å¿uppoÅ¿e this Fancy had Å¿ome probability of ReaÅ¿on in it, how Å¿hall we explain the Production of Grapes, Quinces, Mulberries, Azerolles, Rasberries, &c. which receive their Formation at the Å¿ame time that the Wood does upon which they grow: For Example: There grows upon every old Branch of a Vine that uÅ¿ed to be Pruned in the Spring, as many new Branches as there were Eyes left upon it. Upon theÅ¿e Branches, and at the very Å¿ame time with them are the Grapes formed, which ordinarily do not grow nearer to the end than the third, fourth, or fifth Knot, for from that diÅ¿tance the Branch runs up only in length, without bearing any Fruit.

This being granted, which indeed cannot be denied, I would ask them what Ground they have to aÅ¿Å¿ert, That the Sap is not Å¿ufficiently prepared till it arrive at one of theÅ¿e three Eyes, and there receive its perfect DigeÅ¿tion: for they divide the Sap into two Å¿orts, viz. DigeÅ¿ted, and IndigeÅ¿ted; the former they tell us is employed both in forming the Grapes in Å¿ome one of thoÅ¿e three Knots, and in Production of the Leaves and Branches; and yet there is always Å¿ome Wood, Pulp, and Husk of the Grape between every one of theÅ¿e Knots, to the Formation of which both theÅ¿e Saps did contribute.

LaÅ¿tly, After this Secretion of the DigeÅ¿ted Sap from the IndigeÅ¿ted, they come both of them to be re-united in order to the Production of Boughs and Leaves only, for the remaining part of the Year. I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s ingenuouÅ¿ly, I am not quick enough to penetrate into, and comprehend theÅ¿e Å¿o Å¿ubtile and refined Notions of our modern PhiloÅ¿ophers.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.

argument.p: Reflections upon the Opinion of thoÅ¿e, who from the Generation of Animals Argue concerning the Production of Fruits.

div.p: THere are Å¿ome, as I have formerly obÅ¿erved in my TreatiÅ¿e of Pruning, who Treating of the Production of Fruits, proceed the Å¿ame way they do in their ConÅ¿iderations about the Generation of Animals. Animals (Å¿ay they) do not Procreate their Like, but when they are in their Vigor, Generation being an Act of Vigor in all Natural Productions. Now Å¿ince Trees are alÅ¿o Natural Beings, 'twill hence follow, that they are never Capable of bearing Fruit, but when they are in their full Strength and Vigour, it being abÅ¿urd to make the Production of Fruit a Å¿ign of the WeakneÅ¿s of the Tree. And they further add. That in all the Works of Nature, the CauÅ¿e is known by the Effects, and every Extraordinary Effect muÅ¿t be produced by a Å¿uitable Strength and Vigour in its Agent.
TheÅ¿e indeed are very plauÅ¿ible Arguments and Inferences, and which, when mentioned by PerÅ¿ons of Reputation, may prevail with Å¿uch as do not Å¿ee into the WeakneÅ¿s of them.

But though I highly EÅ¿teem the PerÅ¿ons, and the Works of thoÅ¿e Ingenious Men, who Argue after this manner; yet, when to expoÅ¿e my Notions, they make me Advance Å¿uch a one as this: That the abundance of MoiÅ¿ture which makes the Trees produce a great quantity of Branches and Leaves, is an Effect of their Vigour; they muÅ¿t give me leave to Å¿ay Å¿omething in my own Defence. I might well Å¿ay, and now I Å¿ay it again, That BloÅ¿Å¿oms and Fruits on Trees are Å¿igns of their WeakneÅ¿s, or, that they have but little Sap; as on the contrary, a great number of fair Branches without Fruit, is of the Vigour, or of the abounding quantity of their Sap. For I do not think that the word MoiÅ¿ture does properly Å¿ignifie the Sap in a Tree, and therefore Å¿hould not be underÅ¿tood in that AÅ¿Å¿ertion of mine for any thing elÅ¿e, but the moiÅ¿ture of the Earth where a Tree is planted; there being Å¿o great
a Difference between it and Sap. And we Å¿eldom Å¿ee any very great Quantity of Sap in Å¿uch Fruit-Trees as have very much MoiÅ¿ture about their Roots. Nay, We Å¿ometimes Å¿ee them die, by having their Roots too much drenched in Water; and they will never take well in very wet Ground; whereas, for the moÅ¿t part, they afford both much Lop-wood and Fruit, if they have naturally a Vigorous vital Principle, and are planted in a good Earth, indifferently moÅ¿ten'd, and do thereupon Å¿end forth good Roots to furniÅ¿h the upper Parts with a Å¿ufficient Quantity of Sap.

TheÅ¿e Terms therefore of MoiÅ¿ture and Sap, are not to be promiÅ¿cuouÅ¿ly uÅ¿ed, the one being to be underÅ¿tood only for that NouriÅ¿hment which is in the Tree, and the other for Å¿uch Water as may be about the Root of it.

That which has given OccaÅ¿ion for Mens arguing upon the Production of Plants, after the Å¿ame manner they do upon the Generation of Animals, has been this, as I conceive, that they imagin'd the Fruit to be the Å¿ame, in reÅ¿pect to the Tree, that the young Animal is to its Syre that begat it; and wou'd thence conclude, that as Lyon's Whelp'd, for InÅ¿tance, exactly reÅ¿embles its Syre in all its EÅ¿Å¿entials, Å¿o a Pear, or a Cherry muÅ¿t, in its Formation, that of its Tree, Å¿eeing that in time it may grow up to be as tall and big, and every way like it, juÅ¿t as the young Lyon does at length equal the Old One, both in LargeneÅ¿s and Proportion of Parts.

Now Nature it Å¿elf plainly Å¿hews us, that it does not act the Å¿ame way in both theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es; and that the moÅ¿t that can be gather'd from Å¿uch ConÅ¿iderations, is, hat one Part of the Fruit of each Å¿ort of Trees, is the Å¿ame with reÅ¿pect to its Tree, that the Seed of the Animals is to its reÅ¿pective Animal.

I am not Å¿o well skill'd in Anatomy, as to know, whether the Seminal Matter in Animals require as much Force and Vigor to be formed in the Body, as it afterwards does in being duly employ'd in order to Generation: But Å¿ure I am that no Man ever diÅ¿tinctly perceiv'd in himÅ¿elf, either the Time or Manner of its Formation, any more than he did thoÅ¿e CircumÅ¿tances of the Formation of his MuÅ¿cles, Bones, or Cartilages: and that 'tis certainly a ProviÅ¿ion in Nature, that of the whole MaÅ¿s of NouriÅ¿hment, one Part Å¿hould go to the making of Seed, and the reÅ¿t Å¿hould be imployed either to the EncreaÅ¿e, or the PreÅ¿ervation of the Animal, without ever making any Å¿enÅ¿ible Effort, either in Framing, or perfecting any of the Internal Parts of the Body.

And beÅ¿ides, he will find himÅ¿elf mightily miÅ¿taken, that Å¿hall lay down this as a Å¿tanding Rule, that every kind of Fruit is in the Nature of a CaÅ¿e to Å¿uch a Seed as is capable of producing the Å¿ame Å¿ort of Tree with that it Å¿elf grew upon. The moÅ¿t ordinary way of Multiplying Trees, being not by their Fruits. And indeed who ever Å¿aw a Prunier de Perdrigon, or a Bigarotier grow from the Stones of the Fruit? a Fig, or Mulberry-Tree from the Seed, a Bon-ChreÅ¿tien, or Bergamotte from the Kernels of Å¿uch Pears? Though I know 'tis common for an Oak to come of an Acorn, and a CheÅ¿tnut-Tree of its Nuts, and Å¿ome others to be produc'd in the Å¿ame way; yet Nature has provided other ways of multiplying them, viz. by young Siens growing out at the Roots, and Å¿everal Å¿orts of Graffs. Some of thoÅ¿e ways which Nature makes uÅ¿e of in preÅ¿erving the Å¿everal Kinds of Trees, I have already treated of in another Place: And now I come poÅ¿itively to affirm,

That if a Man firÅ¿t lays down Å¿uch a Maxim as this, that the only ReaÅ¿on why Å¿ome Fir-Trees thrive well, is, becauÅ¿e they grow on the South Å¿ide of a Mountain; And that others do not, becauÅ¿e they Å¿tand on the North Side of it: And thence draw Inferences, and apply them to Fruit-Trees, Å¿uch Arguments muÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿arily be very weak, for theÅ¿e two Å¿orts of Trees are Å¿ubjects very different, and therefore Å¿hould be as differently conÅ¿idered.

For what is chiefly to be conÅ¿idered in Fruit-Trees, is Å¿carcely at all taken notice of in Firrs. In theÅ¿e latter, we are only to compare one Part with another, that is, barely to conÅ¿ider the whole Bulk and Extent of the Tree, to Å¿ee whether it be good for MaÅ¿ts, Planks, Beams, or JoiÅ¿ts. But in the other, all the Branches are to be carefully conÅ¿idered, both the Great and Small, which may be of uÅ¿e, and which not. In theÅ¿e we obÅ¿erve the Working of Nature, in DiÅ¿tributing the Sap to every Å¿ingle Part of the Tree. But in the other, only to what particular UÅ¿e it may be put in the Building of a Ship. Nature is not concern'd whether Å¿uch a particular Firr-Tree be fit for Boards, and whether, or no, it be put to that UÅ¿e; whereas it may not be improperly Å¿aid, that Å¿he is highly concerned in the Productions of Fruit-Trees, which are to bethe Food of the nobleÅ¿t Part of the Creation. And yet of all that is performed in the whole CourÅ¿e of Vegetation, theÅ¿e Fruits
coÅ¿t Nature the leaÅ¿t pains in making, and the PhiloÅ¿opher the moÅ¿t in undertataking them.

And the more to puzzle and confound the Curious Enquirers in the Works of Nature, it proceeds in the Formation and NouriÅ¿hment of Trees in a way quite different from that wherein perfect Animals are Generated and PreÅ¿erved; As if it thereby deÅ¿igned to prevent the drawing of any manner of ConÅ¿equences from the one, whereby to underÅ¿tand or illuÅ¿trate the other.

The DiÅ¿tribution of NouriÅ¿hment in perfect Animals is made in equal Proportions to each of the Members, which exactly anÅ¿wer one another; Å¿o that the Right Arm or Thigh uÅ¿ually receives no more than the Left; and Å¿o of the reÅ¿t: Whereas in Fruit-Trees the Sap is diÅ¿tributed in very unequal MeaÅ¿ures; few of the Branches being perfectly of the Å¿ame bigneÅ¿s, but Å¿ome very large, others very Å¿mall, and a third Å¿ort of a middle Å¿ize between both; and conÅ¿equently requiring a proportionable Quantity of Sap.

It alÅ¿o Å¿ometimes happens that Å¿ome of the Å¿maller Branches receiving more Sap than that particular uÅ¿e for which they Å¿eem'd to be deÅ¿igned, did require, grow in a Å¿hort time to an extraordinary bigneÅ¿s; and on the contrary, others that at firÅ¿t Å¿eem'd large ones, receiving a leÅ¿s Quantity of Sap than was neceÅ¿Å¿ary, never grow much bigger than thoÅ¿e of the Å¿maller Å¿ize.

And this may not unfitly be illuÅ¿trated by thoÅ¿e Alterations we frequently obÅ¿erve in Å¿ome Rivers, where the Main Stream does not always go in the very Å¿ame place: Sometimes you'll Å¿ee it bear Å¿trongly upon one Bank, and within a few Months after, quite removed to the oppoÅ¿ite Å¿ide, or elÅ¿e Å¿ettle in the midÅ¿t between both. Only 'tis to be obÅ¿erved, that whether Å¿ide Å¿oever it takes to, it commonly makes no very long continuance there.

For after the very Å¿ame manner, we frequently Å¿ee Å¿trange Alterations in the Motion of the Sap in the Boughs, which are properly its Channel, and where it never conÅ¿tantly keeps the Å¿ame courÅ¿e it firÅ¿t took. One Year it flows in Å¿o great a quantity into one of the Å¿maller Boughs, which was juÅ¿t upon bearing, that it quite alters its DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition, and puts it upon lengthening and enlarging it Å¿elf; that Matter which otherwiÅ¿e would have been Fruit, aÅ¿Å¿uming the Nature of, and turning into Wood.
The next Year it may happen, that what formerly was employ'd in enlarging the Boughs, now changes its Office, and feeds them chiefly in order to the bearing of Fruit.

Another Year you Å¿hall Å¿ee a Branch, which at firÅ¿t look'd as if it would have grown into a MaÅ¿Å¿ive Bough, begin all on a Å¿uddain to bear; the Channel through which the Sap paÅ¿Å¿ed before in a great quantity, being Å¿ome way altered, and thereby the Branch hinder'd from growing any bigger than thoÅ¿e of the leÅ¿Å¿er Å¿ize.

And 'tis further obÅ¿ervable, that Nature has for each kind of perfect Animals its own peculiar Mould, wherein they are all as it were caÅ¿t exactly into the very Å¿ame Å¿hape, and have Å¿uch an Air as makes them very nearly reÅ¿emble each other; whereas in the DeÅ¿igning and Forming of Fruit-Trees, it neither obÅ¿erves Proportion of Parts, nor Equality in BigneÅ¿s, nor ReÅ¿emblance in Shape. In perfect Animals, the Eyes and the Ears, the Belly and the Feet, &c. are always orderly placed in the Å¿ame Parts of the Body: And none of theÅ¿e is ever Å¿uffered to grow in a wrong place, but when Å¿ome frightful MonÅ¿ter is to be produced: Whereas the Care of Nature is no further concerned about Fruit-Trees, but only that they Å¿end forth large Boughs, and yield good Fruit, whether it be on the top or below, on one Å¿ide or the other: Nay, it Å¿eems willing Å¿o far to comply with the Ingenious Gardiner, as to obÅ¿erve his Orders and Conduct in the Management of Trees, Å¿uffering them to receive what Å¿hape he Å¿hall appoint them, and even to produce what Branches and Fruit he will, and where he pleaÅ¿es.

Now Å¿ince many Productions may be in a Tree at the Å¿ame time, and there is no one Exteriour part of it which is not capable of producing, whereas this Work of Nature is only performed in one certain part of Animals; How unreaÅ¿onable is it to argue in all things concerning the Production of Trees, from the Generation of Animals?

There is a certain CourÅ¿e of Action in the Sap, which very few have the CurioÅ¿ity nicely to obÅ¿erve; and Å¿ome are Å¿o wholly taken up with Studies of a higher and more delightful Nature, or with BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s of greater Importance, that they cannot Å¿ufficiently apply themÅ¿elves to Å¿uch ObÅ¿ervations. And though it would be a very
great AccompliÅ¿hment in any PerÅ¿on that has attained to Å¿ome conÅ¿iderable Perfefection in two or three Sciences, if it were poÅ¿Å¿ible for him to make himÅ¿elf as much MaÅ¿ter of all the reÅ¿t; Yet a Man may properly be Å¿aid to be a Good AÅ¿tronomer, a Geometrician, or Architect, though he be not perfectly well Skill'd in all the other Arts and Sciences. And it would be an unjuÅ¿t CenÅ¿ure, to Å¿ay, That Å¿uch a Man is no Good Architect, becauÅ¿e he is not alÅ¿o a Good Gardiner. For though an Architects Skill in Building might juÅ¿tly be Å¿uÅ¿pected, who Å¿hould make a HouÅ¿e with Smoaking Chimneys, or Rooms that would not hold a Bed; Yet, 'twould be hard to QueÅ¿tion the Å¿ame Man's Abilities in Architecture, becauÅ¿e the Trees in his Orchard were not all well Ordered, or did not bear abundance of Good and Fair Fruit.

And Å¿peaking with Reference to a Gardiner, there are a great many Parts of curious Knowledge which he has no UÅ¿e of in his way, and would not in the leaÅ¿t contribute to the Advancement of his Skill or Art. As for inÅ¿tance, When one knows that the Marble of Å¿uch a Mountain at Genoua, or the Stone of Carriere de St. Leu are very good and fine, either to Build with, or to make Statues of; whereas thoÅ¿e of other Places are much CourÅ¿er, and leÅ¿s fit for Å¿uch UÅ¿es: Pray, Why Å¿hould a Man break his Brain to find out the ReaÅ¿ons of the Excellency of the one, the Imperfections of the other, Å¿ince he can neither Correct the one, nor make the other laÅ¿t for ever? All that is neceÅ¿Å¿ary in this CaÅ¿e, is, To know where to find the beÅ¿t, when he Å¿hall have occaÅ¿ion to make uÅ¿e of it; and where the bad is, that he may not meddle with it.

In Italy, the Firrs that grow on the South-Å¿ide of a Mountain are much better than thoÅ¿e that grow on the North Å¿ide of it. This many of us know upon our own Experience. But I believe a Man would find himÅ¿elf mightily miÅ¿taken, if without any regard to the difference of the Earth, he Å¿hould thence conclude, that the only ReaÅ¿on why the latter are Bad, is becauÅ¿e they grew up expoÅ¿ed to the North: For all our Modern Mariners agree, That the beÅ¿t Firrs for MaÅ¿ts come from the moÅ¿t Northern Parts of Norway; Or if on the contrary, he Å¿hould lay down this as the only ReaÅ¿on why Firrs that Å¿tand expoÅ¿ed to the South, are the BeÅ¿t; namely, BecauÅ¿e nothing elÅ¿e but the exceÅ¿Å¿ive Heat of the Sun can compreÅ¿s the Parts of that matter wherewith they are NouriÅ¿hed, and conÅ¿equently harden and Å¿trengthen the Fibers of Å¿uch Trees more than of thoÅ¿e that are not Å¿o directly expoÅ¿ed to its Influence: How will this way of Arguing hold concerning Å¿uch Firrs as are almoÅ¿t continually in a Frozen Condition? Pray, Is not Cold as apt to cloÅ¿e, and harden, and Å¿trengthen any thing as Heat? And is it not as uÅ¿ual for Rains to come from the South, as from the North? And conÅ¿equently are not Å¿uch things as as lie to the South, as liable to be kept moiÅ¿t, as thoÅ¿e that lie towards the North?

From all which it appears, how unÅ¿afe it is, in Treating of Vegetation, to go upon General ConÅ¿iderations; And that it is much better to examine Particulars; And that not barely with a DeÅ¿ign to Feed and Gratifie a vain and uÅ¿eleÅ¿s CurioÅ¿ity, but eÅ¿pecially to diÅ¿cover Å¿omething that may be of real UÅ¿e and Benefit to the ArtiÅ¿t in the way of his ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion. We Å¿hall therefore take little or no notice of Å¿uch Notions, as being but barely probable, are not Å¿ufficient to advance any general Maxime upon; and keep our Å¿elves from paying too great a defference to the Authority, and being PrepoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed with all the Opinions of PerÅ¿ons, who, not contenting themÅ¿elves to know, and to be juÅ¿tly eÅ¿teemed for their Skill in Å¿ome Things, take upon them to lay down Rules in others they do not Å¿o well underÅ¿tand.

Every Body knows that Trees that grow in an open Plain, and in a dry Earth, yield more Top-Wood then Å¿uch as grow in a ForeÅ¿t, and in a moiÅ¿t Ground. But I believe it matters not much whether Å¿uch Trees as grow in a Plain be more expoÅ¿ed to the South, or to the North; Such PoÅ¿itions being in Å¿ome Countries not at all taken notice of. And this is evident, particularly in the Vines of VerÅ¿enay, which are much better when they are expoÅ¿ed to the North, then to the South, notwithÅ¿tanding that AuÅ¿ter vites Å¿ibi objectas nobilitat, Aquilo f â¢ cundat, Elige plus velis quam melius. CreÅ¿centius Palladius. General Maxim of the Ancients to the contrary.âNow he that taking theÅ¿e Words in their Å¿trict Literal SenÅ¿e for an UniverÅ¿al Maxim, Å¿hould go about to Maintain and Propagate it by ReaÅ¿ons and Arguments, would find many DiÅ¿Å¿enters from this Opinion of his and the Ancients.

How NeceÅ¿Å¿ary Å¿oever the Heat and Influences of the Sun may be in themÅ¿elves, and how advantageouÅ¿ly Å¿oever any Plant may be expoÅ¿ed to it, yet if it have not the Benefit of a good Earth, as well as the ProÅ¿pect of the Mid-day, or Afternoon Sun, we very Å¿eldom Å¿ee that its Productions are any way Extraordinary. Hence comes that vaÅ¿t Difference we Å¿ee in Vines, that have all exactly the Å¿ame PoÅ¿ition towards the Sun: And hence alÅ¿o it comes that we have Å¿o much MarÅ¿h Ground that is wholly UÅ¿eleÅ¿s, Å¿o many Plains that are Rich and Fruitful even without Tillage, and Å¿o many Mountains that produce nothing at all. If the Pipes of an Organ, or any other InÅ¿trument, be not good and well made, to what purpoÅ¿e is it to put them into the moÅ¿t Skillful MuÅ¿icians Hand? Are not all Mens Souls of the Å¿ame Immaterial SubÅ¿tance, and equally Perfect in themÅ¿elves? To what therefore Å¿hall we aÅ¿cribe that Wonderful Difference we find between the Abilities of WiÅ¿e MiniÅ¿ters of State, or Great PhiloÅ¿ophers, and the others who are Å¿o Dull and Rude, that they are capable neither of Ingenious Arts, nor Common Civility, but to the Difference of their Temper, and of the Organs of their Body?

'Tis moÅ¿t certain therefore, that the Good or Bad DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the Earth is chiefly to be look'd upon as the Principal CauÅ¿e of whatÅ¿oever Difference we find in its ProductionsâAnd in order to the Å¿everal uÅ¿es they are to be put to, all that is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be here further obÅ¿erved, is, That Å¿uch Trees as grow in large and thick ForeÅ¿ts are much taller, and their Timber Å¿treighter than thoÅ¿e that grow in thin Woods or Thickets.âThe ReaÅ¿on whereof may be this, That every Tree having a kind of Natural DeÅ¿ire to Enjoy the Benefit of the Sun, and as it were Fearing to be Å¿tifled by the cloÅ¿eneÅ¿s and over-topping of thoÅ¿e next it, endeavours to raiÅ¿e its Head Å¿o high as to reach the free and open Air: And all of them having, if I may Å¿o call it, this Natural InÅ¿tinct, each endeavours to overtop the reÅ¿t; and Å¿o all of them grow to a much greater height than thoÅ¿e that Å¿tand alone: And if Å¿uch a ForeÅ¿t happen to be very thick, the Trees growing up too haÅ¿tily to an exceÅ¿Å¿ive height, have not a proportionable Bulk, whereas Å¿uch as grow up more at liberty, having no Å¿uch NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of growing high on a Å¿udden, make the beÅ¿t advantage of their NouriÅ¿hment, grow up leiÅ¿urely, and with a thickneÅ¿s anÅ¿werable to their height.
And this may be Å¿ufficient to Å¿atisfie our CurioÅ¿ity, as well as to Direct the ArtiÅ¿t what Å¿ort of Trees may be fit, and which not, for his Å¿everal purpoÅ¿es in Building.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.

argument.p: Reflections upon the Influences of the Moon in its Wain and Full, &c.

div.p: I Shall now, in the laÅ¿t place, conÅ¿ider thoÅ¿e SuperÅ¿titious ObÅ¿ervations our Modern Gard'ners make upon the Influences of the Moon in its Wain and Full.

I know they will take it ill, that I Å¿hould look upon that as a piece of SuperÅ¿tition, nay as downright Folly, which they pretend to have been the conÅ¿tant ObÅ¿ervation and Practice of all Times, and in all Parts of the World.âThey will tell you that, according to the Opinion of the Ancients, every Friday the Moon is in a kind of Wain; and that above all the reÅ¿t, Good Friday is to be made choice of for Sowing all manner of Seeds; inÅ¿omuch that Sowing upon that day Å¿uch whoÅ¿e Fruit you would have to be early Ripe, they will perÅ¿wade you that they will be Ripe exactly at the time you expect, Å¿uch for InÅ¿tance, as Melons, Cucumbers, PeaÅ¿e, &c.âAs alÅ¿o that thoÅ¿e you would not have to come Å¿o Å¿oon to their Maturity, will as exactly AnÅ¿wer your Expectation, namely all Å¿orts of Pot-Herbs, Coleworts, Lettuces, Ofeilles, &c. And all this doubtleÅ¿s out of a profound ReÅ¿pect they bear to the day whereon they were Å¿et. And that Å¿uch as are Å¿et in any other time of the Moon do quite fail the Gard'ners Expectations.

This they will not be convinced to be a groÅ¿s DeluÅ¿ion, as are alÅ¿o Å¿everal others which they have received by a kind of Tradition from the Ancients, namely Å¿uch as theÅ¿e, That neither Plants, nor Graffs, nor Lopped Trees, will be quick in Bearing, unleÅ¿s they be Å¿et, or cut in the Wain of the Moon. And that Å¿o many days as any of theÅ¿e is done after the Full, Å¿o many years the Å¿ooner will the Trees come to their Perfection in Bearing.

And they poÅ¿itively AÅ¿Å¿ert, That the only ReaÅ¿on why Å¿ome Trees are Å¿o long before they Bear, is becauÅ¿e they were either Set, or Cut, or Graffed while the Moon was either in the EncreaÅ¿e, or at the FullâThis they contend for as a
matter of UniverÅ¿al Experience, and beyond all manner of DiÅ¿pute, notwithÅ¿tanding all that can be Å¿aid, or Å¿hewn to the contrary.
But for my part, I think there is nothing more Ridiculous, whether we conÅ¿ider the Things themÅ¿elves they contend for, or their way of Proving what they AÅ¿Å¿ert.

As to the Things themÅ¿elves, I profeÅ¿s that I have for above 30 years, obÅ¿erved with all the exactneÅ¿s imaginable, whether the Å¿everal PhaÅ¿es of the Moon have Å¿uch different Influences upon Gardening, to the end I might follow an Opinion Å¿o UniverÅ¿ally received, if it Å¿hould prove true: And that after all, I find that all this is no more than the Old Sayings of Å¿ome Unexperienced and Ignorant Gard'ners, who deÅ¿igned thereby to cover their own Ignorance, and hoped to be remember'd for Å¿uch Jargon among Å¿uch as knew nothing at all of Husbandry.

I Å¿hould be the BoldeÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t InÅ¿olent Man in the World, if I Å¿hould Decry, or go about to DiÅ¿prove a Maxim that has obtained for Å¿o many Ages, and is mentioned by Å¿o many PerÅ¿ons Å¿o Å¿trongly perÅ¿waded of its Truth, and Å¿o Zealous in the Defence of it, if I had not the Authority of a long Experience free from all manner of Prejudice, to confirm what I advance againÅ¿t it.

'Tis true indeed, I have plaid the Critick in all the Å¿everal Parts of Gardening; and laying aÅ¿ide the Authority of Authors, and Modern Practice, I have expoÅ¿ed the Errors of the one, and the Faults of the other: All which I have done with no other DeÅ¿ign but only to Confirm and Improve what I found to be Good, and to Undeceive the World in what upon Experience proved to be otherwiÅ¿e.

And among theÅ¿e latter I may juÅ¿tly reckon this SuperÅ¿titious ObÅ¿ervation of the Moons Wain; for in what Quarter of the Moon Å¿oever you Set your Graffs, provided you do it well, and at Å¿uch times of the Year as are proper for Å¿uch or Å¿uch Graffs; and upon Å¿uch Trees as Suit with the Graffs you Å¿et upon them, that the Stock be good, and rightly Qualified, that it neither Å¿end up too much, nor too little Sap; and that the Graff
â¢ e neither too Å¿trong, nor too weak, your Experiment will, if not always, yet for the moÅ¿t part, have the Å¿ame SucceÅ¿s: Or if the Graff happen to fail, you will have no occaÅ¿ion to blame your Å¿elf for it.

In like manner, Sow or Set any Å¿ort of Seeds or Plants, in all the Å¿everal Quarters of the Moon, and I will promiÅ¿e you the Å¿ame SucceÅ¿s in all, provided your Earth be good and well prepared; that there be no Fault in your Seeds or Plants, and that the SeaÅ¿on be favourable: And that the firÅ¿t day of the Moon will be altogether as good for that purpoÅ¿e as the laÅ¿t.â

Having thus conÅ¿ider'd the thing it Å¿elf, we may, in the laÅ¿t place, look into the AbÅ¿urdity of it: For indeed, how it is poÅ¿Å¿ible that one and the Å¿ame Influence of the Moon in one particular PoÅ¿ition, Å¿hould at the Å¿ame time affect Plants after Å¿uch a different manner, and produce in them quite contrary Effects.â'Twould be a rare Secret indeed, if the Moon Å¿hould hold an Intelligence with the Gard'ner, cauÅ¿ing Å¿ome of his Plants to Spring up apace, and hindering the Growth of others, juÅ¿t as he would have them.âNothing certainly would be of greater Advantage in the way of Gardening than this, if it were True; but Å¿ince nothing is more repugnant either to ReaÅ¿on or Experience; and that I hope Men will grow WiÅ¿er than to Trouble themÅ¿elves any longer about it, I Å¿hall Å¿pare my Å¿elf the Pains of expoÅ¿ing it any further.
